    <article class="post hentry" id="1088165176436431671" itemscope itemtype="http://schema.org/BlogPosting"> 
     <h1 class="post-title entry-title" itemprop="name headline"> AutoBrowser - Create Report and Screenshots of HTTP/s Based Ports on the Network  </h1> 
     <div class="post-header" style="position:absolute;left:-9999px"> 
      <div class="post-header-line-1"></div> 
     </div> 
     <div class="post-body entry-content" id="post-body-1088165176436431671" itemprop="articleBody"> 
      <div style="text-align: justify;">
        AutoBrowser is a tool written in python for penetration testers. The purpose of this tool is to create report and screenshots of http/s based ports on the network. It analyze Nmap Report or scan with Nmap, Check the results with http/s request on each host using headless web browser, Grab a screenshot of the response page content.
      </div> 
      <a name="more"></a>
      <ul> 
       <li style="text-align: justify;">This tool is designed for IT professionals to perform penetration testing to scan and analyze NMAP results.</li> 
      </ul> 
      <div> 
       <br>
      </div> 
      <b><span style="font-size: large;">Proof of concept video (From version: 2.0)</span></b>
      <br> 
      <div style="text-align: center;"> 
       <iframe allowfullscreen frameborder="0" height="360" src="https://www.youtube.com/embed/iiexvh3KLvE" width="640"></iframe>
      </div> 
      <br> 
      <b><span style="font-size: large;">Examples</span></b>
      <br> 
      <br> 
      <strong>Delimiting the values on the CLI arguments it must be by double quotes only!</strong>
      <br> 
      <ul> 
       <li>Get the argument details of <code>scan</code> method: <code>python AutoBrowser.py scan --help</code></li> 
       <li>Scan with Nmap and Checks the results and create folder by name project_name: <code>python AutoBrowser.py scan "192.168.1.1/24" -a="-sT -sV -T3" -p project_name</code></li> 
       <li>Get the argument details of <code>analyze</code> method: <code>python AutoBrowser.py analyze --help</code></li> 
       <li>Analyzing Nmap XML report and create folder by name report_analyze: <code>python AutoBrowser.py analyze nmap_file.xml --project report_analyze</code></li> 
      </ul> 
      <br> 
      <b><span style="font-size: large;">Requirements:</span></b>
      <br> 
      <br> 
      <b>Linux Installation:</b>
      <br> 
      <ol> 
       <li>sudo apt-get install python-pip python2.7-dev libxext-dev python-qt4 qt4-dev-tools build-essential nmap</li> 
       <li>sudo pip install -r requirements.txt</li> 
      </ol> 
      <br> 
      <b>MacOSx Installation:</b>
      <br> 
      <ol> 
       <li>Install Xcode Command Line Tools (AppStore)</li> 
       <li><code>ruby -e "$(curl -fsSL https://raw.github.com/mxcl/homebrew/go)"</code></li> 
       <li>brew install pyqt nmap</li> 
       <li>sudo easy_install pip</li> 
       <li>sudo pip install -r requirements.txt</li> 
      </ol> 
      <br> 
      <b>Windows Installation:</b>
      <br> 
      <ol> 
       <li>Install <a href="http://www.lfd.uci.edu/~gohlke/pythonlibs/#setuptools">setuptools</a></li> 
       <li>Install <a href="http://www.lfd.uci.edu/~gohlke/pythonlibs/#pip">pip</a></li> 
       <li>Install <a href="http://www.lfd.uci.edu/~gohlke/pythonlibs/#pyqt">PyQt4</a></li> 
       <li>install <a href="http://nmap.org/download.html">Nmap</a></li> 
       <li>Open Command Prompt(cmd) as Administrator -&gt; Goto python folder -&gt; Scripts (cd c:\Python27\Scripts)</li> 
       <li>pip install -r (Full Path To requirements.txt)</li> 
      </ol> 
      <br> 
      <br> 
      <div style="text-align: center;"> 
       <b><span style="font-size: x-large;"><a href="https://github.com/El3ct71k/AutoBrowser" target="_blank">Download AutoBrowser</a></span></b>
      </div> 
     </div>
    </article> 
    <article class="post hentry" id="8127270721329909285" itemscope itemtype="http://schema.org/BlogPosting"> 
     <h1 class="post-title entry-title" itemprop="name headline"> AutoReaver - Mutliple Access Point Targets Attack Using Reaver  </h1> 
     <div class="post-header" style="position:absolute;left:-9999px"> 
      <div class="post-header-line-1"></div> 
     </div> 
     <div class="post-body entry-content" id="post-body-8127270721329909285" itemprop="articleBody">
       AutoReaver&nbsp;is bash script which provides 
      <em>multiple access point attack</em> using 
      <em>reaver</em> and BSSIDs list from a text file.
      <br> 
      <br> If processed AP reaches rate limit, script goes to another from the list, and so forth.
      <br> 
      <a name="more"></a>
      <br> 
      <b><span style="font-size: large;">HOW IT WORKS ?</span></b>
      <br> Script takes AP targets list from text file in following format
      <br> 
      <pre><code>BSSID CHANNEL ESSID
</code></pre> For example:
      <br> 
      <pre><code>AA:BB:CC:DD:EE:FF 1 MyWlan 
00:BB:CC:DD:EE:FF 13 TpLink 
00:22:33:DD:EE:FF 13 MyHomeSSID
</code></pre> And then following steps are being processed:
      <br> 
      <ul class="task-list"> 
       <li>Every line of list file is checked separately in for loop</li> 
       <li>After every AP on the list once, script automatically changes MAC address of your card to random MAC using <em>macchanger</em> (you can also setup your own MAC if you need),</li> 
       <li>Whole list is checked again and again, in endless while loop, until there is nothing to check loop is stopped,</li> 
       <li>Found PINS/WPA PASSPHRASES are stored in {CRACKED_LIST_FILE_PATH} file.</li> 
      </ul> 
      <br> 
      <b><span style="font-size: large;">REQUIREMENTS</span></b>
      <br> 
      <ul class="task-list"> 
       <li>Wireless adapter which supports injection (see [<a href="https://code.google.com/p/reaver-wps/wiki/SupportedWirelessDrivers">https://code.google.com/p/reaver-wps/wiki/SupportedWirelessDrivers</a> Reaver Wiki])</li> 
       <li>Linux Backtrack 5 </li> 
       <li>Root access on your system (otherwise some things may not work)</li> 
       <li>AND if you use other Linux distribution* 
        <ul class="task-list"> 
         <li>Reaver 1.4 (I didn't try it with previous versions)</li> 
         <li>KDE (unless you'll change 'konsole' invocations to 'screen', 'gnome-terminal' or something like that... this is easy)</li> 
         <li>Gawk (Gnu AWK)</li> 
         <li>Macchanger</li> 
         <li>Airmon-ng, Airodump-ng, Aireplay-ng</li> 
         <li>Wash (WPS Service Scanner)</li> 
         <li>Perl</li> 
        </ul> </li> 
      </ul> 
      <br> 
      <b><span style="font-size: large;">USAGE EXAMPLE</span></b>
      <br> First you have to download lastest version
      <br> 
      <pre><code>git clone https://code.google.com/p/auto-reaver/</code></pre> Go to auto-reaver directory
      <br> 
      <pre><code>cd ./auto-reaver</code></pre> Make sure that scripts have 
      <em>x permissions</em> for your user, if not run
      <br> 
      <pre><code>chmod 700 ./washAutoReaver
chmod 700 ./autoReaver</code></pre> Run 
      <em>wash scanner</em> to make a formatted list of Access Points with 
      <em>WPS service enabled</em>
      <br> 
      <pre><code>./washAutoReaverList &gt; myAPTargets</code></pre> Wait for 1-2 minutes for 
      <em>wash</em> to collect APs, and hit 
      <em>CTRL+C</em> to kill the script. Check if any APs were detected
      <br> 
      <pre><code>cat ./myAPTargets</code></pre> If there are targets in 
      <em>myAPTargets</em> file, you can proceed attack, with following command:
      <br> 
      <pre><code>./autoReaver myAPTargets</code></pre> 
      <br> 
      <b><span style="font-size: large;">ADDITIONAL FEATURES</span></b>
      <br> 
      <ul class="task-list"> 
       <li>Script logs dates of PIN attempts, so you can check <em>how often AP is locked</em> and for how long. Default directory for those logs is <em>ReaverLastPinDates</em>.</li> 
       <li>Script logs each <em>AP rate limit</em> for every AP (default directory is <em>/tmp/APLimitBSSID</em>), so you can easily check when last <em>rate limit</em> occured</li> 
       <li>You can setup your attack using variables from <em>configurationSettings</em> file (sleep/wait times between AP`s and loops, etc.)</li> 
       <li>You can disable checking AP by adding "#" sign in the beginning of line, in <em>myAPTargets</em> file (then AP will be ommited in loop)</li> 
       <li> <em>(added 2014-07-03)</em> You can setup specific settings per access point.<br> To do that for AP with MAC <em>AA:BB:CC:DD:EE:FF</em>, just create file <em>./configurationSettingsPerAp/AABBCCDDEEFF</em><br> and put there variables from <em>./configurationSettings</em> file that you want to change for example:<br> <pre><code>ADDITIONAL_OPTIONS="-g 10 -E -S -N -T 1 -t 15 -d 0 -x 3";</code></pre> </li> 
      </ul> so 
      <em>AA:BB:CC:DD:EE:FF</em> will have only 
      <em>ADDITIONAL_OPTIONS</em> changed (rest of variables from 
      <em>./configurationSettings</em> file remains unchanged).
      <br> You can define channel as random by setting it's value (in myAPTargets file) to 
      <em>R</em>, you can force script to automatically find 
      <em>AP channel</em>.
      <br> Example: 
      <br> 
      <pre><code>AA:BB:CC:DD:EE:FF R MyWlan</code></pre> 
      <br> But remember that you probably should also increase value of 
      <code>BSSID_ONLINE_TIMEOUT</code> variable - since hopping between all channels takes much more time than searching on one channel.
      <br> 
      <br> 
      <br> 
      <div style="text-align: center;"> 
       <b><span style="font-size: x-large;"><a href="https://github.com/DominikStyp/auto-reaver" target="_blank">Download&nbsp;AutoReaver</a></span></b>
      </div> 
     </div>
    </article> 
    <article class="post hentry" id="3681769658479515541" itemscope itemtype="http://schema.org/BlogPosting"> 
     <h1 class="post-title entry-title" itemprop="name headline"> Autorize - Automatic Authorization Enforcement Detection (Extension for Burp Suite)  </h1> 
     <div class="post-header" style="position:absolute;left:-9999px"> 
      <div class="post-header-line-1"></div> 
     </div> 
     <div class="post-body entry-content" id="post-body-3681769658479515541" itemprop="articleBody"> 
      <div class="separator" style="clear: both; text-align: center;"> 
       <a href="http://1.bp.blogspot.com/-52Na9JxM0kY/VU5bCwXE38I/AAAAAAAAD_k/2VMyPrKKt_I/s1600/Autorize.png" imageanchor="1" style="margin-left: 1em; margin-right: 1em;"><img border="0" height="282" src="http://1.bp.blogspot.com/-52Na9JxM0kY/VU5bCwXE38I/AAAAAAAAD_k/2VMyPrKKt_I/s640/Autorize.png" width="640"></a>
      </div> 
      <br> 
      <div style="text-align: justify;">
        Autorize is an automatic authorization enforcement detection extension for Burp Suite. It was written in Python by Barak Tawily, an application security expert at AppSec Labs. Autorize was designed to help security testers by performing automatic authorization tests.
      </div> 
      <a name="more"></a>
      <br> 
      <div style="text-align: justify;"> 
       <b><span style="font-size: large;">Installation</span></b>
      </div> 
      <ol> 
       <li style="text-align: justify;"> Download Burp Suite (obviously): <a href="http://portswigger.net/burp/download.html">http://portswigger.net/burp/download.html</a> </li> 
       <li style="text-align: justify;"> Download Jython standalone JAR: <a href="http://www.jython.org/downloads.html">http://www.jython.org/downloads.html</a> </li> 
       <li style="text-align: justify;"> Open burp -&gt; Extender -&gt; Options -&gt; Python Environment -&gt; Select File -&gt; Choose the Jython standalone JAR</li> 
       <li style="text-align: justify;"> Install Autorize from the BApp Store or follow these steps:</li> 
       <li style="text-align: justify;"> Download the Autorize.py file.</li> 
       <li style="text-align: justify;"> Open Burp -&gt; Extender -&gt; Extensions -&gt; Add -&gt; Choose Autorize.py file.</li> 
       <li style="text-align: justify;"> See the Autorize tab and enjoy automatic authorization detection :)</li> 
      </ol> 
      <div style="text-align: justify;"> 
       <br>
      </div> 
      <div style="text-align: justify;"> 
       <b><span style="font-size: large;">User Guide - How to use?</span></b>
      </div> 
      <ol> 
       <li style="text-align: justify;"> After installation, the Autorize tab will be added to Burp.</li> 
       <li style="text-align: justify;"> Open the configuration tab (Autorize -&gt; Configuration).</li> 
       <li style="text-align: justify;"> Get your low-privileged user authorization token header (Cookie / Authorization) and copy it into the textbox containing the text "Insert injected header here".</li> 
       <li style="text-align: justify;"> Click on "Intercept is off" to start intercepting the traffic in order to allow Autorize to check for authorization enforcement.</li> 
       <li style="text-align: justify;"> Open a browser and configure the proxy settings so the traffic will be passed to Burp.</li> 
       <li style="text-align: justify;"> Browse to the application you want to test with a high privileged user.</li> 
       <li style="text-align: justify;"> The Autorize table will show you the request's URL and enforcement status.</li> 
       <li style="text-align: justify;"> It is possible to click on a specific URL and see the original/modified request/response in order to investigate the differences.</li> 
      </ol> 
      <div style="text-align: justify;"> 
       <br>
      </div> 
      <div style="text-align: justify;"> 
       <b><span style="font-size: large;">Authorization Enforcement Status</span></b>
      </div> 
      <div style="text-align: justify;"> 
       <br>
      </div> 
      <div style="text-align: justify;">
        There are 3 enforcement statuses:
      </div> 
      <ol> 
       <li style="text-align: justify;">Authorization bypass! - Red color</li> 
       <li style="text-align: justify;">Authorization enforced! - Green color</li> 
       <li style="text-align: justify;">Authorization enforced??? (please configure enforcement detector) - Yellow color</li> 
      </ol> 
      <div style="text-align: justify;">
        The first 2 statuses are clear, so I won’t elaborate on them.
      </div> 
      <div style="text-align: justify;">
        The 3rd status means that Autorize cannot determine if authorization is enforced or not, and so Autorize will ask you to configure a filter in the enforcement detector tab.
      </div> 
      <div style="text-align: justify;">
        The enforcement detector filters will allow Autorize to detect authorization enforcement by fingerprint (string in the message body) or content-length in the server's response.
      </div> 
      <div style="text-align: justify;"> 
       <br>
      </div> 
      <div style="text-align: justify;">
        For example, if there is a request enforcement status that is detected as "Authorization enforced??? (please configure enforcement detector)" it is possible to investigate the modified/original response and see that the modified response body includes the string "You are not authorized to perform action", so you can add a filter with the fingerprint value "You are not authorized to perform action", so Autorize will look for this fingerprint and will automatically detect that authorization is enforced. It is possible to do the same by defining content-length filter.
       <br> 
       <br> 
       <br> 
       <div style="text-align: center;"> 
        <b><span style="font-size: x-large;"><a href="https://github.com/Quitten/Autorize" target="_blank">Download&nbsp;Autorize</a></span></b>
       </div> 
      </div> 
     </div>
    </article> 
    <article class="post hentry" id="6004053098735964563" itemscope itemtype="http://schema.org/BlogPosting"> 
     <h1 class="post-title entry-title" itemprop="name headline"> AVCaesar - Malware Analysis Engine and Repository  </h1> 
     <div class="post-header" style="position:absolute;left:-9999px"> 
      <div class="post-header-line-1"></div> 
     </div> 
     <div class="post-body entry-content" id="post-body-6004053098735964563" itemprop="articleBody"> 
      <div class="separator" style="clear: both; text-align: center;"> 
       <a href="http://3.bp.blogspot.com/-njQxT-i3ODU/VQY0EM7L2fI/AAAAAAAADzE/cncn0vz4TSs/s1600/AVCaesar.png" imageanchor="1" style="margin-left: 1em; margin-right: 1em;"><img border="0" src="http://3.bp.blogspot.com/-njQxT-i3ODU/VQY0EM7L2fI/AAAAAAAADzE/cncn0vz4TSs/s1600/AVCaesar.png"></a>
      </div> 
      <br> 
      <div style="text-align: justify;">
        AVCaesar is a malware analysis engine and repository, developed by malware.lu within the FP7 project CockpitCI.
      </div> 
      <a name="more"></a>
      <br> 
      <b><span class="Apple-style-span" style="font-size: large;">Functionalities </span></b>
      <br> 
      <br> 
      <div style="text-align: justify;">
        AVCaesar can be used to:
      </div> 
      <ul> 
       <li style="text-align: justify;">Perform an efficient malware analysis of suspicious files based on the results of a set of antivirus solutions, bundled together to reach the highest possible probability to detect potential malware;</li> 
       <li style="text-align: justify;">Search for malware samples in a progressively increasing malware repository.</li> 
      </ul> 
      <div style="text-align: justify;">
        The basic functionalities can be extended by:
      </div> 
      <ul> 
       <li style="text-align: justify;">Download malware samples (15 samples/day for registered users and 100 samples/day for premium users);</li> 
       <li style="text-align: justify;">Perform confidential malware analysis (reserved to premium users)</li> 
      </ul> 
      <br> 
      <b><span class="Apple-style-span" style="font-size: large;">Malware analysis process </span></b>
      <br> 
      <br> 
      <div style="text-align: justify;">
        The malware analysis process is kept as easy and intuitive as possible for AVCaesar users:
      </div> 
      <ul> 
       <li style="text-align: justify;">Submit suspicious file via AVCaesar web interface. Premium users can choose to perform a confidential analysis.</li> 
       <li style="text-align: justify;">Receive a well-structured malware analysis report.</li> 
      </ul> 
      <div> 
       <br>
      </div> 
      <div class="separator" style="clear: both; text-align: center;"> 
       <a href="http://4.bp.blogspot.com/-C8gfUwzkA2s/VQY0QGIyZuI/AAAAAAAADzM/MpFuKMR27rk/s1600/product_workflow.png" imageanchor="1" style="margin-left: 1em; margin-right: 1em;"><img border="0" src="http://4.bp.blogspot.com/-C8gfUwzkA2s/VQY0QGIyZuI/AAAAAAAADzM/MpFuKMR27rk/s1600/product_workflow.png" height="640" width="343"></a>
      </div> 
      <div> 
       <br> 
       <br>
      </div> 
      <div> 
       <div style="text-align: center;"> 
        <b><span class="Apple-style-span" style="font-size: x-large;"><a href="https://avcaesar.malware.lu/" target="_blank">AVCaesar - Malware Analysis Engine and Repository</a></span></b>
       </div> 
      </div> 
     </div>
    </article> 
    <article class="post hentry" id="5404526798437337295" itemscope itemtype="http://schema.org/BlogPosting"> 
     <h1 class="post-title entry-title" itemprop="name headline"> B374K - PHP Webshell with handy features  </h1> 
     <div class="post-header" style="position:absolute;left:-9999px"> 
      <div class="post-header-line-1"></div> 
     </div> 
     <div class="post-body entry-content" id="post-body-5404526798437337295" itemprop="articleBody"> 
      <div class="separator" style="clear: both; text-align: center;"> 
       <a href="http://2.bp.blogspot.com/-ZGfuhoWsugg/ViB_FwrezBI/AAAAAAAAEtg/ISl6D-gb1mI/s1600/B374K.jpg" imageanchor="1" style="margin-left: 1em; margin-right: 1em;"><img border="0" height="306" src="http://2.bp.blogspot.com/-ZGfuhoWsugg/ViB_FwrezBI/AAAAAAAAEtg/ISl6D-gb1mI/s640/B374K.jpg" width="640"></a>
      </div> 
      <br> 
      <div style="text-align: justify;">
        This PHP Shell is a useful tool for system or web administrator to do remote management without using cpanel, connecting using ssh, ftp etc. All actions take place within a web browser.
      </div> 
      <a name="more"></a>
      <br> 
      <div style="text-align: justify;"> 
       <b><span style="font-size: large;">Features : </span></b>
      </div> 
      <ul> 
       <li style="text-align: justify;"> File manager (view, edit, rename, delete, upload, download, archiver, etc) </li> 
       <li style="text-align: justify;"> Search file, file content, folder (also using regex) </li> 
       <li style="text-align: justify;"> Command execution </li> 
       <li style="text-align: justify;"> Script execution (php, perl, python, ruby, java, node.js, c) </li> 
       <li style="text-align: justify;"> Give you shell via bind/reverse shell connect </li> 
       <li style="text-align: justify;"> Simple packet crafter </li> 
       <li style="text-align: justify;"> Connect to DBMS (mysql, mssql, oracle, sqlite, postgresql, and many more using ODBC or PDO) </li> 
       <li style="text-align: justify;"> SQL Explorer </li> 
       <li style="text-align: justify;"> Process list/Task manager </li> 
       <li style="text-align: justify;"> Send mail with attachment (you can attach local file on server) </li> 
       <li style="text-align: justify;"> String conversion </li> 
       <li style="text-align: justify;"> All of that only in 1 file, no installation needed </li> 
       <li style="text-align: justify;"> Support PHP &gt; 4.3.3 and PHP 5 </li> 
      </ul> 
      <br> 
      <span style="font-size: large;"> <b> Requirements : </b> </span> 
      <br> 
      <ul> 
       <li> PHP version &gt; 4.3.3 and PHP 5 </li> 
       <li> As it using zepto.js v1.1.2, you need modern browser to use b374k shell. See browser support on zepto.js website <a href="http://zeptojs.com/" target="_blank"> http://zeptojs.com/ </a> </li> 
       <li> Responsibility of what you do with this shell </li> 
      </ul> 
      <br> 
      <span style="font-size: large;"> <b> Installation : </b> </span> 
      <br> Download b374k.php (default password : b374k), edit and change password and upload b374k.php to your server, password is in sha1(md5()) format. Or create your own b374k.php, explained below 
      <br> 
      <br> 
      <span style="font-size: large;"> <b> Customize : </b> </span> 
      <br> After finished doing editing with files, upload index.php, base, module, theme and all files inside it to a server 
      <br> Using Web Browser : 
      <br> Open index.php in your browser, quick run will only run the shell. Use packer to pack all files into single PHP file. Set all the options available and the output file will be in the same directory as index.php 
      <br> Using Console : 
      <br> 
      <pre><code>$ php -f index.php
b374k shell packer 0.4

options :
        -o filename                             save as filename
        -p password                             protect with password
        -t theme                                theme to use
        -m modules                              modules to pack separated by comma
        -s                                      strip comments and whitespaces
        -b                                      encode with base64
        -z [no|gzdeflate|gzencode|gzcompress]   compression (use only with -b)
        -c [0-9]                                level of compression
        -l                                      list available modules
        -k                                      list available themes
</code></pre> example : 
      <br> 
      <pre><code>$ php -f index.php -- -o myShell.php -p myPassword -s -b -z gzcompress -c 9
</code></pre> Don't forget to delete index.php, base, module, theme and all files inside it after you finished. Because it is not protected with password so it can be a security threat to your server
      <br> 
      <br> 
      <br> 
      <div style="text-align: center;"> 
       <b><span style="font-size: x-large;"><a href="https://github.com/b374k/b374k" target="_blank">Download B374K</a></span></b>
      </div> 
     </div>
    </article> 
    <article class="post hentry" id="6829362136717549933" itemscope itemtype="http://schema.org/BlogPosting"> 
     <h1 class="post-title entry-title" itemprop="name headline"> Babun - A Windows shell you will love!  </h1> 
     <div class="post-header" style="position:absolute;left:-9999px"> 
      <div class="post-header-line-1"></div> 
     </div> 
     <div class="post-body entry-content" id="post-body-6829362136717549933" itemprop="articleBody"> 
      <div class="separator" style="clear: both; text-align: center;"> 
       <a href="http://4.bp.blogspot.com/-P5BS2wCMp6M/VZ06mjVdnqI/AAAAAAAAEUs/F72KKjKmsJs/s1600/babun.png" imageanchor="1" style="margin-left: 1em; margin-right: 1em;"><img border="0" height="370" src="http://4.bp.blogspot.com/-P5BS2wCMp6M/VZ06mjVdnqI/AAAAAAAAEUs/F72KKjKmsJs/s640/babun.png" width="640"></a>
      </div> 
      <br> Would you like to use a linux-like console on a Windows host without a lot of fuzz? Try out babun!
      <br> 
      <a name="more"></a>
      <br> 
      <b><span style="font-size: large;"> Installation</span></b>
      <br> 
      <br> 
      <div> 
       <div>
         Just download the dist file from 
        <a href="http://babun.github.io/">http://babun.github.io</a>, unzip it and run the install.bat script. After a few minutes babun starts automatically. The application will be installed to the 
        <code>%USER_HOME%\.babun</code> directory. Use the 
        <em>/target</em> option to install babun to a custom directory.
        <br> 
        <br> 
        <b><span style="font-size: large;"> Features in 10 seconds</span></b>
        <br> 
        <br> 
        <div> 
         <div>
           Babun features the following:
         </div> 
         <div> 
          <ul> 
           <li> Pre-configured Cygwin with a lot of addons<br> </li> 
           <li> Silent command-line installer, no admin rights required<br> </li> 
           <li> pact - advanced package manager (like apt-get or yum)<br> </li> 
           <li> xTerm-256 compatible console<br> </li> 
           <li> HTTP(s) proxying support<br> </li> 
           <li> Plugin-oriented architecture<br> </li> 
           <li> Pre-configured git and shell<br> </li> 
           <li> Integrated oh-my-zsh<br> </li> 
           <li> Auto update feature<br> </li> 
           <li> "Open Babun Here" context menu entry<br> </li> 
          </ul> 
          <div> 
           <br>
          </div> 
         </div> 
        </div> 
       </div> 
      </div> 
      <div> 
       <div> 
        <b><span style="font-size: large;"> Features in 3 minutes</span></b>
        <br> 
        <br> 
        <div> 
         <div> 
          <b> Cygwin</b>
          <br> 
          <br> 
          <div>
            The core of Babun consists of a pre-configured Cygwin. Cygwin is a great tool, but there’s a lot of quirks and tricks that makes you lose a lot of time to make it actually 
           <em>usable</em>. Not only does babun solve most of these problems, but also contains a lot of vital packages, so that you can be productive from the very first minute.
          </div> 
         </div> 
         <div> 
          <br> 
          <b> Package manager</b>
          <br> 
          <br> 
          <div>
            Babun provides a package manager called 
           <code>pact</code>. It is similar to 
           <em>apt-get</em> or 
           <em>yum</em>. Pact enables installing/searching/upgrading and deinstalling cygwin packages with no hassle at all. Just invoke 
           <code>pact --help</code> to check how to use it.
          </div> 
         </div> 
         <div> 
          <br> 
          <b> Shell</b>
          <br> 
          <br> 
          <div>
            Babun’s shell is tweaked in order to provide the best possible user-experience. There are two shell types that are pre-configured and available right away - bash and zsh (zsh is the default one). Babun’s shell features:
          </div> 
          <div> 
           <ul> 
            <li> syntax highlighting<br> </li> 
            <li> UNIX tools<br> </li> 
            <li> software development tools<br> </li> 
            <li> git-aware prompt<br> </li> 
            <li> custom scripts and aliases<br> </li> 
            <li> and much more!<br> </li> 
           </ul> 
          </div> 
         </div> 
         <div> 
          <br> 
          <b> Console</b>
          <br> 
          <br> 
          <div>
            Mintty is the console used in babun. It features an 
           <code>xterm-256</code> mode, nice fonts and simply looks great!
          </div> 
         </div> 
         <div> 
          <br> 
          <b> Proxying</b>
          <br> 
          <br> 
          <div>
            Babun supports HTTP proxying out of the box. Just add the address and the credentials of your HTTP proxy server to the 
           <code>.babunrc</code> file located in your home folder and execute 
           <code>source .babunrc</code> to enable HTTP proxying. SOCKS proxies are not supported for now.
          </div> 
         </div> 
         <div> 
          <br> 
          <b> Developer tools</b>
          <br> 
          <br> 
          <div>
            Babun provides many packages, convenience tools and scripts that make your life much easier. The long list of features includes:
          </div> 
          <div> 
           <ul> 
            <li> programming languages (Python, Perl, etc.)<br> </li> 
            <li> git (with a wide variety of aliases and tweaks)<br> </li> 
            <li> UNIX tools (grep, wget, curl, etc.)<br> </li> 
            <li> vcs (svn, git)<br> </li> 
            <li> oh-my-zsh<br> </li> 
            <li> custom scripts (pbcopy, pbpaste, babun, etc.)<br> </li> 
           </ul> 
          </div> 
         </div> 
         <div> 
          <br> 
          <b> Plugin architecture</b>
          <br> 
          <br> 
          <div>
            Babun has a very small microkernel (cygwin, a couple of bash scripts and a bit of a convention) and a plugin architecture on the top of it. It means that almost everything is a plugin in the babun’s world! Not only does it structure babun in a clean way, but also enables others to contribute small chunks of code. Currently, babun comprises the following plugins:
          </div> 
          <div> 
           <ul> 
            <li> cacert<br> </li> 
            <li> core<br> </li> 
            <li> git<br> </li> 
            <li> oh-my-zsh<br> </li> 
            <li> pact<br> </li> 
            <li> cygdrive<br> </li> 
            <li> dist<br> </li> 
            <li> shell<br> </li> 
           </ul> 
          </div> 
         </div> 
         <div> 
          <br> 
          <b> Auto-update</b>
          <br> 
          <br> 
          <div>
            Self-update is at the very heart of babun! Many Cygwin tools are simple bash scripts - once you install them there is no chance of getting the newer version in a smooth way. You either delete the older version or overwrite it with the newest one losing all the changes you have made in between.
          </div> 
          <div>
            Babun contains an auto-update feature which enables updating both the microkernel, the plugins and even the underlying cygwin. Files located in your home folder will never be deleted nor overwritten which preserves your local config and customizations.
          </div> 
         </div> 
         <div> 
          <br> 
          <b> Installer</b>
          <br> 
          <br> 
          <div>
            Babun features an silent command-line installation script that may be executed without admin rights on any Windows hosts.
          </div> 
         </div> 
        </div> 
       </div> 
       <div> 
        <br> 
        <b><span style="font-size: large;"> Using babun</span></b>
        <br> 
        <br> 
        <div> 
         <div> 
          <b> Setting up proxy</b>
          <br> 
          <br> 
          <div>
            To setup proxy uncomment following lines in the 
           <code>.babunrc</code> file 
           <code>(%USER_HOME%\.babun\cygwin\home\USER\.babunrc)</code>
          </div> 
          <div> 
           <div> 
            <pre><code># Uncomment this lines to set up your proxy
# export http_proxy=http://user:<a href="/cdn-cgi/l/email-protection" class="__cf_email__" data-cfemail="67170614141008150327140215110215">[email&nbsp;protected]</a>:port
# export https_proxy=$http_proxy
# export ftp_proxy=$http_proxy
# export no_proxy=localhost</code></pre> 
           </div> 
          </div> 
         </div> 
         <div> 
          <br> 
          <b> Setting up git</b>
          <br> 
          <br> 
          <div>
            Babun has a pre-configured git. The only thing you should do after the installation is to add your name and email to the git config:
          </div> 
          <div> 
           <div> 
            <pre><code>git config --global user.name "your name"
git config --global user.email "<a href="/cdn-cgi/l/email-protection" class="__cf_email__" data-cfemail="9fe6f0eaeddffaf2fef6f3b1fcf0f2">[email&nbsp;protected]</a>"</code></pre> 
           </div> 
          </div> 
          <div>
            There’s a lot of great git aliases provided by the git plugin:
          </div> 
          <div> 
           <div> 
            <pre><code>gitalias['alias.cp']='cherry-pick'
gitalias['alias.st']='status -sb'
gitalias['alias.cl']='clone'
gitalias['alias.ci']='commit'
gitalias['alias.co']='checkout'
gitalias['alias.br']='branch'
gitalias['alias.dc']='diff --cached'
gitalias['alias.lg']="log --graph --pretty=format:'%Cred%h%Creset -%C(yellow)%d%Creset %s %Cgreen(%cr) %Cblue&lt;%an&gt;%Creset' --abbrev-commit --date=relative --all"
gitalias['alias.last']='log -1 --stat'
gitalias['alias.unstage']='reset HEAD --'</code></pre> 
           </div> 
          </div> 
         </div> 
         <div> 
          <br> 
          <b> Installing and removing packages</b>
          <br> 
          <br> 
          <div>
            Babun is shipped with 
           <code>pact</code> - a Linux like package manager. It uses the cygwin repository for downloading packages:
          </div> 
          <div> 
           <div> 
            <pre><code>{ ~ } » pact install arj                                                                     ~
Working directory is /setup
Mirror is http://mirrors.kernel.org/sourceware/cygwin/
setup.ini taken from the cache

Installing arj
Found package arj
--2014-03-30 19:34:38--  http://mirrors.kernel.org/sourceware/cygwin//x86/release/arj/arj-3.10.22-1.tar.bz2
Resolving mirrors.kernel.org (mirrors.kernel.org)... 149.20.20.135, 149.20.4.71, 2001:4f8:1:10:0:1994:3:14, ...
Connecting to mirrors.kernel.org (mirrors.kernel.org)|149.20.20.135|:80... connected.
HTTP request sent, awaiting response... 200 OK
Length: 189944 (185K) [application/x-bzip2]
Saving to: `arj-3.10.22-1.tar.bz2'

100%[=======================================&gt;] 189,944      193K/s   in 1.0s

2014-03-30 19:34:39 (193 KB/s) - `arj-3.10.22-1.tar.bz2' saved [189944/189944]

Unpacking...
Package arj installed</code></pre> 
           </div> 
          </div> 
          <div>
            Here’s the list of all pact’s features:
          </div> 
          <div> 
           <div> 
            <pre><code>{ ~ }  » pact --help
pact: Installs and removes Cygwin packages.

Usage:
  "pact install &lt;package names&gt;" to install given packages
  "pact remove &lt;package names&gt;" to remove given packages
  "pact update &lt;package names&gt;" to update given packages
  "pact show" to show installed packages
  "pact find &lt;patterns&gt;" to find packages matching patterns
  "pact describe &lt;patterns&gt;" to describe packages matching patterns
  "pact packageof &lt;commands or files&gt;" to locate parent packages
  "pact invalidate" to invalidate pact caches (setup.ini, etc.)
Options:
  --mirror, -m &lt;url&gt; : set mirror
  --invalidate, -i       : invalidates pact caches (setup.ini, etc.)
  --force, -f : force the execution
  --help
  --version</code></pre> 
           </div> 
          </div> 
         </div> 
         <div> 
          <br> 
          <b> Changing the default shell</b>
          <br> 
          <br> 
          <div>
            The zsh (with .oh-my-zsh) is the default babun’s shell.
          </div> 
          <div>
            Executing the following command will output your default shell:
          </div> 
          <div> 
           <div> 
            <pre><code>{ ~ } » babun shell                                                                          ~
/bin/zsh</code></pre> 
           </div> 
          </div> 
          <div>
            In order to change your default shell execute:
          </div> 
          <div> 
           <div> 
            <pre><code>{ ~ } » babun shell /bin/bash                                                                ~
/bin/zsh
/bin/bash</code></pre> 
           </div> 
          </div> 
          <div>
            The output contains two lines: the previous default shell and the new default shell
          </div> 
         </div> 
         <div> 
          <br> 
          <b> Checking the configuration</b>
          <br> 
          <br> 
          <div>
            Execute the following command the check the configuration:
          </div> 
          <div> 
           <div> 
            <pre><code>{ ~ }  » babun check                                                                         ~
Executing babun check
Prompt speed      [OK]
Connection check  [OK]
Update check      [OK]
Cygwin check      [OK]</code></pre> 
           </div> 
          </div> 
          <div>
            By executing this command you can also check whether there is a newer cygwin version available:
          </div> 
          <div> 
           <div> 
            <pre><code>{ ~ }  » babun check                                                                            ~
Executing babun check
Prompt speed      [OK]
Connection check  [OK]
Update check      [OK]
Cygwin check      [OUTDATED]
Hint: the underlying Cygwin kernel is outdated. Execute 'babun update' and follow the instructions!</code></pre> 
           </div> 
          </div> 
          <div>
            It will check if there are problems with the speed of the git prompt, if there’s access to the Internet or finally if you are running the newest version of babun.
          </div> 
          <div>
            The command will output hints if problems occur:
          </div> 
          <div> 
           <div> 
            <pre><code>{ ~ } » babun check                                                                          ~
Executing babun check
Prompt speed      [SLOW]
Hint: your prompt is very slow. Check the installed 'BLODA' software.
Connection check  [OK]
Update check      [OK]
Cygwin check      [OK]</code></pre> 
           </div> 
          </div> 
          <div>
            On each startup, but only every 24 hours, babun will execute this check automatically. You can disable the automatic check in the ~/.babunrc file.
          </div> 
         </div> 
         <div> 
          <br> 
          <b> Tweaking the configuration</b>
          <br> 
          <br> 
          <div>
            You can tweak some config options in the ~/.babunrc file. Here’s the full list of variables that may be modified:
          </div> 
          <div> 
           <div> 
            <pre><code># JVM options
export JAVA_OPTS="-Xms128m -Xmx256m"

# Modify these lines to set your locale
export LANG="en_US.UTF-8"
export LC_CTYPE="en_US.UTF-8"
export LC_ALL="en_US.UTF-8"

# Uncomment these lines to the set your machine's default locale (and comment out the UTF-8 ones)
# export LANG=$(locale -uU)
# export LC_CTYPE=$(locale -uU)
# export LC_ALL=$(locale -uU)

# Uncomment this to disable daily auto-update &amp; proxy checks on startup (not recommended!)
# export DISABLE_CHECK_ON_STARTUP="true"

# Uncomment to increase/decrease the check connection timeout
# export CHECK_TIMEOUT_IN_SECS=4

# Uncomment this lines to set up your proxy
# export http_proxy=http://user:<a href="/cdn-cgi/l/email-protection" class="__cf_email__" data-cfemail="c9b9a8bababea6bbad89baacbbbfacbb">[email&nbsp;protected]</a>:port
# export https_proxy=$http_proxy
# export ftp_proxy=$http_proxy
# export no_proxy=localhost</code></pre> 
           </div> 
          </div> 
         </div> 
         <div> 
          <br> 
          <b> Updating babun</b>
          <br> 
          <br> 
          <div>
            To update babun to the newest version execute:
          </div> 
          <div> 
           <div> 
            <pre><code>babun update</code></pre> 
           </div> 
          </div> 
          <div>
            Please note that your local configuration files will not be overwritten.
          </div> 
          <div>
            The 
           <em>babun update</em> command will also update the underlying cygwin version if never version is available. In such case babun will download the new cygwin installer, close itself and start the cygwin installation process. Once cygwin installation is completed babun will restart.
          </div> 
         </div> 
        </div> 
       </div> 
       <div> 
        <br> 
        <b><span style="font-size: large;"> Screenshots</span></b>
        <br> 
        <br> 
        <div> 
         <div> 
          <b>Startup screen</b>
         </div> 
         <div> 
          <div> 
           <br>
          </div> 
          <div class="separator" style="clear: both; text-align: center;"> 
           <a href="http://4.bp.blogspot.com/-16kem8EgHJs/VZ07-KmP37I/AAAAAAAAEU4/lKMCP6UD5-o/s1600/babun_01.png" imageanchor="1" style="margin-left: 1em; margin-right: 1em;"><img border="0" height="377" src="http://4.bp.blogspot.com/-16kem8EgHJs/VZ07-KmP37I/AAAAAAAAEU4/lKMCP6UD5-o/s640/babun_01.png" width="640"></a>
          </div> 
          <div> 
           <br>
          </div> 
         </div> 
         <div> 
          <b>Pact - package installation</b>
         </div> 
         <div> 
          <div> 
           <br>
          </div> 
          <div class="separator" style="clear: both; text-align: center;"> 
           <a href="http://2.bp.blogspot.com/-RYzLMudWIe0/VZ08ILNNVWI/AAAAAAAAEVA/Wp5bEk9Y64g/s1600/babun_02.png" imageanchor="1" style="margin-left: 1em; margin-right: 1em;"><img border="0" height="372" src="http://2.bp.blogspot.com/-RYzLMudWIe0/VZ08ILNNVWI/AAAAAAAAEVA/Wp5bEk9Y64g/s640/babun_02.png" width="640"></a>
          </div> 
          <div> 
           <br>
          </div> 
         </div> 
         <div> 
          <b>Pact - package installed</b>
         </div> 
         <div> 
          <div> 
           <br>
          </div> 
          <div class="separator" style="clear: both; text-align: center;"> 
           <a href="http://3.bp.blogspot.com/-hgkFXIVMKmc/VZ08N_3WwOI/AAAAAAAAEVI/awzmPVwGPik/s1600/babun_03.png" imageanchor="1" style="margin-left: 1em; margin-right: 1em;"><img border="0" height="370" src="http://3.bp.blogspot.com/-hgkFXIVMKmc/VZ08N_3WwOI/AAAAAAAAEVI/awzmPVwGPik/s640/babun_03.png" width="640"></a>
          </div> 
          <div> 
           <br>
          </div> 
         </div> 
         <div> 
          <b>Babun oh-my-zsh - auto-update</b>
         </div> 
         <div> 
          <div> 
           <br>
          </div> 
          <div class="separator" style="clear: both; text-align: center;"> 
           <a href="http://3.bp.blogspot.com/-eEyLmtq_2X0/VZ08UdRrswI/AAAAAAAAEVQ/BieRGSwwvvg/s1600/babun_04.png" imageanchor="1" style="margin-left: 1em; margin-right: 1em;"><img border="0" height="450" src="http://3.bp.blogspot.com/-eEyLmtq_2X0/VZ08UdRrswI/AAAAAAAAEVQ/BieRGSwwvvg/s640/babun_04.png" width="640"></a>
          </div> 
          <div> 
           <br>
          </div> 
         </div>
