    <article class="post hentry" id="4082726728281941356" itemscope itemtype="http://schema.org/BlogPosting"> 
     <h1 class="post-title entry-title" itemprop="name headline"> BackBox Linux 4.2 - Ubuntu-based Linux Distribution Penetration Test and Security Assessment  </h1> 
     <div class="post-header" style="position:absolute;left:-9999px"> 
      <div class="post-header-line-1"></div> 
     </div> 
     <div class="post-body entry-content" id="post-body-4082726728281941356" itemprop="articleBody"> 
      <div class="separator" style="clear: both; text-align: center;"> 
       <a href="http://2.bp.blogspot.com/-GFlt6aEje3k/VT6jcEoPenI/AAAAAAAAD68/3Kgfeq1naz8/s1600/BackBox%2BLinux.png" imageanchor="1" style="margin-left: 1em; margin-right: 1em;"><img border="0" src="http://2.bp.blogspot.com/-GFlt6aEje3k/VT6jcEoPenI/AAAAAAAAD68/3Kgfeq1naz8/s1600/BackBox%2BLinux.png" height="474" width="640"></a>
      </div> 
      <br> 
      <div style="text-align: justify;">
        BackBox is a Linux distribution based on Ubuntu. It has been developed to perform penetration tests and security assessments. Designed to be fast, easy to use and provide a minimal yet complete desktop environment, thanks to its own software repositories, always being updated to the latest stable version of the most used and best known ethical hacking tools.
      </div> 
      <a name="more"></a>
      <br> 
      <div style="text-align: justify;">
        The BackBox Team is pleased to announce the updated release of BackBox Linux, the version 4.2! This release includes features such as Linux Kernel 3.16 and Ruby 2.1.
      </div> 
      <div style="text-align: justify;"> 
       <br>
      </div> 
      <div style="text-align: justify;"> 
       <strong>What's new</strong>
      </div> 
      <ul> 
       <li style="text-align: justify;">Preinstalled Linux Kernel 3.16</li> 
       <li style="text-align: justify;">New Ubuntu 14.04.2 base</li> 
       <li style="text-align: justify;">Ruby 2.1</li> 
       <li style="text-align: justify;">Installer with LVM and Full Disk Encryption options</li> 
       <li style="text-align: justify;">Handy Thunar custom actions</li> 
       <li style="text-align: justify;">RAM wipe at shutdown/reboot</li> 
       <li style="text-align: justify;">System improvements</li> 
       <li style="text-align: justify;">Upstream components</li> 
       <li style="text-align: justify;">Bug corrections</li> 
       <li style="text-align: justify;">Performance boost</li> 
       <li style="text-align: justify;">Improved Anonymous mode</li> 
       <li style="text-align: justify;">Predisposition to ARM architecture (armhf Debian packages)</li> 
       <li style="text-align: justify;">Predisposition to BackBox Cloud platform</li> 
       <li style="text-align: justify;">New and updated hacking tools: beef-project, crunch, fang, galleta, jd-gui, metasploit-framework, pasco, pyew, rifiuti2, setoolkit, theharvester, tor, torsocks, volatility, weevely, whatweb, wpscan, xmount, yara, zaproxy</li> 
      </ul> 
      <div style="text-align: justify;"> 
       <strong>System requirements</strong>
      </div> 
      <ul> 
       <li style="text-align: justify;">32-bit or 64-bit processor</li> 
       <li style="text-align: justify;">512 MB of system memory (RAM)</li> 
       <li style="text-align: justify;">6 GB of disk space for installation</li> 
       <li style="text-align: justify;">Graphics card capable of 800×600 resolution</li> 
       <li style="text-align: justify;">DVD-ROM drive or USB port (2 GB)</li> 
      </ul> 
      <div style="text-align: justify;"> 
       <br>
      </div> 
      <div style="text-align: center;"> 
       <b><span style="font-size: x-large;"><a href="http://backbox.org/downloads" target="_blank">Download&nbsp;BackBox Linux 4.2</a></span></b>
      </div> 
     </div>
    </article> 
    <article class="post hentry" id="3396073119433518339" itemscope itemtype="http://schema.org/BlogPosting"> 
     <h1 class="post-title entry-title" itemprop="name headline"> BackBox Linux 4.3 - Ubuntu-based Linux Distribution Penetration Test and Security Assessment  </h1> 
     <div class="post-header" style="position:absolute;left:-9999px"> 
      <div class="post-header-line-1"></div> 
     </div> 
     <div class="post-body entry-content" id="post-body-3396073119433518339" itemprop="articleBody"> 
      <div class="separator" style="clear: both; text-align: center;"> 
       <a href="http://1.bp.blogspot.com/-K80kqcSmyVY/VbJ8FVn9y3I/AAAAAAAAEbE/TcARin01Ewg/s1600/BackBox_Linux_4.3.png" imageanchor="1" style="margin-left: 1em; margin-right: 1em;"><img border="0" height="474" src="http://1.bp.blogspot.com/-K80kqcSmyVY/VbJ8FVn9y3I/AAAAAAAAEbE/TcARin01Ewg/s640/BackBox_Linux_4.3.png" width="640"></a>
      </div> 
      <br> 
      <div style="text-align: justify;">
        BackBox is a Linux distribution based on Ubuntu. It has been developed to perform penetration tests and security assessments. Designed to be fast, easy to use and provide a minimal yet complete desktop environment, thanks to its own software repositories, always being updated to the latest stable version of the most used and best known ethical hacking tools.
      </div> 
      <a name="more"></a>
      <br> 
      <div style="text-align: justify;"> 
       <strong><span style="font-size: large;">What's new</span></strong>
      </div> 
      <ul> 
       <li style="text-align: justify;">Preinstalled Linux Kernel 3.16</li> 
       <li style="text-align: justify;">New Ubuntu 14.04.2 base</li> 
       <li style="text-align: justify;">Ruby 2.1</li> 
       <li style="text-align: justify;">Installer with LVM and Full Disk Encryption options</li> 
       <li style="text-align: justify;">Handy Thunar custom actions</li> 
       <li style="text-align: justify;">RAM wipe at shutdown/reboot</li> 
       <li style="text-align: justify;">System improvements</li> 
       <li style="text-align: justify;">Upstream components</li> 
       <li style="text-align: justify;">Bug corrections</li> 
       <li style="text-align: justify;">Performance boost</li> 
       <li style="text-align: justify;">Improved Anonymous mode</li> 
       <li style="text-align: justify;">Predisposition to ARM architecture (armhf Debian packages)</li> 
       <li style="text-align: justify;">Predisposition to BackBox Cloud platform</li> 
       <li style="text-align: justify;">New and updated hacking tools: beef-project, btscanner, dirs3arch, metasploit-framework, ophcrack, setoolkit, tor, weevely, wpscan, etc.</li> 
      </ul> 
      <div style="text-align: justify;"> 
       <br>
      </div> 
      <div style="text-align: justify;"> 
       <strong><span style="font-size: large;">System requirements</span></strong>
      </div> 
      <ul> 
       <li style="text-align: justify;">32-bit or 64-bit processor</li> 
       <li style="text-align: justify;">512 MB of system memory (RAM)</li> 
       <li style="text-align: justify;">6 GB of disk space for installation</li> 
       <li style="text-align: justify;">Graphics card capable of 800×600 resolution</li> 
       <li style="text-align: justify;">DVD-ROM drive or USB port (2 GB)</li> 
      </ul> 
      <div style="text-align: justify;"> 
       <br>
      </div> 
      <div style="text-align: justify;"> 
       <strong><span style="font-size: large;">Upgrade instructions</span></strong>
      </div> To upgrade from a previous version (BackBox 4.x) follow these instructions:
      <br> 
      <pre><code>sudo apt-get update
sudo apt-get dist-upgrade
sudo apt-get install -f
sudo apt-get install linux-image-generic-lts-utopic linux-headers-generic-lts-utopic linux-signed-image-generic-lts-utopic
sudo apt-get purge ri1.9.1 ruby1.9.1 ruby1.9.3 bundler
sudo gem cleanup
sudo rm -rf /var/lib/gems/1.*
sudo apt-get install backbox-default-settings backbox-desktop backbox-tools --reinstall
sudo apt-get install beef-project metasploit-framework whatweb wpscan setoolkit --reinstall
sudo apt-get autoremove --purge</code></pre> 
      <br> 
      <br> 
      <div style="text-align: center;"> 
       <b><span style="font-size: x-large;"><a href="http://www.backbox.org/downloads" target="_blank">Download&nbsp;BackBox Linux 4.3</a></span></b>
      </div> 
     </div>
    </article> 
    <article class="post hentry" id="3527469741458194100" itemscope itemtype="http://schema.org/BlogPosting"> 
     <h1 class="post-title entry-title" itemprop="name headline"> BackBox Linux 4.4 - Ubuntu-based Linux Distribution Penetration Test and Security Assessment  </h1> 
     <div class="post-header" style="position:absolute;left:-9999px"> 
      <div class="post-header-line-1"></div> 
     </div> 
     <div class="post-body entry-content" id="post-body-3527469741458194100" itemprop="articleBody"> 
      <div class="separator" style="clear: both; text-align: center;"> 
       <a href="http://1.bp.blogspot.com/-K80kqcSmyVY/VbJ8FVn9y3I/AAAAAAAAEbE/TcARin01Ewg/s1600/BackBox_Linux_4.3.png" imageanchor="1" style="margin-left: 1em; margin-right: 1em;"><img border="0" height="474" src="http://1.bp.blogspot.com/-K80kqcSmyVY/VbJ8FVn9y3I/AAAAAAAAEbE/TcARin01Ewg/s640/BackBox_Linux_4.3.png" width="640"></a>
      </div> 
      <br> 
      <div style="text-align: justify;">
        BackBox is a Linux distribution based on Ubuntu. It has been developed to perform penetration tests and security assessments. Designed to be fast, easy to use and provide a minimal yet complete desktop environment, thanks to its own software repositories, always being updated to the latest stable version of the most used and best known ethical hacking tools.
      </div> 
      <a name="more"></a>
      <br> 
      <div style="text-align: justify;">
        The release have some special new features included to keep BackBox up to date with last developments in security world. Tools such as OpenVAS and Automotive Analysis will make a big difference. BackBox 4.4 comes also with Kernel 3.19.
      </div> 
      <br> 
      <div style="text-align: justify;"> 
       <strong><span style="font-size: large;">What's new</span></strong>
      </div> 
      <ul> 
       <li>Preinstalled Linux Kernel 3.19</li> 
       <li>New Ubuntu 14.04.3 base</li> 
       <li>Ruby 2.1</li> 
       <li>Installer with LVM and Full Disk Encryption options</li> 
       <li>Handy Thunar custom actions</li> 
       <li>RAM wipe at shutdown/reboot</li> 
       <li>System improvements</li> 
       <li>Upstream components</li> 
       <li>Bug corrections</li> 
       <li>Performance boost</li> 
       <li>Improved Anonymous mode</li> 
       <li>Automotive Analysis category</li> 
       <li>Predisposition to ARM architecture (armhf Debian packages)</li> 
       <li>Predisposition to BackBox Cloud platform</li> 
       <li>New and updated hacking tools: apktool, armitage, beef-project, can-utils, dex2jar, fimap, jd-gui,&nbsp;metasploit-framework, openvas, setoolkit, sqlmap, tor, weevely, wpscan, zaproxy, etc.</li> 
      </ul> 
      <div style="text-align: justify;"> 
       <br>
      </div> 
      <div style="text-align: justify;"> 
       <strong><span style="font-size: large;">System requirements</span></strong>
      </div> 
      <ul> 
       <li style="text-align: justify;">32-bit or 64-bit processor</li> 
       <li style="text-align: justify;">512 MB of system memory (RAM)</li> 
       <li style="text-align: justify;">6 GB of disk space for installation</li> 
       <li style="text-align: justify;">Graphics card capable of 800×600 resolution</li> 
       <li style="text-align: justify;">DVD-ROM drive or USB port (2 GB)</li> 
      </ul> 
      <div style="text-align: justify;"> 
       <br>
      </div> 
      <div style="text-align: justify;"> 
       <strong><span style="font-size: large;">Upgrade instructions</span></strong>
      </div> To upgrade from a previous version (BackBox 4.x) follow these instructions:
      <br> 
      <pre><code>sudo apt-get update
sudo apt-get dist-upgrade
sudo apt-get install -f
sudo apt-get install linux-image-generic-lts-vivid linux-headers-generic-lts-vivid linux-signed-image-generic-lts-vivid
sudo apt-get purge ri1.9.1 ruby1.9.1 ruby1.9.3 bundler
sudo gem cleanup
sudo rm -rf /var/lib/gems/1.*
sudo apt-get install backbox-default-settings backbox-desktop backbox-menu backbox-tools --reinstall
sudo apt-get install beef-project metasploit-framework whatweb wpscan setoolkit --reinstallsudo apt-get autoremove --purge
sudo apt-get install openvas sqlite3
sudo openvas-launch sync
sudo openvas-launch start</code></pre> 
      <br> 
      <br> 
      <div style="text-align: center;"> 
       <b><span style="font-size: x-large;"><a href="http://www.backbox.org/downloads" target="_blank">Download&nbsp;BackBox Linux 4.4</a></span></b>
      </div> 
     </div>
    </article> 
    <article class="post hentry" id="3636432540976744958" itemscope itemtype="http://schema.org/BlogPosting"> 
     <h1 class="post-title entry-title" itemprop="name headline"> Bacula - Network Backup Tool for Linux, Unix, Mac, and Windows  </h1> 
     <div class="post-header" style="position:absolute;left:-9999px"> 
      <div class="post-header-line-1"></div> 
     </div> 
     <div class="post-body entry-content" id="post-body-3636432540976744958" itemprop="articleBody"> 
      <div class="separator" style="clear: both; text-align: center;"> 
       <a href="http://4.bp.blogspot.com/-l2N6QPU5wvI/VVUsSmaU5TI/AAAAAAAAEBA/ee7t9UEqE-c/s1600/bacula.jpg" imageanchor="1" style="margin-left: 1em; margin-right: 1em;"><img border="0" height="456" src="http://4.bp.blogspot.com/-l2N6QPU5wvI/VVUsSmaU5TI/AAAAAAAAEBA/ee7t9UEqE-c/s640/bacula.jpg" width="640"></a>
      </div> 
      <br> 
      <div style="text-align: justify;"> 
      </div> 
      <div style="text-align: justify;">
        Bacula is a set of computer programs that permits the system administrator to manage backup, recovery, and verification of computer data across a network of computers of different kinds. Bacula can also run entirely upon a single computer and can backup to various types of media, including tape and disk.
      </div> 
      <div style="text-align: justify;"> 
       <br>
      </div> 
      <div style="text-align: justify;">
        In technical terms, it is a network Client/Server based backup program. Bacula is relatively easy to use and efficient, while offering many advanced storage management features that make it easy to find and recover lost or damaged files. Due to its modular design, Bacula is scalable from small single computer systems to systems consisting of hundreds of computers located over a large network.
      </div> 
      <a name="more"></a>
      <br> 
      <div style="text-align: justify;"> 
       <b><span class="Apple-style-span" style="font-size: large;">Who Needs Bacula?</span></b>
      </div> 
      <div style="text-align: justify;"> 
       <br>
      </div> 
      <div style="text-align: justify;">
        If you are currently using a program such as tar, dump, or bru to backup your computer data, and you would like a network solution, more flexibility, or catalog services, Bacula will most likely provide the additional features you want. However, if you are new to Unix systems or do not have offsetting experience with a sophisticated backup package, the Bacula project does not recommend using Bacula as it is much more difficult to setup and use than tar or dump.
      </div> 
      <div style="text-align: justify;"> 
       <br>
      </div> 
      <div style="text-align: justify;">
        If you want Bacula to behave like the above mentioned simple programs and write over any tape that you put in the drive, then you will find working with Bacula difficult. Bacula is designed to protect your data following the rules you specify, and this means reusing a tape only as the last resort. It is possible to “force” Bacula to write over any tape in the drive, but it is easier and more efficient to use a simpler program for that kind of operation.
      </div> 
      <div style="text-align: justify;"> 
       <br>
      </div> 
      <div style="text-align: justify;">
        If you would like a backup program that can write to multiple volumes (i.e. is not limited by your tape drive capacity), Bacula can most likely fill your needs. In addition, quite a number of Bacula users report that Bacula is simpler to setup and use than other equivalent programs.
      </div> 
      <div style="text-align: justify;"> 
       <br>
      </div> 
      <div style="text-align: justify;">
        If you are currently using a sophisticated commercial package such as Legato Networker. ARCserveIT, Arkeia, or PerfectBackup+, you may be interested in Bacula, which provides many of the same features and is free software available under the GNU Version 2 software license.
      </div> 
      <div style="text-align: justify;"> 
       <br>
      </div> 
      <div style="text-align: justify;"> 
       <span style="font-size: large;"><b>Bacula Components or Services</b></span>
      </div> 
      <div style="text-align: justify;"> 
       <br>
      </div> 
      <div style="text-align: justify;">
        Bacula is made up of the following five major components or services: Director, Console, File, Storage, and Monitor services.
      </div> 
      <div style="text-align: justify;"> 
       <br>
      </div> 
      <div style="text-align: justify;"> 
       <b>Bacula Director</b>
      </div> 
      <div style="text-align: justify;"> 
       <br>
      </div> 
      <div style="text-align: justify;">
        The Bacula Director service is the program that supervises all the backup, restore, verify and archive operations. The system administrator uses the Bacula Director to schedule backups and to recover files. For more details see the Director Services Daemon Design Document in the Bacula Developer’s Guide. The Director runs as a daemon (or service) in the background. 
       <a href="https://draft.blogger.com/blogger.g?blogID=8317222231133660547" name="UADef"></a>
      </div> 
      <div style="text-align: justify;"> 
       <br>
      </div> 
      <div style="text-align: justify;"> 
       <b>Bacula Console</b>
      </div> 
      <div style="text-align: justify;"> 
       <br>
      </div> 
      <div style="text-align: justify;">
        The Bacula Console service is the program that allows the administrator or user to communicate with the Bacula Director Currently, the Bacula Console is available in three versions: text-based console interface, QT-based interface, and a wxWidgets graphical interface. The first and simplest is to run the Console program in a shell window (i.e. TTY interface). Most system administrators will find this completely adequate. The second version is a GNOME GUI interface that is far from complete, but quite functional as it has most the capabilities of the shell Console. The third version is a wxWidgets GUI with an interactive file restore. It also has most of the capabilities of the shell console, allows command completion with tabulation, and gives you instant help about the command you are typing. For more details see the Bacula Console Design Document_ConsoleChapter.
      </div> 
      <div style="text-align: justify;"> 
       <br>
      </div> 
      <div style="text-align: justify;"> 
       <b>Bacula File</b>
      </div> 
      <div style="text-align: justify;"> 
       <br>
      </div> 
      <div style="text-align: justify;">
        The Bacula File service (also known as the Client program) is the software program that is installed on the machine to be backed up. It is specific to the operating system on which it runs and is responsible for providing the file attributes and data when requested by the Director. The File services are also responsible for the file system dependent part of restoring the file attributes and data during a recovery operation. For more details see the File Services Daemon Design Document in the Bacula Developer’s Guide. This program runs as a daemon on the machine to be backed up. In addition to Unix/Linux File daemons, there is a Windows File daemon (normally distributed in binary format). The Windows File daemon runs on current Windows versions (NT, 2000, XP, 2003, and possibly Me and 98).
      </div> 
      <div style="text-align: justify;"> 
       <br>
      </div> 
      <div style="text-align: justify;"> 
       <b>Bacula Storage</b>
      </div> 
      <div style="text-align: justify;"> 
       <br>
      </div> 
      <div style="text-align: justify;">
        The Bacula Storage services consist of the software programs that perform the storage and recovery of the file attributes and data to the physical backup media or volumes. In other words, the Storage daemon is responsible for reading and writing your tapes (or other storage media, e.g. files). For more details see the Storage Services Daemon Design Document in the Bacula Developer’s Guide. The Storage services runs as a daemon on the machine that has the backup device (usually a tape drive).
      </div> 
      <div style="text-align: justify;"> 
       <br>
      </div> 
      <div style="text-align: justify;"> 
       <b>Catalog</b>
      </div> 
      <div style="text-align: justify;"> 
       <br>
      </div> 
      <div style="text-align: justify;">
        The Catalog services are comprised of the software programs responsible for maintaining the file indexes and volume databases for all files backed up. The Catalog services permit the system administrator or user to quickly locate and restore any desired file. The Catalog services sets Bacula apart from simple backup programs like tar and bru, because the catalog maintains a record of all Volumes used, all Jobs run, and all Files saved, permitting efficient restoration and Volume management. Bacula currently supports three different databases, MySQL, PostgreSQL, and SQLite, one of which must be chosen when building Bacula.
      </div> 
      <div style="text-align: justify;">
        The three SQL databases currently supported (MySQL, PostgreSQL or SQLite) provide quite a number of features, including rapid indexing, arbitrary queries, and security. Although the Bacula project plans to support other major SQL databases, the current Bacula implementation interfaces only to MySQL, PostgreSQL and SQLite. For the technical and porting details see the Catalog Services Design Document in the developer’s documented.
      </div> 
      <div style="text-align: justify;">
        The packages for MySQL and PostgreSQL are available for several operating systems. Alternatively, installing from the source is quite easy, see the Installing and Configuring MySQLMySqlChapter chapter of this document for the details. For more information on MySQL, please see: www.mysql.comhttp://www.mysql.com. Or see the Installing and Configuring PostgreSQLPostgreSqlChapter chapter of this document for the details. For more information on PostgreSQL, please see: www.postgresql.orghttp://www.postgresql.org.
      </div> 
      <div style="text-align: justify;">
        Configuring and building SQLite is even easier. For the details of configuring SQLite, please see the Installing and Configuring SQLiteSqlLiteChapter chapter of this document.
      </div> 
      <div style="text-align: justify;"> 
       <br>
      </div> 
      <div style="text-align: justify;"> 
       <b>Bacula Monitor</b>
      </div> 
      <div style="text-align: justify;"> 
       <br>
      </div> 
      <div style="text-align: justify;">
        A Bacula Monitor service is the program that allows the administrator or user to watch current status of Bacula Directors, Bacula File Daemons and Bacula Storage Daemons. Currently, only a GTK+ version is available, which works with GNOME, KDE, or any window manager that supports the FreeDesktop.org system tray standard.
      </div> 
      <div style="text-align: justify;">
        To perform a successful save or restore, the following four daemons must be configured and running: the Director daemon, the File daemon, the Storage daemon, and the Catalog service (MySQL, PostgreSQL or SQLite).
      </div> 
      <br> 
      <br> 
      <div style="text-align: center;"> 
       <span style="font-size: x-large;"><b><a href="http://sourceforge.net/projects/bacula/" target="_blank">Download&nbsp;Bacula</a></b></span>
      </div> 
     </div>
    </article> 
    <article class="post hentry" id="589232737295529301" itemscope itemtype="http://schema.org/BlogPosting"> 
     <h1 class="post-title entry-title" itemprop="name headline"> Beeswarm - Active IDS made easy  </h1> 
     <div class="post-header" style="position:absolute;left:-9999px"> 
      <div class="post-header-line-1"></div> 
     </div> 
     <div class="post-body entry-content" id="post-body-589232737295529301" itemprop="articleBody"> 
      <div class="separator" style="clear: both; text-align: center;"> 
       <a href="http://2.bp.blogspot.com/-KThqY9ptTzQ/VMf3dvDyzhI/AAAAAAAADm0/-mYFiJb6xAw/s1600/beeswarm.png" imageanchor="1" style="margin-left: 1em; margin-right: 1em;"><img border="0" src="http://2.bp.blogspot.com/-KThqY9ptTzQ/VMf3dvDyzhI/AAAAAAAADm0/-mYFiJb6xAw/s1600/beeswarm.png" height="394" width="640"></a>
      </div> 
      <br> 
      <div style="text-align: justify;">
        Beeswarm is an active IDS project that provides easy configuration, deployment and management of honeypots and clients. The system operates by luring the hacker into the honeypots by setting up a deception infrastructure where deployed drones communicate with honeypots and intentionally leak credentials while doing so. The project has been release in a beta version, a stable version is expected within three months.
      </div> 
      <a name="more"></a>
      <br> 
      <div style="text-align: justify;"> 
       <b><span style="font-size: large;">Installing and starting the server</span></b>
      </div> 
      <div style="text-align: justify;"> 
       <br>
      </div> 
      <div style="text-align: justify;">
        On the VM to be set up as the server, perform the following steps. Make sure to write down the administrative password. 
      </div> 
      <br> 
      <pre><code>$ sudo apt-get install libffi-dev build-essential python-dev python-pip libssl-dev libxml2-dev libxslt1-dev
$ pip install pydes --allow-external pydes --allow-unverified pydes
$ pip install beeswarm
Downloading/unpacking beeswarm
...
Successfully installed Beeswarm
Cleaning up...
$ mkdir server_workdir
$ cd server-workdir/
$ beeswarm --server
...
****************************************************************************
Default password for the admin account is: uqbrlsabeqpbwy
****************************************************************************
...</code></pre> 
      <br> 
      <br> 
      <div style="text-align: center;"> 
       <b><a href="https://github.com/honeynet/beeswarm" target="_blank"><span style="font-size: x-large;">Download Beeswarm </span></a></b>
      </div> 
     </div>
    </article> 
    <article class="post hentry" id="2906290045272420818" itemscope itemtype="http://schema.org/BlogPosting"> 
     <h1 class="post-title entry-title" itemprop="name headline"> BetterCap - A complete, modular, portable and easily extensible MITM framework  </h1> 
     <div class="post-header" style="position:absolute;left:-9999px"> 
      <div class="post-header-line-1"></div> 
     </div> 
     <div class="post-body entry-content" id="post-body-2906290045272420818" itemprop="articleBody"> 
      <div class="separator" style="clear: both; text-align: center;"> 
       <a href="http://1.bp.blogspot.com/-8MWeYju50qY/ValJKOv9GBI/AAAAAAAAEYM/_F0Rf6sKFN8/s1600/BetterCap.png" imageanchor="1" style="margin-left: 1em; margin-right: 1em;"><img border="0" height="230" src="http://1.bp.blogspot.com/-8MWeYju50qY/ValJKOv9GBI/AAAAAAAAEYM/_F0Rf6sKFN8/s640/BetterCap.png" width="640"></a>
      </div> 
      <br> BetterCap is an attempt to create a complete, modular, portable and easily extensible 
      <strong>MITM</strong> framework with every kind of features could be needed while performing a man in the middle attack. 
      <br> It's currently able to sniff and print from the network the following informations:
      <br> 
      <ul> 
       <li>URLs being visited.</li> 
       <li>HTTPS host being visited.</li> 
       <li>HTTP POSTed data.</li> 
       <li>FTP credentials.</li> 
       <li>IRC credentials.</li> 
       <li>POP, IMAP and SMTP credentials.</li> 
       <li>NTLMv1/v2 ( HTTP, SMB, LDAP, etc ) credentials.</li> 
      </ul> 
      <div> 
       <a name="more"></a>
       <br> 
       <b><span style="font-size: large;">DEPENDS </span></b>
       <br> 
       <ul> 
        <li>colorize (<strong>gem install colorize</strong>)</li> 
        <li>packetfu (<strong>gem install packetfu</strong>)</li> 
        <li>pcaprub (<strong>gem install pcaprub</strong>) [sudo apt-get install ruby-dev libpcap-dev]</li> 
       </ul> 
       <div> 
        <br>
       </div> 
      </div> 
      <div> 
       <div style="text-align: center;"> 
        <b><span style="font-size: x-large;"><a href="https://github.com/evilsocket/bettercap" target="_blank">Download&nbsp;BetterCap</a></span></b>
       </div> 
      </div> 
     </div>
    </article> 
    <article class="post hentry" id="6869657204292880863" itemscope itemtype="http://schema.org/BlogPosting"> 
     <h1 class="post-title entry-title" itemprop="name headline"> Beurk - Experimental Unix Rootkit  </h1> 
     <div class="post-header" style="position:absolute;left:-9999px"> 
      <div class="post-header-line-1"></div> 
     </div> 
     <div class="post-body entry-content" id="post-body-6869657204292880863" itemprop="articleBody"> 
      <strong>BEURK </strong> is an userland 
      <a href="http://volatility-labs.blogspot.fr/2012/09/movp-24-analyzing-jynx-rootkit-and.html" target="_blank"> preload rootkit </a> for GNU/Linux, heavily focused around anti-debugging and anti-detection.
      <br> 
      <a name="more"></a>NOTE:&nbsp;
      <strong>BEURK&nbsp;</strong>is a recursive acronym for&nbsp;
      <strong>B&nbsp;</strong>EURK&nbsp;
      <strong>E&nbsp;</strong>xperimental&nbsp;
      <strong>U&nbsp;</strong>nix&nbsp;
      <strong>R&nbsp;</strong>oot&nbsp;
      <strong>K&nbsp;</strong>it
      <br> 
      <br> 
      <span style="font-size: large;"> <b> Features </b> </span> 
      <br> 
      <ul> 
       <li> Hide attacker files and directories </li> 
       <li> Realtime log cleanup (on <a href="http://man7.org/linux/man-pages/man5/utmp.5.html" target="_blank"> utmp/wtmp </a> ) </li> 
       <li> Anti process and login detection </li> 
       <li> Bypass unhide, lsof, ps, ldd, netstat analysis </li> 
       <li> Furtive PTY backdoor client </li> 
      </ul> 
      <br> 
      <span style="font-size: large;"> <b> Upcoming features </b> </span> 
      <br> 
      <ul> 
       <li> <a href="http://man7.org/linux/man-pages/man2/ptrace.2.html" target="_blank"> ptrace(2) </a> hooking for anti-debugging </li> 
       <li> <a href="http://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Pcap#libpcap" target="_blank"> libpcap </a> hooking undermines local sniffers </li> 
       <li> PAM backdoor for <em> local privilege escalation </em> </li> 
      </ul> 
      <br> 
      <span style="font-size: large;"> <b> Usage </b> </span> 
      <br> 
      <ul> 
       <li> <strong> Compile </strong> </li> 
      </ul> 
      <div> 
       <pre><code>    git clone https://github.com/unix-thrust/beurk.git
    cd beurk
    make</code></pre> 
      </div> 
      <ul> 
       <li> <strong> Install </strong> </li> 
      </ul> 
      <div> 
       <pre><code>    scp libselinux.so <a href="/cdn-cgi/l/email-protection" class="__cf_email__" data-cfemail="dba9b4b4af9badb2b8afb2b6f5b8b4b6">[email&nbsp;protected]</a>:/lib/
    ssh <a href="/cdn-cgi/l/email-protection" class="__cf_email__" data-cfemail="3d4f5252497d4b545e495450135e5250">[email&nbsp;protected]</a> 'echo /lib/libselinux.so &gt;&gt; /etc/ld.so.preload'</code></pre> 
      </div> 
      <ul> 
       <li> <strong> Enjoy ! </strong> </li> 
      </ul> 
      <div> 
       <pre><code>    ./client.py victim_ip:port # connect with furtive backdoor</code></pre> 
      </div> 
      <br> 
      <span style="font-size: large;"> <b> Dependencies </b> </span> 
      <br> The following packages are not required in order to build BEURK at the moment: 
      <br> 
      <ul> 
       <li> <strong> libpcap </strong> - to avoid local sniffing </li> 
       <li> <strong> libpam </strong> - for local PAM backdoor </li> 
       <li> <strong> libssl </strong> - for encrypted backdoor connection </li> 
      </ul> 
      <strong> Example on debian: </strong> 
      <br> 
      <div> 
       <pre><code>    apt-get install libpcap-dev libpam-dev libssl-dev</code></pre> 
      </div> 
      <br> 
      <br> 
      <div style="text-align: center;"> 
       <b> <span style="font-size: x-large;"> <a href="https://github.com/unix-thrust/beurk" target="_blank"> Download Beurk </a> </span> </b> 
      </div> 
     </div>
    </article> 
    <article class="post hentry" id="911275156331322820" itemscope itemtype="http://schema.org/BlogPosting"> 
     <h1 class="post-title entry-title" itemprop="name headline"> BlackArch Linux v2015.07.31 - Penetration Testing Distribution  </h1> 
     <div class="post-header" style="position:absolute;left:-9999px"> 
      <div class="post-header-line-1"></div> 
     </div> 
     <div class="post-body entry-content" id="post-body-911275156331322820" itemprop="articleBody"> 
      <div class="separator" style="clear: both; text-align: center;"> 
       <a href="http://1.bp.blogspot.com/-V4UxI3O_2ik/VcAUEGRkFlI/AAAAAAAAEcc/6edErcXkVD8/s1600/BlackArch.png" imageanchor="1" style="margin-left: 1em; margin-right: 1em;"><img border="0" height="354" src="http://1.bp.blogspot.com/-V4UxI3O_2ik/VcAUEGRkFlI/AAAAAAAAEcc/6edErcXkVD8/s640/BlackArch.png" width="640"></a>
      </div> 
      <br> 
      <div style="text-align: justify;">
        BlackArch Linux is an 
       <a href="http://www.archlinux.org/" target="_blank">Arch Linux</a>-based distribution for penetration testers and security researchers. The repository contains 1239 tools. You can install tools individually or in groups. BlackArch Linux is compatible with existing Arch installs.
      </div> 
      <a name="more"></a>
      <br> 
      <div style="text-align: justify;">
        The new ISOs include over 1230 tools for i686 and x86_64 and over 1010 tools. For more details see the ChangeLog below. &nbsp; &nbsp; &nbsp; &nbsp; &nbsp; &nbsp; &nbsp; &nbsp; &nbsp; &nbsp; &nbsp; &nbsp; &nbsp; &nbsp;&nbsp;
      </div> 
      <div style="text-align: justify;"> 
       <br>
      </div> 
      <div style="text-align: justify;"> 
       <b><span style="font-size: large;">Changelog&nbsp;v2015.07.31</span></b>
      </div> 
      <ul> 
       <li style="text-align: justify;">added more than 30 new tools</li> 
       <li style="text-align: justify;">updated system packages including linux kernel 4.1.3</li> 
       <li style="text-align: justify;">updated all tools</li> 
       <li style="text-align: justify;">added new color config for vim</li> 
       <li style="text-align: justify;">replace splash.png</li> 
       <li style="text-align: justify;">deleted blackarch-install.txt</li> 
       <li style="text-align: justify;">updated /root/README</li> 
       <li style="text-align: justify;">fixed typos in ISO config files</li> 
      </ul> 
      <div> 
       <br> 
       <br>
      </div> 
      <div> 
       <div style="text-align: center;"> 
        <b><span style="font-size: x-large;"><a href="http://blackarch.org/downloads.html" target="_blank">Download&nbsp;BlackArch Linux v2015.07.31</a></span></b>
       </div> 
      </div> 
     </div>
    </article> 
    <article class="post hentry" id="4744910710041220591" itemscope itemtype="http://schema.org/BlogPosting"> 
     <h1 class="post-title entry-title" itemprop="name headline"> BlackArch Linux v2015.11.24 - Penetration Testing Distribution  </h1> 
     <div class="post-header" style="position:absolute;left:-9999px"> 
      <div class="post-header-line-1"></div> 
     </div> 
     <div class="post-body entry-content" id="post-body-4744910710041220591" itemprop="articleBody"> 
      <div class="separator" style="clear: both; text-align: center;"> 
       <a href="http://3.bp.blogspot.com/-rY5PbYIuoNk/VlsfTZGYQPI/AAAAAAAAE1o/DNhCpLnRg7s/s1600/blackarch.png" imageanchor="1" style="margin-left: 1em; margin-right: 1em;"><img border="0" height="358" src="http://3.bp.blogspot.com/-rY5PbYIuoNk/VlsfTZGYQPI/AAAAAAAAE1o/DNhCpLnRg7s/s640/blackarch.png" width="640"></a>
      </div> 
      <br> 
      <b>BlackArch Linux</b> is an Arch Linux-based distribution for penetration testers and security researchers. The repository contains 
      <b>1308 tools</b>. You can install tools individually or in groups. BlackArch Linux is compatible with existing Arch installs. 
      <br> 
      <br> The BlackArch Live ISO contains multiple window managers.
      <br> 
      <a name="more"></a>
      <br> 
      <b><span style="font-size: large;">ChangeLog v2015.11.24: </span></b>
      <br> 
      <ul> 
       <li>added more than 100 new tools</li> 
       <li>updated system packages</li> 
       <li>include linux kernel 4.2.5</li> 
       <li>updated all tools</li> 
       <li>updated menu entries for window managers</li> 
       <li>added (correct) multilib support</li> 
       <li>added more fonts</li> 
       <li>added missing group 'vboxsf'</li> 
      </ul> 
      <div> 
       <br>
      </div> 
      <div style="text-align: center;"> 
       <b><span style="font-size: x-large;"><a href="http://blackarch.org/downloads.html" target="_blank">Download&nbsp;BlackArch Linux v2015.11.24</a></span></b>
      </div> 
     </div>
    </article> 
    <article class="post hentry" id="1707639984808196264" itemscope itemtype="http://schema.org/BlogPosting"> 
     <h1 class="post-title entry-title" itemprop="name headline"> Blackbone - Windows Memory Hacking Library  </h1> 
     <div class="post-header" style="position:absolute;left:-9999px"> 
      <div class="post-header-line-1"></div> 
     </div> 
     <div class="post-body entry-content" id="post-body-1707639984808196264" itemprop="articleBody">
       Blackbone, Windows Memory Hacking Library
      <br> 
      <a name="more"></a>
      <br> 
      <b><span style="font-size: large;">Features </span></b>
      <br> 
      <ul> 
       <li>x86 and x64 support</li> 
       <li><strong>Process interaction</strong><br> 
        <ul> 
         <li>Manage PEB32/PEB64</li> 
         <li>Manage process through WOW64 barrier</li> 
        </ul> </li> 
       <li><strong>Process Memory</strong><br> 
        <ul> 
         <li>Allocate and free virtual memory</li> 
         <li>Change memory protection</li> 
         <li>Read/Write virtual memory </li> 
        </ul> </li> 
       <li><strong>Process modules</strong><br> 
        <ul> 
         <li>Enumerate all (32/64 bit) modules loaded. Enumerate modules using Loader list/Section objects/PE headers methods.</li> 
         <li>Get exported function address</li> 
         <li>Get the main module</li> 
         <li>Unlink module from loader lists</li> 
         <li>Inject and eject modules (including pure IL images)</li> 
         <li>Inject 64bit modules into WOW64 processes</li> 
         <li>Manually map native PE images</li> 
        </ul> </li> 
       <li><strong>Threads</strong><br> 
        <ul> 
         <li>Enumerate threads</li> 
         <li>Create and terminate threads. Support for cross-session thread creation.</li> 
         <li>Get thread exit code</li> 
         <li>Get main thread</li> 
         <li>Manage TEB32/TEB64</li> 
         <li>Join threads</li> 
         <li>Suspend and resume threads</li> 
         <li>Set/Remove hardware breakpoints</li> 
        </ul> </li> 
       <li><strong>Pattern search</strong><br> 
        <ul> 
         <li>Search for arbitrary pattern in local or remote process</li> 
        </ul> </li> 
       <li><strong>Remote code execution</strong><br> 
        <ul> 
         <li>Execute functions in remote process</li> 
         <li>Assemble own code and execute it remotely</li> 
         <li>Support for cdecl/stdcall/thiscall/fastcall conventions</li> 
         <li>Support for arguments passed by value, pointer or reference, including structures</li> 
         <li>FPU types are supported</li> 
         <li>Execute code in new thread or any existing one</li> 
        </ul> </li> 
       <li><strong>Remote hooking</strong><br> 
        <ul> 
         <li>Hook functions in remote process using int3 or hardware breakpoints</li> 
         <li>Hook functions upon return</li> 
        </ul> </li> 
       <li><strong>Manual map features</strong><br> 
        <ul> 
         <li>x86 and x64 image support</li> 
         <li>Mapping into any arbitrary unprotected process</li> 
         <li>Section mapping with proper memory protection flags</li> 
         <li>Image relocations (only 2 types supported. I haven't seen a single PE image with some other relocation types)</li> 
         <li>Imports and Delayed imports are resolved</li> 
         <li>Bound import is resolved as a side effect, I think</li> 
         <li>Module exports</li> 
         <li>Loading of forwarded export images</li> 
         <li>Api schema name redirection</li> 
         <li>SxS redirection and isolation</li> 
         <li>Activation context support</li> 
         <li>Dll path resolving similar to native load order</li> 
         <li>TLS callbacks. Only for one thread and only with PROCESS_ATTACH/PROCESS_DETACH reasons.</li> 
         <li>Static TLS</li> 
         <li>Exception handling support (SEH and C++)</li> 
         <li>Adding module to some native loader structures(for basic module api support: GetModuleHandle, GetProcAdress, etc.)</li> 
         <li>Security cookie initialization</li> 
         <li>C++/CLI images are supported</li> 
         <li>Image unloading </li> 
         <li>Increase reference counter for import libraries in case of manual import mapping</li> 
         <li>Cyclic dependencies are handled properly </li> 
        </ul> </li> 
       <li><strong>Driver features</strong></li> 
       <li>Allocate/free/protect user memory</li> 
       <li>Read/write user and kernel memory</li> 
       <li>Disable permanent DEP for WOW64 processes</li> 
       <li>Change process protection flag</li> 
       <li>Change handle access rights</li> 
       <li>Remap process memory</li> 
       <li>Hiding allocated user-mode memory</li> 
       <li>User-mode dll injection and manual mapping</li> 
       <li>Manual mapping of drivers</li> 
      </ul> 
      <div> 
       <br>
      </div> 
      <div style="text-align: center;"> 
       <b><span style="font-size: x-large;"><a href="https://github.com/DarthTon/Blackbone/" target="_blank">Download&nbsp;Blackbone</a></span></b>
      </div> 
     </div>
    </article> 
    <article class="post hentry" id="5900549107502195087" itemscope itemtype="http://schema.org/BlogPosting"> 
     <h1 class="post-title entry-title" itemprop="name headline"> BlueMaho - Bluetooth Security Testing Suite  </h1> 
     <div class="post-header" style="position:absolute;left:-9999px"> 
      <div class="post-header-line-1"></div> 
     </div> 
     <div class="post-body entry-content" id="post-body-5900549107502195087" itemprop="articleBody"> 
      <div class="separator" style="clear: both; text-align: center;"> 
       <a href="http://3.bp.blogspot.com/-JXiJ8tE0Wk0/VKm0_EHt30I/AAAAAAAADew/iS9jEvtLKQA/s1600/BlueMaho.jpg" imageanchor="1" style="margin-left: 1em; margin-right: 1em;"><img border="0" src="http://3.bp.blogspot.com/-JXiJ8tE0Wk0/VKm0_EHt30I/AAAAAAAADew/iS9jEvtLKQA/s1600/BlueMaho.jpg" height="480" width="640"></a>
      </div> 
      <br> 
      <div class="line862"> 
       <div style="text-align: justify;">
         Blue
        <strong></strong>Maho is GUI-shell (interface) for suite of tools for testing security of bluetooth devices. It is freeware, opensource, written on python, uses wxPyhon. It can be used for testing BT-devices for known vulnerabilities and major thing to do - testing to find unknown vulns. Also it can form nice statistics.
       </div> 
       <a name="more"></a>
       <div style="text-align: justify;"> 
        <br>
       </div> 
       <div style="text-align: justify;"> 
        <b><span style="font-size: large;">What it can do? (features)</span></b>
       </div> 
       <ul> 
        <li style="text-align: justify;">scan for devices, show advanced info, SDP records, vendor etc <span class="anchor" id="line-19"></span></li> 
        <li style="text-align: justify;">track devices - show where and how much times device was seen, its name changes <span class="anchor" id="line-20"></span></li> 
        <li style="text-align: justify;">loop scan - it can scan all time, showing you online devices <span class="anchor" id="line-21"></span></li> 
        <li style="text-align: justify;">alerts with sound if new device found <span class="anchor" id="line-22"></span></li> 
        <li style="text-align: justify;">on_new_device - you can spacify what command should it run when it founds new device <span class="anchor" id="line-23"></span></li> 
        <li style="text-align: justify;">it can use separate dongles - one for scaning (loop scan) and one for running tools or exploits <span class="anchor" id="line-24"></span></li> 
        <li style="text-align: justify;">send files <span class="anchor" id="line-25"></span></li> 
        <li style="text-align: justify;">change name, class, mode, BD_ADDR of local HCI devices <span class="anchor" id="line-26"></span></li> 
        <li style="text-align: justify;">save results in database <span class="anchor" id="line-27"></span></li> 
        <li style="text-align: justify;">form nice statistics (uniq devices by day/hour, vendors, services etc) <span class="anchor" id="line-28"></span></li> 
        <li style="text-align: justify;">test remote device for known vulnerabilities (see exploits for more details) <span class="anchor" id="line-29"></span></li> 
        <li style="text-align: justify;">test remote device for unknown vulnerabilities (see tools for more details) <span class="anchor" id="line-30"></span></li> 
        <li style="text-align: justify;">themes! you can customize it <span class="anchor" id="line-31"></span><span class="anchor" id="line-32"></span></li> 
       </ul> 
       <div class="line867"> 
       </div> 
       <div style="text-align: justify;"> 
        <br>
       </div> 
       <div style="text-align: justify;"> 
        <b><span style="font-size: large;">What tools and exploits it consist of?</span></b>
       </div> 
       <ul> 
        <li style="list-style-type: none; text-align: justify;"><b>Tools: </b><span class="anchor" id="line-34"></span></li> 
        <li style="text-align: justify;">atshell.c by Bastian Ballmann (modified attest.c by Marcel Holtmann) <span class="anchor" id="line-35"></span></li> 
        <li style="text-align: justify;">bccmd by Marcel Holtmann <span class="anchor" id="line-36"></span></li> 
        <li style="text-align: justify;">bdaddr.c by Marcel Holtmann <span class="anchor" id="line-37"></span></li> 
        <li style="text-align: justify;">bluetracker.py by smiley <span class="anchor" id="line-38"></span></li> 
        <li style="text-align: justify;">carwhisperer v0.2 by Martin Herfurt <span class="anchor" id="line-39"></span></li> 
        <li style="text-align: justify;">psm_scan and rfcomm_scan from bt_audit-0.1.1 by Collin R. Mulliner <span class="anchor" id="line-40"></span></li> 
        <li style="text-align: justify;">BSS (Bluetooth Stack Smasher) v0.8 by Pierre Betouin <span class="anchor" id="line-41"></span></li> 
        <li style="text-align: justify;">btftp v0.1 by Marcel Holtmann <span class="anchor" id="line-42"></span></li> 
        <li style="text-align: justify;">btobex v0.1 by Marcel Holtmann <span class="anchor" id="line-43"></span></li> 
        <li style="text-align: justify;">greenplaque v1.5 by digitalmunition.com <span class="anchor" id="line-44"></span></li> 
        <li style="text-align: justify;">L2CAP packetgenerator by Bastian Ballmann <span class="anchor" id="line-45"></span></li> 
        <li style="text-align: justify;">obex stress tests 0.1 <span class="anchor" id="line-46"></span></li> 
        <li style="text-align: justify;">redfang v2.50 by Ollie Whitehouse <span class="anchor" id="line-47"></span></li> 
        <li style="text-align: justify;">ussp-push v0.10 by Davide Libenzi <span class="anchor" id="line-48"></span><span class="anchor" id="line-49"></span></li> 
        <li class="gap" style="list-style-type: none; text-align: justify;">exploits/attacks: <span class="anchor" id="line-50"></span></li> 
        <li style="text-align: justify;">Bluebugger v0.1 by Martin J. Muench <span class="anchor" id="line-51"></span></li> 
        <li style="text-align: justify;">bluePIMp by Kevin Finisterre <span class="anchor" id="line-52"></span></li> 
        <li style="text-align: justify;">BlueZ hcidump v1.29 DoS PoC by Pierre Betouin <span class="anchor" id="line-53"></span></li> 
        <li style="text-align: justify;">helomoto by Adam Laurie <span class="anchor" id="line-54"></span></li> 
        <li style="text-align: justify;">hidattack v0.1 by Collin R. Mulliner <span class="anchor" id="line-55"></span></li> 
        <li style="text-align: justify;">Mode 3 abuse attack <span class="anchor" id="line-56"></span></li> 
        <li style="text-align: justify;">Nokia N70 l2cap packet DoS PoC Pierre Betouin <span class="anchor" id="line-57"></span></li> 
        <li style="text-align: justify;">opush abuse (prompts flood) DoS attack <span class="anchor" id="line-58"></span></li> 
        <li style="text-align: justify;">Sony-Ericsson reset display PoC by Pierre Betouin <span class="anchor" id="line-59"></span><span class="anchor" id="line-60"></span></li> 
        <li class="gap" style="list-style-type: none; text-align: justify;">you can add your own tools by editing 'exploits/exploits.lst' and 'tools/tools.lst' <span class="anchor" id="line-61"></span><span class="anchor" id="line-62"></span></li> 
       </ul> 
       <div class="line867"> 
       </div> 
       <div style="text-align: justify;"> 
        <br>
       </div> 
       <div style="text-align: justify;"> 
        <b><span style="font-size: large;">Requirements</span></b>
       </div> 
       <ul> 
        <li style="text-align: justify;">OS (tested with Debian 4.0 Etch / 2.6.18) <span class="anchor" id="line-64"></span></li> 
        <li>
         <div class="line862"> 
          <div style="text-align: justify;">
            python (python 2.4 
           <a class="http" href="http://www.python.org/">http://www.python.org</a>) 
           <span class="anchor" id="line-65"></span>
          </div> 
         </div> </li> 
        <li>
         <div class="line862"> 
          <div style="text-align: justify;">
            wxPython (python-wxgtk2.6 
           <a class="http" href="http://www.wxpython.org/">http://www.wxpython.org</a>) 
           <span class="anchor" id="line-66"></span>
          </div> 
         </div> </li> 
        <li>
         <div class="line862"> 
          <div style="text-align: justify;">
            BlueZ (3.9/3.24) 
           <a class="http" href="http://www.bluez.org/">http://www.bluez.org</a> 
           <span class="anchor" id="line-67"></span>
          </div> 
         </div> </li> 
        <li style="text-align: justify;">Eterm to open tools somewhere, you can set another term in 'config/defaul.conf' changing the value of 'cmd_term' variable. (tested with 1.1 ver) <span class="anchor" id="line-68"></span></li> 
        <li style="text-align: justify;">pkg-config(0.21), 'tee' used in tools/showmaxlocaldevinfo.sh, openobex, obexftp <span class="anchor" id="line-69"></span></li> 
        <li style="text-align: justify;">libopenobex1 + libopenobex-dev (needed by ussp-push) <span class="anchor" id="line-70"></span></li> 
        <li style="text-align: justify;">libxml2, libxml2-dev (needed by btftp) <span class="anchor" id="line-71"></span></li> 
        <li style="text-align: justify;">libusb-dev (needed by bccmd) <span class="anchor" id="line-72"></span></li> 
        <li style="text-align: justify;">libreadline5-dev (needed by atshell.c) <span class="anchor" id="line-73"></span></li> 
        <li style="text-align: justify;">lightblue-0.3.3 (needed by obexstress.py) <span class="anchor" id="line-74"></span></li> 
        <li style="text-align: justify;">hardware: any bluez compatible bluetooth-device&nbsp;</li> 
       </ul> 
       <div> 
        <br>
       </div> 
       <div style="text-align: center;"> 
        <b><span style="font-size: x-large;"><a href="https://wiki.thc.org/BlueMaho" target="_blank">Download BlueMaho</a></span></b>
       </div> 
      </div>

    <article class="post hentry" id="6027145300888051072" itemscope itemtype="http://schema.org/BlogPosting"> 
     <h1 class="post-title entry-title" itemprop="name headline"> BlueScreenView - Blue Screen of Death (STOP error) information in dump files  </h1> 
     <div class="post-header" style="position:absolute;left:-9999px"> 
      <div class="post-header-line-1"></div> 
     </div> 
     <div class="post-body entry-content" id="post-body-6027145300888051072" itemprop="articleBody"> 
      <div class="separator" style="clear: both; text-align: center;"> 
       <a href="http://1.bp.blogspot.com/-e2wT-wFo-oI/VQoURT1uGSI/AAAAAAAADzg/UAD18XG-8xc/s1600/bluescreenview2.gif" imageanchor="1" style="margin-left: 1em; margin-right: 1em;"><img border="0" src="http://1.bp.blogspot.com/-e2wT-wFo-oI/VQoURT1uGSI/AAAAAAAADzg/UAD18XG-8xc/s1600/bluescreenview2.gif" height="530" width="640"></a>
      </div> 
      <br> BlueScreenView scans all your minidump files created during 'blue screen of death' crashes, and displays the information about all crashes in one table. For each crash, BlueScreenView displays the minidump filename, the date/time of the crash, the basic crash information displayed in the blue screen (Bug Check Code and 4 parameters), and the details of the driver or module that possibly caused the crash (filename, product name, file description, and file version).
      <br> 
      <a name="more"></a>
      <br> For each crash displayed in the upper pane, you can view the details of the device drivers loaded during the crash in the lower pane. BlueScreenView also mark the drivers that their addresses found in the crash stack, so you can easily locate the suspected drivers that possibly caused the crash.
      <br> 
      <br> 
      <b><span class="Apple-style-span" style="font-size: large;">Features </span></b>
      <br> 
      <ul> 
       <li>Automatically scans your current minidump folder and displays the list of all crash dumps, including crash dump date/time and crash details. </li> 
       <li>Allows you to view a blue screen which is very similar to the one that Windows displayed during the crash. </li> 
       <li>BlueScreenView enumerates the memory addresses inside the stack of the crash, and find all drivers/modules that might be involved in the crash. </li> 
       <li>BlueScreenView also allows you to work with another instance of Windows, simply by choosing the right minidump folder (In Advanced Options). </li> 
       <li>BlueScreenView automatically locate the drivers appeared in the crash dump, and extract their version resource information, including product name, file version, company, and file description.&nbsp;</li> 
      </ul> 
      <div> 
       <br>
      </div> 
      <div> 
       <b><span class="Apple-style-span" style="font-size: large;">Using BlueScreenView</span></b>
       <br> 
       <br> BlueScreenView doesn't require any installation process or additional dll files. In order to start using it, simply run the executable file - BlueScreenView.exe&nbsp;
      </div> 
      <div> 
       <br> After running BlueScreenView, it automatically scans your MiniDump folder and display all crash details in the upper pane.
      </div> 
      <div> 
       <br> 
       <b><span class="Apple-style-span" style="font-size: large;">Crashes Information Columns (Upper Pane)</span></b>
       <br> 
       <ul> 
        <li><span class="special3">Dump File:</span> The MiniDump filename that stores the crash data. </li> 
        <li><span class="special3">Crash Time:</span> The created time of the MiniDump filename, which also matches to the date/time that the crash occurred. </li> 
        <li><span class="special3">Bug Check String:</span> The crash error string. This error string is determined according to the Bug Check Code, and it's also displayed in the blue screen window of Windows. </li> 
        <li><span class="special3">Bug Check Code:</span> The bug check code, as displayed in the blue screen window. </li> 
        <li><span class="special3">Parameter 1/2/3/4:</span> The 4 crash parameters that are also displayed in the blue screen of death. </li> 
        <li><span class="special3">Caused By Driver:</span> The driver that probably caused this crash. BlueScreenView tries to locate the right driver or module that caused the blue screen by looking inside the crash stack. However, be aware that the driver detection mechanism is not 100% accurate, and you should also look in the lower pane, that display all drivers/modules found in the stack. These drivers/modules are marked in pink color. </li> 
        <li><span class="special3">Caused By Address:</span> Similar to 'Caused By Driver' column, but also display the relative address of the crash. </li> 
        <li><span class="special3">File Description:</span> The file description of the driver that probably caused this crash. This information is loaded from the version resource of the driver. </li> 
        <li><span class="special3">Product Name:</span> The product name of the driver that probably caused this crash. This information is loaded from the version resource of the driver. </li> 
        <li><span class="special3">Company:</span> The company name of the driver that probably caused this crash. This information is loaded from the version resource of the driver. </li> 
        <li><span class="special3">File Version:</span> The file version of the driver that probably caused this crash. This information is loaded from the version resource of the driver. </li> 
        <li><span class="special3">Crash Address:</span>The memory address that the crash occurred. (The address in the EIP/RIP processor register) In some crashes, this value might be identical to 'Caused By Address' value, while in others, the crash address is different from the driver that caused the crash. </li> 
        <li><span class="special3">Stack Address 1 - 3:</span> The last 3 addresses found in the call stack. Be aware that in some crashes, these values will be empty. Also, the stack addresses list is currently not supported for 64-bit crashes.&nbsp;</li> 
       </ul> 
       <br> 
       <b><span class="Apple-style-span" style="font-size: large;">Drivers Information Columns (Lower Pane)</span></b>
       <br> 
       <ul> 
        <li><span class="special3">Filename:</span> The driver/module filename </li> 
        <li><span class="special3">Address In Stack:</span> The memory address of this driver that was found in the stack. </li> 
        <li><span class="special3">From Address:</span> First memory address of this driver. </li> 
        <li><span class="special3">To Address:</span> Last memory address of this driver. </li> 
        <li><span class="special3">Size:</span> Driver size in memory. </li> 
        <li><span class="special3">Time Stamp:</span> Time stamp of this driver. </li> 
        <li><span class="special3">Time String:</span> Time stamp of this driver, displayed in date/time format. </li> 
        <li><span class="special3">Product Name:</span> Product name of this driver, loaded from the version resource of the driver. </li> 
        <li><span class="special3">File Description:</span> File description of this driver, loaded from the version resource of the driver. </li> 
        <li><span class="special3">File Version:</span> File version of this driver, loaded from the version resource of the driver. </li> 
        <li><span class="special3">Company:</span> Company name of this driver, loaded from the version resource of the driver. </li> 
        <li><span class="special3">Full Path:</span> Full path of the driver filename.</li> 
       </ul> 
       <br> 
       <b><span class="Apple-style-span" style="font-size: large;">Lower Pane Modes</span></b>
       <br> 
       <br> Currently, the lower pane has 4 different display modes. You can change the display mode of the lower pane from Options-&gt;Lower Pane Mode menu. 
       <br> 
       <ol> 
        <li><span class="special2">All Drivers:</span> Displays all the drivers that were loaded during the crash that you selected in the upper pane. The drivers/module that their memory addresses found in the stack, are marked in pink color. </li> 
        <li><span class="special2">Only Drivers Found In Stack:</span> Displays only the modules/drivers that their memory addresses found in the stack of the crash. There is very high chance that one of the drivers in this list is the one that caused the crash. </li> 
        <li><span class="special2">Blue Screen in XP Style:</span> Displays a blue screen that looks very similar to the one that Windows displayed during the crash. </li> 
        <li><span class="special2">DumpChk Output:</span> Displays the output of Microsoft DumpChk utility. This mode only works when Microsoft DumpChk is installed on your computer and BlueScreenView is configured to run it from the right folder (In the Advanced Options window).&nbsp;</li> 
       </ol> 
      </div> 
      <br> 
      <b><span class="Apple-style-span" style="font-size: large;">Command-Line Options</span></b>
      <br> 
      <br> 
      <table border="1" bordercolor="#000000" cellpadding="5"> 
       <tbody> 
        <tr>
         <td nowrap>/LoadFrom &lt;Source&gt; </td>
         <td>Specifies the source to load from. <br> 1 -&gt; Load from a single MiniDump folder (/MiniDumpFolder parameter) <br> 2 -&gt; Load from all computers specified in the computer list file. (/ComputersFile parameter) <br> 3 -&gt; Load from a single MiniDump file (/SingleDumpFile parameter) </td>
        </tr> 
        <tr>
         <td nowrap>/MiniDumpFolder &lt;Folder&gt; </td>
         <td>Start BlueScreenView with the specified MiniDump folder. </td>
        </tr> 
        <tr>
         <td nowrap>/SingleDumpFile &lt;Filename&gt; </td>
         <td>Start BlueScreenView with the specified MiniDump file. (For using with /LoadFrom 3) </td>
        </tr> 
        <tr>
         <td nowrap>/ComputersFile &lt;Filename&gt; </td>
         <td>Specifies the computers list filename. (When LoadFrom = 2) </td>
        </tr> 
        <tr>
         <td nowrap>/LowerPaneMode &lt;1 - 3&gt; </td>
         <td>Start BlueScreenView with the specified mode. 1 = All Drivers, 2 = Only Drivers Found In Stack, 3 = Blue Screen in XP Style. </td>
        </tr> 
        <tr>
         <td nowrap>/stext &lt;Filename&gt; </td>
         <td>Save the list of blue screen crashes into a regular text file. </td>
        </tr> 
        <tr>
         <td nowrap>/stab &lt;Filename&gt; </td>
         <td>Save the list of blue screen crashes into a tab-delimited text file. </td>
        </tr> 
        <tr>
         <td nowrap>/scomma &lt;Filename&gt; </td>
         <td>Save the list of blue screen crashes into a comma-delimited text file (csv). </td>
        </tr> 
        <tr>
         <td nowrap>/stabular &lt;Filename&gt; </td>
         <td>Save the list of blue screen crashes into a tabular text file. </td>
        </tr> 
        <tr>
         <td nowrap>/shtml &lt;Filename&gt; </td>
         <td>Save the list of blue screen crashes into HTML file (Horizontal). </td>
        </tr> 
        <tr>
         <td nowrap>/sverhtml &lt;Filename&gt; </td>
         <td>Save the list of blue screen crashes into HTML file (Vertical). </td>
        </tr> 
        <tr>
         <td nowrap>/sxml &lt;Filename&gt; </td>
         <td>Save the list of blue screen crashes into XML file. </td>
        </tr> 
        <tr>
         <td nowrap>/sort &lt;column&gt; </td>
         <td>This command-line option can be used with other save options for sorting by the desired column. If you don't specify this option, the list is sorted according to the last sort that you made from the user interface. The &lt;column&gt; parameter can specify the column index (0 for the first column, 1 for the second column, and so on) or the name of the column, like "Bug Check Code" and "Crash Time". You can specify the '~' prefix character (e.g: "~Crash Time") if you want to sort in descending order. You can put multiple /sort in the command-line if you want to sort by multiple columns. Examples: <br> BlueScreenView.exe /shtml "f:\temp\crashes.html" /sort 2 /sort ~1 <br> BlueScreenView.exe /shtml "f:\temp\crashes.html" /sort "Bug Check String" /sort "~Crash Time" </td>
        </tr> 
        <tr>
         <td nowrap>/nosort </td>
         <td>When you specify this command-line option, the list will be saved without any sorting. </td>
        </tr> 
       </tbody>
      </table> 
      <br> 
      <br> 
      <div style="text-align: center;"> 
       <b><span class="Apple-style-span" style="font-size: x-large;"><a href="http://www.nirsoft.net/utils/blue_screen_view.html" target="_blank">Download BlueScreenView</a></span></b>
      </div> 
     </div>
    </article> 
    <article class="post hentry" id="4194191189199420070" itemscope itemtype="http://schema.org/BlogPosting"> 
     <h1 class="post-title entry-title" itemprop="name headline"> Bluto - DNS Recon, DNS Zone Transfer, and Email Enumeration  </h1> 
     <div class="post-header" style="position:absolute;left:-9999px"> 
      <div class="post-header-line-1"></div> 
     </div> 
     <div class="post-body entry-content" id="post-body-4194191189199420070" itemprop="articleBody"> 
      <div class="separator" style="clear: both; text-align: center;"> 
       <a href="http://1.bp.blogspot.com/--o4NuUXco0o/VkFkFdTLLAI/AAAAAAAAEx8/wIwmNzYkYe4/s1600/bluto.png" imageanchor="1" style="margin-left: 1em; margin-right: 1em;"><img border="0" height="484" src="http://1.bp.blogspot.com/--o4NuUXco0o/VkFkFdTLLAI/AAAAAAAAEx8/wIwmNzYkYe4/s640/bluto.png" width="640"></a>
      </div> 
      <span style="font-size: large;"> <strong style="font-weight: bold;"> BLUTO</strong>&nbsp;</span>
      <strong>DNS recon | Brute forcer | DNS Zone Transfer | Email Enumeration</strong>
      <br> 
      <div style="text-align: justify;"> 
       <br>
      </div> 
      <div style="text-align: justify;">
        The target domain is queried for MX and NS records. Sub-domains are passively gathered via NetCraft. The target domain NS records are each queried for potential Zone Transfers. If none of them gives up their spinach, Bluto will brute force subdomains using parallel sub processing on the top 20000 of the 'The Alexa Top 1 Million subdomains'. NetCraft results are presented individually and are then compared to the brute force results, any duplications are removed and particularly interesting results are highlighted. 
      </div> 
      <div style="text-align: justify;"> 
       <br>
      </div> 
      <div style="text-align: justify;">
        Bluto now does email address enumeration based on the target domain, currently using Bing and Google search engines. It is configured in such a way to use a random 
       <code> User Agent:</code> on each request and does a country look up to select the fastest Google server in relation to your egress address. Each request closes the connection in an attempt to further avoid captchas, however exsesive lookups will result in captchas (Bluto will warn you if any are identified). 
      </div> 
      <div style="text-align: justify;"> 
       <br>
      </div> 
      <div style="text-align: justify;">
        Bluto requires various other dependencies. So to make things as easy as possible, 
       <code> pip</code> is used for the installation. This does mean you will need to have pip installed prior to attempting the Bluto install. 
      </div> 
      <div style="text-align: justify;"> 
       <br>
      </div> 
      <strong><span style="font-size: large;"> Pip Install Instructions </span></strong> 
      <br> Note: To test if pip is already installed execute. 
      <br> 
      <pre><code>  pip -V</code></pre> 
      <br> (1) Mac and Kali users can simply use the following command to download and install 
      <code>pip</code>. 
      <br> 
      <pre><code>  curl https://bootstrap.pypa.io/get-pip.py -o - | python</code></pre> 
      <br> 
      <strong><span style="font-size: large;"> Bluto Install Instructions </span></strong> 
      <br> (1) Once 
      <code>pip</code> has successfully downloaded and installed, we can install Bluto: 
      <br> 
      <pre><code>  sudo pip install git+git://github.com/RandomStorm/Bluto</code></pre> 
      <br> (2) You should now be able to execute 'bluto' from any working directory in any terminal. 
      <br> 
      <pre><code>  bluto</code></pre> 
      <br> 
      <strong><span style="font-size: large;"> Upgrade Instructions </span></strong> 
      <br> (1) The upgrade process is as simple as; 
      <br> 
      <pre><code>  sudo pip install git+git://github.com/RandomStorm/Bluto --upgrade</code></pre> 
      <br> 
      <br> 
      <div style="text-align: center;"> 
       <b> <span style="font-size: x-large;"> <a href="https://github.com/RandomStorm/Bluto" target="_blank"> Download Bluto </a> </span> </b> 
      </div> 
     </div>
    </article> 
    <article class="post hentry" id="3443221335803218636" itemscope itemtype="http://schema.org/BlogPosting"> 
     <h1 class="post-title entry-title" itemprop="name headline"> Bohatei - Flexible and Elastic DDoS Defense  </h1> 
     <div class="post-header" style="position:absolute;left:-9999px"> 
      <div class="post-header-line-1"></div> 
     </div> 
     <div class="post-body entry-content" id="post-body-3443221335803218636" itemprop="articleBody"> 
      <div class="separator" style="clear: both; text-align: center;"> 
       <a href="http://2.bp.blogspot.com/-iTwv_MgwnGI/Vlsqnj23fEI/AAAAAAAAE14/4-gpXAmNSb4/s1600/fayaz.png" imageanchor="1" style="margin-left: 1em; margin-right: 1em;"><img border="0" height="231" src="http://2.bp.blogspot.com/-iTwv_MgwnGI/Vlsqnj23fEI/AAAAAAAAE14/4-gpXAmNSb4/s640/fayaz.png" width="640"></a>
      </div> 
      <br> 
      <div style="text-align: justify;">
        Bohatei is a first of its kind platform that enables flexible and elastic DDoS defense using SDN and NFV.
      </div> 
      <a name="more"></a>
      <br> 
      <div style="text-align: justify;">
        The repository contains a 
       <strong>first</strong> version of the components described in the Bohatei paper, as well as a web-based User Interface. The backend folder consists of :
      </div> 
      <ul> 
       <li style="text-align: justify;">an implementation of the FlowTags framework for the OpenDaylight controller </li> 
       <li style="text-align: justify;">an implementation of the resource management algorithms </li> 
       <li style="text-align: justify;">a topology file that was used to simulate an ISP topology</li> 
       <li style="text-align: justify;">scripts that facilitate functions such as spawning, tearing down and retrieving the topology.</li> 
       <li style="text-align: justify;">scripts that automate and coordinate the components required for the usecases examined.</li> 
      </ul> 
      <div style="text-align: justify;">
        The frontend folder contains the required files for the web interface. 
      </div> 
      <div style="text-align: justify;">
        For the experiments performed, we used a set of VM images that contain implementations of the strategy graphs for each type of attack (SYN Flood, UDP Flood, DNS Amplification and Elephant Flow). Those images will become available at a later stage. The tools that were used for those strategy graphs are the following:
      </div> 
      <ul> 
       <li style="text-align: justify;"><a href="https://www.bro.org/index.html">Bro</a></li> 
       <li style="text-align: justify;"><a href="https://www.snort.org/">Snort</a></li> 
       <li style="text-align: justify;"><a href="http://www.inlab.de/balance.html">Balancer</a></li> 
       <li style="text-align: justify;">Iptables</li> 
       <li style="text-align: justify;">Iperf</li> 
       <li style="text-align: justify;">Custom scripts to simulate the attacks</li> 
      </ul> 
      <div style="text-align: justify;"> 
       <br>
      </div> 
      <div style="text-align: justify;"> 
       <b><a href="https://www.usenix.org/system/files/conference/usenixsecurity15/sec15-paper-fayaz.pdf" target="_blank">Bohatei Paper</a></b>
      </div> 
      <div style="text-align: justify;"> 
       <b><a href="https://www.usenix.org/sites/default/files/conference/protected-files/sec15_slides_fayaz.pdf" target="_blank">Bohatei Slides</a></b>
      </div> 
      <div style="text-align: justify;"> 
       <b><a href="https://2459d6dc103cb5933875-c0245c5c937c5dedcca3f1764ecc9b2f.ssl.cf2.rackcdn.com/sec15/fayaz.mp4" target="_blank">Video</a></b>
      </div> 
      <div> 
       <br>
      </div> 
      <div style="text-align: center;"> 
       <b><span style="font-size: x-large;"><a href="https://github.com/ddos-defense/bohatei" target="_blank">Download&nbsp;Bohatei</a></span></b>
      </div> 
     </div>
    </article> 
    <article class="post hentry" id="6133516086853487817" itemscope itemtype="http://schema.org/BlogPosting"> 
     <h1 class="post-title entry-title" itemprop="name headline"> BruteX - Automatically Brute Force all Services Running on a Target  </h1> 
     <div class="post-header" style="position:absolute;left:-9999px"> 
      <div class="post-header-line-1"></div> 
     </div> 
     <div class="post-body entry-content" id="post-body-6133516086853487817" itemprop="articleBody"> 
      <div class="separator" style="clear: both; text-align: center;"> 
      </div> 
      <div class="separator" style="clear: both; text-align: center;"> 
       <a href="http://3.bp.blogspot.com/-Tft1CrFzHQ0/VXYp7CKOpmI/AAAAAAAAEM4/Ufzh2M3D5Ck/s1600/BruteX.png" imageanchor="1" style="margin-left: 1em; margin-right: 1em;"><img border="0" height="406" src="http://3.bp.blogspot.com/-Tft1CrFzHQ0/VXYp7CKOpmI/AAAAAAAAEM4/Ufzh2M3D5Ck/s640/BruteX.png" width="640"></a>
      </div> 
      <br> Automatically brute force all services running on a target including:
      <br> 
      <ul> 
       <li>Open ports</li> 
       <li>DNS domains</li> 
       <li>Web files</li> 
       <li>Web directories</li> 
       <li>Usernames</li> 
       <li>Passwords</li> 
      </ul> 
      <a name="more"></a>
      <br> 
      <b><span style="font-size: large;">USAGE</span></b>
      <br> 
      <pre><code>./brutex target</code></pre> 
      <br> 
      <b><span style="font-size: large;">DEPENDENCIES</span></b>
      <br> 
      <ul> 
       <li>NMap</li> 
       <li>Hydra</li> 
       <li>Wfuzz</li> 
       <li>SNMPWalk</li> 
       <li>DNSDict</li> 
      </ul> 
      <br> To brute force multiple hosts, use brutex-massscan and include the IP's/hostnames to scan in the targets.txt file.
      <br> 
      <br> 
      <br> 
      <div style="text-align: center;"> 
       <b><span style="font-size: x-large;"><a href="https://github.com/1N3/BruteX" target="_blank">Download BruteX</a></span></b>
      </div> 
     </div>
    </article> 
    <article class="post hentry" id="2645649322753175187" itemscope itemtype="http://schema.org/BlogPosting"> 
     <h1 class="post-title entry-title" itemprop="name headline"> Btproxy - Man In The Middle Analysis Tool For Bluetooth  </h1> 
     <div class="post-header" style="position:absolute;left:-9999px"> 
      <div class="post-header-line-1"></div> 
     </div> 
     <div class="post-body entry-content" id="post-body-2645649322753175187" itemprop="articleBody"> 
      <div class="separator" style="clear: both; text-align: center;"> 
       <a href="http://4.bp.blogspot.com/-PvtfYOTDXS8/ViQGg8x--5I/AAAAAAAAEt8/dZQhXuh44mc/s1600/Btproxy.jpeg" imageanchor="1" style="margin-left: 1em; margin-right: 1em;"><img border="0" height="480" src="http://4.bp.blogspot.com/-PvtfYOTDXS8/ViQGg8x--5I/AAAAAAAAEt8/dZQhXuh44mc/s640/Btproxy.jpeg" width="640"></a>
      </div> 
      <br> 
      <b> Tested Devices </b> 
      <br> 
      <ul> 
       <li> Pebble Steel smart watch </li> 
       <li> Moto 360 smart watch </li> 
       <li> OBDLink OBD-II Bluetooth Dongle </li> 
       <li> Withings Smart Baby Monitor </li> 
      </ul> If you have tried anything else, please let me know at conorpp (at) vt (dot) edu.
      <br> 
      <a name="more"></a>
      <br> 
      <b> Dependencies </b> 
      <br> 
      <ul> 
       <li> Need at least 1 Bluetooth card (either USB or internal). </li> 
       <li> Need to be running Linux, another *nix, or OS X. </li> 
       <li> BlueZ 4 </li> 
      </ul> For a debian system, run 
      <br> 
      <div> 
       <pre><code>sudo apt-get install bluez bluez-utils bluez-tools libbluetooth-dev python-dev</code></pre> 
      </div> 
      <br> 
      <b> Installation </b> 
      <br> 
      <div> 
       <pre><code>sudo python setup.py install</code></pre> 
      </div> 
      <br> 
      <b> Running </b> 
      <br> To run a simple MiTM or proxy on two devices, run 
      <br> 
      <div> 
       <pre><code>btproxy &lt;master-bt-mac-address&gt; &lt;slave-bt-mac-address&gt;</code></pre> 
      </div> Run 
      <code> btproxy </code> to get a list of command arguments. 
      <br> 
      <br> 
      <b> Example </b> 
      <br> 
      <div> 
       <pre><code># This will connect to the slave 40:14:33:66:CC:FF device and 
# wait for a connection from the master F1:64:F3:31:67:88 device
btproxy F1:64:F3:31:67:88 40:14:33:66:CC:FF</code></pre> 
      </div> Where the master is typically the phone and the slave mac address is typically the other peripherial device (smart watch, headphones, keyboard, obd2 dongle, etc). 
      <br> The master is the device the sends the connection request and the slave is the device listening for something to connect to it. 
      <br> After the proxy connects to the slave device and the master connects to the proxy device, you will be able to see traffic and modify it. 
      <br> 
      <br> 
      <b> How to find the BT MAC Address? </b> 
      <br> Well, you can look it up in the settings usually for a phone. The most robost way is to put the device in advertising mode and scan for it. 
      <br> There are two ways to scan for devices: scanning and inquiring. hcitool can be used to do this: 
      <br> 
      <div> 
       <pre><code>hcitool scan
hcitool inq</code></pre> 
      </div> To get a list of services on a device: 
      <br> 
      <div> 
       <pre><code>sdptool records &lt;bt-address&gt;</code></pre> 
      </div> 
      <br> 
      <b> Usage </b> 
      <br> Some devices may restrict connecting based on the name, class, or address of another bluetooth device. 
      <br> So the program will lookup those three properties of the target devices to be proxied, and then clone them onto the proxying adapter(s).
