      <br> Then it will first try connecting to the slave device from the cloned master adaptor. It will make a socket for each service hosted by the slave and relay traffic for each one independently. 
      <br> After the slave is connected, the cloned slave adaptor will be set to be listening for a connection from the master. At this point, the real master device should connect to the adaptor. After the master connects, the proxied connection is complete. 
      <br> 
      <br> 
      <b> Using only one adapter </b> 
      <br> This program uses either 1 or 2 Bluetooth adapters. If you use one adapter, then only the slave device will be cloned. Both devices will be cloned if 2 adapters are used; this might be necessary for more restrictive Bluetooth devices. 
      <br> 
      <br> 
      <b> Advanced Usage </b> 
      <br> Manipulation of the traffic can be handled via python by passing an inline script. Just implement the master_cb and slave_cb callback functions. This are called upon receiving data and the returned data is sent back out to the corresponding device. 
      <br> 
      <div> 
       <pre><code># replace.py
def master_cb(req):
    """
        Received something from master, about to be sent to slave.
    """
    print '&lt;&lt; ', repr(req)
    open('mastermessages.log', 'a+b').write(req)
    return req

def slave_cb(res):
    """
        Same as above but it's from slave about to be sent to master
    """
    print '&gt;&gt; ', repr(res)
    open('slavemessages.log', 'a+b').write(res)
    return res</code></pre> 
      </div> Also see the example functions for 
      <a href="https://github.com/conorpp/btproxy/blob/master/libbtproxy/replace.py#L33" target="_blank"> manipulating Pebble watch traffic in replace.py </a> 
      <br> This code can be edited and reloaded during runtime by entering 'r' into the program console. This avoids the pains of reconnecting. Any errors will be caught and regular transmission will continue. 
      <br> 
      <br> 
      <b> TODO </b> 
      <br> 
      <ul> 
       <li> BLE </li> 
       <li> Improve the file logging of the traffic and make it more interactive for </li> 
       <li> replays/manipulation. </li> 
       <li> Indicate which service is which in the output. </li> 
       <li> Provide control for disconnecting/connecting services. </li> 
       <li> PCAP file support </li> 
       <li> ncurses? </li> 
      </ul> 
      <br> 
      <b> How it works </b> 
      <br> This program starts by killing the bluetoothd process, running it again with a LD_PRELOAD pointed to a wrapper for the bind system call to block bluetoothd from binding to L2CAP port 1 (SDP). All SDP traffic goes over L2CAP port 1 so this makes it easy to MiTM/forward between the two devices and we don't have to worry about mimicking the advertising. 
      <br> The program first scans each device for their name and device class to make accurate clones. It will append the string '_btproxy' to each name to make them distinguishable from a user perspective. Alternatively, you can specify the names to use at the command line. 
      <br> The program then scans the services of the slave device. It makes a socket connection to each service and open a listening port for the master device to connect to. Once the master connects, the Proxy/MiTM is complete and output will be sent to STDOUT. 
      <br> 
      <br> 
      <b> Notes </b> 
      <br> Some bluetooth devices have different methods of pairing which makes this process more complicated. Right now it supports SPP and legacy pin pairing. 
      <br> This program doesn't yet have support for Bluetooth Low Energy. A similiar approach to BLE can be taken. 
      <br> 
      <br> 
      <b> Errors </b> 
      <br> 
      <br> 
      <b> btproxy or bluetoothd hangs </b> 
      <br> If you are using bluez 5, you should try uninstalling and installing 
      <a href="http://www.bluez.org/download/" target="_blank"> bluez 4 </a> . I've had problems with bluez 5 hanging. 
      <br> 
      <br> 
      <b> error accessing bluetooth device </b> 
      <br> Make sure the bluetooth adaptors are plugged in and enabled. 
      <br> Run 
      <br> 
      <div> 
       <pre><code>    # See the list of all adaptors
    hciconfig -a

    # Enable
    sudo hciconfig hciX up

    # if you get this message
    Can't init device hci0: Operation not possible due to RF-kill (132)

    # Then try unblocking it with the rfkill command
    sudo rfkill unblock all</code></pre> 
      </div> 
      <br> 
      <b> UserWarning: &lt;path&gt;/.python-eggs is writable by group/others </b> 
      <br> Fix 
      <br> 
      <div> 
       <pre><code>chmod g-rw,o-x &lt;path&gt;/.python-eggs</code></pre> 
      </div> 
      <br> 
      <br> 
      <div style="text-align: center;"> 
       <b> <span style="font-size: x-large;"> <a href="https://github.com/conorpp/btproxy" target="_blank"> Download Btproxy </a> </span> </b> 
      </div> 
     </div>
    </article> 
    <article class="post hentry" id="6964126321770735275" itemscope itemtype="http://schema.org/BlogPosting"> 
     <h1 class="post-title entry-title" itemprop="name headline"> Burp Suite Professional 1.6.26 - The Leading Toolkit for Web Application Security Testing  </h1> 
     <div class="post-header" style="position:absolute;left:-9999px"> 
      <div class="post-header-line-1"></div> 
     </div> 
     <div class="post-body entry-content" id="post-body-6964126321770735275" itemprop="articleBody"> 
      <div class="separator" style="clear: both; text-align: center;"> 
       <a href="http://1.bp.blogspot.com/-QX7sOJvvbcY/VehGEkxA5VI/AAAAAAAAEkg/nQZ3eT2BVqU/s1600/burpsuite.png" imageanchor="1" style="margin-left: 1em; margin-right: 1em;"><img border="0" height="448" src="http://1.bp.blogspot.com/-QX7sOJvvbcY/VehGEkxA5VI/AAAAAAAAEkg/nQZ3eT2BVqU/s640/burpsuite.png" width="640"></a>
      </div> 
      <br> 
      <div style="text-align: justify;">
        Burp Suite is an integrated platform for performing security testing of web applications. Its various tools work seamlessly together to support the entire testing process, from initial mapping and analysis of an application's attack surface, through to finding and exploiting security vulnerabilities.
      </div> 
      <div style="text-align: justify;"> 
       <br>
      </div> 
      <div style="text-align: justify;">
        Burp gives you full control, letting you combine advanced manual techniques with state-of-the-art automation, to make your work faster, more effective, and more fun.
       <br> 
       <a name="more"></a>
      </div> 
      <div style="text-align: justify;"> 
       <br>
      </div> 
      <div style="text-align: justify;">
        &nbsp;Burp Suite is an integrated platform for performing security testing of web applications. Its various tools work seamlessly together to support the entire testing process, from initial mapping and analysis of an application's attack surface, through to finding and exploiting security vulnerabilities. 
      </div> 
      <div style="text-align: justify;">
        Burp gives you full control, letting you combine advanced manual techniques with state-of-the-art automation, to make your work faster, more effective, and more fun.
      </div> 
      <div style="text-align: justify;"> 
       <br>
      </div> 
      <div style="text-align: justify;">
        Burp Suite contains the following key components:
      </div> 
      <div class="rounded-corner-box grey-box"> 
       <ul class="green-list"> 
        <li style="text-align: justify;">An intercepting <strong><a href="http://portswigger.net/burp/proxy.html">Proxy</a></strong>, which lets you inspect and modify traffic between your browser and the target application.</li> 
        <li style="text-align: justify;">An application-aware <strong><a href="http://portswigger.net/burp/spider.html">Spider</a></strong>, for crawling content and functionality.</li> 
        <li style="text-align: justify;">An advanced web application <strong><a href="http://portswigger.net/burp/scanner.html">Scanner</a></strong>, for automating the detection of numerous types of vulnerability.</li> 
        <li style="text-align: justify;">An <strong><a href="http://portswigger.net/burp/intruder.html">Intruder</a></strong> tool, for performing powerful customized attacks to find and exploit unusual vulnerabilities.</li> 
        <li style="text-align: justify;">A <strong><a href="http://portswigger.net/burp/repeater.html">Repeater</a></strong> tool, for manipulating and resending individual requests.</li> 
        <li style="text-align: justify;">A <strong><a href="http://portswigger.net/burp/sequencer.html">Sequencer</a></strong> tool, for testing the randomness of session tokens.</li> 
        <li style="text-align: justify;">The ability to <strong> <a href="http://portswigger.net/burp/help/suite_functions_savingstate.html">save your work</a></strong> and resume working later.</li> 
        <li style="text-align: justify;"><strong><a href="http://portswigger.net/burp/extender">Extensibility</a></strong>, allowing you to easily write your own plugins, to perform complex and highly customized tasks within Burp.</li> 
       </ul> 
      </div> 
      <div style="text-align: justify;"> 
       <br>
      </div> 
      <div style="text-align: justify;">
        Burp is easy to use and intuitive, allowing new users to begin working right away. Burp is also highly configurable, and contains numerous powerful features to assist the most experienced testers with their work.
      </div> 
      <br> 
      <div style="text-align: justify;"> 
       <b><span style="font-size: large;">Release Notes&nbsp;v1.6.26</span></b>
      </div> 
      <div style="text-align: justify;"> 
       <br>
      </div> 
      <div style="text-align: justify;">
        This release adds the ability to detect 
       <b>blind server-side XML/SOAP injection</b> by triggering interactions with Burp Collaborator.
      </div> 
      <div style="text-align: justify;"> 
       <br>
      </div> 
      <div style="text-align: justify;">
        Previously, Burp Scanner has detected XML/SOAP injection by submitting some XML-breaking syntax like:
      </div> 
      <pre><code>]]&gt;&gt;</code></pre> 
      <br> 
      <div style="text-align: justify;">
        and analyzing responses for any resulting error messages.
      </div> 
      <div style="text-align: justify;"> 
       <br>
      </div> 
      <div style="text-align: justify;">
        Burp now sends payloads like:
      </div> 
      <pre><code>&lt;nzf xmlns="http://a.b/"
xmlns:xsi="http://www.w3.org/2001/XMLSchema-instance" xsi:schemaLocation="http://a.b/ http://kuiqswhjt3era6olyl63pyd.burpcollaborator.net/nzf.xsd"&gt;
nzf&lt;/nzf&gt;</code></pre> 
      <div style="text-align: justify;"> 
       <span style="font-family: inherit;">and reports an appropriate issue based on any observed interactions (DNS or HTTP) that reach the Burp Collaborator server.</span>
      </div> 
      <div style="text-align: justify;"> 
       <br>
      </div> 
      <div style="text-align: justify;"> 
       <span style="font-family: inherit;">Note that this type of technique is effective </span>
       <u style="font-family: inherit;">even when the original parameter value does not contain XML</u>
       <span style="font-family: inherit;">, and there is no indication within the request or response that XML/SOAP is being used on the server side.</span>
      </div> 
      <div style="text-align: justify;"> 
       <br>
      </div> 
      <div style="text-align: justify;"> 
       <span style="font-family: inherit;">The new scan check uses both </span>
       <b style="font-family: inherit;">schema location</b>
       <span style="font-family: inherit;"> and </span>
       <b style="font-family: inherit;">XInclude</b>
       <span style="font-family: inherit;"> to cause the server-side XML parser to interact with the Collaborator server.</span>
      </div> 
      <div style="text-align: justify;"> 
       <br>
      </div> 
      <div style="text-align: justify;">
        In addition, when the original parameter value does contain XML being submitted by the client, Burp now also uses the schema location and XInclude techniques to try to induce external service interactions. (We believe that Burp is now aware of all available tricks for inducing a server-side XML parser to interact with an external network service. But we would be very happy to hear of any others that people know about.)
      </div> 
      <div style="text-align: justify;"> 
       <br>
      </div> 
      <div style="text-align: justify;"> 
       <br>
      </div> 
      <div style="text-align: center;"> 
       <b><span style="font-size: x-large;"><a href="https://portswigger.net/burp/download.html" target="_blank">Download&nbsp;Burp Suite Professional 1.6.26</a></span></b>
      </div> 
     </div>
    </article> 
    <article class="post hentry" id="1755483330623675360" itemscope itemtype="http://schema.org/BlogPosting"> 
     <h1 class="post-title entry-title" itemprop="name headline"> Burp Suite Professional v1.6.16 - The Leading Toolkit for Web Application Security Testing  </h1> 
     <div class="post-header" style="position:absolute;left:-9999px"> 
      <div class="post-header-line-1"></div> 
     </div> 
     <div class="post-body entry-content" id="post-body-1755483330623675360" itemprop="articleBody"> 
      <div class="separator" style="clear: both; text-align: center;"> 
       <a href="http://2.bp.blogspot.com/-9lV_1i3K-EA/VTeYzY_FVHI/AAAAAAAAD5c/3woTiCUiYeE/s1600/scanner_burp_suite.png" imageanchor="1" style="margin-left: 1em; margin-right: 1em;"><img border="0" src="http://2.bp.blogspot.com/-9lV_1i3K-EA/VTeYzY_FVHI/AAAAAAAAD5c/3woTiCUiYeE/s1600/scanner_burp_suite.png" height="448" width="640"></a>
      </div> 
      <br> 
      <div style="text-align: justify;">
        Burp Suite is an integrated platform for performing security testing of web applications. Its various tools work seamlessly together to support the entire testing process, from initial mapping and analysis of an application's attack surface, through to finding and exploiting security vulnerabilities. 
      </div> 
      <div style="text-align: justify;">
        Burp gives you full control, letting you combine advanced manual techniques with state-of-the-art automation, to make your work faster, more effective, and more fun.
      </div> 
      <a name="more"></a>
      <br> 
      <div style="text-align: justify;">
        Burp Suite contains the following key components:
      </div> 
      <div class="rounded-corner-box grey-box"> 
       <ul class="green-list"> 
        <li style="text-align: justify;">An intercepting <strong><a href="http://portswigger.net/burp/proxy.html">Proxy</a></strong>, which lets you inspect and modify traffic between your browser and the target application.</li> 
        <li style="text-align: justify;">An application-aware <strong><a href="http://portswigger.net/burp/spider.html">Spider</a></strong>, for crawling content and functionality.</li> 
        <li style="text-align: justify;">An advanced web application <strong><a href="http://portswigger.net/burp/scanner.html">Scanner</a></strong>, for automating the detection of numerous types of vulnerability.</li> 
        <li style="text-align: justify;">An <strong><a href="http://portswigger.net/burp/intruder.html">Intruder</a></strong> tool, for performing powerful customized attacks to find and exploit unusual vulnerabilities.</li> 
        <li style="text-align: justify;">A <strong><a href="http://portswigger.net/burp/repeater.html">Repeater</a></strong> tool, for manipulating and resending individual requests.</li> 
        <li style="text-align: justify;">A <strong><a href="http://portswigger.net/burp/sequencer.html">Sequencer</a></strong> tool, for testing the randomness of session tokens.</li> 
        <li style="text-align: justify;">The ability to <strong> <a href="http://portswigger.net/burp/help/suite_functions_savingstate.html">save your work</a></strong> and resume working later.</li> 
        <li style="text-align: justify;"><strong><a href="http://portswigger.net/burp/extender">Extensibility</a></strong>, allowing you to easily write your own plugins, to perform complex and highly customized tasks within Burp.</li> 
       </ul> 
      </div> 
      <br> 
      <div style="text-align: justify;">
        Burp is easy to use and intuitive, allowing new users to begin working right away. Burp is also highly configurable, and contains numerous powerful features to assist the most experienced testers with their work.
      </div> 
      <div style="text-align: justify;"> 
       <br>
      </div> 
      <div style="text-align: justify;"> 
       <b><span style="font-size: large;">Release Notes</span></b>
      </div> 
      <br> 
      <div style="text-align: justify;"> 
       <b>v1.6.15</b>
      </div> 
      <div style="text-align: justify;"> 
       <b><br></b> 
      </div> 
      <div class="post-body entry-content" id="post-body-1485655981582276178" itemprop="description articleBody"> 
       <div style="text-align: justify;">
         This release introduces a brand new feature: 
        <b>Burp Collaborator</b>.
       </div> 
       <div style="text-align: justify;"> 
        <br>
       </div> 
       <div style="text-align: justify;">
         Burp Collaborator is an external service that Burp can use to help discover many kinds of vulnerabilities, and has the potential to revolutionize web security testing. In the coming months, we will be adding many exciting new capabilities to Burp, based on the Collaborator technology.
       </div> 
       <ul> 
        <li style="text-align: justify;">Read today's blog post: <a href="http://blog.portswigger.net/2015/04/introducing-burp-collaborator.html">Introducing Burp Collaborator</a></li> 
        <li style="text-align: justify;">Read the full <a href="http://portswigger.net/burp/help/collaborator.html">Burp Collaborator documentation</a></li> 
       </ul> 
       <div> 
        <div style="text-align: justify;">
          This release is officially beta due to the introduction of some new types of Scanner checks, and the reliance on a new service infrastructure. However, we have tested the new capabilities thoroughly and are not aware of any stability issues.
        </div> 
       </div> 
       <div> 
        <div style="text-align: justify;"> 
         <br>
        </div> 
       </div> 
       <div> 
        <div style="text-align: justify;"> 
         <b>v1.6.16 </b>
        </div> 
        <div style="text-align: justify;"> 
         <b><br></b> 
        </div> 
        <div class="post-header"> 
         <div class="post-header-line-1"> 
         </div> 
        </div> 
        <div class="post-body entry-content" id="post-body-7960194530079029354" itemprop="description articleBody"> 
         <div style="text-align: justify;">
           This release fixes some issues with yesterday's beta release of the new Burp Collaborator feature, including a bug that may cause Burp to sometimes send some Collaborator-related test payloads even if the user has disabled use of the Collaborator feature.
         </div> 
         <div style="text-align: justify;"> 
          <br>
         </div> 
         <div style="text-align: justify;">
           This release is still officially beta while we monitor the Burp Collaborator capabilities for any further issues.
         </div> 
         <br> 
         <br> 
         <div style="text-align: center;"> 
          <b><span style="font-size: x-large;"><a href="http://portswigger.net/burp/download.html" target="_blank">Download Burp Suite Professional</a></span></b>
         </div> 
        </div> 
       </div> 
      </div> 
     </div>
    </article> 
    <article class="post hentry" id="7121857568110194069" itemscope itemtype="http://schema.org/BlogPosting"> 
     <h1 class="post-title entry-title" itemprop="name headline"> Burp Suite Professional v1.6.23 - The Leading Toolkit for Web Application Security Testing  </h1> 
     <div class="post-header" style="position:absolute;left:-9999px"> 
      <div class="post-header-line-1"></div> 
     </div> 
     <div class="post-body entry-content" id="post-body-7121857568110194069" itemprop="articleBody"> 
      <div class="separator" style="clear: both; text-align: center;"> 
       <a href="http://2.bp.blogspot.com/-9lV_1i3K-EA/VTeYzY_FVHI/AAAAAAAAD5c/3woTiCUiYeE/s1600/scanner_burp_suite.png" imageanchor="1" style="margin-left: 1em; margin-right: 1em;"><img border="0" height="448" src="http://2.bp.blogspot.com/-9lV_1i3K-EA/VTeYzY_FVHI/AAAAAAAAD5c/3woTiCUiYeE/s1600/scanner_burp_suite.png" width="640"></a>
      </div> 
      <br> 
      <div style="text-align: justify;">
        Burp Suite is an integrated platform for performing security testing of web applications. Its various tools work seamlessly together to support the entire testing process, from initial mapping and analysis of an application's attack surface, through to finding and exploiting security vulnerabilities. 
      </div> 
      <div style="text-align: justify;">
        Burp gives you full control, letting you combine advanced manual techniques with state-of-the-art automation, to make your work faster, more effective, and more fun.
      </div> 
      <a name="more"></a>
      <br> 
      <div style="text-align: justify;">
        Burp Suite contains the following key components:
      </div> 
      <div class="rounded-corner-box grey-box"> 
       <ul class="green-list"> 
        <li style="text-align: justify;">An intercepting <strong><a href="http://portswigger.net/burp/proxy.html">Proxy</a></strong>, which lets you inspect and modify traffic between your browser and the target application.</li> 
        <li style="text-align: justify;">An application-aware <strong><a href="http://portswigger.net/burp/spider.html">Spider</a></strong>, for crawling content and functionality.</li> 
        <li style="text-align: justify;">An advanced web application <strong><a href="http://portswigger.net/burp/scanner.html">Scanner</a></strong>, for automating the detection of numerous types of vulnerability.</li> 
        <li style="text-align: justify;">An <strong><a href="http://portswigger.net/burp/intruder.html">Intruder</a></strong> tool, for performing powerful customized attacks to find and exploit unusual vulnerabilities.</li> 
        <li style="text-align: justify;">A <strong><a href="http://portswigger.net/burp/repeater.html">Repeater</a></strong> tool, for manipulating and resending individual requests.</li> 
        <li style="text-align: justify;">A <strong><a href="http://portswigger.net/burp/sequencer.html">Sequencer</a></strong> tool, for testing the randomness of session tokens.</li> 
        <li style="text-align: justify;">The ability to <strong> <a href="http://portswigger.net/burp/help/suite_functions_savingstate.html">save your work</a></strong> and resume working later.</li> 
        <li style="text-align: justify;"><strong><a href="http://portswigger.net/burp/extender">Extensibility</a></strong>, allowing you to easily write your own plugins, to perform complex and highly customized tasks within Burp.</li> 
       </ul> 
      </div> 
      <br> 
      <div style="text-align: justify;">
        Burp is easy to use and intuitive, allowing new users to begin working right away. Burp is also highly configurable, and contains numerous powerful features to assist the most experienced testers with their work.
      </div> 
      <div style="text-align: justify;"> 
       <br>
      </div> 
      <div style="text-align: justify;"> 
       <b><span style="font-size: large;">Release Notes</span></b>
      </div> 
      <br> 
      <div style="text-align: justify;"> 
       <b>v1.6.23</b>
      </div> 
      <div style="text-align: justify;"> 
       <b><br></b>
      </div> 
      <div style="text-align: justify;">
        This release adds a new scan check for 
       <b>external service interaction</b> and 
       <b>out-of-band resource load</b> via injected XML doctype tags containing 
       <b>entity parameters</b>. Burp now sends payloads like:
      </div> 
      <br> 
      <span style="font-family: Courier New, Courier, monospace;">&lt;?xml version='1.0' standalone='no'?&gt;&lt;!DOCTYPE foo [&lt;!ENTITY % f5a30 SYSTEM "http://u1w9aaozql7z31394loost.burpcollaborator.net"&gt;%f5a30; ]&gt;</span>
      <br> 
      <br> 
      <div style="text-align: justify;">
        and reports an appropriate issue based on any observed interactions (DNS or HTTP) that reach the Burp Collaborator server.
      </div> 
      <div style="text-align: justify;"> 
       <br>
      </div> 
      <div style="text-align: justify;">
        The release also fixes some issues:
      </div> 
      <div style="text-align: justify;"> 
       <br>
      </div> 
      <ul> 
       <li style="text-align: justify;">Some bugs affecting the saving and restoring of Burp state files.</li> 
       <li style="text-align: justify;">A bug in the Collaborator server where the auto-generated self-signed certificate does not use a wildcard prefix in the CN. This issue only affects private Collaborator server deployments where a custom SSL certificate has not been configured.</li> 
      </ul> 
      <div style="text-align: justify;"> 
       <br>
      </div> 
      <div style="text-align: center;"> 
       <b><span style="font-size: x-large;"><a href="https://portswigger.net/burp/download.html" target="_blank">Download&nbsp;Burp Suite Professional v1.6.23</a></span></b>
      </div> 
     </div>
    </article> 
    <article class="post hentry" id="5545645667620181876" itemscope itemtype="http://schema.org/BlogPosting"> 
     <h1 class="post-title entry-title" itemprop="name headline"> Burpkit - Next-Gen Burpsuite Penetration Testing Tool  </h1> 
     <div class="post-header" style="position:absolute;left:-9999px"> 
      <div class="post-header-line-1"></div> 
     </div> 
     <div class="post-body entry-content" id="post-body-5545645667620181876" itemprop="articleBody"> 
      <div class="separator" style="clear: both; text-align: center;"> 
       <a href="http://1.bp.blogspot.com/-JT12bENSJ-A/ViR7Gr2Zh4I/AAAAAAAAEuY/WOskXI4MbVk/s1600/BurpKit.png" imageanchor="1" style="margin-left: 1em; margin-right: 1em;"><img border="0" height="320" src="http://1.bp.blogspot.com/-JT12bENSJ-A/ViR7Gr2Zh4I/AAAAAAAAEuY/WOskXI4MbVk/s320/BurpKit.png" width="320"></a>
      </div> 
      <br> 
      <div style="text-align: justify;">
        Welcome to the next generation of web application penetration testing - using WebKit to own the web. BurpKit is a BurpSuite plugin which helps in assessing complex web apps that render the contents of their pages dynamically. It also provides a bi-directional JavaScript bridge API which allows users to create quick one-off BurpSuite plugin prototypes which can interact directly with the DOM and Burp's extender API.
      </div> 
      <a name="more"></a>
      <br> 
      <span style="font-size: large;"> <b> System Requirements </b> </span> 
      <br> BurpKit has the following system requirements: 
      <br> 
      <ul> 
       <li> Oracle JDK &gt;=8u50 and &lt;9 ( <a href="http://www.oracle.com/technetwork/java/javase/downloads/index.html" target="_blank"> Download </a> ) </li> 
       <li> At least 4GB of RAM </li> 
      </ul> 
      <br> 
      <span style="font-size: large;"> <b> Installation </b> </span> 
      <br> Installing BurpKit is simple: 
      <br> 
      <ol> 
       <li> Download the latest prebuilt release from the <a href="https://github.com/allfro/BurpKit/releases" target="_blank"> GitHub releases page </a> . </li> 
       <li> Open BurpSuite and navigate to the <code> Extender </code> tab. </li> 
       <li> Under <code> Burp Extensions </code> click the <code> Add </code> button. </li> 
       <li> In the <code> Load Burp Extension </code> dialog, make sure that <code> Extension Type </code> is set to <code> Java </code> and click the <code> Select file ... </code> button under <code> Extension Details </code> . </li> 
       <li> Select the <code> BurpKit-&lt;version&gt;.jar </code> file and click <code> Next </code> when done. </li> 
      </ol> If all goes well, you will see three additional top-level tabs appear in BurpSuite: 
      <br> 
      <ol> 
       <li> <code> BurpKitty </code> : a courtesy browser for navigating the web within BurpSuite. </li> 
       <li> <code> BurpScript IDE </code> : a lightweight integrated development environment for writing JavaScript-based BurpSuite plugins and other things. </li> 
       <li> <code> Jython </code> : an integrated python interpreter console and lightweight script text editor.</li> 
      </ol> 
      <br> 
      <span style="font-size: large;"> <b> BurpScript </b> </span> 
      <br> 
      <strong> BurpScript </strong> enables users to write desktop-based JavaScript applications as well as BurpSuite extensions using the JavaScript scripting language. This is achieved by injecting two new objects by default into the DOM on page load: 
      <br> 
      <ol> 
       <li> <code> burpKit </code> : provides numerous features including file system I/O support and easy JS library injection. </li> 
       <li> <code> burpCallbacks </code> : the JavaScript equivalent of the <code> IBurpExtenderCallbacks </code> interface in <code> Java </code> with a few slight modifications. </li> 
      </ol> Take a look at the 
      <code> examples </code> folder for more information. 
      <br> 
      <br> 
      <span style="font-size: large;"> <b> More Information? </b> </span> 
      <br> A readable version of the 
      <code> docs </code> can be found at 
      <a href="http://allfro.github.io/BurpKit/" target="_blank"> here </a> 
      <br> 
      <br> 
      <br> 
      <div style="text-align: center;"> 
       <b> <span style="font-size: x-large;"> <a href="https://github.com/allfro/BurpKit" target="_blank"> Download Burpkit </a> </span> </b> 
      </div> 
     </div>
    </article> 
    <article class="post hentry" id="5365139871297978526" itemscope itemtype="http://schema.org/BlogPosting"> 
     <h1 class="post-title entry-title" itemprop="name headline"> BWA - OWASP Broken Web Applications Project  </h1> 
     <div class="post-header" style="position:absolute;left:-9999px"> 
      <div class="post-header-line-1"></div> 
     </div> 
     <div class="post-body entry-content" id="post-body-5365139871297978526" itemprop="articleBody"> 
      <div class="separator" style="clear: both; text-align: center;"> 
       <a href="http://2.bp.blogspot.com/-ahhw6aWCD_k/Va0NIJShzlI/AAAAAAAAEZ0/uKt1hkY7L5o/s1600/OWASP%2BBroken%2BWeb%2BApplications%2BProject.jpg" imageanchor="1" style="margin-left: 1em; margin-right: 1em;"><img border="0" src="http://2.bp.blogspot.com/-ahhw6aWCD_k/Va0NIJShzlI/AAAAAAAAEZ0/uKt1hkY7L5o/s1600/OWASP%2BBroken%2BWeb%2BApplications%2BProject.jpg"></a>
      </div> 
      <br> 
      <div style="text-align: justify;">
        A collection of vulnerable web applications that is distributed on a Virtual Machine.
      </div> 
      <a name="more"></a>
      <br> 
      <div style="text-align: justify;"> 
       <b><span style="font-size: large;">Description</span></b>
      </div> 
      <div style="text-align: justify;"> 
       <br>
      </div> 
      <div style="text-align: justify;">
        The Broken Web Applications (BWA) Project produces a Virtual Machine running a variety of applications with known vulnerabilities for those interested in: 
      </div> 
      <ul> 
       <li style="text-align: justify;">learning about web application security </li> 
       <li style="text-align: justify;">testing manual assessment techniques </li> 
       <li style="text-align: justify;">testing automated tools </li> 
       <li style="text-align: justify;">testing source code analysis tools </li> 
       <li style="text-align: justify;">observing web attacks </li> 
       <li style="text-align: justify;">testing WAFs and similar code technologies </li> 
      </ul> 
      <div style="text-align: justify;"> 
       <br>
      </div> 
      <div style="text-align: justify;">
        All the while saving people interested in doing either learning or testing the pain of having to compile, configure, and catalog all of the things normally involved in doing this process from scratch.
      </div> 
      <br> 
      <br> 
      <div style="text-align: center;"> 
       <b><span style="font-size: x-large;"><a href="https://code.google.com/p/owaspbwa/wiki/OWASPBWABitTorrentDownload" target="_blank">Download&nbsp;OWASP Broken Web Applications Project</a></span></b>
      </div> 
     </div>
    </article> 
    <article class="post hentry" id="3486643052764442840" itemscope itemtype="http://schema.org/BlogPosting"> 
     <h1 class="post-title entry-title" itemprop="name headline"> BypassWAF - Burp Plugin to Bypass Some WAF Devices  </h1> 
     <div class="post-header" style="position:absolute;left:-9999px"> 
      <div class="post-header-line-1"></div> 
     </div> 
     <div class="post-body entry-content" id="post-body-3486643052764442840" itemprop="articleBody"> 
      <div class="separator" style="clear: both; text-align: center;"> 
       <a href="http://3.bp.blogspot.com/-dRqUU9yAakA/VWsjIKI3DiI/AAAAAAAAEJ0/tMXIGtgM4A8/s1600/bypasswaf.png" imageanchor="1" style="margin-left: 1em; margin-right: 1em;"><img border="0" src="http://3.bp.blogspot.com/-dRqUU9yAakA/VWsjIKI3DiI/AAAAAAAAEJ0/tMXIGtgM4A8/s1600/bypasswaf.png"></a>
      </div> 
      <br> 
      <div style="text-align: justify;">
        Add headers to all Burp requests to bypass some WAF products. This extension will automatically add the following headers to all requests.
      </div> 
      <pre><code>  X-Originating-IP: 127.0.0.1
  X-Forwarded-For: 127.0.0.1
  X-Remote-IP: 127.0.0.1
  X-Remote-Addr: 127.0.0.1</code></pre> 
      <br> 
      <div style="text-align: justify;"> 
       <b><span style="font-size: large;">Usage</span></b>
      </div> 
      <div style="text-align: justify;"> 
       <br>
      </div> 
      <div style="text-align: justify;">
        Steps include:
      </div> 
      <ol> 
       <li style="text-align: justify;">Add extension to burp</li> 
       <li style="text-align: justify;">Create a session handling rule in Burp that invokes this extension</li> 
       <li style="text-align: justify;">Modify the scope to include applicable tools and URLs</li> 
       <li style="text-align: justify;">Configure the bypass options on the "Bypass WAF" tab</li> 
       <li style="text-align: justify;">Test away</li> 
      </ol> 
      <div style="text-align: justify;">
        Read more&nbsp;
       <a href="https://www.codewatch.org/blog/?p=408" target="_codewatch"></a>
       <a href="https://www.codewatch.org/blog/?p=408" target="_blank">here</a>.
      </div> 
      <a name="more"></a>
      <br> 
      <div style="text-align: justify;"> 
       <b><span style="font-size: large;">Features</span></b>
      </div> 
      <div style="text-align: justify;"> 
       <br>
      </div> 
      <div style="text-align: justify;">
        All of the features are based on Jason Haddix's work found 
       <a href="http://h30499.www3.hp.com/t5/Fortify-Application-Security/Bypassing-web-application-firewalls-using-HTTP-headers/ba-p/6418366#.VGlMR-90wsd" target="_hp">here</a>, and Ivan Ristic's WAF bypass work found 
       <a href="https://github.com/ironbee/waf-research" target="_git">here</a> and 
       <a href="https://media.blackhat.com/bh-us-12/Briefings/Ristic/BH_US_12_Ristic_Protocol_Level_WP.pdf" target="_blackhat">here</a>.
      </div> 
      <div style="text-align: justify;"> 
       <br>
      </div> 
      <div style="text-align: justify;">
        Bypass WAF contains the following features:
      </div> 
      <div class="separator" style="clear: both; text-align: center;"> 
       <a href="http://3.bp.blogspot.com/-E5T6Cgj79qA/VWsj8xD5wNI/AAAAAAAAEJ8/YrHBMhtxuEk/s1600/bypasswaf_options.png" imageanchor="1" style="margin-left: 1em; margin-right: 1em;"><img border="0" height="226" src="http://3.bp.blogspot.com/-E5T6Cgj79qA/VWsj8xD5wNI/AAAAAAAAEJ8/YrHBMhtxuEk/s640/bypasswaf_options.png" width="640"></a>
      </div> 
      <br> 
      <div style="text-align: justify;">
        A description of each feature follows:
      </div> 
      <ol> 
       <li style="text-align: justify;">Users can modify the X-Originating-IP, X-Forwarded-For, X-Remote-IP, X-Remote-Addr headers sent in each request. This is probably the top bypass technique i the tool. It isn't unusual for a WAF to be configured to trust itself (127.0.0.1) or an upstream proxy device, which is what this bypass targets.</li> 
       <li style="text-align: justify;">The "Content-Type" header can remain unchanged in each request, removed from all requests, or by modified to one of the many other options for each request. Some WAFs will only decode/evaluate requests based on known content types, this feature targets that weakness.</li> 
       <li style="text-align: justify;">The "Host" header can also be modified. Poorly configured WAFs might be configured to only evaluate requests based on the correct FQDN of the host found in this header, which is what this bypass targets.</li> 
       <li style="text-align: justify;">The request type option allows the Burp user to only use the remaining bypass techniques on the given request method of "GET" or "POST", or to apply them on all requests.</li> 
       <li style="text-align: justify;">The path injection feature can leave a request unmodified, inject random path info information (/path/to/example.php/randomvalue?restofquery), or inject a random path parameter (/path/to/example.php;randomparam=randomvalue?resetofquery). This can be used to bypass poorly written rules that rely on path information.</li> 
       <li style="text-align: justify;">The path obfuscation feature modifies the last forward slash in the path to a random value, or by default does nothing. The last slash can be modified to one of many values that in many cases results in a still valid request but can bypass poorly written WAF rules that rely on path information.</li> 
       <li style="text-align: justify;">The parameter obfuscation feature is language specific. PHP will discard a + at the beginning of each parameter, but a poorly written WAF rule might be written for specific parameter names, thus ignoring parameters with a + at the beginning. Similarly, ASP discards a % at the beginning of each parameter.</li> 
       <li style="text-align: justify;">The "Set Configuration" button activates all the settings that you have chosen.</li> 
      </ol> 
      <div style="text-align: justify;">
        All of these features can be combined to provide multiple bypass options.
      </div> 
      <div style="text-align: justify;"> 
       <br>
      </div> 
      <div style="text-align: justify;"> 
       <br>
      </div> 
      <div style="text-align: center;"> 
       <b><span style="font-size: x-large;"><a href="https://github.com/codewatchorg/bypasswaf" target="_blank">Download&nbsp;BypassWAF</a></span></b>
      </div> 
     </div>
    </article> 
    <article class="post hentry" id="3365493071037458016" itemscope itemtype="http://schema.org/BlogPosting"> 
     <h1 class="post-title entry-title" itemprop="name headline"> CapTipper - Malicious HTTP traffic explorer tool  </h1> 
     <div class="post-header" style="position:absolute;left:-9999px"> 
      <div class="post-header-line-1"></div> 
     </div> 
     <div class="post-body entry-content" id="post-body-3365493071037458016" itemprop="articleBody"> 
      <div class="separator" style="clear: both; text-align: center;"> 
       <a href="http://3.bp.blogspot.com/-1B7By283xXg/VMZQXNBKvAI/AAAAAAAADmk/6bF3m4NWzLI/s1600/CapTipper.png" imageanchor="1" style="margin-left: 1em; margin-right: 1em;"><img border="0" src="http://3.bp.blogspot.com/-1B7By283xXg/VMZQXNBKvAI/AAAAAAAADmk/6bF3m4NWzLI/s1600/CapTipper.png" height="330" width="640"></a>
      </div> 
      <br> 
      <div style="text-align: justify;">
        CapTipper is a python tool to analyze, explore and revive HTTP malicious traffic.
      </div> 
      <div style="text-align: justify;"> 
       <br>
      </div> 
      <div style="text-align: justify;">
        CapTipper sets up a web server that acts exactly as the server in the PCAP file,&nbsp;and contains internal tools, with a powerful interactive console, for analysis and inspection of the hosts, objects and conversations found.
      </div> 
      <br> 
      <div style="text-align: justify;">
        The tool provides the security researcher with easy access to the files and the understanding of the network flow,and is useful when trying to research exploits, pre-conditions, versions, obfuscations, plugins and shellcodes.
       <br> 
       <a name="more"></a>
      </div> 
      <div style="text-align: justify;">
        Feeding CapTipper with a drive-by traffic capture (e.g of an exploit kit) displays the user with the requests URI's that were sent and responses meta-data.
      </div> 
      <br> 
      <div style="text-align: justify;">
        The user can at this point browse to 
       <b>http://127.0.0.1/[URI]</b> and receive the response back to the browser.
      </div> 
      <div style="text-align: justify;"> 
       <br>
      </div> 
      <div style="text-align: justify;">
        In addition, an interactive shell is launched for deeper investigation using various commands such as: hosts, hexdump, info, ungzip, body, client, dump and more...
      </div> 
      <div style="text-align: justify;"> 
       <br>
      </div> 
      <div style="text-align: justify;"> 
       <br>
      </div> 
      <div style="text-align: center;"> 
       <b><span class="Apple-style-span" style="font-size: x-large;"><a href="https://github.com/omriher/CapTipper" target="_blank">Download CapTipper</a></span></b>
      </div> 
      <br> 
     </div>
    </article> 
    <article class="post hentry" id="1159981099696167173" itemscope itemtype="http://schema.org/BlogPosting"> 
     <h1 class="post-title entry-title" itemprop="name headline"> CenoCipher - Easy-To-Use, End-To-End Encrypted Communications Tool  </h1> 
     <div class="post-header" style="position:absolute;left:-9999px"> 
      <div class="post-header-line-1"></div> 
     </div> 
     <div class="post-body entry-content" id="post-body-1159981099696167173" itemprop="articleBody"> 
      <div class="separator" style="clear: both; text-align: center;"> 
       <a href="http://4.bp.blogspot.com/-j0Ws_w_YcDg/VoKg46KRdsI/AAAAAAAAE9g/NMt8CR_NggA/s1600/CC4Screenshot.png" imageanchor="1" style="margin-left: 1em; margin-right: 1em;"><img border="0" height="376" src="http://4.bp.blogspot.com/-j0Ws_w_YcDg/VoKg46KRdsI/AAAAAAAAE9g/NMt8CR_NggA/s640/CC4Screenshot.png" width="640"></a>
      </div> 
      <br> 
      <div style="text-align: justify;">
        CenoCipher is a free, open-source, easy-to-use tool for exchanging secure encrypted communications over the internet. It uses strong cryptography to convert messages and files into encrypted cipher-data, which can then be sent to the recipient via regular email or any other channel available, such as instant messaging or shared cloud storage.
      </div> 
      <a name="more"></a>
      <br> 
      <h2 style="text-align: justify;"> Features at a glance</h2> 
      <ul> 
       <li style="text-align: justify;">Simple for anyone to use. Just type a message, click Encrypt, and go</li> 
       <li style="text-align: justify;">Handles messages and file attachments together easily</li> 
       <li style="text-align: justify;">End-to-end encryption, performed entirely on the user's machine</li> 
       <li style="text-align: justify;">No dependence on any specific intermediary channel. Works with any communication method available</li> 
       <li style="text-align: justify;">Uses three strong cryptographic algorithms in combination to triple-protect data</li> 
       <li style="text-align: justify;">Optional steganography feature for embedding encrypted data within a Jpeg image</li> 
       <li style="text-align: justify;">No installation needed - fully portable application can be run from anywhere</li> 
       <li style="text-align: justify;">Unencrypted data is never written to disk - unless requested by the user</li> 
       <li style="text-align: justify;">Multiple input/output modes for convenient operation</li> 
      </ul> 
      <div style="text-align: justify;"> 
       <br>
      </div> 
      <h2 style="text-align: justify;"> Technical details</h2> 
      <ul> 
       <li style="text-align: justify;">Open source, written in C++</li> 
       <li style="text-align: justify;">AES/Rijndael, Twofish and Serpent ciphers (256-bit keysize variants), cascaded together in CTR mode for triple-encryption of messages and files</li> 
       <li style="text-align: justify;">HMAC-SHA-256 for construction of message authentication code</li> 
       <li style="text-align: justify;">PBKDF2-HMAC-SHA256 for derivation of separate AES, Twofish and Serpent keys from user-chosen passphrase</li> 
       <li style="text-align: justify;">Cryptographically safe pseudo-random number generator ISAAC for production of Initialization Vectors (AES/Twofish/Serpent) and Salts (PBKDF2)</li> 
      </ul> 
      <div style="text-align: justify;"> 
       <br>
      </div> 
      <div> 
       <h2 style="text-align: justify;"> Version History (Change Log)</h2> 
       <h3 style="text-align: justify;"> Version 4.0 (December 05, 2015)</h3> 
       <ul> 
        <li style="text-align: justify;">Drastically overhauled and streamlined interface</li> 
        <li style="text-align: justify;">Added multiple input/output modes for cipher-data</li> 
        <li style="text-align: justify;">Added user control over unencrypted disk writes</li> 
        <li style="text-align: justify;">Added auto-decrypt and open-with support</li> 
        <li style="text-align: justify;">Added more entropy to Salt/IV generation</li> 
       </ul> 
       <h3 style="text-align: justify;"> Version 3.0 (June 29, 2015)</h3> 
       <ul> 
        <li style="text-align: justify;">Added Serpent algorithm for cascaded triple-encryption </li> 
        <li style="text-align: justify;">Added steganography option for concealing data within Jpeg</li> 
        <li style="text-align: justify;">Added conversation mode for convenience</li> 
        <li style="text-align: justify;">Improved header obfuscation for higher security</li> 
        <li style="text-align: justify;">Increased entropy in generation of separate salt/IVs used by ciphers</li> 
        <li style="text-align: justify;">Many other enhancements under the hood</li> 
       </ul> 
       <h3 style="text-align: justify;"> Version 2.1 (December 6, 2014)</h3> 
       <ul> 
        <li style="text-align: justify;">Change cascaded encryption cipher modes from CBC to CTR for extra security</li> 
        <li style="text-align: justify;">Improve PBKDF2 rounds determination and conveyance format</li> 
        <li style="text-align: justify;">Fix minor bug related to Windows DPI font scaling</li> 
        <li style="text-align: justify;">Fix minor bug affecting received filenames when saved by user</li> 
       </ul> 
       <h3 style="text-align: justify;"> Version 2.0 (November 26, 2014)</h3> 
       <ul> 
        <li style="text-align: justify;">Initial open-source release</li> 
        <li style="text-align: justify;">Many enhancements to encryption algorithms and hash functions</li> 
       </ul> 
       <h3 style="text-align: justify;"> Version 1.0 (June 10, 2014)</h3> 
       <ul> 
        <li style="text-align: justify;">Original program release (closed source / beta)</li> 
       </ul> 
       <div> 
        <br>
       </div> 
      </div> 
      <div style="text-align: center;"> 
       <a href="https://gitlab.com/cenocipher/cenocipher" target="_blank"><b><span style="font-size: x-large;">Download&nbsp;CenoCipher</span></b></a>
      </div> 
     </div>
    </article> 
    <article class="post hentry" id="5483873473483395734" itemscope itemtype="http://schema.org/BlogPosting"> 
     <h1 class="post-title entry-title" itemprop="name headline"> Cheat - Create and view interactive cheatsheets on the command-line  </h1> 
     <div class="post-header" style="position:absolute;left:-9999px"> 
      <div class="post-header-line-1"></div> 
     </div> 
     <div class="post-body entry-content" id="post-body-5483873473483395734" itemprop="articleBody"> 
      <div class="separator" style="clear: both; text-align: center;"> 
       <a href="http://4.bp.blogspot.com/-NVbOA4wVWCU/VYLyehg9E4I/AAAAAAAAEPc/4VQgjceUAhY/s1600/cheat.png" imageanchor="1" style="margin-left: 1em; margin-right: 1em;"><img border="0" height="204" src="http://4.bp.blogspot.com/-NVbOA4wVWCU/VYLyehg9E4I/AAAAAAAAEPc/4VQgjceUAhY/s640/cheat.png" width="640"></a>
      </div> 
      <br> 
      <div style="text-align: justify;"> 
       <code>cheat</code> allows you to create and view interactive cheatsheets on the command-line. It was designed to help remind *nix system administrators of options for commands that they use frequently, but not frequently enough to remember.
      </div> 
      <a name="more"></a>
      <br> 
      <div style="text-align: justify;"> 
       <code>cheat</code> depends only on 
       <code>python</code> and 
       <code>pip</code>.
      </div> 
      <div style="text-align: justify;"> 
       <br>
      </div> 
      <div style="text-align: justify;"> 
       <b><span style="font-size: large;"> Example</span></b>
      </div> 
      <br> The next time you're forced to disarm a nuclear weapon without consulting Google, you may run:
      <br> 
      <pre><code>cheat tar
</code></pre> You will be presented with a cheatsheet resembling:
      <br> 
      <pre><code># To extract an uncompressed archive: 
tar -xvf /path/to/foo.tar

# To extract a .gz archive:
tar -xzvf /path/to/foo.tgz

# To create a .gz archive:
tar -czvf /path/to/foo.tgz /path/to/foo/

# To extract a .bz2 archive:
tar -xjvf /path/to/foo.tgz

# To create a .bz2 archive:
tar -cjvf /path/to/foo.tgz /path/to/foo/
</code></pre> To see what cheatsheets are availble, run 
      <code>cheat -l</code>.
      <br> Note that, while 
      <code>cheat</code> was designed primarily for *nix system administrators, it is agnostic as to what content it stores. If you would like to use 
      <code>cheat</code> to store notes on your favorite cookie recipes, feel free.
      <br> 
      <br> 
      <b><span style="font-size: large;"> Installing</span></b>
      <br> 
      <br> 
      <b> Using pip</b>
      <br> 
      <pre><code>sudo pip install cheat
</code></pre> 
      <br> 
      <b> Using homebrew</b>
      <br> 
      <pre><code>brew install cheat
</code></pre> 
      <br> 
      <b> Manually</b>
      <br> First install the required python dependencies with:
      <br> 
      <pre><code>sudo pip install docopt pygments
</code></pre> Then, clone this repository, 
      <code>cd</code> into it, and run:
      <br> 
      <pre><code>sudo python setup.py install
</code></pre> 
      <br> 
      <b><span style="font-size: large;"> Modifying Cheatsheets</span></b>
      <br> 
      <br> 
      <div style="text-align: justify;">
        The value of 
       <code>cheat</code> is that it allows you to create your own cheatsheets - the defaults are meant to serve only as a starting point, and can and should be modified.
      </div> 
      <div style="text-align: justify;"> 
       <br>
      </div> 
      <div style="text-align: justify;">
        Cheatsheets are stored in the 
       <code>~/.cheat/</code> directory, and are named on a per-keyphrase basis. In other words, the content for the 
       <code>tar</code> cheatsheet lives in the 
       <code>~/.cheat/tar</code> file.
      </div> 
      <div style="text-align: justify;"> 
       <br>
      </div> 
      <div style="text-align: justify;">
        Provided that you have an 
       <code>EDITOR</code> environment variable set, you may edit cheatsheets with:
      </div> 
      <pre style="text-align: justify;"><code>cheat -e foo
</code></pre> 
      <div style="text-align: justify;"> 
       <br>
      </div> 
      <div style="text-align: justify;">
        If the 'foo' cheatsheet already exists, it will be opened for editing. Otherwise, it will be created automatically.
      </div> 
      <div style="text-align: justify;"> 
       <br>
      </div> 
      <div style="text-align: justify;">
        After you've customized your cheatsheets, I urge you to track 
       <code>~/.cheat/</code> along with your 
       <a href="http://dotfiles.github.io/">dotfiles</a>.
      </div> 
      <br> 
      <br> 
      <div style="text-align: center;"> 
       <b><span style="font-size: x-large;"><a href="https://github.com/chrisallenlane/cheat" target="_blank">Download Cheat</a></span></b>
      </div> 
     </div>
    </article> 
    <article class="post hentry" id="7033263720674221222" itemscope itemtype="http://schema.org/BlogPosting"> 
     <h1 class="post-title entry-title" itemprop="name headline"> Chrome Autofill Viewer - Tool to View or Delete Autocomplete data from Google Chrome browser  </h1> 
     <div class="post-header" style="position:absolute;left:-9999px"> 
      <div class="post-header-line-1"></div> 
     </div> 
     <div class="post-body entry-content" id="post-body-7033263720674221222" itemprop="articleBody"> 
      <div class="separator" style="clear: both; text-align: center;"> 
       <a href="http://4.bp.blogspot.com/-A0NiKEfg06A/VXh5ELURokI/AAAAAAAAENc/b4X8p05EplQ/s1600/chromeautofillviewer.jpg" imageanchor="1" style="margin-left: 1em; margin-right: 1em;"><img border="0" height="488" src="http://4.bp.blogspot.com/-A0NiKEfg06A/VXh5ELURokI/AAAAAAAAENc/b4X8p05EplQ/s640/chromeautofillviewer.jpg" width="640"></a>
      </div> 
      <br> 
      <div style="text-align: justify;"> 
       <strong>Chrome Autofill Viewer</strong> is the free tool to easily see and delete all your autocomplete data from Google Chrome browser. 
      </div> 
      <div style="text-align: justify;"> 
       <br>
      </div> 
      <div style="text-align: justify;">
        Chrome stores Autofill entries (typically form fields) such as login name, pin, passwords, email, address, phone, credit/debit card number, search history etc in an internal database file.
      </div> 
      <a name="more"></a>
      <br> 
      <div style="text-align: justify;">
        'Chrome Autofill Viewer' helps you to 
       <b>automatically find</b> and view all the Autofill history data from Chrome browser. For each of the entry, it display following details, 
      </div> 
      <ul> 
       <li style="text-align: justify;">Field Name</li> 
       <li style="text-align: justify;"> Value</li> 
       <li style="text-align: justify;">Total Used Count</li> 
       <li style="text-align: justify;"> First Used Date</li> 
       <li style="text-align: justify;"> Last Used Date</li> 
      </ul> 
      <div style="text-align: justify;">
        You can also use it to view from history file belonging to 
       <b>another user on same or remote system</b>. It also provides one click solution to 
       <b>delete all</b> the displayed Autofill data from the history file. 
      </div> 
      <div style="text-align: justify;"> 
       <br>
      </div> 
      <div style="text-align: justify;">
        It is very simple to use for everyone, especially makes it handy tool for 
       <b>Forensic investigators</b>. 
      </div> 
      <div style="text-align: justify;"> 
       <br>
      </div> 
      <div style="text-align: justify;">
        Chrome Autofill Viewer is fully portable and works on both 32-bit &amp; 64-bit platforms starting from Windows XP to 
       <b>Windows 8.</b>
      </div> 
      <div style="text-align: justify;"> 
       <b><br></b> 
      </div> 
      <div style="text-align: justify;"> 
       <b><span style="font-size: large;">Features </span></b>
      </div> 
      <ul> 
       <li style="text-align: justify;">Instantly view all the Autofill list from Chrome browser</li> 
       <li style="text-align: justify;">On startup, it auto detects Autofill file from Chrome's default profile location</li> 
       <li style="text-align: justify;">Sort feature to arrange the data in various order to make it easier to search through 100's of entries.</li> 
       <li style="text-align: justify;">Delete all the Autofill data with just a click of button</li> 
       <li style="text-align: justify;">Save the displayed Autofill list to HTML/XML/TEXT/CSV file</li> 
       <li style="text-align: justify;">Easier and faster to use with its enhanced user friendly GUI interface</li> 
       <li style="text-align: justify;">Fully Portable, does not require any third party components like JAVA, .NET etc</li> 
       <li style="text-align: justify;">Support for local Installation and uninstallation of the software</li> 
      </ul> 
      <div style="text-align: justify;"> 
       <br>
      </div> 
      <div> 
       <div style="text-align: justify;"> 
        <b><span style="font-size: large;">How to Use?</span></b>
       </div> 
      </div> 
      <div style="text-align: justify;"> 
       <br>
      </div> 
      <div style="text-align: justify;">
        Chrome Autofill Viewer is easy to use with its simple GUI interface.
      </div> 
      <div style="text-align: justify;"> 
       <br>
      </div> 
      <div style="text-align: justify;">
        Here are the brief usage details
      </div> 
      <ul> 
       <li style="text-align: justify;">Launch ChromeAutofillViewer on your system </li> 
       <li style="text-align: justify;">By default it will automatically find and display the autofill file from default profile location of Chrome. You can also select the desired file manually. </li> 
       <li style="text-align: justify;">Next click on <span class="highlight">'Show All'</span> button and all stored Autofill data will be displayed in the list as shown in screenshot 1 below.</li> 
       <li style="text-align: justify;">If you want to remove all the entries, click on 'Delete All' button below.</li> 
       <li style="text-align: justify;">Finally you can save all displayed entries to <span class="highlight">HTML/XML/TEXT/CSV </span>file by clicking on 'Export' button and then select the type of file from the drop down box of 'Save File Dialog'.</li> 
      </ul> 
      <div> 
       <div style="text-align: justify;"> 
        <br>
       </div> 
      </div> 
      <div> 
       <div style="text-align: center;"> 
        <b><span style="font-size: x-large;"><a href="http://securityxploded.com/chrome-autofill-viewer.php" target="_blank">Download&nbsp;Chrome Autofill Viewer</a></span></b>
       </div> 
      </div> 
     </div>
    </article> 
    <article class="post hentry" id="342216104287939047" itemscope itemtype="http://schema.org/BlogPosting"> 
     <h1 class="post-title entry-title" itemprop="name headline"> ChromePass - Chrome Browser Password Recovery Tool  </h1> 
     <div class="post-header" style="position:absolute;left:-9999px"> 
      <div class="post-header-line-1"></div> 
     </div> 
     <div class="post-body entry-content" id="post-body-342216104287939047" itemprop="articleBody"> 
      <div class="separator" style="clear: both; text-align: center;"> 
       <a href="http://2.bp.blogspot.com/-372isX5-OFk/VWslKSLEljI/AAAAAAAAEKE/8dTcLRP107I/s1600/chromepass.gif" imageanchor="1" style="margin-left: 1em; margin-right: 1em;"><img border="0" src="http://2.bp.blogspot.com/-372isX5-OFk/VWslKSLEljI/AAAAAAAAEKE/8dTcLRP107I/s1600/chromepass.gif"></a>
      </div> 
      <br> 
      <div style="text-align: justify;">
        ChromePass is a small password recovery tool that allows you to view the user names and passwords stored by Google Chrome Web browser. For each password entry, the following information is displayed: Origin URL, Action URL, User Name Field, Password Field, User Name, Password, and Created Time. 
      </div> 
      <div style="text-align: justify;"> 
       <br>
      </div> 
      <div style="text-align: justify;">
        You can select one or more items and then save them into text/html/xml file or copy them to the clipboard.
       <br> 
       <a name="more"></a>
      </div> 
      <div style="text-align: justify;"> 
       <br>
      </div> 
      <div style="text-align: justify;"> 
       <b><span style="font-size: large;"> Using ChromePass</span></b>
      </div> 
      <div style="text-align: justify;"> 
       <br>
      </div> 
      <div style="text-align: justify;">
        ChromePass doesn't require any installation process or additional DLL files. In order to start using ChromePass, simply run the executable file - ChromePass.exe After running it, the main window will display all passwords that are currently stored in your Google Chrome browser. 
      </div> 
      <div style="text-align: justify;"> 
       <br>
      </div> 
      <div style="text-align: justify;"> 
       <b><span style="font-size: large;"> Reading ChromePass passwords from external drive</span></b>
      </div> 
      <div style="text-align: justify;"> 
       <br>
      </div> 
      <div style="text-align: justify;">
        Starting from version 1.05, you can also read the passwords stored by Chrome Web browser from an external profile in your current operating system or from another external drive (For example: from a dead system that cannot boot anymore). In order to use this feature, you must know the last logged-on password used for this profile, because the passwords are encrypted with the SHA hash of the log-on password, and without that hash, the passwords cannot be decrypted. 
      </div> 
      <div style="text-align: justify;"> 
       <br>
      </div> 
      <div style="text-align: justify;">
        You can use this feature from the UI, by selecting the 'Advanced Options' in the File menu, or from command-line, by using /external parameter. The user profile path should be something like "C:\Documents and Settings\admin" in Windows XP/2003 or "C:\users\myuser" in Windows Vista/2008. 
      </div> 
      <br> 
      <b><span style="font-size: large;"> Command-Line Options</span></b>
      <br> 
      <table border="1" bordercolor="#000000" cellpadding="5"> 
       <tbody> 
        <tr>
         <td nowrap>/stext &lt;Filename&gt; </td>
         <td>Save the list of passwords into a regular text file. </td>
        </tr> 
        <tr>
         <td nowrap>/stab &lt;Filename&gt; </td>
         <td>Save the list of passwords into a tab-delimited text file. </td>
        </tr> 
        <tr>
         <td nowrap>/scomma &lt;Filename&gt; </td>
         <td>Save the list of passwords into a comma-delimited text file. </td>
        </tr> 
        <tr>
         <td nowrap>/stabular &lt;Filename&gt; </td>
         <td>Save the list of passwords into a tabular text file. </td>
        </tr> 
        <tr>
         <td nowrap>/shtml &lt;Filename&gt; </td>
         <td>Save the list of passwords into HTML file (Horizontal). </td>
        </tr> 
        <tr>
         <td nowrap>/sverhtml &lt;Filename&gt; </td>
         <td>Save the list of passwords into HTML file (Vertical). </td>
        </tr> 
        <tr>
         <td nowrap>/sxml &lt;Filename&gt; </td>
         <td>Save the list of passwords to XML file. </td>
        </tr> 
        <tr>
         <td nowrap>/skeepass &lt;Filename&gt; </td>
         <td>Save the list of passwords to KeePass csv file. </td>
        </tr> 
        <tr>
         <td nowrap>/external &lt;User Profile Path&gt; &lt;Last Log-On Password&gt; </td>
         <td>Load the Chrome passwords from external drive/profile. For example: <br> chromepass.exe /external "C:\Documents and Settings\admin" "MyPassword" </td>
        </tr> 
       </tbody>
      </table> 
      <br> 
      <br> 
      <div style="text-align: center;"> 
       <b><span style="font-size: x-large;"><a href="http://www.nirsoft.net/utils/chromepass.html" target="_blank">Download&nbsp;ChromePass</a></span></b>
      </div> 
     </div>
    </article> 
    <article class="post hentry" id="1002203363100248727" itemscope itemtype="http://schema.org/BlogPosting"> 
     <h1 class="post-title entry-title" itemprop="name headline"> CMSmap - Scanner to detect security flaws of the most popular CMSs (WordPress, Joomla and Drupal)  </h1> 
     <div class="post-header" style="position:absolute;left:-9999px"> 
      <div class="post-header-line-1"></div> 
     </div> 
     <div class="post-body entry-content" id="post-body-1002203363100248727" itemprop="articleBody"> 
      <br> 
      <div class="separator" style="clear: both; text-align: center;"> 
       <a href="http://4.bp.blogspot.com/-l4JofeDHlcE/VOXkKxLBynI/AAAAAAAADs0/LFpG8qxMv3Q/s1600/WordPress-Joomla-Drupal.jpg" imageanchor="1" style="margin-left: 1em; margin-right: 1em;"><img border="0" src="http://4.bp.blogspot.com/-l4JofeDHlcE/VOXkKxLBynI/AAAAAAAADs0/LFpG8qxMv3Q/s1600/WordPress-Joomla-Drupal.jpg" height="250" width="640"></a>
      </div> 
      <br> CMSmap is a python open source CMS scanner that automates the process of detecting security flaws of the most popular CMSs. The main purpose of CMSmap is to integrate common vulnerabilities for different types of CMSs in a single tool. 
      <br> 
      <br> At the moment, CMSs supported by CMSmap are WordPress, Joomla and Drupal.
      <br> 
      <br> Please note that this project is an early state. As such, you might find bugs, flaws or mulfunctions. Use it at your own risk!
      <br> 
      <a name="more"></a>
      <br> 
      <b><span class="Apple-style-span" style="font-size: large;">Installation</span></b>
      <br> You can download the latest version of CMSmap by cloning the GitHub repository:
      <br> 
      <pre><code>git clone https://github.com/Dionach/CMSmap.git
</code></pre> 
      <br> 
      <span class="Apple-style-span" style="font-size: large;"><b>Usage</b></span>
      <br> 
      <pre><code>CMSmap tool v0.3 - Simple CMS Scanner
Author: Mike Manzotti <a href="/cdn-cgi/l/email-protection" class="__cf_email__" data-cfemail="a7caceccc289cac6c9ddc8d3d3cee7c3cec8c9c6c4cf89c4c8ca">[email&nbsp;protected]</a>
Usage: cmsmap.py -t &lt;URL&gt;
          -t, --target    target URL (e.g. 'https://abc.test.com:8080/')
          -v, --verbose   verbose mode (Default: false)
          -T, --threads   number of threads (Default: 5)
          -u, --usr       username or file 
          -p, --psw       password or file
          -i, --input     scan multiple targets listed in a given text file
          -o, --output    save output in a file
          -k, --crack     password hashes file
          -w, --wordlist  wordlist file (Default: rockyou.txt - WordPress only)       
          -a, --agent     set custom user-agent  
          -U, --update    (C)MSmap, (W)ordpress plugins and themes, (J)oomla components, (D)rupal modules
          -f, --force     force scan (W)ordpress, (J)oomla or (D)rupal
          -F, --fullscan  full scan using large plugin lists. Slow! (Default: false)
          -h, --help      show this help   

Example: cmsmap.py -t https://example.com
         cmsmap.py -t https://example.com -f W -F
         cmsmap.py -t https://example.com -i targets.txt -o output.txt
         cmsmap.py -t https://example.com -u admin -p passwords.txt
         cmsmap.py -k hashes.txt
</code></pre> 
      <br> 
      <br> 
      <div style="text-align: center;"> 
       <b><span class="Apple-style-span" style="font-size: x-large;"><a href="https://github.com/dionach/CMSmap" target="_blank">Download CMSmap</a></span></b>
      </div> 
     </div>
    </article> 
    <article class="post hentry" id="8188187508245695049" itemscope itemtype="http://schema.org/BlogPosting"> 
     <h1 class="post-title entry-title" itemprop="name headline"> Codetainer - A Docker Container In Your Browser  </h1> 
     <div class="post-header" style="position:absolute;left:-9999px"> 
      <div class="post-header-line-1"></div> 
     </div> 
     <div class="post-body entry-content" id="post-body-8188187508245695049" itemprop="articleBody"> 
      <div class="separator" style="clear: both; text-align: center;"> 
       <a href="http://4.bp.blogspot.com/-pDJRPYWisrA/VkLECcynOgI/AAAAAAAAEyk/uUv7oeInEk4/s1600/codetainer.gif" imageanchor="1" style="margin-left: 1em; margin-right: 1em;"><img border="0" height="419" src="http://4.bp.blogspot.com/-pDJRPYWisrA/VkLECcynOgI/AAAAAAAAEyk/uUv7oeInEk4/s640/codetainer.gif" width="640"></a>
      </div> 
      <br> 
      <div style="text-align: justify;"> 
       <code> codetainer </code> allows you to create code 'sandboxes' you can embed in your web applications (think of it like an OSS clone of 
       <a href="http://codepicnic.com/" target="_blank"> codepicnic.com </a> ). 
      </div> 
      <div style="text-align: justify;"> 
       <br>
      </div> 
      <div style="text-align: justify;">
        Codetainer runs as a webservice and provides APIs to create, view, and attach to the sandbox along with a nifty HTML terminal you can interact with the sandbox in realtime. It uses Docker and its introspection APIs to provide the majority of this functionality. 
      </div> 
      <div style="text-align: justify;"> 
       <br>
      </div> 
      <div style="text-align: justify;">
        Codetainer is written in Go. For more information, see 
       <a href="https://www.slideshare.net/JenAndre/codetainer-a-browser-code-sandbox" target="_blank"> the slides from a talk introduction </a> .
      </div> 
      <a name="more"></a>
      <br> 
      <span style="font-size: x-large;"> <b> Build &amp; Installation </b> </span> 
      <br> 
      <br> 
      <span style="font-size: large;"> <b> Requirements </b> </span> 
      <br> 
      <ul> 
       <li> Docker &gt;=1.8 (required for file upload API) </li> 
       <li> Go &gt;=1.4 </li> 
       <li> <a href="https://github.com/tools/godep" target="_blank"> godep </a> </li> 
      </ul> 
      <br> 
      <b> Building &amp; Installing From Source </b> 
      <br> 
      <div> 
       <pre><code># set your $GOPATH
go get github.com/codetainerapp/codetainer  
# you may get errors about not compiling due to Asset missing, it's ok. bindata.go needs to be created
# by `go generate` first.
cd $GOPATH/src/github.com/codetainerapp/codetainer
# make install_deps  # if you need the dependencies like godep
make</code></pre> 
      </div> This will create ./bin/codetainer. 
      <br> 
      <br> 
      <span style="font-size: large;"> <b> Configuring Docker </b> </span> 
      <br> You must configure Docker to listen on a TCP port. 
      <br> 
      <pre><code>DOCKER_OPTS="-H tcp://127.0.0.1:4500 -H unix:///var/run/docker.sock"
</code></pre> 
      <br> 
      <span style="font-size: large;"> <b> Configuring codetainer </b> </span> 
      <br> See ~/.codetainer/config.toml. This file will get auto-generated the first time you run codetainer, please edit defaults as appropriate. 
      <br> 
      <div> 
       <pre><code># Docker API server and port
DockerServer = "localhost"
DockerPort = 4500

# Enable TLS support (optional, if you access to Docker API over HTTPS)
# DockerServerUseHttps = true
# Certificate directory path (optional)
#   e.g. if you use Docker Machine: "~/.docker/machine/certs"
# DockerCertPath = "/path/to/certs"

# Database path (optional, default is ~/.codetainer/codetainer.db)
# DatabasePath = "/path/to/codetainer.db"</code></pre> 
      </div> 
      <br> 
      <span style="font-size: large;"> <b> Running an example codetainer </b> </span> 
      <br> 
      <div> 
       <pre><code>$ sudo docker pull ubuntu:14.04
$ codetainer image register ubuntu:14.04
$ codetainer create ubuntu:14.04 my-codetainer-name
$ codetainer server  # to start the API server on port 3000</code></pre> 
      </div> 
      <br> 
      <b> Embedding a codetainer in your web app </b> 
      <br> 
      <ol> 
       <li> Copy <a href="https://draft.blogger.com/codetainerapp/codetainer/blob/master/web/public/javascript/codetainer.js" target="_blank"> codetainer.js </a> to your webapp. </li> 
       <li> Include <code> codetainer.js </code> and <code> jquery </code> in your web page. Create a div to house the codetainer terminal iframe (it's <code> #terminal </code> in the example below). <br> 
        <div> 
         <pre><code>&lt;!DOCTYPE html&gt;
&lt;html&gt;
&lt;head&gt;
  &lt;meta charset="UTF-8"&gt;
  &lt;title&gt;lsof tutorial&lt;/title&gt;
  &lt;link rel='stylesheet' href='/stylesheets/style.css' /&gt;
  &lt;script src="http://code.jquery.com/jquery-1.10.1.min.js"&gt;&lt;/script&gt;
  &lt;script src="/javascripts/codetainer.js"&gt;&lt;/script&gt;
  &lt;script src="/javascripts/lsof.js"&gt;&lt;/script&gt;
&lt;/head&gt;
&lt;body&gt;
   &lt;div id="terminal" data-container="YOUR CODETAINER ID HERE"&gt; 
&lt;/body&gt;
&lt;/html&gt; </code></pre> 
        </div> </li> 
       <li> Run the javascript to load the codetainer iframe from the codetainer API server (supply <code> data-container </code> as the id of codetainer on the div, or supply <code> codetainer </code> in the constructor options). <br> </li> 
      </ol> 
      <div> 
       <pre><code> $('#terminal').codetainer({
     terminalOnly: false,                 // set to true to show only a terminal window 
     url: "http://127.0.0.1:3000",        // replace with codetainer server URL
     container: "YOUR CONTAINER ID HERE",
     width: "100%",
     height: "100%",
  });</code></pre> 
      </div> 
      <br> 
      <br> 
      <div style="text-align: center;"> 
       <b> <span style="font-size: x-large;"> <a href="https://github.com/codetainerapp/codetainer" target="_blank"> Download Codetainer </a> </span> </b> 
      </div> 
     </div>
    </article> 
    <article class="post hentry" id="1062842913482317451" itemscope itemtype="http://schema.org/BlogPosting"> 
     <h1 class="post-title entry-title" itemprop="name headline"> Collection Of Awesome Honeypots  </h1> 
     <div class="post-header" style="position:absolute;left:-9999px"> 
      <div class="post-header-line-1"></div> 
     </div> 
     <div class="post-body entry-content" id="post-body-1062842913482317451" itemprop="articleBody"> 
      <div class="separator" style="clear: both; text-align: center;"> 
       <a href="http://1.bp.blogspot.com/-m4z9TEo6E28/Vm3maPyBsaI/AAAAAAAAE8Q/MhWVHiDPsEE/s1600/noney_pot.jpg" imageanchor="1" style="margin-left: 1em; margin-right: 1em;"><img border="0" height="480" src="http://1.bp.blogspot.com/-m4z9TEo6E28/Vm3maPyBsaI/AAAAAAAAE8Q/MhWVHiDPsEE/s640/noney_pot.jpg" width="640"></a>
      </div> 
      <br> 
      <div style="text-align: justify;">
        A curated list of awesome honeypots, tools, components and much more. The list is divided into categories such as web, services, and others, focusing on open source projects.
      </div> 
      <a name="more"></a>
      <br> 
      <h2> Honeypots</h2> 
      <ul> 
       <li>Database Honeypots<br> 
        <ul> 
         <li><a href="https://github.com/jordan-wright/elastichoney">Elastic honey</a> - A Simple Elasticsearch Honeypot</li> 
         <li><a href="https://github.com/schmalle/MysqlPot">mysql</a> - A mysql honeypot, still very very early stage</li> 
         <li><a href="https://github.com/torque59/nosqlpot">A framework for nosql databases ( only redis for now)</a> - The NoSQL Honeypot Framework</li> 
         <li><a href="https://github.com/mycert/ESPot">ESPot</a> - ElasticSearch Honeypot</li> 
        </ul> </li> 
       <li>Web honeypots<br> 
        <ul> 
         <li><a href="https://github.com/mushorg/glastopf">Glastopf</a> - Web Application Honeypot</li> 
         <li><a href="https://github.com/gfoss/phpmyadmin_honeypot">phpmyadmin_honeypot</a> - - A simple and effective phpMyAdmin honeypot</li> 
         <li><a href="https://github.com/schmalle/Servletpot">servlet</a> - Web application Honeypot</li> 
         <li><a href="https://github.com/schmalle/Nodepot">Nodepot</a> - A nodejs web application honeypot</li> 
         <li><a href="https://github.com/bjeborn/basic-auth-pot">basic-auth-pot</a> bap - http Basic Authentication honeyPot</li> 
         <li><a href="https://shadowd.zecure.org/">Shadow Daemon</a> - A modular Web Application Firewall / High-Interaction Honeypot for PHP, Perl &amp; Python apps</li> 
         <li><a href="https://github.com/schmalle/servletpot">Servletpot</a> - Web application Honeypot</li> 
         <li><a href="http://ghh.sourceforge.net/">Google Hack Honeypot</a> - designed to provide reconnaissance against attackers that use search engines as a hacking tool against your resources.</li> 
         <li><a href="https://github.com/freak3dot/smart-honeypot">smart-honeypot</a> - PHP Script demonstrating a smart honey pot</li> 
         <li><a href="https://github.com/MartinIngesen/HonnyPotter">HonnyPotter</a> - A WordPress login honeypot for collection and analysis of failed login attempts.</li> 
         <li><a href="https://github.com/freak3dot/wp-smart-honeypot">wp-smart-honeypot</a> - WordPress plugin to reduce comment spam with a smarter honeypot</li> 
         <li><a href="https://github.com/gbrindisi/wordpot">wordpot</a> - A WordPress Honeypot</li> 
         <li><a href="https://github.com/Argomirr/Honeypot">Bukkit Honeypot</a> Honeypot - A honeypot plugin for Bukkit</li> 
         <li><a href="https://github.com/msurguy/Honeypot">Laravel Application Honeypot</a> - Honeypot - Simple spam prevention package for Laravel applications</li> 
         <li><a href="https://github.com/CHH/stack-honeypot">stack-honeypot</a> - Inserts a trap for spam bots into responses</li> 
         <li><a href="https://github.com/eymengunay/EoHoneypotBundle">EoHoneypotBundle</a> - Honeypot type for Symfony2 forms</li> 
         <li><a href="https://github.com/threatstream/shockpot">shockpot</a> - WebApp Honeypot for detecting Shell Shock exploit attempts</li> 
        </ul> </li> 
       <li>Service Honeypots<br> 
        <ul> 
         <li><a href="https://github.com/desaster/kippo">Kippo</a> - Medium interaction SSH honeypot</li> 
         <li><a href="https://github.com/fygrave/honeyntp">honeyntp</a> - NTP logger/honeypot</li> 
         <li><a href="https://github.com/alexbredo/honeypot-camera">honeypot-camera</a> - observation camera honeypot</li> 
         <li><a href="https://github.com/dutchcoders/troje/">troje</a> - a honeypot built around lxc containers. It will run each connection with the service within a seperate lxc container.</li> 
         <li><a href="https://github.com/rshipp/slipm-honeypot">slipm-honeypot</a> - A simple low-interaction port monitoring honeypot</li> 
         <li><a href="https://github.com/foospidy/HoneyPy">HoneyPy</a> - A low interaction honeypot</li> 
         <li><a href="https://github.com/ahoernecke/ensnare">Ensnare</a> - Easy to deploy Ruby honeypot</li> 
         <li><a href="https://github.com/citronneur/rdpy">RDPy</a> - A Microsoft Remote Desktop Protocol (RDP) honeypot in python</li> 
        </ul> </li> 
       <li>Anti-honeypot stuff<br> 
        <ul> 
         <li><a href="https://github.com/andrew-morris/kippo_detect">kippo_detect</a> - This is not a honeypot, but it detects kippo. (This guy has lots of more interesting stuff)</li> 
        </ul> </li> 
       <li>ICS/SCADA honeypots<br> 
        <ul> 
         <li><a href="https://github.com/glastopf/conpot">Conpot</a> - ICS/SCADA honeypot</li>
