    </article> 
    <article class="post hentry" id="2054540121537459122" itemscope itemtype="http://schema.org/BlogPosting"> 
     <h1 class="post-title entry-title" itemprop="name headline"> Egress-Assess - Tool used to Test Egress Data Detection Capabilities  </h1> 
     <div class="post-header" style="position:absolute;left:-9999px"> 
      <div class="post-header-line-1"></div> 
     </div> 
     <div class="post-body entry-content" id="post-body-2054540121537459122" itemprop="articleBody"> 
      <div class="separator" style="clear: both; text-align: center;"> 
       <a href="http://1.bp.blogspot.com/-qxhPFGINbtM/VamiiJhXeSI/AAAAAAAAEY0/NDok7LhN9vU/s1600/Egress-Assess.png" imageanchor="1" style="margin-left: 1em; margin-right: 1em;"><img border="0" height="420" src="http://1.bp.blogspot.com/-qxhPFGINbtM/VamiiJhXeSI/AAAAAAAAEY0/NDok7LhN9vU/s640/Egress-Assess.png" width="640"></a>
      </div> 
      <br> Egress-Assess is a tool used to test egress data detection capabilities.
      <br> 
      <br> 
      <b><span style="font-size: large;">Setup</span></b>
      <br> 
      <br> To setup, run the included setup script, or perform the following:
      <br> 
      <ol> 
       <li> Install pyftpdlib</li> 
       <li> Generate a server certificate and store it as "server.pem" on the same level as Egress-Assess. This can be done with the following command:</li> 
      </ol> "openssl req -new -x509 -keyout server.pem -out server.pem -days 365 -nodes"
      <br> 
      <a name="more"></a>
      <br> 
      <b><span style="font-size: large;">Usage</span></b>
      <br> 
      <br> Typical use case for Egress-Assess is to copy this tool in two locations. One location will act as the server, the other will act as the client. Egress-Assess can send data over FTP, HTTP, and HTTPS.
      <br> To extract data over FTP, you would first start Egress-Assess’s FTP server by selecting “--server ftp” and providing a username and password to use:
      <br> 
      <pre><code>./Egress-Assess.py --server ftp --username testuser --password pass123</code></pre> Now, to have the client connect and send data to the ftp server, you could run...
      <br> 
      <pre><code>./Egress-Assess.py --client ftp --username testuser --password pass123 --ip 192.168.63.149 --datatype ssn</code></pre> Also, you can setup Egress-Assess to act as a web server by running....
      <br> 
      <pre><code>./Egress-Assess.py --server https</code></pre> Then, to send data to the FTP server, and to specifically send 15 megs of credit card data, run the following command...
      <br> 
      <pre><code>./Egress-Assess.py --client https --data-size 15 --ip 192.168.63.149 --datatype cc</code></pre> 
      <br> 
      <br> 
      <div style="text-align: center;"> 
       <b><span style="font-size: x-large;"><a href="https://github.com/ChrisTruncer/Egress-Assess" target="_blank">Download&nbsp;Egress-Assess</a></span></b>
      </div> 
     </div>
    </article> 
    <article class="post hentry" id="5465189543812118909" itemscope itemtype="http://schema.org/BlogPosting"> 
     <h1 class="post-title entry-title" itemprop="name headline"> Empire - PowerShell Post-Exploitation Agent  </h1> 
     <div class="post-header" style="position:absolute;left:-9999px"> 
      <div class="post-header-line-1"></div> 
     </div> 
     <div class="post-body entry-content" id="post-body-5465189543812118909" itemprop="articleBody"> 
      <div class="separator" style="clear: both; text-align: center;"> 
       <a href="http://1.bp.blogspot.com/-PtGvmPcSaoE/VeRUpO_zUOI/AAAAAAAAEjc/LIgh5NQtdf4/s1600/empire.png" imageanchor="1" style="clear: left; float: left; margin-bottom: 1em; margin-right: 1em;"><img border="0" height="200" src="http://1.bp.blogspot.com/-PtGvmPcSaoE/VeRUpO_zUOI/AAAAAAAAEjc/LIgh5NQtdf4/s200/empire.png" width="200"></a>
      </div> 
      <br> 
      <div style="text-align: justify;">
        Empire is a pure PowerShell post-exploitation agent built on cryptologically-secure communications and a flexible architecture. Empire implements the ability to run PowerShell agents without needing powershell.exe, rapidly deployable post-exploitation modules ranging from key loggers to Mimikatz, and adaptable communications to evade network detection, all wrapped up in a usability-focused framework. 
      </div> 
      <br> 
      <div style="text-align: justify;"> 
       <b><span style="font-size: large;">Why PowerShell? </span></b>
      </div> 
      <div style="text-align: justify;"> 
       <br>
      </div> 
      <div style="text-align: justify;">
        PowerShell offers a multitude of offensive advantages, including full .NET access, application whitelisting, direct access to the Win32 API, the ability to assemble malicious binaries in memory, and a default installation on Windows 7+. Offensive PowerShell had a watershed year in 2014, but despite the multitude of useful projects, many pentesters still struggle to integrate PowerShell into their engagements in a secure manner.
       <br> 
       <a name="more"></a>
      </div> 
      <div style="text-align: justify;"> 
       <br>
      </div> 
      <div style="text-align: justify;"> 
       <b><span style="font-size: large;">Initial Setup</span></b>
      </div> 
      <div style="text-align: justify;"> 
       <br>
      </div> 
      <div style="text-align: justify;">
        Run the 
       <strong>./setup/install.sh</strong> script. This will install the few&nbsp;dependencies&nbsp;and run the 
       <strong>./setup/setup_database.py</strong> script. The setup_database.py file contains various setting that you can manually modify, and then initializes the ./data/empire.db backend database. No additional configuration should be needed- hopefully everything works out of the box.
      </div> 
      <div style="text-align: justify;">
        Running ./empire will start Empire, and 
       <strong>./empire –debug</strong> will generate a verbose debug log at ./empire.debug. The included ./data/reset.sh will reset/reinitialize the database and launch Empire in debug mode.
      </div> 
      <div style="text-align: justify;"> 
       <br>
      </div> 
      <div style="text-align: justify;"> 
       <b><span style="font-size: large;">Main Menu</span></b>
      </div> 
      <div style="text-align: justify;"> 
       <br>
      </div> 
      <div style="text-align: justify;">
        Once you hit the main menu, you’ll see the number of active agents, listeners, and loaded modules.
      </div> 
      <br> 
      <div class="separator" style="clear: both; text-align: center;"> 
       <a href="http://1.bp.blogspot.com/-dBu27XvYtiw/VeRVUPb62MI/AAAAAAAAEjk/NSlgiOHbdI4/s1600/empire_main_menu.png" imageanchor="1" style="margin-left: 1em; margin-right: 1em;"><img border="0" height="388" src="http://1.bp.blogspot.com/-dBu27XvYtiw/VeRVUPb62MI/AAAAAAAAEjk/NSlgiOHbdI4/s640/empire_main_menu.png" width="640"></a>
      </div> 
      <br> 
      <div style="text-align: justify;">
        The 
       <strong>help</strong> command should work for all menus, and almost everything that can be tab-completable is (menu commands, agent names, local file paths where relevant, etc.).
      </div> 
      <div style="text-align: justify;"> 
       <br>
      </div> 
      <div style="text-align: justify;">
        You can ctrl+C to rage quit at any point. Starting Empire back up should preserve existing communicating agents, and any existing listeners will be restarted (as their config is stored in the sqlite backend database).
      </div> 
      <div style="text-align: justify;"> 
       <br>
      </div> 
      <div style="text-align: justify;"> 
       <b><span style="font-size: large;">Listeners 101</span></b>
      </div> 
      <div style="text-align: justify;"> 
       <br>
      </div> 
      <div style="text-align: justify;">
        The first thing you need to do it set up a local listener. The 
       <strong>listeners</strong> command will jump you to the listener management menu. Any active listeners will be displayed, and this information can be redisplayed at any time with the 
       <strong>list</strong> command. The 
       <strong>info</strong> command will display the currently set listener options.
      </div> 
      <div style="text-align: justify;"> 
       <br>
      </div> 
      <div class="separator" style="clear: both; text-align: center;"> 
       <a href="http://3.bp.blogspot.com/-fPN5itkoNkU/VeRWZ6f3tPI/AAAAAAAAEjw/8RvK94kTWcE/s1600/empire_listeners_menu.png" imageanchor="1" style="margin-left: 1em; margin-right: 1em;"><img border="0" height="326" src="http://3.bp.blogspot.com/-fPN5itkoNkU/VeRWZ6f3tPI/AAAAAAAAEjw/8RvK94kTWcE/s640/empire_listeners_menu.png" width="640"></a>
      </div> 
      <div style="text-align: justify;"> 
       <br>
      </div> 
      <div style="text-align: justify;">
        The info command will display the currently configured listener options. Set your host/port by doing something like 
       <strong>set Host <a href="http://192.168.52.142:8081/">http://192.168.52.142:8081</a></strong>. This is tab-completable, and&nbsp;you can also use domain names here). The port will automatically be pulled out, and the backend will detect if you’re doing a HTTP or HTTPS listener. For HTTPS listeners, you must first set the CertPath to be a local .pem file. The provided 
       <strong>./data/cert.sh</strong> script will generate a self-signed cert and place it in ./data/empire.pem.
      </div> 
      <div style="text-align: justify;"> 
       <br>
      </div> 
      <div style="text-align: justify;">
        Set optional and WorkingHours, KillDate, DefaultDelay, and DefaultJitter for the listener, as well as whatever name you want it to be referred to as. You can then type 
       <strong>execute</strong> to start the listener. If the name is already taken, a nameX variant will be used, and Empire will alert you if the port is already in use.
      </div> 
      <div style="text-align: justify;"> 
       <br>
      </div> 
      <div style="text-align: justify;"> 
       <b><span style="font-size: large;">Stagers 101</span></b>
      </div> 
      <div style="text-align: justify;"> 
       <br>
      </div> 
      <div style="text-align: justify;">
        The staging process and a complete description of the available stagers is 
       <a href="http://www.powershellempire.com/?page_id=147">detailed here</a>&nbsp;and 
       <a href="http://www.powershellempire.com/?page_id=104">here</a>.
      </div> 
      <div style="text-align: justify;"> 
       <br>
      </div> 
      <div style="text-align: justify;">
        Empire implements various stagers in a modular format in ./lib/stagers/*. These include dlls, macros, one-liners, and more. To use a stager, from the main, listeners, or agents menu, use 
       <strong>usestager &lt;tab&gt;</strong>&nbsp;to tab-complete the set of available stagers, and you’ll be taken to the individual stager’s menu. The UI here functions similarly to the post module menu, i.e set/unset/info and 
       <strong>generate</strong> to generate the particular output code.
      </div> 
      <div style="text-align: justify;"> 
       <br>
      </div> 
      <div style="text-align: justify;">
        For UserAgent and proxy options, default uses the system defaults, none clears that option from being used in the stager, and anything else is assumed to be a custom setting (note, this last bit isn’t properly implemented for proxy settings yet). From the Listeners menu, you can run the 
       <strong>launcher [listener ID/name]</strong>alias to generate the stage0 launcher for a particular listener (this is the 
       <strong>stagers/launcher</strong> module in the background). This command can be run from a command prompt on any machine to kick off the staging process. (
       <strong>NOTE:</strong> you will need to right click cmd.exe and choose “run as administrator” before pasting/running this command if you want to use modules that require administrative privileges). Our PowerShell version of BypassUAC module is in the works but not 100% complete yet.
      </div> 
      <div style="text-align: justify;"> 
       <br>
      </div> 
      <div style="text-align: justify;"> 
       <b><span style="font-size: large;">Agents 101</span></b>
      </div> 
      <div style="text-align: justify;"> 
       <br>
      </div> 
      <div style="text-align: justify;"> 
      </div> 
      <div style="text-align: justify;">
        You should see a status message when an agent checks in (i.e. [+] Initial agent CGUBKC1R3YLHZM4V from 192.168.52.168 now active). Jump to the Agents menu with 
       <strong>agents</strong>. Basic information on active agents should be displayed. Various commands can be executed on specific agent IDs or 
       <strong>all</strong> from the agent menu, i.e. 
       <strong>kill all</strong>. To interact with an agent, use 
       <strong>interact AGENT_NAME</strong>. Agent names should be tab-completable for all commands.
      </div> 
      <br> 
      <div class="separator" style="clear: both; text-align: center;"> 
       <a href="http://2.bp.blogspot.com/-OhKjo0U3ujY/VeRW1DkAy0I/AAAAAAAAEj4/0zvx5ChoIQA/s1600/empire_agent_checkin.png" imageanchor="1" style="margin-left: 1em; margin-right: 1em;"><img border="0" height="184" src="http://2.bp.blogspot.com/-OhKjo0U3ujY/VeRW1DkAy0I/AAAAAAAAEj4/0zvx5ChoIQA/s640/empire_agent_checkin.png" width="640"></a>
      </div> 
      <br> 
      <div style="text-align: justify;">
        In an Agent menu, 
       <strong>info</strong> will display more detailed agent information, and 
       <strong>help</strong> will display all agent commands. If a typed command isn’t resolved, Empire will try to interpret it as a shell command (like ps). You can 
       <strong>cd</strong> directories, 
       <strong>upload/download</strong> files, and 
       <strong>rename NEW_NAME</strong>.
      </div> 
      <div style="text-align: justify;">
        For each registered agent, a ./downloads/AGENT_NAME/ folder is created (this folder is renamed with an agent rename). An ./agent.log is created here with timestamped commands/results for agent communication. Downloads/module outputs are broken out into relevant folders here as well.
      </div> 
      <div style="text-align: justify;">
        When you’re finished with an agent, use 
       <strong>exit</strong>&nbsp;from the Agent menu or 
       <strong>kill NAME/all</strong> from the Agents menu. You’ll get a red notification when the agent exits, and the agent will be removed from the interactive list after.
      </div> 
      <div style="text-align: justify;"> 
       <br>
      </div> 
      <div style="text-align: justify;"> 
       <b><span style="font-size: large;">Modules 101</span></b>
      </div> 
      <div style="text-align: justify;"> 
       <br>
      </div> 
      <div style="text-align: justify;">
        To see available modules, type 
       <strong>usemodule &lt;tab&gt;</strong>. To search module names/descriptions, use 
       <strong>searchmodule privesc</strong> and matching module names/descriptions will be output.
      </div> 
      <div style="text-align: justify;"> 
       <br>
      </div> 
      <div style="text-align: justify;">
        To use a module, for example netview from PowerView, type 
       <strong>usemodule situational_awareness/network/sharefinder</strong>&nbsp;and press enter. 
       <strong>info</strong> will display all current module options.
      </div> 
      <br> 
      <div class="separator" style="clear: both; text-align: center;"> 
       <a href="http://3.bp.blogspot.com/-QSMsSmC2TPk/VeRXJiBxFUI/AAAAAAAAEkA/34ofc0sbdio/s1600/empire_module_menu.png" imageanchor="1" style="margin-left: 1em; margin-right: 1em;"><img border="0" height="432" src="http://3.bp.blogspot.com/-QSMsSmC2TPk/VeRXJiBxFUI/AAAAAAAAEkA/34ofc0sbdio/s640/empire_module_menu.png" width="640"></a>
      </div> 
      <br> 
      <div style="text-align: justify;">
        To set an option, like the domain for sharefinder, use 
       <strong>set Domain testlab.local</strong>. The Agent argument is always required, and should be auto-filled from jumping to a module from an agent menu. You can also 
       <strong>set Agent &lt;tab&gt;</strong>&nbsp;to tab-complete an agent name. 
       <strong>execute</strong> will task the agent to execute the module, and 
       <strong>back</strong> will return you to the agent’s main menu. Results will be displayed as they come back.
      </div> 
      <div style="text-align: justify;"> 
       <br>
      </div> 
      <div style="text-align: justify;"> 
       <b><span style="font-size: large;">Scripts</span></b>
      </div> 
      <div style="text-align: justify;"> 
       <br>
      </div> 
      <div style="text-align: justify;">
        In addition to formalized modules, you are able to simply import and use a .ps1 script in your remote empire agent. Use the 
       <strong>scriptimport ./path/</strong> command to import the script. The script will be imported and any functions accessible to the script will now be tab completable using the “scriptcmd” command in the agent. This works well for very large scripts with lots of functions that you do not want to break into a module.
      </div> 
      <div style="text-align: justify;"> 
       <br>
      </div> 
      <br> 
      <div style="text-align: center;"> 
       <b><span style="font-size: x-large;"><a href="https://github.com/PowerShellEmpire/Empire" target="_blank">Download&nbsp;Empire</a></span></b>
      </div> 
     </div>
    </article> 
    <article class="post hentry" id="8881044078832373999" itemscope itemtype="http://schema.org/BlogPosting"> 
     <h1 class="post-title entry-title" itemprop="name headline"> Evil FOCA - MITM, DoS, DNS Hijacking in IPv4 and IPv6 Penetration Testing Tool  </h1> 
     <div class="post-header" style="position:absolute;left:-9999px"> 
      <div class="post-header-line-1"></div> 
     </div> 
     <div class="post-body entry-content" id="post-body-8881044078832373999" itemprop="articleBody"> 
      <div class="separator" style="clear: both; text-align: center;"> 
       <a href="http://3.bp.blogspot.com/-SdepbtMo-i0/VgJDuhgJT3I/AAAAAAAAEpI/2Z9fUjsYw2s/s1600/evilfoca.jpg" imageanchor="1" style="margin-left: 1em; margin-right: 1em;"><img border="0" height="358" src="http://3.bp.blogspot.com/-SdepbtMo-i0/VgJDuhgJT3I/AAAAAAAAEpI/2Z9fUjsYw2s/s640/evilfoca.jpg" width="640"></a>
      </div> 
      <br> 
      <div style="text-align: justify;">
        Evil Foca is a tool for security pentesters and auditors whose purpose it is to test security in IPv4 and IPv6 data networks. The tool is capable of carrying out various attacks such as:
      </div> 
      <ul> 
       <li style="text-align: justify;">MITM over IPv4 networks with ARP Spoofing and DHCP ACK Injection.</li> 
       <li style="text-align: justify;">MITM on IPv6 networks with Neighbor Advertisement Spoofing, SLAAC attack, fake DHCPv6.</li> 
       <li style="text-align: justify;">DoS (Denial of Service) on IPv4 networks with ARP Spoofing.</li> 
       <li style="text-align: justify;">DoS (Denial of Service) on IPv6 networks with SLAAC DoS.</li> 
       <li style="text-align: justify;">DNS Hijacking.</li> 
      </ul> 
      <div style="text-align: justify;">
        The software automatically scans the networks and identifies all devices and their respective network interfaces, specifying their IPv4 and IPv6 addresses as well as the physical addresses through a convenient and intuitive interface.
      </div> 
      <a name="more"></a>
      <br> 
      <div style="text-align: justify;"> 
       <span style="font-size: large;"><b> Requirements</b></span>
      </div> 
      <ul> 
       <li style="text-align: justify;">Windows XP or later.</li> 
       <li style="text-align: justify;">.NET Framework 4 or later.</li> 
       <li style="text-align: justify;">Winpcap library (<a href="http://www.winpcap.org/">http://www.winpcap.org</a>)</li> 
      </ul> 
      <div style="text-align: justify;"> 
       <br>
      </div> 
      <div style="text-align: justify;"> 
       <span style="font-size: large;"><b> Man In The Middle (MITM) attack</b></span>
      </div> 
      <div style="text-align: justify;"> 
       <br>
      </div> 
      <div style="text-align: justify;">
        The well-known “Man In The Middle” is an attack in which the wrongdoer creates the possibility of reading, adding, or modifying information that is located in a channel between two terminals with neither of these noticing. Within the MITM attacks in IPv4 and IPv6 Evil Foca considers the following techniques:
      </div> 
      <ul> 
       <li style="text-align: justify;"><strong>ARP Spoofing</strong>: Consists in sending ARP messages to the Ethernet network. Normally the objective is to associate the MAC address of the attacker with the IP of another device. Any traffic directed to the IP address of the predetermined link gate will be erroneously sent to the attacker instead of its real destination.</li> 
       <li style="text-align: justify;"><strong>DHCP ACK Injection</strong>: Consists in an attacker monitoring the DHCP exchanges and, at some point during the communication, sending a packet to modify its behavior. Evil Foca converts the machine in a fake DHCP server on the network.</li> 
       <li style="text-align: justify;"><strong>Neighbor Advertisement Spoofing</strong>: The principle of this attack is identical to that of ARP Spoofing, with the difference being in that IPv6 doesn’t work with the ARP protocol, but that all information is sent through ICMPv6 packets. There are five types of ICMPv6 packets used in the discovery protocol and Evil Foca generates this type of packets, placing itself between the gateway and victim.</li> 
       <li style="text-align: justify;"><strong>SLAAC attack</strong>: The objective of this type of attack is to be able to execute an MITM when a user connects to Internet and to a server that does not include support for IPv6 and to which it is therefore necessary to connect using IPv4. This attack is possible due to the fact that Evil Foca undertakes domain name resolution once it is in the communication media, and is capable of transforming IPv4 addresses in IPv6.</li> 
       <li style="text-align: justify;"><strong>Fake DHCPv6 server</strong>: This attack involves the attacker posing as the DCHPv6 server, responding to all network requests, distributing IPv6 addresses and a false DNS to manipulate the user destination or deny the service.</li> 
       <li style="text-align: justify;"><strong>Denial of Service (DoS) attack</strong>: The DoS attack is an attack to a system of machines or network that results in a service or resource being inaccessible for its users. Normally it provokes the loss of network connectivity due to consumption of the bandwidth of the victim’s network, or overloads the computing resources of the victim’s system.</li> 
       <li style="text-align: justify;"><strong>DoS attack in IPv4 with ARP Spoofing</strong>: This type of DoS attack consists in associating a nonexistent MAC address in a victim’s ARP table. This results in rendering the machine whose ARP table has been modified incapable of connecting to the IP address associated to the nonexistent MAC.</li> 
       <li style="text-align: justify;"><strong>DoS attack in IPv6 with SLAAC attack</strong>: In this type of attack a large quantity of “router advertisement” packets are generated, destined to one or several machines, announcing false routers and assigning a different IPv6 address and link gate for each router, collapsing the system and making machines unresponsive.</li> 
       <li style="text-align: justify;"><strong>DNS Hijacking</strong>: The DNS Hijacking attack or DNS kidnapping consists in altering the resolution of the domain names system (DNS). This can be achieved using malware that invalidates the configuration of a TCP/IP machine so that it points to a pirate DNS server under the attacker’s control, or by way of an MITM attack, with the attacker being the party who receives the DNS requests, and responding himself or herself to a specific DNS request to direct the victim toward a specific destination selected by the attacker.</li> 
      </ul> 
      <div> 
       <br> 
       <br>
      </div> 
      <div style="text-align: center;"> 
       <b><span style="font-size: x-large;"><a href="https://github.com/ElevenPaths/EvilFOCA" target="_blank">Download&nbsp;Evil FOCA</a></span></b>
      </div> 
     </div>
    </article> 
    <article class="post hentry" id="7069108300035529855" itemscope itemtype="http://schema.org/BlogPosting"> 
     <h1 class="post-title entry-title" itemprop="name headline"> Exploit Pack - Open Source Security Project for Penetration Testing and Exploit Development  </h1> 
     <div class="post-header" style="position:absolute;left:-9999px"> 
      <div class="post-header-line-1"></div> 
     </div> 
     <div class="post-body entry-content" id="post-body-7069108300035529855" itemprop="articleBody"> 
      <div class="separator" style="clear: both; text-align: center;"> 
       <a href="http://1.bp.blogspot.com/-GPVYCIXgDpw/VL7N4qkccQI/AAAAAAAADkk/WHqV411KPQQ/s1600/ExploitPack.png" imageanchor="1" style="margin-left: 1em; margin-right: 1em;"><img border="0" src="http://1.bp.blogspot.com/-GPVYCIXgDpw/VL7N4qkccQI/AAAAAAAADkk/WHqV411KPQQ/s1600/ExploitPack.png" height="400" width="640"></a>
      </div> 
      <br> 
      <div style="text-align: justify;">
        Exploit Pack, is an open source GPLv3 security tool, this means it is fully free and you can use it without any kind of restriction. Other security tools like Metasploit, Immunity Canvas, or Core Iimpact are ready to use as well but you will require an expensive license to get access to all the features, for example: automatic exploit launching, full report capabilities, reverse shell agent customization, etc. Exploit Pack is fully free, open source and GPLv3. Because this is an open source project you can always modify it, add or replace features and get involved into the next project decisions, everyone is more than welcome to participate. We developed this tool thinking for and as pentesters. As security professionals we use Exploit Pack on a daily basis to deploy real environment attacks into real corporate clients.
       <br> 
       <a name="more"></a>
       <br>
      </div> 
      <div style="text-align: justify;">
        Video demonstration of the latest Exploit Pack release:
      </div> 
      <div style="text-align: justify;"> 
       <br>
      </div> 
      <div style="text-align: center;"> 
       <iframe allowfullscreen frameborder="0" height="360" src="//www.youtube.com/embed/JZq5TdXoucI" width="640"></iframe>
      </div> 
      <div style="text-align: justify;"> 
       <br>
      </div> 
      <div style="text-align: justify;"> 
       <b><span style="font-size: large;">More than 300+ exploits</span></b>
      </div> 
      <div style="text-align: justify;"> 
       <br>
      </div> 
      <div style="text-align: justify;">
        Military grade professional security tool
      </div> 
      <div style="text-align: justify;"> 
       <br>
      </div> 
      <div style="text-align: justify;">
        Exploit Pack comes into the scene when you need to execute a pentest in a real environment, it will provide you with all the tools needed to gain access and persist by the use of remote reverse agents.
      </div> 
      <div style="text-align: justify;"> 
       <br>
      </div> 
      <div style="text-align: justify;"> 
       <b><span style="font-size: large;">Remote Persistent Agents</span></b>
      </div> 
      <div style="text-align: justify;"> 
       <br>
      </div> 
      <div style="text-align: justify;">
        Reverse a shell and escalate privileges
      </div> 
      <div style="text-align: justify;"> 
       <br>
      </div> 
      <div style="text-align: justify;">
        Exploit Pack will provide you with a complete set of features to create your own custom agents, you can include exploits or deploy your own personalized shellcodes directly into the agent.
      </div> 
      <div style="text-align: justify;"> 
       <br>
      </div> 
      <div style="text-align: justify;"> 
       <b><span style="font-size: large;">Write your own Exploits</span></b>
      </div> 
      <div style="text-align: justify;"> 
       <br>
      </div> 
      <div style="text-align: justify;">
        Use Exploit Pack as a learning platform
      </div> 
      <div style="text-align: justify;"> 
       <br>
      </div> 
      <div style="text-align: justify;">
        Quick exploit development, extend your capabilities and code your own custom exploits using the Exploit Wizard and the built-in Python Editor moded to fullfill the needs of an Exploit Writer.
      </div> 
      <br> 
      <br> 
      <div style="text-align: center;"> 
       <b><span style="font-size: x-large;"><a href="http://exploitpack.com/" target="_blank">Download Exploit Pack</a></span></b>
      </div> 
     </div>
    </article> 
    <article class="post hentry" id="3074404172343565807" itemscope itemtype="http://schema.org/BlogPosting"> 
     <h1 class="post-title entry-title" itemprop="name headline"> Faraday 1.0.15 - Collaborative Penetration Test and Vulnerability Management Platform  </h1> 
     <div class="post-header" style="position:absolute;left:-9999px"> 
      <div class="post-header-line-1"></div> 
     </div> 
     <div class="post-body entry-content" id="post-body-3074404172343565807" itemprop="articleBody"> 
      <div class="separator" style="clear: both; text-align: center;"> 
       <a href="http://2.bp.blogspot.com/-7o0a9fOA9aA/VhSdKXodsoI/AAAAAAAAEs8/8MVaUoheV8M/s1600/Faraday.png" imageanchor="1" style="margin-left: 1em; margin-right: 1em;"><img border="0" height="310" src="http://2.bp.blogspot.com/-7o0a9fOA9aA/VhSdKXodsoI/AAAAAAAAEs8/8MVaUoheV8M/s640/Faraday.png" width="640"></a>
      </div> 
      <br> 
      <div style="text-align: justify;">
        A brand new version is ready for you to enjoy! Faraday v1.0.15 (Community, Pro &amp; Corp) was published today with new exciting features.
      </div> 
      <div style="text-align: justify;"> 
       <br>
      </div> 
      <div style="text-align: justify;">
        As a part of our constant commitment to the IT sec community we added a tool that runs several other tools to all IPs in a given list. This results in a major scan to your infrastructure which can be done as frequently as necessary. Interested? Read more about it&nbsp;
       <a href="http://blog.infobytesec.com/2015/09/faraday-continuous-scanning.html">here</a>.
       <br> 
       <a name="more"></a>
      </div> 
      <div style="text-align: justify;"> 
       <br>
      </div> 
      <div style="text-align: justify;">
        This version also features three new plugins and a fix developed entirely by our community! Congratulations to&nbsp;
       <a href="https://github.com/atarantini">Andres</a>&nbsp;and&nbsp;
       <a href="https://github.com/Ezequieltbh">Ezequiel</a>&nbsp;for being the first two winners of the&nbsp;
       <a href="http://blog.infobytesec.com/2015/09/the-faraday-challenge.html">Faraday Challenge</a>! Are you interested in winning tickets for Ekoparty as well? Submit your pull request or find us on freenode #faraday-dev and let us know.
      </div> 
      <div style="text-align: justify;"> 
       <br>
      </div> 
      <div style="text-align: justify;"> 
       <strong><strong><span style="font-size: large;">Changes:</span></strong></strong>
      </div> 
      <br> 
      <div style="text-align: justify;">
        * Continuous Scanning Tool cscan added to ./scripts/cscan
      </div> 
      <div style="text-align: justify;">
        * Hosts and Services views now have pagination and search
      </div> 
      <br> 
      <br> 
      <div class="separator" style="clear: both; text-align: center;"> 
       <a href="http://4.bp.blogspot.com/-tGnrWQ7sffY/VhSbutJpMQI/AAAAAAAAEso/vWMzmTRDfac/s1600/Faraday_01.png" imageanchor="1" style="margin-left: 1em; margin-right: 1em;"><img border="0" height="176" src="http://4.bp.blogspot.com/-tGnrWQ7sffY/VhSbutJpMQI/AAAAAAAAEso/vWMzmTRDfac/s640/Faraday_01.png" width="640"></a>
      </div> 
      <br> * Updates version number on Faraday Start
      <br> * Added Services columns to Status Report
      <br> 
      <br> 
      <div class="separator" style="clear: both; text-align: center;"> 
       <a href="http://1.bp.blogspot.com/-rUwlgHItDuo/VhSb11OayHI/AAAAAAAAEsw/yrb2YAjB5ZM/s1600/Faraday_02.png" imageanchor="1" style="margin-left: 1em; margin-right: 1em;"><img border="0" height="298" src="http://1.bp.blogspot.com/-rUwlgHItDuo/VhSb11OayHI/AAAAAAAAEsw/yrb2YAjB5ZM/s320/Faraday_02.png" width="320"></a>
      </div> 
      <br> 
      <div style="text-align: justify;">
        * Converted references to links in Status Report. Support for CVE, CWE, Exploit Database and Open Source Vulnerability Database
      </div> 
      <div style="text-align: justify;">
        * Added Pippingtom, SSHdefaultscan and pasteAnalyzer plugins
      </div> 
      <div style="text-align: justify;"> 
       <br>
      </div> 
      <div style="text-align: justify;"> 
       <strong><span style="font-size: large;">Fixes:</span>&nbsp;</strong>
      </div> 
      <div style="text-align: justify;"> 
       <br> * Debian install
      </div> 
      <div style="text-align: justify;">
        * Saving objects without parent
      </div> 
      <div style="text-align: justify;">
        * Visual fixes on Firefox
      </div> 
      <br> 
      <br> 
      <div style="text-align: center;"> 
       <b><span style="font-size: x-large;"><a href="https://github.com/infobyte/faraday" target="_blank">Download&nbsp;Faraday 1.0.15</a></span></b>
      </div> 
     </div>
    </article> 
    <article class="post hentry" id="3807473951833291007" itemscope itemtype="http://schema.org/BlogPosting"> 
     <h1 class="post-title entry-title" itemprop="name headline"> Faraday 1.0.16 - Collaborative Penetration Test and Vulnerability Management Platform  </h1> 
     <div class="post-header" style="position:absolute;left:-9999px"> 
      <div class="post-header-line-1"></div> 
     </div> 
     <div class="post-body entry-content" id="post-body-3807473951833291007" itemprop="articleBody"> 
      <div class="separator" style="clear: both; text-align: center;"> 
       <a href="http://3.bp.blogspot.com/-Y4_dOXQvAYQ/Vn2kChtYuJI/AAAAAAAAE9Q/-Q58MV7HMdk/s1600/faraday.png" imageanchor="1" style="margin-left: 1em; margin-right: 1em;"><img border="0" height="92" src="http://3.bp.blogspot.com/-Y4_dOXQvAYQ/Vn2kChtYuJI/AAAAAAAAE9Q/-Q58MV7HMdk/s400/faraday.png" width="400"></a>
      </div> 
      <br> 
      <div style="text-align: justify;">
        Faraday introduces a new concept - IPE (Integrated Penetration-Test Environment) a multiuser Penetration test IDE. Designed for distribution, indexation and analysis of the generated data during the process of a security audit.
      </div> 
      <a name="more"></a>
      <br> 
      <div style="text-align: justify;">
        This version comes with major changes to our Web UI, including the possibility to mark vulnerabilities as false positives. If you have a Pro or Corp license you can now create an Executive Report using only confirmed vulnerabilities, saving you even more time.
      </div> 
      <div style="text-align: justify;"> 
       <br>
      </div> 
      <div style="text-align: justify;">
        A brand new feature that comes with v1.0.16 is the ability to group vulnerabilities by any field in our Status Report view. Combine it with bulk edit to manage your findings faster than ever!
      </div> 
      <div style="text-align: justify;"> 
       <br>
      </div> 
      <div style="text-align: justify;">
        This release also features several new features developed entirely by our community.&nbsp;
      </div> 
      <div style="text-align: justify;"> 
       <br>
      </div> 
      <b></b>
      <br> 
      <div style="text-align: justify;"> 
       <b><b>Changes:</b></b>
      </div> 
      <b> </b> 
      <br> 
      <div style="text-align: justify;"> 
       <br>
      </div> 
      <div style="text-align: justify;">
        * Added group vulnerabilities by any field in our Status Report
      </div> 
      <br> 
      <br> 
      <div class="separator" style="clear: both; text-align: center;"> 
       <a href="http://1.bp.blogspot.com/-6bJpbbHBWYQ/Vngufvv4vjI/AAAAAAAABn0/_MoRoUvkPTg/s1600/Screen%2BShot%2B2015-12-21%2Bat%2B1.52.14%2BPM.png" imageanchor="1" style="margin-left: 1em; margin-right: 1em;"><img border="0" height="224" src="http://1.bp.blogspot.com/-6bJpbbHBWYQ/Vngufvv4vjI/AAAAAAAABn0/_MoRoUvkPTg/s640/Screen%2BShot%2B2015-12-21%2Bat%2B1.52.14%2BPM.png" width="640"></a>
      </div> 
      <div class="separator" style="clear: both; text-align: right;"> 
      </div> 
      <div class="separator" style="clear: both; text-align: center;"> 
      </div> 
      <div class="separator" style="clear: both; text-align: center;"> 
       <a href="http://3.bp.blogspot.com/-sTV1n5NQmKc/Vngufn9SEBI/AAAAAAAABns/NOzd6H6I4iA/s1600/Screen%2BShot%2B2015-12-21%2Bat%2B1.50.49%2BPM.png" imageanchor="1" style="margin-left: 1em; margin-right: 1em;"><img border="0" height="236" src="http://3.bp.blogspot.com/-sTV1n5NQmKc/Vngufn9SEBI/AAAAAAAABns/NOzd6H6I4iA/s640/Screen%2BShot%2B2015-12-21%2Bat%2B1.50.49%2BPM.png" width="640"></a>
      </div> 
      <div style="text-align: right;"> 
      </div> 
      <div style="text-align: center;"> 
      </div> 
      <div class="separator" style="clear: both; text-align: center;"> 
       <a href="http://1.bp.blogspot.com/-mop2l81nq1U/VngufmCQDvI/AAAAAAAABno/t6wDQWpcrWM/s1600/Screen%2BShot%2B2015-12-21%2Bat%2B1.52.28%2BPM.png" imageanchor="1" style="margin-left: 1em; margin-right: 1em;"><img border="0" height="276" src="http://1.bp.blogspot.com/-mop2l81nq1U/VngufmCQDvI/AAAAAAAABno/t6wDQWpcrWM/s640/Screen%2BShot%2B2015-12-21%2Bat%2B1.52.28%2BPM.png" width="640"></a>
      </div> 
      <div style="text-align: right;"> 
      </div> 
      <br> * Added port to Service type target in new vuln modal
      <b> </b>
      <br> * Filter false-positives in Dashboard, Status Report and Executive Report (Pro&amp;Corp)
      <br> 
      <br> 
      <table align="center" cellpadding="0" cellspacing="0" class="tr-caption-container" style="margin-left: auto; margin-right: auto; text-align: center;">
       <tbody> 
        <tr>
         <td><a href="http://3.bp.blogspot.com/-sxrS8w1pZKo/Vmn9JUboJMI/AAAAAAAAAB0/0DpsQ6bEg7I/s1600/confirmed.png" imageanchor="1" style="margin-left: 1em; margin-right: 1em;"><img border="0" height="310" src="http://3.bp.blogspot.com/-sxrS8w1pZKo/Vmn9JUboJMI/AAAAAAAAAB0/0DpsQ6bEg7I/s320/confirmed.png" width="320"></a></td>
        </tr> 
        <tr>
         <td class="tr-caption">Filter in Status Report view</td>
         <td class="tr-caption"><br></td>
        </tr> 
       </tbody>
      </table> * Added Wiki information about running Faraday without configuring CouchDB 
      <a href="https://github.com/infobyte/faraday/wiki/APIs">https://github.com/infobyte/faraday/wiki/APIs</a>
      <br> * Added parametrization for port configuration on APIs
      <br> * Added scripts to:
      <br> &nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp; - get all IPs from targets that have no services (
      <b>/bin/getAllIpsNotServices.py</b>)
      <br> 
      <br> 
      <div class="separator" style="clear: both; text-align: center;"> 
      </div> 
      <div class="separator" style="clear: both; text-align: center;"> 
      </div> 
      <table align="center" cellpadding="0" cellspacing="0" class="tr-caption-container" style="margin-left: auto; margin-right: auto; text-align: center;">
       <tbody> 
        <tr>
         <td><a href="http://4.bp.blogspot.com/-5Qne-hiW1Uw/VmoQeu_0w5I/AAAAAAAAACE/-3jiLovRDYE/s1600/ips.png" imageanchor="1" style="margin-left: 1em; margin-right: 1em;"><img border="0" height="160" src="http://4.bp.blogspot.com/-5Qne-hiW1Uw/VmoQeu_0w5I/AAAAAAAAACE/-3jiLovRDYE/s400/ips.png" width="400"></a></td>
        </tr> 
        <tr>
         <td class="tr-caption">/bin/getAllIpsNotServices.py</td>
        </tr> 
       </tbody>
      </table> &nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp; - get all IP addresses that have defined open port (
      <b>/bin/getAllbySrv.py</b>) and get all IPs from targets without services (
      <b>/bin/delAllVulnsWith.py</b>)
      <br> &nbsp; &nbsp; &nbsp; &nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp; It's important to note that both these scripts hold a variable that you can modify to alter its behaviour. 
      <b>/bin/getAllbySrv.py</b> has a port variable set to 
      <b>8080</b> by default. 
      <b>/bin/delAllVulnsWith.py</b> does the same with a RegExp
      <br> * Added three Plugins:
      <br> &nbsp; &nbsp; - Immunity Canvas
      <br> 
      <br> 
      <table align="center" cellpadding="0" cellspacing="0" class="tr-caption-container" style="margin-left: auto; margin-right: auto; text-align: center;">
       <tbody> 
        <tr>
         <td><a href="http://1.bp.blogspot.com/-pK4bHajhxcs/VnRaXwPy6RI/AAAAAAAAACU/Du0TpQLvLk4/s1600/Screen%2BShot%2B2015-12-18%2Bat%2B3.54.56%2BPM.png" imageanchor="1" style="margin-left: auto; margin-right: auto;"><img border="0" height="244" src="http://1.bp.blogspot.com/-pK4bHajhxcs/VnRaXwPy6RI/AAAAAAAAACU/Du0TpQLvLk4/s640/Screen%2BShot%2B2015-12-18%2Bat%2B3.54.56%2BPM.png" width="640"></a></td>
        </tr> 
        <tr>
         <td class="tr-caption">Canvas configuration</td>
        </tr> 
       </tbody>
      </table> 
      <br> &nbsp; &nbsp; - Dig
      <br> &nbsp; &nbsp; - Traceroute 
      <br> * Refactor Plugin Base to update active WS name in var
      <br> * Refactor Plugins to use current WS in temp filename under $HOME/.faraday/data. Affected Plugins:
      <br> &nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp; - amap
      <br> &nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp; - dnsmap
      <br> &nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp; - nmap
      <br> &nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp; - sslcheck

      <br> * When the last workspace was null Faraday wouldn't start

    <article class="post hentry" id="7183930268699231991" itemscope itemtype="http://schema.org/BlogPosting"> 
     <h1 class="post-title entry-title" itemprop="name headline"> Faraday v1.0.7 - Integrated Penetration-Test Environment a multiuser Penetration test IDE  </h1> 
     <div class="post-header" style="position:absolute;left:-9999px"> 
      <div class="post-header-line-1"></div> 
     </div> 
     <div class="post-body entry-content" id="post-body-7183930268699231991" itemprop="articleBody"> 
      <div class="separator" style="clear: both; text-align: center;"> 
       <a href="http://1.bp.blogspot.com/-c9kA47sqiOk/VKs4kpGezgI/AAAAAAAADf0/_O6ZYhR4lnA/s1600/faraday.png" imageanchor="1" style="margin-left: 1em; margin-right: 1em;"><img border="0" src="http://1.bp.blogspot.com/-c9kA47sqiOk/VKs4kpGezgI/AAAAAAAADf0/_O6ZYhR4lnA/s1600/faraday.png" height="400" width="640"></a>
      </div> 
      <br> 
      <br> 
      <div style="text-align: justify;">
        Faraday introduces a new concept (IPE) Integrated Penetration-Test Environment a multiuser Penetration test IDE. Designed for distribution, indexation and analysis of the generated data during the process of a security audit.
      </div> 
      <div style="text-align: justify;"> 
       <br>
      </div> 
      <div style="text-align: justify;">
        The main purpose of Faraday is to re-use the available tools in the community to take advantage of them in a multiuser way.
      </div> 
      <div style="text-align: justify;"> 
       <br>
      </div> 
      <div style="text-align: justify;">
        Designed for simplicity, users should notice no difference between their own terminal application and the one included in Faraday. Developed with a specialized set of functionalities that help users improve their own work. Do you remember yourself programming without an IDE? Well, Faraday does the same as an IDE does for you when programming, but from the perspective of a penetration test.
      </div> 
      <div style="text-align: justify;"> 
      </div> 
      <a name="more"></a>
      <br> 
      <div class="separator" style="clear: both; text-align: justify;"> 
       <b>Changes made to the UX/UI:</b>
      </div> 
      <div class="post"> 
       <ul> 
        <li style="text-align: justify;">Improved Vulnerability Edition usability, selecting a vulnerability will load it's content automatically.</li> 
        <li style="text-align: justify;">ZSH UI now is showing notifications.</li> 
        <li style="text-align: justify;">ZSH UI displays active workspaces.</li> 
        <li style="text-align: justify;">Faraday now asks confirmation when exiting out. If you have pending conflicts to resolve it will show the number for each one.</li> 
        <li style="text-align: justify;">Vulnerability creation is now supported in the status report.</li> 
        <li style="text-align: justify;">Introducing SSLCheck, a tool for&nbsp;verifying&nbsp;bugs in SSL/TLS Certificates on remote hosts. This&nbsp;is integrated with Faraday as a plugin.</li> 
        <li style="text-align: justify;">Shodan Plugin is now working with the new API.</li> 
        <li style="text-align: justify;">Some cosmetic changes for the status report.</li> 
       </ul> 
       <div style="text-align: justify;"> 
        <b>Bugfixes:</b>
       </div> 
       <ul> 
        <li style="text-align: justify;">Sorting columns in the Status Report is running smoothly.</li> 
        <li style="text-align: justify;">The Workspace icon is now based on the type of workspace being used.</li> 
        <li style="text-align: justify;">Opening the reports in QT UI opens the active workspace.</li> 
        <li style="text-align: justify;">UI Web dates fixes, we were showing dates with a off-by-one error.</li> 
        <li style="text-align: justify;">Vulnerability edition was missing 'critical' severity.</li> 
        <li style="text-align: justify;">Objects merge bugfixing</li> 
        <li style="text-align: justify;">Metadata recursive save fix</li> 
       </ul> 
      </div> 
      <br> 
      <div style="text-align: center;"> 
       <b><span class="Apple-style-span" style="font-size: x-large;"><a href="http://www.faradaysec.com/buy.html" target="_blank">Download&nbsp;Faraday</a></span></b>
      </div> 
     </div>
    </article> 
    <article class="post hentry" id="5834528921988621529" itemscope itemtype="http://schema.org/BlogPosting"> 
     <h1 class="post-title entry-title" itemprop="name headline"> FastNetMon - Very Fast DDoS Analyzer with Sflow/Netflow/Mirror Support  </h1> 
     <div class="post-header" style="position:absolute;left:-9999px"> 
      <div class="post-header-line-1"></div> 
     </div> 
     <div class="post-body entry-content" id="post-body-5834528921988621529" itemprop="articleBody"> 
      <div class="separator" style="clear: both; text-align: center;"> 
       <a href="http://3.bp.blogspot.com/-yZKloHqWlk8/VVEV5EHTA2I/AAAAAAAAD_4/BcucEwHqsTE/s1600/fastnetmon_screen.png" imageanchor="1" style="margin-left: 1em; margin-right: 1em;"><img border="0" height="508" src="http://3.bp.blogspot.com/-yZKloHqWlk8/VVEV5EHTA2I/AAAAAAAAD_4/BcucEwHqsTE/s640/fastnetmon_screen.png" width="640"></a>
      </div> 
      <br> 
      <div style="text-align: justify;">
        A high performance DoS/DDoS load analyzer built on top of multiple packet capture engines (NetFlow, IPFIX, sFLOW, netmap, PF_RING, PCAP).
      </div> 
      <div style="text-align: justify;"> 
       <br>
      </div> 
      <div style="text-align: justify;">
        What can we do? We can detect hosts in our own network with a large amount of packets per second/bytes per second or flow per second incoming or outgoing from certain hosts. And we can call an external script which can notify you, switch off a server or blackhole the client.
      </div> 
      <a name="more"></a>
      <br> 
      <div style="text-align: justify;"> 
       <b><span class="Apple-style-span" style="font-size: large;">Features:</span></b>
      </div> 
      <ul> 
       <li style="text-align: justify;">Can process incoming and outgoing traffic</li> 
       <li style="text-align: justify;">Can trigger block script if certain IP loads network with a large amount of packets/bytes/flows per second</li> 
       <li style="text-align: justify;">Could <a href="https://github.com/FastVPSEestiOu/fastnetmon/blob/master/docs/EXABGP_INTEGRATION.md">announce blocked IPs</a> to BGP router with <a href="https://github.com/Exa-Networks/exabgp">ExaBGP</a> </li> 
       <li style="text-align: justify;">Have integration with <a href="https://github.com/FastVPSEestiOu/fastnetmon/blob/master/docs/GRAPHITE_INTEGRATION.md">Graphite</a> </li> 
       <li style="text-align: justify;">netmap support (open source; wire speed processing; only Intel hardware NICs or any hypervisor VM type)</li> 
       <li style="text-align: justify;">Supports L2TP decapsulation, VLAN untagging and MPLS processing in mirror mode </li> 
       <li style="text-align: justify;">Can work on server/soft-router</li> 
       <li style="text-align: justify;">Can detect DoS/DDoS in 1-2 seconds</li> 
       <li style="text-align: justify;">Tested up to 10GE with 5-6 Mpps on Intel i7 2600 with Intel Nic 82599</li> 
       <li style="text-align: justify;">Complete plugin support</li> 
       <li style="text-align: justify;">Have <a href="https://github.com/FastVPSEestiOu/fastnetmon/blob/master/docs/DETECTED_ATTACK_TYPES.md">complete support</a> for most popular attack types</li> 
      </ul> 
      <div style="text-align: justify;"> 
       <br>
      </div> 
      <div style="text-align: justify;"> 
       <b><span class="Apple-style-span" style="font-size: large;">Supported platforms:</span></b>
      </div> 
      <ul> 
       <li style="text-align: justify;">Linux (Debian 6/7/8, CentOS 6/7, Ubuntu 12+)</li> 
       <li style="text-align: justify;">FreeBSD 9, 10, 11</li> 
       <li style="text-align: justify;">Mac OS X Yosemite </li> 
      </ul> 
      <div style="text-align: justify;">
        What is "flow" in FastNetMon terms? It's one or multiple udp, tcp, icmp connections with unique src IP, dst IP, src port, dst port and protocol.
      </div> 
      <div style="text-align: justify;"> 
       <br>
      </div> 
      <div style="text-align: justify;">
        Example for cpu load on Intel i7 2600 with Intel X540/82599 NIC on 400 kpps load:
      </div> 
      <div class="separator" style="clear: both; text-align: center;"> 
       <a href="http://3.bp.blogspot.com/-bliUMqzeJ48/VVEWpYdva6I/AAAAAAAAEAA/N8p1q8g4sF8/s1600/fastnetmon_stats.png" imageanchor="1" style="margin-left: 1em; margin-right: 1em;"><img border="0" src="http://3.bp.blogspot.com/-bliUMqzeJ48/VVEWpYdva6I/AAAAAAAAEAA/N8p1q8g4sF8/s1600/fastnetmon_stats.png"></a>
      </div> 
      <br> 
      <br> To enable sFLOW simply specify IP of server with installed FastNetMon and specify port 6343. To enable netflow simply specify IP of server with installed FastNetMon and specify port 2055.
      <br> Why did we write this? Because we can't find any software for solving this problem in the open source world!
      <br> 
      <br> 
      <br> 
      <div style="text-align: center;"> 
       <b><span class="Apple-style-span" style="font-size: x-large;"><a href="https://github.com/FastVPSEestiOu/fastnetmon" target="_blank">Download&nbsp;FastNetMon</a></span></b>
      </div> 
     </div>
    </article> 
    <article class="post hentry" id="6155240189394085220" itemscope itemtype="http://schema.org/BlogPosting"> 
     <h1 class="post-title entry-title" itemprop="name headline"> Fing - Find out Which Devices are Connected to your Wi-Fi Network  </h1> 
     <div class="post-header" style="position:absolute;left:-9999px"> 
      <div class="post-header-line-1"></div> 
     </div> 
     <div class="post-body entry-content" id="post-body-6155240189394085220" itemprop="articleBody"> 
      <div class="separator" style="clear: both; text-align: center;"> 
       <a href="http://3.bp.blogspot.com/-Y2-rNi33acI/VVV0YHxlsqI/AAAAAAAAEBQ/JlCp_qdMJWI/s1600/fing_1.jpg" imageanchor="1" style="margin-left: 1em; margin-right: 1em;"><img border="0" height="400" src="http://3.bp.blogspot.com/-Y2-rNi33acI/VVV0YHxlsqI/AAAAAAAAEBQ/JlCp_qdMJWI/s400/fing_1.jpg" width="240"></a>
       <a href="http://2.bp.blogspot.com/--3eEX8aJMhk/VVV0ZVKMZmI/AAAAAAAAEBY/gS90-n7-xjA/s1600/fing_2.jpg" imageanchor="1" style="margin-left: 1em; margin-right: 1em;"><img border="0" height="400" src="http://2.bp.blogspot.com/--3eEX8aJMhk/VVV0ZVKMZmI/AAAAAAAAEBY/gS90-n7-xjA/s400/fing_2.jpg" width="240"></a>
      </div> 
      <br> 
      <div style="text-align: justify;">
        Find out which devices are connected to your Wi-Fi network, in just a few seconds.
      </div> 
      <div style="text-align: justify;"> 
       <br>
      </div> Fast and accurate, Fing is a professional App for network analysis. A simple and intuitive interface helps you evaluate security levels, detect intruders and resolve network issues.
      <br> 
      <a name="more"></a>
      <ul> 
       <li style="text-align: justify;">Discovers all devices connected to a Wi-Fi network. Unlimited devices and unlimited networks, for free!&nbsp;</li> 
       <li style="text-align: justify;">Displays MAC Address and device manufacturer.</li> 
       <li style="text-align: justify;">Enter your own names, icons, notes and location</li> 
       <li style="text-align: justify;">Full search by IP, MAC, Name, Vendor and Notes&nbsp;</li> 
       <li style="text-align: justify;">History of all discovered networks.&nbsp;</li> 
       <li style="text-align: justify;">Share via Twitter, Facebook, Message and E-mail</li> 
       <li style="text-align: justify;">Service Scan: Find hundreds of open ports in a few seconds.</li> 
       <li style="text-align: justify;">Wake On LAN: Switch on your devices from your mobile or tablet!&nbsp;</li> 
       <li style="text-align: justify;">Ping and traceroute: Understand your network performances.</li> 
       <li style="text-align: justify;">Automatic DNS lookup and reverse lookup</li> 
       <li style="text-align: justify;">Checks the availability of Internet connection</li> 
       <li style="text-align: justify;">Works also with hosts outside your local network&nbsp;</li> 
       <li style="text-align: justify;">Tracks when a device has gone online or offline</li> 
       <li style="text-align: justify;">Launch Apps for specific ports, such as Browser, SSH, FTP&nbsp;</li> 
       <li style="text-align: justify;">Displays NetBIOS names and properties</li> 
       <li style="text-align: justify;">Displays Bonjour info and properties</li> 
       <li style="text-align: justify;">Supports identification by IP address for bridged networks</li> 
       <li style="text-align: justify;">Sort by IP, MAC, Name, Vendor, State, Last Change.&nbsp;</li> 
       <li style="text-align: justify;">Free of charge, no banner Ads&nbsp;</li> 
       <li style="text-align: justify;">Available for iPhone, iPad and iPod Touch with retina and standard displays.</li> 
       <li style="text-align: justify;">Integrates with Fingbox to sync and backup your customizations, merge networks with multiple access points, monitor remote networks via Fingbox Sentinels, get notifications of changes, and much more.&nbsp;</li> 
       <li style="text-align: justify;">Fing is available on several other platforms, including Windows, OS X and Linux. Check them out!</li> 
      </ul> 
      <div> 
       <br>
      </div> 
      <div style="text-align: center;"> 
       <b><span class="Apple-style-span" style="font-size: x-large;"><a href="https://play.google.com/store/apps/details?id=com.overlook.android.fing&amp;hl=es_419" target="_blank">Download&nbsp;Fing</a></span></b>
      </div> 
     </div>
    </article> 
    <article class="post hentry" id="5281377082215057927" itemscope itemtype="http://schema.org/BlogPosting"> 
     <h1 class="post-title entry-title" itemprop="name headline"> Firefox Autocomplete Spy - Tool to View or Delete Autofill Data from Mozilla Firefox  </h1> 
     <div class="post-header" style="position:absolute;left:-9999px"> 
      <div class="post-header-line-1"></div> 
     </div> 
     <div class="post-body entry-content" id="post-body-5281377082215057927" itemprop="articleBody"> 
      <div class="separator" style="clear: both; text-align: center;"> 
       <a href="http://2.bp.blogspot.com/-a1Z6nAaqF3U/VWstJyfB1JI/AAAAAAAAEKU/8pw8VB44Sa4/s1600/firefoxautocompletespy.jpg" imageanchor="1" style="margin-left: 1em; margin-right: 1em;"><img border="0" height="488" src="http://2.bp.blogspot.com/-a1Z6nAaqF3U/VWstJyfB1JI/AAAAAAAAEKU/8pw8VB44Sa4/s640/firefoxautocompletespy.jpg" width="640"></a>
      </div> 
      <br> 
      <div style="text-align: justify;"> 
       <strong>Firefox Autocomplete Spy</strong> is the free tool to easily view and delete all your autocomplete data from Firefox browser. 
      </div> 
      <div style="text-align: justify;"> 
       <br>
      </div> 
      <div style="text-align: justify;">
        Firefox stores Autocomplete entries (typically form fields) such as login name, email, address, phone, credit/debit card number, search history etc in an internal database file.
       <br> 
       <a name="more"></a>
      </div> 
      <div style="text-align: justify;"> 
       <br>
      </div> 
      <div style="text-align: justify;">
        'Firefox Autocomplete Spy' helps you to 
       <b>automatically find</b> and view all the Autocomplete history data from Firefox profile location. For each of the entry, it display following details, 
      </div> 
      <ul> 
       <li style="text-align: justify;">Field Name</li> 
       <li style="text-align: justify;"> Value</li> 
       <li style="text-align: justify;">Total Used Count</li> 
       <li style="text-align: justify;"> First Used Date</li> 
       <li style="text-align: justify;"> Last Used Date</li> 
      </ul> 
      <div style="text-align: justify;"> 
       <br>
      </div> 
      <div style="text-align: justify;">
        You can also use it to view from history file belonging to 
       <b>another user on same or remote system</b>. It also provides one click solution to 
       <b>delete all</b> the displayed Autocomplete data from the history file. 
      </div> 
      <div style="text-align: justify;"> 
       <br>
      </div> 
      <div style="text-align: justify;">
        It is very simple to use for everyone, especially makes it handy tool for 
       <b>Forensic investigators</b>. 
      </div> 
      <div style="text-align: justify;"> 
       <br>
      </div> 
      <div style="text-align: justify;">
        Firefox Autocomplete Spy is fully portable and works on both 32-bit &amp; 64-bit platforms starting from Windows XP to 
       <b>Windows 8.</b> 
      </div> 
      <div style="text-align: justify;"> 
       <br>
      </div> 
      <div style="text-align: justify;"> 
       <b><span style="font-size: large;">Features</span></b>
      </div> 
      <ul> 
       <li style="text-align: justify;">Instantly view all the autocomplete data from Firefox form history file</li> 
       <li style="text-align: justify;">On startup, it auto detects Autocomplete file from default profile location</li> 
       <li style="text-align: justify;">Sort feature to arrange the data in various order to make it easier to search through 100's of entries.</li> 
       <li style="text-align: justify;">Delete all the Autocomplete data with just a click of button</li> 
       <li style="text-align: justify;">Save the displayed autocomplete list to HTML/XML/TEXT/CSV file</li> 
       <li style="text-align: justify;">Easier and faster to use with its enhanced user friendly GUI interface</li> 
       <li style="text-align: justify;">Fully Portable, does not require any third party components like JAVA, .NET etc</li> 
       <li style="text-align: justify;">Support for local Installation and uninstallation of the software</li> 
      </ul> 
      <div style="text-align: justify;"> 
       <br>
      </div> 
      <div style="text-align: justify;"> 
       <b><span style="font-size: large;">How to Use</span></b>
      </div> 
      <div style="text-align: justify;"> 
       <br>
      </div> 
      <div style="text-align: justify;">
        Firefox Autocomplete Spy is easy to use with its simple GUI interface.
      </div> 
      <div style="text-align: justify;"> 
       <br>
      </div> 
      <div style="text-align: justify;">
        Here are the brief usage details
      </div> 
      <ul> 
       <li style="text-align: justify;">Launch FirefoxAutocompleteSpy on your system </li> 
       <li style="text-align: justify;">By default it will automatically find and display the autocomplete file from default profile location. You can also select the desired file manually. </li> 
       <li style="text-align: justify;">Next click on <span class="highlight">'Show All'</span> button and all stored Autocomplete data will be displayed in the list as shown in screenshot 1 below.</li> 
       <li style="text-align: justify;">If you want to remove all the entries, click on 'Delete All' button below.</li> 
       <li style="text-align: justify;">Finally you can save all displayed entries to <span class="highlight">HTML/XML/TEXT/CSV </span>file by clicking on 'Export' button and then select the type of file from the drop down box of 'Save File Dialog'.</li> 
      </ul> 
      <br> 
      <br> 
      <div style="text-align: center;"> 
       <b><span style="font-size: x-large;"><a href="http://securityxploded.com/firefox-autocomplete-spy.php" target="_blank">Download&nbsp;Firefox Autocomplete Spy</a></span></b>
      </div> 
     </div>
    </article> 
    <article class="post hentry" id="3153112564145072164" itemscope itemtype="http://schema.org/BlogPosting"> 
     <h1 class="post-title entry-title" itemprop="name headline"> FireMaster - The Firefox Master Password Cracking Tool  </h1> 
     <div class="post-header" style="position:absolute;left:-9999px"> 
      <div class="post-header-line-1"></div> 
     </div> 
     <div class="post-body entry-content" id="post-body-3153112564145072164" itemprop="articleBody"> 
      <div class="separator" style="clear: both; text-align: center;"> 
       <a href="http://2.bp.blogspot.com/-4vONscPWYOM/VcKywEZgIbI/AAAAAAAAEdU/oeLDGNC1re0/s1600/firemaster.jpg" imageanchor="1" style="margin-left: 1em; margin-right: 1em;"><img border="0" height="488" src="http://2.bp.blogspot.com/-4vONscPWYOM/VcKywEZgIbI/AAAAAAAAEdU/oeLDGNC1re0/s640/firemaster.jpg" width="640"></a>
      </div> 
      <br> 
      <div style="text-align: justify;"> 
       <span style="font-weight: bold;">FireMaster</span> is the 
       <strong>First</strong> ever tool to recover the 
       <strong>lost Master Password</strong> of Firefox. 
      </div> 
      <div style="text-align: justify;"> 
       <br>
      </div> 
      <div style="text-align: justify;"> 
       <span style="font-weight: bold;">Master password</span> is used by Firefox to protect the stored loign/password information for all visited websites. If the master password is forgotten, then there is no way to recover the master password and user will lose all the passwords stored in it. 
      </div> 
      <div style="text-align: justify;"> 
       <br>
      </div> 
      <div style="text-align: justify;">
        However you can now use 
       <strong>FireMaster</strong> to recover the forgotten master password and get back all the stored Login/Passwords. 
      </div> 
      <div style="text-align: justify;"> 
       <br>
      </div> 
      <div style="text-align: justify;">
        FireMaster supports 
       <span style="font-weight: bold;">Dictionary</span>, 
       <span style="font-weight: bold;">Hybrid,</span> 
       <span style="font-weight: bold;">Brute-force</span> and advanced 
       <strong> Pattern</strong> 
       <strong>based Brute-force</strong> password cracking techniques to recover from simple to complex password. Advanced pattern based password recovery mechanism reduces cracking time significantly especially when the password is complex. 
      </div> 
      <div style="text-align: justify;"> 
       <br>
      </div> 
      <div style="text-align: justify;">
        FireMaster is successfully tested with 
       <strong>all versions of Firefox</strong> starting from 1.0 to latest version v13.0.1. 
      </div> 
      <div style="text-align: justify;"> 
       <br>
      </div> 
      <div style="text-align: justify;">
        It works on wide range of platforms starting from Windows XP to 
       <strong>Windows 8.</strong>
      </div> 
      <a name="more"></a>
      <br> 
      <div style="text-align: justify;"> 
       <b><span style="font-size: large;"><a href="https://draft.blogger.com/null" name="Firefox_Password_Manager_FireMaster"> </a>Firefox Password Manager and Master Password</span></b>
      </div> 
      <div style="text-align: justify;"> 
       <br>
      </div> 
      <div style="text-align: justify;"> 
       <strong>Firefox</strong> comes with built-in password manager tool which remembers username and passwords for all the websites you visit. This 
       <strong>login/password</strong> information is stored in the encrypted form in Firefox database files residing in user's profile directory. 
       <br> However any body can just launch the password manager from the Firefox browser and view the credentials. Also one can just copy these database files to different machine and view it offline using the tools such as 
       <a href="http://securityxploded.com/firepassword.php">FirePassword</a>.
      </div> 
      <div style="text-align: justify;"> 
       <br>
      </div> 
      <div style="text-align: justify;">
        Hence to protect from such threats, Firefox uses 
       <strong>master password</strong> to provide enhanced security. By default Firefox does not set the master password. However once you have set the master password, you need to provide it every time to view login credentials. So if you lose the master password then that means you have 
       <strong>lost all the stored passwords</strong> as well. 
      </div> 
      <div style="text-align: justify;"> 
       <br>
      </div> 
      <div style="text-align: justify;">
        So far there was no way to recover these credentials once you have lost the master password. Now the 
       <strong>FireMaster</strong> can help you to recover the master password and get back all the sign-on information.
      </div> 
      <div style="text-align: justify;"> 
       <br>
      </div> 
      <div style="text-align: justify;"> 
       <b><span style="font-size: large;"><a href="https://draft.blogger.com/null" name="Internals_FireMaster"> </a>Internals of FireMaster</span></b>
      </div> 
      <div style="text-align: justify;"> 
       <br>
      </div> 
      <div style="text-align: justify;">
        Once you have lost master password, there is no way to recover it as it is not stored at all. 
       <br> Whenever user enters the master password, Firefox uses it to decrypt the encrypted data associated with the known string. If the decrypted data matches this known string then the entered password is correct. FireMaster uses the similar technique to check for the master password, but in more optimized way. 
       <br> The entire operation goes like this. 
      </div> 
      <ul style="line-height: 180%;"> 
       <li style="text-align: justify;">FireMaster generates passwords on the fly through various methods. </li> 
       <li style="text-align: justify;">Then it computes the hash of the password using known algorithm.</li> 
       <li style="text-align: justify;">Next this password hash is used to decrypt the encrypted data for known plain text (i.e. <span style="font-weight: bold;">"password-check"</span>).</li> 
       <li style="text-align: justify;">Now if the decrypted string matches with the known plain text (i.e. "password-check") then the generated password is the master password.</li> 
      </ul> 
      <div style="text-align: justify;"> 
       <br>
      </div> 
      <div style="text-align: justify;">
        Firefox stores the details about encrypted string, salt, algorithm and version information in key database file 
       <strong>key3.db</strong> in the user's profile directory. You can just copy this key3.db file to different directory and specify the corresponding path to FireMaster. You can also copy this key3.db to any other high end machine for faster recovery operation.
      </div> 
      <div style="text-align: justify;"> 
       <br>
      </div> 
      <div style="text-align: justify;"> 
       <b><span style="font-size: large;">FireMaster supports following password recovery methods</span></b>
      </div> 
      <div style="text-align: justify;"> 
       <br>
      </div> 
      <div style="text-align: justify;"> 
       <b><a href="https://draft.blogger.com/null" name="Dictionary_Method"></a>1) Dictionary Cracking Method</b>
      </div> 
      <div style="text-align: justify;">
        In this mode, FireMaster uses dictionary file having each word on separate line to perform the operation. You can find lot of online dictionary with different sizes and pass it on to Firemaster. This method is more quicker and can find out common passwords.
      </div> 
      <div style="text-align: justify;"> 
       <br>
      </div> 
      <div style="text-align: justify;"> 
       <b><a href="https://draft.blogger.com/null" name="Hybrid_Method"> </a>2) Hybrid Cracking Method</b>
      </div> 
      <div style="text-align: justify;">
        This is advanced dictionary method, in which each word in the dictionary file is prefixed or suffixed with generated word from known character list. This can find out password like pass123, 12test, test34 etc. From the specified character list (such as 123), all combinations of strings are generated and appended or prefixed to the dictionary word based on user settings.
      </div> 
      <div style="text-align: justify;"> 
       <br>
      </div> 
      <div style="text-align: justify;"> 
       <b><a href="https://draft.blogger.com/null" name="Bruteforce_Method"> </a>3) Brute-force Cracking Method</b>
      </div> 
      <div style="text-align: justify;">
        In this method, all possible combinations of words from given character list is generated and then subjected to cracking process. This may take long time depending upon the number of characters and position count specified.&nbsp;
      </div> 
      <div style="text-align: justify;"> 
       <br>
      </div> 
      <div style="text-align: justify;"> 
       <b>4) Pattern based Brute-force Cracking Method</b>
      </div> 
      <div style="text-align: justify;">
        Pattern based cracking method significantly reduces the password recovery time especially when password is complex. This method can be used when you know the exact password length and remember few characters.
      </div> 
      <div style="text-align: justify;"> 
       <br>
      </div> 
      <div style="text-align: justify;"> 
       <b><span style="font-size: large;">How to use FireMaster?</span></b>
      </div> 
      <div style="text-align: justify;"> 
       <br>
      </div> 
      <div style="text-align: justify;">
        First you need to copy the 
       <strong>key3.db</strong> file to temporary directory. Later you have to specify this directory path for FireMaster as a last argument.
      </div> 
      <div style="text-align: justify;"> 
       <br>
      </div> 
      <div style="text-align: justify;">
        Here is the general usage information
      </div> 
      <br> 
      <pre><code>Firemaster [-q]
           [-d -f 
        <dict_file>
         ] [-h -f 
         <dict_file>
           -n 
          <length>
            -g "charlist" [ -s | -p ] ] [-b -m 
           <length>
             -l 
            <length>
              -c "charlist" -p "pattern" ] 
             <firefox_profile_path>
               Note: With v5.0 onwards, you can specify 'auto' (without quotes) in place of "
              <firefox_profile_path>
               " to automatically detect default profile path. Dictionary Crack Options: -d Perform dictionary crack -f Dictionary file with words on each line Hybrid Crack Options: -h Perform hybrid crack operation using dictionary passwords. Hybrid crack can find passwords like pass123, 123pass etc -f Dictionary file with words on each line -g Group of characters used for generating the strings -n Maximum length of strings to be generated using above character list These strings are added to the dictionary word to form the password -s Suffix the generated characters to the dictionary word(pass123) -p Prefix the generated characters to the dictionary word(123pass) Brute Force Crack Options: -b Perform brute force crack -c Character list used for brute force cracking process -m [Optional] Specify the minimum length of password -l Specify the maximum length of password -p [Optional] Specify the pattern for the password
              </firefox_profile_path>
             </firefox_profile_path>
            </length>
           </length>
          </length>
         </dict_file>
        </dict_file></code></pre> 
      <br> Examples of FireMaster
      <br> 
      <pre><code>// Dictionary Crack
FireMaster.exe -d -f c:\dictfile.txt auto
 
// Hybrid Crack
FireMaster.exe -h -f c:\dictfile.txt -n 3 -g "123" -s auto
 
 // Brute-force Crack
FireMaster.exe -q -b -m 3 -l 10 -c "abcdetps123" "c:\my test\firefox"
 
 // Brute-force Crack with Pattern
FireMaster.exe -q -b -m 3 -c "abyz126" -l 10 -p "pa??f??123" auto
</code></pre> 
      <br> 
      <br> 
      <div style="text-align: center;"> 
       <b><span style="font-size: x-large;"><a href="http://securityxploded.com/download.php#firemaster" target="_blank">Download FireMaster</a></span></b>
      </div> 
     </div>
    </article> 
    <article class="post hentry" id="5406334574963516507" itemscope itemtype="http://schema.org/BlogPosting"> 
     <h1 class="post-title entry-title" itemprop="name headline"> FireMasterCracker - Firefox Master Password Cracking Software  </h1> 
     <div class="post-header" style="position:absolute;left:-9999px"> 
      <div class="post-header-line-1"></div> 
     </div> 
     <div class="post-body entry-content" id="post-body-5406334574963516507" itemprop="articleBody"> 
      <div class="separator" style="clear: both; text-align: center;"> 
       <a href="http://2.bp.blogspot.com/--mQxsbx2B0Y/VdqcSun1EfI/AAAAAAAAEg8/dQHIV4rNL68/s1600/firemastercracker.jpg" imageanchor="1" style="margin-left: 1em; margin-right: 1em;"><img border="0" height="500" src="http://2.bp.blogspot.com/--mQxsbx2B0Y/VdqcSun1EfI/AAAAAAAAEg8/dQHIV4rNL68/s640/firemastercracker.jpg" width="640"></a>
      </div> 
      <br> 
      <div style="text-align: justify;"> 
       <div style="text-align: justify;"> 
        <br>
       </div> 
       <div style="text-align: justify;">
         Firefox browser uses 
        <strong>Master password</strong> to protect the stored login passwords for all visited websites. If the master password is forgotten, then there is no way to recover the Master Password and user will also lose all the webiste 
        <strong>login passwords</strong>.
        <br> 
        <a name="more"></a>
        <br> In such cases, FireMasterCracker can help you to recover the lost Master Password. It uses 
        <strong>dictionary</strong> based password cracking method. You can find good collection of password dictionaries (also called wordlist).
        <br> 
        <br> Though it supports only Dictinary Crack method, you can easily use tools like 
        <a href="http://sourceforge.net/projects/crunch-wordlist/" target="_blank">Crunch</a>, 
        <a href="http://www.darknet.org.uk/2010/09/cupp-common-user-passwords-profiler-automated-password-profiling-tool/" target="_blank">Cupp</a> to generate 
        <strong>brute-force</strong> based or any custom password list file and then use it with FireMasterCracker.
        <br> 
        <br> It is very easy to use with its cool &amp; simple interface. It is designed to make it very simpler and quicker for users who find it difficult to use command-line based FireMaster. 
        <br> 
        <br> 
        <br> FireMasterCracker works on wide range of platforms starting from Windows XP to 
        <strong>Windows 8</strong>. 
        <br> 
        <br> 
        <b><span style="font-size: large;">Features </span></b>
        <br> 
        <br> Here are prime features of FireMasterCracker 
        <br> 
        <ul> 
         <li>Free &amp; Easiest tool to recover the Firefox Master Password </li> 
         <li> Supports Dictionary based Password Recovery method </li> 
         <li> Automatically detects the current Firefox profile location </li> 
         <li> Displays detailed statistics during Cracking operation </li> 
         <li> Stop the password cracking operation any time. </li> 
         <li> Easy to use with cool graphics interface. </li> 
         <li> Generate Password Recovery report in HTML/XML/TEXT format. </li> 
         <li> Includes Installer for local Installation &amp; Uninstallation.&nbsp;</li> 
        </ul> 
        <div> 
         <br>
        </div> 
        <div style="text-align: center;"> 
         <a href="http://securityxploded.com/download.php#firemastercracker" target="_blank"><b><span style="font-size: x-large;">Download&nbsp;FireMasterCracker</span></b></a>
        </div> 
       </div> 
      </div>
     </div>

    <article class="post hentry" id="7759707119583855325" itemscope itemtype="http://schema.org/BlogPosting"> 
     <h1 class="post-title entry-title" itemprop="name headline"> FirePassword - Firefox Username &amp; Password Recovery Tool  </h1> 
     <div class="post-header" style="position:absolute;left:-9999px"> 
      <div class="post-header-line-1"></div> 
     </div> 
     <div class="post-body entry-content" id="post-body-7759707119583855325" itemprop="articleBody"> 
      <div class="separator" style="clear: both; text-align: center;"> 
       <a href="http://3.bp.blogspot.com/-17hXA1DZUy8/VLhpc_7z-MI/AAAAAAAADjQ/PhzC5c0uqfc/s1600/firepassword.jpg" imageanchor="1" style="margin-left: 1em; margin-right: 1em;"><img border="0" src="http://3.bp.blogspot.com/-17hXA1DZUy8/VLhpc_7z-MI/AAAAAAAADjQ/PhzC5c0uqfc/s1600/firepassword.jpg" height="392" width="640"></a>
      </div> 
      <br> 
      <strong>FirePassword</strong> is first ever tool (back in early 2007) released to recover the stored website login passwords from 
      <strong>Firefox Browser</strong>.
      <br> 
      <br> 
      <div style="text-align: justify;">
        Like other browsers, Firefox also stores the login details such as username, password for every website visited by the user at the user consent. All these secret details are stored in Firefox sign-on database securely in an encrypted format. FirePassword can 
       <strong>instantly decrypt and recover</strong> these secrets even if they are protected with 
       <strong>Master Password</strong>.
       <br> 
       <a name="more"></a>
       <br> Also FirePassword can be used to recover sign-on passwords from different profile (for other users on the same system) as well as from the different operating system (such as Linux, Mac etc).
