     <h1 class="post-title entry-title" itemprop="name headline"> LMD - Linux Malware Detect  </h1> 
     <div class="post-header" style="position:absolute;left:-9999px"> 
      <div class="post-header-line-1"></div> 
     </div> 
     <div class="post-body entry-content" id="post-body-4087938785352396175" itemprop="articleBody"> 
      <div style="text-align: justify;">
        Linux Malware Detect (LMD) is a malware scanner for Linux released under the GNU GPLv2 license, that is designed around the threats faced in shared hosted environments. It uses threat data from network edge intrusion detection systems to extract malware that is actively being used in attacks and generates signatures for detection. In addition, threat data is also derived from user submissions with the LMD checkout feature and from malware community resources. The signatures that LMD uses are MD5 file hashes and HEX pattern matches, they are also easily exported to any number of detection tools such as ClamAV.
      </div> 
      <a name="more"></a>
      <br> 
      <div style="text-align: justify;">
        The driving force behind LMD is that there is currently limited availability of open source/restriction free tools for Linux systems that focus on malware detection and more important that get it right. Many of the AV products that perform malware detection on Linux have a very poor track record of detecting threats, especially those targeted at shared hosted environments. 
      </div> 
      <div style="text-align: justify;"> 
       <br>
      </div> 
      <div style="text-align: justify;">
        The threat landscape in shared hosted environments is unique from that of the standard AV products detection suite in that they are detecting primarily OS level trojans, rootkits and traditional file-infecting viruses but missing the ever increasing variety of malware on the user account level which serves as an attack platform.
      </div> 
      <div style="text-align: justify;"> 
       <br>
      </div> 
      <div style="text-align: justify;">
        The commercial products available for malware detection and remediation in multi-user shared environments remains abysmal. An analysis of 8,883 malware hashes, detected by LMD 1.5, against 30 commercial anti-virus and malware products paints a picture of how poorly commercial solutions perform.
      </div> 
      <pre><code>DETECTED KNOWN MALWARE: 1951
% AV DETECT (AVG): 58
% AV DETECT (LOW): 10
% AV DETECT (HIGH): 100
UNKNOWN MALWARE: 6931
</code></pre> 
      <div style="text-align: justify;">
        Using the Team Cymru malware hash registry, we can see that of the 8,883 malware hashes shipping with LMD 1.5, there was 6,931 or 78% of threats that went undetected by 30 commercial anti-virus and malware products. The 1,951 threats that were detected had an average detection rate of 58% with a low and high detection rate of 10% and 100% respectively. There could not be a clearer statement to the need for an open and community driven malware remediation project that focuses on the threat landscape of multi-user shared environments.
      </div> 
      <div style="text-align: justify;"> 
       <br>
      </div> 
      <div style="text-align: justify;"> 
       <strong><span style="font-size: large;">Features:</span></strong>
      </div> 
      <div style="text-align: justify;"> 
      </div> 
      <ul> 
       <li>MD5 file hash detection for quick threat identification</li> 
       <li>HEX based pattern matching for identifying threat variants</li> 
       <li>statistical analysis component for detection of obfuscated threats (e.g: base64)</li> 
       <li>integrated detection of ClamAV to use as scanner engine for improved performance</li> 
       <li>integrated signature update feature with -u|–update</li> 
       <li>integrated version update feature with -d|–update-ver</li> 
       <li>scan-recent option to scan only files that have been added/changed in X days</li> 
       <li>scan-all option for full path based scanning</li> 
       <li>checkout option to upload suspected malware to rfxn.com for review / hashing</li> 
       <li>full reporting system to view current and previous scan results</li> 
       <li>quarantine queue that stores threats in a safe fashion with no permissions</li> 
       <li>quarantine batching option to quarantine the results of a current or past scans</li> 
       <li>quarantine restore option to restore files to original path, owner and perms</li> 
       <li>quarantine suspend account option to Cpanel suspend or shell revoke users</li> 
       <li>cleaner rules to attempt removal of malware injected strings</li> 
       <li>cleaner batching option to attempt cleaning of previous scan reports</li> 
       <li>cleaner rules to remove base64 and gzinflate(base64 injected malware</li> 
       <li>daily cron based scanning of all changes in last 24h in user homedirs</li> 
       <li>daily cron script compatible with stock RH style systems, Cpanel &amp; Ensim</li> 
       <li>kernel based inotify real time file scanning of created/modified/moved files</li> 
       <li>kernel inotify monitor that can take path data from STDIN or FILE</li> 
       <li>kernel inotify monitor convenience feature to monitor system users</li> 
       <li>kernel inotify monitor can be restricted to a configurable user html root</li> 
       <li>kernel inotify monitor with dynamic sysctl limits for optimal performance</li> 
       <li>kernel inotify alerting through daily and/or optional weekly reports</li> 
       <li>e-mail alert reporting after every scan execution (manual &amp; daily)</li> 
       <li>path, extension and signature based ignore options</li> 
       <li>background scanner option for unattended scan operations</li> 
       <li>verbose logging &amp; output of all actions</li> 
      </ul> 
      <br> 
      <div style="text-align: justify;"> 
       <br>
      </div> 
      <div style="text-align: justify;"> 
       <strong><span style="font-size: large;">Source Data:</span></strong>
      </div> 
      <div style="text-align: justify;">
        The defining difference with LMD is that it doesn’t just detect malware based on signatures/hashes that someone else generated but rather it is an encompassing project that actively tracks in the wild threats and generates signatures based on those real world threats that are currently circulating.
      </div> 
      <div style="text-align: justify;"> 
       <br>
      </div> 
      <div style="text-align: justify;">
        There are four main sources for malware data that is used to generate LMD signatures:
      </div> 
      <div style="text-align: justify;">
        – 
       <em>Network Edge IPS:</em> Through networks managed as part of my day-to-day job, primarily web hosting related, our web servers receive a large amount of daily abuse events, all of which is logged by our network edge IPS. The IPS events are processed to extract malware url’s, decode POST payload and base64/gzip encoded abuse data and ultimately that malware is retrieved, reviewed, classified and then signatures generated as appropriate. The vast majority of LMD signatures have been derived from IPS extracted data.
      </div> 
      <div style="text-align: justify;">
        – 
       <em>Community Data:</em> Data is aggregated from multiple community malware websites such as clean-mx and malwaredomainlist then processed to retrieve new malware, review, classify and then generate signatures.
      </div> 
      <div style="text-align: justify;">
        – 
       <em>ClamAV:</em> The HEX &amp; MD5 detection signatures from ClamAV are monitored for relevant updates that apply to the target user group of LMD and added to the project as appropriate. To date there has been roughly 400 signatures ported from ClamAV while the LMD project has contributed back to ClamAV by submitting over 1,100 signatures and continues to do so on an ongoing basis.
      </div> 
      <div style="text-align: justify;">
        – 
       <em>User Submission:</em> LMD has a checkout feature that allows users to submit suspected malware for review, this has grown into a very popular feature and generates on average about 30-50 submissions per week.
      </div> 
      <div style="text-align: justify;"> 
       <br>
      </div> 
      <div style="text-align: justify;"> 
       <strong><span style="font-size: large;">Signature Updates:</span></strong>
      </div> 
      <div style="text-align: justify;">
        The LMD signature are updated typically once per day or more frequently depending on incoming threat data from the LMD checkout feature, IPS malware extraction and other sources. The updating of signatures in LMD installations is performed daily through the default cron.daily script with the –update option, which can be run manually at any time.
      </div> 
      <div style="text-align: justify;"> 
       <br>
      </div> 
      <div style="text-align: justify;">
        An RSS feed is available for tracking malware threat updates: 
       <a href="http://www.rfxn.com/api/lmd">http://www.rfxn.com/api/lmd</a>
      </div> 
      <div style="text-align: justify;"> 
       <br>
      </div> 
      <div style="text-align: justify;"> 
       <strong><span style="font-size: large;">Detected Threats:</span></strong>
      </div> 
      <div style="text-align: justify;">
        LMD 1.5 has a total of 10,822 (8,908 MD5 / 1,914) signatures, before any updates. The top 60 threats by prevalence detected by LMD are as follows:
      </div> 
      <pre><code>base64.inject.unclassed     perl.ircbot.xscan
bin.dccserv.irsexxy         perl.mailer.yellsoft
bin.fakeproc.Xnuxer         perl.shell.cbLorD
bin.ircbot.nbot             perl.shell.cgitelnet
bin.ircbot.php3             php.cmdshell.c100
bin.ircbot.unclassed        php.cmdshell.c99
bin.pktflood.ABC123         php.cmdshell.cih
bin.pktflood.osf            php.cmdshell.egyspider
bin.trojan.linuxsmalli      php.cmdshell.fx29
c.ircbot.tsunami            php.cmdshell.ItsmYarD
exp.linux.rstb              php.cmdshell.Ketemu
exp.linux.unclassed         php.cmdshell.N3tshell
exp.setuid0.unclassed       php.cmdshell.r57
gzbase64.inject             php.cmdshell.unclassed
html.phishing.auc61         php.defash.buno
html.phishing.hsbc          php.exe.globals
perl.connback.DataCha0s     php.include.remote
perl.connback.N2            php.ircbot.InsideTeam
perl.cpanel.cpwrap          php.ircbot.lolwut
perl.ircbot.atrixteam       php.ircbot.sniper
perl.ircbot.bRuNo           php.ircbot.vj_denie
perl.ircbot.Clx             php.mailer.10hack
perl.ircbot.devil           php.mailer.bombam
perl.ircbot.fx29            php.mailer.PostMan
perl.ircbot.magnum          php.phishing.AliKay
perl.ircbot.oldwolf         php.phishing.mrbrain
perl.ircbot.putr4XtReme     php.phishing.ReZulT
perl.ircbot.rafflesia       php.pktflood.oey
perl.ircbot.UberCracker     php.shell.rc99
perl.ircbot.xdh             php.shell.shellcomm
</code></pre> 
      <strong><br></strong> 
      <br> 
      <div style="text-align: justify;"> 
       <strong><span style="font-size: large;">Real-Time Monitoring:</span></strong>
      </div> 
      <div style="text-align: justify;">
        The inotify monitoring feature is designed to monitor paths/users in real-time for file creation/modify/move operations. This option requires a kernel that supports inotify_watch (CONFIG_INOTIFY) which is found in kernels 2.6.13+ and CentOS/RHEL 5 by default. If you are running CentOS 4 you should consider an inbox upgrade with:
      </div> 
      <div style="text-align: justify;"> 
       <a href="http://www.rfxn.com/upgrade-centos-4-8-to-5-3/">http://www.rfxn.com/upgrade-centos-4-8-to-5-3/</a>
      </div> 
      <div style="text-align: justify;"> 
       <br>
      </div> 
      <div style="text-align: justify;">
        There are three modes that the monitor can be executed with and they relate to what will be monitored, they are USERS|PATHS|FILES.
      </div> 
      <pre><code>       e.g: maldet --monitor users
       e.g: maldet --monitor /root/monitor_paths
       e.g: maldet --monitor /home/mike,/home/ashton
</code></pre> 
      <br> 
      <div style="text-align: justify;">
        The options break down as follows:
      </div> 
      <div style="text-align: justify;"> 
       <strong>USERS:</strong> The users option will take the homedirs of all system users that are above inotify_minuid and monitor them. If inotify_webdir is set then the users webdir, if it exists, will only be monitored.
      </div> 
      <div style="text-align: justify;"> 
       <strong>PATHS:</strong> A comma spaced list of paths to monitor
      </div> 
      <div style="text-align: justify;"> 
       <strong>FILE:</strong> A line spaced file list of paths to monitor
      </div> 
      <div style="text-align: justify;"> 
       <br>
      </div> 
      <div style="text-align: justify;">
        Once you start maldet in monitor mode, it will preprocess the paths based on the option specified followed by starting the inotify process. The starting of the inotify process can be a time consuming task as it needs to setup a monitor hook for every file under the monitored paths. Although the startup process can impact the load temporarily, once the process has started it maintains all of its resources inside kernel memory and has a very small userspace footprint in memory or cpu usage.
      </div> 
      <div style="text-align: justify;"> 
       <br>
      </div> 
      <div style="text-align: justify;"> 
       <br>
      </div> 
      <div style="text-align: center;"> 
       <b><span style="font-size: x-large;"><a href="https://github.com/rfxn/linux-malware-detect" target="_blank">Download LMD</a></span></b>
      </div> 
     </div>
    </article> 
    <article class="post hentry" id="3957062329978159103" itemscope itemtype="http://schema.org/BlogPosting"> 
     <h1 class="post-title entry-title" itemprop="name headline"> Loki - Scanner for Simple Indicators of Compromise  </h1> 
     <div class="post-header" style="position:absolute;left:-9999px"> 
      <div class="post-header-line-1"></div> 
     </div> 
     <div class="post-body entry-content" id="post-body-3957062329978159103" itemprop="articleBody"> 
      <div class="separator" style="clear: both; text-align: center;"> 
       <a href="http://4.bp.blogspot.com/-ZQw-y_cM9r8/VV303SS_RnI/AAAAAAAAEEs/qn-HuzQRRZU/s1600/loki.png" imageanchor="1" style="margin-left: 1em; margin-right: 1em;"><img border="0" src="http://4.bp.blogspot.com/-ZQw-y_cM9r8/VV303SS_RnI/AAAAAAAAEEs/qn-HuzQRRZU/s1600/loki.png"></a>
      </div> 
      <br> Simple IOC Scanner
      <br> 
      <br> Detection is based on four detection methods:
      <br> 
      <pre><code>1. File Name IOC
   Regex match on full file path/name

2. Yara Rule Check
   Yara signature match on file data and process memory

3. Hash check
   Compares known malicious hashes (MD5, SHA1, SHA256) with scanned files
</code></pre> The Windows binary is compiled with PyInstaller 2.1 and should run as x86 application on both x86 and x64 based systems.
      <br> 
      <a name="more"></a>
      <br> 
      <b><span style="font-size: large;">Run</span></b>
      <br> 
      <ul> 
       <li>Download the program archive via the button "Download ZIP" on the right sidebar</li> 
       <li>Unpack LOKI locally</li> 
       <li>Provide the folder to a target system that should be scanned: removable media, network share, folder on target system</li> 
       <li>Right-click on loki.exe and select "Run as Administrator" or open a command line "cmd.exe" as Administrator and run it from there (you can also run LOKI without administrative privileges but some checks will be disabled and relevant objects on disk will not be accessible)</li> 
      </ul> 
      <br> 
      <b><span style="font-size: large;">Reports</span></b>
      <br> 
      <ul> 
       <li>The resulting report will show a GREEN, YELLOW or RED result line.</li> 
       <li>Please analyse the findings yourself by: 
        <ol> 
         <li>uploading non-confidential samples to Virustotal.com</li> 
         <li>Search the web for the filename</li> 
         <li>Search the web for keywords from the rule name (e.g. EQUATIONGroupMalware_1 &gt; search for "Equation Group")</li> 
         <li>Search the web for the MD5 hash of the sample</li> 
        </ol> </li> 
       <li>Please report back false positives via the "Issues" section, which is accessible via the right sidebar (mention the false positive indicator like a hash and/or filename and the rule name that triggered)</li> 
      </ul> 
      <div> 
       <br> 
       <span style="font-size: large;"><b>Usage</b></span>
       <br> 
       <br> 
       <pre><code>usage: loki.exe [-h] [-p path] [-s kilobyte] [--printAll] [--noprocscan]
                [--nofilescan] [--noindicator] [--debug]

Loki - Simple IOC Scanner

optional arguments:
  -h, --help     show this help message and exit
  -p path        Path to scan
  -s kilobyte    Maximum file site to check in KB (default 2000 KB)
  --printAll     Print all files that are scanned
  --noprocscan   Skip the process scan
  --nofilescan   Skip the file scan
  --noindicator  Do not show a progress indicator
  --debug        Debug output
</code></pre> 
      </div> 
      <br> 
      <br> 
      <div style="text-align: center;"> 
       <b><span style="font-size: x-large;"><a href="https://github.com/Neo23x0/Loki" target="_blank">Download Loki</a></span></b>
      </div> 
     </div>
    </article> 
    <article class="post hentry" id="7823568563031162934" itemscope itemtype="http://schema.org/BlogPosting"> 
     <h1 class="post-title entry-title" itemprop="name headline"> LUKS-OPs - Automate the usage of LUKS volumes in Linux  </h1> 
     <div class="post-header" style="position:absolute;left:-9999px"> 
      <div class="post-header-line-1"></div> 
     </div> 
     <div class="post-body entry-content" id="post-body-7823568563031162934" itemprop="articleBody"> 
      <div class="separator" style="clear: both; text-align: center;"> 
       <a href="http://4.bp.blogspot.com/-G8UC5DaYD5M/VKnmzKI07AI/AAAAAAAADfQ/T7UvQIIHePI/s1600/luks-logo.png" imageanchor="1" style="margin-left: 1em; margin-right: 1em;"><img border="0" src="http://4.bp.blogspot.com/-G8UC5DaYD5M/VKnmzKI07AI/AAAAAAAADfQ/T7UvQIIHePI/s1600/luks-logo.png"></a>
      </div> 
      <br> A bash script to automate the most basic usage of LUKS volumes in Linux. Like:
      <br> 
      <ul class="task-list"> 
       <li>Creating a virtual disk volume with LUKS format.</li> 
       <li>Mounting an existing LUKS volume</li> 
       <li>Unmounting a Single LUKS volume or all LUKS volume in the system.</li> 
      </ul> 
      <a name="more"></a>
      <b><span style="font-size: large;">Basic Usage</span></b>
      <br> 
      <br> There is an option for a menu:
      <br> 
      <div class="highlight highlight-bash"> 
       <pre><code>./luks-ops.sh menu or simply ./luks-ops.sh</code></pre> 
      </div> 
      <br> Other options include:
      <br> 
      <div class="highlight highlight-bash"> 
       <pre><code>./luks-ops.sh new disk_Name Size_in_numbers
./luks-ops.sh mount /path/to/device (mountpoint) 
./luks-ops.sh unmount-all
./luks-ops.sh clean
./luks-ops.sh usage</code></pre> 
      </div> 
      <br> 
      <b><span style="font-size: large;">Default Options: </span></b>
      <br> 
      <ul class="task-list"> 
       <li>Virtual-disk size = 512 MB and it's created on /usr/ directory</li> 
       <li>Default filesystem used = ext4</li> 
       <li> <strong>Cipher options:</strong> 
        <ul class="task-list"> 
         <li>Creating LUKS1: aes-xts-plain64, Key: 256 bits, LUKS header hashing: sha1, RNG: /dev/urandom</li> 
         <li>plain: aes-cbc-essiv:sha256, Key: 256 bits, Password hashing: ripemd160 (about-time :D)</li> 
        </ul> </li> 
       <li>Mounting point = /media/luks_* where * is random-string.</li> 
       <li>Others.. <strong>NB.</strong> You can change /dev/urandom to /dev/zero (speed?)</li> 
      </ul> 
      <b><span style="font-size: large;">Dependencies (Install applications:) </span></b>
      <br> 
      <ol class="task-list"> 
       <li> <strong>dmsetup</strong> --- low level logical volume management</li> 
       <li> <strong>cryptsetup</strong> --- manage plain dm-crypt and LUKS encrypted volumes</li> 
      </ol> 
      <div> 
       <br>
      </div> 
      <div style="text-align: center;"> 
       <b><span style="font-size: x-large;"><a href="https://github.com/JohnTroony/LUKS-OPs" target="_blank">Download&nbsp;LUKS-OPs</a></span></b>
      </div> 
     </div>
    </article> 
    <article class="post hentry" id="8202870447264453804" itemscope itemtype="http://schema.org/BlogPosting"> 
     <h1 class="post-title entry-title" itemprop="name headline"> Lynis 2.0.0 - Security Auditing Tool for Unix/Linux Systems  </h1> 
     <div class="post-header" style="position:absolute;left:-9999px"> 
      <div class="post-header-line-1"></div> 
     </div> 
     <div class="post-body entry-content" id="post-body-8202870447264453804" itemprop="articleBody"> 
      <div class="separator" style="clear: both; text-align: center;"> 
       <a href="http://2.bp.blogspot.com/-u3-KnDxSxtI/VG4P6aOn0qI/AAAAAAAADWc/iVGIkfEll0A/s1600/lynis-screenshot.png" imageanchor="1" style="margin-left: 1em; margin-right: 1em;"><img border="0" src="http://2.bp.blogspot.com/-u3-KnDxSxtI/VG4P6aOn0qI/AAAAAAAADWc/iVGIkfEll0A/s1600/lynis-screenshot.png" height="480" width="640"></a>
      </div> 
      <br> 
      <div style="text-align: justify;">
        Lynis is an 
       <i>open source</i> 
       <b>security auditing tool</b>. Primary goal is to help users with 
       <b>auditing and hardening</b> of Unix and Linux based systems. The software is very flexible and runs on almost every Unix based system (including Mac). Even the installation of the software itself is optional!
       <br> 
       <br>
      </div> 
      <div style="text-align: justify;"> 
       <b><span style="font-size: large;">How it works</span></b>
       <br> 
       <b><span style="font-size: medium;"><br></span></b>
      </div> 
      <div style="text-align: justify;"> 
      </div> 
      <div style="text-align: justify;">
        Lynis will perform hundreds of individual tests to determine the security state of the system. Many of these tests are also part of common security guidelines and standards. Examples include searching for installed software and determine possible configuration flaws. Lynis goes further and does also test individual software components, checks related configuration files and measures performance. After these tests, a scan report will be displayed with all discovered findings.
       <br> 
       <a name="more"></a>
       <br> 
       <b>Typical use cases for Lynis:</b>
      </div> 
      <ul style="list-style-type: square;"> 
       <li style="text-align: justify;">Security auditing</li> 
       <li style="text-align: justify;">Vulnerability scanning</li> 
       <li style="text-align: justify;">System hardening</li> 
      </ul> 
      <div style="text-align: justify;"> 
       <br>
      </div> 
      <div style="text-align: justify;"> 
       <span style="font-size: large;"><b>Requirements</b>:</span>
       <br> 
       <div itemprop="permissions">
         Privileged or non-privileged
       </div> 
       <div itemprop="permissions"> 
        <br>
       </div> 
       <br> 
       <div style="text-align: center;"> 
        <b><span style="font-size: x-large;"><a href="https://cisofy.com/download/lynis/" target="_blank">Download&nbsp;Lynis 2.0.0</a></span></b>
       </div> 
      </div> 
     </div>
    </article> 
    <article class="post hentry" id="2991167288074138276" itemscope itemtype="http://schema.org/BlogPosting"> 
     <h1 class="post-title entry-title" itemprop="name headline"> Lynis 2.1.0 - Security Auditing Tool for Unix/Linux Systems  </h1> 
     <div class="post-header" style="position:absolute;left:-9999px"> 
      <div class="post-header-line-1"></div> 
     </div> 
     <div class="post-body entry-content" id="post-body-2991167288074138276" itemprop="articleBody"> 
      <div class="separator" style="clear: both; text-align: center;"> 
       <a href="http://4.bp.blogspot.com/-TkbGcRgEXCg/VTQEoeLCtQI/AAAAAAAAD44/zzAnsPzwbNw/s1600/lynis.png" imageanchor="1" style="margin-left: 1em; margin-right: 1em;"><img border="0" src="http://4.bp.blogspot.com/-TkbGcRgEXCg/VTQEoeLCtQI/AAAAAAAAD44/zzAnsPzwbNw/s1600/lynis.png" height="480" width="640"></a>
      </div> 
      <br> 
      <div style="text-align: justify;">
        Lynis is an open source security auditing tool. Commonly used by system administrators, security professionals and auditors, to evaluate the security defenses of their Linux/Unix based systems. It runs on the host itself, so it can perform very extensive security scans.
      </div> 
      <a name="more"></a>
      <br> 
      <div style="text-align: justify;"> 
       <b><span class="Apple-style-span" style="font-size: large;">Supported operating systems</span></b>
      </div> 
      <div style="text-align: justify;"> 
       <br>
      </div> 
      <div style="text-align: justify;">
        The tool has almost no dependencies, therefore it runs on almost all Unix based systems and versions, including:
      </div> 
      <ul> 
       <li style="text-align: justify;">AIX</li> 
       <li style="text-align: justify;">FreeBSD</li> 
       <li style="text-align: justify;">HP-UX</li> 
       <li style="text-align: justify;">Linux</li> 
       <li style="text-align: justify;">Mac OS</li> 
       <li style="text-align: justify;">NetBSD</li> 
       <li style="text-align: justify;">OpenBSD</li> 
       <li style="text-align: justify;">Solaris</li> 
       <li style="text-align: justify;">and others</li> 
      </ul> 
      <div style="text-align: justify;">
        It even runs on systems like the Raspberry Pi and several storage devices!
      </div> 
      <div style="text-align: justify;"> 
       <br>
      </div> 
      <div style="text-align: justify;"> 
       <b><span class="Apple-style-span" style="font-size: large;">No installation required</span></b>
      </div> 
      <div style="text-align: justify;"> 
       <br>
      </div> 
      <div style="text-align: justify;">
        The tool is very flexible and easy to use. It is one of the few tools, in which installation is optional. Just place it on the system, give it a command like "audit system", and it will run. It is written in shell script and released as open source software (
       <abbr title="GNU Public License">GPL</abbr>).
      </div> 
      <div style="text-align: justify;"> 
       <br>
      </div> 
      <div style="text-align: justify;"> 
       <b><span class="Apple-style-span" style="font-size: x-large;">How it works</span></b>
      </div> 
      <div style="text-align: justify;"> 
       <br>
      </div> 
      <div style="text-align: justify;">
        Lynis performs hundreds of individual tests, to determine the security state of the system. The security scan itself consists of performing a set of steps, from initialization the program, up to the report.
      </div> 
      <div style="text-align: justify;"> 
       <br>
      </div> 
      <div style="text-align: justify;"> 
       <b><span class="Apple-style-span" style="font-size: large;">Steps</span></b>
      </div> 
      <ol style="font-size: 14px;"> 
       <li style="text-align: justify;">Determine operating system</li> 
       <li style="text-align: justify;">Search for available tools and utilities</li> 
       <li style="text-align: justify;">Check for Lynis update</li> 
       <li style="text-align: justify;">Run tests from enabled plugins</li> 
       <li style="text-align: justify;">Run security tests per category</li> 
       <li style="text-align: justify;">Report status of security scan</li> 
      </ol> 
      <div style="text-align: justify;">
        During the scan, technical details about the scan are stored in a log file. At the same time findings (warnings, suggestions, data collection), are stored in a report file.
      </div> 
      <div style="text-align: justify;"> 
       <br>
      </div> 
      <div style="text-align: justify;"> 
       <b><span class="Apple-style-span" style="font-size: large;">Opportunistic scanning</span></b>
      </div> 
      <div style="text-align: justify;"> 
       <br>
      </div> 
      <div style="text-align: justify;">
        Lynis scanning is opportunistic: it uses what it can find.
      </div> 
      <div style="text-align: justify;">
        For example if it sees you are running Apache, it will perform an initial round of Apache related tests. When during the Apache scan it also discovers a SSL/TLS configuration, it will perform additional auditing steps on that. While doing that, it then will collect discovered certificates, so they can be scanned later as well.
      </div> 
      <div style="text-align: justify;"> 
       <br>
      </div> 
      <div style="text-align: justify;"> 
       <b>In-depth security scans</b>
      </div> 
      <div style="text-align: justify;"> 
       <br>
      </div> 
      <div style="text-align: justify;">
        By performing opportunistic scanning, the tool can run with almost no dependencies. The more it finds, the deeper the audit will be. In other words, Lynis will always perform scans which are customized to your system. No audit will be the same!
      </div> 
      <div style="text-align: justify;"> 
       <br>
      </div> 
      <div style="text-align: justify;"> 
       <b><span class="Apple-style-span" style="font-size: large;">Use cases</span></b>
      </div> 
      <div style="text-align: justify;"> 
       <br>
      </div> 
      <div style="text-align: justify;">
        Since Lynis is flexible, it is used for several different purposes. Typical use cases for Lynis include:
      </div> 
      <ul style="list-style-type: square;"> 
       <li style="text-align: justify;">Security auditing</li> 
       <li style="text-align: justify;">Compliance testing (e.g. PCI, HIPAA, SOx)</li> 
       <li style="text-align: justify;">Vulnerability detection and scanning</li> 
       <li style="text-align: justify;">System hardening</li> 
      </ul> 
      <div style="text-align: justify;"> 
       <br>
      </div> 
      <div style="text-align: justify;"> 
       <b><span class="Apple-style-span" style="font-size: large;">Resources used for testing</span></b>
      </div> 
      <div style="text-align: justify;"> 
       <br>
      </div> 
      <div style="text-align: justify;">
        Many other tools use the same data files for performing tests. Since Lynis is not limited to a few common Linux distributions, it uses tests from standards and many custom ones not found in any other tool.
      </div> 
      <ul> 
       <li style="text-align: justify;">Best practices</li> 
       <li style="text-align: justify;">CIS</li> 
       <li style="text-align: justify;">NIST</li> 
       <li style="text-align: justify;">NSA</li> 
       <li style="text-align: justify;">OpenSCAP data</li> 
       <li style="text-align: justify;">Vendor guides and recommendations (e.g. Debian Gentoo, Red Hat)</li> 
      </ul> 
      <div style="text-align: justify;"> 
       <br>
      </div> 
      <div style="text-align: justify;"> 
       <b><span class="Apple-style-span" style="font-size: large;">Lynis Plugins</span></b>
      </div> 
      <div style="text-align: justify;"> 
       <br>
      </div> 
      <div style="text-align: justify;">
        Plugins enable the tool to perform additional tests. They can be seen as an extension (or add-on) to Lynis, enhancing its functionality. One example is the compliance checking plugin, which performs specific tests only applicable to some standard.
      </div> 
      <div style="text-align: justify;"> 
       <br>
      </div> 
      <div style="text-align: justify;"> 
       <b><span class="Apple-style-span" style="font-size: large;">Comparison with other tools</span></b>
      </div> 
      <div style="text-align: justify;"> 
       <br>
      </div> 
      <div style="text-align: justify;">
        Lynis has a different way of doing things, so you have more flexibility. After all, you should be the one deciding what security controls make sense for your environment. We have a small comparison with some other well known tools:
      </div> 
      <div style="text-align: justify;"> 
       <br>
      </div> 
      <div style="text-align: justify;"> 
       <b>Bastille Linux</b>
      </div> 
      <div style="text-align: justify;"> 
       <br>
      </div> 
      <div style="text-align: justify;">
        Bastille was for a long time the best known utility for hardening Linux systems. It focuses mainly on automatically hardening the system.
      </div> 
      <blockquote> 
       <div style="text-align: justify;"> 
        <b>Differences with Bastille</b>
       </div> 
       <div style="text-align: justify;">
         Automated hardening tools are helpful, but at the same time might give a false sense of security. Instead of just turning on some settings, Lynis perform an in-depth security scan. You are the one to decide what level of security is appropriate for your environment. After all, not all systems have to be like 
        <a href="http://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Fort_Knox" title="Fort Knox Wikipedia page">Fort Knox</a>, unless you want it to be.
       </div> 
       <div style="text-align: justify;"> 
        <br>
       </div> 
       <div style="text-align: justify;"> 
        <b>Benefits of Lynis</b>
       </div> 
       <ul> 
        <li style="text-align: justify;">Supports more operating systems</li> 
        <li style="text-align: justify;">Won't break your system</li> 
        <li style="text-align: justify;">More in-depth audit</li> 
       </ul> 
      </blockquote> 
      <hr style="text-align: justify;"> 
      <div style="text-align: justify;"> 
       <br>
      </div> 
      <div style="text-align: justify;"> 
       <b>OpenVAS / Nessus</b>
      </div> 
      <div style="text-align: justify;"> 
       <br>
      </div> 
      <div style="text-align: justify;">
        These products focus primarily on vulnerability scanning. They do this via the network by polling services. Optionally they will log in to a system and gather data.
      </div> 
      <blockquote> 
       <div style="text-align: justify;"> 
        <b>Differences with OpenVAS / Nessus</b>
       </div> 
       <div style="text-align: justify;">
         Lynis runs on the host itself, therefore it can perform a deeper analysis compared with network based scans. Additionally, there is no risk for your business processes, and log files remain clean from connection attempts and incorrect requests.
       </div> 
       <div style="text-align: justify;">
         Although Lynis is an auditing tool, it will actually discover vulnerabilities as well. It does so by using existing tools and analyzing configuration files.
       </div> 
       <div style="text-align: justify;">
         Lynis and OpenVAS are both open source and free to use. Nessus is a closed source and paid.
       </div> 
       <div style="text-align: justify;"> 
        <br>
       </div> 
       <div style="text-align: justify;"> 
        <b>Benefits of Lynis</b>
       </div> 
       <ul> 
        <li style="text-align: justify;">Much faster</li> 
        <li style="text-align: justify;">No pollution of log files, no disruption to business services</li> 
        <li style="text-align: justify;">Host based scans provides more in-depth audit</li> 
       </ul> 
      </blockquote> 
      <br> 
      <span class="Apple-style-span" style="font-size: x-large;"><b>Changelog</b></span>
      <br> 
      <b><span class="Apple-style-span" style="font-size: large;">Lynis 2.1.0</span></b>
      <br> 
      <pre><code> = Lynis 2.1.0 (2015-04-16) =

General:
---------
Screen output has been improved to provide additional information.

OS support:
------------
CUPS detection on Mac OS has been improved. AIX systems will now use csum
utility to create host ID. Group check have been altered on AIX, to include
the -n ALL. Core dump check on Linux is extended to check for actual values
as well.

Software:
----------
McAfee detection has been extended by detecting a running cma binary.
Improved detection of pf firewall on BSD and Mac OS. Security patch checking
with zypper extended.

Session timeout:
-----------------
Tests to determine shell time out setting have been extended to account for
AIX, HP-UX and other platforms. It will now determine also if variable is
exported as a readonly variable. Related compliance section PCI DSS 8.1.8
has been extended.

Documentation:
---------------
- New document: Getting started with Lynis
https://cisofy.com/documentation/lynis/get-started/

Plugins (Enterprise):
----------------------
- Update to file integrity plugin
Changes to PLGN-2606 (capabilities check)

- New configuration plugins:
PLGN-4802 (SSH settings)
PLGN-4804 (login.defs)</code></pre> 
      <br> 
      <br> 
      <div style="text-align: center;"> 
       <b><span class="Apple-style-span" style="font-size: x-large;"><a href="https://cisofy.com/download/lynis/" target="_blank">Download Lynis 2.1.0</a></span></b>
      </div> 
     </div>
    </article> 
    <article class="post hentry" id="6588682892619761179" itemscope itemtype="http://schema.org/BlogPosting"> 
     <h1 class="post-title entry-title" itemprop="name headline"> Lynis 2.1.1 - Security Auditing Tool for Unix/Linux Systems  </h1> 
     <div class="post-header" style="position:absolute;left:-9999px"> 
      <div class="post-header-line-1"></div> 
     </div> 
     <div class="post-body entry-content" id="post-body-6588682892619761179" itemprop="articleBody"> 
      <div class="separator" style="clear: both; text-align: center;"> 
       <a href="http://4.bp.blogspot.com/-p2rdZ63sxRU/VbBxt5iYZuI/AAAAAAAAEac/8yjkIc_IDdU/s1600/lynis2.1.1.png" imageanchor="1" style="margin-left: 1em; margin-right: 1em;"><img border="0" height="480" src="http://4.bp.blogspot.com/-p2rdZ63sxRU/VbBxt5iYZuI/AAAAAAAAEac/8yjkIc_IDdU/s640/lynis2.1.1.png" width="640"></a>
      </div> 
      <br> 
      <div style="text-align: justify;">
        Lynis is an open source security auditing tool. Commonly used by system administrators, security professionals and auditors, to evaluate the security defenses of their Linux/Unix based systems. It runs on the host itself, so it can perform very extensive security scans.
      </div> 
      <a name="more"></a>
      <br> 
      <div style="text-align: justify;"> 
       <b><span class="Apple-style-span" style="font-size: large;">Supported operating systems</span></b>
      </div> 
      <div style="text-align: justify;"> 
       <br>
      </div> 
      <div style="text-align: justify;">
        The tool has almost no dependencies, therefore it runs on almost all Unix based systems and versions, including:
      </div> 
      <ul> 
       <li style="text-align: justify;">AIX</li> 
       <li style="text-align: justify;">FreeBSD</li> 
       <li style="text-align: justify;">HP-UX</li> 
       <li style="text-align: justify;">Linux</li> 
       <li style="text-align: justify;">Mac OS</li> 
       <li style="text-align: justify;">NetBSD</li> 
       <li style="text-align: justify;">OpenBSD</li> 
       <li style="text-align: justify;">Solaris</li> 
       <li style="text-align: justify;">and others</li> 
      </ul> 
      <div style="text-align: justify;">
        It even runs on systems like the Raspberry Pi and several storage devices!
      </div> 
      <div style="text-align: justify;"> 
       <br>
      </div> 
      <div style="text-align: justify;"> 
       <b><span class="Apple-style-span" style="font-size: large;">No installation required</span></b>
      </div> 
      <div style="text-align: justify;"> 
       <br>
      </div> 
      <div style="text-align: justify;">
        The tool is very flexible and easy to use. It is one of the few tools, in which installation is optional. Just place it on the system, give it a command like "audit system", and it will run. It is written in shell script and released as open source software (
       <abbr title="GNU Public License">GPL</abbr>).
      </div> 
      <div style="text-align: justify;"> 
       <br>
      </div> 
      <div style="text-align: justify;"> 
       <b><span class="Apple-style-span" style="font-size: x-large;">How it works</span></b>
      </div> 
      <div style="text-align: justify;"> 
       <br>
      </div> 
      <div style="text-align: justify;">
        Lynis performs hundreds of individual tests, to determine the security state of the system. The security scan itself consists of performing a set of steps, from initialization the program, up to the report.
      </div> 
      <div style="text-align: justify;"> 
       <br>
      </div> 
      <div style="text-align: justify;"> 
       <b><span class="Apple-style-span" style="font-size: large;">Steps</span></b>
      </div> 
      <ol> 
       <li style="text-align: justify;">Determine operating system</li> 
       <li style="text-align: justify;">Search for available tools and utilities</li> 
       <li style="text-align: justify;">Check for Lynis update</li> 
       <li style="text-align: justify;">Run tests from enabled plugins</li> 
       <li style="text-align: justify;">Run security tests per category</li> 
       <li style="text-align: justify;">Report status of security scan</li> 
      </ol> 
      <div style="text-align: justify;">
        During the scan, technical details about the scan are stored in a log file. At the same time findings (warnings, suggestions, data collection), are stored in a report file.
      </div> 
      <div style="text-align: justify;"> 
       <br>
      </div> 
      <div style="text-align: justify;"> 
       <b><span class="Apple-style-span" style="font-size: large;">Opportunistic scanning</span></b>
      </div> 
      <div style="text-align: justify;"> 
       <br>
      </div> 
      <div style="text-align: justify;">
        Lynis scanning is opportunistic: it uses what it can find.
      </div> 
      <div style="text-align: justify;">
        For example if it sees you are running Apache, it will perform an initial round of Apache related tests. When during the Apache scan it also discovers a SSL/TLS configuration, it will perform additional auditing steps on that. While doing that, it then will collect discovered certificates, so they can be scanned later as well.
      </div> 
      <div style="text-align: justify;"> 
       <br>
      </div> 
      <div style="text-align: justify;"> 
       <b>In-depth security scans</b>
      </div> 
      <div style="text-align: justify;"> 
       <br>
      </div> 
      <div style="text-align: justify;">
        By performing opportunistic scanning, the tool can run with almost no dependencies. The more it finds, the deeper the audit will be. In other words, Lynis will always perform scans which are customized to your system. No audit will be the same!
      </div> 
      <div style="text-align: justify;"> 
       <br>
      </div> 
      <div style="text-align: justify;"> 
       <b><span class="Apple-style-span" style="font-size: large;">Use cases</span></b>
      </div> 
      <div style="text-align: justify;"> 
       <br>
      </div> 
      <div style="text-align: justify;">
        Since Lynis is flexible, it is used for several different purposes. Typical use cases for Lynis include:
      </div> 
      <ul style="list-style-type: square;"> 
       <li style="text-align: justify;">Security auditing</li> 
       <li style="text-align: justify;">Compliance testing (e.g. PCI, HIPAA, SOx)</li> 
       <li style="text-align: justify;">Vulnerability detection and scanning</li> 
       <li style="text-align: justify;">System hardening</li> 
      </ul> 
      <div style="text-align: justify;"> 
       <br>
      </div> 
      <div style="text-align: justify;"> 
       <b><span class="Apple-style-span" style="font-size: large;">Resources used for testing</span></b>
      </div> 
      <div style="text-align: justify;"> 
       <br>
      </div> 
      <div style="text-align: justify;">
        Many other tools use the same data files for performing tests. Since Lynis is not limited to a few common Linux distributions, it uses tests from standards and many custom ones not found in any other tool.
      </div> 
      <ul> 
       <li style="text-align: justify;">Best practices</li> 
       <li style="text-align: justify;">CIS</li> 
       <li style="text-align: justify;">NIST</li> 
       <li style="text-align: justify;">NSA</li> 
       <li style="text-align: justify;">OpenSCAP data</li> 
       <li style="text-align: justify;">Vendor guides and recommendations (e.g. Debian Gentoo, Red Hat)</li> 
      </ul> 
      <div style="text-align: justify;"> 
       <br>
      </div> 
      <div style="text-align: justify;"> 
       <span style="font-size: large;"><b>Parameters</b></span>
      </div> 
      <pre><code>--auditor "Given name Surname"     Assign an auditor name to the audit (report)
--checkall  -c  Start the check
--check-update     Check if Lynis is up-to-date
--cronjob     Run Lynis as cronjob (includes -c -Q)
--help  -h  Shows valid parameters
--manpage     View man page
--nocolors     Do not use any colors
--pentest     Perform a penetration test scan (non-privileged)
--quick  -Q  Don't wait for user input, except on errors
--quiet     Only show warnings (includes --quick, but doesn't wait)
--reverse-colors   Use a different color scheme for lighter backgrounds
--version  -V  Check program version (and quit)</code></pre> 
      <br> 
      <span class="Apple-style-span" style="font-size: x-large;"><b>Changelog</b></span>
      <br> 
      <b><span class="Apple-style-span" style="font-size: large;">Lynis 2.1.1</span></b>
      <br> 
      <pre><code>=  Lynis 2.1.1 (2015-07-22)  =

    This release adds a lot of improvements, with focus on performance, and
    additional support for common Linux distributions and external utilities.
    We recommend to use this latest version.

    * Operating system enhancements
    -------------------------------
    Support for systems like CentOS, openSUSE, Slackware is improved.

    * Performance
    -------------
    Performance tuning has been applied, to speed up execution of the audit on
    systems with many files. This also includes code cleanups.

    * Automatic updates
    -------------------
    Initial work on an automatic updater has been implemented. This way Lynis
    can be scheduled for automatic updating from a trusted source.

    * Internal functions
    --------------------
    Not all systems have readlink, or the -f option of readlink. The
    ShowSymlinkPath function has been extended with a Python based check, which
    is often available.

    * Software support
    ------------------
    Apache module directory /usr/lib64/apache has been added, which is used on
    openSUSE.

    Support for Chef has been added.

    Added tests for CSF's lfd utility for integrity monitoring on directories and
    files. Related tests are FINT-4334 and FINT-4336.

    Added support for Chrony time daemon and timesync daemon. Additionally NTP
    sychronization status is checked when it is enabled.

    Improved single user mode protection on the rescue.service file.

    * Other
    -------
    Check for user permissions has been extended.
    Python binary is now detected, to help with symlink detection.
    Several new legal terms have been added, which are used for usage in banners.
    In several files old tests have been removed, to further clean up the code.

    * Bug fixes
    ---------
    Nginx test showed error when access_log had multiple parameters.
    Tests using locate won't be performed if not present.
    Fix false positive match on Squid unsafe ports [SQD-3624].
    The hardening index is now also inserted into the report if it is not displayed
    on screen.

    * Functions
    ---------
    Added AddSystemGroup function

    * New tests
    ---------
    Several new tests have been added:

    [PKGS-7366] Scan for debsecan utility on Debian systems
    [PKGS-7410] Determine amount of installed kernel packages
    [TIME-3106] Check synchronization status of NTP on systemd based systems
    [CONT-8102] Docker daemon status and gather basic details
    [CONT-8104] Check docker info for any Docker warnings
    [CONT-8106] Check total, running and unused Docker containers

    * Plugins
    ---------

    [PLGN-2602] Disabled by default, as it may be too slow for some machines
    [PLGN-3002] Extended with /sbin/nologin

    * Documentation
    ---------------
    A new document has been created to help with the process of upgrading Lynis.
    It is available at https://cisofy.com/documentation/lynis/upgrading/

  --------------------------------------------------------------</code></pre> 
      <br> 
      <br> 
      <div style="text-align: center;"> 
       <b><span class="Apple-style-span" style="font-size: x-large;"><a href="https://cisofy.com/download/lynis/" target="_blank">Download Lynis 2.1.1</a></span></b>
      </div> 
     </div>
    </article> 
    <article class="post hentry" id="9069758872457116752" itemscope itemtype="http://schema.org/BlogPosting"> 
     <h1 class="post-title entry-title" itemprop="name headline"> MALHEUR - Automatic Analysis of Malware Behavior  </h1> 
     <div class="post-header" style="position:absolute;left:-9999px"> 
      <div class="post-header-line-1"></div> 
     </div> 
     <div class="post-body entry-content" id="post-body-9069758872457116752" itemprop="articleBody"> 
      <div style="text-align: justify;"> 
       <b><span style="font-size: large;">A novel tool for malware analysis</span></b>
      </div> 
      <div style="text-align: justify;"> 
       <br>
      </div> 
      <div style="text-align: justify;">
        Malheur is a tool for the automatic analysis of malware behavior (program behavior recorded from malicious software in a sandbox environment). It has been designed to support the regular analysis of malicious software and the development of detection and defense measures. Malheur allows for identifying novel classes of malware with similar behavior and assigning unknown malware to discovered classes.
      </div> 
      <div style="text-align: justify;"> 
      </div> 
      <a name="more"></a>
      <br> 
      <div style="text-align: justify;"> 
       <b><span style="font-size: large;">Analysis of malware behavior?</span></b>
      </div> 
      <div style="text-align: justify;"> 
       <br>
      </div> 
      <div style="text-align: justify;">
        Malheur builds on the concept of 
       <em>dynamic analysis</em>: Malware binaries are collected in the wild and executed in a sandbox, where their behavior is monitored during run-time. The execution of each malware binary results in a report of recorded behavior. Malheur analyzes these reports for discovery and discrimination of malware classes using 
       <i>machine learning</i>. 
      </div> 
      <div style="text-align: justify;"> 
       <br>
      </div> 
      <div style="text-align: justify;">
        Malheur can be applied to recorded behavior of various format, as long as monitored events are separated by delimiter symbols, for example as in reports generated by the popular malware sandboxes 
       <a href="http://www.sunbeltsandbox.com/">CWSandbox</a>, 
       <a href="http://anubis.iseclab.org/">Anubis</a>, 
       <a href="http://sandbox.norman.no/">Norman Sandbox</a> and 
       <a href="http://www.joebox.org/">Joebox</a>.
      </div> 
      <br> 
      <div class="separator" style="clear: both; text-align: center;"> 
       <a href="http://4.bp.blogspot.com/-UTYfEO1gv-A/Vf-cazexOqI/AAAAAAAAEoA/zhIFs61INYw/s1600/mal_proto_toy1.png" imageanchor="1" style="margin-left: 1em; margin-right: 1em;"><img border="0" src="http://4.bp.blogspot.com/-UTYfEO1gv-A/Vf-cazexOqI/AAAAAAAAEoA/zhIFs61INYw/s1600/mal_proto_toy1.png"></a> 
       <a href="http://4.bp.blogspot.com/-bg5yUKMZUXE/Vf-ca1A9gyI/AAAAAAAAEoE/t4d4oSouh4A/s1600/mal_proto_toy2.png" imageanchor="1" style="margin-left: 1em; margin-right: 1em;"><img border="0" src="http://4.bp.blogspot.com/-bg5yUKMZUXE/Vf-ca1A9gyI/AAAAAAAAEoE/t4d4oSouh4A/s1600/mal_proto_toy2.png"></a> 
       <a href="http://3.bp.blogspot.com/-pp9rmoxXxvc/Vf-ca3z-s7I/AAAAAAAAEoI/cw4ac_zfqMM/s1600/mal_proto_toy3.png" imageanchor="1" style="margin-left: 1em; margin-right: 1em;"><img border="0" src="http://3.bp.blogspot.com/-pp9rmoxXxvc/Vf-ca3z-s7I/AAAAAAAAEoI/cw4ac_zfqMM/s1600/mal_proto_toy3.png"></a>
      </div> 
      <br> 
      <div style="text-align: justify;">
        Malheur allows for identifying novel classes of malware with similar behavior and assigning unknown malware to discovered classes. It supports four basic actions for analysis which can be applied to reports of recorded behavior:
      </div> 
      <ol> 
       <li style="text-align: justify;"><em>Extraction of prototypes:</em> From a given set of reports, malheur identifies a subset of prototypes representative for the full data set. The prototypes provide a quick overview of recorded behavior and can be used to guide manual inspection.</li> 
       <li style="text-align: justify;"><em>Clustering of behavior</em> Malheur automatically identifies groups (clusters) of reports containing similar behavior. Clustering allows for discovering novel classes of malware and provides the basis for crafting specific detection and defense mechanisms, such as anti-virus signatures.</li> 
       <li style="text-align: justify;"><em>Classification of behavior:</em> Based on a set of previously clustered reports, malheur is able to assign unknown behavior to known groups of malware. Classification enables identifying novel and unknown variants of malware and can be used to filter program behavior prior to manual inspection.</li> 
       <li style="text-align: justify;"><em>Incremental analysis:</em> Malheur can be applied incrementally for analysis of large data sets. By processing reports in chunks, the run-time as well as memory requirements can be significantly reduced. This renders long-term application of malheur feasible, for example for daily analysis of incoming malware programs.</li> 
      </ol> 
      <div style="text-align: justify;"> 
       <br>
      </div> 
      <div> 
       <span style="font-size: large;"><b> Dependencies</b></span>
       <br> 
       <ul> 
        <li> libconfig &gt;= 1.4, <a href="http://www.hyperrealm.com/libconfig/">http://www.hyperrealm.com/libconfig/</a></li> 
        <li> libarchive &gt;= 2.70, <a href="http://libarchive.github.com/">http://libarchive.github.com/</a></li> 
       </ul> 
       <br> 
       <b> Debian &amp; Ubuntu Linux</b>
       <br> The following packages need to be installed for compiling Malheur on Debian and Ubuntu Linux
       <br> 
       <pre><code>gcc
libconfig9-dev
libarchive-dev
</code></pre> For bootstrapping Malheur from the GIT repository or manipulating the automake/autoconf configuration, the following additional packages are necessary.
       <br> 
       <pre><code>automake
autoconf
libtool
</code></pre> 
       <br> 
       <b> Mac OS X</b>
       <br> For compiling Malheur on Mac OS X a working installation of Xcode is required including 
       <code>gcc</code>. Additionally, the following packages need to be installed via Homebrew
       <br> 
       <pre><code>libconfig
libarchive (from homebrew-alt)
</code></pre> 
       <br> 
       <b> OpenBSD</b>
       <br> For compiling Malheur on OpenBSD the following packages are required. Note that you need to use 
       <code>gmake</code> instead of 
       <code>make</code> for building Malheur.
       <br> 
       <pre><code>gmake
libconfig
libarchive
</code></pre> For bootstrapping Malheur from the GIT repository, the following packages need be additionally installed
       <br> 
       <pre><code>autoconf
automake
libtool
</code></pre> 
       <br> 
       <span style="font-size: large;"><b> Compilation &amp; Installation</b></span>
       <br> 
       <br> From GIT repository first run
       <br> 
       <pre><code>$ ./bootstrap
</code></pre> From tarball run
       <br> 
       <pre><code>$ ./configure [options]
$ make
$ make check
$ make install
</code></pre> Options for configure
       <br> 
       <pre><code>--prefix=PATH           Set directory prefix for installation
</code></pre> By default Malheur is installed into /usr/local. If you prefer a different location, use this option to select an installation directory.
      </div> 
      <div> 
       <br>
      </div> 
      <br> 
      <div style="text-align: center;"> 
       <a href="https://github.com/rieck/malheur/" target="_blank"><b><span style="font-size: x-large;">Download&nbsp;MALHEUR</span></b></a>
      </div> 
     </div>
    </article> 
    <article class="post hentry" id="4970264585535727524" itemscope itemtype="http://schema.org/BlogPosting"> 
     <h1 class="post-title entry-title" itemprop="name headline"> Maligno v2.0 - Metasploit Payload Server  </h1> 
     <div class="post-header" style="position:absolute;left:-9999px"> 
      <div class="post-header-line-1"></div> 
     </div> 
     <div class="post-body entry-content" id="post-body-4970264585535727524" itemprop="articleBody"> 
      <div class="separator" style="clear: both; text-align: center;"> 
       <a href="http://4.bp.blogspot.com/-qRkgtB8cbfE/VP5ez2fOD5I/AAAAAAAADwI/EFUZubNCXew/s1600/msf.png" imageanchor="1" style="margin-left: 1em; margin-right: 1em;"><img border="0" src="http://4.bp.blogspot.com/-qRkgtB8cbfE/VP5ez2fOD5I/AAAAAAAADwI/EFUZubNCXew/s1600/msf.png"></a>
      </div> 
      <div style="text-align: justify;"> 
       <br>
      </div> 
      <div style="text-align: justify;">
        Maligno is an open source penetration testing tool written in Python that serves Metasploit payloads. It generates shellcode with msfvenom and transmits it over HTTP or HTTPS. The shellcode is encrypted with AES and encoded prior to transmission.
       <br> 
       <a name="more"></a>
      </div> 
      <div style="text-align: justify;">
        Maligno also comes with a client tool, which supports HTTP, HTTPS and encryption capabilities. The client is able to connect to Maligno in order to download an encrypted Metasploit payload. Once the shellcode is received, the client will decode it, decrypt it and inject it in the target machine.
      </div> 
      <div style="text-align: justify;"> 
       <br>
      </div> 
      <div style="text-align: justify;">
        The client-server communications can be configured in a way that allows you to simulate specific C&amp;C communications or targeted attacks. In other words, the tool can be used as part of adversary replication engagements.
      </div> 
      <div style="text-align: justify;"> 
       <br>
      </div> 
      <div style="text-align: justify;"> 
       <strong>Are you new to Maligno?</strong> Check&nbsp;
       <a href="https://www.youtube.com/playlist?list=PLUANA2JtKjNszz4OD4ZFvNwUFdZGozwZ_" target="_blank">Maligno Video Series</a> with examples and tutorials.
      </div> 
      <div style="text-align: justify;"> 
       <br>
      </div> 
      <div style="text-align: center;"> 
       <iframe allowfullscreen frameborder="0" height="360" src="https://www.youtube.com/embed/videoseries?list=PLUANA2JtKjNszz4OD4ZFvNwUFdZGozwZ_" width="640"></iframe> 
      </div> 
      <div style="text-align: justify;"> 
       <br>
      </div> 
      <div style="text-align: justify;"> 
       <b>Changelog: </b>Adversary replication functionality improvements. POST and HEAD method support added, new client profile added, server multithreading support added, perpetual shell mode added, client static HTTP(S) proxy support added, documentation and stability improvements.
      </div> 
      <div style="text-align: justify;"> 
       <br>
      </div> 
      <div style="text-align: justify;"> 
       <b>Important: </b>Configuration files or profiles made for Maligno v1.x are not compatible with Maligno v2.0.
      </div> 
      <div style="text-align: justify;"> 
       <br> 
       <br>
      </div> 
      <div style="text-align: justify;"> 
       <div style="text-align: center;"> 
        <b><span style="font-size: x-large;"><a href="http://www.encripto.no/tools/" target="_blank">Download&nbsp;Maligno v2.0</a></span></b>
       </div> 
      </div> 
     </div>
    </article> 
    <article class="post hentry" id="4677156111194973484" itemscope itemtype="http://schema.org/BlogPosting"> 
     <h1 class="post-title entry-title" itemprop="name headline"> MalwaRE - Malware Repository Framework  </h1> 
     <div class="post-header" style="position:absolute;left:-9999px"> 
      <div class="post-header-line-1"></div> 
     </div> 
     <div class="post-body entry-content" id="post-body-4677156111194973484" itemprop="articleBody"> 
      <div class="separator" style="clear: both; text-align: center;"> 
       <a href="http://3.bp.blogspot.com/-48qFM6ywCk4/VMvT-ecMMXI/AAAAAAAADnk/vROROeIiLAA/s1600/malwaRE.png" imageanchor="1" style="margin-left: 1em; margin-right: 1em;"><img border="0" src="http://3.bp.blogspot.com/-48qFM6ywCk4/VMvT-ecMMXI/AAAAAAAADnk/vROROeIiLAA/s1600/malwaRE.png" height="344" width="640"></a>
      </div> 
      <br> 
      <div style="text-align: justify;">
        malwaRE is a malware repository website created using PHP Laravel framework, used to manage your own malware zoo. malwaRE was based on the work of 
       <a href="http://www.adlice.com/softwares/malware-repository-framework/">Adlice</a> team with some extra features.
      </div> 
      <div style="text-align: justify;"> 
       <br>
      </div> 
      <div style="text-align: justify;">
        If you guys have any improvements, please let me know or send me a pull request.
      </div> 
      <a name="more"></a>
      <br> 
      <div style="text-align: justify;"> 
       <b><span style="font-size: large;">Features </span></b>
      </div> 
      <ul class="task-list"> 
       <li style="text-align: justify;">Self-hosted solution (PHP/Mysql server needed)</li> 
       <li style="text-align: justify;">VirusTotal results (option for uploading unknown samples)</li> 
       <li style="text-align: justify;">Search filters available (vendor, filename, hash, tag)</li> 
       <li style="text-align: justify;">Vendor name is picked from VirusTotal results in that order: Microsoft, Kaspersky, Bitdefender</li> 
       <li style="text-align: justify;">Add writeup url(s) for each sample</li> 
       <li style="text-align: justify;">Manage samples by tag</li> 
       <li style="text-align: justify;">Tag autocomplete</li> 
       <li style="text-align: justify;">VirusTotal rescan button (VirusTotal's score column)</li> 
       <li style="text-align: justify;">Download samples from repository</li> 
      </ul> 
      <div> 
       <br>
      </div> 
      <div> 
       <div style="text-align: center;"> 
        <a href="https://github.com/c633/malwaRE" target="_blank"><b><span style="font-size: x-large;">Download&nbsp;MalwaRE</span></b></a>
       </div> 
      </div> 
     </div>
    </article> 
    <article class="post hentry" id="6372579284509577146" itemscope itemtype="http://schema.org/BlogPosting"> 
     <h1 class="post-title entry-title" itemprop="name headline"> MassBleed - Mass SSL Vulnerability Scanner  </h1> 
     <div class="post-header" style="position:absolute;left:-9999px"> 
      <div class="post-header-line-1"></div> 
     </div> 
     <div class="post-body entry-content" id="post-body-6372579284509577146" itemprop="articleBody"> 
      <div class="separator" style="clear: both; text-align: center;"> 
       <a href="http://2.bp.blogspot.com/-R03rah0GmiI/VluZ4GxGkqI/AAAAAAAAE4I/EF_VR6RSZsw/s1600/MassBleed.png" imageanchor="1" style="margin-left: 1em; margin-right: 1em;"><img border="0" height="640" src="http://2.bp.blogspot.com/-R03rah0GmiI/VluZ4GxGkqI/AAAAAAAAE4I/EF_VR6RSZsw/s640/MassBleed.png" width="488"></a>
      </div> 
      <br> 
      <b><span style="font-size: large;">USAGE</span></b>
      <br> 
      <pre><code>&nbsp;sh massbleed.sh [CIDR|IP] [single|port|subnet] [port] [proxy]</code></pre> 
      <br> 
      <b><span style="font-size: large;">ABOUT</span></b>
      <br> This script has four main functions with the ability to proxy all connections:
      <br> 
      <ol> 
       <li>To mass scan any CIDR range for OpenSSL vulnerabilities via port 443/tcp (https) (example: sh massbleed.sh 192.168.0.0/16)</li> 
       <li>To scan any CIDR range for OpenSSL vulnerabilities via any custom port specified (example: sh massbleed.sh 192.168.0.0/16 port 8443)</li> 
       <li>To individual scan every port (1-10000) on a single system for vulnerable versions of OpenSSL (example: sh massbleed.sh 127.0.0.1 single)</li> 
       <li>To scan every open port on every host in a single class C subnet for OpenSSL vulnerabilities (example: sh massbleed.sh 192.168.0. subnet)</li> 
      </ol> 
      <div> 
       <a name="more"></a>
       <br>
      </div> 
      <b>PROXY:</b> A proxy option has been added to scan via proxychains. You'll need to configure /etc/proxychains.conf for this to work. 
      <br> 
      <br> 
      <b>PROXY USAGE EXAMPLES:</b> (example: sh massbleed.sh 192.168.0.0/16 0 0 proxy) (example: sh massbleed.sh 192.168.0.0/16 port 8443 proxy) (example: sh massbleed.sh 127.0.0.1 single 0 proxy) (example: sh massbleed.sh 192.168.0. subnet 0 proxy)
      <br> 
      <br> 
      <b>VULNERABILITIES:</b>
      <br> 
      <ol> 
       <li>OpenSSL HeartBleed Vulnerability (CVE-2014-0160)</li> 
       <li>OpenSSL CCS (MITM) Vulnerability (CVE-2014-0224)</li> 
       <li>Poodle SSLv3 vulnerability (CVE-2014-3566)</li> 
      </ol> 
      <br> 
      <div style="text-align: center;"> 
       <b><span style="font-size: x-large;"><a href="https://github.com/1N3/MassBleed" target="_blank">Download&nbsp;MassBleed</a></span></b>
      </div> 
     </div>
    </article> 
    <article class="post hentry" id="1685499659768727929" itemscope itemtype="http://schema.org/BlogPosting"> 
     <h1 class="post-title entry-title" itemprop="name headline"> Medusa - Speedy, Parallel and Modular Login Brute-Forcer  </h1> 
     <div class="post-header" style="position:absolute;left:-9999px"> 
      <div class="post-header-line-1"></div> 
     </div> 
     <div class="post-body entry-content" id="post-body-1685499659768727929" itemprop="articleBody"> 
      <div class="separator" style="clear: both; text-align: center;"> 
       <a href="http://1.bp.blogspot.com/-IXDqANUvD5I/VXYydpNV5SI/AAAAAAAAENI/3y-b5zoVHfg/s1600/medusa.png" imageanchor="1" style="margin-left: 1em; margin-right: 1em;"><img border="0" height="502" src="http://1.bp.blogspot.com/-IXDqANUvD5I/VXYydpNV5SI/AAAAAAAAENI/3y-b5zoVHfg/s640/medusa.png" width="640"></a>
      </div> 
      <br> 
      <div style="text-align: justify;">
        Medusa is intended to be a speedy, massively parallel, modular, login brute-forcer. The goal is to support as many services which allow remote authentication as possible. The author considers following items as some of the key features of this application: 
      </div> 
      <ul> 
       <li style="text-align: justify;"><b>Thread-based parallel testing.</b> Brute-force testing can be performed against multiple hosts, users or passwords concurrently. </li> 
       <li style="text-align: justify;"><b>Flexible user input.</b> Target information (host/user/password) can be specified in a variety of ways. For example, each item can be either a single entry or a file containing multiple entries. Additionally, a combination file format allows the user to refine their target listing. </li> 
       <li style="text-align: justify;"><b>Modular design.</b> Each service module exists as an independent .mod file. This means that no modifications are necessary to the core application in order to extend the supported list of services for brute-forcing. </li> 
      </ul> 
      <div style="text-align: justify;"> 
      </div> 
      <a name="more"></a>
      <br> 
      <div style="text-align: justify;"> 
       <b><span style="font-size: large;">Why?</span></b>
      </div> 
      <div style="text-align: justify;"> 
       <br>
      </div> 
      <div style="text-align: justify;">
        Why create Medusa? Isn't this the same thing as THC-Hydra? Here are some of the reasons for this application:
      </div> 
      <ul> 
       <li style="text-align: justify;"><b>Application stability.</b> Maybe I'm just lame, but Hydra frequently crashed on me. I was no longer confident that Hydra was actually doing what it claimed to be. Rather than fix Hydra, I decided to create my own buggy application which could crash in new and exciting ways. </li> 
       <li style="text-align: justify;"><b>Code organization.</b> A while back I added several features to Hydra (parallel host scanning, SMBNT module). Retro-fitting the parallel host code to Hydra was a serious pain. This was mainly due to my coding ignorance, but was probably also due to Hydra not being designed from the ground-up to support this. Medusa was designed from the start to support parallel testing of hosts, users and passwords. </li> 
       <li style="text-align: justify;"><b>Speed.</b> Hydra accomplishes its parallel testing by forking off a new process for each host and instance of the service being tested. When testing many hosts/users at once this creates a large amount of overhead as user/password lists must be duplicated for each forked process. Medusa is pthread-based and does not unnecessarily duplicate information. </li> 
       <li style="text-align: justify;"><b>Education.</b> I am not an experienced C programmer, nor do I consider myself an expert in multi-threaded programming. Writing this application was a training exercise for me. Hopefully, the results of it will be useful for others.&nbsp;</li> 
      </ul> 
      <div> 
       <div style="text-align: justify;"> 
        <br>
       </div> 
       <div style="text-align: justify;"> 
        <b><span style="font-size: large;">Module specific details:</span></b>
       </div> 
       <ul> 
        <li style="text-align: justify;">&nbsp; &nbsp; AFP</li> 
        <li style="text-align: justify;">&nbsp; &nbsp; CVS</li> 
        <li style="text-align: justify;">&nbsp; &nbsp; FTP</li> 
        <li style="text-align: justify;">&nbsp; &nbsp; HTTP</li> 
        <li style="text-align: justify;">&nbsp; &nbsp; IMAP</li> 
        <li style="text-align: justify;">&nbsp; &nbsp; MS-SQL</li> 
        <li style="text-align: justify;">&nbsp; &nbsp; MySQL</li> 
        <li style="text-align: justify;">&nbsp; &nbsp; NetWare NCP</li> 
        <li style="text-align: justify;">&nbsp; &nbsp; NNTP</li> 
        <li style="text-align: justify;">&nbsp; &nbsp; PcAnywhere</li> 
        <li style="text-align: justify;">&nbsp; &nbsp; POP3</li> 
        <li style="text-align: justify;">&nbsp; &nbsp; PostgreSQL</li> 
        <li style="text-align: justify;">&nbsp; &nbsp; REXEC</li> 
        <li style="text-align: justify;">&nbsp; &nbsp; RDP</li> 
        <li style="text-align: justify;">&nbsp; &nbsp; RLOGIN</li> 
        <li style="text-align: justify;">&nbsp; &nbsp; RSH</li> 
        <li style="text-align: justify;">&nbsp; &nbsp; SMBNT</li> 
        <li style="text-align: justify;">&nbsp; &nbsp; SMTP-AUTH</li> 
        <li style="text-align: justify;">&nbsp; &nbsp; SMTP-VRFY</li> 
        <li style="text-align: justify;">&nbsp; &nbsp; SNMP</li> 
        <li style="text-align: justify;">&nbsp; &nbsp; SSHv2</li> 
        <li style="text-align: justify;">&nbsp; &nbsp; Subversion (SVN)</li> 
        <li style="text-align: justify;">&nbsp; &nbsp; Telnet</li> 
        <li style="text-align: justify;">&nbsp; &nbsp; VMware Authentication Daemon (vmauthd)</li> 
        <li style="text-align: justify;">&nbsp; &nbsp; VNC</li> 
        <li style="text-align: justify;">&nbsp; &nbsp; Generic Wrapper</li> 
        <li style="text-align: justify;">&nbsp; &nbsp; Web Form&nbsp;</li> 
       </ul> 
       <div> 
        <div style="text-align: justify;"> 
         <br>
        </div> 
       </div> 
      </div> 
      <div style="text-align: justify;"> 
       <strong><span style="font-size: large;">News</span></strong>
      </div> 
      <div style="text-align: justify;">
        2015-06-07: Released Medusa v2.2_rc2
      </div> 
      <div style="text-align: justify;">
        2015-05-28: Released Medusa v2.2_rc1
      </div> 
      <div style="text-align: justify;">
        2012-05-25: Released Medusa v2.1.1
      </div> 
      <div style="text-align: justify;">
        2012-04-02: Released Medusa v2.1
      </div> 
      <div style="text-align: justify;">
        2011-03-04: tak and bigmoneyhat have released a Java-based GUI for Medusa (
       <a href="https://github.com/Tak31337/medusa-gui" title="Medusa-gui">Medusa-gui</a>)
      </div> 
      <div style="text-align: justify;">
        2010-02-09: Released Medusa v2.0
      </div> 
      <br> 
      <br> 
      <div style="text-align: center;"> 
       <b><span style="font-size: x-large;"><a href="https://github.com/jmk-foofus/medusa" target="_blank">Download&nbsp;Medusa</a></span></b>
      </div> 
     </div>
    </article> 
    <article class="post hentry" id="772044478861977703" itemscope itemtype="http://schema.org/BlogPosting"> 
     <h1 class="post-title entry-title" itemprop="name headline"> Metasploit AV Evasion - Metasploit payload generator that avoids most Anti-Virus products  </h1> 
     <div class="post-header" style="position:absolute;left:-9999px"> 
      <div class="post-header-line-1"></div> 
     </div> 
     <div class="post-body entry-content" id="post-body-772044478861977703" itemprop="articleBody"> 
      <div class="separator" style="clear: both; text-align: center;"> 
       <a href="http://2.bp.blogspot.com/-udZtk-p7Pwg/VcvUVm2IcuI/AAAAAAAAEes/cYwTnaWKHFY/s1600/Metasploit%2BAV%2BEvasion.png" imageanchor="1" style="margin-left: 1em; margin-right: 1em;"><img border="0" height="324" src="http://2.bp.blogspot.com/-udZtk-p7Pwg/VcvUVm2IcuI/AAAAAAAAEes/cYwTnaWKHFY/s640/Metasploit%2BAV%2BEvasion.png" width="640"></a>
      </div> 
      <br> Metasploit payload generator that avoids most Anti-Virus products.
      <br> 
      <a name="more"></a>
      <br> 
      <b><span class="Apple-style-span" style="font-size: large;">Installing </span></b>
      <br> 
      <pre><code>git clone https://github.com/nccgroup/metasploitavevasion.git</code></pre> chmod +x the avoid.sh file before use.
      <br> 
      <br> 
      <b><span class="Apple-style-span" style="font-size: large;">How To Use </span></b>
      <br> 
      <pre><code>./avoid.sh</code></pre> Then follow the on screen prompts.
      <br> 
      <br> 
      <b><span class="Apple-style-span" style="font-size: large;">Features</span></b>
      <br> 
      <ul> 
       <li>Easily generate a Metasploit executable payload to bypass Anti-Virus detection</li> 
       <li>Local or remote listener generation</li> 
       <li>Disguises the executable file with a PDF icon</li> 
       <li>Executable opens minimised on the victims computer</li> 
       <li>Automatically creates AutoRun files for CDROM exploitation</li> 
      </ul> 
      <div> 
       <br>
      </div> 
      <div style="text-align: center;"> 
       <b><span class="Apple-style-span" style="font-size: x-large;"><a href="https://github.com/nccgroup/metasploitavevasion" target="_blank">Download&nbsp;Metasploit AV Evasion</a></span></b>
      </div> 
     </div>
    </article> 
    <article class="post hentry" id="4928959689221310462" itemscope itemtype="http://schema.org/BlogPosting"> 
     <h1 class="post-title entry-title" itemprop="name headline"> MicEnum - Mandatory Integrity Control Enumerator for Windows  </h1> 
     <div class="post-header" style="position:absolute;left:-9999px"> 
      <div class="post-header-line-1"></div> 
     </div> 
     <div class="post-body entry-content" id="post-body-4928959689221310462" itemprop="articleBody"> 
      <div class="separator" style="clear: both; text-align: center;"> 
       <a href="http://2.bp.blogspot.com/-1V2XfN-duJs/VakXkFQru6I/AAAAAAAAEXs/ijDn9AmnLHE/s1600/micenum.jpg" imageanchor="1" style="margin-left: 1em; margin-right: 1em;"><img border="0" height="529" src="http://2.bp.blogspot.com/-1V2XfN-duJs/VakXkFQru6I/AAAAAAAAEXs/ijDn9AmnLHE/s640/micenum.jpg" width="640"></a>
      </div> 
      <br> 
      <br> 
      <div style="text-align: justify;">
        In the context of the Microsoft Windows family of operating systems, 
       <b>Mandatory Integrity Control (MIC)</b> is a core security feature introduced in Windows Vista and implemented in subsequent lines of Windows operating systems. It adds Integrity Levels(IL)-based isolation to running processes and objects. The IL represents the level of trustworthiness of an object, and it may be set to files, folders, etc. 
       <b>Believe it or not, there is no graphical interface for dealing with MIC in Windows</b>. 
       <b>MicEnum</b> has been created to solve this, and as a tool for forensics.
       <br> 
       <a name="more"></a>
       <br> MicEnum is a simple graphical tool that:
       <br> 
       <ul> 
        <li>Enumerates the Integrity Levels of the objects (files and folders) in the hard disks.</li> 
        <li>Enumerates the Integrity Levels in the registry.</li> 
        <li>Helps to detect anomalies in them by spotting different integrity levels.</li> 
        <li>Allows to store and restore this information in an XML file so it may be used for forensic purposes.</li> 
        <li>Allows to set or modify the integrity levels graphically.</li> 
       </ul> 
       <br> 
       <table align="center" cellpadding="0" cellspacing="0" class="tr-caption-container" style="margin-left: auto; margin-right: auto; text-align: center;">
        <tbody> 
         <tr>
          <td style="text-align: center;"><a href="http://4.bp.blogspot.com/-Abw6MS0OIzc/VZp1iyED2BI/AAAAAAAADJs/YiNYDsXBmGo/s1600/MICEnum1.PNG" imageanchor="1" style="margin-left: auto; margin-right: auto;"><img border="0" height="380" src="http://4.bp.blogspot.com/-Abw6MS0OIzc/VZp1iyED2BI/AAAAAAAADJs/YiNYDsXBmGo/s400/MICEnum1.PNG" width="400"></a></td>
         </tr> 
         <tr>
          <td class="tr-caption" style="text-align: center;">MicEnum scanning a folder</td>
         </tr> 
        </tbody>
       </table> 
       <br> 
       <b>How does the tool work?</b>
       <br> 
       <br> The only way by now, to show or set Integrity Levels in Windows is by using icacls.exe, a command line tool. There is no easy or standard way to detect changes or anomalies. As in NTFS, an attacker may have changed Integrity Levels of a file in a system 
       <b>to elevate privileges or leverage another attack</b>, so, watching this kind of movements and anomalies is important for forensics or preventive actions.
       <br> 
       <br> The tool represents files and folders in a tree style. The integrity level of files and folders is shown in a column next to them. By scanning a folder, 
       <b>the tool will check all Integrity Levels and, if any of them does not match with its parent, it will expand it.</b> If you have expanded some folders and want to group back the ones that are known to be the same, just use the checkbox at the bottom. It will hide the folders that are supposed to share same integrity level.
       <br> 
       <br>
