    <article class="post hentry" id="8898718726464998160" itemscope itemtype="http://schema.org/BlogPosting"> 
     <h1 class="post-title entry-title" itemprop="name headline"> NetRipper - Smart Traffic Sniffing for Penetration Testers  </h1> 
     <div class="post-header" style="position:absolute;left:-9999px"> 
      <div class="post-header-line-1"></div> 
     </div> 
     <div class="post-body entry-content" id="post-body-8898718726464998160" itemprop="articleBody"> 
      <div class="separator" style="clear: both; text-align: center;"> 
       <a href="http://3.bp.blogspot.com/-0V5DL6t7TW0/Vd54LX5njeI/AAAAAAAAEjM/bar3BMeLWzo/s1600/NetRipper.png" imageanchor="1" style="margin-left: 1em; margin-right: 1em;"><img border="0" src="http://3.bp.blogspot.com/-0V5DL6t7TW0/Vd54LX5njeI/AAAAAAAAEjM/bar3BMeLWzo/s1600/NetRipper.png"></a>
      </div> 
      <br> 
      <div style="text-align: justify;">
        NetRipper is a post exploitation tool targeting Windows systems which uses API hooking in order to intercept network traffic and encryption related functions from a low privileged user, being able to capture both plain-text traffic and encrypted traffic before encryption/after decryption.
       <br> 
       <a name="more"></a>
      </div> 
      <div style="text-align: justify;"> 
       <br>
      </div> 
      <div style="text-align: justify;">
        NetRipper was released at Defcon 23, Las Vegas, Nevada.
      </div> 
      <div style="text-align: justify;"> 
       <br>
      </div> 
      <div style="text-align: justify;"> 
       <b><span style="font-size: large;">Abstract</span></b>
      </div> 
      <div style="text-align: justify;"> 
       <br>
      </div> 
      <div style="text-align: justify;">
        The post-exploitation activities in a penetration test can be challenging if the tester has low-privileges on a fully patched, well configured Windows machine. This work presents a technique for helping the tester to find useful information by sniffing network traffic of the applications on the compromised machine, despite his low-privileged rights. Furthermore, the encrypted traffic is also captured before being sent to the encryption layer, thus all traffic (clear-text and encrypted) can be sniffed. The implementation of this technique is a tool called NetRipper which uses API hooking to do the actions mentioned above and which has been especially designed to be used in penetration tests, but the concept can also be used to monitor network traffic of employees or to analyze a malicious application.
      </div> 
      <div style="text-align: justify;"> 
       <br>
      </div> 
      <div style="text-align: justify;"> 
       <b><span style="font-size: large;">Tested applications</span></b>
      </div> 
      <div style="text-align: justify;"> 
       <br>
      </div> 
      <div style="text-align: justify;">
        NetRipper should be able to capture network traffic from: Putty, WinSCP, SQL Server Management Studio, Lync (Skype for Business), Microsoft Outlook, Google Chrome, Mozilla Firefox. The list is not limited to these applications but other tools may require special support.
      </div> 
      <br> 
      <b><span style="font-size: large;">Components</span></b>
      <br> 
      <pre><code>NetRipper.exe - Configures and inject the DLL  
DLL.dll       - Injected DLL, hook APIs and save data to files  
netripper.rb  - Metasploit post-exploitation module
</code></pre> 
      <br> 
      <b><span style="font-size: large;">Command line</span></b>
      <br> 
      <pre><code>Injection: NetRipper.exe DLLpath.dll processname.exe  
Example:   NetRipper.exe DLL.dll firefox.exe  

Generate DLL:

  -h,  --help          Print this help message  
  -w,  --write         Full path for the DLL to write the configuration data  
  -l,  --location      Full path where to save data files (default TEMP)  

Plugins:

  -p,  --plaintext     Capture only plain-text data. E.g. true  
  -d,  --datalimit     Limit capture size per request. E.g. 4096  
  -s,  --stringfinder  Find specific strings. E.g. user,pass,config  

Example: NetRipper.exe -w DLL.dll -l TEMP -p true -d 4096 -s user,pass  
</code></pre> 
      <br> 
      <b><span style="font-size: large;">Metasploit module</span></b>
      <br> 
      <pre><code>msf &gt; use post/windows/gather/netripper 
msf post(netripper) &gt; show options

Module options (post/windows/gather/netripper):

   Name          Current Setting                  Required  Description
   ----          ---------------                  --------  -----------
   DATALIMIT     4096                             no        The number of bytes to save from requests/responses
   DATAPATH      TEMP                             no        Where to save files. E.g. C:\Windows\Temp or TEMP
   PLAINTEXT     true                             no        True to save only plain-text data
   PROCESSIDS                                     no        Process IDs. E.g. 1244,1256
   PROCESSNAMES                                   no        Process names. E.g. firefox.exe,chrome.exe
   SESSION                                        yes       The session to run this module on.
   STRINGFINDER  user,login,pass,database,config  no        Search for specific strings in captured data
</code></pre> Set PROCESSNAMES and run.
      <br> 
      <br> 
      <b><span style="font-size: large;">Metasploit installation (Kali)</span></b>
      <br> 
      <ol> 
       <li>cp netripper.rb /usr/share/metasploit-framework/modules/post/windows/gather/netripper.rb</li> 
       <li>mkdir /usr/share/metasploit-framework/modules/post/windows/gather/netripper</li> 
       <li>g++ -Wall netripper.cpp -o netripper</li> 
       <li>cp netripper /usr/share/metasploit-framework/modules/post/windows/gather/netripper/netripper</li> 
       <li>cd ../Release</li> 
       <li>cp DLL.dll /usr/share/metasploit-framework/modules/post/windows/gather/netripper/DLL.dll</li> 
      </ol> 
      <br> 
      <b><span style="font-size: large;">PowerShell module</span></b>
      <br> 
      <br> @HarmJ0y Added Invoke-NetRipper.ps1 PowerShell implementation of NetRipper.exe
      <br> 
      <br> 
      <b><span style="font-size: large;">Plugins</span></b>
      <br> 
      <ol> 
       <li>PlainText - Allows to capture only plain-text data</li> 
       <li>DataLimit - Save only first bytes of requests and responses</li> 
       <li>Stringinder - Find specific string in network traffic</li> 
      </ol> 
      <div> 
       <br>
      </div> 
      <div style="text-align: center;"> 
       <b><span style="font-size: x-large;"><a href="https://github.com/NytroRST/NetRipper/" target="_blank">Download&nbsp;NetRipper</a></span></b>
      </div> 
     </div>
    </article> 
    <article class="post hentry" id="2840005975437808054" itemscope itemtype="http://schema.org/BlogPosting"> 
     <h1 class="post-title entry-title" itemprop="name headline"> Netsparker 4 - Easier to Use, More Automation and Much More Web Security Checks  </h1> 
     <div class="post-header" style="position:absolute;left:-9999px"> 
      <div class="post-header-line-1"></div> 
     </div> 
     <div class="post-body entry-content" id="post-body-2840005975437808054" itemprop="articleBody"> 
      <div class="separator" style="clear: both; text-align: center;"> 
       <a href="http://2.bp.blogspot.com/-VqmDxr9XIa8/VRiHjka9btI/AAAAAAAAD2w/30Bm-2crpIQ/s1600/netspark.png" imageanchor="1" style="margin-left: 1em; margin-right: 1em;"><img border="0" src="http://2.bp.blogspot.com/-VqmDxr9XIa8/VRiHjka9btI/AAAAAAAAD2w/30Bm-2crpIQ/s1600/netspark.png" height="320" width="640"></a>
      </div> 
      <br> 
      <div style="text-align: justify;">
        Netsparker Web Application Security Scanner version 4. The main highlight of this new version is the new fully automated Form Authentication mechanism; it does not require you to record anything, supports 2 factor authentication and other authentication mechanisms that require a one time code to work out of the box.
      </div> 
      <div style="text-align: justify;"> 
       <br>
      </div> 
      <div style="text-align: justify;">
        The below is a list of features highlights of the new Netsparker Web Application Security Scanner version 4.
       <br> 
       <a name="more"></a>
      </div> 
      <div style="text-align: justify;"> 
       <br>
      </div> 
      <div style="text-align: justify;"> 
       <b><span class="Apple-style-span" style="font-size: large;">Configuring New Web Application Security Scans Just Got Easier</span></b>
      </div> 
      <div style="text-align: justify;"> 
       <br>
      </div> 
      <div style="text-align: justify;">
        This is the first thing you will notice when you launch the new version of Netsparker Desktop; a more straightforward and easier to use New Scan dialog. Easy to use software has become synonymous with Netsparker’s scanners and in this version we raised the bar again, giving the opportunity to many users to launch web security scans even if they are not that familiar with web application security.
      </div> 
      <br> 
      <div class="separator" style="clear: both; text-align: center;"> 
       <a href="http://2.bp.blogspot.com/-je3m1iCAr9U/VRiFJnXE53I/AAAAAAAAD1s/Ca8Ot_64CHo/s1600/Start%2Ba%2BNew%2BScan.png" imageanchor="1" style="margin-left: 1em; margin-right: 1em;"><img border="0" src="http://2.bp.blogspot.com/-je3m1iCAr9U/VRiFJnXE53I/AAAAAAAAD1s/Ca8Ot_64CHo/s1600/Start%2Ba%2BNew%2BScan.png" height="547" width="640"></a>
      </div> 
      <br> 
      <br> 
      <div style="text-align: justify;">
        As seen in the above screenshot all the generic scan settings you need are ergonomically placed in the right position, allowing you to quickly configure a new web application security scan. All of the advanced scan settings, such as HTTP connection options have been moved to scan policies.
      </div> 
      <div style="text-align: justify;"> 
       <br>
      </div> 
      <div style="text-align: justify;"> 
       <b><span class="Apple-style-span" style="font-size: large;">Revamped Form Authentication Support to Scan Password Protected Areas</span></b>
      </div> 
      <div style="text-align: justify;"> 
       <br>
      </div> 
      <div style="text-align: justify;">
        The 
       <strong>new fully automated form authentication </strong>mechanism of Netsparker Desktop emulates a real user login, therefore even if tokens or other one time parameters are used by the web application an out of the box installation of the scanner can still login in to the password protected area and scan it. For example in the below example Netsparker is being used to login to the MailChimp website.
      </div> 
      <br> 
      <div class="separator" style="clear: both; text-align: center;"> 
       <a href="http://3.bp.blogspot.com/-xLctkrykAvQ/VRiFXsVQ0mI/AAAAAAAAD10/Su89EBMjayc/s1600/Conifiguring%2Bform%2Bauthentication.png" imageanchor="1" style="margin-left: 1em; margin-right: 1em;"><img border="0" src="http://3.bp.blogspot.com/-xLctkrykAvQ/VRiFXsVQ0mI/AAAAAAAAD10/Su89EBMjayc/s1600/Conifiguring%2Bform%2Bauthentication.png" height="547" width="640"></a>
      </div> 
      <br> 
      <div style="text-align: justify;">
        Once you enter the necessary details, mainly the login form URL and credentials you can click&nbsp;
       <strong>Verify Login &amp; Logout&nbsp;</strong>to verify that the scanner can automatically login and identify a logged in session, as shown in the below screenshot.
      </div> 
      <br> 
      <div class="separator" style="clear: both; text-align: center;"> 
       <a href="http://4.bp.blogspot.com/-VDUWe7oPFK0/VRiFkXD7_YI/AAAAAAAAD18/1nxNjXGdNfA/s1600/Verify%2BForm%2BAuthentication.png" imageanchor="1" style="margin-left: 1em; margin-right: 1em;"><img border="0" src="http://4.bp.blogspot.com/-VDUWe7oPFK0/VRiFkXD7_YI/AAAAAAAAD18/1nxNjXGdNfA/s1600/Verify%2BForm%2BAuthentication.png" height="378" width="640"></a>
      </div> 
      <br> 
      <div style="text-align: justify;">
        You 
       <strong>do not have to record </strong>any login macros because the new mechanism is all based on DOM. You just have to 
       <strong>enter the login form URL, username and password and it will automatically login </strong>to the password protected section. We have tested the new automated form authentication mechanism on more than 300 live websites and can confirm that while using an out of the box setup, it works on 85% of the websites. 13% of the remaining edge cases can be fixed by writing 2-5 lines of JavaScript code with Netsparker’s new JavaScript custom script support. Pretty neat, don’t you think? The below are just a few of the login forms we tested.
      </div> 
      <br> 
      <div class="separator" style="clear: both; text-align: center;"> 
       <a href="http://4.bp.blogspot.com/-r3p0SayGLQk/VRiFw6GAGQI/AAAAAAAAD2E/XccAlOv-Qs0/s1600/login_forms_samples.png" imageanchor="1" style="margin-left: 1em; margin-right: 1em;"><img border="0" src="http://4.bp.blogspot.com/-r3p0SayGLQk/VRiFw6GAGQI/AAAAAAAAD2E/XccAlOv-Qs0/s1600/login_forms_samples.png"></a>
      </div> 
      <br> 
      <br> 
      <div style="text-align: justify;">
        The new Form Authentication mechanism also supports custom scripts which can be used to override the scanner’s behaviour, or in rare cases where the automated login button detection is not working. The custom scripting language has been changed to JavaScript because it is easier and many more users are familiar with it.
      </div> 
      <div style="text-align: justify;"> 
       <br>
      </div> 
      <div style="text-align: justify;"> 
       <b>Out of the Box Support for Two-Factor Authentication and One Time Passwords</b>
      </div> 
      <div style="text-align: justify;"> 
       <br>
      </div> 
      <div style="text-align: justify;">
        The new Form Authentication mechanism of Netsparker Desktop can also be used to automatically scan websites which use two-factor authentication or any other type of one time passwords technologies. Very simple to configure; specify the login form URL, username and passwords and tick the option 
       <strong>Interactive Login </strong>so a browser window automatically prompts allowing you to enter the third authentication factor during a web application security scan.
      </div> 
      <br> 
      <div class="separator" style="clear: both; text-align: center;"> 
       <a href="http://1.bp.blogspot.com/-CCsq8NMWHvE/VRiF4AIslcI/AAAAAAAAD2M/ar6cxEkoVtY/s1600/Interactive%2BForm%2BAuthentication.png" imageanchor="1" style="margin-left: 1em; margin-right: 1em;"><img border="0" src="http://1.bp.blogspot.com/-CCsq8NMWHvE/VRiF4AIslcI/AAAAAAAAD2M/ar6cxEkoVtY/s1600/Interactive%2BForm%2BAuthentication.png" height="593" width="640"></a>
      </div> 
      <br> 
      <br> 
      <div style="text-align: justify;"> 
       <b>Ability to Emulate Different User Roles During a Scan</b>
      </div> 
      <div style="text-align: justify;"> 
       <br>
      </div> 
      <div style="text-align: justify;">
        To ensure that all possible vulnerabilities in a password protected area are identified, you should scan it using different users that have different roles and privileges. With the new form authentication mechanism of Netsparker you can do just that! When configuring the authentication details specify multiple usernames and passwords so in between scans you just have to select which credentials should be used without the need to record any new login macros or reconfiguring the scanner.
      </div> 
      <br> 
      <br> 
      <br> 
      <div class="separator" style="clear: both; text-align: center;"> 
       <a href="http://2.bp.blogspot.com/-r7Q23M3AlRk/VRiGCgTBiII/AAAAAAAAD2U/xX0ZCZn6u7k/s1600/Configuring%2Bdifferent%2Broles%2Bin%2Bauthentication.png" imageanchor="1" style="margin-left: 1em; margin-right: 1em;"><img border="0" src="http://2.bp.blogspot.com/-r7Q23M3AlRk/VRiGCgTBiII/AAAAAAAAD2U/xX0ZCZn6u7k/s1600/Configuring%2Bdifferent%2Broles%2Bin%2Bauthentication.png" height="546" width="640"></a>
      </div> 
      <br> 
      <br> 
      <div style="text-align: justify;"> 
       <b>Automatically Identify Vulnerabilities in Google Web Toolkit Applications</b>
      </div> 
      <div style="text-align: justify;"> 
       <br>
      </div> 
      <div style="text-align: justify;">
        Google Web Toolkit, also known as GWT is an open source framework that gained a lot of popularity. Nowadays many web applications are being built on it, or using features and functions from it. Since the web applications that are built with GWT heavily depend on complex JavaScript, we built a dedicated engine in Netsparker to support GWT.
      </div> 
      <div style="text-align: justify;"> 
       <br>
      </div> 
      <div style="text-align: justify;">
        This means that you can use Netsparker Desktop to automatically crawl, scan and identify vulnerabilities and security flaws in Google Web Toolkit applications.
      </div> 
      <br> 
      <div class="separator" style="clear: both; text-align: center;"> 
       <a href="http://2.bp.blogspot.com/-h5iN7Xr-5L0/VRiGZ0J202I/AAAAAAAAD2c/pHpJKv7xUGA/s1600/GWT%2BVulnreability.png" imageanchor="1" style="margin-left: 1em; margin-right: 1em;"><img border="0" src="http://2.bp.blogspot.com/-h5iN7Xr-5L0/VRiGZ0J202I/AAAAAAAAD2c/pHpJKv7xUGA/s1600/GWT%2BVulnreability.png" height="118" width="640"></a>
      </div> 
      <br> 
      <br> 
      <div style="text-align: justify;"> 
       <b>Identify Vulnerabilities in File Upload Forms</b>
      </div> 
      <div style="text-align: justify;"> 
       <br>
      </div> 
      <div style="text-align: justify;">
        Like with every version or build of Netsparker we release, we included a number of new security checks in this version. Though one specific web application security check that is included in this version needs more attention that the others; file upload forms vulnerabilities.
      </div> 
      <div style="text-align: justify;"> 
       <br>
      </div> 
      <div style="text-align: justify;">
        From this version onwards Netsparker Desktop will check all the file upload forms on your websites for vulnerabilities such forms are typically susceptible for, for example Netsparker tests that all proper validation checks in a file upload form work and that they cannot be bypassed by malicious attackers.
      </div> 
      <br> 
      <div class="separator" style="clear: both; text-align: center;"> 
       <a href="http://1.bp.blogspot.com/-7wJN7Pq-FSI/VRiGl3YHlTI/AAAAAAAAD2k/wZGZD92RtVg/s1600/File%2BUpload%2Bvulnerability.png" imageanchor="1" style="margin-left: 1em; margin-right: 1em;"><img border="0" src="http://1.bp.blogspot.com/-7wJN7Pq-FSI/VRiGl3YHlTI/AAAAAAAAD2k/wZGZD92RtVg/s1600/File%2BUpload%2Bvulnerability.png" height="482" width="640"></a>
      </div> 
      <br> 
      <br> 
      <div style="text-align: justify;"> 
       <b>Mixed Content Type, Cross-Frame Options, CORS configuration</b>
      </div> 
      <div style="text-align: justify;"> 
       <br>
      </div> 
      <div style="text-align: justify;">
        We also added various new web security checks mostly around HTML5 security headers. For example Netsparker now checks for X-Frame-Options usage, and possible problems in the implementation of it which can lead to Clickjacking vulnerabilities and some other security issues.
      </div> 
      <div style="text-align: justify;"> 
       <br>
      </div> 
      <div style="text-align: justify;">
        Another new check is checking the configuration of CORS headers. Finally in this category we added Mixed Content Type checks for HTTPS pages and Content Type header analysis for all of the pages.
      </div> 
      <div style="text-align: justify;"> 
       <br>
      </div> 
      <div style="text-align: justify;"> 
       <b>XML External Entity (XXE) Engine</b>
      </div> 
      <div style="text-align: justify;"> 
       <br>
      </div> 
      <div style="text-align: justify;">
        Applications that deal with XML data are particularly susceptible to XML External Entity (XXE) attacks. A successful exploitation of a XXE vulnerability allows an attacker to launch other and more grievous malicious attacks, such as code execution. Since this version, Netsparker automatically checks websites and web applications for XXE vulnerabilities.
      </div> 
      <div style="text-align: justify;"> 
       <br>
      </div> 
      <div style="text-align: justify;"> 
       <b>Insecure JSONP Endpoints - Rosetta Flash &amp; Reflected File Download Attacks</b>
      </div> 
      <div style="text-align: justify;"> 
       <br>
      </div> 
      <div style="text-align: justify;">
        In this version we added a new security check to identify insecure JSONP endpoints and other controllable endpoints that can lead to Rosetta Flash or Reflected File Download attacks.
      </div> 
      <div style="text-align: justify;"> 
       <br>
      </div> 
      <div style="text-align: justify;">
        Even if your application is not using JSONP you can be still vulnerable to these type of attacks in other forms, hence why it is always important to scan your website with Netsparker.
      </div> 
      <div style="text-align: justify;"> 
       <br>
      </div> 
      <div style="text-align: justify;"> 
       <b>Other Netsparker Desktop 4 Features and Product Improvements</b>
      </div> 
      <br> 
      <div style="text-align: justify;"> 
       <br>
      </div> 
      <br> 
      <div style="text-align: justify;">
        The above list just highlights the most prominent features and new security checks of Netsparker Desktop version 4, the only false positive free web application security scanner. Included in this version there are also more new security checks and we also improved several existing security checks, hence the scanner’s coverage is better than ever before. Of course we also included a number of product improvements.
      </div> 
      <div style="text-align: justify;">
        Since there have been a good number of improvements and changes in this version there are also some things from older versions of Netsparker which are no longer supported, such as scan profiles. Because we changed the way Netsparker saves the scan profiles, scan profiles generated with older versions of Netsparker will no longer work. Therefore I recommend you to check the 
       <a href="https://netsparker.zendesk.com/entries/90847637-Changelog-4-0-0">Netsparker Desktop version 4 changelog</a> for more information on what is new, changed and improved.
      </div> 
      <br> 
      <br> 
      <div style="text-align: center;"> 
      </div>
     </div>
    </article> 
    <article class="post hentry" id="122614707308758452" itemscope itemtype="http://schema.org/BlogPosting"> 
     <h1 class="post-title entry-title" itemprop="name headline"> Netsparker Cloud - Online Web Application Security Scanner  </h1> 
     <div class="post-header" style="position:absolute;left:-9999px"> 
      <div class="post-header-line-1"></div> 
     </div> 
     <div class="post-body entry-content" id="post-body-122614707308758452" itemprop="articleBody"> 
      <div class="separator" style="clear: both; text-align: center;"> 
       <a href="http://4.bp.blogspot.com/-rBAkFa_kmpw/VcGHp-Rc70I/AAAAAAAAEcw/6AOYma85qzk/s1600/Netsparker%2BCloud.png" imageanchor="1" style="margin-left: 1em; margin-right: 1em;"><img border="0" height="310" src="http://4.bp.blogspot.com/-rBAkFa_kmpw/VcGHp-Rc70I/AAAAAAAAEcw/6AOYma85qzk/s640/Netsparker%2BCloud.png" width="640"></a>
      </div> 
      <br> 
      <br> 
      <div style="text-align: justify;">
        Netsparker Cloud is an online web application security scanner built around the advanced scanning technology of Netsparker Web Application Security Scanner; the only false positive free automated desktop based web vulnerability scanner.
       <br> 
       <a name="more"></a>
      </div> 
      <div style="text-align: justify;"> 
       <br>
      </div> 
      <div style="text-align: justify;"> 
       <b><span style="font-size: large;">Benefit from the Cloud</span></b>
      </div> 
      <div style="text-align: justify;"> 
       <br>
      </div> 
      <div style="text-align: justify;"> 
       <b>AFFORDABLE AND MAINTENANCE FREE WEB APPLICATION SECURITY SOLUTION</b>
      </div> 
      <div style="text-align: justify;"> 
       <br>
      </div> 
      <div style="text-align: justify;">
        Embrace the benefits of the cloud! With Netsparker Cloud you do not need to buy, license, install and support any hardware or software. Simply pay a yearly fee and launch as many web application security scans as you want from anywhere using the web based portal.
      </div> 
      <div style="text-align: justify;"> 
       <br>
      </div> 
      <div style="text-align: justify;"> 
       <b>SCALABLE AND ALWAYS AVAILABLE: SCAN AS MANY WEBSITES AS YOU WANT WHEN YOU WANT</b>
      </div> 
      <div style="text-align: justify;"> 
       <br>
      </div> 
      <div style="text-align: justify;">
        Netsparker Cloud enables you to launch as many web application security and vulnerability scans as you want within just minutes, thus allowing you to boost your productivity and easily stay a step ahead of malicious attackers.
      </div> 
      <div style="text-align: justify;"> 
       <br>
      </div> 
      <div style="text-align: justify;">
        A new vulnerability such as Heartbleed or Shellshock is being exploited in the wild and you need to scan 500, or 1000 web applications in just a few hours? You have new web applications that you need to add to your extensive scanning program? No need to setup any additional hardware and software or call in an emergency team, just login to Netsparker Cloud web portal and launch the web security scans.
      </div> 
      <div style="text-align: justify;"> 
       <br>
      </div> 
      <div style="text-align: justify;"> 
       <b><span style="font-size: large;">Other Netsparker Cloud Features Organizations Can Benefit From:</span></b>
      </div> 
      <div style="text-align: justify;">
        &nbsp;&nbsp;
      </div> 
      <div style="text-align: justify;"> 
       <b>FULLY CONFIGURABLE ONLINE WEB VULNERABILITY SCANNER</b>
      </div> 
      <div style="text-align: justify;"> 
       <br>
      </div> 
      <div style="text-align: justify;"> 
       <a href="https://www.netsparker.com/online-web-application-security-scanner/fully-configurable/" target="_blank">Netsparker Cloud is fully configurable</a>, just like the desktop version of Netsparker. You can configure every single detail of the web application security scan including scan policies, attack options, HTTP options, URL rewrite rules, authentication options and everything else.
      </div> 
      <div style="text-align: justify;"> 
       <br>
      </div> 
      <div style="text-align: justify;"> 
       <b>EASILY INTEGRATE WEB SECURITY SCANNING IN YOUR SDLC</b>
      </div> 
      <div style="text-align: justify;"> 
       <br>
      </div> 
      <div style="text-align: justify;"> 
       <a href="https://www.netsparker.com/online-web-application-security-scanner/sdlc-integration/" target="_blank">Netsparker Cloud has a web service based API</a> that allows you to remotely trigger new web security scans and much more from anywhere and anytime. Such API enables organizations to easily integrate web application security scans in their development environment so they can launch security scans throughout every stage of the software development lifecycle.
      </div> 
      <div style="text-align: justify;">
        &nbsp; &nbsp;&nbsp;
      </div> 
      <div style="text-align: justify;"> 
       <b>TEAM AND ENTERPRISE LEVEL COLLABORATION MADE EASY</b>
      </div> 
      <div style="text-align: justify;"> 
       <br>
      </div> 
      <div style="text-align: justify;">
        You can add multiple users with different privileges to the same Netsparker Cloud account, thus 
       <a href="https://www.netsparker.com/online-web-application-security-scanner/ease-team-collabration/" target="_blank">allowing everyone in the organization to easily collaborate and share all the findings to streamline the process of securing web applications</a>.
      </div> 
      <div style="text-align: justify;"> 
       <br>
      </div> 
      <div style="text-align: justify;"> 
       <b>CORRELATED TRENDING REPORTS HELP YOU KEEP TRACK OF WEB APPLICATION PROJECTS</b>
      </div> 
      <div style="text-align: justify;"> 
       <br>
      </div> 
      <div style="text-align: justify;">
        Web applications are constantly evolving; new features, functionality and improvements are the order of the day to ensure they continuously meet all business requirements. Though such changes also open up new security issues.
      </div> 
      <div style="text-align: justify;"> 
       <br>
      </div> 
      <div style="text-align: justify;">
        Netsparker Cloud security dashboard allows you to easily keep an eye on the state of security of all web applications while the trending reports will help you keep track of the quality of work your developers are doing. Trending reports can also help you monitor who is improving so you can better assign tasks according to each of the developer’s skills.
      </div> 
      <div style="text-align: justify;"> 
       <br>
      </div> 
      <div style="text-align: justify;"> 
       <br>
      </div> 
      <div style="text-align: justify;"> 
       <div style="text-align: center;"> 
        <b><span style="font-size: x-large;"><a href="https://www.netsparker.com/online-web-application-security-scanner/trial" target="_blank">Try Netsparker Cloud</a></span></b>
       </div> 
      </div> 
     </div>
    </article> 
    <article class="post hentry" id="8895440692363444538" itemscope itemtype="http://schema.org/BlogPosting"> 
     <h1 class="post-title entry-title" itemprop="name headline"> Nikto2 - Web Server Scanner  </h1> 
     <div class="post-header" style="position:absolute;left:-9999px"> 
      <div class="post-header-line-1"></div> 
     </div> 
     <div class="post-body entry-content" id="post-body-8895440692363444538" itemprop="articleBody"> 
      <div> 
       <div style="text-align: justify;"> 
        <div class="separator" style="clear: both; text-align: center;"> 
         <a href="http://2.bp.blogspot.com/-gNJ1odvvMnw/VZMK6H3ipTI/AAAAAAAAETo/EEA5GdbiyJY/s1600/nikto.png" imageanchor="1" style="margin-left: 1em; margin-right: 1em;"><img border="0" height="270" src="http://2.bp.blogspot.com/-gNJ1odvvMnw/VZMK6H3ipTI/AAAAAAAAETo/EEA5GdbiyJY/s640/nikto.png" width="640"></a>
        </div> 
        <br> Nikto is an Open Source (
        <a href="http://www.gnu.org/licenses/licenses.html#GPL">GPL</a>) web server scanner which performs comprehensive tests against web servers for multiple items, including over 6700 potentially dangerous files/programs, checks for outdated versions of over 1250 servers, and version specific problems on over 270 servers. It also checks for server configuration items such as the presence of multiple index files, HTTP server options, and will attempt to identify installed web servers and software. Scan items and plugins are frequently updated and can be automatically updated. 
       </div> 
       <div style="text-align: justify;"> 
        <br>
       </div> 
       <div style="text-align: justify;">
         Nikto is not designed as a stealthy tool. It will test a web server in the quickest time possible, and is obvious in log files or to an IPS/IDS. However, there is support for LibWhisker's anti-IDS methods in case you want to give it a try (or test your IDS system).
       </div> 
       <a name="more"></a>
       <br> 
       <div style="text-align: justify;">
         Not 
        <i>every</i> check is a security problem, though most are. There are some items that are "info only" type checks that look for things that may not have a security flaw, but the webmaster or security engineer may not know are present on the server. These items are usually marked appropriately in the information printed. There are also some checks for unknown items which have been seen scanned for in log files.
       </div> 
      </div> 
      <div> 
       <div style="text-align: justify;"> 
        <br>
       </div> 
      </div> 
      <div> 
       <div style="text-align: justify;"> 
        <b><span style="font-size: large;">Features</span></b>
        <br> 
        <b><br></b>
       </div> 
      </div> 
      <div> 
       <div style="text-align: justify;">
         Here are some of the major features of Nikto. See the 
        <a href="http://cirt.net/nikto2-docs/">documentation</a> for a full list of features and how to use them.
       </div> 
       <ul> 
        <li style="text-align: justify;">SSL Support (Unix with OpenSSL or maybe Windows with ActiveState's&nbsp;Perl/NetSSL) </li> 
        <li style="text-align: justify;">Full HTTP proxy support</li> 
        <li style="text-align: justify;">Checks for outdated server components</li> 
        <li style="text-align: justify;">Save reports in plain text, XML, HTML, NBE or CSV </li> 
        <li style="text-align: justify;">Template engine to easily customize reports </li> 
        <li style="text-align: justify;">Scan multiple ports on a server, or multiple servers via input file (including nmap output)</li> 
        <li style="text-align: justify;"><a href="http://www.wiretrip.net/rfp/lw.asp">LibWhisker</a>'s IDS encoding techniques </li> 
        <li style="text-align: justify;">Easily updated via command line</li> 
        <li style="text-align: justify;">Identifies installed software via headers, favicons and files</li> 
        <li style="text-align: justify;">Host authentication with Basic and NTLM</li> 
        <li style="text-align: justify;">Subdomain guessing</li> 
        <li style="text-align: justify;">Apache and cgiwrap username enumeration</li> 
        <li style="text-align: justify;">Mutation techniques to "fish" for content on web servers</li> 
        <li style="text-align: justify;">Scan tuning to include or exclude entire classes of vulnerability&nbsp;checks </li> 
        <li style="text-align: justify;">Guess credentials for authorization realms (including many default id/pw combos)</li> 
        <li style="text-align: justify;">Authorization guessing handles any directory, not just the root&nbsp;directory </li> 
        <li style="text-align: justify;">Enhanced false positive reduction via multiple methods: headers,&nbsp;page content, and content hashing </li> 
        <li style="text-align: justify;">Reports "unusual" headers seen</li> 
        <li style="text-align: justify;">Interactive status, pause and changes to verbosity settings</li> 
        <li style="text-align: justify;">Save full request/response for positive tests</li> 
        <li style="text-align: justify;">Replay saved positive requests</li> 
        <li style="text-align: justify;">Maximum execution time per target</li> 
        <li style="text-align: justify;">Auto-pause at a specified time</li> 
        <li style="text-align: justify;">Checks for common "parking" sites</li> 
        <li style="text-align: justify;">Logging to Metasploit</li> 
        <li style="text-align: justify;">Thorough <a href="https://cirt.net/nikto2-docs/">documentation</a></li> 
       </ul> 
      </div> 
      <div> 
       <br> 
       <b><span style="font-size: large;">Basic usage</span></b>
       <br> 
       <pre><code>   Options:
       -ask+               Whether to ask about submitting updates
                               yes   Ask about each (default)
                               no    Don't ask, don't send
                               auto  Don't ask, just send
       -Cgidirs+           Scan these CGI dirs: "none", "all", or values like "/cgi/ /cgi-a/"
       -config+            Use this config file
       -Display+           Turn on/off display outputs:
                               1     Show redirects
                               2     Show cookies received
                               3     Show all 200/OK responses
                               4     Show URLs which require authentication
                               D     Debug output
                               E     Display all HTTP errors
                               P     Print progress to STDOUT
                               S     Scrub output of IPs and hostnames
                               V     Verbose output
       -dbcheck           Check database and other key files for syntax errors
       -evasion+          Encoding technique:
                               1     Random URI encoding (non-UTF8)
                               2     Directory self-reference (/./)
                               3     Premature URL ending
                               4     Prepend long random string
                               5     Fake parameter
                               6     TAB as request spacer
                               7     Change the case of the URL
                               8     Use Windows directory separator (\)
                               A     Use a carriage return (0x0d) as a request spacer
                               B     Use binary value 0x0b as a request spacer
        -Format+           Save file (-o) format:
                               csv   Comma-separated-value
                               htm   HTML Format
                               msf+  Log to Metasploit
                               nbe   Nessus NBE format
                               txt   Plain text
                               xml   XML Format
                               (if not specified the format will be taken from the file extension passed to -output)
       -Help              Extended help information
       -host+             Target host
       -IgnoreCode        Ignore Codes--treat as negative responses
       -id+               Host authentication to use, format is id:pass or id:pass:realm
       -key+              Client certificate key file
       -list-plugins      List all available plugins, perform no testing
       -maxtime+          Maximum testing time per host
       -mutate+           Guess additional file names:
                               1     Test all files with all root directories
                               2     Guess for password file names
                               3     Enumerate user names via Apache (/~user type requests)
                               4     Enumerate user names via cgiwrap (/cgi-bin/cgiwrap/~user type requests)
                               5     Attempt to brute force sub-domain names, assume that the host name is the parent domain
                               6     Attempt to guess directory names from the supplied dictionary file
       -mutate-options    Provide information for mutates
       -nointeractive     Disables interactive features
       -nolookup          Disables DNS lookups
       -nossl             Disables the use of SSL
       -no404             Disables nikto attempting to guess a 404 page
       -output+           Write output to this file ('.' for auto-name)
       -Pause+            Pause between tests (seconds, integer or float)
       -Plugins+          List of plugins to run (default: ALL)
       -port+             Port to use (default 80)
       -RSAcert+          Client certificate file
       -root+             Prepend root value to all requests, format is /directory
       -Save              Save positive responses to this directory ('.' for auto-name)
       -ssl               Force ssl mode on port
       -Tuning+           Scan tuning:
                               1     Interesting File / Seen in logs
                               2     Misconfiguration / Default File
                               3     Information Disclosure
                               4     Injection (XSS/Script/HTML)
                               5     Remote File Retrieval - Inside Web Root
                               6     Denial of Service
                               7     Remote File Retrieval - Server Wide
                               8     Command Execution / Remote Shell
                               9     SQL Injection
                               0     File Upload
                               a     Authentication Bypass
                               b     Software Identification
                               c     Remote Source Inclusion
                               x     Reverse Tuning Options (i.e., include all except specified)
       -timeout+          Timeout for requests (default 10 seconds)
       -Userdbs           Load only user databases, not the standard databases
                               all   Disable standard dbs and load only user dbs
                               tests Disable only db_tests and load udb_tests
       -until             Run until the specified time or duration
       -update            Update databases and plugins from CIRT.net
       -useproxy          Use the proxy defined in nikto.conf
       -Version           Print plugin and database versions
       -vhost+            Virtual host (for Host header)
              + requires a value
</code></pre> 
      </div> 
      <br> 
      <div class="section" title="Basic Testing"> 
       <div class="titlepage"> 
        <b><span style="font-size: large;"> Basic Testing</span></b>
        <br> 
        <br>
       </div> 
       <div style="text-align: justify;">
         The most basic Nikto scan requires simply a host to target, since port 80 is assumed if none is specified. The host can either be an IP or a hostname of a machine, and is specified using the 
        <em class="parameter"><code>-h</code></em> (
        <em class="parameter"><code>-host</code></em>) option. This will scan the IP 192.168.0.1 on TCP port 80:
       </div> 
       <pre><code>perl nikto.pl -h 192.168.0.1</code></pre> 
       <div style="text-align: justify;">
         To check on a different port, specify the port number with the 
        <em class="parameter"><code>-p</code></em> (
        <em class="parameter"><code>-port</code></em>) option. This will scan the IP 192.168.0.1 on TCP port 443:
       </div> 
       <pre><code>perl nikto.pl -h 192.168.0.1 -p 443</code></pre> 
       <div style="text-align: justify;">
         Hosts, ports and protocols may also be specified by using a full URL syntax, and it will be scanned:
       </div> 
       <pre><code>perl nikto.pl -h https://192.168.0.1:443/</code></pre> 
       <div style="text-align: justify;">
         There is no need to specify that port 443 may be SSL, as Nikto will first test regular HTTP and if that fails, HTTPS. If you are sure it is an SSL server, specifying 
        <em class="parameter"><code>-s</code></em> (
        <em class="parameter"><code>-ssl</code></em>) will speed up the test.
       </div> 
       <pre><code>perl nikto.pl -h 192.168.0.1 -p 443 -ssl</code></pre> 
       <div class="note" style="margin-left: 0.5in; margin-right: 0.5in;" title="Note"> 
       </div> 
       <div style="text-align: justify;">
         More complex tests can be performed using the 
        <em class="parameter"><code>-mutate</code></em> parameter, as detailed later. This can produce extra tests, some of which may be provided with extra parameters through the 
        <em class="parameter"><code>-mutate-options</code></em> parameter. For example, using 
        <em class="parameter"><code>-mutate</code></em> 3, with or without a file attempts to brute force usernames if the web server allows ~
        <em class="replaceable"><code>user</code></em> URIs:
       </div> 
       <pre><code>perl nikto.pl -h 192.168.0.1 -mutate 3 -mutate-options user-list.txt</code></pre> 
      </div> 
      <div class="section" title="Multiple Port Testing"> 
       <div class="titlepage"> 
        <br> 
        <b><span style="font-size: large;"> <a href="https://draft.blogger.com/null" name="id2740890"></a>Multiple Port Testing</span></b>
        <br> 
        <br>
       </div> 
       <div style="text-align: justify;">
         Nikto can scan multiple ports in the same scanning session. To test more than one port on the same host, specify the list of ports in the 
        <em class="parameter"><code>-p</code></em> (
        <em class="parameter"><code>-port</code></em>) option. Ports can be specified as a range (i.e., 80-90), or as a comma-delimited list, (i.e., 80,88,90). This will scan the host on ports 80, 88 and 443.
       </div> 
       <pre><code>perl nikto.pl -h 192.168.0.1 -p 80,88,443</code></pre> 
      </div> 
      <br> 
      <br> 
      <div style="text-align: center;"> 
       <b><span style="font-size: x-large;"><a href="https://github.com/sullo/nikto" target="_blank">Download&nbsp;Nikto2</a></span></b>
      </div> 
     </div>
    </article> 
    <article class="post hentry" id="1379236143122456066" itemscope itemtype="http://schema.org/BlogPosting"> 
     <h1 class="post-title entry-title" itemprop="name headline"> Nipe - Script To Redirect All Traffic From The Machine To The Tor Network  </h1> 
     <div class="post-header" style="position:absolute;left:-9999px"> 
      <div class="post-header-line-1"></div> 
     </div> 
     <div class="post-body entry-content" id="post-body-1379236143122456066" itemprop="articleBody"> 
      <div class="separator" style="clear: both; text-align: center;"> 
       <a href="http://4.bp.blogspot.com/-P8oX7hcAD8s/VoWCflU013I/AAAAAAAAE-A/N3ZFlbMs2xA/s1600/nipe.png" imageanchor="1" style="margin-left: 1em; margin-right: 1em;"><img border="0" src="http://4.bp.blogspot.com/-P8oX7hcAD8s/VoWCflU013I/AAAAAAAAE-A/N3ZFlbMs2xA/s1600/nipe.png"></a>
      </div> Script to redirect all the traffic from the machine to the Tor network. 
      <br> 
      <pre><code>    [+] AUTOR:        Vinicius Gouvea
    [+] EMAIL:        <a href="/cdn-cgi/l/email-protection" class="__cf_email__" data-cfemail="56203f383f163f38263a393f227835393b">[email&nbsp;protected]</a>
    [+] BLOG:         https://medium.com/viniciusgouvea
    [+] GITHUB:       https://github.com/HeitorG
    [+] FACEBOOK:     https://fb.com/viniciushgouvea
</code></pre> 
      <br> 
      <a name="more"></a>
      <br> 
      <span style="font-size: large;"> <b> Installing: </b> </span> 
      <br> 
      <pre><code>git clone https://github.com/HeitorG/nipe
cd nipe
cpan install  strict warnings Switch
</code></pre> 
      <br> 
      <span style="font-size: large;"> <b> Commands: </b> </span> 
      <br> 
      <pre><code>COMMAND          FUNCTION
install          For install.
start            To start
stop             To stop
</code></pre> 
      <br> 
      <b> Tested on: </b> 
      <br> 
      <ul> 
       <li> Ubuntu 14.10 and 15.04 </li> 
       <li> Busen Labs Hydrogen </li> 
       <li> Debian Jessie 8.1 and Wheezy 7.9 </li> 
       <li> Lubuntu 15.04 </li> 
       <li> Xubuntu 15.04 </li> 
       <li> LionSec 3.0</li> 
      </ul> 
      <br> 
      <div style="text-align: center;"> 
       <b> <span style="font-size: x-large;"> <a href="https://github.com/HeitorG/nipe" target="_blank"> Download Nipe </a> </span> </b> 
      </div> 
     </div>
    </article> 
    <article class="post hentry" id="9218581676239294784" itemscope itemtype="http://schema.org/BlogPosting"> 
     <h1 class="post-title entry-title" itemprop="name headline"> Nipper - Toolkit Web Scan for Android  </h1> 
     <div class="post-header" style="position:absolute;left:-9999px"> 
      <div class="post-header-line-1"></div> 
     </div> 
     <div class="post-body entry-content" id="post-body-9218581676239294784" itemprop="articleBody"> 
      <div class="separator" style="clear: both; text-align: center;"> 
       <a href="http://4.bp.blogspot.com/-p1U89c1Rwkg/VKs7aeaBU7I/AAAAAAAADgA/ogcoNLA91Ow/s1600/Nipper.png" imageanchor="1" style="margin-left: 1em; margin-right: 1em;"><img border="0" src="http://4.bp.blogspot.com/-p1U89c1Rwkg/VKs7aeaBU7I/AAAAAAAADgA/ogcoNLA91Ow/s1600/Nipper.png" height="640" width="358"></a>
      </div> 
      <br> 
      <div style="text-align: justify;">
        La Primera herramienta de escáner de vulnerabilidades WEB, En entorno Android (Versión para iOS en desarrollo), este escáner de vulnerabilidad fue enfocado para CMS más usadas, (WordPress, Drupal, Joomla. Blogger ).
      </div> 
      <br> 
      <div style="text-align: justify;">
        En su primera versión Nipper cuenta con 10 módulos distintos, para recopilar información acerca de un URL en específica.
      </div> 
      <br> 
      <div style="text-align: justify;">
        Su interfaz ha sido pensada para que tan solo con unos “toques” en su interfaz extraerías gran parte de su información.
       <br> 
       <a name="more"></a>
      </div> 
      <br> 
      <b><span class="Apple-style-span" style="font-size: large;">Módulos Disponibles:</span></b>
      <br> 
      <ul> 
       <li style="text-align: justify;">IP Server</li> 
       <li style="text-align: justify;">CMS Detect &amp; Version</li> 
       <li style="text-align: justify;">DNS Lookup</li> 
       <li style="text-align: justify;">Nmap ports IP SERVER</li> 
       <li style="text-align: justify;">Enumeration Users</li> 
       <li style="text-align: justify;">Enumeration Plugins</li> 
       <li style="text-align: justify;">Find Exploit Core CMS</li> 
       <li style="text-align: justify;">Find Exploit DB</li> 
       <li style="text-align: justify;">CloudFlare Resolver</li> 
      </ul> 
      <div style="text-align: justify;">
        Nipper NO requiere ROOT, tan solo requiere permiso a internet.
      </div> 
      <div style="text-align: justify;">
        Compatible desde 2.3 a Android L.
      </div> 
      <div style="text-align: justify;"> 
       <br>
      </div> 
      <div style="text-align: justify;"> 
       <br>
      </div> 
      <div style="text-align: center;"> 
       <b><span class="Apple-style-span" style="font-size: x-large;"><a href="https://play.google.com/store/apps/details?id=com.websecuritydev.nipper" target="_blank">Download&nbsp;Nipper</a></span></b>
      </div> 
     </div>
    </article> 
    <article class="post hentry" id="2150869017814835327" itemscope itemtype="http://schema.org/BlogPosting"> 
     <h1 class="post-title entry-title" itemprop="name headline"> Nmap 7 - Security Scanner For Network Exploration &amp; Security Audits  </h1> 
     <div class="post-header" style="position:absolute;left:-9999px"> 
      <div class="post-header-line-1"></div> 
     </div> 
     <div class="post-body entry-content" id="post-body-2150869017814835327" itemprop="articleBody"> 
      <div class="separator" style="clear: both; text-align: center;"> 
       <a href="http://3.bp.blogspot.com/-aJgMvqE2484/Vk54XQa5aRI/AAAAAAAAE0c/ROqIccOGx2w/s1600/zenmap7.png" imageanchor="1" style="margin-left: 1em; margin-right: 1em;"><img border="0" height="608" src="http://3.bp.blogspot.com/-aJgMvqE2484/Vk54XQa5aRI/AAAAAAAAE0c/ROqIccOGx2w/s640/zenmap7.png" width="640"></a>
      </div> 
      <br> 
      <div style="text-align: justify;">
        Nmap (“Network Mapper”) is a free and open source (
       <a href="https://nmap.org/data/COPYING">license</a>) utility for network discovery and security auditing. Many systems and network administrators also find it useful for network inventory, managing service upgrade schedules, monitoring host or service uptime, and many other tasks. Nmap uses raw IP packets in novel ways to determine what hosts are available on the network, what services (application name and version) those hosts are offering, what operating systems (and OS versions) they are running, what type of packet filters/firewalls are in use, and dozens of other characteristics. It was designed to rapidly scan large networks, but works fine against single hosts. Nmap runs on all major computer operating systems, and official binary packages are available for Linux, Windows, and Mac OS X. In addition to the classic command-line Nmap executable, the Nmap suite includes an advanced GUI and results viewer (
       <a href="https://nmap.org/zenmap/">Zenmap</a>), a flexible data transfer, redirection, and debugging tool (
       <a href="https://nmap.org/ncat/">Ncat</a>), a utility for comparing scan results (
       <a href="https://nmap.org/ndiff/">Ndiff</a>), and a packet generation and response analysis tool (
       <a href="https://nmap.org/nping/">Nping</a>).
       <br> 
       <a name="more"></a>
      </div> 
      <br> 
      <div style="text-align: justify;">
        Nmap was named “Security Product of the Year” by Linux Journal, Info World, LinuxQuestions.Org, and Codetalker Digest. It was even featured in 
       <a href="https://nmap.org/movies.html">nineteen movies and TV series</a>, including 
       <a href="https://nmap.org/movies.html#matrix">The Matrix Reloaded</a>, 
       <a href="https://nmap.org/movies.html#bourne">The Bourne Ultimatum</a>. 
       <a href="https://nmap.org/movies.html#gwtdt">Girl with the Dragon Tattoo</a>, 
       <a href="https://nmap.org/movies.html#dredd">Dredd</a>, 
       <a href="https://nmap.org/movies.html#elysium">Elysium</a>, and 
       <a href="https://nmap.org/movies.html#diehard4">Die Hard 4</a>. Nmap was released to the public in 1997 and has earned the trust of millions of users.
      </div> 
      <div style="text-align: justify;"> 
       <br>
      </div> 
      <b><span style="font-size: large;">Top 7 Improvements in Nmap 7</span></b>
      <br> 
      <br> 
      <div style="text-align: justify;">
        Before we get into the 
       <a href="https://nmap.org/7/#changes">detailed changes</a>, here are the top 7 improvements in Nmap 7:
      </div> 
      <dl> 
       <dt style="text-align: justify;">
        <b>1. Major Nmap Scripting Engine (NSE) Expansion</b>
       </dt> 
       <dd>
        <div style="text-align: justify;">
          As the Nmap core has matured, more and more new functionality is developed as part of our NSE subsystem instead. In fact, we've added 171 new scripts and 20 libraries since Nmap 6. Exmaples include 
         <a href="https://nmap.org/nsedoc/scripts/firewall-bypass.html">firewall-bypass</a>, 
         <a href="https://nmap.org/nsedoc/scripts/supermicro-ipmi-conf.html">supermicro-ipmi-conf</a>, 
         <a href="https://nmap.org/nsedoc/scripts/oracle-brute-stealth.html">oracle-brute-stealth</a>, and 
         <a href="https://nmap.org/nsedoc/scripts/ssl-heartbleed.html">ssl-heartbleed</a>. And NSE is now powerful enough that scripts can take on core functions such as host discovery (
         <a href="https://nmap.org/nsedoc/scripts/dns-ip6-arpa-scan.html">dns-ip6-arpa-scan</a>), version scanning (
         <a href="https://nmap.org/nsedoc/scripts/ike-version.html">ike-version</a>, 
         <a href="https://nmap.org/nsedoc/scripts/snmp-info.html">snmp-info</a>, etc.), and RPC grinding (
         <a href="https://nmap.org/nsedoc/scripts/rpc-grind.html">rpc-grind</a>). There's even a proposal to 
         <a href="https://secwiki.org/w/GSoC_community_ideas#Exploring_port_scanning_from_within_NSE">implement port scanning in NSE</a>. [
         <a href="https://nmap.org/7/#changes-nse">More Details</a>]
        </div> 
       </dd>
       <dd>
        <div style="text-align: justify;"> 
         <br>
        </div> 
       </dd> 
       <dt style="text-align: justify;">
        <b>2. Mature IPv6 support</b>
       </dt> 
       <dd>
        <div style="text-align: justify;">
          IPv6 scanning improvements were a big item in the Nmap 6 release, but Nmap 7 outdoes them all with full IPv6 support for CIDR-style address ranges, Idle Scan, parallel reverse-DNS, and more NSE script coverage. [
         <a href="https://nmap.org/7/#changes-ipv6">More Details</a>]
        </div> 
       </dd>
       <dd>
        <div style="text-align: justify;"> 
         <br>
        </div> 
       </dd> 
       <dt style="text-align: justify;">
        <b>3. Infrastructure Upgrades</b>
       </dt> 
       <dd>
        <div style="text-align: justify;">
          We may be an 18-year-old project, but that doesn't mean we'll stick with old, crumbling infrastructure! The Nmap Project continues to adopt the latest technologies to enhance the development process and serve a growing user base. For example, we converted all of Nmap.Org to SSL to reduce the risk of trojan binaries and reduce snooping in general. We've also been using the 
         <a href="https://git-scm.com/">Git version control system</a> as a larger part of our workflow and have an official 
         <a href="https://github.org/nmap/nmap">Github mirror of the Nmap Subversion source repository</a> and we encourage code submissions to be made as Github pull requests. We also created an 
         <a href="https://github.com/nmap/nmap/issues/">official bug tracker</a> which is also hosted on Github. Tracking bugs and enhancement requests this way has already reduced the number which fall through the cracks. [
         <a href="https://nmap.org/7/#changes-infrastructure">More Details</a>]
        </div> 
       </dd>
       <dd>
        <div style="text-align: justify;"> 
         <br>
        </div> 
       </dd> 
       <dt style="text-align: justify;">
        <b>4. Faster Scans</b>
       </dt> 
       <dd>
        <div style="text-align: justify;">
          Nmap has continually pushed the speed boundaries of synchronous network scanning for 18 years, and this release is no exception. New Nsock engines give a performance boost to Windows and BSD systems, target reordering prevents a nasty edge case on multihomed systems, and NSE tweaks lead to much faster -sV scans. [
         <a href="https://nmap.org/7/#changes-performance">More Details</a>]
        </div> 
       </dd>
       <dd>
        <div style="text-align: justify;"> 
         <br>
        </div> 
       </dd> 
       <dt style="text-align: justify;">
        <b>5. SSL/TLS scanning solution of choice</b>
       </dt> 
       <dd>
        <div style="text-align: justify;">
          Transport Layer Security (TLS) and its predecessor, SSL, are the security underpinning of the web, so when big vulnerabilities like Heartbleed, POODLE, and FREAK come calling, Nmap answers with vulnerability detection NSE scripts. The 
         <a href="https://nmap.org/nsedoc/scripts/ssl-enum-ciphers.html">ssl-enum-ciphers</a> script has been entirely revamped to perform fast analysis of TLS deployment problems, and version scanning probes have been tweaked to quickly detect the newest TLS handshake versions. [
         <a href="https://nmap.org/7/#changes-ssl">More Details</a>]
        </div> 
       </dd>
       <dd>
        <div style="text-align: justify;"> 
         <br>
        </div> 
       </dd> 
       <dt style="text-align: justify;">
        <b>6. Ncat Enhanced</b>
       </dt> 
       <dd>
        <div style="text-align: justify;">
          We are excited and proud to announce that Ncat has been adopted by the Red Hat/Fedora family of distributions as the default package to provide the "netcat" and "nc" commands! This cooperation has resulted in a lot of squashed bugs and enhanced compatibility with Netcat's options. Also very exciting is the addition of an embedded Lua interpreter for creating simple, cross-platform daemons and traffic filters.
        </div> 
       </dd>
       <dd>
        <div style="text-align: justify;"> 
         <br>
        </div> 
       </dd> 
       <dt style="text-align: justify;">
        <b>7. Extreme Portability</b>
       </dt> 
       <dd>
        <div style="text-align: justify;">
          Nmap is proudly cross-platform and runs on all sorts of esoteric and archaic systems. But our binary distributions have to be kept up-to-date with the latest popular operating systems. Nmap 7 runs cleanly on Windows 10 all the way back to Windows Vista. By popular request, we even built it to run on Windows XP, though we suggest those users upgrade their systems. Mac OS X is supported from 10.8 Mountain Lion through 10.11 El Capitan. Plus, we updated support for Solaris and AIX. And Linux users—you have it easy.
        </div> 
       </dd>
      </dl> 
      <br> 
      <div style="text-align: center;"> 
       <b><span style="font-size: x-large;"><a href="https://nmap.org/download.html" target="_blank">Download Nmap 7</a></span></b>
      </div> 
     </div>
    </article> 
    <article class="post hentry" id="7829632691968735443" itemscope itemtype="http://schema.org/BlogPosting"> 
     <h1 class="post-title entry-title" itemprop="name headline"> NoPo - NoSQL Honeypot Framework  </h1> 
     <div class="post-header" style="position:absolute;left:-9999px"> 
      <div class="post-header-line-1"></div> 
     </div> 
     <div class="post-body entry-content" id="post-body-7829632691968735443" itemprop="articleBody"> 
      <div class="separator" style="clear: both; text-align: center;"> 
       <a href="http://3.bp.blogspot.com/-_xNkwG1Lgis/VWnI4rvvK8I/AAAAAAAAEIk/s-DSlkfw3DE/s1600/NoPo.png" imageanchor="1" style="margin-left: 1em; margin-right: 1em;"><img border="0" height="302" src="http://3.bp.blogspot.com/-_xNkwG1Lgis/VWnI4rvvK8I/AAAAAAAAEIk/s-DSlkfw3DE/s640/NoPo.png" width="640"></a>
      </div> 
      <br> 
      <div style="text-align: justify;">
        NoSQL-Honeypot-Framework (NoPo) is an open source honeypot for nosql databases that automates the process of detecting attackers,logging attack incidents. The simulation engines are deployed using the twisted framework.Currently the framework holds support for redis.
      </div> 
      <div style="text-align: justify;"> 
       <br>
      </div> 
      <div style="text-align: justify;">
        N.B : The framework is under development and is prone to bugs
       <br> 
       <a name="more"></a>
      </div> 
      <br> 
      <b><span style="font-size: large;">Installation</span></b>
      <br> You can download NoPo by cloning the Git repository:
      <br> 
      <pre><code>git clone https://github.com/torque59/nosqlpot.git

pip install -r requirements.txt
</code></pre> NoPo works out of the box with Python version 
      <strong>2.6.x</strong> and 
      <strong>2.7.x</strong> on any platform.
      <br> 
      <br> 
      <b><span style="font-size: large;">Added Features:</span></b>
      <br> 
      <ul> 
       <li>First Ever Honeypot for NoSQL Databases</li> 
       <li>Support For Config Files </li> 
       <li>Simulates Protocol Specification as of Servers</li> 
       <li>Support for Redis</li> 
      </ul> 
      <br> 
      <b><span style="font-size: large;">Usage</span></b>
      <br> Get a list of basic options :
      <br> 
      <pre><code>python nopo.py -h
</code></pre> Deploy an nosql engine:
      <br> 
      <pre><code>python nopo.py -deploy redis
</code></pre> Deploy an nosql engine with a configuration file:
      <br> 
      <pre><code>python nopo.py -deploy redis -config filename
</code></pre> Log commands,session to file :
      <br> 
      <pre><code>python nopo.py -deploy redis -out log.out
</code></pre> 
      <br> 
      <br> 
      <div style="text-align: center;"> 
       <b><span style="font-size: x-large;"><a href="https://github.com/torque59/nosqlpot/" target="_blank">Download NoPo</a></span></b>
      </div> 
     </div>
    </article> 
    <article class="post hentry" id="9175729299006977840" itemscope itemtype="http://schema.org/BlogPosting"> 
     <h1 class="post-title entry-title" itemprop="name headline"> Noriben - Your Personal, Portable Malware Sandbox  </h1> 
     <div class="post-header" style="position:absolute;left:-9999px"> 
      <div class="post-header-line-1"></div> 
     </div> 
     <div class="post-body entry-content" id="post-body-9175729299006977840" itemprop="articleBody"> 
      <div class="separator" style="clear: both; text-align: center;"> 
       <a href="http://2.bp.blogspot.com/-Uak5LLRHT_U/VdvvgyzvYuI/AAAAAAAAEho/0gSoRGntIAM/s1600/Noriben.png" imageanchor="1" style="margin-left: 1em; margin-right: 1em;"><img border="0" src="http://2.bp.blogspot.com/-Uak5LLRHT_U/VdvvgyzvYuI/AAAAAAAAEho/0gSoRGntIAM/s1600/Noriben.png"></a>
      </div> 
      <br> 
      <div style="text-align: justify;">
        Noriben is a Python-based script that works in conjunction with Sysinternals Procmon to automatically collect, analyze, and report on runtime indicators of malware. In a nutshell, it allows you to run your malware, hit a keypress, and get a simple text report of the sample's activities.
      </div> 
      <div style="text-align: justify;"> 
       <br>
      </div> 
      <div style="text-align: justify;">
        Noriben allows you to not only run malware similar to a sandbox, but to also log system-wide events while you manually run malware in ways particular to making it run. For example, it can listen as you run malware that requires varying command line options. Or, watch the system as you step through malware in a debugger.
      </div> 
      <a name="more"></a>
      <br> 
      <div style="text-align: justify;">
        Noriben only requires Sysinternals procmon.exe (or procmon64.exe) to operate. It requires no pre-filtering (though it would greatly help) as it contains numerous white list items to reduce unwanted noise from system activity.
      </div> 
      <div style="text-align: justify;"> 
       <br>
      </div> 
      <div style="text-align: justify;"> 
       <b><span style="font-size: x-large;">Cool Features</span></b>
      </div> 
      <div style="text-align: justify;"> 
       <br>
      </div> 
      <div style="text-align: justify;">
        If you have a folder of YARA signature files, you can specify it with the --yara option. Every new file create will be scanned against these signatures with the results displayed in the output results.
       <br> 
       <br>
      </div> 
      <div style="text-align: justify;">
        If you have a VirusTotal API, place it into a file named "virustotal.api" (or embed directly in the script) to auto-submit MD5 file hashes to VT to get the number of viral results. 
       <br> 
       <br>
      </div> 
      <div style="text-align: justify;">
        You can add lists of MD5s to auto-ignore (such as all of your system files). Use md5deep and throw them into a text file, use --hash to read them.
       <br> 
       <br>
      </div> 
      <div style="text-align: justify;">
        You can automate the script for sandbox-usage. Using -t to automate execution time, and --cmd "path\exe" to specify a malware file, you can automatically run malware, copy the results off, and then revert to run a new sample.
       <br> 
       <br>
      </div> 
      <div style="text-align: justify;">
        The --generalize feature will automatically substitute absolute paths with Windows environment paths for better IOC development. For example, C:\Users\malware_user\AppData\Roaming\malware.exe will be automatically resolved to %AppData%\malware.exe.
      </div> 
      <br> 
      <b><span style="font-size: large;">Usage:</span></b>
      <br> 
      <pre><code>--===[ Noriben v1.6 ]===--
--===[   @bbaskin   ]===--

usage: Noriben.py [-h] [-c CSV] [-p PML] [-f FILTER] [--hash HASH]
                  [-t TIMEOUT] [--output OUTPUT] [--yara YARA] [--generalize]
                  [--cmd CMD] [-d]

optional arguments:
  -h, --help            show this help message and exit
  -c CSV, --csv CSV     Re-analyze an existing Noriben CSV file
  -p PML, --pml PML     Re-analyze an existing Noriben PML file
  -f FILTER, --filter FILTER
                        Specify alternate Procmon Filter PMC
  --hash HASH           Specify MD5 file whitelist
  -t TIMEOUT, --timeout TIMEOUT
                        Number of seconds to collect activity
  --output OUTPUT       Folder to store output files
  --yara YARA           Folder containing YARA rules
  --generalize          Generalize file paths to their environment variables.
                        Default: True
  --cmd CMD             Command line to execute (in quotes)
  -d                    Enable debug tracebacks
</code></pre> 
      <br> 
      <br> 
      <div style="text-align: center;"> 
       <b><span style="font-size: x-large;"><a href="https://github.com/Rurik/Noriben" target="_blank">Download Noriben</a></span></b>
      </div> 
     </div>
    </article> 
    <article class="post hentry" id="5343067594908628975" itemscope itemtype="http://schema.org/BlogPosting"> 
     <h1 class="post-title entry-title" itemprop="name headline"> NSEarch - Nmap Script Engine Search  </h1> 
     <div class="post-header" style="position:absolute;left:-9999px"> 
      <div class="post-header-line-1"></div> 
     </div> 
     <div class="post-body entry-content" id="post-body-5343067594908628975" itemprop="articleBody"> 
      <div class="separator" style="clear: both; text-align: center;"> 
       <a href="http://2.bp.blogspot.com/-gtJe_hGJSD8/VOV3VOaGjMI/AAAAAAAADsY/uOGy-AqZDvU/s1600/NSEarch.png" imageanchor="1" style="margin-left: 1em; margin-right: 1em;"><img border="0" src="http://2.bp.blogspot.com/-gtJe_hGJSD8/VOV3VOaGjMI/AAAAAAAADsY/uOGy-AqZDvU/s1600/NSEarch.png" height="370" width="640"></a>
      </div> 
      <br> NSEarch is a tool that helps you find scripts that are used nmap (NSE) , can be searched using the name or category , it is also possible to see the documentation of the scripts found.
      <br> 
      <a name="more"></a>
      <br> 
      <b><span class="Apple-style-span" style="font-size: large;">USAGE:</span></b>
      <br> 
      <pre><code>  $ python nsearch.py
</code></pre> 
      <br> 
      <b><span class="Apple-style-span" style="font-size: large;">Main Menu</span></b>
      <br> 
      <br> 
      <b>Initial Setup</b>
      <br> 
      <pre><code> ================================================
    _   _  _____  _____                     _
   | \ | |/  ___||  ___|                   | |
   |  \| |\ `--. | |__    __ _  _ __   ___ | |__
   | . ` | `--. \|  __|  / _` || '__| / __|| '_ \
   | |\  |/\__/ /| |___ | (_| || |   | (__ | | | |
   \_| \_/\____/ \____/  \__,_||_|    \___||_| |_|
 ================================================
   Version 0.3     |   @jjtibaquira
 ================================================

  Creating Database :nmap_scripts.sqlite3
  Creating Table For Script ....
  Creating Table for Categories ....
  Creating Table for Scripts per Category ....
  Upload Categories to Categories Table ...
</code></pre> 
      <br> 
      <b>Main Console</b>
      <br> 
      <pre><code>  ================================================
    _   _  _____  _____                     _
   | \ | |/  ___||  ___|                   | |
   |  \| |\ `--. | |__    __ _  _ __   ___ | |__
   | . ` | `--. \|  __|  / _` || '__| / __|| '_  |
   | |\  |/\__/ /| |___ | (_| || |   | (__ | | | |
   \_| \_/\____/ \____/  \__,_||_|    \___||_| |_|
  ================================================
   Version 0.3     |   @jjtibaquira
  ================================================

  nsearch&gt;
</code></pre> 
      <br> 
      <b>Basic Commands</b>
      <br> 
      <pre><code>  ================================================
    _   _  _____  _____                     _
   | \ | |/  ___||  ___|                   | |
   |  \| |\ `--. | |__    __ _  _ __   ___ | |__
   | . ` | `--. \|  __|  / _` || '__| / __|| '_  |
   | |\  |/\__/ /| |___ | (_| || |   | (__ | | | |
   \_| \_/\____/ \____/  \__,_||_|    \___||_| |_|
  ================================================
   Version 0.3     |   @jjtibaquira
  ================================================

  nsearch&gt; help

  Nsearch Commands
  ================
  clear  doc  exit  help  history  last  search

  nsearch&gt;
</code></pre> 
      <pre><code>  ================================================
    _   _  _____  _____                     _
   | \ | |/  ___||  ___|                   | |
   |  \| |\ `--. | |__    __ _  _ __   ___ | |__
   | . ` | `--. \|  __|  / _` || '__| / __|| '_  |
   | |\  |/\__/ /| |___ | (_| || |   | (__ | | | |
   \_| \_/\____/ \____/  \__,_||_|    \___||_| |_|
  ================================================
   Version 0.3     |   @jjtibaquira
  ================================================

  nsearch&gt; help search

  name     : Search by script's name
  category : Search by category
  Usage:
    search name:http
    search category:exploit

  nsearch&gt;
</code></pre> 
      <pre><code>  ================================================
    _   _  _____  _____                     _
   | \ | |/  ___||  ___|                   | |
   |  \| |\ `--. | |__    __ _  _ __   ___ | |__
   | . ` | `--. \|  __|  / _` || '__| / __|| '_  |
   | |\  |/\__/ /| |___ | (_| || |   | (__ | | | |
   \_| \_/\____/ \____/  \__,_||_|    \___||_| |_|
  ================================================
   Version 0.3     |   @jjtibaquira
  ================================================

  nsearch&gt; search name:ssh
  1.ssh-hostkey.nse
  2.ssh2-enum-algos.nse
  3.sshv1.nse
  nsearch&gt;
</code></pre> 
      <pre><code>  ================================================
    _   _  _____  _____                     _
   | \ | |/  ___||  ___|                   | |
   |  \| |\ `--. | |__    __ _  _ __   ___ | |__
   | . ` | `--. \|  __|  / _` || '__| / __|| '_  |
   | |\  |/\__/ /| |___ | (_| || |   | (__ | | | |
   \_| \_/\____/ \____/  \__,_||_|    \___||_| |_|
  ================================================
   Version 0.3     |   @jjtibaquira
  ================================================

  nsearch&gt; doc ssh &lt;TAB&gt;
  ssh-hostkey.nse      ssh2-enum-algos.nse  sshv1.nse
  nsearch&gt; doc sshv1.nse
  local nmap = require "nmap"
  local shortport = require "shortport"
  local string = require "string"

  description = [[
    Checks if an SSH server supports the obsolete and less secure SSH Protocol Version 1.
  ]]
  author = "Brandon Enright"
  nsearch&gt;
</code></pre> 
      <br> 
      <br> 
      <div style="text-align: center;"> 
       <b><span class="Apple-style-span" style="font-size: x-large;"><a href="https://github.com/JKO/nsearch" target="_blank">Download&nbsp;NSEarch</a></span></b>
      </div> 
     </div>
